description:
Now one of my favorite places in Chinatown. We went for lunch and the service was friendly and fast. Extensive menu with reasonably priced items. The dishes were exciting, adding unique flavors to more traditional dishes, such as the sweet potato with the sesame chicken. Looking forward to trying more options next time!

Pictured below: Sesame chicken, wonton soup, and pork dumplings.
author: Rad A.

description:
I feel if you've ever talked or walked through this part of SF, someone has mentioned to you House of Nanking. Between the rainbow sign, the history, sometimes the lines, House of Nanking has a reputation in the City. And I finally got to try it.

My date originally was craving dumplings but as we walked nearby, I mentioned the stories I had heard of HoN and she made the decision for us to go there. Fortunately for us, we timed it right where there was no line and got the seat by the door.

Featuring a more specialized menu than other Chinese restaurants that feature everything in the kitchen sink, you get the sense that House of Nanking has perfected what they have and that's what you get.

-Pork Dumplings in Spicy Sauce: These were just okay. I felt we could have gone for the pot stickers, and seeing the table next to us get the eggrolls, I will definitely order those on a return visit.

-Famous Sesame Chicken: I mean, its what they are famous for. A plate of crispy sesame chicken with sweet potatoes. These were good and I get the hype but the pieces weren't as chunky or tender as other places.  This also could have been due to the late evening.

-Crispy Rice Noodle Tower: We got it with pork, I recommend getting it with Shrimp. Still good, but make sure you eat it all as it doesn't leftover well.

-Blossom Tea: You get a liter mug of tea with the blossom at the bottom. And I feel this was slightly sweat, which I enjoyed. Also always good for warm tea on a cold San Francisco night.

The staff was excellent and incredibly hardworking. 

I wasn't necessarily blown away but I get the hype of this place. I definitely want to come back and try more of the dishes I didn't get a chance to, from the eggrolls, pea shoots, and more.

Also before you leave, read some of the great articles or pictures they have across the walls.
author: Michael C.

description:
The service from the old Chinese lady here is so shockingly rude it's as if it's one of those restaurants that people go to just to experience the worst service imaginable. 

The sesame chicken was good and crispy. It's a simple dish though, and it wasn't amazing enough to warrant the mistreatment. I'm pretty sure there are other similarly capable mom and pop type restaurants in Chinatown that could do something very similar. I may or may not be back depending on where my friends want to go, but this place isn't worth a special detour.
author: Brent M.

description:
I went here based upon several recommendations and I can't fathom why. The food was mediocre at best. Service was meh and ALL of our dishes were dirty. I had to wipe pink lipstick off of my wine glass. Ew. 

We ordered their so called "famous" sesame chicken. Which tasted ok, but was mostly overly fried batter with a tiny bit of chicken. Their house noodles were gross. Way over cooked, mushy and lacking flavor. The fried potstickers were also just ok. I did enjoy the peanut sauce they were served in. 

Maybe I just didn't order the correct items, but I will not be going back.
author: Emily G.

description:
Omg I am shook. How was my experience here so terrible. IDK, but here's a retelling of how my night unfolded. A friend recommended we get dinner here because his ~Uber driver recommended it~ and neither the friend nor his Uber driver were Chinese so I was already skeptical tbh but I was like okay sure why not. It's in Chinatown - it can't be that bad right?

WRONG BINCH I WAS SHOOK. I get here around 8:15pm and this place is packed! with people of mostly non-Chinese descent but it's okay because it's packed so something must be good here right? I ordered Fried Onion Pancakes and Fried Pork Potstickers and my friend ordered something else. Ok so far so good.

We waited around 10-15 minutes and the first dish came. Ok good turnaround time!! Not bad House of Nanking I see you. But this dish is the fried onion pancake and let me just tell you in NO chinese restaurant have I seen them make the scallion pancake (蔥油餅) the way they do here. Instead it's literally a bunch of scallions tossed in between two crisped layers and smothered with peanut sauce. It wasn't the peanut sauce so much that disappointed me as the fact that fundamentally this dish is NOT 蔥油餅. But ok. I guess some places be trying to do art, so fine. 3/5 for the flavor, and my disappointment is just a side effect of artistic differences.

Anyway not soon after the second dish comes which is my friends dish. He starts eating it, cool. But then 5 minutes later they come out and are like oops wrong dish and take his dish back. Ok to be fair it's also actually the wrong dish and maybe it's the friends fault for not paying attention to what he's eating but also maybe they shouldn't have taken a used dish back to the kitchen. Kinda sketch for health/food waste reasons. But at this point in the night this place would have gotten a 3/5 from me easy.

Anyway it's another 15-20 minutes and my pork potstickers still haven't arrived and the restaurant is kinda clearing out. so i flag the waiter down and tell him and he says oops he didn't hear it and he'll put the order in. at this time the rating drops to a 2.5 because i very clearly remember ordering my two dishes so it's not a matter of hmmm did I forget to say it?

BUT HERES THE KICKER. when the pork potstickers come out and the waiter brings them to me... THEYRE NOT POTSTICKERS BUT DUMPLINGS BINCH. (ps let me elaborate here - this isn't an artistic difference like ~oh they just make their potstickers differently~ no they literally got me the steamed dumpling DIFFERENT ITEM ON THE MENU instead of the pork potstickers) So i'm just like OK at this point imma just eat them bc me and House of Nanking are officially done. I don't know how you can put in an order wrong on the second time you're supposed to put it in. It's honestly ridiculous.

I told the waiter later and they did comp the dumplings but come on? I came here with really optimistic expectations, but that kicker kills.

Also, it's really weird that I always end up having super bad experiences at Kathy Fang related restaurants :/ because I had a terrible one at Fang too. I swear to God I'm cursed or something because other people seem to be having a fantastic time to be fair. But from my experience here tonight, I'm never coming back. Disappointed through and through.
author: Brian W.

description:
I love this place. Had the best meal of my trip here. When we told the waitress that it was our first time to the restaurant, she took our menus away and said that she would pick out for dishes for us that we would love. We were really nervous about giving up control of our selections, but we were all afraid to say no to her. 

We Loved every selection! She prepared two off-menu dishes for us and two more standard dishes. Of particular note or the two off-menu dishes. I would have never ordered them on my own but they were amazing. There was a tender beef that melted in your mouth: it had bok Choy and came with a light flavorful sauce.  The other dish was a shrimp and chunk apple with a honey mayonnaise glaze. Who would ever think that apple and shrimp went together - but it really did! It was lightly and sweet and very refreshing to eat. 

The prices were reasonable - it cost is about $80 for 4 of us. We left stuffed!
author: Chad B.

description:
Chinese food in Chinatown, SFO...a little hideaway on the busy streets of SFO.  You walk in there and it's quite busy but, I noticed everyone had pretty much ordered the same dish...Sesame Chicken.  Of course, I had to do the same, needing to find out why the craze over this chicken dish.   I ordered Sesame Chicken w/steam rice n a flower tea.  The chicken had a flavor of sweet n tangy (I don't cook so, I couldn't tell you exactly what the sweet and tangy was).  It just had a lot of delicious flavors.  The tea had many things floating it in but, had a mild aroma and sweet taste to it.
I must admit, the chicken was good but, the service not as inviting as the food.  No one smiled, just seemed to be in a hurry, not really even trying to be courteous or nice.
Good chicken, not so good service...think I'll pass the next time.
author: Barbara P.

description: I would definitely and I already have recommended the House of Nanking to friends that will be heading to San Francisco for the Holidays! The service was great, the food was delicious and the tea was amazing!
author: Rebecca P.

description:
Don't come here for shi shi food or amazing service. And there is usually a line. The menu is also limited. But come for the items that they do better than anyone!

We got in line at 7pm on  a Thursday and happened to get called in quick. The tables here are family style and we sat next to a couple of nice gals who recommended the eggplant.  We ordered the pork pot stickers and house rice for the kids. Both were excellent in my opinion. Hubs and I had the eggplant and chicken and green beans. Delish. Also got the chow mein which was the only dish I didn't really like.  I would like to try the mushrooms w/ shrimp someday.

Service in this place is brusk and no nonsense. No time for chit chat, they move you through quickly so don't expect to linger long over your tea or Tsing Tao. But do have the eggplant.
author: Maureen W.

description:
Oh, how I love SF Chinatown. So many delicious spots & such a great variety of different regional Chinese cooking. You wouldn't be able to find spots quite like this in San Diego. Of the many Chinatown spots we go to whenever I'm in town, House of Nanking stuck out for me. You can spot the famous colorful sign from streets away.

My sister and her boyfriend (both locals) brought me here. We came here for lunch during the week and upon walking in, it was crammed with all walks of life - locals, professionals, and the *necessary* cute old Chinese people (that's how you know it's a good spot). Perhaps it's the nostalgia of going to family restaurants with my grandma and grandpa... but it's hard to hate a place that has old people who look like they've been going there for years, who probably have also been ordering the same dishes. And you wouldn't believe how many tables they tetris'd into this small space.

We started with the rice porridge - it was so good!! My only negative is that I don't like peas and they throw in a generous amount. We then ordered the fried calamari and pea shoot salad. For the salad we asked to add scallops, which was a great addition. My sister enjoyed the calamari but I found them just a bit vinegar-y for my taste. It's just a matter of preference I guess. The calamari was tender (not at all rubbery) and their house satay sauce complimented it well. The salad was amazing. It was really light but still very flavorful. There's nothing worse than an overdressed salad. The scallops were also really tender, but perfectly crispy on the outside. This place treats their seafood really well. By the way, the house blossoming tea is a MUST. 

Service-wise, they are so quick! I can see why it's a hotspot for professionals - you can definitely be in and out in 30 minutes. It's also one of the spots where it's definitely a plus to know your order beforehand. You'll most likely have a server arrive upon seating.

I'd love to return and try their other teas & dishes - hopefully in the near future. I highly recommend!
author: Rhonda P.

description:
Luckily I'm staying at a hotel very nearby, and a friend mentioned this place.  He said all the chefs have been here, and I can see why.  I got there close to closing on a Sunday night.  I wasn't feeling 100% so was leery of ordering anything too spicy or filling or anything too-anything. 
 
The waitress seated me in a cozy spot with no delay.  The door was open and there was a small fly but other than that the place was sufficiently neat.  Its charm made up for its age.

I asked for tea and was quickly provided a tall glass brimming with an understated black (maybe green?) tea with a delicate flower standing in the middle of the glass.  

I ordered a simple dish - the house noodles and Chinese market greens - which also arrived quickly at my table, fresh and hot.  Not too spicy, just right.  It was just what I needed, and for the right price.

I left feeling much better than when I arrived and will go back soon just to try other items on the menu.  I hope to be reporting back on the dumplings and sizzling rice soup soon.
author: Revelmama O.

description:
**** Review 103 ****

If you're looking for the best Chinese food in San Francisco, then look no further. Portions are huge, prices are reasonable, and the food was great. The staff is ok, not really very friendly, but don't let that stop you from eating there. Lunch time gets busy, so plan accordingly.
author: Luis S.

description:
My boss suggested we grab dinner at the House of Nanking, her go-to Chinese restaurant whenever she's in SF. I looked over the menu and found several things I wouldn't mind trying, so off we went.

We started off as a party of two, but turned into a party of four by the time we left. It's a bit of a walk over from the Moscone Center, so by the time we arrived it was a little bit before 6pm. I've been told that there are lines down the block the later it got, so I was very happy that we were able to get seated right away. It was a Friday night - I was half afraid we'd have to wait for a while.

We ordered a bunch of dishes and shared family style - as it should be in any Chinese restaurant.

What we ate:
Fried Pork Pot Stickers
Chinatown Market Greens - Bak choy
Salt & Pepper Shrimp with Mushrooms
Fried Tofu with Peanut Sauce
Dry Braised Green Beans
Cold Sesame Noodles
Scallion Pancake with Peanut Sauce

My favorite was definitely between the Dry Braised Green Beans and the Fried Tofu. Everything tasted really good - and it really tasted different than East Coast Chinese food. I'm not sure what it is, I can't quite put my finger on it. But everything tasted really, really good.

Service was about the same as your usual Chinese restaurant - quick, brisk, and efficient. They do rush you out as soon as you look like you're done eating, so be mindful of that. If you're looking for somewhere to sit and chat, don't go to Nanking.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Legitness!!! This place is absolutely fire. We didn't even look at the menu just sat down at the table and told the chef to hooooook it uppppp (Martin voice). They brought course after course everything was delicious, the stand out dishes for me though were the veggie pie and hot oil garlic fish! All those flavors danced around on my tongue like a stripper on stage lol can't wait to go back to SF so I can hit Nanking again. The place is pretty small and tight so, If you have a large party like we did, call ahead and give them your name, head count and they will accommodate. Lastly don't be cheap leave a tip! 

Thank you Nanking I'll beeee back!
author: Darius B.

description:
Service was the only thing holding this place back. Me and two others, whom admittedly, look pretty young, came in on a Tuesday afternoon. They didn't seem to pay us any attention and we had to flag down the server many times. They seemed to pay a lot of attention to a elderly group of four however. We ordered three dishes, the calamari, famous meat, and the soup. 
The calamari was very good and the sauce was very tasty and just the right amount of saltiness. The soup was spicy and had a good lemongrass flavor to it. The dumplings in it were a nice touch. The meat texture seemed like it had been sitting out for a while, but the flavor was good. The prices were a bit steep, ended up spending $50, but apparently the cook was famous... so worth?
author: Lilan N.

description:
Went for a victory lap during lunch yesterday.
Took my coworkers and they loved it!

Got the green beans, the Sichuan chicken, calamari, and of course the sesame chicken.

Delicious!
author: David T.

description: This is the first time I'm writing a review on yelp! That's how much I loved this place. I got the sizzling rice soup, and the sesame chicken. It definitely has a unique flavor! I think they put coconut milk in the soup which was really good. The sesame chicken was also really good. It came with sweet potatoes which wasn't expected but super delicious! I loved it!
author: Anna M.

description:
Found this place on yelp while searching for something local in San Francisco and we could not have made a better choice.  

There was a line out the door but this place is super efficient and the line moved quickly.  We ordered two glasses of wine and some water along with egg rolls as an appetizer.  We ordered fried rice, sesame chicken and pot stickers for entrees  (they are famous for the sesame chicken). 

The food was extremely tasty and (everything) including a very nice wine. I absolutely cannot day enough good about this restaurant. 

Many places have reviews and awards hanging on the walls inside but this is truly the real deal and if you are in San Francisco and are looking for excellent food in Chinatown this is a must eat!
author: Rob S.

description:
I wasn't impressed with this place. I didn't come with high expectations, seeing as most of Chinatown is a tourist trap anyways but it was Friday and we were hungry. To be honest, Panda Express is still my go-to for chinese food (judge me all you want) and I still think it reigns supreme.

Ordered the house fried rice and the sesame chicken. I make way better fried rice than this place. It literally was like a plate of white rice with some bits of egg and soy sauce mixed in. No originality. No flavor.

The sesame chicken was good but I felt it had more batter than actual pieces of chicken. The flavor is sweet, typical of most asian dishes for this type of cuisine. The fried potatoes were a nice added touch.

Not the best but not the worst. Service also slower than I'd like.
author: Connie M.

description:
Don't pay attention to those negative reviewers. Must be food snobs or visit Chipotle way too much. Yes the service is designed to fit as many as possible into their restaurant and turn quick. I personally love sharing a table near some new friends

Cant go wrong with this order:
Pork dumpling soup
Nanking famous sesame chicken
Side of fried rice

Love this place!!
author: Steve W.

description:
I hate complaining about service.

Came on a Friday and ordered the fish soup, fried tofu, and two orders of rice.

The entrees were good, no doubt about it. As other reviews have mentioned, this is an authentic flavor that's pricey, but absolutely worth it for the price. The fish was aromatic and had been butchered and lightly fried before being made into a milky white soup. The tofu as well was tender and crisp -- a great variety of texture.

So, why the 1-star review?

I usually don't care about service. Places with lower-than-average service often have the best food, since their waiters are too busy bringing the orders to the numerous guests. However, House of Nanking was egregious and disappointing on two counts.

First, the house was not busy when we sat down. We waited for our water and reminded the waiter politely that we'd like waters. After affirming, we went another several minutes without water. When we reminded the waiter again, he pointed at my girlfriend and impatiently told us to wait.

I felt we'd been waiting a while. From an onlooker's perspective, maybe we'd been impatient. Regardless, from my perspective, you never disrespect customers as an employee. This was an unnecessary breach of respect -- we hadn't shouted, demeaned, or demanded in any way.

Later, when we saw a neighboring table get their 4 orders of rice, we realized that each bowl was larger than we'd expected. We asked a server that we change our order to 1 rice instead of 2. At this point, neither of our entrees had arrived, and neither had our rice.

Our entrees arrived before our rice and, indeed, we were brought 1 bowl of rice. We enjoyed our food and got our check, and we were charged for 2 bowls of rice. No problem -- simple misunderstanding. We told the wait staff.

She thought for a full 3 seconds before saying, "No, we gave you two orders of rice in one bowl. We gave you more."

0) The hesitation made obvious that she was thinking of an excuse for not having to reprint a receipt.
1) They didn't give us more rice.
2) We were two people. Why would House of Nanking decide to give us one bowl to serve two people?

They were busy at this point, and we had plans for the afternoon. Rather than argue, we paid our bill and left.

I hate complaining about service.

I just want the bare minimum -- for the food to be brought to me, for any errors to be corrected. You don't have to have a good attitude, you don't have to fill my water every 3 minutes. But don't be intentionally rude, and don't lie to me.

Well-made food that left a bitter taste as a result of disrespect and neglect from two wait staff -- a middle-aged gentleman and a slightly younger woman.
author: Dan Z.

description:
I was warned that this place would be overrated and that I'd like the food but there are so many better places with a shorter wait time.

Well, I must have had some luck on my side because when we came in to eat, the restaurant was only half full and we were seated immediately.  

We didn't order much as we had been eating all day, and that is the only regret I have about this place.  I wish I could have tried more because what we did try was excellent.

We order the crispy rice soup.  I could eat this soup everyday.  As a matter of fact I want this soup right now.  I feel like I would fly to SF every weekend just to have some of this soup.  We also ordered the famous sesame chicken.  It was quite delicious.  The people next to us ordered quite a bit of food and although I can't say anything about the taste, I can tell you that it all looked great.  The serving sizes are great for the price as well.
author: Christina R.

description:
I learned about this place from some local foodies while waiting outside online at Dotti's. So last night in town I Uber over from my hotel. However San Fransico is the City that sleeps so whenever I come here to visit I always find myself rushing before closing or it being closed. In this case I ordered take out while heading over so not to miss eating here all together. For this South Floridian 9 PM closing of a restaurant is insane. They actually close not we will give you a table at 8:59PM. So I order won ton soup and house fried rice who could go wrong. 

So Uber drops me off and I go to pay for my pickup. They were very happy I could see as they hand me a receipt in Chinese writing. Than I sat down at a table at the back waiting for another Uber to arrive to take me back to my hotel. The restaurant itself was about half full. Than a couple arrive they tell them take out only they seemed frazzled by the rush so chose to leave instead. 

When I got back to my hotel the food was hot and delicious. No condiments or fortune cookie but the soup snd rice were full of flavor and delicious no condiments needed. Too big a portion for one definitely enough food for two people.
author: Clarissa K.

description:
This place is delicious! We had the sesame chicken and the tofu with black beans. The dishes were both extremely flavorful and innovative (the sweet potatoes were to die for!).

The restaurant isn't fancy and the tables are very close together. They also weren't playing music so it was cosy and we could actually hear each other talk. 

The service was fine...no complaints there! We brought our 2 year old and they don't have booster chairs. The guy who brought us water noticed that he could be more comfortable if he were higher to the table and brought a case of soda for him to sit on. Not fancy, but considerate. 

Overall, I'll definitely be back next time!
author: Leslie T.

description: First time in San Francisco. I did not get lost in China town, but I did get lost in this soup. An older Chinese gentleman asked me what I liked and said, "I gotchu." He did not disappoint. I got lost in the spicy flavor, lost in the handmade noodles, lost in the tea egg, lost in the tofu and fish. It was a delicious surprise. Sometimes you just have to trust that life will give you what you need.
author: Sylvia K.

description:
Based on the Zagat review & they been on TV couple of times. 
I really expect more from this restaurant. My husband and I was so looking forward to have our labor day lunch here. We ordered Pork Dumpling Soup, their 'so-called' famous Sesame Chicken & Spicy Eggplant. It was so disappointing if not horrible. They put rice and lemon in the pork dumpling soup, made it looked so "yucky"! Their famous sesame chicken is just a 6,5 score for me! And wait, their spicy eggplant actually just a plain-sautéed eggplant. When we asked: "Where are the chilies? Because you called it spicy-eggplant" 
The waitress said: "Oh our style like that, if you want spicy you just need to spice it up with the chilies on the table". WHAT THE HECK?? LOL. OVER-RATED. Don't come here! There are many delicious local Chinese restaurants in San Fran! Like Mission Chinese Food, Shantung, etc. Those are real ones!
author: Mrs H.

description:
Not sure how they have such good reviews as the food is just mediocre.  It didn't blow me away and there is NO WAY I'd stand in any line for it.

The waitstaff is very rude, short and snappy with customers.  I see some reviews where the manager or owner responds saying they may come off rude because they are working to turn over their customers quickly due to the amount of people they need to serve.  What?! I was in for lunch and there was no line and the 2nd half of the restaurant was empty.  When I left...still no line.  And this was s Saturday! So why the rude behavior from the servers?  Every question we had was responded with a snooty response as if we were wasting her time.  Take a lesson from the other restaurants in town who have numerous reviews...many are small in size and serve hundreds of patrons yet aren't rushed through their dining experience. NO ONE WANTS TO BE TREATED RUDELY JUSY SO YOU CAN GET MORE PEOPLE THROUGH THE DOOR! 

Seriously, I suggest delving deeper into Chinatown for another place to spend your money...especially when the food here isn't mind blowing!

Garlic Fish - good but could have used a lot more garlic and a pinch more salt

Eggplant - was delicious

Egg rolls -  weird and sorta disgusting.  They weren't even finished by us

House noodles - grey, dry and tasteless

Rice soup - was told it was very good
author: Liz K.

description:
Honestly, the food was not bad but, I WILL NEVER GO BACK NOR RECOMMEND THIS PLACE.

The SERVER was TERRIBLE. Unlike anything I've ever experienced in my many years of dining out. The lady was short in her attitude & snapped at my mother inlaw when she inquired about a missing dish. I mean, so rude and she raised her voice at us. I was in complete shock. I felt like a child who was getting scolded.

She only asked about the missing dish because we had everything else on the table and we were half way finished with our meal. Her answer to us was "just wait, it's not done, it's cooking ok, not everything comes out at once". She yelled this to us while flailing her hands around in disgust. 

I was also snapped at. I asked if they have club soda and she very bluntly says  "NO!" as she walks away. 

I'll say this with confidence....We are a very laid back family. We are easy going. We are NOT high maintenance. That shouldn't be a reason for a server to be so rude anyway but, I'm just trying to figure out why she was so aggressive. 

My husband asked about a soup on their menu and the lady very rudely answers him as she's walking away so he couldn't even order it. It's like she wanted us out of there. 

Finally...

My mother in law was given the bill by a different server and he says put 15% here as he's pointing to tip line. My mother inlaw says  " I'll think about it" & he says " No, you put 15% here" and my mother inlaw says "Our server was very rude" & he still demanded a tip. Once she signed the bill with no tip, the server tells us to get out! 

If someone of influence is reading this review, believe me when I say I don't like to give bad reviews but, this experience was so unbelievably bad.
author: Kris K.

description: My husband and I ate here at the recommendation of our daughter. We were not impressed. We don't mind hole-in-the-wall restaurants but the food just wasn't that great. The sesame chicken was very crunchy - almost tasted like fried chicken and the chicken in the chicken fried rice looked like it was added as an afterthought and was pretty bland. I did like the marinated cucumbers that came with the sesame chicken but that was about it. Oh and they don't have sweet & sour sauce either. I'm sure a lot of people like this place but it wasn't for us.
author: Erica M.

description: The food is actually really good though most Chinese people make fun of this place. House of Nanking has been able to take some of the more traditional Chinese dishes and put a twist on it and serve it to mostly what seems to be tourists. For instance, I usually only get Pea Sprouts at a typical Cantonese family restaurant but they have it here and do a good job with it. I introduced my friends from the South to the Pea Sprouts and they were surprised to learn of another new tasty veggie. The Spicy Won Ton Soup has a white broth and has rice in it which is totally different from the clear broth we're accustomed to seeing. There's usually a long line and you might have to share a table with others because they have a ton of people to move in and out. Most of their staff isn't too friendly but it does add to the experience and it's kind of expected. They focus on the food more so than the service.
author: Jen L.

description: This is my favorite restaurant.  Every time I'm here the food is amazing.  Sometimes the wait is a little long and the service seems rushed but it's busy for a reason.
author: Chago G.

description:
I love this place.
 If you ever have a chance to have eat here don't pass it up.  If there is a line just wait.
Ask for the candied shrimp.
author: Jean S.

description:
Despite the busy crowd and recommendations by others... I was not a fan. 

A few thoughts came to mind and I apologize in advance...

How come there are no stray cats running the streets of china town? Did I just eat cat?

Upon sitting down the waitress asked us what we like. I said Chicken and my wife said Seafood. 

The waitress says  "ok, you get Seseme chicken and you get Beef"...  (there was no mention of seafood).  But ok, we're first timers and we'll go along and see what comes out. 

We also got a bowl of egg drop and sweet and sour soup. 

The food and soup were aweful. Literally terrible. At any other restaurant I would have sent the food back or refused to pay but here I felt like it was best to avoid conflict and just get out of there. 

Plus I watched them refill my water straight from the tap, with warm water! 

I promise I'm not a snob. It's just that bad. 

One and done. $50 for terrible Chinese food. Pass. 

Pics are egg drop soup and the beef.
author: Daniel R.

description: My family and friends love coming to San Francisco especially coming here. This is our first stop before we go anywhere in San Francisco. The food is excellent and the owner gets 2 thumbs up for always ordering for us. Unfortunately it only allows me to give you five stars but I'll give you 6!
author: George S.

description: House of Nanking is a quaint, family-owned, hidden gem Chinese restaurant in San Francisco's bustling Chinatown neighborhood. The tables are cozy and you might be touching elbows with the person next to you. But who cares when the food is THAT good. They aren't known for exceptional customer service, but they are known for their world famous sesame chicken, which definitely lives up to the hype. It was my favorite dish that our group tried. A second favorite was the eggplant smothered in a sweet tangy sauce. I ended the meal with a beautiful flower blossom tea that refreshed and delighted. Great place to check out if you pass through. And if that doesn't persuade you... A local told me that 50 cent once dined here. So you know it's gotta be legit. :) lol.
author: Helina G.

description:
Oily 
Abrupt wait staff 
Wish my experience here was a little more welcoming. The minute we sat down, we were forced to order. Barely enough time to even look at the menu. The restaurant was not even busy, so I would understand if it were, but. Ordered the eggplant. Barely any sauce, mostly oil, felt like entire cup of oil was poured over the dish. Not strong flavor, because the oil overpowered. Sad I wasted my time here. If you're looking for a more authentic Chinese food experience, I would try another place. Didn't even offer chopsticks!!
author: Elana T.

description:
When you come here, get the chinese menu. You'll know it when you see it because it is laminated, old, greasy, hand written. All good signs IMO.

Got a fish soup, twice cooked pork, some ribs, veggies (snow peas?), shrimp and eggs, nanjing duck, fish filets.

The best item was the fish soup. The noodles are really thin and the soup is so flavorful. It's a little thick and the color is pale. The pieces of fish that were simmered are still there, but they aren't the highlight of the soup. It really is just the stock.

The twice cooked pork was interesting since they added basil and chili powder into the dish. I don't think they did it as traditionally because there wasn't any bean paste and the pork was really fatty.

The ribs, eh...I wouldn't get them again. They were deep fried and the sauce wasn't sticky so it was hard to add flavor. I heard it was authentic, I just didn't like it that much.

The shrimp and eggs, nothing special. It was like shrimp and eggs cooked together, with very few chives.

The fish filets we thought were going to be spicy since it was similar in naming to couple's delight. However, it really was just fish filets without too much sauce or flavoring IMO.

The duck reminded me a lot of drunken chicken. Others really liked this dish, I thought the two were very similar and thought it was fine.

Service there is lacking (didn't clear the table of our dishes ever)
author: Victor D.

description: House of Nanking was recommended to us by a friend. We walked in and were immediately greeted and seated immediately. A gentleman approached the table and introduced himself as the chef and pointed to his picture on the wall. He said, "First time here? I order for you." Out of the kitchen came a delicious square egg roll filled with rice noodles and vegetables. Right after we finished that comes the entrees. Equally delicious and fresh were honey apples with shrimp, marinated beef and with wilted bokchoy. DELICIOUS   We would both recommend this place to anyone in San Francisco while in Chinatown.
author: Bill B.

description: This is the worst Chinese food I have ever had. I was so disappointed the food was so salty and it was not Chinese food. Everything was over priced . The green onion pancake was deep fried not pan fried. I was so surprised there was a line outside. I will not recommend to anyone.
author: Shirley W.

description: This is a must-have when in San Francisco! We came at lunch mid-week to miss the crowd. This is my favorite asian food spot in the city. Recommended dishes: dumplings (steamed and fried), crackling beef (with crispy rice), sesame chicken, house noodles. The food is ridiculously good. Staff is amazing. Really great service. Highly recommend this spot!
author: Junu P.

description:
We got the special Nanking sesame 

chicken it was great

The steam chicken dumplings were also great

cracked beef dish was great

The car like what seemed like beef tips and 

bok choy was pretty incredible

Make sure you get the flower tea it was 

quite a treat

We did sit in line for 30 minutes but it was 

well worth the wait and I hate waiting in 

lines
author: B I.

description: I had the most satisfying comfort food at the House of Nanking: the Spicy Wor Dumpling Soup! It doesn't look very appetizing, but don't be fooled by it. To describe how the soup tastes like is quite hard, actually. At the basic, it is a soup with dumplings, shrimps, vermicelli, and topped with fried crispy rice. The fragant of the burned rice, combined with a slice of lemon, and fresh basil leaves provide a unique umami flavor. I've never seen this dish served elsewhere. I wonder if it is a specialty from Nanking.
author: Thuc V.

description: Rude service. We came because of a reccomendation but the staff treated us rudely. A terrible experience
author: Karina T.

description: Eaten here years ago! Before I became such an avid Yelper, so coming across the venue on a fellow yelper's feed, this review is definitely long overdue. I recall being brought here by a friend who was a local. Even then, the service appears to be the same as the majority are writing presently. Hasty service, but they're prompt and efficient. The dishes were more exotic and unique from what I recall, but not too memorable as I didn't note to myself that I should need to return if ever I am back in San Francisco. There is one dim sum place I've noted to revisit every time, but Nanking hadn't made that list. Since it has been at least eight-ten years since I've visited this restaurant, I will reconsider on my next trip and make an updated review.  Once I locate my hard drive of earlier food photos, I know I'll find Nanking's first visit and can share.
author: Jen S.

description: I've always passed by this place every time I hit Columbus or Chinatown. Always busy and frequently have a line out the door. Get their dried green beans, sesame chicken, melt in your mouth calamari and your are set. People who are claustrophobic should bother coming here because you will be seated with people you don't know and probably be rubbing elbows with each other. Definitely a must try but parking is a big, juicy, fat biznich up here.
author: Jan R.

description:
The food is okay, but definitely not Nanking food. But what can u expect? Chinese food in Chinatown are more Cantonese style since it is pack of old immigrants from south China. So better having dim sum in Chinatown rather than other style of Chinese food. Sometimes I will come to Chinatown for dim sum to experience the lost atmosphere of old time.
The service, it is complicated to say. Let me tell u the story. First was good and like any other Chinese restaurants here. Waitress came and asked. My hubby and I needed time to decide. 
After 10 mins, we made our decision. So in Chinese restaurant don't wait for waiter or waitress come. U have to gave them a sign that u are ready to order. I did that. One of waitresses standing in the back noticed me and told me that she would send one. Then one middle-aged lady came, but she ignored me and began to clean the table next to me. First I didn't have any negative feeling coz I knew they were busy. Then she was gone. 
I raised my arm again. The same one told me the same thing. Mins later the previous lady passed me to pass some food to the other table, and she ignored me again. Now I felt hurt! Why she kept ignoring me! She knew I was ready to order food! 
Then the third time. Finally I was pissed! And told them I was here waiting for 30 mins! And the ignorant lady raised her voice and shouted to me saying that she was busy. 
Well, This is how you treat your customers?!
Then the restaurant manger realized the situation and came to serve my table. He is nice guy. 
Though I did find human hair in one of my dishes. The manager retreated that one and gave me an offer that I can order one more without charging that one. 
I didn't wanna argue anymore coz I was exhausted already. 
I definitely won't step in this restaurant once more, though the food is better than its neighbors.
author: Anna Y.

description: I've been coming here for decades for the incredibly delicious Chinese food in the heart of bustling North beach, on the edge of Chinatown. My two favorite goto dishes are the crispy, sesame chicken, which is drenched in an exquisite, rich savory glaze sauce. I also love the crispy pot stickers, which are deep fried and served with a yummy peanut sauce. Expect a relatively long wait and service is fine.
author: William H.

description:
After going here 20 years ago for my honeymoon I was really excited to return.  It was no where near as good as I had remembered.  I had the onion pancake and while good itself the peanut sauce that they poured onto it had too much soy sauce added to it. It also just drowned the pancake. 
I also had their famous sesame chicken dish and while good, there were few pieces that contained large chunks of meat. It was a lot of batter and not that much meat.  I think an older version made it famous and people's excitement about being in Chinatown keeps it famous. Or it is the item that they make the most profit on so they keep it famous.  
I would not return here next time I could to SF. It wasn't awful, but just not great when there are so many other options out there.
author: Scott A.

description: Stumbled upon this place during a trip in 2012, and though we were ready to order, we were asked if we would be willing to just try whatever. Turns out the waiter was actually the chef and though I can't remember what was brought to us, we were all surprised at how delicious it was (we did have two picky eaters in the group at the time). Flash forward to March of this year, we stopped in because, of course we remembered this place! Though the meal was less eventful, it was still good! The tea was great and watching the flower bloom in it was so neat! Definitely quick service and would recommend to anyone!
author: Cassandra C.

description:
Chinatown is overloaded with choices. In a search for the most reviewed on Yelp, House of Nanking popped up. Our party was immensely grateful that we came across this restaurant because the food was delicious. There wasn't a single complaint in our whole group. 

The food is served family style. The portions are huge, so keep that in mind when ordering. We were told to wait outside for about ten minutes while space cleared for our party of five waited. We were seated in half the time, but ended up being seated a table with a young woman from New Zealand. Yes, they will seat you with strangers. In our case, it worked out wonderfully, but I could see this getting a little awkward if on a date. 

The food was excellent. I ordered the veggie egg rolls which are served in a pair and are almost a meal unto themselves. I also ordered Salt & Pepper shrimp, easily enough for two people, it was outstanding. It was seasoned perfectly and the shrimp was plentiful (not stingy like most places). In some ways, I think House of Nanking is slightly underrated by reviewers and I can understand why. Firstly, the space is too cramped, but that's a good thing because business is booming and House of Nanking is doing something right. Secondly, when we looked around everyone had something bottled to drink. At first we ordered water and were each brought warm tap water, without ice. Not sure if the temperature was intentional or not, but it certainly did the trick. It was a weird moment, but our group felt compelled to order sodas after the warm drinking water delivery. Will be visiting again.
author: Kari C.

description: Loved the menu and atmosphere!  Quick and friendly service to top it off.  Great experience and the sesame chicken was awesome.  And order the dumplings as an appetizer.  Great lunch!
author: Burton C.

description: For china town, you can do much better. It's very Americanized. I got the sesame seed chicken, which I guess is their signature dish, and it was basically BBQ chicken. Mix that with higher prices than usual for ChinaTown (without deserving it, IMO), and thus I won't be planning to come back anytime soon.
author: Matthew P.

description: Amazing Chinese food, at a really casual restaurant. The wonton soup and lo mein were amazing. The wine was franzia, but the food more than made up for it
author: Marie D.

description:
Beyond amazing!! I was sent by concierge to a restaurant down the street but it had a long wait list. Someone outside the restaurant referred me here. I wanted soup & tea in this chilly SF wind. I almost ordered wonton (silly me) but the very sweet & amazing competent waitress recommended crispy rice soup & mixed flower tea. FANTASTIC CHOICE!! And this place is very clean with a perfect Chinatown ambiance! 

The Traveling Texan very highly recommends this great place!! It competes with places I've been around the World!!
author: Renee D.

description: The food was absolutely delicious. Definitely Authentic. Flavorful and tasty. It's not fancy, but a good lunch restaurant.
author: Lekisha B.

description: Fast food when order for a sit-down restaurant. The atmosphere is lively and has the charm of a hole-in-the-wall place. We liked the potstickers which had a thicker crust than most potstickers that added a different flare with an added crunch. The sesame chicken was decent but didnt really taste like sesame chicken and barely had any sesame on it.
author: Erica W.

description:
AMAZINGGG CHINESE FOOD! Only con is that the staff literally yell at you and its quite comical actually...my dad would pretty much yell back at them...chillll lady we are about to order! HA but we did come in late ish but they were not having it.

Fooood was on-point as always! This is such a local fav!!
author: Ellie J.

description: This is a bit of an institution in SF and a lot of famous people have come here. Keeping that aside...I though the food was just OK. The Sesame chicken was a little chewy.
author: Sunil R.

description:
This is my favorite Asian Food in San Francisco! 
Take the recommendations from the server, you won't go wrong.
author: Lorena B.

description: Came here by accident with my boyfriend. Meant to go to the place nextdoor but saw that this place had a ton of people so we were wondering what it was all about. The restaurant is actually pretty large and we were ushered to our table right away. The food was typical oily Chinese food at an okay price. Don't think I would come back again as everything was so oily and the place not so clean either.
author: Megan K.

description: Wanted to give them that extra star I REALLY DID!! It wasn't for the rude non attentive person taking our order, it was a tad for cleanliness. I can see why they get really busy it was good.. it will take an extra "UMPH" to get me to give them that last most wanted 5th star. Keep it up though.. good food...
author: Jose G.

description: Is our go to place. The soup was the best. I personally don't like the beef although the owner always recommended it. Is the same owner as Fang and slightly cheaper due to locations. They tend to order for you if you don't have specific preference.
author: Anya C.

description:
This place is truly bad. We ordered:

Potstickers: These aren't really pot stickers, they're crunchy and fried. They came out really quickly and were lukewarm. Bland taste. If I had to guess, they have a ton pre-made and bring them out when someone orders them. In addition, they're covered in peanut sauce. Never in my life have I seen peanut sauce on Pot Stickers.

Sesame Chicken: Again, cold. this is one of their popular dishes so again i'd say they pre-make a bunch and bring them out when people order it. It was pretty bland and drenched in sugary sauce. Not good

Chow Mein: This was actually decent, as it was warm. 

Rice: We ordered this, never received it, and it was still on the bill

Tea: Good hot tea, and the flower expands while you drink it. Pretty cool!

Overall, there is simply no reason to go here when there's far better chinese restaurants within a block of here.
author: Bert J.

description:
I will not return to this nor recommend anyone to come here. My friend and I originally wanted to try the restaurant next door, but the wait was long. We decided to give this place a try since there was no wait. We were first given the English menu but later got taken away because we said we understand Chinese? ( which makes no sense because we preferred reading the more thorough menu which had more food options and pictures). The food was served after we waited for 5 minutes and the food was terrible. We ordered the Guilin rice noodles and the noodles were undercooked and the broth was way too SALTY. And water was not offered until we asked for it. Later when I found out one of the items from my food was missing, I asked the server if they have accidently forgot about it. But guess what? The server was not friendly about it and made fun of me for not looking "carefully." I felt very uncomfortable sitting there and as the check arrived, the server kept staring at us as if we were not going to pay. 

Food: 1 star
Customer Service: -10 ( I am not expecting to get excellent customer service here in this restaurant but at least show some RESPECT to your customers ) 

You can find way better food in Chinatown just avoid coming here!!
author: Yi K.

description:
I didn't realize how much of an SF establishment this place was when we drove up to it. We came around 5:30PM and we beat the rush. While we were eating the line was out the door, but it clears out around 7PM. 

FOOD: The food comes out in ~10 mins so it's crazy fast. 

+ Sesame Chicken - The easiest dish to share. It was my second favorite and I enjoyed how the chicken pieces were cut very small. This made it easy for all pieces to be coated with the sauce. 
+ Fried Gyoza - I wish they had a sauce for this one since this was too dry for my taste
+ Fried Rice - So so. Nothing too special but it was alright with the dishes we had.
+ Fried Beef & Bok Choy - They meat was tender and paired well with the bok choy. The flavors definitely balanced each other out. 
+ Baby Pea Shoots - This was my favorite dish of the night! 
+ Honey Shrimp - this is not what I expected. Instead of walnuts they added apple slices. Not sure if I was the biggest fan of this one.

SERVICE: 

It was our first time here so once our waitress heard that she basically made the order for us - one chicken, pork, beef, seafood, etc and brings that to your table. It could come off as rude, but for us it made it easy to order since we had no clue what to get.

Once they bring the food to your table they're pretty hands off. They come around once to refill your water and afterwards come by to drop off the check. I did think it was weird to read about the waitress waiting until you sign the bill before walking away, but it happened to us as well. 

***I can totally see how this place gets raving reviews from others, but the dishes I had here weren't what my taste buds were used to and I wasn't a fan. 

Fun Fact: The owner's daughter was on an episode of Chopped & they own the restaurant Fang that's also in SF.
author: Keizzel C.

description: This was a bit of a mixed experience. Loved the feel of the place and the service was good. Fried rice and tofu was great but the chow mein was really greasy. I had the sesame chicken which was really not great - the sauce only covered half of it and it felt like it had been sitting a while. Maybe would try again - perhaps we caught them on a bad day.
author: Simon H.

description:
Compliments to the Chef ‍ Peter Fang!

This unassuming older gentleman went to our table, took the menu and asked us to trust him with the selection. We were NOT disappointed. The dishes served by the Chef were simply delicious!

Sadly, I'm not sure what the dishes are called but will try my best to describe them:

- Pork dumplings with (probably) hoisin sauce.
- Fried packets filled with bean sprouts, green onions, egg and (maybe) shrimp.
- Flash fried braised beef with sautéed baby bok choy
- Coconut shrimp with chopped apples.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Poor service, substandard food. Snatched menu off my table, while I was still reading it.

When we requested that the sour and inedible 'Hot & Sour Soup' be returned, we were told 'You ordered, your table, you pay'. Sure, moving on.

Post soup, next fiasco presented itself in form of fried rice, later by Chow Mein and spicy chicken. Chow Mein was saving grace but we couldn't finish half of it. 

At end, we got our appetizers: Fried green beans, a standard affair. And the most recommended dish, Onion Cakes, which were the only decent food we ate on a most unfortunate late afternoon.

Oh, oh, before I forget: While paying, a girl pointed at bill and asked for tip. I said no, I'm really unhappy with food and service. She still insisted. Ended up paying $10 on a $100 good for nothing lunch!
author: Shantanu B.

description:
Hands down, the BEST part about coming to San Francisco. 

You go in there, and you tell them to let the chef take care of you...and he will not disappoint. 

I could say everything about this place but the fact is, it's just damn good. 

One dish- grilled apple and battered shrimp with an orange cream sauce...WHAT?!?! So. Good.
author: Krystin K.

description: Absolutely loved this place!! I got the black bean tofu and chow mein. The black bean tofu was yummy but quite salty. However, the chow mein was incredible-by far the best i've ever had. Had many good flavors with a lot of garlic and it was absolutely delicious. The table's favorite for sure. Quick seating and very fast service, but we did go on a weekday. Loved it!
author: Kate B.

description:
I truly enjoy every meal and experience at HONK, a fan since the early 00s. It's not the same as it was before the space burned down and the rebuild, but no harm in capitalizing on its notoriety and reputation of years prior. The larger space allows for bigger parties and opportunity for more family-style adventure. I do miss the old gritty feel but again, it's really about the food. 

I love their sesame chicken, hot n sour soup, and whatever market greens are offered- there is a lot to explore and plenty of vegetarian and noodle options as well. Go hungry, leave with belly full.
author: Meredith R.

description:
Despite the rankings - I will have to give this my worst review - one  out of five. The place is small overcrowded and dirty. The waitress was quite grumpy and the food was boring at best, if not inedible. We went there at recommendation of the Omni, and let them know when we got back so that we can spare someone else in the future. 
PS - I know the world has changed but allowing pot smoking was another downer
author: Jay D.

description: Looking for your usual bland Chinese food? You're at the wrong place. Food here comes out piping hot and full of flavor! Each time we visit San Francisco, about twice a year, we eat here. My favorites are the Salt & Pepper Shrimp and Onioncakes. There's enough food to share served family style and more than likely you'll be seated communal style. Be prepared to give your order right after you're sat or you'll wait a while before they come back
author: Mai D.

description:
This place is definitely overrated! 
Came here as a party of 5 and the lady taking orders was all over us, trying to get us to order by making suggestions and standing over us, which made us feel really rushed and pressured although there was no line! The lunch menu was also disappointing with few options.
The food was just ok; nothing spectacular or memorable. 
Our bill was $92 and we ended up tipping $6. The lady taking orders caught sight of this and demanded we tip more. Although we didn't feel the service or the food deserved more, we obliged but looking back, I regret giving into her demands as it builds up her ego and confidence to continue demanding more money from customers, as if her service and food was exceptional when in reality, it wasn't close to.
Overall, based on service and food, I will not return and would not recommend.
author: Hello E.

description:
I traveled the world in my 70 years , and I've  never encountered rudest server in my life.  Server snaps at me cause I ask if she has remainder of our order fir we were halfway done.  She also snap at my daughter in law because she asked if they have soda water.  At the end when the bill was presented they send a gentlemen & told me tip was not included and I should put 15%.  I told him I cant do that, only good service deserves good tip.  And told us to get out. The lady server also said something, and I politely told her she doesnt have to be rude to their customer.

So glad the dishes  we ordered was good and it was not a total disaster (salt & pepper shrimp, garlic fish, eggplant dish, pork dumplings was good). Chowmein and eggroll was so so.

We will not recommend this place to our friends and relatives.  After the incident today  I looked at reviews and  it  has alit of negative reviews.gThe Owner or Manager should look into this unless  they don't care either.

Dear Manager, 
Thank you for the response.  I know how business is run , I used to have one.  Rudeness, snapping at customers, body gestures and talking loud chinese language which we dont understand, we knew she was talking about us cause the staff were looking at us.  That time the place was not busy, no waiting line, NO EXCUSE.
Not so good food is much better than NASTY, RUDE SERVER.
author: Evelyn K.

description: The food was AMAZING. I'm from jersey and I work in New York City so I have access to great Chinese. Lemme just say this is the best Chinese food I have ever eaten.
author: Shawn A.

description: I was not impressed. I was seated when I arrived. I waited 10 minutes then had to ask when someone would take my order. I was told someone was coming. Meanwhile, patrons that came in after me were being served. I had to walk up and ask for someone to take my order. I ordered the pork egg rolls and the sesame chicken. Both were gross. I did not leave a tip because the food and service were bad. My waiter actually pointed out that I didn't leave a tip. How rude! I'm upset I spent my money hear on my day trip to San Francisco.
author: Erika M.

description: 1) Food is fantastic!!! What great flavors. 2) There is a line out the door to get into this tiny place. DON'T let it deter you, it moves fast. They guys know what they are doing and turning tables is an art form they have mastered. 3) Let them order for you. We just sat there And they brought us an awesome combination of dishes. Every one better than the next. 4) as authentic as you will get. Eat here and step back in time. Bottom line: If you're in San Francisco And you don't have dinner here you blew it.
author: Bj R.

description: House of Nanking is a little restaurant in the heart of San francisco. If your in the city its worth a stop. Food is good and tasty. Service is good and order time is reasonable.  We had the sesame chicken, pot stickers, house noodles, shrimp and mushrooms. All were good. The only thing I dont care for is when you order a coke and you get a can. Also be aware of the prices. Although the food is good their prices have went up and very expensive. Two can of coke were over $5.00 cant rember the change. For what we had it ended up close to $60.00 $57 and some change. So be prepared to dig into your pockets. We would come down to the city time to time and stop here, food is consistant. But with prices increased. it will be less. theres lots of good places to eat in the city at a good price.  Parking is tough on the street but a parking garage is near by and we have never had a problem.
author: Joe Q.

description:
This restaurant was highly recommended.
The food is delicious. My husband and I are visiting from New Jersey. The food is affordable and scrumptious.
author: Laura L.

description:
This restaurant is always packed and my friend HAS to eat here every time he visits San Francisco, so we went. We ordered 3 different chicken dishes and an eggplant dish, which my dinner companions enjoyed more than I.

When going in my friend said the woman who takes orders reminded him of the Soup Nazi from a Seinfeld episode and I now know why....he's the guy who always wants something a little different than what's on the menu - add this, take away that - and she gave him a very hard time about it. 

The folks sitting next to us ordered directly off the menu and got no grief, but her food came and they shared and finished it before his came out.

When we left people were lined up to get a table, so evidently it's well liked by locals and visitors alike.
author: Mitch P.

description: Came here for dinner on Saturday night. We decided to order a few things to share. The waitress was kind of unpleasant and tried to rush us. She asked if we were ready to order as soon as we sat down and when we asked for a few minutes to look at the menu, she came back literally 30 seconds later and asked annoyingly if we were ready.  The wonton soup was very good, and very interesting. I think they add lemon and some sort of crispy rice to it or something. Anyways, the soup was very large and came in a self serve pot with ladle. We also tried their famous sesame chicken, it did not disappoint. Their house noodles were kind of interesting.  Very fresh because they had a lot of sprouts on them. The star of the meal was the steamed prop dumplings. They were in a salty but tangy sauce.
author: Karolina T.

description: The concierge at our hotel insisted we come here for dinner so we decided to give it a try. The line was out the door so it seemed kind of promising. Aside from the Sesame Chicken and the Sizzling Rice Soup, the food was just okay and not worth coming back for again. Pretty disappointed we wasted our time at this restaurant tonight since we only have two nights here in San Francisco.
author: Kristen D.

description:
Found this place when searching for Chinese food. Was within walking distance so off we went. 

I typically check to see who is dining in specialty restaurants. This one I saw the majority was non-Asian diners and took this as a sign that the menu has been adjusted for foreign tastes. Went in anyway and was seated right away. Were given menus that looked like the business had gotten their money's worth from them. 

While trying to decide what to order, a server came over speaking English very quickly and asking us if we like beef, chicken or seafood. Said chicken and seafood. What kind of seafood, shrimp or calamari? If we liked sweet or not. Said sweet. 

I asked her for the house noodles too. We were asked what we wanted to drink so we both ordered hot tea. 

The tea showed up in beer mugs. In the tea was this round ball shaped object. Was told it was a tea ball. The ball starts to unravel and just like a blooming flower it opens into a blossom with a string of flowers rising from the center. Pretty neat. 

Within 10 minutes our food arrived. All we knew was we were getting shrimp, chicken and noodles. 

The chicken came as fried pieces in a garlic and soy sauce coating with slices of what tasted like potato and slices of some crunchy green vegetable. The chicken was crisp and tasty. 

The shrimp also came fried with a batter coating and covered with a white sauce. Was told it was honey shrimp with apples. The apples were battered and fried too. The honey shrimp was tasty but I didn't like the fried apples. 

The house noodles showed up and was topped with sliced cabbage and some other greens. The menu said it was egg noodles but what we got didn't resemble egg noodles that I know of. Taste was plain and the noodles were too soft. 

So, overall it was okay but I wouldn't go there again. Just nothing real special after I noticed quite a few of the other tables were getting the same chicken, some the same noodle dish. 

They don't even need menus since they pretty much order for you and everyone else in the restaurant. That's probably why lots of diners got the same dishes.
author: Barry A.

description: My husband and I came in for lunch to find it semi empty. People say the wait staff are rude but it's a cultural thing. We didn't mind it at all. We both ordered hot tea with goji berry and fried eggplant to start with. Then we both ordered spicy dishes, one with chicken and green beans, the other with black bean sauce. They were all so good that we finished all of our dishes. The price wasn't too bad for the both of us and the wait wasn't long at all. They do stop by to see if your dish is done so they can take it in to clear your table. We loved the food and we'd come back if ever in the area.
author: Jackie R.

description:
What can I really say about House of Nanking. You really have to experience it for yourself. My wife told me about this place and how the wait staff tells you what to order, and is kind of rude, but in a funny way. 

We arrived around 7 and waited outside with some other people. Then some lady comes out and got the whole group of us and took us inside to be seated. If you aren't aware, House of Nanking is communal dining. So if you don't like eating with strangers at your table, then this isn't the place for you. Once you are seated, menus are thrown at you and then you order. 

We had the scallops in garlic sauce, house fried rice, and sesame chicken. Out of all the dishes, the sesame chicken was the best. The scallops were basically jacked up scallops with soy sauce. The fried rice had no flavor at all. 

So if you want good Chinese food, I would say look elsewhere.
author: Bill S.

description:
Decent food but pricey. Good for sharing. 

Spent $26 each person (6 people) and still felt hungry when I left. I think this place is mainly for tourists as I didn't see any actual Chinese people dining.
author: John S.

description: Delicious Chinese food at it's best! The house noodles, and sesame chicken are my favorite go to's at this spot. I usually take out for lunch, and have plenty leftover for dinner, or lunch the next day.
author: Kim H.

description: We ordered the crunchy noodle tower with beef and the fried pork dumplings. Both were delish and arrived super fast!
author: Lori S.

description:
ZERO stars if it were possible.  There's a reason why there are a lot of negative reviews all with the same theme.  Basically, my parties experience is on par with all of the negative reviews.

It's a dirty, packed area.
Rude/No customer service.  To the point where, as most have said, they bully you into giving them a tip/specific amount, and if not they give you dirty looks, throw the receipt back at you, and even had one person stand by the door before my party left (not sure what she had planned to do, but luckily we left when she got distracted).

Food:  Hot and sour soup was the only saving grace.  We had the Sesame chicken and the crispy noodle tower with chicken.  This was one of those meals that ruined our day.  You know when you have a bad meal, it ruins the evening.  The sesame chicken had some flavor, but it looks like they gave us a smaller plate, with all the ends/scraps and no chicken.  The noodle tower was disgusting honestly.  Dry, no sauce, and the chicken was just huge chicken cube chunks that were bland and not marinated at all with anything.

I honestly would advise all my friends to stay away from this place and do not intend on coming back.  Again, look at the all the negative reviews = all with the same theme...yet they haven't fixed it still...
author: Ali N.

description:
I walked back toward my hotel After a work conference into Chinatown for dinner. Yelp had me looking at 3 different places, and I must've changed my mind 5 times, but finally ended up at House of Nanking.

It did not disappoint. Except I ordered orange chicken (never had it and wanted it so very bad) and think I got sesame chicken. Their spin on it was delicious as it had thin-sliced potatoes and apples thrown in.

The fried eggplant appetizer had black bean sauce, y'all! I love black bean sauce.

I also tried fried shrimp packets, they came with peanut sauce. Oh my! They were so good...and the outer fried part was so crispy. I was pleasantly surprised.

I would've gone back for my orange chicken, but was already settled into hotel. Maybe I can get some for lunch next.
author: Kelly W.

description:
We recently visited SF and were lookin for a good place to try in China town. A friend suggested house of Nanking and we decided to give it a try. 

We walked in and were sat right away. It's a somewhat smaller place but they know how to keep a steady flow going so that people don't have to wait a long time. We immediately had drinks and our orders taken. We got the house noodles and general Tso's chicken. We started with potstickers that came with a peanut sauce and man were they delish!!! The house noodles had an interesting but good flavor and the chicken was amazing as well! We enjoyed every dish and the food came out in record timing! We left satisfied but not extremely full which is nice cause often times Chinese food can do that to ya. I would recommend this restaurant to others in SF!
author: Stevi K.

description:
I've been a frequent visitor of house of nanking since my last review. However, the rudeness of the staff for my last few visits have been unbelievable and I don't think I will be coming back. 

The waiter has always been rude and unpleasant ever since my first visit but I was able to overlook that because I enjoyed the food. However this last visit was absolutely terrible. We were rushed from the moment we sat down even though the restaurant had many empty tables available and no one waiting. After ordering hastily, I realized we misheard an order and went up to change the dish immediately. The waiter looked incredibly annoyed even though he was just about to enter our order so this change didn't affect anything. I went back to my table and hoped that he wouldn't spit on our food. Our first dish arrived and it was a steak dish. I was completely shocked when it was placed on our table because it came with 4 pitiful small pieces of steak. It took up 1/4 of the plate. No joke. 

The consistently terrible service is so frustrating and I will not be returning any time soon.
author: Kelly Z.

description:
Food was ok, nothing spectacular or even above average. Worst part was it gave my mom and I food poisoning just a couple hours after we finished our dinner tonight. Save yourself the awful post-meal effects and skip this restaurant.

While we were eating dinner, we also saw the owner, Mr. Fang, get mad at one of the waiters for giving us an extra bowl ("wasteful"). Left a bad taste in our mouths. We will not be returning here or the sister restaurant (Fang on Howard in SOMA/FiDi).
author: Mai N.

description: This is a place I used to love years ago.  Lately, it's been horrific.  Trying to adhere to the masses of Financial District people and tourists, they've lost all sense of decorum.  In and out mentality, pressure, high prices and indecent service, I was shocked.  I went in alone and while I was still eating the dry chicken, they presented me with the check and took my credit card.  Then, again, before I was finished, they told me I needed to sign the bill.  (as other patrons poured in).  I signed.  Still eating, a man came up to me with the bill and said I forgot to include the tip within a minute .  The bill was for $14 without tip for a small plate of noodles with chicken, yet they forgot to put any veges, but that's irrelevant.  I said I would pay with cash for the tip, which is usually appreciated.  Immediately, the waitress stood behind me waiting for the tip, hovering over me, waiting for her cash tip.  Meanwhile, please note I was STILL eating.  It was a fast machine, with sub-par food and completely without a care.  The arrogance was astounding.  There are many places more worthy that I hope people coming to our city will appreciate other than this factory of "amazing asian food".  Trust me - they have watered down any brilliance to their food since the days of old when we gave it five stars.  Now just a factory.  Brandy Ho's from now on -
author: Kbai F.

description:
Food went really downhill, came here first time after 4 years(back when they used to have 4.5 stars on yelp). Everything is way too much on the sweet side and extremely oily. Most of their food now tastes the same. I ordered the mushu tofu and there were pineapples in it? 

As bad as the food was, The service is a nightmare, the staff is rude will yell at customers if they are not happy with a dish and ask for it to be remade or exchanged. Not sure if the staff is just too fresh off the boat or simply doesn't understand service, but raising your voice at customers is unacceptable. I had to tell him to leave me alone, before he stopped yelling this is mushu tofu over and over. When leaving, he said fuck you to me since I left no tip after being yelled at. Awesome.

Kathy, I see that you reply to many 1 star reviews about the horrible third world country style service provided by your restaurant. Instead of saying sorry and asking us to try you again, why don't you start training these guys to not argue, yell, threaten, and treat your customers like dirt. Btw, there's big difference between authentic, efficient, and direct vs. mean, rude, and  classless. Your staff is the latter.

Yeah, this place might be a sf staple and more about food than service, but how crazy are you going to let it get before you do something.
author: Lee X.

description: 2.5 stars. This place is mostly pretty average, slightly-Americanized Chinese food eg sesame chicken, green beans. Nothing is that bad but there isn't anything I would specifically want to come here to eat, with so many better options in Chinatown.
author: Michelle R.

description:
So I didn't really had high expectations for the house of Nanking to be honest. I'm Asian and I live in Houston. We have our very own Chinatown and it's good. One of my girlfriends recommended this place for me to check out while visiting San Francisco. I think it's def a 5 star place. The food was hot and delicious and it came out really fast. The service is just as u would expect with any other authentic Asian restaurant, fast but the staff doesn't speak English well. Don't expect an automatic drink refill. But the food was great. The sesame chicken and the tofu with broccoli was my fav out of all the stuff I ordered. The weirdest thing I ordered was pea shoots(was it like the pea shoots from plants vs zombies? Bc that's what I was expecting ). I didn't know what that looked like or tasted like but it just tastes like any veg sautéed in garlic. House of Nanking was really good and I would come back here and would recommend this place to my friends to try. 

We sat in the middle so the tables were really close together. It feels like community dining to me. But I'm ok with that.
author: Ciara N.

description: My mom is visiting and it's my first time here even though I live in the bay area. This place gets packed around 6 pm. We just came at 545 just in time for dinner. I truly think it's a bit overrated the only dished we liked is the spicy fish. Being from South East Asia and the peninsula, I think the sesame chicken, wanton soup, tofu, calamari and fried rice was just okay not spectacular
author: MariaAnne V.

description: I honestly do not understand all of these reviews giving this place 5 stars. My family and I came to SF for a trip and decided to give this place a try, it was AWFUL! The food was noting to rave about and the service was very fast and rushed. We asked for a water and they gave us water from the sink, with no ice, in a purple plastic cup. Also when we paid our bill with a credit card the server stood there waiting for me to write a tip for him and he did not move from our table until I did so.I am still in shock about the food and the whole experience.
author: Mariam A.

description:
Food waaaaaaayyy too salty..

Not yummy at all..

Tourist trap.. 

Sux.. 

Go elsewhere.. 

Thank me later..
author: Jws J.

description:
The famous House of Nanking, well it was just okay. Finally made my way to try it over the weekend. I feel like they do attract tourist a lot more than people who do have standards for Chinese food. ha! There is always a wait but goes by quickly. Communal seating so Asia which I do not mind at all. Great way to meet new people. Service was okay. 

I ordered the Spicy Wor Dumpling Soup. A hint of spice but it was tasty but nothing amazing. The fried rice they had inside was all soggy. No crispiness to it at all. 
Fried Pork Potstickers - The skin was so thick and hard. Not the way it's suppose to me. Wasn't tasty and was not a fan of the peanut sauce. 
Fried Tofu In Black Bean Sauce - My favorite dish. But I do wish they had some salt to the tofu rather than just the black bean sauce. 
House Fried Rice - Yes, I found a hair. Gross right? But didn't see it till the very end. Sending it back would be like, did you put that there? Oooo wells. Wouldn't kill me. And yes wasn't great. Rice was too wet for my liking. 

I won't be coming back because there are so many better places for Chinese food in Chinatown or even in SF.
author: Sandy B.

description: It was highly recommended by locals and for sure not a disappointment. The sesame chicken and pork dumplings are must haves!
author: Mlissa T.

description:
This the the most ridiculous and worst place to
Eat, I dont really know why they get positive reviews but if you don't want to believe me then go try it. 
1st they serve with dirty spoon, fork and plate
2nd if you ask for another plate because it is dirty the owner gave me a random dirty plate (color blue) 
3rd we are asking for the receipt and he eat first and wait for 15 mins
4th the server ask for a tip and she told me the amount to give 
I hope you guys will enjoy eating in this dirty no attitude House of NANKING

Oh plus the guy who put the sesame in the food he is using his hand and you know that it is so dirty.

Yes Kathy, even the other table is complaining I just dont know if they post a comment too, you need tell your crew to take care of their customers and stop being rude
author: Aeden B.

description: Excellent food for many years running.  The service and ambiance is horrible, though.  Enjoy!!
author: Blake G.

description: We were quickly seated and had food in no time. Tell the waitress what you like. My husband like spicy chicken, and vegetables. He was very happy. I had vegetable dumplings. They had fresh peas and other chopped vegetables- very good! The house noodles were a nice thin noodle with seasoning and some chopped vegetables. The price was reasonable. Not a fancy place but your stomach will be full and happy for a reasonable price.
author: Terrie S.

description: Best Chinese food I have ever tasted. The shrimp lettuce wraps and house made noodles are AMAZING.
author: Sarah S N.

description:
Quick service, amazing food, awesome choice. Highly recommended 

Blossoming Tea is so cool
author: Mike T.

description:
I grew up in San Francisco. Been a resident for over 50 years and have dined at literally hundreds of Chinese restaurants. We'd go as a family every Sunday night.
