The only thing I really enjoyed was the fried shrimpackets. The peanut sauce that came with it was bomb (amazing)!

Overall, nothing to rave to your friends about, but a good meal if you find yourself in Chinatown.
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
What the fuck? I went here with my beautiful girlfriend and my mind was blown. We barely spoke as we ate because my mouth and my mind was engulfed with the delicious flavors of the honey sesame chicken. 10/10. Going back right now as you are reading this. 

Signed Josh and Nina
author: Joshua O.

description:
Its not worth the hype!
Taste is below average.

Just running this place based on the previous glory. 
Quality of the food and service is too bad.
There were other places in china town to try for a better food.
author: Padmanabha Praveen C.

description:
This tourist-trap has been under my radar and bookmarked since I started yelping back in 2006.  

I have dined here twice within the last two weeks (once dined in and take out). Both of my visits, I ordered the popular Sesame Chicken. For $10.95, I get boneless chicken meat glazed in a thick and spicy Hunan-style sauce.  I also got an order of House-style fried rice for $8.95. 

Many of my followers have questioned my decision in ordering the restaurant's top entrée. But I thought the sesame chicken was tangy and spicy enough to my liking. The fried rice is your basic diced vegetables, scramble eggs and stale rice. Any restaurant can not possibly screw up fried rice. 

For brews, the restaurant only carries Tsingtao and that is it for the beer selection.

Many of my friends have given lousy reviews from here. For me, I enjoyed my dinner from this tourist-trap in Chinatown.
author: Matt G.

description: Was at SF on vacation and a local friend to me to this tiny gem. We had the sesame chicken and the dumplings. The food was amazing! I highly recommend. Small and quaint. Friendly service.
author: Jo R.

description: Not sure why some of these reviews are saying this is the "BEST" Chinese food ever...I put it in the same category as panda express. The food wasn't as fresh and it wasn't as tasteful either. Feels like a typical american-chinese food. I wasn't impressed.
author: Jenn L.

description: Waited outside in line for 15 minutes expecting great food; finally when we got to the front of the line the lady points at us from her cashier desk and then points to an empty table that still had dirty plates; had to tell a server to remove them. Waited 5 minutes then had to ask for a menu. Took another 5 minutes to take order. The food did come out fast. Staff is not friendly at all, honestly I've had better Asian food at Panda Express.
author: Marty A.

description: Great place to have some eastern style Chinese food, especially the Shanghai style wonton soup tastes exactly the same as what I had in Shanghai
author: Yufan H.

description:
This place is a hidden gem in SF downtown/Chinatown. 
Great and authentic food, especially great for Chinese tastebuds. Decor is also decent. Food was served very quickly. 
Highly recommend if you are looking for authentic Nanking food!
author: Wenyi F.

description: Went there for lunch on a regular weekday. The food was okay- some people may believe it's authentic Chinese food- salty and greasy, but I've had better in other restaurants to be honest. However, what really gave this place one star is their service. After paying the bill and stepped out, one staff ran to us and claimed we left without leaving the bill on table.  I showed him my purse, saying I kept the customer copy only, nothing else and my colleagues also told him they saw it on the table. He insisted it wasn't there and I felt I was accused of not paying the bill. Me and my colleagues decided to go back with him to check ourselves. After stepping into the restaurant, another staff asked why we took away the bill. Omg I felt sooo insulted! We checked around the table we were sitting while the staff yelled that they didn't clean the table yet so we definitely kept it. I had to sign a reprint bill cuz we couldn't find it, which is fine with me but no one should be treated like this! If this is the service you can provide to your customers, go ahead and keep losing them!
author: Ivy L.

description: I am sorry but this food is not Chinese. Tough broken rice was thrown in our soup and entrees as filler. Very disappointed with our meal.
author: A N.

description: Let me start off by saying that this place has really good food.... but their service is terrible. The waitresses are rude beyond belief and if you're on a schedule don't bother going because you won't be waited for a long amount of time. They harass you for tips despite having to be flagged down to take orders and we were literally thrown menus by the manager. Other customers during our stay complained about mean servers as well.
author: Gennesis C.

description: Best Chinese food in SF! Had to go back before my trip ended. Small restaurant, big flavor!
author: Diana A.

description:
Summary: white people's Chinese food.  

Okay. I knew I've made a bad idea when 1. I was the only Asian eating at this place and 2. It was packed with a sea of white folks/ tourist. No bueno. Reasons besides why I ended up here.. 

This is a place to go if 1. You're white and can't be asked to actually walk a block or two up to see where the Chinese are actually eating at and 2. You lack a bit of observatory common sense 3. You like fried food.

As a Chinese, I've rarely/ almost never seen lemon as a topping for a fish soup (the extra fish was FRIED-- hey, if I wanted fish tacos?), and secondly, have never seen half cooked tomatoes and PINEAPPLES diced up (with crispy rice) in a lettuce wrap. Fried shrimp, no thank you. It's easy to hide non fresh seafood, k guys? 

Oh and $5 Tsingtao beer? Pfff

Tourist trap, inauthentic fried oily t(c)rap food? *I told ya so dance*
author: Janice L.

description: An awesome experience! Our food came out very quickly, which I loved. I got the Sizzling rice soup (or something like that) and it was so freaking delicious. Great size, taste, and texture. It was light but rich in flavor! I would get it 1000 more times.
author: Emily S.

description:
Everything we ate was wonderful! We came here yesterday for dinner at 6:00 and were seated right away even though we were a large group of 6. Since it was our first time here our waiter suggested we let him pick our dishes and we were very pleased with all his selections. Everything came out extremely quickly. We had water and an appetizer within 10 minutes of being seated and all the disses were served 10 minutes after the appetizer. I would eat here again and recommend it to others as a delicious option in Chinatown. Our favorite dishes were the sesame chicken, salt and pepper pork belly, melt in your mouth calamari, crispy garlic beef (not on the menu) and the honey shrimp. The green beans that accompanied the pork belly were delicious and the bock choy that accompanied the garlic beef was cooked perfectly and had so much flavor. The apples that accompanied the honey shrimp were a nice surprise and were delicious. 
We were very satisfied with our meal and would eat here again.
author: Jessica S.

description: Place smelled like someone just cleaned up a murder scene with bleach. The food was pretty bad too considering that two of us cost $55 when the menu prices it out to $30. Service was pretty bad as well. We won't go back. Panda Express is better on a bad day so I went there to make up for this horrible lunch.
author: Andrew V.

description: Food was decent but their service was disappointing. Staff was not welcoming at all. They made us feel like a burden instead of paying customers the entire time we were there. My sister asked for a tea but had to ask the waiter to repeat himself twice because we couldn't understand his heavy accent. Instead of getting someone else or repeating himself he told her: "you want it or not?" Even though they didn't deserve it, I left a tip on the table as we were leaving. The waiter went straight to the money and made it a point to count it in front of us and the table next to us before we left. Food is not worth the crappy service you have to put up with.
author: Sylvia M.

description: LOVE this place! Lady straight up decided what food we were going to have, but no regrets! It was amazing! Come in with an open mind and ready to have a fun experience with the staff!
author: Jeremy R.

description: Had a great lunch today. Enjoyed green beans, shrimp with mushrooms and flowering tea. All were fantastic. Note - while I didn't ask for (and didn't really want) waitress brought rice and charged me $2 for it... not a big deal but if you don't want rice be clear so you don't get charged. Will absolutely come back when I'm in town again.
author: Joanne G.

description: The chef ordered for us but it turned out to be pretty good! Kinda pricey, but very flavorful and spicy food. Friendly staff.
author: Kat P.

description: My dream Chinese food! Let them pick your dishes and enjoy!  Wonderful service and able to accommodate gluten free. Yum!
author: Cheryl R.

description:
I ordered pepper and salt shrimps with mushrooms and rice.  The dish was dry and it seemed the mushrooms were cooked a day earlier.  I had the same dish last year and it looked and tasted much much better.  Quality keeps on going down not keeping up with the high prices.

I would not recommend.  I do not know how to add a picture to this or I would.  Just yuk in Flavor.
author: Sohail Z.

description: Simple menu, but every dish is absolutely delicious.  The sesame chicken and house noodles are the best, you can tell noodles are handmade and fresh.  The sizzling rice soup is also always satisfying.  My mom and I always eat here when we visit the city.
author: Clarissa S.

description:
A rare 5-Star.

In the late 1980s I'd ride BART from the East Bay just for the pleasure of waiting in their long line.  This was before they annexed the other Chinese restaurant next door (which never had a line.)  It was so cramped that other diner's plates would overlap mine, we'd often end up sharing.

The owner (Peter?) would ALWAYS be there and we got into a routine where I wouldn't even look a menu.  Their "Nanking Sauce" is evident in many dishes.

I haven't been back in ~10 years, but still readily recommend when visiting San Francisco.  Good memories.
author: Andrew A.

description:
Always amazing! These reviews crack me up. I have been coming to this restaurant for about 8 years and the food is always delicious and the servers consistently stern and efficient. 

Keep it up Nanking! Your unique recipes make you stand out from the rest.
author: Curtis H.

description: Don't expect good service here. Don't expect clean water. Don't expect a clean table or even a comfortable chair. Don't get fried rice. The poached scallops were the BEST I've ever had. Their food is very yummy besides the fried rice.
author: Haylie F.

description: This place was recommended by friends and did not disappoint.  It's a little hectic at first and the waitress is very to the point, but then she gave recommendations that were fantastic along w great service.  Try the vegetable pie!
author: Dawn B.

description:
I love this place!! The food is delicious and served quickly, the portions are large (two people can share one order) and the prices are affordable. There are also a variety of vegetarian options. 
My only complaint would be that the servers weren't super friendly, but everything else was wonderful.
author: Maricella R.

description:
I love this place! It's always buzzing but they do their best to accommodate you, even in larger groups!

If you're like me and have decision fatigue, just tell the server to get you a few things and tell them about all your preferences and allergies. 

Get the blossoming flower tea or goji berry tea. The veggie spring rolls are amazing but the dumplings are ok - didn't like how soaked in soy sauce they were. 

I love the crispy chicken, garlic beans, melt-in-your-mouth calamari (but be prepared for a few not so fresh pieces), and the piece de resistance - shrimp with apples.
author: S S.

description: It's a legend in San Francisco for a reason. We ordered the fried calamari, the tofu with bean curd, black bean sauce, and broccoli, and their famous sesame chicken. Everything showed up in less then 10 minutes and was incredible. Don't fear the line, it moves fast. Just do it!
author: Dave S.

description:
I just want to say thank you to the owner for your response. Anyone who cares enough to respond to their customers comments deserves a second look.

Thank you soo much!
author: John H.

description: Friendly service, fresh food and an excellent variety of choices.  The expansion makes more room, but there may be a line (thanks Yelp.)  Find the manager and get a recommendation.  Large serving sizes, but sometimes can feel a bit rushed.
author: Sean K.

description: This was our favorite meal from our 5 day trip to SF. We arrived shortly after 11 for lunch and were the second table. By the time we left the house was nearly full. Skip the Sesame Chicken (I have had better at the local grocery store Chinese) and try the Crispy Beef and the cubed beef entree. House made noodles were to die for. The fried rice has zucchini and an overall different flavor - so we preferred the steamed rice. The pork egg roll was all meat and no cabbage. No chopsticks or soy sauce in site because it's not needed. This is a Chinatown must!
author: Paige R.

description: Great food. We shared potstickers, which were made with wonton dough - for a nice change. The salt & pepper mushrooms were excellent!! Bok Choy - cold and almost pickled - was really great.
author: Bulldog W.

description:
If you speak or read Cantonese you are in luck ... for everyone else, buyer beware! We were told of the shortcomings before attending ... service that is curt at best, meals that are inconsistent and feeling as if you needed to be done almost as quickly as you started.  

I am relatively tolerant and can try to overlook many things, but pile them on top of each other and you get a 3 star rating. Our meal was blah at best. The shrimp dish had mayo esque sauce that tasted like poo ... the beef and tofu was over cooked and unexpected and the fried rice was unmemorable. 

There were plenty of people waiting ... for what I am not sure ... I'm sure there are other great options worth trying in this food mecca.
author: Nombre O.

description:
Amazing food. Would DEFINITELY come back. Sitting with people you don't know is also so fun, we got talking with a guy here on business and ended up ordering dinner with him so we could try new things. 

Don't be afraid to try and of the seafood dishes - they're especially incredible!!
author: Diana A.

description:
The food here was amazing. We did the basics and were pleasantly surprised. We ordered steamed rice, fried prok egg rolls, fried rice, chow mein, and sesame chicken.  Everything was fresh and served hot! The seasoning and sauces were perfection. The plates are good to share between 2-3 people. I highly recommend this place!

Please be aware that the staff is very rude and will make you feel rushed, but if you can make it past that I promise the food is worth it.
author: Brianna C.

description:
I'm so torn by how I feel about House of Nanking! I know it's very popular and the food here has a unique twist on northern Chinese cuisine. My party ordered the beef wrap, dumplings,  sesame chicken, green string beans, shrimp and mushrooms, and chow mein. The portions were smaller than usual, so we had to order double of several dishes so our party could all enjoy it. All very good quality ingredients, the flavors were there, but I felt it was a bit heavier on the salt than I'm used to. I loved the piping hot goji berry tea to wash down the food. 

We were mistakenly served potstickers instead of dumplings and after we had them divided on everyone's plates, one of the waitresses came back and made us give back the potstickers and then took the plate away which was an odd and awkward experience since I was eating lunch with my manager and her manager. I think if we were given the chance, we would have just paid for the potstickers since we had already touched them and had them on our individual plates. Not sure if that plate of touched potstickers was served to another table afterwards which poses for a question in sanitation? 

I didn't love or hate the food here, I just feel bewildered. I don't feel like I'll rush back to House of Nanking, but I do want to give them a second try to see if I can figure out if there's a dish that will blow me away.
author: Bonnie S.

description: Onion cake appetizer is sweet and delicios.  Homemade Wonton soup was my favorite.  Potstickeres were tasty.  Bock choy fresh and crunchy...
author: Robin M.

description: Food was absolutely amazing. Best hot and sour soup I've ever had. Got the house chicken, fried rice and chow mein. All fantastic. Went on a Sunday night and it was still really busy.
author: Amy C.

description: Not bad. Seems like a classic American restaurant served with the American taste buds in mind. I appreciate both classic Chinese food and American Chinese food, and I would say this place is a solid place to bring your non-Asian friends. A little bit overvalued compared to some other places in Chinatown, but I think it's worth trying at least once.
author: Dion L.

description: Food is ok, nothing exceptional. Service is rude, abrupt and cranky, that in itself is zero stars. No salutations, no thank you, just give me your money. People are crammed in, tables slammed together so you are eating with strangers.  There are so many restaurants in Chinatown, you may want to consider others who may appreciate you and your money. I do not recommend.
author: JJ M.

description:
What a surprise this was.  Not sure where the 3.5 start rating comes from.  Maybe the restaurant itself as it's definitely in the "hole in the wall" category - which I love.

Priced well, very fresh food, unique dishes, quick service.

Highly recommend letting the server decide what you eat - aka family style.
author: Sean S.

description:
Loved, loved, loved this place! Great atmosphere in the middle ofChina town, food was delicious, and service was fast. We had onion cake, house noodles, sesame chicken and steamed rice.

It's definitely not a fancy spot but the food is the star, as it should be!
author: Jeff P.

description:
If you're looking for an authentic Chinese food in Chinatown experience, at a family-owned restaurant that's popular with locals, this is the spot. The food is that authentic ABC (American-Born Chinese) cuisine that mixes everything just right.

Get the potstickers. Many places can do a great order of egg rolls, but potstickers are much tougher. This place does them perfectly. 

Later in the night, it does busy, and the restaurant and its workers do go very fast paced, but that's reasonable for a famous restaurant with a line out the door, trying to get your food to you as fast as possible.

All in all, one of the best Chinese restaurants I've ever been to. Will come again when I'm in town.
author: Mike P.

description: Great Chinese food. Sesame chicken was great. Also loved the scallops. Egg rolls were tasty.
author: David B.

description: Love Chinese food in San Francisco. Make a point of eating here ever trip back to the bay. Small place...longish lines. No nonsense service...order and eat. And we ate!!! If you are looking for a traditional typical experience in a Chinese restaurant ....this isn't it. This is just good food plain and simple.
author: Lisa M.

description: Way below expectations! Bad attitude from the old lady serving us. She was very impatient and rude to us. The hot and sour soup smelled like stinky/rotten chicken. The sesame chicken was overly fried chicken with a sauce poured over it, barely covering all of the fried chicken, i saw the server sprinkle sesame seeds onto the entree before bringing it to us with his bare hands (after handling cash, without washing his hands!). We were very grossed out. This place just looks dirty everywhere. No hygiene. I cant believe this place is still open! The fried onion cakes were ok. The fried rice tasted rotten with the eggs. Disgusting and very disappointing place. Don't waste your appetite or money on this place.
author: Roro C.

description: Bad environment with oily table and chair. Also lots of flies. Food were OK, but the waiter's has no perception. We asked her 3 time for water.
author: Peng Hui C.

description: The food is good and beautiful. But the service is really really bad...waited a long time after seated, got ignored many times during the meal when I wanna order something ... anyhow, one bad experience meal.
author: Zzz C.

description: This place is definitely a true authentic Chinese hole in the wall were the workers barely speak English.  The service was sup par the dude who took our order was eating a bowl of food by the table right next to us and he was rude AF I guess he was on lunch break .  When we finished ordering he went back to eating but he never gave us our drinks then that really pissed him off lol.  He never washes his hands after eating and when he gave us our drinks which btw come in some big ass colorful kids cup(super tacky) this place was apparently zagat rated a couple years back!!  The food made up for it thank goodness! We order the sesame chicken it was super crispy and just the right amount of sweetness to it.  We also got the tower noodles which was good and spicy, eat this one fast cause the crunchy noodles get soggy quick, and we got a shrimp and sautéed green beans dish which was good also.  I think if your okay with getting treated badly but like authentic Chinese food this is for you!! This place won't be on my to come back to eat list!
author: Elvin D.

description: I travel for work and this is one of my go-to stops whenever I am in SF. I absolutely love the scallion cake, the sesame chicken and the eggplant! The sprouts are good too. I just tried the potstickers because I thought they would be panfried and to my dismay they were deep fried and not good. Otherwise I highly recommend this place! Get there early because the line gets long and the staff there is pretty rude but worth the food!
author: Meghan H.

description: Food was amazing!!! A must come in sf . Literally noodles were so good plus the service was amazing. Owners were so nice and friendly
author: Larissa C.

description:
Good prices and great tasting food. The customer service is so bad it's ridiculous! First I try to order to go and they tell me no to go orders but they just took one for a woman waiting for her food behind me, secondly they make me wait to be seated after 2 other larger parties who showed up after me because I was only a party of 2. Lastly they only give u one napkin and tap water with no ice and pressure u into placing your order quickly. The house is packed and they don't give u the time of day when u speak to them. 
Up to u if u want to deal with the customer to get decent food in SF.
Let u be the judge...
author: Roxy L.

description: Omg!! The sesame chicken was to die for and the pea shoot salad was a must! Classic Chinese food with a fun city atmosphere. A must in China town!
author: Jess C.

description:
I visited this place after receiving many recommendations and reading great reviews on Trip Advisor and Yelp. I should not have had high expectations after coming in and observing the atmosphere. There was not a single Asian diner. If you have had real/authentic Chinese food, do not expect much from this place. 

We were greeted and seated immediately upon entering. This place is so small and busy that you share tables with other parties. We decided to order one item from the menu and then allow the staff to choose four dishes for us, since that's what this place is known for. They ask if you like shrimp, beef, chicken, etc... and from there, they surprise you. I like the concept. Unfortunately, the food was not at all appetizing. This is very Americanized Chinese food that is overly salted, but aside from that, poorly seasoned and overly cooked to dryness.

In addition, the dishes do not come with rice. Our food was dropped off at our table and we were not asked if we needed anything else. We had to flag someone down to ask for some rice and we were told that rice would be $1 per bowl. We were fine with that. When we were brought the rice, they had put "5 bowls" worth of rice onto one plate - definitely not 5 bowls worth. 

Not once did anyone ask how the food was. We asked for our check and our total came out to almost $100 (not including tip) for just 5 dishes. The one dish we ordered off the menu was $12, so I guess the 4 "surprises" were almost $20. Very disappointed and will not come here again.
author: Trisha B.

description:
This is NOT the place to go for friendly service. But their food is Amazing. Fast service. Very abrupt & short answered servers but that is what this place is famous for other than their great food! Their sizzling rice soup is so tasty! Slightly lemony, full of flavor, not just a broth with soggy vegetables/rice. We had their most popular dish, the sesame chicken...crispy, veggies as well. Soooo good!!!!!! Their fried rice: each ingredient can be tasted. It's not a sloppy mess of rice and stale vegetables (can vegetables be stale?! I think so....) Their green beans were tasty too, and crunchy, not rubbery.
 If I had found this place earlier in my trip, I would've been here everyday! I wonder if they would open one here in SD? We need a good place. You don't always have to have 'friendly' service to make a restaurant worth going to. Their short, abrupt, almost to the point of rude service was fun and added to the ambiance of the place. You def don't want to linger after you've eaten. At the end of the meal, we split the check 3 ways and I ended up getting the tip, but I forgot to tip on the ENTIRE bill and only tipped on my portion of the check. The server came back and told me that I didn't tip enough. Most places don't allow their servers to do that...but here, it was not unexpected nor out of line. You have to experience it to understand...and the food is definitely worth the experience! 
BTW, the dishes are served family style...so sharing is caring!
author: Carmela S.

description: After eating at Shandong in Oakland (and ordering the right dishes.  Go find your Asian friend to help you), these other places are another level below.  It's fine,  but kind of like realizing after you stop dating a loser how good other people can be,  once you eat at the aforementioned,  you'll dump a star off of this place.
author: A A.

description:
The intersection of divine flavor and the worst service you'll ever receive in your life.  
The waitstaff has total disdain for the patrons.  
I called to order soup to take out and was hung up on.  When I showed up 10 minutes later, they took my money fast enough but hadn't even begun making the soup so I had to wait and was given no ETA. When I asked about it 5 minutes in, I had a hand put in my face and was told, "Don't talk to me about it."  So I waited, awkwardly held captive for 10 MORE minutes.
For seven years, I've written it off as part of their brand, and kept telling myself the food was worth the poor treatment, but I'll never be back now.  It's dirty here, I'm so over the community tables and the hustle to simply get you fed and out the door is beyond rude.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Anytime I'm in the city I have to make  my way over to HON, order the sesame chicken and pork dumplings. You won't be disappointed!
author: Andrea M.

description: Great service fast food is awesome can't wait to come back my honey always talking about this place no wonder it's fantastic
author: Lisamarie L.

description:
We were on those city bus tours when they mentioned this place while we passed through china town. It was good but it wasn't the greatness that warranted waiting in line to be seated. They were very nice and attentive not rude or pushy. They gave recommendations when asked and they were very nice compared to what some reviews have stated. 

We tried the sesame seed chick which was the best thing we tried. It was really good.

The fried rice was bland I thought it would have more flavor. 

The mushroom shrimp was pretty good as well. It would be something I would order again.

I ordered something else but can't remember what it was, if I remember I will update the review.

It was overall ok, service was good the food just was ok though. I would go back to try it again when I am in the city again. 

Try the beer
author: Leo S.

description: It's extremely busy in there and the waitstaff is not particularly friendly, so, if that will both you, avoid going there. We ordered the house special sesame chicken, which was very good. We also got the fried tofu with peanut sauce, which started out good, but began to feel heavy on the stomach. We can recommend the veggie dumplings, which were probably the best thing we ordered. Overall, the food was good, but not the best Chinese we had in SF.
author: Isaac C.

description: Always a delicious treat when we come to the city! I love the house noodles, the texture is really nice and everything is super filling. Its a good place to go when eating in a group, since food is serviced in big plates that you share. The service is as expected, with such a busy restaurant  it's still courteous and gets all your food in a good time. Don't expect 5 Star attentiveness but definitely expect 5 Star food!
author: Mia S.

description: Very popular place. The service is just okay, servers seem to be in a rush for you to eat and go. Food is okay.
author: Yaz R.

description: Tell server that u were here before and ask her/him to surprise you with shrimp meal and ask for flowering green tea to experience the patience ( while waiting on flower to "bloom" in your glass).
author: Svetlana K.

description:
First restaurant for which I feel compelled to leave a review. The food is very average. Not terrible, not great. 

The issue is the service. Some terrible, rude, greedy people run this establishment.

We witnessed the couple sitting next to us getting shook down for a tip by the waitress. 

When it came time for our bill, they were reaching for our receipts before I even finished signing my name. I held my receipt until my partner was done signing hers so we could have them over together. They still tried to grab it right out of my hand. 

Despite watching me sign the receipt over my shoulder, they later accused me of not signing my receipt and demanded I show them I signed it to the point of loudly yelling at me in front of others customers. 

I regret coming here and never plan on coming back. I advise you to stay away. They should be embarrassed. I'm certainly embarrassed for them.

Chong Qing Xiao Mian is right next door. I suggest you give them your business instead.
author: Andrew L.

description:
House of Nanking is a pretty good place to get reasonably priced Chinese that'll hit the spot!

Not much Parking around so it's best done at the garage a couple blocks down the street.

While there's always a line for dinner the pro is there is a high turnover rate so it moves fast but that's also a con because service-wise you feel rushed.

Nanking was my very first meal in one of my all time favorite culinary cities so it will always have a special place in my heart! Was back in '98 (geesh time flies), I remember that first time the owner ordered for us (and basically every time since) and suffice to say that first meal was epic!

I've enjoyed the food the times I've been back (namely the Sizzling Rice Soup, Potstickers, Calamari and Sesame Chicken), just not as much as the first time and I've discovered better restaurants in Chinatown since. 

So, in light of there being better Chinese food around and the service Nanking probably deserves three stars but I'll give it +1 for nostalgia.
author: Justin I.

description:
I adore this place, I think we found it recommended in a Marco Polo guide book maybe? A fell upon in when exploring chinatown. 

As suggested on every review we'd seen, we asked the staff to pick for us, they were polite enough, but you could tell they were used to working like a well oiled machine, as its quite a small place, so it was banter free (probably also why they provide forks rather than chopsticks). We were a group of four, so got a table to ourselves, but saw that others were sharing. 

As a british consumer, it's hard to judge american portions, as they all look pretty damn big to me, but it came in big sharing plate mounds, which is how we always ate chinese at home so we were pretty happy. Sesame chicken was a particular fave with us. 

I've seen on a review or two, complaints about hygiene, which isn't something I spotted at all. 

Overall we were pretty happy, and I've recommended it to friends happily since.
author: Hannah M.

description: So we had to share a table, no exceptions, so it was a total of 8 people, including 3 strangers. The waiters were very fast paced, and were not patient at all. I understand it was very busy, however, everyone that works there wants you to eat and leave. The food was good, way better than any fast food restaurant, however the service tainted their reputation with me. I am not from San Fran, so if this is normal service, I am not used to it. When someone from our table had a question, the waiters were not helpful, and seem very bothered and the made me feel stupid for not knowing their food items. Overall, I would not recommend this place if you like good service, but if you just want to eat hot food, then go for it.
author: Iliana R.

description:
I'm usually not a picky eater but the food I had here was a way below what I was expecting for a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown with a line outside the door.  We ordered the Spicy Wor Dumpling Soup and Cold Sesame Noodles (this was recommended on Foursquare).

Positives:
- Seating was quick and we didn't have to wait outside for very long.
- Waiters and waitresses were quick.
- Gave us a Chinese menu (but we couldn't read it unfortunately and seemed way more expensive)

Negatives:
- Definitely did not cater to a Chinese audience because the flavors were all not Chinese and no chopsticks! 
- Very loud and crowded. You will most likely share a table with other people.
- The soup was too salty and small for something that's usually served for the whole table (again, this restaurant caters more to individual meals).
- The cold noodles were the biggest disappointment.  Nothing like what we imagined and basically tasted like noodles with Italian dressing over it.  I ate all the veggies but the noodles weren't even worth taking back home.

If you're looking for an authentic Chinese restaurant, go somewhere else even if it doesn't have a line.  If you want food that's really salty, sweet and sour at the same time, this is the place to go but it's unfortunately not for my taste.  We noticed that there were hardly any Asians in the restaurant but the line drew us in and that was the mistake that we made.
author: Jasmine C.

description: I went to House of Nanking with my son and his GF this past week. I got to House on Nanking 10 minutes before they did and I asked if I could just order everything so that when they got there the food would be out soon. As I went through the menu I was struggling over so many fun choices. The server (found out later she was the owner) asked me if I had any questions. I asked for her recommendation for Squid, Beef, Scallops, Shrimp and Chicken. She suggested the Melt in your mouth fried Calamari, Scallop Tower, Nan King Beef, Sesame chicken and a shrimp dish. Everything was flavorful and cooked to perfection. I ask her what was the vegetable in the shrimp dish thinking it was a light sweet potato and she said apple. I was blown away with the soft texture yet added flavor. By far there very beat Chinese food I have ever eaten. A 5 ***** must go place in San Francisco
author: Robert A.

description: This place is so unsanitary. The waiter/host put our menu on the clean plate and utensils. She cleaned the table next to us and not wash her hands. We asked for a straw and brings it with her bare dirty hands and put the straws in our water. The straws had no cover/wraps. Then one of the waiters brings our food with purple gloves on. Are you kidding me? I don't even know if those gloves were clean. If your waiter wearing gloves to bring your food that should tell you something and take a hint. The food is good but NEVER going back too scared to contact anything.
author: Mae S.

description: This place was AWFUL! Disgusting. The food is poor quality, the restaurant is grimy and the service is impersonal and rushed. We had the Nanking sesame chicken and it was a slimy ball of deep fried yuck. The eggplant had a very tough skin on it and the rice was so full of egg it overwhelmed the whole dish. When we arrived a rude girl told us to wait outside...and we were seated quickly. When we left - there was a line of about 12 people to eat this garbage. Our bill was $40 (2 diet cokes included), and not worth one dime of it. This place must be in tourist books - but it should not be. Really bad...bad...bad.
author: Shelly R.

description: I've been to this place plenty of times and the food never seem to disappoint me. Service is fast and food is goodie goodie.
author: Denise L.

description:
After a few years, we finally get to go back and eat here again. 
This place is always busy. Great to see Chef Peter here always. He is so nice, and very accommodating. His daughter Kathy was also there doing a taping with the food channel. 
Food is always great, and more than enough to eat. We always just ask for recommendations of the day, and never disappoints us. This place is well run, and continuing to do well with the next generations. This place is a must try spot in SF.
author: Chris C.

description: Silverware & water cup dirty (yellowish). Look at the wall wood paneling around your table, looks like hasn't been cleaned for ages. The famous sesame chicken is no better than what you get at a shopping mall food court. The calamari was the highlight.
author: Ifred M.

description: Yum! Everything here seems to be good and has a unique flavor to it. The dumpling soup with crispy rice is AH-MAZING. So delicious. It was on the appetizer menu but I could eat a whole bowl of that for a meal. Also enjoyed the garlic noodles and salt n pepper shrimp. The sesame chicken was so-so, but the baked sweet potato that came on the plate with it was delish. Great spot to eat with friends so you can try a few different dishes. Will be back to try other goodies on the menu.
author: Michelle E.

description: Delicious food. We ate what the staff recommended - Sesame Chicken, steamed pork wontons, and a shrimp dish with lemongrass and mushrooms. Another patron ordered Lo Mein that looked amazing but she felt it was too spicy... might need to be aware of this with certain dishes. Our food was flavorful, not spicy. Service was efficient - we weren't rushed but we didn't think we should linger... they obviously want to turn over tables on busy weekends, etc. We will definitely return next time we're in SF and I look forward to trying more dishes.
author: Denise J.

description: Terrible service. I usually don't care if the service is bad, I understand sometimes people are short of staff or whatever reason but this was next level. We walk in and we get seated right away. We were sitting for 20 minutes and no one came to us. Our menus were thrown at us and when saying we are ready to order the waitress got offended and processed to throw our food on the table. She also didn't even look at us the rest of the night so of course we had to ask someone else for the check. The water cup I received was used which then made me skeptical about the food. The food was alright, we got the pot stickers and fried rice along with the sesame chicken. The sesame chicken was really good so I highly recommend that, maybe for take out! This was my first time in San Francisco but I was disappointed overall with this place.
author: Hetal P.

description: As my family walked through the busy streets of Chinatown, we came across the House of Nanking. We were soon at a table but we stayed there for 15 minutes until a waiter showed up. Meanwhile people who came 4-7 minutes after us had already had their food. Slowly our food came in intervals of about 7 minutes. I had the fried calamari and it was amazing. The sauce gave you a sharp sweet taste and the meat was cooked to perfection. The only reason this is getting 3 stars is because of the very annoying wait times. It was annoying to look over to another group of people that came 8 minutes after you and they would be getting their main meal while you wouldn't have your appetizer. Overall the food was pretty good but the wait times compared to other restaurants was very bad.
author: Eli B.

description: Never coming back. Food and service were horrible. No idea where people on here got their idea of decent food. The sesame chicken was dry and chow menu was alright.
author: Nick L.

description:
Today was my third time visiting this place and I enjoyed the food so much, which was sesame chicken with fried rice and we order honey shrimp which wasn't on the menu but it was delicious!

The portions are huge so think about sharing whenever you visit + if you're indecisive, don't hesitate to leave it up to the lady who walks around screaming at everyone :) she knows her stuff and always on point!

I will come back again and this is definitely a good spot for a casual lunch with friends, don't know about a date because it gets pretty loud in there.

Cheers!
author: Adel F.

description: Very nice place. Friendly and very helpful waitresses. Loved it. Food was awesome. Very reasonable prices.
author: Eugene F.

description:
House of Nanking is one of my favorite restaurants in North beach. I love both of their goji berry and blossom flower tea in the beer mug. 

I've been here a few times in the past 6 months and I notice that many dishes have similar thick&sweet base sauce such as scallop tower, pork stuffed mushroom , eggplant and sesame chicken. The food here is good. Don't give me wrong. Just don't order the same sweet sauce. 
If you ask your server to recommend the foods, you would get the short / quick answer. Maybe you get the answer you what , or not. Service depends on your luck;) However the tea and plain white rice would help to cut the overly sweet flavor.

Definitely going back.
author: Ffaahh N.

description: Their menu lists pan fried pork chop "crusted" with onion and spices. It was smothered in corn-starch sauce.
author: Chris C.

description: So let me start by saying this food will leave an explosion of flavors in your boca. It was a delectable variety of food we ordered that included pot stickers, house noodles, sesame chicken and chicken lettuce wraps. Everything was scrumptious. Skip the garlic beef dish, did not care for it. Service was ok but the food Devi girly makes up for it.
author: Diana F.

description:
If you like Chinese food, then you have to try one of my favorite spots in the Chinatown district of San Francisco called House of Nanking. Located on 919 Kearny St, it is not too far from the city center and is within walking distance to other shops and transportation.

On busier days, there is often a line out front, so plan to spend a little extra time waiting as the locals really like this place and call it one of their favorite restaurants in the city. I have been here only a few times and have learned a very important lesson: DO NOT order off the menu, but rather have the owner order for you. Somehow, he's able to look at you and know what your preferences are from there. Then out of nowhere, four to five dishes come out of nowhere! I have no idea what I ate, but it was amazingly good for the standards that I hold Chinese food up to. All you have to say is the magic words, "hook me up."

This used to be a little hole in the wall, but over time, it has grown and grown and now looks more like a more mainstream restaurant than it did years ago. You'll find decent quality food that is always fresh, delicious and fast.
author: Steve N.

description:
If you like Chinese American food you may like this place. I used to like this place back in 2000 when the chef would just choose what's on the menu for me. He would ask if I like spicy food and he'd order something. I never knew what was actually on the menu back then.

But it's not like that now. We ordered 3 dishes. Sesame chicken, fried tofu with bead sauce, eggplant with garlic sauce and vegetarian dumpling. All have brown sauce and taste sweet. I wouldn't say it's bad, I think it's more to suit the American palate. 

If you are looking for a more authentic Chinese food, then it's not the place.
author: Yen T.

description: Would have been higher if the staff had treated us better. We were passed up multiple times for a table in favor of larger or smaller groups. They didn't even ask if we wanted to split the group up, which we would have liked to do because it meant we could actually make it to our show. Once we were seated, they demanded our order right away and freaked out when we asked if it came with rice. Our waitress straight up screamed at us, it was very disturbing. Our waters were never refilled. The food was fine but not worth the treatment. I begged my brother in law not to tip, but he is too nice. Overall, an extremely disappointing experience.
author: Julie C.

description:
Beware the sesame chicken dish. Mostly batter, a few tiny pieces of actual chicken.  Ended up arguing with the waitress, asking her how she could serve such a dish to her customers. Go to Panda Express if you want better sesame chicken.

To be fair, rest of the dishes were quite good.  But we left the restaurant feeling a bit cheated.
author: Steve Z.

description: It was 1999 when I first had a taste of House of Nan King and I couldn't remember the names of the dishes but I knew I loved them all. I remember the lines,  the tight space, the goji tea, and the feeling of absolute satiety after leaving the restaurant. Tonight,  it was my family's turn to get that same feeling.  That famous chicken sesame is a must! Sure, it does look like Gen. Tso's; it even tastes similar, but BETTER,  like 100 times better. It was the first to go.  We also had salted shrimp with mushrooms,  green beans,  short ribs, chicken dumplings and a fish soup that the waitress recommended.  The blossoming tea is the perfect beverage for this.
author: Penelope M.

description: The owner came up to us, asked if it was only three of us, and said he would take care of us. The rest is history, just like the food that didn't even last ten minutes on our table. The best Chinese food ever! The staff takes command of the restaurant and they take care of you like they were at home. Blessings to the owner!
author: Edwin S.

description: While in the city my eating itinerary included the house of Nanking me and my girl ate here about 5 years ago and really enjoyed it so it was on our list for lunch. This time it was not so good it was not inviting that means the service was  blaaa not so good and the food was the same the sizzling rice soup was not sizzling just warm enough said the worst part of hitting a restaurant you don't like is you have to wait till dinner to try something else the House is off the eating list
author: Carlos R.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I wanted to take my friend, who has never been to San Francisco before and I wanted her to have an authentic Chinese experience.  We went there on a Sunday night, and it was crowded; however we were able to be seated immediately despite the crowded restaurant.  Yes it is communal seating, but it is fun to see what everyone ordered. We decided to order the Sesame Chicken, Calamari and Chow Mein. Within 10 minutes we had all of our food. Both of us were full, and my friend enjoyed her first trip there.
author: Jeremy K.

description:
Decent above average Chinese restaurant right by the financial-chinatown district. Went on a Thursday afternoon around 2pm so there were only a few other families and I can't really comment on the service when busy. However, the wonton soup with a ricey type crunch was a delight. The sesame fried chicken was great as well as the fried rice. The fried calamari was in a coconut vinegarish sauce which was just ok. 

Decent lunch for sure but feels slightly overrated.
author: Errol S.

description:
As a guy who was born in Nanking and lived in Nanking for 18 years, I am totally disappointed.  They are definitely not real Nanking style food. I promise those cooks are not from Nanking and They made all these food by imagination. I must say that I have never tried these in my hometown. 

Btw the American style Chinese food looks very good.  Anyway, the servers are very nice.

If you wanna try real Nanking style cuisine, I strongly recommend you get a flight ticket and come to Nanking.



作为土生土长的南京人，这家店打开了我新世界的大门。
这家店除了不正宗的盐水鸭，没有一个菜是南京菜。
看到菜单上的红油抄手那一刻，我惊呆了。
老板操着广东口音和我们推荐各种菜。
酸菜鱼竟然是酸豆角炒炸鱼片。

吐槽归吐槽。
不过这家的美餐看起来还真不错！外国人吃的挺开心。
author: Zhongyuan Z.

description: House of Nanking is a great Chinese Food restaurant located in Chinatown. Although the sesame chicken was a bit dry, the hot and sour soup was an amazingly cooked creation. The fried tofu and melt in your mouth calamari were wondrous dishes. The service was okay, our waitress was a tiny bit lousy; we sat at the end of a long table and she just placed them at the front of the table. This restaurant offers amazing food with could be improved staff, in a historic and festive location in San Francisco!
author: Sophia L.

description: House of Nanking is always packed, this is the second time we try this place and the food didn't   disappoint us, the service is not so good but whatever, The portions are huge, and the taste is amazing
author: Marychuy T.

description: Ok food, terrible service, my fork hade rice on it, don't go there.it was sooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo bad I didn't like it at all
author: Karina B.

description: We chose House of Nanking on recommendation of the concierge at our San Francisco hotel (the Omni--wonderful stay;I'll review it later).  Could not have been better!  The food is real Chinese, not Americanized pablum.  We liked it so much that we went back a couple more times.  I can understand why people line up outside waiting for a table.  The service can sometimes be a bit slow, but all the better to linger over a cup of their special teas.  My advice:  if you are within 1000 miles of House of Nanking, make a detour for the best Chinese my wife and I have ever eaten (and we have eaten at about half of the best Chinese restaurants in the US.
author: Ed C.

description:
Growing up in the Bay Area means growing up on pretty tasty Asian food, particularly Chinese food and I would say this popular and frequented restaurant deserves a slightly above average rating, but I'm not going back.

 It's a good place to try once and see what the fuss is about, but I'd rather have a fun, laid back experience, rather than feeling like once I sit down I'm forced to stuff food in my face and bounce. House of Nanking gets a 3.5 in my book for its not bad, not the best food and its kind of wack service.

We started with the 4 piece green onion pancake that had 1 piece of shrimp in each piece. Kinda skimpy if you ask me, but I'd give that dish a 3. They were kind of on the crispy side, but I didn't mind it so much.

Another starter we ordered was the calamari. It's ring style calamari, so if you're looking for the fishy and squid like kind, this ain't the one. It didn't come with lemon and the sauce was poured on for you instead of on the side for dipping, so I wasn't impressed. If you're a calamari connoisseur, it's definitely not worth your money. I'd say pass and I'd give it a 2, by the way, it's also a bit oily. 

As much as I enjoy the oily Chinese dishes,  I love to test the green option/s they have in store at these kind of spots, so, I ordered the shrimp lettuce wraps, which came with a mixed veggie stuffing; mostly frozen veggies and peas, cubed squash and about 8 pieces of medium sized shrimp. They gave several pieces of lettuce for the wraps. The veggies were doused in a brown, sweet (but not too sweet) sauce. It was on the thicker side and I think the dish would have been better without so much sauce to go with this being one of the only  healthy options, as this is one of the cleaner (light and healthy) options of food here. Overall I'd give it a 4. 

House of Nanking was decent Chinese food. I'd give it a 3.5, but since service wasn't great and the main guy/owner was there making sure he made quick bucks, I'm going to give it a 3. The waitresses were alright, but they're probably trained to keep the line moving, so they don't get too personable. We went before 6 and it wasn't too packed, but half an hour later, there was a huge line waiting to get in. I would never wait in line to eat here, but it's definitely worth trying.

With love in the Bay, 
Renee Rises-- The Filipina foodie
author: Renee R.

description: Food was amazing, but some of the staff members were rude,  as we were still eating they came up to us with the receipt already and made my family and I feel rushed, mind you the restaurant wasn't full. We continued to finish our food and they took back the receipt to only give it back with a higher amount for the "tip" that they didnt 100% deserve because of their attitudes. We went to pay the amount our food was and left and one of the male staff members flipped off my 15 year old daughter for us not giving them a tip, if you don't like people with bad attitudes I wouldn't recommend.
author: Trinidad R.

description:
This restaurant is over hyped. When I was standing in front of the gate, seeing no Chinese dining inside, I felt it's not authentic already. I was right...

If you're a Chinese, you'll know this is American Chinese food. I have never seen any onion pancake stuffed with onion inside and peanut butter outside??? Seriously???

I wouldn't recommend to anybody if you want authentic Chinese food when you visit San Francisco.
author: Victoria S.

description: The restaurant had a very good reputation back in the day, however my visit today wasn't held up to what I remember. The sesame chicken was all in all my favorite platter, nothing to complain about there, but the rice noodle chicken tower was bland and had no taste, the lettuce wraps were also bland and the servers were throwing Lettuce on the plates without any gloves and turning it around to throw it on the table. The silverware and cups seemed very dirty and asking for a straw or more water seemed like such a hassle for the wait staff. The service was very rude and would even eat food and snacks in between service while serving. This place is a NO-GO for me. Been there done that, never going back.
author: Jesse R.

description:
I'm from New York and know great Chinese food and this restaurant is 
By far the best Chinese I've ever eaten in 
Everything fresh and amazing
author: Bruce W.

description: Excellent little diner! Food and drink were both served quickly and noodles were cooked perfectly. Nothing fancy, just solid Chinese fair. I'm a vegetarian and there were tons of options. Would definitely go back!
author: Carl N.

description:
We eat here every time we visit the city. Located on a busy street, the inside is humming with energy, too. Diners come in and out...not a place to linger or worry too much about personal space. 

The owner (I assume) greets us, hustles us to a seat, and brings dishes out that we don't even know the name of!

This time we had pork belly w/green beans and sesame chicken. 

The green tea w/jasmine was lovely.
author: Holly W.

description: I was so disappointed! I had high expectations because of all the great reviews. The food lacked flavor and was just plain terrible! Hell. Panda Express is gourmet compared to this restaurant!! Will never recommend or come back!! If your looking for great Chinese food in the Bay Area go to Chef Chu's in Los Altos, CA!!
author: Theresa K.

description:
Orders ($11-15 per dish)
Melt in your mouth Calamari (1/5 stars)
Salt and Pepper Shrimp and Mushrooms (4/5)
Chow Mein, add beef (2/5)
Fried rice, add chicken (2/5)
Stuffed mushrooms (3/5)
Flower tea (4/5) - $3.45

Service 4/5

Food 2/5

I was so disappointed with this place. I've learned my lesson about choosing places by most reviews and most stars. I'd feel too bad giving this place 2 stars. I went on a Friday afternoon around 1. It wasn't too busy, so there's no excuse about quality diminishing due to rushing. Food came out very fast but was really plain. I need to find a true authentic Chinese place. I've had great Chinese/Chinese American in DC NY and London. Disappointed with my first Cali spot  (San Diego has nothing). 

Calamari did not melt in your mouth nor was crunchy with little salt and pepper flavor. Some were soggy and sitting in vinegar  (intentionally?). I've had better from cheap delivery places.

The s&p shrimp and Mushrooms however were very good. Texture and flavors were on point. Not that many shrimp came with it, but generous with the tasty mushrooms.

Chow Mein was very bland, but the beef was cooked nicely and flavorful. Vegetables seemed like they were cut up and tossed on as an afterthought. Very unflavored. If you don't use msg or go light on it, work up some seasoning or something!

Fried rice and chicken was very bland. Chicken wasn't that dry, but again was bland.

Stuffed mushrooms were mediocre. Nothing to rave about but prepared well. Pork stuffed I think.

The flower tea was cool and tasted nice.
author: Anton S.

description:
After 30 minutes of trying to decide what Chinese to eat, we decided to go for House of Nanking. It was an excellent choice. It may not look like the most happening place from the outside, but it's got some good food. It's all incredibly fresh. 

You should do family style so you get to try as much as possible. The famous sesame chicken could actually be famous. I've also never been serves green tea like this before.
author: Matt F.

description: First and last time ever coming here again. The service sucks! The server that was helping us with our food actually touched the noodles with his hands... gross! Super cramped and awkward seating. The food wasn't all that great either.. the crispy noodle tower was not what I was expecting. Sesame chicken was ok. Overall my experience wasn't that great...
author: Christopher L.

description: Horrible food. Crispy noodle tower was not worth eating. Not sure how this place has so many good reviews.
author: Jeff F.

description: Chinatown has many choices. my co-worker recommended the House of Nanking. The food was good, service was good, My daughter and I enjoyed our meal here.
author: Julieann B.

description: So, this place has slowly but inexorably declined since the Pink Section gave it a stellar review 25-odd years ago. Last trips for us were about 2pm on a weekday recently and also this past Christmas. It is as ever noisy and crowded, but now it is also pretty dirty as well. I don't advise wiping your table with the provided white paper napkin unless you really want to know how much. We ordered sesame chicken, pot stickers, spinach salad and pork egg rolls. The chicken was extremely tough. They clearly dumped some frozen into the deep fryer, dumped a few seeds and treacly sauce over the top and job done. The pieces weren't close to uniform and many were just stuck together in a lump. The spinach leaves we're fresh, but destroyed by several pints of the same brown sweet sauce that graced our chicken. Chicken came with some edible starchy roots of some type. The pot stickers are also deep fried. This may or may not be the Nanjing style but they are really hard to cut and probably also came from the Food4Less feeezer. The egg rolls, deep fried, featured a hint of ginger so they won the taste test, but the bar was very low. Tough to get out of there for less than $50. They feature an interesting hot tea that comes with what looks like an alien pod floating in your cup of hot water. When saturated it sinks to the bottom and blooms into a flower. It is pretty, but as a source of tea, the flavor is not particularly distinguished. Avoid.
author: Douglas S.

description: This was my first time here and the food was very delicious. All the dishes we ordered were delicious but my favorite dish was the green onion pancake.
author: Hnin T.

description: Food was very tasty. Ordered the house fried rice, fried calamari, and salt and pepper mushroom shrimp. The mushroom shrimp dish was flavored perfectly. The calamari is fresh and juicy, nice meaty calamari. These three dishes were shared and still hard to finish...so larger size portions. Food is served very quickly also.
author: Alexis R.

description:
Really surprised by some of the comments here. Lived and worked in the neighborhood for years. Yes, there's a Soup Nazi (Seinfeld reference) element at play here, and it's not the place to go for ambiance or a wait staff that cracks jokes and spends time with you. 

The food is excellent. More or less get the same order: Sizzling Rice Soup, Sesame Chicken, Spicy String Beans, Fried Potstickers. Perfect for two. The quality of the ingredients and cooking here should be pointed out as well - it's hard to cook Chinese food that is not terribly greasy but still has flavor. This place has always nailed it.
author: Peter T.

description:
I was here a few years back and can't stop thinking about it. By far, the best Chinese food I have ever had (including NY, Boston and Vancouver BC).
It's a small hole in the wall kind of place. The server came out and asked if it was our first time there. After we replied yes. Maybe we looked confused as to what to order, but he motioned us to give him back the menus and said, I'll take care of you. He brought us out a calamari dish which was to die for, along with a chicken and a shrimp dish, which we all shared. I need to get back to SF and satisfy my belly here!
author: Jo D.

description:
Came here on Saturday for lunch. We were sat down right away and then greeted by the owner who asked us a few questions on what types of foods we prefer, vegetarian, meat, spice level, etc. Then he said he'll prepare a dish for us accordingly. We were a bit hesitant at first, because we like knowing what we get but this was a first time experience to try.
The interior has two seating sections. Most of the patrons were non Asian, so I can tell from the start that the place steers on the side of Asian fusion.
Besides the mystery dish, we also ordered the sweet potato and eggplant stir fry and hot tea.
The hot tea had goji berries, and came out in a big glass mug. It tasted pretty good, and kept me warm.
The sweet potato and eggplant was cooked in a very flavorful sauce, but a bit too salty. I really liked the texture of the eggplant. However, the sweet potatoes were undercooked, and not sweet. It tasted more like a regular potato. I like my sweet potatoes fairly sweet and softer.
The second dish, prepared by the chef, was a stir fried cauliflower and crispy pork belly. The sauce was pretty good, not overly salty, and I had mostly the cauliflower, while the boyfriend took the pork belly.
The meal came out to be $35, a bit more than we expected, since it meant the two dishes were $15 each. And I didn't think they were worth that much. The tea was around $4, quite expensive compared to other Chinese restaurants. And a tub of white rice was $1-2.
Anyhow, I wouldn't come back again since there's many more authentic Chinese restaurants down the street in Chinatown. I think this place caters to Americans who are intimidated by authentic Chinese food.
author: Alice S.

description: I want to continue to love this place, and visit this place, and enjoy the food in this place. The Sentinel Building across the street is such a wonderful view. The waitress continues to work here, a constant, since my first visit too many years ago, now. Maybe, I should maintain the program, specify the main, and allow them to concoct the cure. I made the mistake of just ordering the sesame chicken, and I was less than satisfied on this visit. The concoction didn't quite work. While the chicken was mostly still well prepared, the sweet potatoes were not good - maybe they were not properly in season, I don't know. I just wasn't pleased with the overall. The taste of the sauce was still spot on, as was the rice, and the black iced tea. I will return, like a Canadian Goose returns to Canada each Spring. And next time, I'll go with their advice. And their stand-offishness delightful chinese well-prepared delicious food. I look forward to it. Cheers!
author: Michael C.

description:
Ok I'll be extremely brief this place has a solid menu. Food was good service was pretty sketchy,
well let's be honest this place has very rude in your face service. So if your in the mood for good Chinese not great, but good and don't mind being treated like a stepchild. Well then look no further thank House of Nanking my friends!!
author: Eric A.

description: The BEST Food. Get the sesame chicken and green beans. Your. Life. Will. Change. So flavorful! They were so friendly and fast. You have to try this place!
author: Sara R.

description: Visiting SF with the fam & Husband was raving about this place being famous, so we decided to give it a try.  It was a little busy, but got a table right away.  I was straight out surprised when the waitresses were rude.  The food was ok, nothing too special, pretty blend.  Having had a lot of good Chinese food all over, it was nothing much to get excited for.  But anyways what breaks the deal was, since it was closing time, the staffs were preparing to leave, I was sitting facing towards where the kitchen was and saw a waitress holding a whole raw fish with her bare hands and put it in a plastic bag in the eating area. Then on an empty table just next to us, a waitress placed her shoe bag and took out her shoes to wear them.  We asked for an empty glass and was given a dirty one, so my husband asked to replace it, and the waitress took it and just rinse it with water and brought it back and I watched her do this.  At this point I am already shaking my head.
author: Yamin S.

description:
Way overhyped. I don't know what draws people to wait in a line outside in the cold for this place.

ARRIVAL:
If not crowded, they seem to try seating customers by the door.
If crowded, "10-15 minute! Wait outside!" followed by some initial confusion of what was just said and then comes the line of incredibly cold customers outside on these chilly winter nights.

SEATING:
Parties of two are seated uncomfortably close to each other, by American standards. House of Nanking will move two tables (meant for parties of four) about two inches away form each other and seat two parties. It's almost like the hella Chinese places that have two parties share a large round table to seat more people. 

FOOD:
-- House Special Sesame Chicken = OK? Not bad but not amazing. Sweet brown sauce smothering fried chicken pieces, accompanied by sliced orange (yam? carrot? sweet potato?) and green veggies (cucumber?). Tastes kinda like general tso chicken. The staff use bare hands to top the dish off with sesame seeds... after pressing the register's touch screen and other things. I HOPE THEY WASH THEIR HANDS AFTER HANDLING DIRTY DISHES.
-- Melt in your Mouth Calamari = Eh. The texture of the calamari pieces is nice since you don't have to break your jaw gnawing away. The batter is light but doesn't stick to the calamari well because of the light citrus sauce making it soggy. Chewy, yes. Crunchy, nada.
- Pork Egg Rolls = Decent. They taste different than any other egg roll I've ever had. They make nice appetizers, sure.

SERVICE: Sub-par Asian service
Less pleasant than usual Asian service.
-- "Wait outside!" when they have customers waiting to be seated. When there was a reservation holding two rows of tables, there was no explanation to incoming customers why they need to wait and not be seated there.
-- Instead of making suggestions to new customers (i.e. tourists), "Get this *points*" or "You want this *points*." Uhh okay.... The staff definitely rushes people to order.
-- Raising voices at customers asking questions
author: Liana F.

description:
The food it's good, but not great. I've heard a lot about their sesame chicken. It was good, but not worthy of a gold medal. 
Service it's average and the food just above that.
author: Marcelo B.

description: This restaurant was efficient and adequate, but certainly didn't wow me with any of the dishes we ordered. The sesame chicken and potstickers were fine, the calamari I couldn't even take more than two bites, just not good. A little bit of a disappointment.
author: Melissa C.

description: Gross. Don't believe the yelp reviews. They must be fake because this is the worst Chinese I've had. Try MY China in the mall
author: Matt K.

description: The noodles here were bomb. Tiny crammed location, however I'll definitely go back for the good food, and good prices too.
author: Mike W.

description:
After finding this place on yelp and looking like the best Chinese food in the area, we decided to go. The place was packed but we were seated pretty quickly. They took our order fast and some of the food came quickly while the meat dishes took way longer to come out. It was very poorly timed and spaced out considering we wanted to eat all the dishes together. They recommended the house noodles which were good but we preferred the chow mien noodles which were significantly better. The sesame chicken was really good and crispy. Also the eggplant was delicious. The only bad thing that we got was the beef with bok choy. We were so turned off by the beef we just ate the bok choy and not the beef. 

Definitely not the place for a leisurely lunch. You can tell they want you in and out real quick. But still good if you order the right thing.
author: Brigitte N.

description:
Food is flavorless, no taste or aroma. Have heard good things about the restaurant but felt like it's overrated. ordered mixed vegetable, fried rice and the curry in mixed vegetable was just watered down. 

Service was bad on top of that. Order taker didn't really seem to care.
author: Bhumil P.

description:
Note- Came here years ago and it was amazing!

Revisited a couple of days ago, and was slightly disappointed. 

Order:
Veggie fried rice- Came out cold
Salt and Pepper Shrimp and Mushrooms- Great taste . . . just not amazing
Fried Chinese Eggplant- My favorite of the evening. Lightfly fried, full of flavor, and perfect texture. 
Ginger Scallops- Sad. Bland. 
Detox Tea- 2nd favorite. I tried both the hot and iced. The iced tasted sweeter, the hot detox tea is my favorite. I even took some to go.

Bill was about $55

Not sure if I came during an off moment. I would definitely come back . . . minus my high expectations.
author: A B.

description: Got to the place at around 730pm on a Tuesday night. Place was crowded. As we walked in a table had cleared up and were seated right away. After ordering our drinks, waitress brought it all within a couple of mins. We ordered 5 dishes and all of our orders came within 5 mins from ordering. Talk about quick!  Service is quick and turn around time is also quick. We were able to walk in and out within 45 minutes. Parking is terrible during dinner time. We drove around and in and out of several streets to find parking. Food menu is limited unlike other Chinese restaurants that have several pages of food items. House, noodles, house fried rice, sesame chicken, shrimp with mushrooms and fried calamari was our food choices for the evening.
author: Patrick O.

description:
On the recommendation of a friend, we decided to try House of Nanking today for lunch. There is a lot of hype for this place, especially considering its presence on the 7x7 list a few times recently. The atmosphere here is different than I expected in a good way. I thought this would be in the style of your classic grungy chinese hole in the wall but instead it was very clean and had an almost rustic feel to it. 

Shrimp packets - 2/5 - This would have been a 4/5 if it had more than one shrimp in each one and a whole lot less peas. As it is though, it should be renamed to pea packets. 
Pork egg rolls - 3/5 - Decent but average.
Onion pancakes - 2/5 - This was a bit different than most onion pancakes but really not that impressive.
Calamari - 4/5 - This was a very unique and interesting way to prepare calamari. It walked the line between a crispy fried snack and a soft saucy dish. I can't place the sauce but it definitely had some (chili?) oil to it and a cream base as well. I enjoyed this.
Sesame chicken - 4/5 - Nicely fried sesame chicken, which was a bit above average but nothing special. However, together with the sauce and the sweet potato this dish came together as my favorite of the meal. I'd order this again.

Overall, House of Nanking was good, but it didn't live up to expectations. It was "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description: Great place to eat.  Go in hungry and don't order from menu.  Just tell them to bring it.  They will just bring you plates of food.  It's awesome.
author: Robert W.

description: Our all time favorite, went here with a bunch of nasa colleagues, during supercomputer training. Had a blast!
author: Craig S.

description: The ONLY reason for four stars is the service. We did show up 10 mins before closing so I wasn't expecting a welcome wagon, but what others have said about their service is true. They yell a lot and aren't big on hospitality. But I can see how they wouldn't have time because their SESAME CHICKEN was the best I ever had! My husband and I shared a plate with rice and got the pork egg rolls and that was filling enough. If you want amazing Chinese in Chinatown  go here! Just don't expect 5 star service
author: Dominique G.

description:
I came to this restaurant with my law school friends. A buddy recommended that we come check it out. As soon as we arrived the owner asked us if this was our first time. We said yes and he asked if we had any food allergies. He took our menus away and created a special menu for us 4. It was the most amazing dining experimented I've ever had in San Francisco. He took our breath away and my glass of wine made the night that much better! 

I will now frequent this restaurant at least once a month. It's all so fresh, unique and delicious! You can't miss it.
author: Cece F.

description:
Listen up Yuppie Yelpers- here's the deal. 
The staff isn't going to dote on you. They aren't going to make you feel special or welcome or accommodate a gluten free diet. But you shouldn't always go to places to inflate your own ego, sometimes you should go to places to eat.

Why is this place amazing? The wild blossoming tea, the delicious sea food, we had sesame chicken that was out of this world and tofu in peanut sauce that was amazing. It's the kind of place where we're all sitting close enough together that you talk to the people next to you. Embrace it. Eating is a human experience and the food is special. If you're not coming in with the desire to eat great food, but rather to be controlling of your surroundings and try to boost your own ego- go to Panda Express! At least they'll deserve your 2 star rating and pretentious feedback.
author: Kelcie S.

description:
When you walk into House of Nanking, you might have to wait a minute. This place is much beloved, and they are very very busy. Here's what you should be prepared for: 

When they have a space for you, the older gentleman at the door will ask you quickly if you want a menu. The answer is no -- they will take care of you. Then he might ask if you have any dietary restrictions: "You eat meat? Dairy? Anything you don't eat?" You'll keep it simple and quick out of respect for how busy he is.

Then they will jam you in quick as they can and bring you dish after dish of whatever they are cooking at that moment in the kitchen until you beg them to stop. You might enjoy a half dozen amazing and creative dishes at Nanking. For instance, an unexpected dish I remember was sublime butternut stuffed wantons.

It is not only really great food, but an amazing experience to be so well taken care of.
author: Wes M.

description: The food here is very good, I personally really enjoyed the sesame chicken and pork dumplings. However, I will warn you, the service is terrible. You will encounter nothing but rude waiters and waitresses. Their rudeness can over shadow the food experience if you are walking in unprepared. Last tip, you also might be seated right next to complete strangers if it is a busy night. Best of luck for those that decide to dine here.
author: Melissa D.

description:
I've heard amazing things about House of Nanking, and when afforded a long lunch break, I knew I had to give it a try.

I went with the classic Sesame Chicken, which was a pretty solid dish. It was nice and crispy, and coupled with sweet potatoes, a great combination of sweet and salty. I don't normally eat sweet potatoes, but House of Nanking made them good enough to eat.

Where I am not impressed is that this isn't the most lunch-friendly place for single diners. The dishes tend to be very large, so it was sort of intimidating for me to finish a whole family style plate with an order of rice. With no lunch specials, it's hard for me to come by and grab a quick meal during lunch break. There's plenty of places with lunch specials in Chinatown, so it's a shame that somewhere as well-known as House of Nanking doesn't have any. Feel free to correct me if I'm wrong, and I am more than willing to come by again.

While this isn't the best place for single diners, it seems like a fantastic place for groups. Bring your families and friends, and enjoy some decent Chinese food in SF Chinatown.

TIP: Come with friends!
author: Brian L.

description:
We stopped in a little before they closed and were happy to be seated. Inside is packed and you sit family style. The seating was cramped and our neighbors food covered more of our table than theirs.

Sesame Chicken- this was very tasty and the steamed rice was a great side. The chicken is fried mixed pieces with a sweet glaze but is not overly sweet. There is a small spicy element.

Calamari - nothing special. We took our order to go and these didnt hold their crunchiness. Soggy and dipped in the bland butter sauce, these werent our favorite.

Shrimp Packets- Delicious! Will order 2 next time.

P.s. our server was pushy and not helpful but we didnt mind since it helped us decide we wanted our order to go.
author: Lisa H.

description: Delicious food. The fried calamari was the best I've had. Highly recommend. Came in and got seated right away. Steaming rice soup is a great way to start the meal especially on a cool day
author: Jacob G.

description: Friend said to go here when in Chinatown, what a great place.
