Go in your first time and just tell them to pick your meal, it's weird but if you say "We like Shrimp or Beef" they will come out with something spectacular, really enjoyed this place. Was an experience and the food was super good.
author: Jake M.

description: My visit to this restaurant was a delightful experience. The food was delicious. The restaurant is rather small and cramped and we sat directly next to people we didn't know, but all of that was part of how great it was. We ordered the house noodles, egg rolls, a bottle of wine and asked the waitress to bring us whichever two entrees were her favorite. She brought us sesame chicken and a shrimp dish; both were to die for. I would go back to this place over and over.
author: Allison J.

description:
This place is fun - it has windows that open to the street - it's bustling, it feels busy, it feels like a restaurant in NYC East Village.

That being said, the food was ... gross. I think the tip off should have been all the Caucasian tourists that packed the joint. But all the same, this restaurant is a SF legend and all the waiters spoke Mandarin and were abrupt and cold (critical factors when evaluating  Chinese establishments)

The food came out very quickly but it was gawd awful. Trigger warning: the following descriptions may turn you off from food for the next 24 hours.

Pork chop - WTF? It was a thin pan seared pork chop covered in this thick brown sauce that looked like mole but tasted like bouliion thicker with cornstarch.

Fried rice - with zucchini? What Chinese grandma is putting zucchini in fried rice? And what's with the wet slightly mushy rice. Fried rice at Panda Express is way better

Chick n lettuce cup- oh hell, wtf is up with those chunks of raw tomato. You know Chinese folk don't put raw anything and certainly not 1 inch cubes of raw tomato in a stir fry. The stir fry itself was weird. It was a scrambled egg concoction with rancid chicken meat and raw tomato. You were supposed to put this in the lettuce cup... but why would I want to taint the only delicious thing on the plate, the raw lettuce.

Pea shoots - ugh, they were the little pea shots that have the texture of toothpicks. So imagine green think toothpicks stir fried with onion. Ugh

Tofu with broccoli - again the brown sauce... barf. Though the tofu was fried and very tasty. But everyone scraped off the brown sauce.

Love the atmosphere, the location - 3.5-4
The food - 1-1.5

Which is about a 2-2.5 rating
author: Madison W.

description:
It has been over a decade since I dined here. I was so pleased to walk in and experience the communal tables and fast paced ordering. 

The food was close to the same but just didn't have the same feel. Don't get me wrong! It was delicious but was missing somethings that I can't put my finger on.

Don't mind me, I have issues and everyone loved their food!

It is still well worth the visit!
author: Chris C.

description: Disappointing to say the least. Flavorless and greasy , just not what it used to be. The  gyoza skins were way to thick and starchy, and lacked flavor. House noodles the bland. Will not be going back there anytime soon
author: Richard L.

description: I don't know why this place has great reviews. Bad food and overpriced. Spent close to 55$ for lunch for 2 people. We didn't order any drinks. No ambience. Whole place smelled of bleach. Won't be going there again.
author: Rajni J.

description: Our favorite go to place for Chinese in the city! It may look like a hole in the wall, but we haven't found better, mor than authentic Chinese food in all of San Francisco. Definitely recommend!
author: Chey J.

description: Delicious! And super friendly people. Highly recommended after a cold San Francisco tourist walk.
author: Fernanda N.

description: Must order: hot and sour soup, sesame chicken and  melt in your mouth calamari. Service is very friendly. Highly recommend this place if you're craving good Chinese food.
author: Salisa K.

description:
I discovered this place wandering around SF in 1991. I decided to go to the place with the longest line, and this was it. Any restaurant open this long has to be good. They doubled their space since the 1990s.

I don't remember specific menu items except for the lettuce wrapped chicken. I've eaten most of what they offer over the years. Everything is delicious.

There is zero ambiance. You go here to eat.
author: Rob S.

description: Don't get comfy! they will more than likely move you to move to another table on order to accommodate bigger parties. You will also be sitting right next to or even across from strangers. The current health and safety rating is 83 here. It doesn't look like much from the outside but the food here is bomb, I had the sesame chicken, garlic fish, and chow mein. All came out hella fast and were delicious! Lines can get long!
author: Mariah R.

description: Service was fast and efficient, but as for the food..The house fried rice came out looking really wet and kind of tasted like unevenly cooked rice. Wish the presentation could've been better, especially the fried potstickers with the sauce was splatter over them which make it look unappetizing.
author: Tran C.

description: The most horrible customer service. Very limited options on menu. Food tasted disgusting. Avoid!!!!!
author: Julie K.

description: They have a very special recipes of Chinese food that you can never find anywhere else. I can feel ghat even non-Chinese dinner love to go to this place, too. Recommended. You have a new experience of eating Chinese food here.
author: Tran M.

description: Loved this place!! Authentic food like I've never had. Our server was difficult to understand and did all the ordering for us. Seemed awkward, but her recommendations were spot on. Sesame chicken and noodle tower were top notch!! Potstickers were delish. We had tofu and broccoli, not even sure what it was called but we loved it. Highly recommend this place.
author: Sarah C.

description: We were seated quickly so that was a plus.  The menu is extremely limited. The food lacked flavor and was overpriced especially when compared to the portion size.  I asked for water and it came in a Tupperware plastic glass without ice . Not the experience or cuisine we were looking for.
author: Rica T.

description:
The food is great and the service has always been fine when I have went. They will sometimes be short with you but hey the food is great so I cant complain. 

The dumplings are must order along with the Sizzling rice soup, Calamari and Stuffed Mushrooms. 

Dont be afraid to order outside of your comfort zone because its going to be awesome. 

There isnt much parking nearby so I would definitely recommend taking a taxi and going at off hours because they dont take reservations and this place can get incredibly busy.
author: Jeremy A.

description: Fast paced and delicious, had to try out their crispy noodle tower and it was good along with everything else my wife ordered lol..
author: Joser S.

description: OMG! The best Chinese food I ever had! Ask for their soup salty with chicken! You'd never forget the taste then! They serve just as how Chinese restaurants do :)) I was enjoying my food so much that I forgot taking a photo' sorry ... ‍
author: Shima Z.

description:
Very mediocre food on 9/13/17 (our second visit since 2015), presented in a careless manner.

I don't understand why this place gets such attention. I'd put it in the tourist trap category.
author: Letty B.

description:
Have to try the Egg Plant-Scallops w/Serried Lemon [Cut in half and eat all including lemon] burst of flavor...we also had Pork-Dumpling with traditional family style table shares.

-Tight space but worth it even sharing the table

-Blessings
author: James O.

description: Great food as always.  It has been a while since we've been here last.  I have to say I love the unique cooking style.  Seems like they have updated their dishes but it's still very tasty.  We had the onion cakes, Salt & pepper shrimp and the sesame chicken.  They were really delicious.
author: M T.

description: My experience here years ago with a portion of my college cohort was exponentially better than my most recent solo visit. This restaurant is definitely better for big groups and family-style eating than for small portions. So, when I showed up alone for a salad and tea... I think everyone was a little disappointed. But still, the food was beautifully seasoned. My most sincere complaint is that I felt somewhat out of place for being alone and unfortunately, was certainly treated as such. This experience has tainted my love for the restaurant.
author: Sara P.

description:
The food was delicious. We were a group and the waitress told us each ordering individual sesame chickens would be too much. Everything is served family style. 
Started out with the home made wonton, and was pleasantly surprised considering it did not look like the traditional clear broth wonton I am used to seeing in the restraunts back home. Everything was absolutely delicious and would come back to this wonderful place.
author: S B.

description:
Food was okay. Service was pathetic. Water hygiene another issue. Staff will not talk to you plus very rude.
At the end they will keep reminding you about tip while waiting for you to sign the check.
author: Anusheel A.

description:
Nanking is a staple for me and my friends and family. Over the last decade I've introduced countless friends and family to the experience of House of Nanking. It's like a SF institution.

It was never about fine dining and high customer service. It's about pack in for AMAZING authentic and incredibly unique flavors.

I recommend letting them order for you and watch the surprises come. (you can request any food allergies/requirements you have, they're surprisingly responsive to them)
author: Rob B.

description: Years and I've been there before but this time it was very underwhelming in a crowded and too saucy way and the waitstaff is not friendly and it's basically a tourist trap so I suggest avoiding it
author: ari s.

description:
I love the House of Nan King. We have been coming for decades and each time we enjoy a fresh and quality meal. Usually, we just fell out server what we like and don't like (spicy, fish, chicken, beef, noodle, etc.) and then let them bring us dishes they recommend. We have never left hungry or unsatisfied.

The house chicken dish is amazing. Pot stickers steamed or fried in peanut sauce. All is amazing. 
Enjoy. The house special rice is delicious.
author: Randy M.

description: Ok, their food is better than average, so I came back for the 2nd time. However, their service is terribly bad. The waitresses are pretty rude and disrespectful. So if you feel you get offended, don't be surprised. Definitely won't go back again
author: Xavier B.

description:
House of Nanking is quite a trek from my office. Alright, it's not really that far, but high heels can turn the most innocent walk into a slog to the top of Half Dome (read: ouch). Nevertheless, I refuse to wear running shoes with a dress or a skirt, on principle. 

I had previously tried to go to HON (ha) and failed (see my Dumpling House review for the explicit details). Be careful to note where you're at, because the Dumpling House next door is quite popular, and it typically has a line going out the door. If you're prone to attacks of sudden onset ADD like myself, you might just get in that line if you're not paying attention. And that would be tragic. 

Since then I have been to HON twice, once for lunch and once for dinner, and I kind of love it. 

Strangely, the item I love the most at HON is the steamed pork dumplings. I think dumplings are so satisfying, and the ones that are not deep fried tend to taste better to me. HON's dumplings do not disappoint. They are the perfect texture (and I'm a freak about texture), and cooked to perfection (I.e., HON gets that "steamed" does not mean "boil" the sh*t out of them). But all of that aside, order these dumplings simply for the sauce they come in--what the FRAKK is that sauce? It doesn't taste like peanut sauce to me. It's nice and cool yet pleasingly spicy and delicious. Yes, please. 

I've also had the sesame chicken, since HON describes it as their signature dish. It's served with yams (or some kind of sweet potato) and a green apple garnish. The portion is huge (please be advised that you will need assistance finishing this dish, and that I'm available to help). But it's pretty tasty. It's very filling, of course, because it's fried. The yams are a surprisingly good element of the dish, although they will make you feel pretty full as well. I can get one order for take out and live off of it for three days, easily. Call me crazy, but I don't think it's diet. 

I'll be back for the garlic fish and the melt in your mouth calamari, naturally. The soup looks bangin as well. I want all of it. 

The interior of the restaurant is split into two rooms, mostly with large community tables. The service is supremely efficient (read: lightening fast). The Tsingtao is flowing like wine.  

Never mind the restaurant next door, this is what you want.
author: Sunny S.

description:
The food is really tasty but the staff are really rude and non polite at all. Should improve the service.
The negative point is you share the table with strangers...so if you want intimacy this is not the place. I recommend the sesame chicken and salt & pepper shrimps.
author: Isaac L.

description:
:) Christmas night dinner.

 We waited in line for close to 45 minutes, but it was worth the wait.  As it was a bit chilly waiting in line, we decided to warm up with egg drop soup to start.  It was quite good.  Three of us shared two entrees - sesame chicken and honey shrimp.  Both were very tasty.  A bit pricey, but it is San Francisco!
author: Ruth C.

description: Went here with my wife on an anniversary vacation, this place had spectacular noodles at a reasonable price. The food came faster than expected at a restaurant that was full of people
author: Carson W.

description: This is probably the BEST Chinese food I've ever had. I have def had my fair share of Chinese food living in the valley but coming to the city and stopping at this place was amazing! The service was great! We got here at 7 for dinner and we were seated immediately. We ordered the populars on yelp which were the calamari and the sesame chicken which were golden* also ordered chow mein broccoli beef, fried rice and pork potstickers. Everything was Amazing! This place is definitely the place to go in the city and I will plan to come here again and again! Happy birthday to me:-)
author: Stephanie I.

description:
I had heard from a friend about how popular this place was in Chinatown and wanted to give it a shot. I did hear that they do tend to have a long line - but we were lucky that night! As a Chinese restaurant owner's daughter - I'd say I am pretty particular about dishes from Chinese restaurants (if I even go to them at all!) But this place definitely had some delicious flavor that made me a fan.

Pork Wonton Soup - HIGHLY recommend! They add a small twist where the broth that the soup comes in is reminiscent of Tom Kha thai soup. It wasn't so citrus-y flavor wise so it did not overwhelm the taste of the pork wontons. The Medium was enough to feed my group of 3 people for two small soup bowls. Great as a starter/appetizer dish.

House Special Fried Rice - We shared the rice and it was good as well! Nothing particularly special about it (honestly if a Chinese restaurant can't get their Fried Rice right, then we got a problem). 

Snow Pea Leaves - We got the Snow Pea vegetable dish and that was delicious! Highly recommend as a flavorful veggie dish to go along with any meat item you choose.

5 Spice Porkchops - Flavor was good but there was only about 4-5 slices 4 oz thin slices that was barely shareable between 3 people, so just keep that in mind for trying to go family-style. 

Overall a pretty great try and would definitely recommend for people trying to find a place to eat in Chinatown!
author: Tracy L.

description: Amazing food always a must when in SF.  Crowded and noisy,  very New York.   You will not be disappointed.  Try the calamari in coconut milk.
author: Kathryn R.

description:
Love the place! 
It's fun, there is good food, and it's definitely something you have to experience!
author: Lary C.

description: I just dont know how others rated this place so high. First, the food was very bad. We ordered house fried rice, Nanjing Sesame chicken, fried calamari and Sweet & Sour soup, two bowls of steamed rice. All of the food was very bad, we didn't even ask to take our left-over home. Oh, our two bowls of steamed rice? First, they didn't give us the two bowls of steamed rice that we ordered, so I shown them the receipt and that's when they brought us just one bowl. Me and my wife just shock our heads and left the place. Don't come here, it'll waste your time, money and your appetite.
author: Keith C.

description: I've been telling people about a House of Nanking for 20 years. While the service is always kind of like they are doing you a favor, it fits with the style of this restaurant. I feel like they are doing me a favor by bringing the best steamed pork dumplings I've ever had. I always get the peanut sauce on the side with them. I don't know what Peter Fang does to make that sauce so good but when you have a little of the dumpling sauce mixed with the peanut sauce... hello. Awesome! Just ask him to bring you a crispy chicken or shrimp dish, something with his incredible veggies, some dumplings and a Tsingtao beer and that's all you will need to complete your China town eating experience in San Francisco. Apparently David Letterman and The Rolling Stones have the same opinion as they eat there or order to go whenever they are in town (so I've heard). I like the remodel they've done. Back in the day the cooks manned the woks right up front but now they're in the back and they've spruced up the two divided dinning areas. It's certainly still crowded and not elegant or anything but everyone I come to the city, I'll stop in for a treat.
author: Michael W.

description: I went to this place on the recommendation of one of my friend , he is a foodie like me but my experience of this place is not very good as far as food is concern it was below average . We ordered house special noodles and calamari in white gravy. Noodles taste was ok but they were not even warm and calamari was so sour. Sitting arrangement is horrible. I would not recommend this place.
author: Food L.

description: This restaurant has great food! Out of the 7 places I ate whilst I was in San Francisco this was by far the best. The food is served super quick but is still super tasty. I recommend the Chicken Noodle Tower. It's sooo good.
author: Aidan B.

description:
We eat here every trip to the city. It doesn't look fancy and that's fine with me. The food is generally pretty fabulous. The service is not overly friendly but I'm fine with that too. The bathroom leaves a lot to be desired. Small, dirty and watered down hand soap makes me wonder how clean staff hands are but I've never been sick after eating here. 
Until this past visit I had loved every entree we have ordered. I didn't care for the scallop tower at all. It's $15 for 3 scallops which were cooked until rubbery and set atop an orange wedge and piece of mushy eggplant. Definitely wouldn't order that again! Something about the word "tower" made me think it would be more than 3 also. Everything is served family style to share, except that apparently.
author: Denice B.

description: This place is very simple not upscale but the food is superb, I crave for it! I had to go eat here when I was in town even though I had to commute from Burlington.
author: Mary Jeannette Hollero S.

description:
Featuring uncompromisingly tasty dishes like their famous* sesame chicken, fried shrimpackets (that contain actual succulent shrimp) in sesame sauce and my favorite, the insanely addictive house noodles...this is a restaurant I would regularly return to if I lived in this city.

My only major complaint is the blossom in my blossom tea was the only blossom that didn't blossom. I obviously demanded my entire meal be comped,** but the staff refused. 

Truth be told, the service is a bit perfunctory; however, I've come to expect that from any excellent Chinese restaurant from coast to coast. P.F. Chang's has friendly servers, and I'd rather eat at the House of Nanking any day. 
____________

*I'm not sure to whom, but it was good. 
**I didn't actually do this. Don't do things like this, or nobody will like you.
author: Peter D.

description: I would give it ZERO stars but that's not an option on Yelp! The servers are rude. The plates are dirty. The food is horrible. Save your time and money and go to Panda Express. Possibly the worst Chinese food on the West Coast, if not the entire USA! The food they served us would not be found anywhere in China -- it is just sweet, syrupy goopy Americanized crap. Avoid like the plague.
author: James W.

description: Delicious Chinese food offered with a hurried service. I've been coming here since 2001 and never miss it when I'm in SF. It's my favorite Chinese food restaurant. The sesame chicken is a must, but really, you can't go wrong with anything else on the menu. It's a small place and gets crowded, so expect a line out the door if you come late.
author: Amine A.

description: Very good family style food. Melt in your mouth calimari lives up to it's name, tasty fried rice, yummy noodles, wonton soup is delicious. People sitting next to us loved everything they ordered
author: Christine B.

description: Good food. Horrible service. Only from the crazy ass woman who seats people like she's crowd control at an anti-Trump rally in Portland. Broccoli Beef  was off the hook not to mention the menu. Crispy noodles stack or whatever it was, was ok but lacked the flavor flav of the Broccoli Beef!!!
author: D L.

description:
Recently visited this place. I was really excited about this restaurant due to it's reputation. However, my expectations for this place were not met. 

The service was just awful. None of the staff members, except for maybe one, were nice. We felt rushed when ordering our food to the rude server. Maybe it's just a language barrier, but I noticed the awful service throughout the night, not just to me and my bf but to other guests that evening. 

Despite the 1 star service, the food was good. But overpriced for what it is. I can probably go somewhere else for better Chinese food and better service.
author: Luis G.

description: Tourist trap at this point.  The inspiration and creativity of 15 years ago is long gone.  The Nanking dishes are unique but really just a sweet General Tso without the sour and heat.  The version of hot and sour soup i had was disgusting.  No flavor and just looked like strings of egg.  The non-nanking dishes lacked flavor.  There was a time 15 years ago I enjoyed this place.  My last 2 visits over the past 3 months - I gave it a 2nd chance in case other visit was an off day -  will be my last.  Customer service has always been non-existent.  There was a time that was funny to locals.  It isn't any longer.  When your food is this bad you better kiss the ring on customer service.  Yet arrogant and rude customer service remains the norm.  This place should close down.
author: Bryan V.

description: Kinda like Panda Express. The food isn't traditional and doesn't have anything special about it. Service is super quick. Very loud and crowded. You're better off trying something else...
author: Peanuts M.

description: Thank you for getting back to me so quickly I really appreciate you taking the time to look at your reviews yes our second visit was on December 31st
author: Rodney S.

description: Got the tower crispy noodle with fish and it was terrible.  Just hard crispy noodles with teriyaki sauce.  The wonton soup was like porridge soup with crunchy rice also not great.  We were squished between people.  Service was the only thing that was good.  We got our food quick.  Ambience not great.  People next to us likes the sesame chicken.
author: Shazia M.

description: This place is litty af. 74/74 would eat again. Chill. Had light lemonade though. Was okay but not good.  House noodles were on point.  Doesn't really like crispy noodle tower.
author: Daniel T.

description: This is a wonderful full of flavor restaurant, I highly recommend it. If your in town (San Francisco) this is a must!!! Great service, excellent tea and fresh food.
author: Nancy F.

description: Went there after seeing 2700+ reviews. Food was good. We went in a group and ordered quite a lot of items. After paying bills later I realized they charged $16 for a house fried rice(without chicken it's 8.95 on their menu). I asked them to add chicken and there were around 7-8 pieces of chicken. I mean how can someone charge $32 for two plates of fried rice?? That's outrageous. My husband n friend had prawns n mushrooms and fried noodles with chicken for 14.95. I just don't see any reason for charging so much for a fried rice. Usually restaurant charges 1-4 dollars extra for chicken or any other meat but $7 is way too much. They should have mention prices on their menu. Highly disappointed.
author: Piyali V.

description:
My wife and I were hugely disappointed with our meal last night. We were careful to read a good quantity of recent Yelp reviews and foolishly overlooked the negative ones. Unfortunately, those were most in line with our experience. Crispy Pork Potstickers: these were over-fried and served covered in a thick brown sauce. Dough was too thick and almost crunchy. Sauce overwhelmed everything. I can honestly say this is the first order of potstickers I've ordered anywhere that I was not able to finish. Fried Onion Cake: same heavy dough as the potstickers, same brown sauce on top. I wish the server would have told us these would taste so similar. Could not finish. Salt and Pepper Shrimp with Mushrooms: this was OK. Nothing spectacular. Sesame Chicken: heavily fried, thick and cloying. On a positive note, I heard the couple beside us say the fried calamari was the best they had ever had.
Wish I had ordered that. Check please.
author: Rob J.

description:
I get that this is China Town and you have to cater to both tourists and locals, but do you need to discriminate against people? Why do you have to distinctly separate menus, one for Chinese and one for everyone else?  

Apart from the bias, the "other" menu items were what you would expect: noodles, rice, chicken and pork dishes. 

We opted for the House Noodles and 5 Spice Pork Chops. We started with the pot stickers. 

The pot stickers were very good and I wish I would have stopped there. The pork chops were tiny, thin and dry, though the sauce on top was good. The major disappointment was with the noodles. If these are your house noodles, why do they taste like Pasta-Roni Fettuccine Alfredo? I don't even know how that's possible, but that's what it tasted like.  

Maybe their Chinese only menu has hidden secrets that are authentic and delicious, but since Im not Chinese, I'll never know.
author: Joseph F.

description: Good food. Onion pancake is a must. Chow mein was alright. Tofu Bao Bin Wrap was delicious.
author: Ash M.

description:
What a yummy place to eat!
Ive been coming here for years.
My parents would bring me here on our visits to the
Bay when I was growing up and it always seemed 
a little bit magical. The chicken rice soup is one
of the most delicious dishes Ive ever had.
author: Amanda B.

description:
A San Francisco classic! Can't believe I haven't yet reviewed House of Nanking.

Here's the quick 'n' dirty version of what you need to know (in no particular order):
+ Gotta try the calamari as well as the sesame chicken with sweet potatoes
+ If you are a tea lover, order the blooming mug of tea. It expands right in front of you!
+ Sure, you can eat with chopsticks, but they'll default with a fork, which is fine by me.
+ Service is nice enough, not the friendliest, but they make sure you order plenty of food and get it fast.
+ They now accept credit cards, so no worries about hitting up the ATM before your visit!
+ If you go right at noon, there isn't a long line out the door to score a table.

Great spot to take out of town guests who want the real SF experience. It's nothing fancy, but the food is crazy good!
author: Abby S.

description:
Date of visit: 8/13/2017 at 11 AM 

This place gets a lot of traction so I thought I'd try it out. I have had a lot of Chinese food in my life and I don't think it's that good. We stood in line before they opened, and I had high hopes.

We ordered the house fried rice and house noodles and they were both okay. Nothing special. The calamari (HIGHLY RECOMMENDED, according to them) was NOTHING special. It was fried, and no sauce, so I'm not sure what's so special about it. 

The worst part of the experience was the service. It place looked dirty, our server was eating and shoving noodles in her mouth in front of us like she hasn't eating in years. No one speak English. They have poor manners. Yuck! 

I definitely won't be back!

Kathy, the date of the visit was 8/13/2016, I was standing in line before you even opened. The food was okay, but the service was unacceptable!
author: Casey M.

description:
This place was highly recommended by a local SF native as the place to try the Chinatown food experience without breaking the bank. 

Atmosphere:  
This place is busy.  There was a line that formed shortly after we sat down, so it's clearly popular.  Like most places in downtown San Francisco, it looks like it's been there fifty years or longer, and has the classic dark lacquered wood furniture and walls.  The seating is packed together tightly and, while there are silk flowers in vases that haven't been dusted in a while, there is nothing of note that stands out about the decor otherwise. 

Service:  
Wow.  The service here takes some getting used to.  If, as others have noted, it is the standard for restaurants in Chinatown to get you in an out while addressing you as little as possible, then this restaurant definitely met that standard.  The total conversation from the server from start to finish was as follows:
"Two?"  Flopped two menus on the table with a loud slap.
"What do you want?"  Orders taken.  Food later placed quickly on table.
"Your check".  Flopped check tray on table.  
I understand we were not regulars, and we were not friends with anyone there, but this made me smile.  I hadn't seen interaction this efficient in a place without a kiosk.  In other words, don't come here to commiserate on the human experience, or to connect with your fellow humans in the Chinese Restaurant industry. 
  
Food:  
The food was good.  Not great, but good.  The menu looked unusual and had many what seemed like great choices.  I had the wonton soup, which was huge, and a shrimp dish, which was good.  Not great.  Which overall sums up my experience at this very popular restaurant.
author: Robert M.

description:
Had lowly salt and pepper shrimp with mushrooms.  Not greasy which is great but not review worthy. Flower blossom tea is over priced for an old chrysanthemum floating around in a beer mug. Boiling hot tea certainly nuked contents. Not sure if waiter was rude and surly for tourists or if that's just who he is. 
People next to me never got their appetizer. I paid with a $20 + 5. I Never got my change. They Presumed change was all for them? Which it was but  $1 was real value of service.
Only went there because all other restaurants in Jackson Kearney area had lines at lunch hour
author: Dan A.

description:
Waitress #1 walks by: "Are you chinese?"
Us: "no" 

Waitress #2 walks by: "Are you chinese?"
Us: "NO"

Waitress #1 comes to take order: "What do you want?"
Us: "Can we get the number..."

Chinese customer walks in and speak chinese
Waitress #1 turns and speaks to them.
Us: "Yeah can we get the number..."

Waitress #1: "WAIT."
Us: "What?"

Waitress #1: "You Wait"
Waitress starts talking to chinese customer and ignoring us mid order.
Chinese customer puts a pad of paper on our table

My friend looks at me: "W. T. F. ?"

Us: "Can I get this 'amazing flavor' calamari - 'highly recommend' ?"

Sometime later...

Calamari comes out. 

The calamari is in on a blanket of milk like broth. I prod the calamari with a fork.
It was soggy and soft. The calamari was the blandest and worst calamari I had in my life. 
"Amazing flavor". "Highly recommended". 

My friend's pork ribs arrives.
He looks at me, again. Pissed off.

The bill comes out, and it's $40.
My friend looks even more pissed.

The restaurant was crowded.
I give up on San Francisco.
author: Tuan V.

description: Whether you are a tourist or a local, House of Nanking is a great place for a filling meal. They get pretty busy at peak time, there is usually a line out the door. Tables can get pretty cramped because they have communal seating. Sesame chicken tastes great, sweet and made with white meat chicken. My favorite part of the sesame chicken is the sweet potatoes that they are served with. Sesame chicken is an entree meant to be shared, so don't order it solo. Also ordered shrimp packets served with a peanut sauce and the wontons with chili oil. All the food was great and served hot and fresh.
author: Daryll G.

description:
This breaks my heart! I have such fond memories of eating here! I LOVED this place in college and was so excited to come back. Sadly, the once amazing food, is now nothing special. Just meh. Chicken chow mein had completely over cooked, rubbery chicken. Sesame chicken was ok, but not the Nanking chicken that was to die for. 
The food for the price is still good, but the food I would drive from Berkeley to get take out, or make detour to the city on every trip is now gone.
author: Kat M.

description:
I've been here several times with my husband since 2010. Food was decent, and service was ok. 
We and our guest went there 3 days ago, i don't know... the quality wasn't good, and meat was too salty and  way small.. maybe over seasoned..? A kid couldn't eat them at all, so she just had only white rice. 
We  left lots of food, and just headed a boba milk tea shop instead... we were so disappointed. I don't think we will go there again.
author: Sun-a Y.

description: This place was fun and the food was good. I especially liked the mouth watering calamari.
author: William W.

description:
There service here was rapid fire - get used to it, because the food is absolutely worth it. Solid entree choices for both me and a vegetarian friend and the prices were quite fair as well.

Definitely a tourist-trap on the edge of Chinatown, so keep that in mind, but the because of the service the line will move a lot faster than you think!
author: Rotimi O.

description: This place must have turned into a business factory. The food is not bad but nothing incredible neither. The quantities are kind of small, specially for what you expect from a Chinese restaurant. But the worst is probably the service. The waitress treats you like the living wallet you are and have then the indecency to write herself the tip. I'll never come back there for sure and recommend to anyone to avoid such a bad place while Chinatown is already full of other marvels in matter of eating.
author: X L.

description: I came here for lunch on Sunday for the first time with two family members visiting from out of town. I don't know what took me so long to get here! I've been living in this city for nearly 10 years. We enjoyed everything we ate. It was warm outside so we didn't order a ton of food. I loved the cool noodles with sesame sauce, the onion cake and pork dumplings. I even enjoyed the leftovers that I brought in for lunch today :) I definitely want to go back and try the blossom tea and the beef with crispy noodles.   We arrived right around the time the restaurant opened for Sunday lunch and within 30minutes, the place was packed.  Either stop by early or on off hours or you can expect a little bit of a wait.  However, the service is fast and friendly so you probably won't have to wait too long. I will be back for more yummy food soon!
author: Theresa A.

description: I'm just saying that I'm not really digging this place.  Every dish came out salty for me.  My fried dumplings came out with hot shell but luke warm filling in peanut sauce.  We were rushed rushed in and rushed rushed out, or at least felt that way.  We ordered the famous sesame chicken, which tasted salty, and couldn't understand why it's so famous.  The fried potato they came with it was good. Also ate salt shrimp with mushroom and green pea salad.  All salty.  We ended up at the restaurant next door called House of Xian Dumplings for dumplings and beef braised noodles, and that was 4 stars.
author: Paul L.

description: The food here is delicious and flavorful. It gets super busy so don't expect you'll get attentive service . And it's very loud In here . the food I give a 5 the service a 2/3 but the food was so good it swayed me to still give 4 stars . It doesn't taste like other Chinese food in area. Delicious!
author: Mariangeles C.

description: Be prepared to be rushed to order, eat, and pay the bill. Okay food. The main concern is how rushed you feel when you're there. Towards the end, we felt like they were going to escort us out, they were in such a hurry, and it wasn't even busy. Not going back.
author: R J.

description:
The food was just okay. Nothing to write home about. The sesame chicken was overfried and sweet, the potstickers were nice and the fried rice was meh. 

The service was not good. We walked in and she asked how many we were and when I said 3 adults and 2 kids, she directed is to a table and then said you're 5. Um ... yes, I said that. There were tree ladies who kept repeating why would you say 2, say 5... and then more inside talking. We were right there, so it was kinda rude and odd. In general, it wasn't good service. 

Wouldn't recommend it. There are so many options in China town would explore it for better options.
author: Wildeflower M.

description: I bring out-of-towners here whenever I can, and let the staff suggest the meals, it never fails. My wife can't have gluten and the last time we were there the staff brought us things we never suspected we could have ordered -- I hadn't seen her that happy at a restaurant in a really long time!
author: Jesse G.

description:
I'm not sure of what to make of this place but I was not impressed! I remember when my aunt lived and worked here as an consultant, she said this place was amazing.

This place is not kid friendly and most of all DIRTY looking. A waitress (not ours) was blowing her nose in front of me. I was scared to go to the bathroom but it turned out to be not too bad. It had a cute little bowl sink and a weird mirror.

The waiter wanted to order for us but I decided to pick our own items: the signature sesame chicken, eggplant, and sizzling rice soup with tofu but you could pick other proteins. The rice is 75 cents per person. 

The eggplant tasted just like the sesame chicken, same flavor/sauce, which was fine but overpriced for what it was. I thought it was $5.95 but it was $9.95 and there was one for $6.95 so I guess they automatically give you the bigger size. The sesame chicken was also $9.95, same size serving as the eggplant. It had slices of fried sweet potato and slices of a vegetable that was the texture of green tomato and a cucumber. The sizzling rice (another signature item) was interesting: it had fresh peas, zucchini, red basil, rice, coconut milk, tofu and a little heat which tickled my throat. It actually tasted healthy and flavorful. 

I saw a lot of other things people ordered that looked interesting but if I had to choose again, I'd rather go to R&G lounge a block away which is expensive but amazing...
author: Christina W.

description: The first place my husband and I stopped upon our arrival to San Francisco before checking into our hotel.  Love this place.
author: Lynette J.

description: Went to the house of Nanking 10 years ago with our family of 15 and we were blown away. I have been thinking about the bok choy since the time I had it. It is still an outstanding restaurant and the bok choy did not disappoint. Enjoyed the steamed pork dumplings as well.
author: Laura R.

description: We were told there is usually a line so we arrived 5 min before noon and were in the front with our family. As someone else has said - its a hustling and bustling business.  They seat you and you need to get busy looking at the menu to decide. We ordered the hot tea and a variety of dishes and appetizers.  - the tea was a work of art (I'd heard of flower tea but had never seen it).  The food was really good and everything tasted so distinctive and different.  I will be spoiled now from the usually Chinese places in my small town area.  I had no comparison before.  I didn't rate it a 5 star because it is noisy and crowded.  but - its all about the food!
author: Kat V.

description: Wow, mind blown, food comes out instantaneously. It's gone just as quick as it comes but boy was it delicious. Will be coming back time and time again.
author: Logan A.

description: Sesame chicken was delicious! Food took a little time to come out but otherwise service was prompt. Enjoyable atmosphere and affordable price.
author: Matthew E.

description:
HoN is an old-school Chinatown restaurant; dingy interior, 1960s-era furniture, prompt service and good food. Not great, but good. Unfortunately the dishes are not always prepared in the same way: there are times when a particular item is amazing, order the same thing on a different day and it is merely OK. 

Don't dawdle, this isn't a place to leisurely peruse the menu. Be greeted, be seated, and order your food -- that's the best practice here. Have been here several times for lunch and the place is always bustling. I've always ordered from the menu, but those who let the owner choose for them are satisfied.

The celebrated onion pancake was a one-time experience for me; none of those at my table thought it was anything special: just ... onions.
author: Deborah G.

description:
The place is very dirty. You can easily spot food residues smashed on the sides of the tables that have been there quite a while. Add chewing gums stuck to the walls and dirty cutlery to complete the picture.
Overpriced for the food and service quality.
The apple shrimps were the low point of the experience for us. Presentation was horrible and taste was almost as bad.
author: Carlo N.

description: Holy cow...SO GOOD!  The sesame chicken is out of this world!  As are the house noodles and the onion cake appetizer.
author: David F.

description: This is by far hands down the best Chinese food  ever in San Francisco . When you go with a big group just let Peter Fang know to take care of ordering for you. Unbelievable.....
author: T B.

description:
Fairly good restaurant, it's a good place if you're into the whole westernized Chinese thing--it's pretty much like PF chang's. As a vegetarian, I was able to get some fresh green beans that were not overly seasoned like other Chinese restaurants. My family really liked the beef-quite different than the typical we get in the midwest. Very tender.

Perhaps the biggest downside: portions are pretty small for the price.
author: Mendi C.

description:
Authentic chinglish Chinese food here!  The chefs create "Chef Specialties" rather than authentic Chinese food. (Thank God! spoken from someone who has visited China and Hong King twice this year!) Their menu is easy for we Americans to understand and gives nice twists on the typical Chinese/American menu. The dumplings and Nanking Chicken are to die for!

Get there early! As a line normally forms well before they open their doors and the tables fill up fast! Check the hours of operation as they do close between Lunch and Dinner services! There is definitely a hustle and bustle to the service. Not great and you may share a table with a few people. They definitely cram them in! It all adds to the experience so if you aren't into sharing this place may not be for you!  The portions are so large sometimes the "sharing" carries over to your food as well! Its all good fun and on my go-to list every time i visit my favorite city: )
author: Elayne L.

description: The food here really is pretty good. If the rating was for the food alone, I'd probably give it a 3 (or even a 3.5 for the squid). I've rated it so low, though, because everything else is plain awful: The service is unbelievably rude and offhanded, diners are packed in like sardines, the place is dirty and rundown, and the prices, taking everything into account, are too high. Oh, and if you tip less than they think they deserve, you'll get into trouble! They apparently think it's acceptable to treat their customers like an unwanted inconvenience. Never again.
author: Chris T.

description: I used to come here in 90s and early 2000s way before the emergence of Yelp and popularity of internet, I came here for the first time today after years and quickly found out that the food taste and quality are not the same as it used to be. Fast service, alright food. I guess that's it for me.
author: Z H.

description: To me the food was not great, not even good. I was riding by on my tour bus and saw this place, it was crowded. I hopped off my bus and had my family to meet at Nanking.  What a disappointment.  The only thing good was the sesame chicken.  The food was tasteless and frankly it all looked scary as did the restaurant. It was served as though they just slung some food on a plate and said here you go. I am in Chinatown and got the worst Chinese food ever!
author: G W.

description: Be ready to get seated and get your food super fast. Everything we had was amazing! Green beans, veggie dumplings, house noodles, FRIED CALAMARI was incredible, pork egg rolls. Loved everything!
author: Sarah R.

description:
I had very high expectations for House of Nanking after all the talk behind it. I started with the hot and sour soup which was absolutely decadent. This is by far the best hot and sour soup that I've ever had. Also, the most unique. Very obvious that it's made fresh, daily. 

For my entree, I ordered a simple Chinese dish. Sautéed chicken with broccoli. I was extremely disappointed in the sauce this dish was cooked in. The chicken used for the dish was chicken thigh. This is uncommon for this type of dish and I'm sure they do this for two different reasons. 1. Chicken thigh is generally more tender. 2. Much less expensive alternative to using all white chicken breast. The chicken was just ok. The sauce was the big disappointment. Sent me running to the toilet. No Bueno. 

House of Nanking is known for the Sesame Chicken and this would have probably been the safe order, however I steer clear of fried food at all costs. If you like fried food and sesame chicken you may have a better experience. Nonetheless, be sure to order the hot and sour soup!
author: Chris B.

description:
We were doing the bus tour and when we reached close to this place the guide mentioned this place and said it is must have for any food lover. But he also warned about the service. So we were sort of mentally prepared. 
As hungry we were, we went to the restaurant around 5 and were readily seated. The place is simple and reminded of roadside restaurants in India. Nothing flashy and so is their service. and you know what, I like it. Its a place where you go, eat good food and get out. The service style infact adds to the authenticity in a good way. 

I wanted to have something spicy in chicken and I asked the owner if they have something nd she told me that she will make something special for me and actually the dish turned out to be very tasty and i dont think it was on the menu. So it goes to show that they care for customers and will be happy to adjust to the demands. 

This place is a must visit if you like Chinese food.
author: Mohit M.

description: Caution for Chinese foodies. Food here isn't authentic in any acceptable Chinese standard. The noodle we ordered is Lee's deli quality, the wonton is tasteless although they claim it's made fresh. The beef is so salty and over marinated that had a hard time finishing.
author: Kris Z.

description:
So this is how our meal starts at House of Nanking...

Our waitress approaches our table and tells us that since this is our first visit to House of Nanking we do not know what to order.  She takes the menus from our hands before we can argue and she tells us not to worry; she will bring us food and we will like it... Wait, what?!?!?! 

At this point my in-laws are weirded out, but I tell them that we should trust the waitress to bring us a good meal.  We were not disappointed.  This was the best Chinese meal ever!!!  I cannot tell you the names of the dishes we had, but it was the most incredible meal!

We started off our meal with a portabella mushroom and shrimp appetizer.  I don't like mushrooms so this was not the highlight of the meal for me, but everyone else at our table loved the dish.  Our next course was a delicious wonton soup with an interesting twist of rice and coconut milk broth.  Our third course was fried sesame chicken - wow!  At this point I would have been satisfied, but there were more delicious dishes to be sampled.  Our fourth course was a beef and scallion dish that was so tender that the meat fell apart like pot roast.  When I thought I could not eat another bite our waitress brought us a lightly breaded white fish dish paired with spinach and a divine sweet and sour sauce.

Apparently this restaurant draws in quite the crowds, but we were lucky and snagged the last table during lunch.  Next time a waitress tells me to "sit down and shut up" I will gladly do so!
author: Michelle M.

description:
If you're looking for a true Chinese authentic experience you should come try and do this great simple place.
No parking unless you have a bike.
author: Oren G.

description:
Great tasting food. Spices and flavor are sooo good. No reservations so you have to get there and wait if there's a line. WORTH IT. 

Old school furniture. Duct tape holding chairs together. 

Quick food prep because they want to move people through the restaurant.
author: Dave Q.

description:
Recently wandering in Chinatown after an appointment downtown, per chance, I happened upon the storied Nanking House that Kearny built.  Around mid-afternoon, the restaurant was empty, and I realized the opportunity that had presented itself. Most of the time I've passed by, there has been a line outside the door. I'd never brave that line, and certainly not by myself when I'd only be able to sample one dish. To make matters more challenging, the restaurant closes early, at 9p (which is odd being so close to the bustle of Columbus Avenue). 

I had heard many things about the House of Nanking. Among them and most notably, the servers allegedly will bring off-menu dishes to the table once dietary preferences and budget are disclosed. I'm vegetarian, so upon sitting down, refusing a menu, I asked my server to bring me a something vegetarian and spicy. She looked at me as if I were - excuse the expression - speaking Chinese. She had no idea what I meant or what I wanted.  Instead, she turned over the menu, pointed to a section, and said, "These are all vegetarian dishes" and left.  When she came back, I further probed and asked what she might recommend or if the kitchen could create something. Nope. The handful of vegetarian dishes on offer all sounded pedestrian and uninspired, none of which was spicy. I once again tried to explain what I had understood to be the strength of the Nanking experience, but she didn't seem to care. So, I gave up. In the process, however, I discovered that all of the soup broths are vegetarian, even the wonton soup (but the wontons have pork), and that none of the vegetarian items has oyster sauce. There are no vegetarian potstickers, but there are veg egg rolls. Notably, few of the traditional favorites of Chinese staple -- such as Kung Pao, General Tso's Chicken, Mongolian Chicken/Beef -- were on this menu. Nothing was spicy.

I started with the Hot & Sour soup. Not great. I appreciated that the soup came out hot (as in temperature), as soup should but often does not. I could see wafts of steam emit from the bowl, but the flavor was neither hot nor sour. Lots of drizzled egg - definitely not vegan - but no julienned vegetables or mushrooms to which I'm accustomed. It wasn't bad, but this is not the flavor profile that would inspire me to re-order in the future.

For my entree, I had asked a different server, if I could have the Sesame Chicken (EVERYONE around me ordered it and raved) but with tofu instead. The man refused, shaking his head. Then I asked him about some of the veg entrees on offer. Are there vegetables in the tofu dish? Was the mushroom dish deep fried or stir fried?  He walked away, uninterested. On this particular day, the indifference of the staff is not something that engendered affection. Had my mood been different, I may have chalked it up to "Chinatown" charm - like a Jewish deli in NY in which the snarly responses are part of the ambiance - but even in the hustle and bustle of delicatessens in Manhattan, there is a sense that the indifference is part of the gestalt. Here, I felt like the man couldn't be bothered. I thought at that point of just paying the bill and leaving, but I really wanted to sample an offering from the Nanking Province of SF, as it was unlikely that I'd be coming back anytime soon. So I asked him if the Salt & Pepper Mushroom dish had a sauce. He answered, "Deep Fried" (which it wasn't), and walked away. He understood English, proved moments later when I told him that I'd just go with the Salt & Pepper Mushrooms. His response? "No cancellations." Not endearing.

The mushroom dish was in the range of decent to good, but ultimately boring and uninspired as I had feared. This was literally a plate of small button mushrooms in a brown sauce with fried basil (nice touch), not a mixture of different varietals of mushrooms. The sauce had flavor - the menu said that all sauces were original creations of the Chef/Owner Peter Fang - and I appreciated that, but it would have been more tolerable as a side dish or something shared. On the plus side, the food was cooked super quick, arrived hot, and did not appear to contain MSG.

Based on my experience, I can't recommend House of Nanking, but I also can't not recommend it. I won't go back - it's not practical - though my one experience didn't leave me enthralled: I didn't get much help from the staff; I wasn't impressed with the service; and I couldn't order off-menu, which other reviewers claimed to have done. Finally, while I appreciate Mr. Fang's consideration of vegetarians, the menu shows little creativity. Omnivores, however, appeared happy with their Sesame Chicken (and House Noodles), and that was mostly what everyone else ate.

All in all, the food was a serviceable 3-stars.
Service was a weak 2 stars.
author: SalsaBoy S.

description: We are from out town and after seeing people lining up and glancing at the reviews on yelp, we decided to give this place a try. Overall, the food is good. Fresh and tasty. They would have earned an easy five from me had it not been for their famed sesame chicken, which for us turned out to be a pile of seasoned batter with no traces of chicken. So I read it is delish but unfortunately I can't comment on it because I never got to taste it. But what I can comment on is their dubious business practice: How can you call a dish sesame chicken and forget to include chicken? That is wrong. I get that you are busy and you can accidentally let a bad one, or even three, slip, but when you have multiple customers complaining about the same issue -we now realize that this had happened to many others- and still neglect to address the problem, then we are speaking of something else. Please fix!
author: Laura L.

description: This is he worst restaurant I've been lately. Pls don't waste your money coz food is not legit Chinese food and service is terrible. There were bunch of Cantonese waiters there making fake Chinese food. Highly dis-recommended!!!
author: Qianqian J.

description:
My friends really built this place up, so I went there last week and got the Sesame Chicken and my wife got Mushrooms with pork.  It really did live up to the hype.  

Usually, when I get sweet and sour chicken or general's chicken, the breading is too crispy and thick.  The breading was cooked just right, but the sauce is the main thing I loved.

It's a bit crammed in there, but I liked the mood of the place. Give it a try.
author: Matt H.

description: This is a great spot! Love the "family style" seating. They pack them in. We had the wontons, the shrimp cakes, the peanut sauce was a bit spicy for the kids but tasty. The sesame chicken was a hit with all of us. The service was excellent and everyone is friendly. The kids loved the house noodles and chow mein. A great spot to check out if you are visiting the area. Portions were just right for our group of 2 adults and 2 kids. Ice tea wasn't the best, it was sour, and soda comes in a can.
author: Jennifer O.

description: The food was okay. Nothing amazing. My biggest complaint, was there customer service. The waiter had given us our checks when we just started to eat. We felt rushed, so we then payed. After we received our change back, the waiter was hovering us saying "tip not included" and wouldn't leave us alone. Mind that we just started eating, so we didn't intend on tipping until we left. He kept demanding a certain amount of tip price while we were eating, and it was making us uncomfortable and started to get annoying. So we tipped and left.
author: Natalie N.

description: I was so hyped about this place, everyone in the city raves about this place. We got there no line but we were sat next to another family literally in the same table. Kinda weird. Food was so flavorful but unfortunately was a tad bit salty. If it wouldn't have been for the salt it would have been awesome.
author: Evelyn L.

description: The food was definitely worth the wait and breathing on complete strangers. Every time I visit San Francisco I come here.
author: Claudia C.

description:
Saw all of the Zagat ratings and other accolades posted all over the front door so I figured it must be decent. Was some of the worst Chinese food I've ever had the displeasure of eating. 

Maybe they had an off day because I dined before the Chinese New Years Parade started and the place was packed. You'd think though that they'd put their best foot forward instead of their worst. The house fried rice was a soggy mound with some cabbage slices, fried egg, and almost undiscernable bits of zucchini.  The calamari was bland and unappetizing to look at.  

The first 2 dishes were on our table in under 10 minutes.  Then we patiently sat waiting for the scallop dish to show up.  A waitress came by after we'd been waiting for about 15 minutes and said "Are you waiting for something?".   She probably thought we were just sitting there taking up space.  My response was "Yes. The rest of my order."  I was so irritated that they obviously forgot the order of scallops and disappointed with the lackluster food that I told her to cancel it.  She tried to tell us it was "on the way out".   Code for we are going to start cooking it now. 

Spent $40 on two sad representations of Chinese cuisine.  I don't care how many accolades you post.  Never again.
author: Maxx W.

description:
We were not going to leave San Francisco without trying their chinese food, I mean, I feel like it is a must. After walking around, we decided to try House of Nanking after noticing its huge line the night before and the rave reviews that it was given. 

We started out with the vegetable dumplings, which were very good and fresh tasting. For lunch, we ordered the Nanking chicken and the Mongolian beef. The chicken was good, but was heavily fried to the point where parts had more fried coating than actual chicken. Overall, it was nothing to rave about. Just average chinese food. The Mongolian beef itself was not very good, it had a taste I really just didn't like (and I really wanted to like it). The rice was good, and the vegetables fine as well, but overall it was nothing special. 

The service was fine, and the food quick. However, I was a bit disappointed in the actual food, considering the great reviews and remarks that it got.
author: Abby C.

description: Let me start this out with a positive. The chicken, contained in the dish I ordered, sesame chicken, a speciality of the house, was very tasty.  BUT...I did not expect half of the portion to be sliced sweet potatoes, with the chicken on layered on top, which gives the impression of a large serving.  I also did not expect to pay $4 for hot tea, served in a large beer stein.  I have never paid more than a buck or two for a pot of hot tea in a Chinese restaurant. In summary, the actual entree portion was about the size of a lunch special portion at another restaurant(which would have cost half the price). San Francisco demographics are changing, perhaps things are this way because people are unaware of what restaurant food costs elsewhere? Twenty dollars for one padded entree, a small bowl of rice and a giant glass of hot tea(which is an unruly portion. I suggest going elsewhere unless you have a large wallet. Good, sensibly priced Chinese food is not scarce in SF.
author: Allan F.

description: Best hole in the wall Chinese I've ever had. Chicken dumplings, nanking chicken and crispy shrimp are all must haves. Easiest is to tell your server what you do and don't eat, and then let them bring you dishes!
author: Kim D.

description:
I can't quite place my finger on what makes this place works.... somehow, it just does! This is like your typical Chinese food restaurant - loud, squeezy and long waiting line (no reservations) outside. However, it is also dimly lit and has a semblance of an asian fusion restaurant, I guess to cater to a more caucasian crowd?

Being Asian, I spoke to the lady boss in mandarin, and she showed me a special menu (written in Chinese) which I presume is reserved for Asian customers. She also immediately made recommendations on what to order, even going so far to telling us not to order a certain dish since it was "not good" and more catered to a Western palate. In the end, she ended up making all the orders for us since we were rather undecided. I must say, the food was really good and authentic Asian :)

The signature "Melt in your mouth calamari" is definitely the best dish, and really literally melts in your mouth. This is definitely a must order.

Everything else, just leave it to the lady boss to order for you and it'll most definitely be a hit. Just remember to speak in Mandarin, or bring a friend who can :)
author: Christina N.

description: Trying to understand if the calamari is real? There are no tentacles. Is this imitation calamari? Google "This American Life Artificial Calamari" for more details.
author: David A.

description: If i could give this place zero stars, I would. Great food but terrible service. Extremely rude and do not assist well. They force you to tip and wait until u hand them something, as if it is was obligated. And If not, they make a scene. Ridiculous and incredibly unprofessional. Would not go again.
author: Lizeth C.

description: Haven't ate yet but the service sucks. The lady doesn't acknowledge you. The cups are ugly I gave three stars before I ate just cuz of service then after the review it got worse and the severs were more and more rude. They did not talk to you they just run. I get better service at fast food. (I'm not a crazy person I own a restaurant.) this was just bad. I hope you take this review and solve this issue
author: Nathan S.

description: Not impressed; the fried rice was the worst I ever had. It was very bland, the chicken was super burnt without any meat. I'm disappointed in all the high ratings this place has. Don't waste your time!
author: Lauren S.

description:
In the heart of Chinatown, this place definitely has culture. The food is incredible but very rich. I especially loved their Onion Cakes with peanut sauce, Sesame Chicken, and Chow Mein. Their Salt and Pepper shrimp was mediocre. 

I will definitely be back - great prices, quick service, and amazing food!
author: Erica C.

description: Omg the food is amazing! Don't think I've had better Chinese food before. Parking is a tad scarse so I'd take a cab. Don't expect 5 star service - this place is about food not pampering patrons with niceties.
author: Eugene R.

description: Warning: bao bing wrap comes with tortillas not Chinese pancakes as described on the menu. Fri Sept 2, 2016.
author: Jessica O.

description:
Service was fine.... ordered chicken chow mien .

Chicken was cooked separately , not rested and dry.

The chow mien smelled like soy sauce and was a little too sweet.

Might try them one more time with a different dish but not super impressed so far.
author: Ricky y.

description:
This dump is so over rated! 
The potstickers were old, hard and awful 
The sesame chicken was adequate however the waitress and entire staff could care less if you enjoyed your food or not. Also my father once said if the bathroom is dirty you know what the kitchen looks like - well the bathroom was pitiful and the place is filthy 
I read good reviews so we walked a long distance to find it and we Do not recommend this restaurant at all!! It's also curious that there were no Asians eating there only tourists !!!
author: Janice P.

description: As many others have noted, the food is amazing, especially for vegetarian options, the service is charmingly abrupt, and the lines can be long. This is not a place to linger over the menu.  Your best bet is to tell the waiter generally what you want and let them recommend something.  The service is fast, and the food delicious.  Don't plan to have a long, leisurely meal.  The pace is brisk, and you'll likely be in and out in under an hour. But the prices are very reasonable, and this is about the best Chinese food I have ever jad.
author: Phil B.

description:
Ok,  a a person of color who grew up in the San Gabriel Valley (626!), I know good Asian food. Hell , , I just about have my honorary Asian card. This was by far some of the WORST Chinese food I've ever had.  

Flavorless.  

No soy sauce.  

And they gave everyone FORKS. FORKS!!!! 

WTF??

It felt like I walked into a Chinese restaurant in Dublin,  and the Irish are not known for their cuisine,  lol. How un-diverse can a restaurant  be in SF (although most patrons seemed like tourists) ???  My coworker swore up and down about trying this place, and the Yelp reviews seemed convincing... 

.... wrong WRONG WROOOOONG!!! Ugh,  get this taste outta my mouth...
author: Lili X.

description: I'm an American who's lived in China for 8 years and I love Chinese food dearly. This place is not authentic Chinese at all. They don't even have cooked vegetables, which is a staple at every single meal in China: no 芥兰，no 菜心, no broccoli, no cabbage, NOTHING. And the "Famous Nanking Chicken" is just deep fried, boneless chicken pieces, drenched in sweet and sour sauce. Might as well go to KFC and save your money. I'm sorely disappointed by SF's Chinese food. Maybe try Great Eastern Restaurant instead.
author: Brian D.

description: This place has been around for a long time making a lot of $$ because of the flavors in their food.  I just don't understand why, after all of the feedback about the negative aspects of cleanliness, service, etc. they don't bother improving in the areas where they have problems.  Maybe it's their way of curbing demand?  Can't they just improve their bathroom and keep it clean, get some new glasses (plastic is okay, but old foggy, stratched plastic not too appetizing) - maybe even a minor upgrade in furniture - like I said they've made a bundle, they could spend some on improvement.  And the staff attitude, I guess they keep that up for entertainment. Just saying...
author: Nancy T.

description: Food was tasty. Would eat here again. Crispy Beef (not on menu) is delicious and the beef quality is outstanding. It has light curry on it.
author: Reesuk K.

description: My cousin was set on grabbing a meal in Chinatown during our recent trip to San Francisco. However, she left it up to me to find a place. Great. After much googling, I settled on House of Nanking. It was a good mix between price and cleanliness. Not the best service but they get you in and out. The sesame chicken is delish as is the fried rice. It sounds funny to say but the pork egg roll was very porky. Wouldn't recommend. It looks like the line can get fairly long but we barely had to wait for a table. They move people in and out.
author: Megan T.

description:
Be Warned: Food here are NOT clean, and they may use illegal seasonings or ingredients. 

Just be warned, you may get food poisoning or even worse if you eat here, plus their health score is so low - 77 out of 100


This review is an update towards House of Nanking's reply. 

I was very scared and concerned about this horrible food poisoning experience me and my friend had caused by your food. So while I was still in your restaurant, I asked at least 7 times, me, my friend and my BF who later picked me up, we all asked about what ingredients you used in our food. But the waitress (or owner), she seemed very very annoyed and scared to tell what was used in our dishes. 

We are 100% sure, there are something wrong with your food, and your food put our healthy in danger. Otherwise, why wound't you provide the ingredient info to us? If you are so confident about your kitchen being clean, food being the freshest, how come you got such a low healthy score - 77 out of 100?? How come your waitresses and owner seemed so suspicious when we asked about the ingredients in our food. We couldn't even get a chance to take a sample of what we ate, all the food were taken away so quickly after we told them we weren't feeling well.  

How big is the chance that you discover you are allergic to the same food with your friend while having dinner together, after having hundreds of meals together as friends for over 4 years? You must had weird seasonings and ingredients put in our dishes. Also your waitresses had no shame about charging us after I got faint and almost went to the emergency room. Oh WOW, this is how your restaurant is. Dangerous food with awful services. 

If I could think straight, and didn't feel that dizzy, that night would not end as me leaving without taking any actions towards your owner. I would've dig down to the truth.

You should be feeling fortunate, that this situation could've been worse. 

STOP SERVING DANGEROUS FOOD! This seriously could've been worse!!!
author: Josie Z.

description:
Every time I visit SanFran I eat at Nanking. 

Probably the best Chinese food ever!!! 

It is a causal no frills place. Great place to visit with friends. They have long tables so you can fit 10 people at most tables.
author: Trevor M.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, I really really did. I even came here multiple times in 1 week, bringing friends and family along, trying to figure out if it might be a better kind of Chinese food.  But it's really not that special. I will not ever understand why people wait in line to eat here. Sure the food is tasty. However, the portions are small, the prices are through the roof for this quality of food, and the staff are extremely abrupt & impolite.  Unless, they are using organic, pastures meats & organic produce they shouldn't be charging $14 a plate for fried chicken.  We came with 8 in our party. If you have a party of 6 or more, they add on a tip for you, already added onto your bill.  When we asked how much tip they added, our server told us it's 20%.  It was $4 over. Check it out for yourself in my photo.
The friends I brought here told me they won't be back because the quality of food is just not worth the price. I guess staff and owners here can just keep on being rude to customers, because they don't care since people keep on coming anyway.
I doubt I will be back. 

You guys still overcharged on the tip, and that's bad business -- for you.
author: Mary P.

description:
I honestly don't know why this place has gotten great reviews or has received awards. My experience here was just terrible! 

Service is horrible. They got short with me. Major attitude. The plates and cups were still wet. 

The food wasn't delicious. Some items were cold. Cold food with dingy, stuffy environment with people lined up through the restaurant really was not enjoyable. I also ordered a lot of food for me and my family, but we left not satisfied.

Very very disappointed. 

Hi there, thank you for reaching out. I'm actually from Los Angeles. I visited House of Nanking during my summer break. I probably won't be in town for another couple months. It is great to know my concerns were heard. :)
author: A S.

description:
Once you eat here, Chinese food will be ruined forever. It's that good! Every time I return to SF, I AM eating here.

1. The line is worth it.

2. Service is prompt, short and a bit unusual, but run with it. It's part of the experience.

3. What to order? We were three people.

- Sweet and sour soup with chicken. Amazing.
- Sesame chicken. Amazing.
- House noodles with beef. Fantastic.
- Honey garlic beef. OUT OF THIS WORLD.

The END.
author: Josh D.

description: We only told the waitress we wanted seafood.  She served a shrimp dish and fish dish. Both were delicious and they complemented one another perfectly. A first rate Chinatown feast.
author: Anna H.

description: They have an english menu and a Chinese menu. The waitress was quite impatient with getting the order done as soon as possible. The presentation of the sesame chicken was surprisingly well done. The thin slices of fried sweet potatoes were quite confusing to the tastebuds. There was too much sauce in the dish, leaving my mouth very sweet and salty after the meal. Perhaps I just ordered the wrong item.
author: James S.

description: Very good!  I'd recommend it and go there again on another trip to the Bay area.  :)
author: J A.

description: My girlfriend and I went here last night after our usual spot (Hunan Homes around the corner on Jackson) was too busy to seat us. I had always heard good things about House of Nanking all around the city. The service was awful, incredibly rude staff. The food was equally terrible. Our sesame chicken was mediocre (other than the bites I had to spit out because they had pieces of bone and tendon in them), our potstickers tasted like they were frozen and thawed, and our chow mein was disgusting. Save yourself the money and frustration, go to hunan homes around the corner, delicious food!
author: Curtis Reid H.

description:
Food:
-Sesame chicken with sweet potatoes, decent but I didn't find it too different from all the other sesame chicken I've had, my white friend thought it was crispier/better than most and I'll take his word because he's more of a fake asian food expert than I am
-Some beef dish from their chinese menu, this was amazing, beef chunks came with a sweet chinese jerky flavor (don't know how to explain this but the flavor was basically synonymous with "unique" and "spectacular")

Service:
-As non-mean as could be (chinese lady there actually smiled at me multiple times) at a hole-in-the-wall chinese restaurant, especially with their level of popularity

Tip:
-Speak chinese (or fake it non-obnoxiously to show effort) and get recommendations from their secret chinese menu
author: Tian Q.

description: Best Chinese food I've had in a long time. First time to this restaurant and we weren't sure which dishes to try so we asked our waiter if he would just bring us whatever was good. We had a severe peanut allergy in our group and he helped us steer clear of any peanuts. He brought honey shrimp entree and some type of egg rolls that were amazingly tasty! I would def return to this place!
author: Bevan J.

description:
Great food, but you need to get used to the service.
We had chicken in two different styles, beef and shrimps. Everything was very tasty. Shrimp and apple with mayonnaise was something different, but still good. 
The service however was a little weird. The waitress basically chose our food instead of letting us read the menu first. Everything seemed a little rushed.
author: Maurice H.

description:
Authenticity is not an issue for me if the food is good. Innovation should be celebrated as long as the new recipe is not far inferior to the original. Unfortunately in most cases the new is not nearly as good as the old.

House of Nanking is certainly an intriguing place. There is little doubt they cater mostly to non Chinese clientele. As soon as our server found out we could converse in Chinese, he immediately took away our English menus and handed us a 10-lines menu hand written only in traditional Chinese that no one in my party other than myself could read.

Good thing did come out of it. The fish soup on the secret menu was quite impressive. It was a whole fish (head, tail and fins and all) stewed with vermicelli noodles, fried tofu and wontons. The milky broth was a bit on the sweet side but flavorful.

Had the other dishes been as good as the soup this would probably be a more positive review. Stir fried dishes were regrettably predictable with overly sweet sauce soaked in a sea of grease. A lot of the ingredients were deep fried and then stir fried to achieve a good crispy texture. Not the healthiest way of cooking but sadly addicting. 

House of Nanking is interesting restaurant but it is also slightly over-hyped and over-priced. Americanized Chinese food at its best? I think not.
author: Mona W.

description:
My friends invited me here for dinner on a Saturday night and...
- we got seated as soon as we stepped in
- food came to us very quickly despite how fairly packed and busy the restaurant was experiencing
- sesame chicken and fried shrimp packet was bomb.  I love the sauce on the shrimp packet so much that I scraped it all onto my rice.   The pan-fried garlic fish was good but greasy and not much of a garlic flavor as expected.  The steamed veggie dumplings was also delicious. 
- authentic chinese or not, the food is still good. 
- yes, it's small inside and u may have to sit directly next to strangers but it's San Fran.  Space is a commodity. We're all here to eat. 


Not sure why the last several reviews were negative regarding food and service as I did not experience any bad service or food.   And no, I'm not chinese and neither are my friends who came with me.
author: Ava H.

description: We had really high hopes for this place.... But the staff was rude and the food was mediocre at best. We were craving Chinese food and ordered the Sesame Chicken, Fried Rice and Sizzling Rice Soup. The food was mehhhhhh- Basic, boring, and  fast food quality, not worth the wait or staff attitude. While we were eating the staff was busy sorting plates right next to us.. Which they were doing aggressively and loudly. I use to wait tables for 7 years and would never do side work next to a table, talk about a dining experience :/
author: Melanie R.
