To drink we had the detox tea, which is a delicious fruit-infused tea. I believe we spent in the $40 range for our meal. There seemed to be more meatless options, which is OK if that's your thing. All in all, I liked it. Not sure I'd return, since there are so many other options in the area.
author: April B.

description:
Sesame chicken, soup and the noodle are a must try! Will definitely come back! Yummy.... 

Just bear in mind that this place is a bit small for party more than 6ppl.
author: Joline K.

description:
Great place. Friends at work and family members suggested eating here, so we went our first night in SF. The restaurant is on the heart of Chinatown. The sign outside is kind of funky, with bright, neon colors. The inside is completely different though. Nice atmosphere, simple decor. It wasn't a small place (I've seen smaller in SF), but it was full at 6:30 pm, probably because it was during peak hours. 

The food here is delicious. My boyfriend got the Melt in Your Mouth Calamari and I got the sesame chicken. The calamari was just amazing. Freaking delicious. Lightly breaded, not like any other calamari I've tried. Covered in a delicious lemon sauce. I still dream about it. The sesame chicken though is only eh. It was way too crispy, fried too much. I wouldn't get it again. 

Service is pretty good as well. Overall, will come back here for the calamari, but not fo that chicken.
author: May C.

description:
Nanking does it right. Went here on a Sunday night and the place was as full as it is any other day of the week. Speaks to the quality. 

Went here with 3 other lions with similar sized appetites. We were carnivores tearing up plates of chicken (and a little rice/noodles). Everything was BOMB. 

Can't wait to come back some day and put down even more of this authentic amazingness. 

Don't play yourself in Chinatown, go to Nanking.
author: Matt W.

description:
What a San Francisco classic. When I was a little kid, before I lived in San Francisco, my mom and I would come here after recommendations from friends and family. Came here again and was just a bit disappointed. Its still quite good, but not as good as when I came here ten years prior. 

Anyways, the potstickers with the thick sauce is awesome and the Nanking chicken is a must order. It is in a sketchy neighborhood and a bum actually came in grabbed a bunch of our potstickers and threw them at another guest. (I can't make this sh*t up) The staff apologized and gave us a new plate and I appreciated they did this and I thought they handled the situation as best they could. Just letting everyone know though that its not that staff's fault that its in a bad neighborhood. Don't let it deter you from checking out Nanking!
author: Cody M.

description: We ate here two years ago and were excited to come back to Nanking.  The good news is there was no wait for dinner, but after eating there, we now understand why.  The quality and service have really gone downhill.   We ordered the sesame chicken and chicken fried rice.  The sesame chicken meat was very fatty and the fried rice had very little flavor.  The waitress never came back to check on us or offer us any sauce.   Very disappointed.  Thankfully we had several nights in town and we were able to have a fantastic dinner at another chinatown restaurant down the street.
author: Darlene O.

description:
I have visited this restaurant couple times I come to SF since 2005. Taste and quality have kept worsening and obviously the worst services ever. Specially this time, while I brought my biz colleagues, the lady (owner's wife?) made me frustrated and shameful -  Pushed us to pay a bill before we finished eating. Even they kindly put an amount of tip to a bill and ordered to sign.

I will never recommend this place and never come back again - they are not deseved even one star.
author: Jay H.

description:
Delicious food. Cool joint. 

Sesame chicken was a great flavor and came with a wonderful sauce that combined nicely with the thin cut sweet potatoes.
The chow mien had a fantastic and exotic flavor mixed with assorted veggies. 

I would definitely recommend this place for a nice bite.
author: Andy B.

description: Eggplant in chili garlic sauce -10! Sesame chicken - 12! Loud, crowded, line out the door. Worth the 15 minute wait. Excellent!!!!
author: Thomas M.

description: Outstanding meal at a great price. I highly recommend this restaurant. This was our first time here and we came at a great time by the time we were leaving there was a line around the corner!
author: Lisa G.

description:
After eating there on our honeymoon because of a friend's recommendation, we actually just flew up there this past weekend to eat there again. Not kidding, the reason we flew from Orange County to San Francisco was mainly just to eat at House of Nanking. My husband I find ourselves on a weekly basis commiserating that there just isn't anything as good to eat in SoCal.

Often for dinner there can be a bit of a line. It is a small restaurant so there usually is a wait, but the line moves extremely fast. They seat diners as quickly as possible - often sitting right next to complete strangers (this is not a great restaurant for an intimate, romantic meal). The service is very fast, abrupt and you may even feel a bit like they are pressuring you to eat and leave quickly.

We find the staff's rudeness kinda funny. They are absolutely on top of all your needs - refilling drinks, bringing food out quickly, etc. If it was bad service, I'd be frustrated. Instead, it's just a staff that is too busy to be friendly and too aware that there is a line of people waiting to get in to allow you to sit and sip on the last of your diet coke for 20 minutes after your food is finished.

Still, despite all that, it is worth it. The food is outstanding, memorable and will leave you truly satisfied.
author: Kaitlyn M.

description:
House of Nanking is a tourist trap and I admit that I keep going back to this tourist trap. The food is really good but it's just better-than-usual Americanized Chinese food with interesting taste combinations that make it a place to seek out from time to time. 

So the primary novelty, if you know what you are doing, is to just tell the order person, usually the owner, an amount that your table is willing to spend and see how he works that all in. 15-20 dollars a person usually nails it in terms of a dumpling appetizer and a plate per person. It makes it a lot easier in terms of figuring out what you want :(the menu isn't that big but you don't have to second guess yourself). The first main plate is almost always the Nanking Chicken which is basically Sesame Chicken, Hunan style. The second plate is always something more interesting. We've had some sort of odd peanut crusted chicken one time, and last night, we had spinach salad with fried fish. 

Anyway, it is a tourist trap and it is basically Americanized Chinese food with a twist. But it's still very good... and terse service makes it very efficient once you get past the line.
author: Hj W.

description: How is this Chinese food? How is this edible?? For the most reviewed restaurant in Chinatown, this was such a HUGE letdown. Really? The sesame chicken and the fried calamari are the most recommended dishes on their menu? The appetizers were awful, the recommended dishes were awful, the service was awful. I couldn't even finish half of any of the dishes because they were just so bad... How did House of Nanking get so popular?
author: Tunaidi A.

description: I have been eating here since 1997,  the food is still as delicious as ever,  always a treat. Super hectic,  always very crowded, inventive dishes,  dingy yet charming organized chaos at its finest, and oh those yams with the Nanking sauce,   couldn't ask for more from a Chinese restaurant.
author: Nicholas P.

description:
I would say this restaurant is one of those hidden gems of SF. Luckily, both times I have gone, there was hardly a line. 

I've ordered their fried rice, the hot & sour soup, the sesame chicken, calamari, and house noodles. Just about everything was delicious and even though the waiters were a tad rude and difficult at times and one of the dishes actually had hair in it (gladly, the dish was taken off the bill), my overall satisfaction from the food was not compromised. 

The fried rice and noodles complement the saltiness and heaviness from the sesame chicken and the hot and sour soup is a spicy and great way to start the meal. The calamari was nothing like I've had before, but was a great addition to our meal. 

Definitely will be heading back soon to this great, unique restaurant and have definitely found my go-to Chinese restaurant in SF!
author: Yehrin P.

description: The crispy chicken was beyond unreal. You must try it!!!!!! The customer service is whatever, but the chicken was soooo good! Good to pair with fried rice.
author: Kayla S.

description:
Why is this place rated as highly as R&G Lounge?  I came here for a quick bite, and while it was very speedy, the food was less than memorable.  I couldn't help but notice how decidedly Americanized this Chinese restaurant looked and felt.  Each table had napkins with a fork and plate (no chopsticks or rice bowls - oh the horror!), there was a serious lack of Asian customers, and the decor felt more like a diner than a Chinese restaurant.

We ordered the sesame chicken with sweet potatoes, house made noodles, and garlic calamari.  All foods were tasty, but heavily fried and/or salted.  The calamari was okay, but the batter was more soggy than anything else due to the garlic sauce.  I think a better approach would be to have the garlic sauce in a dish on the side to leave the calamari crispy.  The noodles and chicken lacked the hot wok flavor that characterizes my favorite Chinese dishes.  I enjoyed the house noodles the most, but they still tasted like something I could make at home.  Unlike other Yelpers, I didn't mind the service too much.  The waitress was cordial enough. 

I would suggest coming to House of Nanking if you are in a hurry to have a meal in less than 20 minutes.  However, for any family gathering or authentic Chinese food, I'd head over to R&G Lounge, Hong Kong Lounge, or Kirin Chinese Restaurant.
author: Brittany N.

description:
Be brave. Let them choose. 

Sit down. Smile at your server, and say "feed me".  They'll do the rest.

Love this place.  Very good food.  Fast service.  Fairly priced.

Small, crowded, intimate.
author: Fred B.

description: Brought here by a friend.  In a really cool part of town and the food was good and the price was great.  Best part was that after a long walk to the restaurant, the beer was ICE COLD.
author: Sherif E.

description:
This rating is based on the food, not service. I had the best egg roll I've ever eaten in my life at this place. It tasted like duck to me but the menu said pork. The sauce was incredibly delicious! Loved the pork fried dumplings, even though they completely forgot that part of our order and we had to ask 3 times in order to get it at the very end of our meal. House noodles were insanely good- wow, I'll never forget the garlic sauce! Also loved the Sesame chicken. The beef covered in gravy wrapped in Chinese pancakes was to die for and demolished in minutes. Every single dish we had was delicious and quickly devoured. 

Service was sub par as many have already complained. I would definitely come back despite the wait and so-so service. Park for $1/hour at night at the St. Mary's garage.
author: Dan N.

description:
Location and Interior:
This place is rather small inside and as clean as a Chinese food restaurant can get.(im not being racist. im asian fyi) The location of this place is a block or two from broadway near all the stripclubs. During the day when the sun is out, its a good place to go. But being here when its dark might get the best of you. 2 stars

Service:
Service was poor. They really do rush you to order and eat. Im guessing they just try to make as much revenue and tips as they can. If you are not sure what to order, their might be a chance they order for you. Most of the servers here have an attitude unless you are with someone who is chinese. My first time here, I tried to get food to go, but was rudely pushed away, but I was starving so I ended up just eating in . 2nd time I came here with my mandarin speaking coworker who asked the same server if we can order to go, it wasn't a problem. Interesting...2 star

Food:
I have gotten the crispy fried ribs, crispy beef, prawns, noodles. Food was REALLY good. Flavor was on point. The portions are a little small though. Thats all I have to say about that. 4stars.

Price:
Price is pretty decent compared to other chinese restaurants in the city. Especially how good their food is. Price is great. Go their for lunch. 4 stars

Overall, good place to eat for lunch.
author: Michael G.

description:
The people that says it's the best Chinese food, don't really know good tasting Chinese food when they taste it.

Food are greasy and the taste are very average, don't know why the long lines! This is more for tourist restaurants.

The not so good experience are the not so good service.

You are better off at Suily's Restaurant on Stockton/Broadway.
author: Tony S.

description: Crispy rice soup, fish with greens on top, garlic green beans omggggg, everything was amazing!
author: Imafood E.

description: Gross! After YEARS of watching people stand in line outside, we decided to try HNK.  The service was RUDE Soup Nazi style.  The tea they brought wasn't steeped.  The water they brought my kids had soap in it.  The food was so lack luster.  The Hot and Sour Soup tastes straight up like MSG Chicken Bouillon.  Needless to say, I'm writing this in an Uber on the way to another restaurant.  Why oh why do people stand in line for this crap?  Yuck.
author: Gabrielle W.

description: Wait in line to sit, when you sit don't ask too many questions, get your food and go. Awesome menu
author: Harout K.

description: This place has such great reviews. I'm currently seating here waiting for my food in hopes it is anything like the service. The waitress was beyond rude and impolite. Shoved our table to the right while complaining about the space. Looked annoyed to take our order and made sure we were aware of it. When we asked about tea she said they don't have any cold tea.
author: Kenia O.

description: Probably the best Chinese food I've ever had. The waitress simply asked what we liked (chicken, pork, veggies, etc) and made us what she thought we'd like. She was dead on. No bullshit attitude type of place. I like it.
author: Matt H.

description: Super fast amazing food. Order as much as you think you can eat and you won't be disappointed. The food is all fresh and perfectly seasoned. I recommend the salt and pepper shrimp and the bao wrap beef. Sesame chicken is kickin' too. The bowls of wonton soup are huge so be prepared.
author: Jennifer C.

description: The food here was delicious. After a recommendation by a tour director , we headed here for lunch. The wonton soup was very tasty . Nice big plump pork wontons won me over from the start. This was followed by the pork crispy noodles . Do so much flavour in this dish it was delicious. One person in our party had the black bean tofu and raved about it as well . The simple yet diverse menu made having a vegetarian with us so easy .
author: Kirsty D.

description:
Chinatown San Francisco is overwhelming when it comes to finding food.
We went on a recommendation, walked off the main street and were very pleased.
Tiny place with a sort of gruff gent who seats you.  He is all business!
We ordered sesame chicken, Noodles and fried calamari.
Now we gobbled them up so fast we weren't sure if it was the fantastic food (which it was) or that we were starved (we were)  so its both, and we gave four stars with the assurance that we would be back tomorrow ...just in case ;-)
Great spot, and the gruff gent even smiled at us at the end of the meal!
author: Mimi B.

description:
Four years later and this is still some of the best Chinese food I have ever had.  Coming back for Thanksgiving weekend I knew I had to squeeze a trip to Chinatown to get some more House of Nanking.  This place has become my Mecca for Chinese food.  It can get busy and crowded there so try to come during a non peak hour. Just like last time the place was packed and so going during non peak hours you have a better chance of getting seated right away.  Be prepared to get friendly with your neighbors because it's almost all community seating.

In 2009 I ate here twice and my husband and I got the following items: vegetarian noodle bowl, crispy calamari with spicy coconut sauce, sesame chicken with sweet potatoes, and lettuce wraps with chicken.  All four of the dishes were delicious.  My favorite item has got to be the lettuce wraps with various veggies like cucumber, peas, onions with pineapple and mint with chicken wrapped in crispy lettuce.  For my 2013 trip we ordered the calamari and vegetable noodles.  Still just as tasty as I remember.  Adding in some steamed rice we mixed the remaining sauce from the calamari for a spicy and sweet treat.

The teas are really amazing, especially the blossoming flower tea and the antioxidant fruit tea (which you can order hot or cold).

Some people may not like how rushed and hustle bustle this place is. I don't mind it it at all.  I've been to enough Chinese, Japanese, and Vietnamese restaurants where this is what to expect from a business that hasn't been overly Americanized, and I am more than ok with it.  My food comes out quickly and I don't have to deal with making pleasantries with the server. I want my food and she wants to get paid.  This is a mutual thing to agree upon.  

Also if you're not sure what you want to order, just tell them how hungry you are and say "pick something for me."
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
I enjoyed my meal here much more than expected...I'd been here years ago and remembered enjoying the meal and on this recent trip I enjoyed another great meal here...

I did the whole let-the-chef-fill-your-table-with-food-thing and I was not disappointed.  We had plates including shrimp, beef, chicken and vegetables and everything was great...I really remember the sesame chicken being so good as well as the special beef dish.

This place is known as being a spot to visit in San Francisco so I'd suggest avoiding this place (because there is a long line) during typical meal hours during the weekend (7pm - 9pm)...it's a bit better to visit in the early evening and during the week.
author: Ken G.

description:
Porbably the best Chinese restaurant in town although it is suited to the American palate. Everything we ordered was exceptional. The pork-stuffed mushroom creates the perfect combination that would satisfy your savory needs. The pork chop is probably the best dish out of the ones we ordered. And of course not to mention their infamous sesame chicken; if you think panda express' orange chicken is good, this is next level. 

Service was subpar but pretty good for a Chinese restaurant. Will definitely come back!
author: Glen O.

description: We ordered House Noodles, Garlic Eggplant, Mushu Vegetables with Tofu, & Sesame Chicken. We also ordered a small bowl of rice (which you have to ask for here...). The Mushu Vegetables was by far the best item we tried and we would certainly return just for that dish alone. We actually preferred the dish without the burrito like wrapping. Flavors were amazing. The garlic eggplant was also fresh and delicious. House Noodles were good. Savory with a bit of a nutty flavor from the sprouts they placed on top. Everything tastes fresh and not over saturated with oils or sauces. Great balance. Will return.
author: Kimber L.

description:
Like the other reviewers have said, if you can get past the quick, sometimes 'hurried' service and lack of warm, open smiles, then this place is dynamite.

A hidden gem.

No, they don't bathe you in smiles and soft white cotton clouds and serenade you with daffodils as far as their service. You kinda get seated, someone comes over a while later, quick, to the point, and they wisk off and start making your food.

But the food is AMAZING.  Every bit of it, I've tried several of the appetizers and main dishes, they're all good.  My faves are the sesame chicken and potstickers.  The House noodles are really good also.

If you're looking to be cuddled and whispered to in your ear while someone massages your feet, this might not be your place.  But if you want authentic, good Chinese food in a fun, clean environment, come here.
author: John B.

description: LORD, this place is amazing. My mom has been taking me here for years until we moved across the country. When I moved back as a teenager, I would take my dad's car and drive my friends out here. As an adult, I have LITERALLY traveled 3,000 miles for their house noodles. I was pregnant last year and traveled again to eat at this restaurant (6 times in a four day period), I am so sad that we can't afford to live next door. Next time I am pregnant, I will need to get their recipes, $1500 one way for a meal is getting to be out of budget. All thumbs up!
author: Isabel D.

description:
I have been going here for years and most recently a couple weeks ago to meet a big group of friends.  The popularity has certainly died down here since their expansion along with the eruption of food options all around the city.  It hasn't stopped them from still being one of the best around.  The room has expanded since it's early days and is far more upscale than it's quick turn over traditional past. 

With all it's changes the one thing that has stood strong is their menu. Their items are unique to their location so if you're looking for General Tso or Broccoli Beef this is not your place. If you're willing to feel adventurous without truly being adventurous you well enjoy most everything here.  Though at times some dishes can be a little salty. You rarely see people leave with leftovers because it almost always gets finished. 

Service is still as unpleasurable as before they just have more room to move around. if you're coming expecting white linens and a staff willing to sing your girlfriend happy birthday don't come in.  If you want an original and satisfying spin on Chinese food then come right in and enjoy a true San Francisco treat.
author: Joco F.

description: Delicious! We got the sesame chicken, fried dumpings and scallops with eggplant. Everything was fantastic! One note, they don't have high chairs for babies, but the food was so good I didn't mind holding our 1 year old on my lap. What we ordered was the right amount of food for 2 adults and cost about $45 before tip.
author: Beth B.

description:
I've been going here for years, and the food is consistently excellent. As the House of Nanking got recognized, it became busier and the restaurant upgraded its decor and tables from the shared metal picnic benches they used to have.
House of Nanking is crowded and loud. If you manage to be there on a day when the waiter has an extra second, ask what's good that day. I've thoroughly enjoyed dishes like their standard sesame chicken with sweet potato to their house noodle and stuffed mushrooms. 
House of Nanking also serves tea blossoms that open up in the hot water. Very pretty. 

While this has become a more touristy spot, the quality of the food is still good. 
I wouldn't say this is "authentic," nor is it anything like typical "take-out inauthentic." It's more along the lines of fusion. 

The price is about right for the quality of food. This is an in-demand spot! The line often goes down the block.
author: Allxie C.

description:
Four of us came here for lunch
We did not know what to order , but the lady she brought four different dishes

We like it do much that we ordered two more dishes
We loved it
This is the place to go
author: Jack P.

description: This restaurant has really gone downhill. I've been eating here on vacations for the last 5+ years. The calamari used to be so amazing for a decent price. I just went a few months ago and the quality was worse and price doubled. We also ordered fried noodles and veggies and it was all noodles (those were actually good) and maybe 3 pieces of spinach, again way overpriced. If you like being overcharged and waitresses that glare at you till you order and throw a menu at you, then this is your kind of place! I'll be eating elsewhere on my next visit to SF.
author: Morgan J.

description: This place was recommended by the front desk staff at our hotel. We were glad, because the options are endless. We gave up menus to let the chef pick for us, which wound up being a fantastic idea. Everything was wonderful. Service and good were top-notch.
author: Courtney G.

description: I remember it to be much better but still delicious, try the eggplant and the onion cakes.
author: Lourdes F.

description: Amazing food, they gave us the bok choy and meat of the old menu. It's a quick turn over kind of place and honestly anything is very yummy! Great find!
author: Kat S.

description: We just happened to walk by and saw the line out the door which never went away even when we did get seated.  The 5 stars is for the food. The service and ambience is not necessarily the best but it also adds for the charm of the restaurant. If your looking for a nice quiet restaurant this is not your place. If you want to feel the hustle and bustle of the city it's perfect. The crunch rice soup was my absolute favorite. The perfect warming meal with amazing flavor. We also ordered the nanking shrimp. If you like your food to be sweet and spicy then you'll love it. The house noodles were fabulous.
author: Sarah T.

description: I took friends here visiting from the east coast and they approved the great quality of the dishes in comparison to the china town in NYC.. Specifically the sesame chicken..
author: Joe C.

description:
This is the place if you have a sense of humor & history!!
This is a San Francisco tradition..
Best quality food, rushed, dirty, rude service, lines around the block!!
If you don't love it you are way too new in town!!
author: Deborah Jo D.

description: Stopped in during my "urban hike". Got the best seat in the house. Literally solo table, window seat. Chow mein was as good as ever.
author: Margie P.

description:
We celebrated our 11th Wedding Anniversary today. We were lucky enough to get in right away. We lined up a little before their opening at 5p. 
Unfortunately the Owner, Peter Fang, arrived after we placed our order (we tried our best to wait for him-15 mins) so we didnt get him to surprise us this time. Hence, the 4 stars. 
We ordered the crispy rice soup, Fang's panfried garlic fish, the pork chops, panfried baby peashoots, the crispy noodle tower with chicken, and fried rice. My favorite was the soup, the fish and pork chops. 
My husband noticed that Mr. Fang kept looking at our table. Maybe because we ordered a lot or that we truely enjoyed our meal. 
We had plenty left to take home back to Elk Grove. 
Thank you again!!!
author: Cristina O.

description:
SUMMARY:
I'm 1.5 gen Chinese-American, but I've grown up learning what authentic Chinese food is. The Bay Area has a growing number of authentic Chinese restaurants, but HoN is not one of them. First, HoN is neither authentic nor good Chinese food. You don't get what you pay for here - it is really expensive for disgusting food. Secondly, you get worse-than-usual Chinese customer service to boot.

Continuation of story from previous review:

Our bill was something like $25 per person for sharing 3 dishes and a soup. Go to any respectable place in Oakland Chinatown and it'd be like $30 TOTAL for 3 dishes and a soup, and it'd be good food. R&G Lounge is even more expensive, but at least their quality measures up.

We wanted to leave no tip for our experience. However, Chinese/Korean restaurants and services will typically come after you and say, "You didn't leave enough tip." We half-expected the waitress to start yelling at us in front of our visiting friend and the completely packed restaurant so we left a small tip that would show that we didn't forget to pay tip, this is exactly how we feel about you and your food and service.

I NEVER rate a Chinese restaurant based on its service, so this 1 star is for the food alone. I'll mention service but it won't affect the number of stars I give b/c I rate purely on food quality. I've been to many really good Chinese restaurants with rude service. In fact, I have a rule of thumb - the dirtier the restaurant and the ruder the service, the better the food. HoN has no right to be cocky and rude when the quality of their food deserves to shut the restaurant down. There's a couple legit places in Chinatown, e.g. R&G Lounge just a block away, and extremely legit places further out west in Sunset.

People differ on the importance of service vs. food quality. I say that if they had AMAZING food with the RUDE service experienced (even though this rudeness was above and beyond other rude restaurants I've been to), I'd be giving 5 stars. My bf says that if at least the service was good, he wouldn't be complaining as much about the food. He wouldn't think it's good, but at least he wouldn't be demeaned like a child. We paid for our visiting friend because we were so embarrassed and sorry to have taken him to such a bad place. Due to how repulsive the food was to our taste buds, we didn't finish any of our dishes except the soup and boxed it all up...and nobody wanted to take it home. My bf and I ended up taking it but I refuse to eat it, so it's all on him. :P

I think it is important to steer everybody away from this restaurant until they improve in the quality of their food first and foremost, and secondly, their customer service. If they never reach the second goal, that would be fine, but for heaven's sake, make edible food!
author: Esther Y.

description:
The place was legit despite that there was more white people than "non-white." Loved everything we ordered which was about 9 different things!

I would say worth the wait for a sure thing!
author: CC P.

description:
For a while now, I have heard rave reviews of this place, especially from my wife who swears by how good the food is. I have never been so we tried to grab dinner there about a year ago. Unfortunately it was Chinese New Year so Nanking was closed which is understandable so we figure we try again when the opportunity presented itself. Last night we decided to make a trip to the city and finally see why so many people love Nanking.

Regretfully, Nanking wouldn't let us in. We arrived at 9:20 PM but a very rude waitress told us that they were closed even though their web site states that they close at 10 PM on a Friday night (you see the same thing when you do a Google search). She essentially slammed the door on us as we were about to walk in (door was propped open as we were approaching the restaurant). There were clearly people inside still eating and waiting for food and there were enough open tables to seat us. Plus there were a few other customers who arrived at the same time as us but were also turned away so Nanking felt the extra business was not worth their time.

This is the first time I have ever written a review for a restaurant I have yet to eat at which does seem odd but I feel people need to know how deceptive Nanking is about their closing times and how rude their service people are. Yes, I do know that service at a traditional Chinese restaurant is not what you expect from most restaurants and I am totally OK with that as I am a Bay Area native and have dined at traditional Chinese restaurants before (you don't go for the service but for the food!). But Come On Man! You couldn't even at least say sorry we are closed or at least honor the closing time you post on your web site?! 

We tried pleading our case to the waitress telling her that we drove all the way from Redwood City just to try Nanking but she didn't even bother to listen to us. I get the feeling that Nanking is coming down with a strong case of arrogance since they know they are the renowned Chinese restaurant in a city like SF which prides itself on good food. Note to the management, if you want to keep your restaurant as the top Chinese restaurant in SF, honor your closing times and treat your potential customers with a bit more respect. I can easily get good Chinese food at so many places and I hope you make the necessary changes so that this doesn't happen again to any one else. I've struck out twice with Nanking. Not sure if I will try for a third time to eat at this supposedly really good Chinese restaurant that apparently felt I was not worth their time to be a patron at their establishment.
author: Gus E.

description:
Tried it to see what the hype is all about. Our plates and spoons were dirty with oily bottoms and dried food stuck to them (Bad impression). Tried their HIGHLY recommended Melt In Your Mouth Calamari which was just soggy little pieces of Calamari drenched in a very weird sour garlic sauce. The Sizzing Rice Soup was the best dish; crispy rice in a tasty Basil Chicken broth. Also had the Scallop in garlic black bean sauce; very sweet sauce with shredded assorted sizes of Scallops on top of spinach which was disappointing as well. Also found a random Shrimp tail in the Scallop dish which shows lack of attention to detail and consistency.

After our meal, I've come to realize that there are 2 menus?! Why was my group not given the choice of the authentic Chinese food menu? If translation is an issue, I highly recommend getting new updated menus that infuse both so everyone gets an equal choice on food selections. I was also going to comment on the old rugged paper menus inside the plastic sleeves; they looked very unappealing and chewed up.
author: Alex K.

description:
As we walked inside, instead of walking up and greet us, a waitress screamed across the room asking HOW MANY. I was shocked at this type of mannerism from a restaurant. She then pointed at a table and walked away. When I tried to close the window because it is too cold, another waiter came us to us, screamed at my girlfriend and I "NO NO NO IT IS HOT" and told us to sit inside if we are cold. This type of mannerism and hospitality in a restaurant is totally not acceptable. 

The food. Was. Terrible. As Kathy, the manager said, "serving good quality food is our top priority." Well it is such a shame that I did not get to meet you, Kathy. I would love to tell you that you have failed your job as the manager to manage the restaurant because you lack the leadership to discipline your workers, and cannot stand by the common sense morals of your "top priority". 

I would not go here ever again, and would also tell my friends, family and family's friends to never go here.
author: Ivan K.

description: This place is so great, you don't even need a menu. Just sit down and tell the waitress what you like or don't like and dishes will just start coming out. We had a cauliflower dish with some type of sausage and a great sauce, beef with bok choy,  salt and pepper shrimp and the super delicious sesame chicken. Have a Tsingtao beer or a Blossoming Tea to drink.
author: Shawn H.

description:
I really enjoyed the sesame chicken and the house noodles dishes!!
The service was pretty quick although the place seemed pretty tight and compact.
author: Brooke M.

description: Overrated tourist trap! Lousy service! Asked the waitress twice for water, and she walked away before I could finish my sentence! Food is average and definitely overrated!
author: R T.

description:
Fan of the food. Not the wait. Luckily I came here Monday right when it opened so there was no waiting other than the food coming to the table.

The Sesame Chicken came highly recommended but I was not that impressed. I mean, it was crispy, not overly sauced, was flavorful but was a little on the dry side once you bit into it. 

The Tender Sauteed Calamari was exactly that, tender, good bite, and the lemon-vinegar sauce that was drizzled on top is what made is zing!

My absolute favorite is the Sizzling Rice Soup. I want to know their recipe because it's different than what I'm used to. It had bite-sized chunks of zucchini and tofu, and the broth was super flavorful! The thing that surprised me is that the broth is white...so does it have coconut milk in it? If anyone knows the recipe, PLEASE share!!!!

The House Fried Rice is no different than any other Chinese restaurant's fried rice. It's good. Chinese people cannot eff it up.

Come here again? Yes! Wait in line? No.
author: Angela A.

description:
Whenever I'm in San Francisco, I always try and get here.  I've never been disappointed.  Sizzling Rice Soup is incredible, the Sesame Chicken is deservedly famous, the Calamari exquisite.  I recommend trying to get 4 to 6 people together for a meal and just ask them to bring food--always delicious, and you can sample to your hearts content.

Every time we are in S.F. we come here--just go in and say "we're hungry, bring food".  Never disappointed!

And here's an update, Oct. 2015--Still Never Disappointed.  I've been back numerous times since my initial review in 2010.  The unfavorable reviews are right in that there's not much in the way of decor, and it's crowded, and the service is not fawning.  But everyone is friendly, I think it's great to sit close to other patrons and have struck up fun conversations with strangers enjoying their food.  So don't go to be impressed by ambience or jacket and bow tie service, just sit back and ask them to bring you good food--and they will!  Fast!
author: Tom C.

description: Most gorgeous aubergine there ever lived.
author: Katie B.

description:
Not really experienced in Chinese food...  I got a western trained taste.

Most important for me is the food.

And the food was really really excellent.
Great taste, not too spicy, not to plain, different than the usual.
I can't really tell if it is original Chinese cuisine or improvised but it is the best oriental/chinese food I have tried at normal price.

The service is a little strange by SF standards. 
They are in a hurry, fast, they don't waste time being polite, they will drop the plate on your table with noise, so if service manners are important to you this is not your restaurant.
Personally I don't really care about the fake service smiles and I find it disturbing having somebody coming over my head and asking me "how is everything"  every 5 minutes.

Si I will give it 5 starts, knowing it is not perfect but one of the places that you will go and eat real food.
author: Antony T.

description: I was very disappointed in this place.  It had been highly recommended to me.  I felt that they didn't have much of a selection on their menu, the service was horrible, the place was dirty, and the food did not taste good.  You would have thought that they would have asked if everything was ok since neither one of us hardly ate any of it but they didn't.
author: Trudi S.

description:
I wish there were less than one star. This place was TERRIBLE. The service was by far the WORST I've ever had in my life. I ordered an entree and asked for sauce on the side (they said it wasn't possible and would place very very light sauce on the beef), it came out drenched with sauce that didn't taste good at all. I told the server and the server told me I had to get something else, when at this point I didn't want to even try anything else. I said no thank you I'm fine. The manager proceeded to tell me I had to order something else. 

Now, for the next 15 minutes while my girl firm finished her food, the manager and server screamed back and forth about the situation "sauce this sauce that" were the only words I could make out... So unprofessional and uncomfortable. I sat there as they stared and screamed about me not liking my entree. 

Long story short they took it off and our bill ended up being $30 and we only tipped $2 and they had the audacity to say (standing over the table as I signed my receipt) "YOU ONLY TIPPED ME $2?" 

TERRIBLE TERRIBLE SERVICE. To be honest they didn't deserve a tip at all, I always tip great but they made us feel so uncomfortable after we told them we didn't like the food that we didn't even finish the rest of our other entree.
author: Jeremy R.

description: Awful experience. The waitstaff was rude! They even tried to shame us as we didn't leave a tip on the credit card receipt as we  were going to leave cash. Instead of giving us that opportunity the waitress came up to us and told us we were required to leave a tip. We weren't even ready to leave yet. We were sitting and talking...yeah never again. And the food? Unfortunately the chicken tasted old and had a slight bitter taste. Not to mention that the  food was slammed onto our table, no one came back to ask if we were ok and never even got a refill on our waters.  This was a complete fail.
author: Rish K.

description: Horrible!!  The food was sub-par and the service was even worse.  Wait... What service?  The staff was rude and it felt like being back in the grade school cafeteria. If you go here, go with zero expectations!
author: Chelsea A.

description: One of the worst customer service and not even good food. We ordered the chow mein and sesame chicken. The chow mein was way too salty and not even much taste to it. The chicken was good except the fact that there was barely any for $10. It was all covered with the sweet potato. At the end we just paid for our food and started heading out. One of the workers comes up to us with our receipt that we signed and was like there's no tip. We were like " it's our option whether or not we liked the service to tip you". He's like write $5 and I said no. He tried bargaining down to $4. So I just wrote $1 and he's like are you serious! Get out of my store. Never will we be going back here. The owners need to teach their servers proper manners. I work at a restaurant and the gratuity is optional. But this was ridiculous!
author: Julie B.

description:
Good stuff!

The chef is a true expert at his craft. An authentic dining experience. 

Their dumplings are to die for.
author: Viet P.

description: TERRIBLE SERVICE.  Forced to sit with strangers and told by the owner - move; you have 5 minute!!! No time and yanked the menus out of our hands.  Oddly enough - I noticed a table with 6 chairs and two people who were locals eating by themselves and getting excellent service.  They slammed the food down at our table and ghosted out to never be seen again.  Lastly; a waitress came up within 20 minutes of our food being delivered to get our money - she said "hurry, we closing!!"  Food was average - NOT WORTH IT
author: Amy F.

description:
Dayum, that's some solid Chinese food. It's a teeny little place with delicious eats that are served up lightning fast. And while service was friendly, I'll agree with others that they do seem to drop the dishes in front of you and disappear. But hey, the food disappears just as fast, so it all works. 

A few items I sampled...

Potstickers: 4/5: Tender pork, nicely cooked dumpling blanketed in a tasty sauce. No gelatinous, overly sweet topper here!

Sesame chicken: 3/5: The menu mentions that they are famous for this dish, but I was fairly underwhelmed. It was fine. Just fine. But nothing to write home about. 

Scallops: 4/5: Light and flavorful with a beautiful bunch of bok choy. Some of the thinly sliced scallops were a bit gritty, but that's kind of what I expect from affordable shellfish. 

Eggplant and sweet potatoes: 5/5: Katie B recommended this dish and it is as beautiful as it is delicious. Just order it - thank me later. 

Honey beef: 4/5: Our server recommended the honey beef - good choice! Big hunks of beef lightly covered in a semi-sweet crust. I know that reads none too appetizing but it was a nice respite among the saucy dishes on the table. 

With fair prices, moderate portions and great flavors, House of Nanking is a winner.
author: Nicole W.

description:
Went here for the first time with my friends and after checking out the menu, was greeted by theee chef himself:

"Have you ever been here?"
"No. We're thinking of ge-"
::snatches menus and walks away::

Apparently this isn't unusual here. 
The chef gave us some awesome and iconic dishes of theirs (which I am unfortunately not remembering), which were tasty. Our stomachs were satisfied and wallets relieved, as we were afraid he had ordered the whole kitchen for a party of three.

Bummer they only take cash!
author: Kris I.

description: Delicious! Get the sesame chicken and chow mein noodles! We went at 3:30pm on a Sunday which was perfect because it wasn't packed. We were seated right away.
author: Kristina M.

description:
Excellent! Delicious food, great price and no frills service. Got lucky and only had to wait 10 min for table. Met some nice locals in line that we ended up sharing a table with. Great opportunity for making new friends!

Favorites: sesame chicken, chicken fried rice (had a little gravy/sauce in it that was so good), salt and pepper prawns, calamari, potstickers.

Will definitely return next time we're in SF!
author: Ash L.

description: Service was rude! The waitress tried to rush our table to finish fast so they could serve more people! Foods were all about fried! Not a good place to have Chinese food! All the dishes we had were overpriced according to the portion! Will never go back!
author: Yingmei C.

description: Wow! The food is amazing, check out the pics on Yelp and you will find something you like, I got the shrimp and mushroom and it's amazing!
author: Oscar C.

description: My wife is from Tianjin China. She thought the food was great. It's surprisingly inexpensive as well. We got to have some things you can't find in Portland.
author: Brendan A.

description: I went to the House of Nanking today and have never been more grossed out in my life. I watched the older man that worked there cough without covering his mouth, blow his nose,put his finger in his mouth and his ear, clean dirty tables and then deliver food and put food on plates and deliver them to customers all without washing his hands. He coughed over the clean plates on that they have sitting in the front and still did not cover his mouth or wash his hands. The lady that works in there was constantly scratching her head while delivering plates of food to people also never washed her hands. This is how people get sick. If you care about your health and don't want the risk of getting sick by the employees lack of hygiene, I would highly recommend not eating at the House of Nanking!
author: D J.

description:
Truly amazing food! Our hotel referred us...so glad we made the walk! 

The sesame chicken and house noodles were amazing.
author: Adam C.

description:
Food was disgusting, worker disgusting, the whole place was disgusting. They had a 87 for the food inspection. Save your self the money and find somewhere else. This place sucks! 

Fist we got there and our server was very rude. She just threw some plates on our table and pushed them at us telling us to order. This was as soon as me and the 6 other people i was with sat down. We ordered our drinks. As they were brought to us by some man who wasn't our server he has stuck his fingers into the drinks. This happened because he carried the cups from them rim of the glass. (None of us drank our beverages) After the man walked away we saw him scratching his hair.... Since we had already ordered some basic fried rice and lo mein we waited for our food. Fried rice was flavorless however, you can sorta save it with chili oil and soy sauce. The lo mein was flavorless as well. My boyfriends mothers lo mein was not cooked thoroughly. When telling the waitress she got attitude because we told her it wasn't good because it was not thoroughly cooked as we proceeded to show her the clumps of uncooked noodle. She then said she would only charge us for the shrimp telling us that it would be the price of the noodles. Which didn't make any since. They then cleaned the table beside me with the same wash cloth the were using to clean there hands. I would never eat here again or recommend it to anyone worst Asian food I have ever had! 

Also some people came in and was looking at our food, I could tell they thought it looked good so I just told them it was disgusting. Then we left and didn't tip.
author: Varonica M.

description: I heard how good this restaurant was supposed to be. My wife and I went to the restaurant on a Friday for lunch. We were extremely disappointed in the service we received. The waiters were very rude and rushed us to order. The food was good but not great like I'd read. We were never offered a refill on water or ice tea. Find another Chinese restaurant in Chinatown.
author: Alfred M.

description: I would give 5 stars, but it's just hard to get past the brusque treatment. Best meal we had. We ordered off menu this time though. The house noodles and the garlic beef. Can't wait to go back.
author: Nancy P.

description: I was not sold on the idea of Chinese food for brunch so I walked in a skeptic and walked out a fan. The garlic green beans were phenomenal. The fried calamari had a refreshing yet rich lemon, butter sauce. The fried rice was very flavorful and the sesame chicken with sweet potatoes was delicious. I'll be back to try the impressive looking, exotic teas.
author: Kat T.

description:
Great food, fast service!! 

Served family style, there is ample opportunity to share with friends and enjoy a wide variety of fantastic food!!
author: Nicole R.

description:
The reason why I didn't give one star is the good service. Being asked if we could read Chinese after we walked in. We said yes and they handed us 2 menus which were hand written. The selections were too limited, and I noticed other tables had different menus.  Soon our waitress came over and helped us to decide what to eat. We ordered what she recommended like soup with wonton& fish, duck (yan shui ya) and stir-dried tofu&preserved pork.( I am sorry that I dont remember exactly names of these dishes and what I could remember was what I ate.) 
 The food was ehhh...We really dont know WHY that we felt uncomfortable after eating there. On the way home my friend told me that I didn't look good.  
Never Again!
author: Rila C.

description: If I can give half a star, I would. This place gave us an upset stomach. Everything here is heavily fried. We ordered their sesame chicken, eggplant, fried rice and fish dish. The food came in less than 2 minutes after we ordered. We were shocked how fast it was served. Tasted real good. But I spent my whole night in the bathroom so did my husband. We were so disappointed since we heard that the line would be wrapped around the restaurant. This place is so overrated to the real food they serve.
author: Liyan A.

description:
Possible the best Chinese food I have EVER had. Easily in the top three. The cuisine is outstanding. Fresh, delicious, savory, different. Great for vegetarians. 
Now, we all know Nanking is famous/infamous for their rude service, and they know this so keep it up. As long as they can keep that feeling real and not play it up, they are in great shape.
The fun starts at dinnertime, when there is a line down the block to get in (be ready to wait) and it is very crowded and you are seated RIGHT up against strangers and you amy not always get what your order and they may order for you but whatever you get is fabulous. 
Try the onion appetizer, with fried crust. it is light and incredible wonderful. Also, be sure to get their sweet potatoes!
Easy walk from Chinatown and North Beach-it is right on the edge of both.
author: Anne B.

description: Literally the worst restaurant I've eaten at during my 2 years living in San Francisco. None of the others even come close.
author: Samantha S.

description:
This is the place to eat in Chinatown.  One way to tell is that they are busy as most other restaurants around are not.  The crispy beef and chicken dishes were both very good. 

 Don't go here expecting great service because you won't get it, this place is about the food.  Be sure to ask your waiter for other choices because there are items available that are not on the menu.
author: Greg T.

description: Have to agree with other reviews. House of Nan King (HONK) used to be way better back when they just had counter seating. It was actually kind of amusing how "unrefined" the service was but that's not why you went there. You went there to get an honest Chinese meal for an honest price.  You'll still get a great meal here but it won't resemble the Chinese comfort foods you were used to as a kid. You could say the food has evolved to appeal to broader palettes so it's maybe not as authentic as I remembered it to be.
author: Jeff C.

description: So worth every penny!! House noodles were my favorite! The place is always packed but it flows nicely. Would recommend it!
author: Nancy M.

description: Simple - to the point. Nothing fancy but great food. The house fried rice and honey chicken are a great combination!
author: Nico S.

description: Had the best Chinese meal here last night. My favorite thing is probably the snap peas they brought out first! So fresh and yummy! We didn't order, they just kept bringing food!
author: Elisha J.

description: The is probably the best Chinese food I have ever had.  I love coming here when I am in the city. I tell the staff to have the chef just make me something it always amazing.
author: Chad D.

description:
Really hard to judge this place. I actually liked the food. I'm not a huge fan of Chinese but all the dishes were great. There service was terrible and some of the staff so incredibly rude it's hard give them a good rating.  When our bill came we were charged for all types of stuff that didn't get. The number of dishes we got seemed correct, but not the names (the server insisted on bringing us what they thought we'd like, since it was our first time. So we weren't sure on names or prices, but we knew we didn't get certain things). Asked if this was our bill because we didn't order half the items. He scoffed and pointed to the dishes. At that point we wanted to get out of there so we decided just to pay (fairly certain they screwed us on a couple prices). Would I ever go here again? No. Would I recommend it to friends? No.

Just looked at the prices online. They really screwed us over on the dishes.
author: Andrew D.

description: We've had quite an experience at House of Nanking - it was very memorable to say the least. Now onto the review. Best Chinese food I've had. Very happy that we listen to our tour guide and gave this place a try. We had the scallop tower, sesame chicken, and wontons. Will definitely come back to San Francisco to try other items on the menu.
author: J. C.

description:
This is absolutely my favorite Chinese restaurant in the world!  I've been coming to House of Nanking for many years...  Though I no longer live in the Bay Area, I make it a point to eat here at least once each time I visit.

Peter Fang and the House of Nanking practically put San Francisco's Chinatown culinary scene on the map! The food here, in my opinion, is some of the most unique Chinese food you'll find anywhere!  It's an incredible fusion of the various styles of cooking, with Mr. Fang's signature touch on several of the dishes they serve.  

There are a lot of wonderful things I can say about this place...  Over the years I've developed some fond memories.  If you've never been here before, don't hesitate, and don't let the long lines or communal seating arrangement scare you away.  Enjoy the food, because every single thing here is good, and make your own memories.

TIP:  If it's your first time and you & your table are indecisive, ask the staff to order for you.  You won't be disappointed!

ANOTHER TIP:  Be adventurous and don't go for the stuff you find at Brandy Ho's or your local mall's food court.  It's a real shame when people come to House of Nanking for egg rolls, pot stickers, sesame chicken, and fried rice.  Instead, try something you won't find on the menu anywhere else.
author: Jaszon S.

description:
I've actually liked this place and have been here several times before - the last time a little about a year ago. Unfortunately, after my last experience here it is unlikely that I will visit this restaurant again. It looks like whatever left of the service has gone down the tubes and the overall unremarkable quality of food paired with the crappy service no longer seems worth the long wait.

After waiting for 1 hour in the cold, our party of three were initially asked to take a table that seats 4. However as soon as we sat down and old waitress came along and yelled "NO" we could not sit on that table and instead were taken to another table for 6 where we shared the table with another party of 3. I don't mind sharing a table but who yells at their customers?

The quality of the dishes didn't seem to match what I recall from my previous visits. For example the szechuan chicken appears to have reduced to only about half plate of chicken and the rest was sliced potatoes. 

When we received the bill, I was shocked to see that a gratuity in excess of 20% had already been added to the total! We were not even a large group - just 3 people. 

Towards the end we were having a conversation after finishing our meals when a waitress came along and asked if I had signed the receipt and when I said yes, she rudely asked me to give it to her as if she wanted us to get up and leave immediately. 

Even though I have visited this place several times before and have actually brought friends/family here when I've had visitors in town I will no longer be doing so as the crappy service combined with just OK and not so remarkable food no longer seems worth the time visiting this restaurant anymore.
author: Pranab P.

description: Lets just say, the food speaks for it self and so do other peoples reviews for "House Of Nanking" the food is great here. If your in San Francisco, a definitely stop as a eat here place.
author: Mario M.

description: This is my favorite Chinese restaurant and my go to place for whenever I have out of town visitors.  I was brought here by friends when I first moved to San Francisco and have been a big fan ever since.  I'm a vegetarian and every non meat dish knocks it out of the park, but my staples are the house noodles, string beans, fried tofu and eggplant. My non vegetarian friends are equally impressed by their meat and seafood dishes.  The lines are long but that is just testament to how good the food is.  It is no frills, simple interior with service that gets the job done----the Ritz Carlton it is not.  But I grew up loving the family owned mom and pops Chinese restaurants that remind me of NYC and Toronto Chinatowns.  I'd give this place 10 stars if I could.
author: Robert W.

description: Great spot. Fantastic food, hip environment, unique presentation. Convenient if you work in the financial district.
author: Graig N.

description: Great food and a great family atmosphere. Not your typical American Chinese- this is probably one of the most unique and tasty restaurants in Chinatown.
author: Max H.

description:
We had no idea what this place was about, but left without a grain of rice left behind. We were lucky to have Peter Fang wait on us and I instinctively asked if he would order for us (much to my wife's apprehension).

By the end of the meal all of us agreed that this was the best Chinese food we had ever had, and appreciative of our teenager for picking this place.

It is an experience. Let the man work his magic.
author: Manish D.

description: Food was good. My favors thing was the lettuce wraps with chicken. Can pass on the dumpling soup next time around. Over all experience was good too.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
It was our first visit to this restaurant, it had been recommended to us. 
They were quick to seat us  and we were trying to look over the menu as we are never been there before. 
They kept coming over to see if we are ready to order. 
We finally picked two items one being the eggplant with chilli garlic sauce and the other being a mixed vegetable with tofu. 

The food came quickly, however no one ever came back to check on us until they brought us the bill. 
The food was good, not great though. 
I thought it could've been spicier which is why I would've liked to have seen a waitress so I could asked for some seasoning! 

With all the Chinese restaurants in downtown San Francisco I would not choose to go back to this one.
author: Patti K.

description:
Before heading up to SF, I polled my Facebook and Twitter friends on places to eat for the obligatory marathon victory dinner. As you can see, I keep traditions in tact. Nanking was mentioned several times however it wasn't exactly close to our hotel so we had a fun (read: challenging) time mapping out a route to get here without having to take the car. 

The journey proved to be quite an adventure. It was freezing cold and the wait for the trolley was 30 minutes long. Good thing I took a nap. The trolley stopped a mile away from our destination so it was another uphill walk (mind you I just ran up a few hills earlier that day so this was NOT fun) and in through China Town before we reached Nanking. And then there was a line. I was thankful for my jacket. It was freezing cold out there.

The line outside Nanking is common but moves fast. It's not first come, first serve either. It's actually controlled by the amount of space they have, so if you have a small party you'll be seated faster. Since it was just the two of us, we were standing in the back, managed to take a few pictures, and were seated shortly after that but near the door. If you complain about your seat or want to switch, you have to wait outside again so we braved the elements and the rush of wind from outside. 

Nanking is a well oiled machine and a tightly run operation. They're all about quick and efficient service here. You can't lolligag and take your time shooting the breeze here. They need to keep the tables going. Upon being seated we were given menus and water, the next time around she brought us our order of flower tea, and then took our dinner order. There's no "can you give us 5 minutes please?" So look at the menu or know what you want in advance. 

The Flower Tea is amazing. It's loose leaf tea and a flower bud. The flower bud opens up in the hot water and creates an amazing taste bud tantalizing flavor. It was perfect for the cold weather and there's nothing quite like it. 

Next up was our pork pot sticker appetizer. This was my first time trying pork and it was similar to chicken. I loved the flavor and the sauce. I could have easily had a few more. 

Our main dishes consisted of the house favorite - the sesame chicken, salt/pepper shrimp with mushrooms, and the chow mein. The sesame chicken was amazing. The chicken was perfectly spiced and crunchy and the green beans went along with it very well. The chow mein was a little too much for me. The sauce was very heavy and I could barely eat it. The shrimp and mushroom were also good. I preferred the mushrooms vs the shrimp though. 

Overall, I think this was an amazing meal. I would definitely come here again if I'm in town.
author: Sukhraj B.

description: Heard good things about this place, however when arrived and sat down we asked if they had any dishes Without MSG   When told no, we had to say we were going to have to leave, allergies from two of us.  They were SO RUDE about this and told us we needed to Tip???
author: Gayle F.

description: I would give House of Nanking 0 stars if I could. We ordered beverages when we arrived and our can of lemonade had some sort of food particle stuck to the tab. We sent it back, and the server returned with a Diet Coke. We told her we ordered lemonade and she delivered a can of lemonade to us. The food was great and we decided to take some of it home with us. That's when our experience took a nose dive. They brought to us a filthy takeout container that looked like they'd pulled it out of the trash. It had grease and food particles on the inside and outside of the container. We told them about it and told them this was unacceptable. They took the container, crushed it, threw it away, and brought a new container with very little apology. We asked for their manager and they acted like they didn't understand our request. Overall, they were not apologetic. We paid, left and will never return again. If you must go, don't order carryout or take anything home with you. Better yet, don't go. This place definitely has its filthy aspects.
author: M P.

description: On the wall it says quick and delicious. Whomever wrote that article was on point. The shuffle in this restaurant is crazy and fun to watch. The staff was friendly, quick, and to the point. You must try the "off the menu" beef with broccoli, egg rolls, sesame chicken too! The plates are huge, definitely a great place to share a little of everything. When we return to SF we are coming back to eat here. Four stars because I felt like they wanted us fed and out the door a little too quickly for my liking.
author: Cassandra M.

description:
I just walked out and I am very weirded out and felt like the servers were very rude to me. First off i came in and no one was there. But the servers jst kept talking in their language and touched their teeth and ignored me. I said i wanted to order a big to go order for family style. And the lady looked at me with a disgusted look shaking her head. So i said ok i will just pick from your menu. AND An older lady looked at me and told me no i am not gonna do orders for you. TOO many!

So i just said OOOHHH kay and walked out. I mean there was no one there! Its not like it was busy or anything. 

Dont order there for to go. You will waste your time walking.
author: Joelle C.

description:
Oh. My. God. You HAVE to get the fish soup. I'm sure it's not really called "fish soup" but it is a huge bowl of 6-8 servings for about $15. It is a MEDLEY of texture and flavor, from sweet to spicy to coconutty and a bit lemony - and then simmered with ingredients like basil, a fish whose name I'm unsure of (but is BONY and delicious - beware!), some fried tofu and dumplings plus some additional spices. It's NOT on the American menu - you have to ask for it. Or if you're lucky unlike me, you can order it off the Chinese menu, which I'd gotten for the first time in the multiple times I've been here.

Link to the picture here : ) It's an 8th of what actually comes in a HUUUUGE bowl: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/house-of-nanking-san-francisco?select=_8HKTTAUfE4Bme1k8YAm-Q#_8HKTTAUfE4Bme1k8YAm-Q
author: Lily T.

description: Whatever you do, make it at least once to this place.  Some of the tastiest Chinese I've ever had - and especially satisfying with friends for a family-style pig out.
author: Josh B.

description:
I thought I had left a review for House of Nanking already - I've only been here twice but I do enjoy it. My first experience had to have been my favorite - my ex, son and I had New Years Eve dinner here a few years ago and really enjoyed ourselves. We went all out and ordered probably around 10 or 12 dishes and completely feasted like it was our last meal on Earth. Everything was delicious.

I recently returned, alone - and wasn't sure exactly what to order being that it was only me. I ended up ordering the won ton soup and didn't care for it too much. I also wanted a protein dish so I went with the Sesame Chicken - it was very good but when I spotted someones Tofu dish come out, I wondered to myself - should I have ordered that instead.

I also ordered the fried rice because I was running a marathon the next day and was looking for some carbs! The soup came out right away and the chicken dish followed behind it but I waited almost 30 minutes for the fried rice, not sure what the deal was with that, but it was really good.

I'm sure I'll return in the future.
author: Candace L.

description: Went there for lunch on a week day, hoping to find some decent Chinese food. The food left much to be desired, and on top of that, a homeless man got into the restaurant, put his hand into my dish, took some food, and then got kicked out by the owner. The owner didn't even think of taking that dish off our check, and seemed rather upset when we asked to use credit card instead of cash. The combo bad food + owner's attitude didn't make a good first impression, so it is likely that I won't be returning to this place.
author: Ana K.

description: The line will always be long. But I have never waited more than 20 minutes for a table. The food is so good, it would be worth it even if the wait were over an hour. Definitely order the green beans and the sesame chicken. I don't even like Chinese food that much and I absolutely LOVE House of Nanking. I go there  every time I'm in SF. When I'm not there, I wish I could be.
author: Jenny J.

description:
Wow, after reviewing my recent SF check in's I realized I haven't reviewed a bunch of restaurants! I believe that House of Nanking needs to be reviewed. I've been here probably 5 times within the last few years and it's one of our favorite Chinese (Hunnan) food of all time. Yes it can get super busy here and service really isn't its strongest point although never poor, but come down here on off peak times and you will never have to wait. I've tried many of their dishes but recently we shared the sesame chicken and garlic fish. Both were amazing and I love their blooming teas.  It was a tough choice because the calamari is truly excellent too, I was just in the mood for chicken and fish on our recent visit. 

I can see why Nanking gets a lot of press in tour books. Great food, reasonable prices, equals a great meal and experience.
author: Aaron A.

description:
I have no idea what all of the fuss is about for this place. I certainly will seek other options when visiting San Fran. The staff was flat out rude. After being seated a woman finally came to take our order about 15 mins later. When she finally did her question was "what do you want"?
We had egg rolls, dumplings, noodles, and sesame chicken. The dumplings were excellent and I wished we ordered nothing but those. The rest was average to poor. Don't waste your time.
author: Jason P.

description:
Waited in line for about 15 minutes but it was worth it, as the line moves quick. Tight packed, we shared a table with another couple but it was alright, even though they didn't share their food with us. 
We order the house sesame chicken, fried calamari and lettuce wraps. The first two were fried, but you could barely tell. The flavor was superb. 
Prices were reasonable and portions are a little on the small side so maybe get 3 entrees for 2 people.
author: Kevin A.

description: We had been here before a few times and loved it. This visit was a little more meh. The waiter told us we had to order the Sesame Chicken instead of what we were planning and it felt like that was their mass produced for the tourists entree. Not spectacular and not as good as a previous trip.
author: Julia P.

description: Authentic food with a cool environment but the menu was lacking a lot of options. Sesame chicken was good as well as the salt and pepper shrimp.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
I can forgive almost everything is Chinese restaurants (bad service, dirty tables, slow food arrival, awful bathrooms) but I can't forgive the food not being at the very least edible.  

Ordered the sezchuan (sp?) beef and it was behind awful.  I tasted as thought they took hot & sour soup, left over rice (there were pieces of rices throughout the dish) and poured it over steak-ums.  So bad, I left it on the table (paid of course) and left--afraid to get sick.

Tasted like sh**t.  

Back in the day (15 years ago) this place was fun (if a bit pricey for Chinese food) place to eat for lunch.  

AVOID.
author: Max L.

description: THIS PLACE IS AMAZING!!!!!!! My family and I were greeted by the owner at our table.  As this was our first time, he insisted he pick our menu, we accepted hesitantly.  But Wow!  Every dish was delicious and not over the top.  Would definitely recommend.
author: Kristin N.

description:
The food is good, but the service and the attitude are so awful.....
The boss will give you an another Chinese handwriting menu if you speak Mandarin or Cantonese, and those dishes that listed on the handwriting menu are usually more expensive than other dishes on the English menu.
If you want to order some stuff from the English menu, they will strongly not recommend for the reason that those dishes are just designed for Americans, and "encourage" and force you to order those expensive dishes on the handwriting menu.
Anyway, the food is good but the service is so bad.
author: Will Z.

description: I ate here almost 10 years ago, and had high hopes of it being as wonderful as I have always remembered.  Basically, we were ignored for the first 20 minutes, then finally our order was taken.  The food was not nearly as good as I remembered that we didn't even even finish it after taking a few bites and decided to stop eating and have dinner elsewhere.  Safe your time if you plan on waiting in the crazy long line, and eat down the street at R&G for truly one of the best Chinese meals you'll ever have!
author: Meagan H.

description:
I ordered the Nanking chicken here and it was decent, not too salty which is usually my biggest complaint for chinese places.

My biggest complaint for this place is the one table setting for two that faces the window. My wife and I ate our lunch there, looking at the passerbys. She had just taken a picture of her plate on her phone meaning to IG it later. (Sorry yelp) and left it on the table. while we were eating, two thieves ran up and grabbed her phone thru the window and tried to steal mine and ran.

the restaurant is layed out like a maze of people so i couldnt run off after them. The owner suggested we call the cops if not for our lost phone (which i knew we were never going to see again) but for future tourists. who also might be eating at that same table.

the owner comp'd our meal for our trouble. so instead of a $420 meal, it was just a $400 meal if you include the lost iphone.

we called the cops and it turns out, the camera facing the street is a dummy camera, so no footage is being recorded. 

he was wearing a hoodie and hat on a 90 degree day. and somehow i'm sure it'll happen again, likely when someone spots a phone on a table and a guy runs in and grabs it.

so the TL;DR version, got seated next to a window, got our phone stolen, with 0 chance of catching the guy.
author: Tony Y.

description: The food was average, typical Chinese restaurant. I guess their infamy earns them their higher rating because it isn't much better than your local takeout Chinese.
author: Joshua W.

description: Was pretty busy on a random Tuesday night when we came for dinner - there was a line waiting out the door. We ordered the famous chicken with sweet potatoes, eggplant with garlic sauce, and shrimp packets. All very good! pretty greasy though (not for the weak-stomached)
author: Amanda L.

description:
Don't bother ordering from the menu if you're in a group. They will make "recommendations", which to be honest aren't actually bad. Our group of 5 were all pretty pleased with the taste of things.

Now on to the bad. They whole time you are there, it feels like they are rushing you. It's a small place, so they want people in/out quickly. By "recommending" dishes, it probably aligns with what the kitchen is making. The food came out almost immediately. 

While the food tastes good, in reality, all the seafood/meat has been deep-fried in some batter first before being stir-fried in some other sauce to make the dish. I can imagine this being great drunk food though.

It's definitely over-hyped, but it's still quite the experience. If you happen to come by the place, and there's no line, I would say go in, but I'm not going to wait for this.
author: Peter T.

description:
I just moved to SF...and have gone to a number of Chinese restaurants in the past couple of weeks.  I will not be going back to this one.  They didn't do anything wrong...just nothing right.

I care way more about food than service.  The service was slow.  But that's not why I'm docking stars.

I've heard great stuff about this place.  But the food just wasn't good.  The sesame chicken was overcooked and the pieces were small and mostly small pieces of the fried breading.  The eggplant appetizer wasn't bad...but didn't do enough to save the meal.  We didn't finish either.
author: Andrew D.

description: I came here after reading reviews and seeing the restaurant listed in an article as one of the best chinese restaurants in San Francisco.  I was disappointed.  Why?  The Melt-in-Your-Mouth Calamari tasted like it was on the verge of being rotten.  So fishy tasting and not fresh at all.  I've had tons of calamari in  my life - never like this.  So disgusting.  On the other hand, the sesame chicken and fried egg packets were delicious and their tea is a generous portion of flowering tea so for that, they saved their star-rating.  3-stars.
author: Maureen E.

description: It is not true Nanking food. It is American Chinese food. I didn't see any Chinese customers in the restaurant. The entrees on menu are not Nanjing food. The chief is not from Nanjing. The waitress was very rude and asked us to go to Nanjing for true Nanjing food.
author: Fangfang O.

description: Not a big fan of Chinese food but I found the offerings here quite good.  You know you found a good place when the locals are lined up outside raving about the food and the people walking out tell you that you won't be disappointed.   The shrimp pockets were yummy and so was the sesame chicken.
author: Dunia A.

description: This is that hole on the wall restaurant that you hear about being so great. It does not look like much but holy cow the food is amazing. They bring a menu but then pretty much come out and say "I'll take care of you" and they do bringing dish after dish of outstanding food. Extremely reasonably priced and you walk away loving everything. Don't miss it!
author: Tim B.

description:
Grab a table and a local brew, lay out the parameters of the food you want to come to you ("I'm a vegetetarian," "I love eggplant," "no beef dishes please,", whatever), and enjoy.  

All the food we had was uniformly excellent.  We had some foodies and rather particular food people at our table, and all of them were impressed.

The service is a bit abrupt.  Not rude, just abrupt.  But they were also nice when you consider that we showed up about 15 minutes before closing, and they were very accommodating nonetheless.

This is restaurant is apart from Chinatown, and is popular with vaguely hipster sorts.  If that sort of thing puts you off, make an exception, and don't allow it to dissuade you from coming here.  The food is excellent, and regardless of who else likes it, that's what really matters in the end.
author: Ken L.

description:
We loved the food here! There were no tables, so we got takeaway and had a cocktail across the road while we waited. 

It was still nice and fresh and hot by the time we got home, except for the calamari which wasn't as nice as I'm sure it would have been piping hot.
