The house noodles were unbelievably good- homemade noodles with pea shoots. And the vegetarian hot and sour soup was delicious- more like a stew than a soup. Lots of vegetarian options!
author: Anastasia J.

description:
The food was terrible. it was so crowded the person next to me was at my elbow.
It was Hot inside the restaurant.
The sesame chicken was so over cooked. was like a Fossil !!! Really I tell the truth.
DON'T waste Your Money or time
author: August S.

description: This place is amazing!! Big portions.. Great to go with friends and you can all order something different and have a taste of each other's. So worth the money. I didn't even have to wait in line when I went. It's a very small and cute place to dine when visiting San Francisco!!! Must go!
author: Tyler M.

description: Not a fan. The hype was over rated. Very crowded, squeeze them in as many as you can.. Fortunately our 'table mates were friendly folks. Schooled some British tourists on what 'tippinn' was because they became confused when the restaurant requested they use a card when they gave them exact change for their meal. (For real..) The food, which included their specialty was overrunneth with Five spice powder. Not my cup of tea, but if that's your spice of preference, this may be your place! Not worth the wait in line with so many other places to choose from in Chinatown.
author: Pamela K.

description: The food was very good.  We had noodles and the sesame chicken with sweet potato.   Enjoyed both very much!
author: Honest R.

description:
I went to this restaurant while visiting San Francisco. I decided to go based on an article that I read that this place was supposed to be the #1 place to eat in Chinatown. They did mention that the service was brusque there and they were right...... customer service is non existent.

I had the house fried rice, not the best I have. It was just ok.
The famous sesame chicken was just ok as well, not as good as I was expecting it to be.
author: C A.

description:
I'm from Dallas, Texas and I was visiting family in San Francisco last weekend. I absolutely loved this place. Our first bite of their steamed potsticker dumplings was magical and I usually don't even care for them. Every bite after that from our other dishes were just as amazing. It was so delicious that I had to pinch myself to make sure I wasn't dreaming. I wish I could I have taken some left overs to Texas but there was not any. I am craving another wonderful meal from here but since the bar is so high, I'm afraid the Chinese food here in Dallas can not compete. I will make sure to visit again when I am back. I may even bring a group of followers since I can't stop talking about it. 

Long wait is totally worth it.
Only 1 bathroom so had to wait.
Waiter was nice but not helpful for a first timer, although it was super busy food came out quick.
Small place but who cares the food is awesome. 
Price is great.

Had the sesame chicken and some bites from a beef plate.
author: Liza M.

description: Food was ok which is the only reason I'm giving 2 stars.  Menu was extremely limited, not a lot to choose from.  Staff was unfriendly and pushed us in and out.  They never once checked on us during our meal and never offered us more to drink.  Not sure I'd go back since there are literally hundreds of restaurants to choose from in China Town.
author: Katrina F.

description: Onion pancake and ginger beef good. House noodles ok
author: Duke A.

description: Used to be a favorite spot when we came 10 years ago.  Food was served cold and very bland. Almost no flavor and the meat was dry. So sad.
author: Sharla W.

description: My favorite restaurant in Chinatown, hands down. Excellent orange flavored chicken. Not too salty, not overcooked. Flavorful and as authentic as orange chicken gets for the price. The hot and sour soup was very memorable, wasn't too gooey like you find in some restaurants. Fried rice is fried rice, it was fine. I've been here a number of times, and as expected in SF- there is NO PARKING, so park in a structure nearby, and try visiting during non-peak hours. It gets packed quickly and you may be waiting a long time for a table.
author: Christina G.

description: Had to wait 20 minutes to eat here, it was really busy inside as usual. Ordered the sesame chicken and the noodle tower. Both were really good. They were sold out of the blossom tea but their other tea was good. Service was decent, some workers came off a little rude but nothing too crazy. Overall my experience here was good.
author: Zack C.

description:
Everytime I taste sugar in main dishes, I slightly freakout.   Sweetness to me belongs at the end of a meal, during dessert or at the beginning of the meal for those who eat dessert first, LOL.  Most of the sauces here are sugared, totally unappetizing.  It's like eating at Panda Express. The restaurant itself is hot inside and the food is boring.  Im sure it caters to certain clientele and they like to eat here, its just not for me.


JYFMY!
author: Will S.

description:
Minus one star for the customer service. "party of 6? U stay outside! Party of 4? Come in!  NOW!!" we waited outside for about 1/2 an hr before being seated. And they literally threw the plates and utensils at us.

Minus one star for the food residue on the fork they served us.

I do like how quickly they can whip up food dishes based on what u do and don't want to eat. For us we wanted "no beef & pork" so the waiter quickly said "veggie, seafood & chicken ok?" yes mam!

The food overall was "average Chinese food" although I'm not much of a fan. For starters, we had marinated bok choy (was a little on the bitter side but was rather refreshing to eat as an appetizer). Then came the calamari, which i thought was probably the best dish of the nite. It wasn't your typical "crunchy fried calamari" but rather a bit more chewy, but still good. It was drizzled with a coconut sauce that was actually quite tasty. The next dish was a "shrimp cake" which was basically Shrimp wonton with peanut sauce drizzled over it and I felt it was a bit overbearing & killed the flavor of the shrimp.  The final 2 dishes came out about 5 min later. Sesame chicken & fish filet with sauteed spinach. The chicken dish again, way too much sauce. So much so that i had to eat a bunch of rice to tone it down a notch. 

It took longer for us to get seated, then to actually order & eat. Will i come here again?? probably not by choice...but i'm glad i got to experience what the hype was all about. Blah.
author: Gina N.

description: This place is not your traditional Chinese food but everything here is very tasty! You gotta get the shrimp dish here and their beef is very tender and goes very well with the Bok Choy (Chinese cabbage).  I been to this place years ago when it was very small and just a hole in the wall type of place but now it has expanded.  There is always a line outside and I can see why!  They also serve tea in a huge beer mug glass.  Fast service and decent prices.
author: Rissa K.

description:
This place was recommended by my little brother who was up from LA. He did well!  The food is was very good. Ordering was an experience... First off, there aren't 100+ items to choose from like at many other Chinese places, and I liked that. 
 
.... So one of the owners (I'm guessing) arrives at our table and asks "what u like?" Chicken,beef,seafood, noodles,etc.  Before we could answer, she had written down 4-5 items and walked away? We looked at each other to figure out what had just happened. a few minutes later, food just began coming. Dish after dish kept showing up. After all was said and done, 7 dishes came and all were very tasty. I have no complaints at all. If you find yourself in the city, make an effort to try Nanking.
author: Brooklyn D.

description: Delicious!! Reasonable prices. We got the sesame chicken, house noodles and egg rolls. Everything was fantastic! Very friendly staff too!
author: Cindi S.

description: This place is littered with white tourists who obviously have no clue what good chinese food tastes like. I got dragged here by a non chinese coworker and needless to say my expectations were very low. We ordered a chicken dish and fried spare ribs... both were average at best.
author: Sheena N.

description:
I dined at House of Nanking back in January and finally decided to write a great review for a deserving restaurant. In a nutshell, this is one of the best cuisines I've ever had in my life. I've been reluctant to eat here for years because of the hype and many Yelpers labeled it a "tourist trap". Man, are they dead wrong -- including me!

The sesame chicken and panfried garlic fish are outstanding! I've seldom had my taste buds dance, but I was just floored that food can be that tasty. Amazing! I consider myself a bit of a foodie and a discerning home chef, so it doesn't come lightly when I say that HON is at the very top tier of great food experiences. 

Forget all the nay-sayers. Drop by and get wowed.
author: Dante G.

description:
Only reason I am giving this 4 instead of 5 stars is because prompt service is absent, BUT they do a good job of recommending delicious dishes and having the food come out fairly quickly even when they are slammed so it balances out. 
The Chinese food was awesome! Sesame chicken and fried onion cakes are a "must order" there because they are great and I had a few other dishes that were also very good--nothing I tried at the table was anything less than what I would call "really good Chinese food." 
I will definitely be going back.
author: Courtney F.

description: Chaotic atmosphere but it adds to the experience. Incredible food. A staff full of characters. I would totally recommend.
author: Tyler B.

description:
Waited in a long line on a December weekend to try this popular spot; it was worth the wait (which actually wasn't very long after all)!

Food:
We ordered the pork ribs, green beans, and the signature sesame chicken.  Since the little ones were with us, we asked the kitchen to make chicken and broccoli with no seasonings of any kind (which, after a couple of confused looks, they obliged).  Sesame chicken was very good as many other reviews state, and the sweet potatoes on the side were delightful, but my favorite was the pork ribs (baby backs).  Sticky, sweet, salty, and savory all at the same time. I could have eaten three orders.  Green beans added, well, some necessary green.  They were well-cooked and not over-cooked.  I saw other tables ordering soups, which looked amazing, and the calamari looked pretty good to me, too.  

Service:
It was obvious that many people read up on the "order quickly and don't make a fuss" policy here, because everything  happened super-fast.  Our food arrived very quickly, special order for the kids and all, which I thought would annoy the staff, but if it did, we didn't know it. When I needed another Tsing Tao, all I had to do was make eye contact with anyone (server, busser, whoever) and raise my empty bottle.  A quick nod acknowledged my request and thirty seconds later I had another cold one.  Other reviews mention "the angry lady," but we didn't experience any anger.  Just fast, efficient service.  And they do accept credit cards these days, which is great.

Vibe:
Dark, homey, and noisy in all the best ways.  Not a place to linger over your meal, especially since you are likely to be sharing your table with other diners, but that isn't a problem for us as the children rarely offer us the "lingering luxury" anyway!

Family-friendly:
Yup.  Just like all Chinese restaurants I have been to.  I especially liked the communal-table-style seating; when seated with "strangers," my kids are apprehensive enough to be quiet (at least at first), and then after they warm up they get a kick out of talking to the others at the table.  It's like built-in childcare, especially since others find our children much more charming than we jaded parents do by dinnertime...

Summary:
Solid food delivered quickly and many good dishes to enjoy.  Some may complain that the food is a bit less than authentic, but I don't care.  It's tasty food and I would not hesitate to come back alone or with the family.
author: Aneesh B.

description:
I took my parents here for a vegan meal as we'd heard the chef does special vegan dishes. In fact, the chef/owner came out and took our order personally; I felt like were were in capable hands even though he refused to tell us what he actually planned on making for us. "Leave it to me. Trust me," he said.

We started off with a scallion pancake which was huge and delicious. I love scallion pancakes in general, and this one was practically a meal in itself, covered in a heavy, but tasty, tamarind-based sauce. The sauce especially impressed my picky Indian parents.

For the main course we got a curry tofu dish with a variety of vegetables. My parents were also impressed with this dish. I liked the flavor of the sauce, but the dish was so oily without reason that I couldn't quite fall in love it. Mapo tofu is oily by default, but this dish, on the other hand, was just a curry stir-fry and didn't call for it to be oozing oil.

They don't offer brown rice here, which was both disappointing and surprising.

House of Nanking does offer an unusual experience for vegans and vegetarians looking for a good, non-mockmeat meal in Chinatown. Combined with the friendly service and the "in-the-know" feel that it imparts upon you, House of Nanking is recommended.
author: Kedar D.

description:
One of those greasy hole-in-the-wall places with a line out the door in SF's Chinatown.  

That line tells you all you need to know.  Order anything. My favorite is anything with yams and chili and protein!
author: Rachel H.

description:
This is a place I would normally walk by & ignore. If not for the recommendation from my hotel bell hop I'd never would have gone. The food was excellent. I would say a hybrid of New England style Chinese and authentic Chinese. 
It's small and my wife & I had to share a table with a family of 4 even though there was a open table for 6. The food is a little expensive but not really for a city like San Fran. 

I would recommend you try for yourself. We were pleasantly surprised
author: Jamie K.

description:
We are here for lunch on Sat at 3:30pm. We were expecting we were the only one here.. but we are wrong.. There were so many customers!
We ordered famous sesame chicken, pork spring rolls and onion pancakes. 
Everything was good. I liked pork spring rolls. Sesame chicken was good too but it was heavy for me.. but I don't really eat deep-fried dish and I grew up eating Japanese food which is really light, so probably it's just tasty for others.
Unfortunately service wasn't that great. 
Also they were out of jasmine tea.. They didn't have it a month ago either so we were little disappointed.
There is a big parking lot near by, so parking is easy and you can just need to walk a block.
author: Yoshie A.

description:
This is by far the best Chinese food I have ever had the pleasure of eating. This place is an experience and should not be missed when visiting SF! I was actually sad eating here knowing that it would probably be years before I made it back here again and that there is nothing that can even compare to this back home. 

Most of the negative reviews about this place are that the wait is too long or that they pack you in and rush you out. Well this is all true, but if you enjoy delicious food none of those things will matter. This is not the place to go for a quiet evening and a long multi course dinner. Come here to eat delicious food and maybe make some friends with other food lovers at your table and then move on so that more ppl can enjoy the same experience. 

I hope you all enjoy Nanking as much as we did. I'll be dreaming of it for years to come!
author: Jennifer W.

description: Great spot. Amazing wonton soup and Nanking chicken. Clean and most staff friendly. Came here for lunch, hubby and I were very satisfied with our meal and service.  Reasonably priced too!  Def worth checking out.
author: Jewelz C.

description: I ate at House of Nanking a few years back and really enjoyed it. Went last week, and should have been tipped off by the fact that the entire restaurant was full of Caucasians. The food was more Panda  Express fare than authentic Chinese.
author: Lori T.

description: I visited House of Nanking with some coworkers, one of which was vegetarian, and we were served a feast! Everything was served family-style, and we enjoyed every dish we tried. Everybody left full and happy.
author: Jessi M.

description: Horrid place.  The service was terrible.  Awful, the place was dirty and all three of us were poisoned by one (or maybe more) of the dishes.  On the plus side, I didn't gain any weight from the meal since I threw up all night!  Gross.  Gross.  Gross.
author: D H.

description: This doesnt taste like nanjing at all!! The dishes were overpriced and waiters were rude...
author: Chang L.

description: The pancake with scallions really stands out! I saw other people ordering things which aren't on the menu, I wish they would disclose everything.
author: Basima L.

description: Best Chinese food I have ever tasted. If you are craving Chinese today stop searching and go now. Service is good, direct, quick and no wasted time on conversation but the food is great.  Not a tourist trap or fufu restaurant ... best Chinese food I have ever tasted...  get the camalara, sesame chicken, pork chops and union cake and fried rice.
author: Glenn S.

description:
this is definitely an authentic Chinese food place for two reasons. 1st: terrible service 2nd: great food. 

Worth every penny
author: Ian D.

description: Thanks for the response, Kathy.  We visited your restaurant on Tuesday, October 8 at 2pm.  Hope this information helps your investigation.
author: Miriam M.

description: I ordered this through the app OrderAhead, and it was disgusting. Obviously not the apps fault, but it is SO weird because I've eaten there twice before; the most recent being about 3 years ago and it was amazing. Idk if ownership changed or the chef changed or what, but I got the house noodles which had no flavor, the calamari which was soggy and made my stomach hurt it was so limp and rubbery. I also got the lettuce wraps, which was maybe my fault because I did not know it was all vegetables which was gross. I was SO disappointed because I got so happy that it was able to be delivered, and then I get it and it was like a slap in the face. Idk what happened to the food, but it was extremely subpar.
author: Camille C.

description: Love this place. If it's your first time, can't go wrong with the spicy dumpling soup (which serves at least 2), pea shoots, general tso's chicken and stir-fried fish.  We also got the noodle tower thing but I wasn't a huge fan. There's usually a wait esp after 6 pm but it moves fast.  Parking can be hit or miss but there's a cheap public garage nearby (forgot the name).
author: Emily L.

description:
Dropped in with my boys during a vaca in SF.  I've been before and had been referred by a friend who is nutty about all asian food.  I wouldn't call it the best chinese in SF but I've never gone wrong here.

We ordered Calamari, House Noodles and Sesame Chicken.  The sesame chicken was perfectly cooked and the sauce was very tasty (and not overpowering).  The dish also came with yams that my kids scarfed up as quickly as the chicken.  Calamari was solid and not too chewy.  It was served with a side sauce with a good spicy flavor.

Staff was OK but it was a slow time (weekday - midafternoon).
author: Steven C.

description:
For over a decade I've been hearing about a Chinese food restaurant located in Chinatown that has amazing food that I had to try. Although I'm not one to feed into over hyped opinions about restaurants, I finally had the opportunity to try it this place out so I took advantage of it. So last Sunday My wife and I took two friends and tried out their lunch menu. My wife loves the food here and will always be a fan. Unfortunately for me it did not live up to all the hype.

When we first arrived parking was just terrible and almost impossible to find. The location of the restaurant is in the area of china town where it is so clustered and busy that it can be a headache to find parking. Let me put it like this, unless you get lucky and find street parking you're going to have to park in a garage. Luckily we found street parking so we then walked to the Resturant  and I realized that it's a small place. Due to the size there's not much wiggle room to sit down and feel comfortable in. There's very little to no space in-between you and other tables. This can make things very tight and at times uncomfortable. Also the restaurant has very dim lighting, which makes it hard to see others if you're there to entertain friends or family.

So we were shown to our table which had a rustic look and feel to it. It had some classic charm to it but the chairs are small and made out of wood. So after a while sitting down can be very uncomfortable. Another thing I noticed is that due to the size there must be little, to no room in their back storage area. Because they keep a lot of their beer, as well as other things up front. It kinda makes things look chaotic. There's beer, and a bunch of random supplies all over the place. It should be in back-stock but unfortunately with no extra space, they just leave it in the dinning area. I guess you can say their making the best out of a bad situation.  So We ordered the Potstickers as appetizers then moved on to the main courses of chow mein, fried rice and sesame chicken. Followed by the fried onion cake drizzled with an amazing peanut sauce. I mean this peanut sauce is so good that you can put it on a shoe and eat it!! Lol

The food was delicious and had flavor but in my opinion it was good, not great. The fried rice had tons of vegetables in it and at times a little bit too much. So much that during some bites that's all I tasted. I would've preferred a better balance between the rice, vegetables and meat. The chow main had a little bit of a salty after taste too, but it still held its own and I would recommend it. Once again you get more onions and saltiness in every bite more than anything else. The sesame chicken was good and one of my favorites of all The dishes I had there. Although, I do wish the actual pieces of chicken were little bit bigger, it still was one of the highlights of the meal. Unfortunately with the Sauce glazed over the chicken it was a little bit dry and could've used a little bit more tenderness to it. So the last dish was the onion cake. It was a tasty dish as well but with the large amount of onions in it, if you're not a fan of cooked onions then I suggest you don't order it. I felt the peanut sauce created a great balance and allowed me to enjoy a dish that it comprised of mostly onions.

Ultimately the place is decent and I would definitely go back to try other dishes but don't believe all the hype. Try you're best to ignore what everybody says and simply make your own decision on this location. based off of what I was told and for so long. I don't think it could've ever live up to what I envisioned.
author: Donald W.

description:
3.5/5 sometimes cash only, be prepared!

came here with a coworker as we had a conference at the hilton across the street. always been a fan, and it was legendary among friends when we used to go to cal. we were greeted warmly and just chanced on an awkwardly placed table for 2 (which is really any space that will allow 2). had to shuffle a bit to let other sit/leave, which kinda made the experience a little disjointed. we ordered some veggie dishes and the chef offered up a couple extras (portobello and fried chile) for free! hot tea to warm against the fog, and it was a great meal.
author: Alvin D.

description:
I would give them a solid 4 stars based on this, my first visit.  Our service was quick, perfunctory and in most Chinatown spots that is all you get.  Exceptions to that rule are if you are a regular patron, then you are treated like a friend.  So, I won't complain if the wait staff if not "Oh Hai!  How are you Dear"  they were not rude and the food came out of the kitchen quickly and hot.  

I ordered the Nanking Chicken and would do so again.  It is their version of a sweet and sour, but the chicken is not a heavy, breaded fried affair.  It's light, dusted with cornstarch and deep fried, tossed in a garlicky sweet sauce, but not drowned in it.  Came with a plate of rice that was enough to feed 4.  Next time I will ask for a rice bowl, no need for that much rice.

We were given the only option of a lunch menu.  Next time I will know better to ask if they will let me have a full menu.  

My companion had the house special chow mein, I had a taste.  It was good, white meat chicken and spicy enough.  He said on his next visit he would order what I did.

I will be back for the salt and pepper shrimps, that is a must try and/or the calamari!

When the bill was brought she was insisting we use our credit card and seemed a bit miffed we were paying cash.  I think, for no good reason, future visits will be cash only, as well.  ;-)  ymmv.

In it's past life this place had to have been an Italian joint or a bar with the wood paneling and heavy wooden tables and chairs.  That said, I loved it.  Unique for a Chinese place!
author: Donna H.

description: I am very disappointed with this restaurant. It's name is Nanking restaurant, but it doesn't have any Nanking style food. The waiters and waitresses are Cantonese. It is also not clean at all. The table has chewing gum! The food is very bad. We ordered fish and found the fish was not fresh. To be honest, this is the worst Chinese restaurant I have had in Bay Area. Terrible experience!
author: Youzhong W.

description:
The food is absolutely amazing although the customer service could be worked on. If you are okay with that then you should defiantly drop on by if you are in the area. I personally am coming back next time I'm in Chinatown.

Also try the blooming tea, it's a favorite of mine.
author: Chris B.

description:
Amazing place!!! I went in with no expectations and no idea on what to order. When the waiter/owner came over he asked what we would like.... I told him we had never been to his restaurant. He took the menu's wrote something down and right after that the food began to roll in. They brought us almost everything on the menu and everything was amazing. 

Family style so with a group of 7 everyone got to eat a small portion of everything. At the end no one was hungry or overly stuffed.
author: Vincent V.

description: I would say this is the best Chinese food I've ever eaten.  By far.  Shocked by the mediocre reviews, however I read a few and I get it.  The staff is not over the top friendly, and it is always packed.  And, you do have to sit at tables that are usually right next to other people who you don't know.  If you have a social fobia and don't want to be around people, this is NOT the place for you.  If you want friendly Chinese folks to wait on you hand and foot, not the place for that either.  It has to have 4 stars though because the food is out of this world.  I don't like that the soda is served in a can, because well, there's not much soda in one can.  And, the waitresses probably won't check back on you when it's drank.  It is what it is.  But, to be in the heart of one of America's greatest Chinatowns, and eat food that will make you want to slap your Momma - or at the very least slap the rude waitresses, you just can't pick a better place.  The owner serves food too and everyone might me borderline rude, but they are working very hard.
author: Todd G.

description:
Not real Chinese food, but I'd eat this.
The food and service don't match. Seems they're trying way too hard to resemble the service of a Chinese restaurant from "an episode of Seinfeld". While the " get in, eat, get out " factor of this place may help make this dining experience "real Chinese", the food is far from it. Maybe this is to be expected nowadays from the historic Chinatowns of American big cities.
This place is a tourist trap and a bit of a disappointment. From the moment you walk in, the one thing you will immediately notice, is the lack of Asian persons eating here. Having, lived, worked, made Asian friends, and dined in the San Gabriel Valley for 16 years, this was a red flag. Chinese restaurants in the SGV don't make their food to serve tourists, they make it to serve Chinese people that don't speak a word of English, that just came from China, and demand only authentic delicious, and reasonably priced (due to the competitive market here) of Chinese restaurants. 
Check out this article about San Gabriel Valley Chinese food, from 1999 but it applies even more so today ;

 http://m.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/1999/01/going-all-out-for-chinese/305473/
 

    When a place like this automatically tacks on an 18% gratuity charge for a group of 4 adults and one 5 year old, it should be another red flag, and for their slightly better than nonexistent service, a joke at that. I see reviews before me have mentioned or complained about them charging an automatic gratuity, and the management/owner exclaim as to how " appalled" or "surprised" they are, and that they would like to pinpoint the problem to resolve it. Well guess what? Months and months and months later they're still doing it, so obviously they have to intention of stopping the scamming of people that don't check their bill, so Kathy, please spare me the fake lines of your shock. Also, please clean your clear glasses more thoroughly, in particular, things that resemble freshly picked snot. We did not drink the water, needless to say.
 We ordered a crispy chicken, fried chicken, like an orange chicken of some sort, and there were yams, instead of Asian sweet potatoes. Yams are for traditional Thanksgiving dinners, not Chinese food.
Fortunately I like yams,  I'm not a Chinese food purist snob, although I prefer it authentic, and so the yams worked for me.
Again, don't come here thinking you're going to get Chinese food, rather, you will be getting Chinese inspired food.
As a side note, hardly any, if any at all, of just about every single Chinese restaurant I have ever been to in the vast San Gabriel Valley area, has ever had service as crappy and rude as this. Although these places may differ from what traditional Americans consider good in terms of hospitality, they still provide quick, well focused, cordial service, without being in your face, asking if is everything OK every 5 minutes. Maybe the idea that Chinese restaurants give crappy service comes from the comical exaggerated movie and TV depictions, and the mistake of comparing traditional Chinese restaurants to traditional American ones. This place takes it too far.

Minus points for lack of authenticity
Minus points for crappy service
Minus points for hygiene
Minus points for stupid auto 18% gratuity charge
Minus points for pissing me off by saying something in Chinese when i asked about the 18%, and thinking I wouldn't understand you.
Plus points for decent, although not real Chinese food.

PS. I've lowered my rating due to management's response to complaints and negative reviews with a generic " we hope you will give us another chance by coming and spending your money here again."

Right right; your staff sure doesn't act like a "fusion" type of place. More like a no class type of place.
author: Juan P.

description:
Amazing!  It's been a few months since I ate there but I still think about my meal every now and then.  The reviews are not lying - the sesame chicken is divine!  Forget about greasy, fatty, double-deep fried pieces you get at other places.  The sesame chicken here is seasoned just right, just enough flavor and lightly fried, making it the perfect companion with fluffy white rice.  The tea is served in huge beer jugs and the other dishes we had were amazing too.

I'm a Chinese food snob and this place blew away my expectations.
author: Michael P.

description:
Strictly living on its reputation. Surly staff and service. They throw the food at you. The food has lost its mojo as well. 

There are so many much better cutting edge asian restaurants that are worthy of the price.
author: Robert W.

description: This place was everything I wanted it to be. This was my first time in San Francisco China Town and it was so delicious. I had the house noodles and they were amazing. So fresh and good. I wish I knew how to re-create them at home. Make sure you let them know if advance if you want it on different checks... that was an issue. Customer service wasn't great, but the good and fast food made up for it.
author: Becky W.

description:
I have been wanting to try this restaurant out for ages and I finally did. Ive read rave reviews about it and it always seems to be quite busy.

To start off with I had the detoxifying cold tea which was really lovely. I love the bits of fruit that are in it! And the best thing about it are the free refills. I had 3 of them and they were very refreshing. 

I ordered the Fang's Panfried Garlic Fish (crusted in Asian spices, served with seasonal garlic chinese veggies [bok choy i think and some onion] ) along with rice. My first impression was that the serving was quite small for $13.95 especially considering it didn't include rice. The fish was very airy and light, the greens very sweet, not as spicy as I would have liked but it was very good and I left feeling satisfied. 

The service was fine I dont know why people have issues with it. I quite like to be given my drink and order and be left alone.

I do recommend coming to this place in a group of friends or family so you can try as many dishes as possible although they are quite pricey and that is one reason I am only giving HONK 3 stars. They must be making good margin on the products they serve. 

This is not a place to have a leisurely quiet long supper at. Order fast eat and enjoy and leave. The staff are very quick to get you out as soon as possible and there's no question why considering the massive queue for their food. 

Glad I didn't order the sesame chicken which seems to be quite common among Chinese Restaurants apart from the Sweet Potatoes. Good thing Im not keen on Sweet Potatoes...

Will be coming back again but this time with a group of ppl. Happy eating! 

House of Nanking conveniently accepts credit cards.
author: Julian I.

description:
I was in SF for one night and one night only and it happened to be my birthday.  This place came recommended from a friend and it did not disappoint.  Like many reviewers before, once the waiter heard that it was our first time, our menus disappeared and they just started bringing out the dishes.  While some might find this disconcerting, it was the perfect scenario for a birthday dinner where I wanted to spend as much time catching up with my local friends instead of reading a menu.  Especially after a long day of sightseeing it was nice to not even have to think about what to order.  

There was soup, shrimp, fish, scallops, beef and chicken, the dishes kept coming at the perfect pace and stopped at the perfect point before we were too full.  I loved it.  Everything was delicious and while it may not have blown me out of the water, it exceeded my expectations and we had a blast and for that NanKing you get 5 stars from this Chicagoan.  

There's always a line I hear, but it moved very quickly and we were seated within 15 minutes of arriving on a Monday night.  

Did I mention that the bottles of wine are $14 and aren't too shabby?  Yeah we definitely took advantage of that good deal :)
author: Caroline B.

description: The food is remarkable. The atmosphere could be much worse. All in all, I would recommend checking out the House of Nanking for some really good Chinese food made really well. The dumplings with peanut sauce are wonderful. Get a side of green beans. Your mom will be proud and you won't regret it.
author: Rob M.

description: Oh how we LOVE this place!!  There's usually a line.  But a quick secret is one waits in line and the other goes next door to the bar (I don't know the name, but it's clean, cheap and cool) and get a shot--and then switch places with the other in line.  Eventually you're gonna be seated, it might be a solo table or a communal--don't fret, AMAZING YUM food is coming!!  Service may be quick and abrupt, or very friendly.  It really doesn't matter, the food is THE KEY!!  Now I don't know the "technical" names for our faves, we just order: the bean shoots, the fried chicken, steamed rice, corn chowder, and the fried eggplant!!  Oh, and two iced teas with lemon.  They deliver when food is ready, and the eating extravaganza begins!!  Use your BIG WORDS if you need something; it will be served QUICKLY.  Add some hot-pepper paist/sauce or maybe a beer! To-go containers are available. This really is about the food NOT the "hoity toity" please serve me NOW experience.  It's LEGIT!!!  This is a family restaurant, and many have waited on us, the ACTAUL owner/patriarch has as well!!  Love this place!!  Love SF!!  We'll be back soon enough!!
author: A H.

description: Food is good, prices are reasonable. If you do not know the restaurant, the people who run the place seem only too happy to recommend and feed you what they think you like. I have taken friends from out of town there, and we have not regretted that yet.
author: Namm L.

description: The food is great. The service acts a bit rushed. The seating is a bit awkward. Go there for the food.
author: William W.

description: Some of the best Chinese food in the city! The place is very small and they crowd you in but the food is well worth the crowds and the wait. This is a must visit for me when I'm in the area.
author: Justin M.

description: This is not Nanking food.just like the Taiwan food. But it is ok, lots of American like it, so funny.
author: Yunxiang Z.

description:
I'm speechless. For the past couple of years I've heard countless people including several SF tour companies talk up this place. I finally tried it...MEH!

Out of the four dishes we shared, the only slightly authentic dish was the crispy rice dumpling soup. The chow mein was really bland and more like Italian noodles, spinach & ginger scallops terribly salty and the green onion cakes were dough with a ton of scallions cut. I'm no virgin to any Asian food and seriously wandered what type of Asian food I was eating. It certainly wasn't the type of Chinese I've enjoyed in countless SF hole in the walls.

My hope is that tourists will venture to clement street or elsewhere to sample SF's Chinese food.
author: Leanne S.

description:
This meal revitalized me after I died the night before, so House of Nanking will always have a special place in my heart.

My friend, Eggplant and I ate the sesame chicken with sweet potatoes and also that eggplant dish that everyone likes (yep, Eggplant ate eggplant).

The worst part of the meal was the rude man who shushes.  He's the gangly server that takes the drink orders and later ignores you.  He shushed my friend for simply trying to look at him.  Eggplant didn't deserve to be sushed.   

The shushing incident aside, this was a revitalizing four star meal.
author: Geoff B.

description:
Well, I liked this restaurant for a while, but today I was really disappointed and shocked. After the meal, the bill was outrageous. The server added $5 as a tip for himself in every copy of the bill. WTF?? Well, and another server was waiting for me to sign the bill and I think she was worried that I may rewrite the (automatically) added tip part. This was pretty unpleasant experience. Well, they might earn $5 this time, but they lost one customer forever. 

If you guys go to this restaurant, please look at the bill closely. They may have added tips already in your bill.
author: Joohyun K.

description: I was not happy with my overall experience here. The service was rude (I didnt take it personally, but there is clearly a language barrier), the meals were not explained very well, and the price was outrageous. I ordered calamari and ended up having a pool of butter with squid chunks. It was good for the first few bites, but afterwards, it became too much. I really feel I should have ordered something else, but at the time I was focused on seafood (since Texas fails in that area). Maybe Im being too harsh, but all I can say is if you want super buttery calamari and a fat check to pay, then have fun at this place.
author: Gill S.

description:
I have to give them a star in order to write a review but seriously House of Nanking deserves -100 stars! 

The tables are lined up like benches in order to fit as many customers in as possible. The staff doesn't give you enough time to read the menu, which lacks in vegetarian options. We ordered and when the pushy server brought us our drinks she threw my straw at me. 

My dinner companion's food came out before mine. No biggie, I took a bite of his and it was way to salty. Be warned that once you order the server does not come back to the table. Not even for refills. I got up and walked over after 10 minutes to ask if my lettuce wraps would be arriving soon. She forgot to place the order. When the wraps finally did arrive they tasted entirely of pepper. At that point we asked for our check and found another restaurant. 

AVOID THIS PLACE LIKE THE PLAGUE!!!!
author: Jen S.

description: Best Chinese Restaurant period! Came with a party of five, there was a line outside but.....totally worth it. Food, wine and treas are exceptionally good. Will be back soon.
author: Nutty V.

description:
Heard about this place from a friend and wanted to try it out. Cute hole in the wall .. cozy and comfy. The furniture takes one back to one of the six different dynasties Nanjing once was the capital of. We all can agree that Chinese restaurants don't have the friendliest staff and this place was one of them. The only smiling one was the girl that returned back my CC after paying for lunch. English isn't their strength either. Ordered TWO drinks and got one only. It was a bit hard to communicate about the menu as well BUT once the food was placed on the table all worries disappeared. The taste of their dishes were exceptional. Hot and sour soup, chicken chow mein and chicken fried rice. 3 diff dishes and my taste buds were on cloud 9 somewhere above Jiangsu Province. If you are in the area, try it out. It is worth the "Two coke" order/ one delivered. Prices are good and the portions are pretty big. So what the waiter doesn't speak (well) English and doesn't smile ?!? The cook adds all his/her love to each dish they prepare. 
Only one bathroom, but very clean.
author: Chrissy T.

description: This place was recommended by a SF aficionado and it is definitely good. The menu is nice, but it's the dishes off the menu that you want. What we've done both times is told our server our price limit and told her to surprise us with a handful of dishes. I'm not sure what the dishes were called, but they all left us happy.
author: Ashley E.

description: This is the worst chinese restaurant i have ever been to.  It must be in guidebooks or something because there is always a long line outside-- don't believe the hype.  We ordered a couple dishes from the americanized menu.  FIrst of all, the servingware is disgusting.  We were served near boiling-temp soup in a plastic bowl that was peeling.  I could barely eat it.  The water cups were also plastic (but I did notice that foreign looking tourists got glass cups).  Everything felt oversalted and msg-filled.  I feel bad for tourists who come here and think this is the best chinatown has to offer.
author: T Y.

description:
God I love Kathy!

I'm from NY so I can hang with the rudeness...er....abrasive behavior and quite enjoy it. The wife had never experienced so I took her and the 2 little ones on Dec 30th.

Line was 7 minutes tops. Ordered right away and Kathy immediately scolded me, "You order too much!!!!" - but the food, as always, was delicious.

The wife tried to pay Kathy a compliment but Kathy just turned her head away as if to say, "I know it's good, dear, you don't have to tell me."

So that was me, Kathy who punched you in the shoulder with a smile and said, "good to see you again." - I hope it hurt :)

See you again when I'm S.F.
author: Matthew B.

description: It's my go to spot in the city. Traveled close to 20 years now to SFO for fun and work. Such a consistently great meal.
author: Bart J.

description: What happened?  Modified menu with much fewer offerings than in the old days so they can get peeps in and out quicker??? So sad to see this iconic fun place turn into a greasy spoon with no personality, flavor or chicken in the sesame chicken pieces! Yuck!
author: Nan R.

description:
Hits the spot if you are craving Chinese comfort food! If you want to eat healthy food and avoid grease, don't come here. 

Service is fast and no-frills. The waitstaff became much more friendly after I started speaking Chinese to them. 

The food is somewhere between American-Chinese fast food and fine dining at R&G lounge.
author: Sylvia W.

description: Tracked this place down based on a friend's "got to go if you want Chinese" recommendation. Some don't like community tables and almost too quick service, but frankly it gets me to the food faster. The navy vets we sat next to told us to start with the hot and sour soup and pot stickers and just let the staff choose the rest. Contrary to some reviews, we got plenty of smiles from staff and good choices for food without hesitation. The star was the honey beef over bok choy. My only regret was not asking for something else off menu. Dishes were flying out of the kitchen so fast that you had to make sure you weren't delivered your neighbours dish or vise versa, but maybe that was half the fun. I'd be happy to come back.
author: J K.

description: Terrible service. Noodles weren't even cooked properly. They obtained an 87 from food safety, which was evident in how they handled their food.
author: Gloria S.

description: Incredible food, very nice staff.  We had the Sesame Chicken and the cold sesame noodles and both were really delicious and so much better than your run of the mill Chinese food AND the prices were very reasonable!  Sat near the window for prime people watching.  Definitely recommend this place to those in San Francisco's Chinatown who are unsure of where to go!
author: Adam S.

description:
We got the sesame house chicken with sweet potato and fried tofu with broccoli in black bean sauce. Both were delicious. 

Very touristy. 
Nice interior decor. 
Busy and loud. 
Quick service. 
Good sized portions.

They only accept one credit card and cash. So don't go thinking you split the bill on two or more cards.
author: Ali B.

description: I took my family here on the first night of a big Christmas vacation from so Cal. A friend recommended it, so we thought that we would give it a shot. Right from the moment we walked in, the people were relatively dismissive and uninterested in service, they pointed to some seats, where we sat and waited for someone to speak to us, a woman came and threw menus at us, a few minutes later a man came and asked about drinks, we ordered a few beers and waters, then the lady comes by again wanting to know what we wanted to eat, no conversation or even a smile, very matter of fact. We ordered food, I ordered the scallop towers, we ate our food, which wasn't especially flavorful or remarkable, but we paid and left. Later that night I got horribly sick and am just now 4 days later getting over it. I got some bad food! I could not in good conscience recommend this place to anyone!
author: Steve B.

description:
I have to agree with Juan P. in everything that he wrote. 

This place is a huge TOURIST TRAP and unauthentic Chinese cuisine. It should've been a red flag when majority of the customers were non-Asians.. The food came out fast but our bok choy and potsticker dishes were undercooked. On top of it all, all the dishes came out drenched in sauce and lots of oil. 

I usually don't expect much of a service from Chinese restaurants and I'm ok with their lack of attentiveness. But when it was time to pay the bill, they hover over you and demand that you tip at least 15%. WTF.

Never coming here again. It's a shame that a restaurant with so much history is such a disappointment.
author: Anj H.

description:
What's the sign of a truly great restaurant?

Every single time you go, you just can't wait to go back!

Every time you go and sit at a table and see some gloriously steaming plate come out of the kitchen and land on someone else's table, you follow it with lusty, envious, popping-out eyes as you wonder: "what's that?!? I want some!" :-)
                                            
Every time you go and look at the menu, you can't make up your mind whether to order the same great stuff you had last time or the other stuff you wish you had ordered last time!

That's the  House of Nanking (or "House of Nan(do)king," as I call it! :-) ) for you!

Looooooooooooove them lunch specials, too! Unbeatable! ;-)
author: Nando G.

description:
First, I've have never written a restaurant review but was so appalled that I felt compelled as so many said that the food is the best Chinese in SF. For me this was absolutely the worst Chinese food I've ever eaten. The owner (?)/ hostess came to my table and I asked if they had Kung Pao Chicken. She said, "we make for you". What arrived was over cooked fried chicken pieces with no flavor or any spiciness. After taking a few bites, it was apparent this had no relationship to any Kung Pao preparation I've ever had. I called the woman over and she says, "you no like"?  I told her the above and she took the dish away and returned w a dish of undercooked chicken that appeared to have set out for some time that they covered with pepper flakes. It was tasteless except for the pepper which made it so hot it was inedible. No peanuts but had apples and carrots...really. She said too many people were allergic to peanuts. Oh, thanks for telling me. My other dish was pork dumplings the skin so fried it acted as a shield to protect the contents and covered with a sweet sauce that I've never had served w pork dumplings. The sauce was so bad that I couldn't even tell what the contents of the dumpling was by taste.

Perhaps a bad night but...
author: James D.

description:
Peter still visits this restaurant, I just saw him the other day. Calm down.

I love coming here, also brought my parents here and they liked it a lot. My favorite dish is the peashoots with garlic. You can request for it to be spicy. It's so simple and has so much flavor. The noodle tower, meh. Not enough sauce. Yes to the eggplant! One time we just asked the lady for a mushroom dish, I cannot remember what it was called at Fang, I just said, that REALLY good one! She nodded in confusion and put in our order. It came out nothing like the one we ate at Fang, but a yummier one! It was dry and I hate button mushrooms, but it was coated with very simple spices and it was perfect.
author: May G.

description:
With over 1750 reviews I expected more. The food is wonderful. 4.5 stars for the food.

But the service is questionable. I've never dined in but I always sit at a table and watch while I wait. Keep hoping to be offered hot tea or water. Nope. 

Today is a perfect example of typical Nanking service. We entered, a robust man was blocking the isle. I squeezed past to a corner where I could study the menu for a moment. Suddenly an Asian woman brushed past me to sit down and continue eating. From the plastic dish I assumed correctly she was an employee. So I stated my desire to order to go.

"What do u want?" Spoken rapidly between hurried bites. ( now some people would be offended by her eating while taking my order but I coulda asked a different employee, plus having worked as a server for years I know how rare and priceless time to eat before a sat dinner shift is. I told her a menú and she pointes to one chubby guy finally released. Just then my boyfriend alerted me he had been seated so I joined him.

When a server came by to take our order I asked for dumplings and sesame chicken. I asked if they could make the chicken not fried. I was told no. I asked if there was a dish of chicken prepared not fried. Yes the sauteed. Well can I have sesame sauce on that? Nope.. sigh.. trying to eat healthy is tough lol.

The chicken was amazing. Who knew. 

My boyfriend ordered combo fried rice. We get back to hotel and two things were wrong. No dumplings and no meat in the fried rice. 

My boyfriend went back to fix the order. Was rudely told we paid for what we got. Uhm ok woulda happily paid for what I wanted.

Sigh...
author: Lisa H.

description: Still love this place. Still had the best fish soup and 菜泡饭。 also most tender beef ever! Love that it has Americanized dishes and very authentic Chinese dishes
author: Maria W.

description: This place always has a line out the door. It's always fun with a group. It started real small, expanded and got a little bit fancier. It is not really authentic Chinese food, but the more popular westernized version of Chinese food done up to be more fancy catering to caucasian tastes kind of like PF Chang's. It's a real crowd pleaser. I don't really look at it as Chinese food, but as a new fusion concoction, but the food is pretty good, nonetheless. The owner, Fang, opened another similar even fancier place by the Moscone Convention Center called Fang's.
author: Peter K.

description:
Best Chinese food in San Francisco, without a doubt. Line out front? Stick it out. Their staff turn people over real quick.  Be ready to get settled up with another table of randoms who are all going to be struggling through a coma of satisfied consumption.  I will go here anytime a friend is in town and wants to try an authentic chinese food joint.

Sesame Chicken, melt in your mouth calamari, potstickers, onion cake.  All amazing, super reasonable with price and just top notch all around.
author: Kevin O.

description:
I wish there was a 3 1/2 since the food wasn't that great to me but the overall experience was fun so I'll round up.

I went with this place to a guy I had met around SF while I was down there for orientation for a new job. R&G Lounge had a 45 minute wait and I'm not willing to wait that long for a place I don't know so we walked around Chinatown when we stumbled upon House of Nanking. 

Very packed so me and the guy sat in a little two seater in the corner. This was at the beginning of the trip so I could still squeeze in to get to my seat. I looked over the menu and it seemed like typical Chinese fare. A cute little old man came up and asked if this was our first time then said he'll "take care of us" as he was the chef and owner.  I told him that I didn't want the typical Orange/Sesame/General Tso's chicken-sugar-hybrid and wanted something authentically Chinese.

We started with an appetizer that was a huge mushroom that was cut and put on our plates. We then got this fish dish and beef bok choy. The fish dish was okay; I think it tasted like something my grandma would cook so it didn't seem like anything different what I typically eat. The beef boy choy, on the other hand, is a different story. Very, very tender beef that just melts in your mouth. A bit of curry spices, boy choy, and some stir-fried onions made it a very delicious dish. Definitely would come back just for this.

We got the bill and the mushroom was $10! That blew my mind. $10 for just a mushroom?! The beef bok choy was around $17 and the fish was around $15. So, I only really liked one of 3 dishes. 

If you do manage to come here, get the blooming flower tea! The tea is served in a mug with a little plant that literally blooms after a few minutes in the hot water. Coolest thing ever.
author: Gina T.

description:
I do not recommend this restaurant.  Read about it and was majorly dissapointed.  The sesame chicken was overfried, chewy and barely could taste the chicken. 
The service was a bit rude.
Calamary was so so.  

We were so looking forward to some good Chinese in the city and were disappointed.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Thank you Rachael Ray for recommending House of Nanking! First visit here was a few years ago after watching an episode of Ray's 'Tasty Travels' show on Food Network. 

Try the Famous Sesame Chicken. Slightly crunchy, slightly tender and full of flavor. The sesame sauce is a great balance of sweet and savory. The Crispy Noodle Tower is also very tasty! A tower of crispy noodles with stir fried beef, veggies and a Mongolian beef type sauce. The Eggplant with chile sauce was a great suggestion. Not too spicy and the eggplant was still tender. 

House of Nanking is a super small restaurant and great if you don't mind making new friends while eating your meal. It's cafeteria style seating and you are seated wherever a space is open. A line almost always forms outside the restaurant around 7PM, so be prepared with a jacket! Also, have the staff order for you! One time, they just asked us what flavors we liked (spicy, sweet, salty) and what kind of ingredients we preferred, and then served us a great meal of all that was mentioned above. If you are close to the Chinatown area, try this place out!
author: Paul C.

description: Awesome food! Authentic taste of Nanking! We are visitors from North Carolina. Best Chinese food ever We had in US! It worth waiting for 30 mins to get a seat. We first were concerned as there were not many Chinese customers in the restaurant! But the food turned so good which far beyond our expectation! :)
author: Jing L.

description: Came in expecting some authentic chinese food and got americanized panda express instead. Not even a hard food critic but this was pretty disappointing. Got the sesame chicken/chili eggplant and bao bing wrap for reference.
author: Paul C.

description: My husband and I decided to give this place a try since it was highly recommended by a few friends, fortunately for us the line wasn't bad at all but since it was our first time we didn't know if we needed to sign in order to be seated, my husband asked and we were told to "just wait outside" so we did. It is by far very tight seating inside you are basically elbow to elbow with your neighbor but everyone was very social. Waitress came over to take our order she didn't seem very pleasant and I was by far shocked when she walked away when we weren't even done ordering. We ordered the onion cakes those were good, the house noodle not so much I informed them that we didn't like it and they refused to remove it off our bill or even offer a different plate after the fact that we waited 40 minutes for our food, our neighbors were seated promptly and yet received they're food before we did..they also rush you to get out.I will honestly say that our visit was an unpleasant one and our plans of going back will be slim to none.
author: Lourdes L.

description: Amazing food and quick service! We had the fried rice with egg and tofu and brocolli in black bean sauce.
author: Priya G.

description: Great food! Good prices. Very efficient. Typical Chinatown service but you won't find much better anywhere else in Chinatown
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Great spot in/near Chinatown. I've been here twice now. Both times it was packed.

The first time I went with a big group (around 12), including someone who somehow made a special connection with the staff because the kitchen just kept sending out dish after delicious dish.  My favorite: the sweet potatoes.

For those complaining about the service, I'm not sure what you were expecting. This place is busy and fast paced. If you want something, you have to flag someone down and ask for it. West coast American passivity and politeness won't work
author: Brad F.

description: This place does not need another good review, but here I am giving one. Recommended by a friend who told me "I don't even know why they have menus, just let the wait staff order for you". My dining partner has lots of food allergies, so we were a little worried everything would have peanuts and fish sauce but no! There were plenty of things he could eat that were delicious. Sesame chicken, steamed pot stickers, a beef dish - and flowering tea!  Awesome food, and terrible service - but even though it's usually not, that was totally okay with me. I kinda felt like I was imposing on someone's aunt to make my dinner - they were irritated when we asked for things and were happy to rush us along - but that didn't take away from the meal. I can't wait to go back.
author: Leigh S.

description:
When in San Francisco back in September I was in Chinatown so Chinese food was a no brainer.  I was actually looking for another place I saw on yelp but it was no where to be found.  I am glad I stopped in this place.

  This place is small and dimly lit but had windows on the street that let in a nice breeze.  While looking at the menu a female waitress approached us and asked us what we liked and asked us if we trusted her To choose for us.  I said yes my partner was a little reluctant.  I said I liked shrimp and my partner said chicken and we ordered a bowl of wonton soup.  After a few minutes the lady brought a big bowl of family Style soup and some shrimp that had been fried with apples.  Both items were exceptional.  A few minutes later she brought out the order of Sesame chicken that was served with fried sweet potatoes that had been thinly sliced.  

The food was absolutely amazing...a little pricey but worth every penny.  We will be back here next time We are In San Francisco. I would even say this is probably the best Chinese food we have had and Austin (my partner) doesn't care for Asian.
author: James B.

description:
Yum!   Don't come here if you are looking for Americanized Chinese food.  Do come here if you are looking for delicious food and you are willing to have an adventure!  

Sesame chicken and onion cake did not disappoint.  Sadly, I couldn't eat all of the food - too much - but what I did eat was delicious!  Make sure to stop here on your next trip to SF, and don't be afraid of the lines (or afraid to ask for help)!
author: Rebecca E.

description:
If you want familiar Chinese food as your going in circles around Chinatown, this is your place.  Someone told me this is actually the only good place to eat in Chinatown and while I have no idea if that's true, I wasn't about to test it out....
Sesame chicken, fried calamari..just your typical stuff but with a side of cucumbers and glazed sweet potatoes instead!
author: Annie O.

description: Me and my girlfriend have tried various restaurants in Chinatown specifically looking for dumplings. This is by far the best place we have tried to eat dumplings. They are a little spicy though. So if you dont like spicy food it may not be for you.
author: Xavier G.

description: I came here a few years back and honestly, I was blown away. This restaurant has been open forever and is always crazy packed.  I came to do the typical touristy crap and found this place from Frommers. This is the first time coming to any type of restaurant where they can make a "custom menu" for you. What is a custom menu you may ask? The day that I went, I think the owner came by our table, if you tell them that you want them to order, they start asking some questions to get a flavor profile so they could completely make a menu on your likes and dislikes and your country of origin. They asked what country we were from, we said Thai, they then asked if we wanted fish, chicken, beef, vegetables etc. We named a few proteins and the owner places the order and said "ok, I will take care of you." It's kind of like a custom Omakase, if you will. Well, there was about four dishes for the four of us and honestly, I thought the food was excellent. Yes, it's touristy, yes it's crowded, yes Rachel Ray approves of it but at the end of the day, you give me good food and I will be happy. The food, since we mentioned we were Thai, had some heat to all the dishes. I wouldn't say the food was 100% authentic per se, but the flavors on everything really worked. On the dishes, they gave us a fish dish, a vegetable dish, a chicken dish and I forgot the last one but truly amazing food. Next time I go back to San Fran, there is no doubt I will be back here.
author: Ben L.

description:
My parents had come here with my brother and his wife the last time they were in the City and loved it so we all came here last night for dinner after a full day of sight seeing.  My dad was really excited and wanted the nice women to just order for us and bring out what she tought we'd enjoy.  There was 7 of us and one who can't eat any kind of fish.  She was very attentive to keep only a few of the dishes having shell fish.  Unfortunatly those were the best dishes. 

Everything was OVERLY greasy and everything dish was fried.  After 7 very small plates (which were split between 7 of us) we told her to stop bringing food that we were full.  The bill was a HUGE suprise.  $141.00 and we only had water! 

Chicken egg rolls - Gross
Chicken Won Ton w/ peanut sauce - just okay
beef with unripe tomatoes and mushrooms - yuck
Seasame chicken w/sweetpotatoes - overly greasy and sweet
Crispy pork was strips of fried pork fat - Dry and stringy
Calamari  - Best dish we had hands down 
Sweet Shrimp with fried greenbeans - WAY to sweet and the green beans were from a frozen bag. 

With so many other options in SF, we will not be returning.

1-star for the calamari
1-star for the customer service and atentiveness to my sis-in-laws no fish request.
author: Christie B.

description: Best Chinese food I've ever had. Tastes like real food, as if I bought ingredients at whole foods and cooked myself a gourmet, authentic meal of Chinese food. If only I had the skills. Simply amazing.
author: Dean A.

description: While the food here was delicious (beef bao bing, and they serve wine!), the service here absolutely sucked. I thought as a Nanking native that the waitress might have considered paying more attention, but I had to catch them every single time I wanted to sit or order. The only time they were insistent on paying attention to me was when I accidentally walked out not having written proper tip on the bill. I learned my lesson, especially that this is not the place to be during Chinese New Year.
author: Sheena C.

description:
I loved this place! And sadly I can't even tell you the names of any of the dishes because our server  ordered for us. It went down like this:

Server: how hungry are you? A lot or a little?
Group: A lot!
Server: Ok, I order for you

Moments later dish after dish just appeared on the table. I was careful to let the server know of my dietary restrictions and she accommodated without any hassle. The food was great, teriyaki chicken, shrimp dishes, chicken egg rolls and tons of other stuff that I can't even recall. 

Add in a couple of Chinese beers and a great time was had by all. The kicker? 10 people had a feast with alcohol for about $27 per person (pre-tip). Insane! In a good way. The place doesn't look like much and you might wait for a little bit but you'll enjoy it.
author: Rhonda G.

description:
House of Nanking may not be a feast for the eyes, but it certainly is for your stomach. Not much to look at, but certainly worth the trip and wait if you're caught in the long lines I've heard about.

My timing was perfect--came here mid Friday afternoon and there was no wait. 

As my friend had told me...don't order off the menu, just ask the waiter what's good today. Well, that was a bit of a challenge, as I'm pretty sure our waiter had ADD. He'd start making recommendations, then walked off to do other things. Alrighty then!

Regardless, we got the hot flowering tea. Looks a bit sketchy, but is delicious, and needs no sweetener. Just fish the flower buds out with your fork and leave them on your plate. Leave the stuff at the bottom of your mug at the bottom of your mug. No idea what it is, but just leave it alone. The tea is good and that's all you need to know.

Entrees we had:
- Mu Shu Pork: really yummy and came with tons of veggies
- Beef with green beans: delicious flavor and came with white rice (not sure if they offer brown). Beef was a bit fatty, but that's what makes it taste so good.

Delicious, fresh, authentic, and fast! All the raves you've heard/read about are true!
author: Jill M.

description: Finally decided to try this place for dinner with the family. It's always busy with a line out the door so one of many we bookmarked to try. Nothing to boast about. Far from fancy. Definite hole in the wall with a few tasty dishes. Won't go as far as to say it was delicious. And more than likely won't come back. Service was light speed. No time to socialize. They make sure you're in and out.
author: Danielle G.

description:
NO NO NO

My bf's coworkers/chefs wanted to have lunch together in sf on Sunday, so someone chose to come here based on another person's suggestion. of course I had to yelp the place first and saw that..um....this place isn't good....but okay, maybe everyone is wrong and we'll love it.

Wrong.

Parking was a tad bit difficult but not too bad....we just kept missing the open spots.
the place wasn't packed at 1pm, which was good for us. 

let me try to remember everything we ordered, and oh yes, if you know what you want, order it! if not, the crazy chinese lady will try to order for you and order you the expensive stuff!

salt and pepper mushrooms- oh thats what its called..no wonder it was so SALTY. BLAHHHHHHH. nice big mushrooms but godly salty
calamari- don't know which one we had but it was good...tender and not too chewy...but swimming in some oily stuff...
peashoots...with sweet potatoe- this was pretty good, prolly since it had veggies to counter the SALTINESS
the famous sesame chicken- prettyy good. i guess a must order here. crispy...meaty..
house noodles- egg noodles....it was okay....kids liked it
chow mein- normal...oily..
fried rice- definitely need rice with everything
eggplants- salty..
blossom flower tea- great help to down the oily salty food.

overall....SALTYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYY to me, others say it was too sweet and the flavors of the dishes started blending together...all tasted the same basically.
how is this place on Rachel Ray or even owned by a "famous chef" beats me.

never again thank you, and the service was sparse, everyone was on their cell phones. c'mon now
author: Christine M.

description: pretty disappointing. heard it was the best in SF. ended up giving my leftovers (which there was a lot of) to my roomie bc i had no interest in eating more. maybe its just because i'm picky and can't handle anything even remotely spicy (which their classic nanking sesame chicken IS, despite the lack of mention on the menu) but i was so underwhelmed. that being said, the vibe is cool and there is lots of seating. but i've had better from hole-in-the-wall places.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
There was a line when we got there so we had to wait some time. 

Pros: true "Chinese culture experience" it's very fast paced. The food is very good. I had the calamari & shrimp cakes. 

Cons: servers do not try to please you. They are simply there to give you your food. You may get a wrong check (they charged us for 3 servings of rice...we ordered 1). I had to yell at the waitress to come back since she just kept leaving before taking my order. You will also most likely be seated with another party since it is always packed and there is limited space.
author: Nadia L.

description: This is the first time we went here and we are excited for it since it got 3.5 stars wit lots of review. The lady is the one who ordered our food because we didnt know what to eat. It came out terrible and the service was not good. The food was so salty, and 3 from 4 food that she ordered for us were taste the same which is just pepper and salt taste.
author: Christofer K.

description:
I have now been here twice and I do not even live in San Francisco!  I come to SF often for business and will seek this place out :)  The service is meh, but the food makes up for it!  So good!  Be prepared for a wait out the door - they are not fancy, so you will have to physically wait outside in a line.  Some of the seating is communal.  Drinks are average, cheap wine.  Again, you must go here for the food and that is it.  

I have ordered the house noodles, sesame chicken, calamari, and potstickers.  The potstickers were served with a peanut sauce and I am typically not a huge fan of peanut sauce, but this stuff is GOOD.  The sesame chicken is probably my favorite dish that I have tried -- fried and the sauce is also very good.  The Calamari is lightly fried and not chewy like it can be sometimes -- very easy to eat and a large portion as well!  

Overall, very good!  I'll be going back :)
author: Lindsay J.

description:
Yes, this place is packed with tourists.  No, that doesn't mean the food will be bad.  I first visited this restaurant years ago and had several slam dunk, 5 star experiences.  Then, about 3 years ago, I came back and the food wasn't memorable at all.  The person sitting next to me told me that there was a new owner, so that was probably the reason for the downgrade.  

Well, I'm happy to say that the restaurant is back on it's "A" game now.  The owner/chef takes your order and you should definitely ask for recommendations; he won't steer you wrong.  He even asks about food allergies/religious restrictions.  The menu had changed a lot from the last time I was there, so I asked him about the crackling rice w/ beef dish that's no longer on the menu.  He said, "don't worry, I have something better," and just jotted something down.  I wish I had asked him what he ordered for me, because it was out of this world!  The beef was so tender and was seasoned perfectly.  It was served with some bok choy, and I could've eaten 2 orders of it, it was so good.  

So I recommend asking for the "crackling rice dish" that was on the old menu.   I also got some steamed dumplings, which were also excellent.  Can't wait to come back again when I'm in the area.

FYI: Cash only!
author: Troy P.

description: I don't understand why this place is so highly rated. Everything we ordered was good, but not great. Wish we had gone somewhere else given the options around there.
author: Rhoda M.

description:
Delicious. I know everyone is complaining about the service, but we had 8 people for dinner on a fairly crowded night and it only took us about 10 minutes at the most to get seated. The food was great, and the flower tea was delicious, so much so that I had to get a refill (and the tea was in a large beer mug, which now must be the way to drink my tea from now on).

We had the salt and pepper shrimp, sesame chicken, calamari, and stuffed mushrooms.

Calamari: Would get again! So good, tender and not rubbery at all.
Salt and pepper shrimp: Wouldn't get again Yummy, but something I can find anywhere
Sesame Chicken: YUMM! I wanted to finish the bowl, but i was soo full from the amazing tea. I would get it again.
stuffed mushrooms: good, but not my favorite, I would try it if its your first time though. if I go back I'll skip and try something new.

Get the flower tea. So yummy.
author: Samantha D.

description: please don't eat at this location, unless you speak and read chinese.  rude waiters, poor service! waiter actually demanded that i pay/tip more tips than what i left it on the table.
author: Jane D.

description:
Not very authentic at all. This place is definitely more catered towards the Caucasian taste. Heavy on the sweet/sour spices. When I came in, I was the only Asian person eating there. Definitely overpriced as well. We ordered the steamed dumplings, it was $9 for 6 dumplings! The dumplings felt like they were defrosted and put on our place with a big glop of sweet/sour sauce. The meat was still kind of hard.

We also got the bao bing wrap. It was horribly overpriced at $14. They give you 4 wraps that are not fresh, they break when you try to roll them. The meat was good, nice and tender but the portions definitely are not that great. And of course it was drenched in a strong sweet/sour sauce.

Usually I don't really fuss when the service at a chinese restaurant is lacking. But with  subpar food/portions/service, there is really no reason to come here.
author: Dale C.

description: Used to be my go to mouth watering and favorite spot where I could over look the filth and lack of customer service. However, the last few visits have resulted in poor food quality and displeased diners. We usually order more to take food home togo, this last time we left our food. Sauces were greasy and runny, like water, and off color. It was quite a disappointment. I haven't seen the owner Peter over the past few visits. He may be focusing on the newer and more upscale Fang Restaurant.
author: April C.

description:
I would eat the house noodles and sauteed greens for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. 

If the staff seems rude, it is for your own good.
author: Steve P.

description:
While visiting our friends on Sunday, we mentioned that we'd be going to Chinatown for dinner. They immediately started recommending places and House of Nanking got the vote.

So, after walking through Chinatown for a bit, we set off to find House of Nanking. We eventually found it and lo and behold - that's quite a line outside for 8pm on a Sunday! (Granted, the next day was Memorial Day.) I guess it really IS good. Although, as we were waiting, some diners left and said "don't do it!!" Curious, we asked if the food was bad. "The food is good, the service is horrible... Don't do it!" Uh oh. Starting to question our decision.

The people who got on line behind us said they asked the cab driver for a good place, and he brought him there. Hmm... Starting to feel better about our choice. We decided to stick with it and see what happened.

We didn't wait long and were brought inside to a table RIGHT next to the door, which was somehow stolen out from under us by an older couple. That was interesting. We were sat elsewhere, basically sharing the table with a couple next to us. They recommended the Sesame Chicken, which we had been thinking about getting.

We started with the Onion Cakes - basically an over-sized, over-greased version of Scallion Pancakes with a tasty, spicy plum sauce. Pretty tasty!

Then we shared a big bowl of the Sizzling Rice Soup (which our friends had recommended earlier). This was RIDIC spicy but SO good. The rice was crispy, the chicken was tender and the flavors fantastic. I think I had 2 and a half bowls.

Next was the Sesame Chicken, which is cooked with Sweet Potatoes. A bit odd, although tasty. 

I don't remember exactly how much it was, but they are CASH ONLY, so be prepared.

And the guy was right - the service is NOT good. The food however, is... Be prepared for a cramped, fast eating experience and you won't be disappointed. If you go in expecting a nice, leisurely, 5-star dining establishment, you'll be thoroughly upset.
author: Jenn S.

description: Run! I wouldn't expect the service to be good at a hole in the wall kind of place like this... And it wasn't! But I did expect the food to be great... And it wasn't even good! Never again.
author: James P.

description:
