So I'm Asian and have eaten at hundreds of Chinese food restaurants and this place is the worst. Over priced school cafeteria grade food and even worse service. I've never been to a Chinese restaurant where they serve you loose leaf tea in a beer mug. I spent half of my time picking tea leaves out of my teeth. Absolutely disgusting. While we were waiting for our food, other customers came in and asked to sit by the window, the owner refused and said they are not opened and continued to read newspaper while munching on her food loudly. We got hot & sour soup as an appetizer, the smell of hot vinegar was a punch in the face. The soup tasted like hot rotten garbage left over night on the side of the street. For the entree we had sesame chicken which was edible but the wrapped beef and chow mein was a dirty oil slick down my throat, covered in burnt oil and grease. 
Our first time in San Francisco, listened to the tour bus driver's recommendation which now I think he got paid to send customers there. Tourist rip off, skip it, skip it!
author: May L.

description:
I continue to be a fan of this place, especially now that it's less crowded and there's not lines out the door (in the past year or so, the quality of the food briefly went down).  

The ambience and service could be better, but the food is pretty good (but don't expect authentic Chinese, the food can best be described as vaguely Asian).  You'll really be packed in here, so don't come here for private conversations or to pop the question :-p

Get the fish soup (it's a whole fish in coconut lemony broth, it just melts in your mouth).  It's not on the English menu, but it is FANTASTIC and big enough for two to share.  2 years after my first review and it's still great!  I have no idea why it's not on the main menu, b/c it is great!  This time they even cut the head off without us asking, which was very considerate.  

The onion pancakes continue to be ok - it's a good deal and pretty large (full plate), and they are fully fried.  But we didn't particularly care for the peanut sauce and hot sauce they automatically put on top. Next time I'll specifically ask for the sauce on the side.
author: Bee M.

description: Ate here for the first time a few days ago.  The restaurant was a bit crowded, but the food was delicious. We had the chow mein and sesame chicken.  Both were great, and we will definitely eat here again next time we are in the city.
author: Eric N.

description:
NANKING'S HOUSE IS NOT A HAPPY HOME!!!!

This was probably the worst dining experience I have ever had.

I have been to this place about 5 other times but not when it was crazy busy.  I've waited in line but last night we were waiting in a relatively small line, watching other people cut and pass the whole line, go into the restaurant, beg for a table and then taking a table while we stood and waited like decent patrons.

Then we actually got sat and waited 20 mins. for our server to even talk to us.  No drink order or anything.

We were taking my girlfriend's 16-year old brother there while he is visiting.  Normally, we just tell the server what we don't like and they surprise us with amazing food but he wasn't into that and really wanted to eat something off the menu.   Basically, we weren't going to order meat and the Texan boy really wanted to try some beef.

We explained to the waitress that he was going to order separately and we were going to let her decide.  She freaked out and looked at us all crazy.  I don't think she understood English well enough to grasp what we meant by "separately".  She took his order and ran off, screaming into the kitchen...   

We thought that she was done so we kept calling to her so we could finish our order and she got all flustered and finally came back.   Then we ordered and I went to use the restroom to wash my hands.

I waited for about 10 mins at the door.  I tried to open it and the handle was all messed up but i pushed and nothing happened.

I asked the hostess if there was a problem with the handle and after she downright ignored me a couple times she finally snapped back at me, "We know the handle is broken!!"

I was pretty pissed.  I had been waiting now for 45 mins and I couldn't even wash my hands in the place.   All the female crew were completely out of control rude and seemed to have a lot of disdain for their jobs or maybe just white people.

I waited another 5 mins and said "fuck it" and washed my hands with no soap in their dirty-ass sink they have by the toilets.  I went back and my girlfriend's brother had his food and we had one, smallish sized app sitting there getting cold.

We demolished it quickly and were waiting for another 10 mins for more food to come.  

Her brother went to get up and use the restroom and our server started YELLING at him in Chinese!!!   He was walking through the dining room and the server kept YELLING and darting towards her other employees to stop him.   Finally she rushed back and slammed his "separate check" down at his spot on the table.  

I couldn't believe it!!!    The poor kid goes to use the toilet and this crazy, incompetent server accosts him and treats him like a criminal.   

I had asked her for about 5 things that she forgot, including napkins and water, I flagged her down to explain how rude she was and she walked around a bunch, ignoring me, and when she came back she had our check in her hand!

I told her, can I please have the things you told me you were going to bring me 20 mins ago and also that her treatment towards our guest was extremely rude as he was just going to the bathroom.   She screamed back in her pea-sized brain voice, "I didn't know!!!!!!!!"


I am a server and I usually always tip well.   This time I had no qualms stiffing the incredibly rude server.  If there was a way to talk to anyone at this place who gave a crap I might have complained to them.  

This place just abuses the fact that they are popular and forces their guests to deal with an awful atmosphere because they know no one will stop going.

But I, for one, am waking up the street to the 100's of other good Chinese restaurants next time and saving my time, money, and stress.   

If any women servers of Nanking can or do read this, you should look for a new career!    Do us all a favor.
author: William G.

description: 1 star for service and the space, but 4 1/2 stars for the food. Truly the worst service EVER, but I will always keep coming back for punishment because the food is that good. Don't know what you want? First time in? Can't keep up with the menu? Don't worry, the waitress will quickly collect your menu and without a word of your input will order for you! I haven't had anything that I haven't thoroughly enjoyed. So get in, eat and get out! ;)
author: MissM R.

description: I had to update my review.  The first time I was here it was after just moving to the city and this was my first stop in Chinatown.  After exploring Chinatown more this last year, visiting china last month, and my most recent stop here this weekend I realized how great this place is.  We showed up at about 5 on a Saturday for a super late lunch.  No wait at all and sat down.  What first surprised me was how low the prices were after visiting several other Chinatown restaurants I forgot how inexpensive this one was!  And for huge portions!!  I get that people are thrown off by the restaurant but this is Chinatown not some Michelin star restaurant!  To me it just adds to the experience.  Especially after visiting Beijing where so many of the restaurant are like this- its just part of the fun!  We ordered some house wine and the pour were amazing- 3.95$ for a full glass of wine is a deal in San Francisco and the wine wasn't that bad at all!  I thought the chardonnay paired really well with some of their heavier dishes.  But anyway back to the food- won ton soup was like nothing I  have ever had and it was amazing! A little creamy and the won tons were outstanding.  We got the sesame chicken again which did not disappoint.  The house noodles were a big hit as well.  We ordered the bao bao beef which was very tender and flavorful.  WE ordered a couple other items but those were my favorite.  I will keep coming back here whenever I am in Chinatown- what a great place for an incredible price!
author: Kate F.

description:
I don't really understand how this place became so popular. The chinese food taste like PF Changs and Panda Express. It's definitely not authentic. But I guess there's a reason why PF Changs is a booming business!!

There's this awful after taste that I hate when eating here and places like PF Changs... it's like an orange tangy syrup taste that stays in my mouth. 

We ordered all the popular dishes such as the sesame chicken, garlic fish, fried tofu, chow mein and fried rice. It's decent food and a great place for a quick lunch if you're too scared to try a Chinese restaurant filled with all Asians... this place is less intimidating ;)
author: Stacey P.

description:
Went here for lunch on Presidents day. The service was so bad that we were just about to leave when they finally came and took our drink order. We didnt get the food at the same time and we finished the first dish before the second came. 
The food was great! We are veggies and had the house noodles and a mushu tofu dish. Both were terrific. 
5 stars for the food, 1 star for service.
author: Lisa A.

description: Lost a star because, as others have noted, the service sucks.  Ten minute wait time between when my meal was served and when Hubby's arrived.  We asked three, count 'em - THREE times for water before we got our refill. No one came back to check on us, and for the first time in five years, we left no tip. The gal who took our money blocked our exit from our table to remind us the tip wasn't included in the meal. Really? We tip 20% always for standard service; however,  I wont reward horrible service. Tacky.  Food was good, just don't expect even mediocre service.
author: missy a.

description: We went to Nanking based on our tour bus driver's recommendation. We just wanted to eat some decent Chinese food. Wow! This was THE WORST FOOD we have ever ate bar none. The service was non existent except to bring the "food" out. The owners and employees were very loud talking amongst themselves without any care to the customers. This crappy "food" is over priced. Really shitty experience period. Avoid this place at all cost.
author: Kiki L.

description: Don't buy the hype. This place has gone so down hill - should have known when the ubiquitous line outside wasn't there at Noon on a  Friday. Pot stickers are a deep fried mess now - still can't figure out what kind of dough they are using - definitely not what I would consider traditional.  The Nanking Sesame chicken was so over crispy, I was a afraid I was going to break a tooth. And where were the yummy orange sweet potatoes??? That was one of the best things about this dish!  My dining partner said the noodles smelled and tasted like the bottom of a fishing boat - after the first two mishaps I took his word for it and passed completely on that dish.  So disappointed - I've been coming here since 1990 and have now removed it from my "can't miss" list.  We left 3 potstickers and 2/3 of the Nanking Chicken and  Noodles on the table - the waiter said "do you want a to-go box" and when we said "no thank you" he didn't even have the courtesy to ask if everything was okay...methinks they know they are putting out slop.
author: Holly H.

description: I had the house sesame chicken and it was the best Chinese food I have have ever eaten! The place is small and crowded but the service was friendly and efficient. Once I took the first bite I didn't mind the cramped little room anymore. A must visit. Will come back again.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
I did it.
Barry Manilow made it through the rain.
Chaka Khan made it through the fire.
I made it through lunch at House of Nanking.
I danced with the devil in the pale moonlight.
Well, it was actually sunny ...and it wasn't really Satan.
But I ate and I walked away ....I WON! ...Ya hear me? (cue for delirious Peter Lorre-like laugh)

Hey, did you know if you go to the business location listing on the SF Dept. of Public Health site, you will find a yes-or-no column that asks, "Symbol of Excellence?" I'm sure only a meager few would be surprised to find the response under House of Nanking to be "No". I had been curious to come here since it became like a totally rad place to go in the nineties. On MTV, those self-absorbed housemates from "Real World - San Francisco" came here to have a couple of their passive-aggressive confrontations to figure out what to do with Puck.

Then of course, chipmunk-cheeked Rachael Ray found it, or at least one of her minions did, on one of those $40-a-Day-But-I-Don't-Tip episodes. And Jamie Oliver came here to once again prove that the British have steel-belted palates. Their smiling faces adorn the walls of this hovel of a place. I just want to know who the press relations manager is for this place. I'd hire him or her in a flash.

I came here for lunch today totally expecting a wait but got lucky - if you should pardon the expression - and landed the little table facing the window. The girl in the House of Nanking T-shirt simply waved in my direction to sit. It took quite a while to get anyone's attention - for a menu perhaps, a glass of water - because a loud Aussie family wanted a detailed explanation of every item on the menu and then they needed to repeat them to each other. Actually, "loud Aussie" is a redundant descriptor.

Finally, I got a well-worn menu, but here comes local legend Peter Fang looking somewhat constipated and fully expecting me to be prepared to order the minute his pen hits his pad. To his chagrin, I was indeed prepared and didn't let him suggest anything to me. I ordered the $9.95 plate of chopped snow pea shoots with eggplant chunks. It came with a truckload of yams cut into matchsticks, and it was all slathered in some kind of lubricating sauce I couldn't quite make out.

The eggplant was better than I expected, but the snow pea shoots tasted like they were barely acquainted with the wok. I do like the smell of a freshly mowed lawn but not on my plate (...did ya hear that, Cafe Gratitude?). I also think yams as a stir-fry accompaniment are odd. They might as well given me a burnt marshmallow topping and sang "Jingle Bells" to me at the same time.

Ten dollars seems a bit steep for an all-veggie dish no matter the size (judge for yourself in my photo). Service was pretty much at their convenience. The dirty dishes left by the preceding customers lingered for about five minutes before anyone thought to pick them up and wipe down the table. You can probably guess I had a pretty lackluster experience at the mythic House of Nanking. No wonder everyone was so bitchy in that Lombard house on "The Real World".

FOOD - 2.5 stars...somebody get me my hedge clippers, the plate needs to be cut back
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...Rachael and Jamie can smile all they want..it still feels like Sam Wo's North
SERVICE - 2 stars...indifferent to surly...they run the gamut from A to B
TOTAL - 2 stars...House of Nanking?...how about House of Yanking...My Chain?
author: Ed U.

description:
I came here because the mother of an ex was in town for a day and wanted to eat at the place she said had some of the best Chinese food she'd eaten outside China. Disclaimer: I have never been to China.

 I'd never been here before myself, but I do eat a fair amount of Chinese food, home cooked & at restaurants around the Bay Area. 

This was meh. Sizzling Rice soup did not sizzle (literally). I ordered the house-made noodles and they arrived with a sort of black bean sauce and fresh sprouts of something that may have been pea sprouts and tasted like grass. From your lawn. If I were cooking I'd have cooked them just a bit to sweeten the flavor.

She got tofu with broccoli and it was just ok. There was very loud and very bad US pop music blaring from speakers behind the counter that echoed throughout the place, which had a dark interior. The music negated the intimacy of the place for me. I'm glad I could grant her wish, will not be back unless she wants to the next time she's in town.
author: irene n.

description: Delicious! I had the house sesame chicken which is a very large portion and could probably be shared. It comes with sweet potatoes and veggies. The house fried rice is also tasty. A definite must try while in SF Chinatown. The long lines are worth it!
author: Sara D.

description: Best Chinese food I have ever had. Period. The lady running the place was a bit short with us, but that was expected by the culture. They ordered for us, as they didn't have time to wait for us to look at the menu. Best decision. We wouldn't have ordered any of the stuff they brought. It was an adventure. Not a single thing we had we didn't like. If you are going to San Francisco, go eat here, and be sure to wear some flowers in your hair.
author: Drew B.

description:
Food was good but service was terrible.  When we sat down, server flung menus at the table and immediately walked away without saying a word to us. 

When asked to close the windows right above our table, waiter shook his head and walked away as he mumbled something completely unintelligible. 

Again, food was alright although they messed up parts of our order and each plate came out 5 minutes apart.

Cherry on top of the experience came when we attempted to split the check between 4 credit cards.  We understand if its not possible but would appreciate if we would've been told of these rules to begin with.  It also would've been nice if our credit cards weren't thrown back on the table at us while muttering "no no no no no" by the women who seemed to be in charge.

Table next to us had their credit card charged for more than what they were billed. We heard them arguing about this as we walked out.  After talking to them outside they told us this isn't the first time thats happened to them.

I dont know what all the hype is about.  Food is okay, service is horrendous.
author: Ola H.

description: I love this place!!! When I'm in SF I squeeze it into my Schedule no matter what. The eggplant dish is very tasty and one of my favorites.
author: mariam n.

description: Well, the service here kinda sucked but the food was great.  Get there early so  you aren't standing in line.  The egg rolls rock, shrimp is tasty, portion sizes great.
author: Nikki A.

description:
I went here with my friends because the place was recommended by Lonely Planet, but I really don't understand why it is so popular. The food is okay and not authentic (although if you know Chinese food real well you might get better deal). My friends and I ordered a beef dish and we could tell that the beef wasn't fresh. People say that their green onion cake is great, unfortunately it's really unauthentic and the onion is super strong.

The worst part is the fact that the service blows. Unhelpful, clueless, and disorganized. They don't care about fire hazard when arranging the table. They don't bother trying to figure out the answers to our questions.
author: Cal R.

description: A must in every visit to San Francisco.   Yes sometimes there are lines and the waiters are not friendly but the food is so good!!!!!  A tip let them order for you (if you have allergies or don't like some type of food, just let them know and they will accommodate your request).  Portions are huge and did I mentioned that the food is good?
author: Kenneth R.

description: House of Nanking was recommended by a friend for our visit to San Francisco. I looked them up here on Yelp and the menu looked intriguing. We waited in line and the hostess was kind of frantic, but the place was really humming, it is a crowded busy restaurant, I always find that a good sign. We were seated at a large table next to a couple (seating is tight, but it didn't bother us) we (4 of us) planned out our meal based on what each person wanted. The owner came to take our order and asked if we had ever been there before. We said no and he said, "give me the menus, I'll take care of you, trust me!" (As he pointed to his picture on the wall wearing his chef coat and a cooking award medal around his neck.) he truly did take care of us. Snow peas, honey shrimp with crispy apples! (My favorite). Nanking beef with bok choy, dumplings, and portabella mushrooms, it was an amazing meal! It was so good we went back on the last day of our trip and had lunch there, high quality great tasting Chinese food. We will always go to House of Nanking when we visit San Francisco.
author: Vito A.

description: Can't say enough good stuff about this place. The chef/owner took our menus away and cooked for us and everything he brought out to us was amazing. Def recommend this place if you are looking for great food in Chinatown!
author: Michelle D.

description: The food was excellent. Authentic Chinese in Chinatown. The service is mediocre. It feels a little touristy. The food was excellent.
author: Pete K.

description: 1st time here, short line to get in, less than 5 minutes. Limited menu but ample selections. Salt and Pepper Shrimp were really fresh and tasty. Brown Sauce complemented the shrimp and fresh mushroom to complete the meal. Service was quick and friendly. Large serving just right to share,
author: Mark R.

description: Well, pretty tasty Chinese food.  Let them order for you if you are not sure.  Just tell them what you like.  Ask for prices though.  It can be bit on the expensive side given this is a casual place.
author: Rick K.

description: I was not impressed with this place. I liked the atmosphere and the staff was very friendly but the food I had heard so much about was ho hum. I ordered the moo shoo chicken. The funniest thing if all was that it came with regular tortillas. I thought they came with something similar to a tortilla, not an actual tortilla. I wasn't the only one disheartened by this. Because the attitude (highly appreciated customer service) of this establishment and the fact that this place is highly rated I will plan on at least giving it another shot.
author: Lisa C.

description: After asking everyone where to go in Chinatown, finally tried HoN and were not disappointed.   Quick, tasty lo mein and shrimp and mushroom dish.  Not much atmosphere but in and out fast and very satisfied with the food.
author: Rick R.

description: Suggested by many friends from years past. I imagine things are different after the renovation. Decent food. If you are looking for a reputable dining experience in Chinatown, this is a good choice.
author: Cory W.

description: Horrible service, mediocre food, dirty. Rude waiters. 1 bathroom for the whole place....DIRTY! Not going. Back. Glad the owner responded. But to elaborate on why some of your standards of hygiene may not necessarily be on point. Citing 1 example,  I ordered wine with my food and after I had a taken a sip of my drink before ordering any food, there was a piece of food particle stuck inside the glass which I did not notice because the section in question was not facing me when I took a drink. Needless to say, there's no reason for that. Replacing it with an already not so happy waiter was definitely not welcomed. All in all if your standards of cleanliness have been met, there wouldn't be any reviews on the contrary. Just my 2 cents.
author: Tricia E.

description: Great food, super fast and friendly service. The homemade noodles were delicious! The pan fried fish melts in your mouth and the accompanying greens taste like they've been soaked in honey. The salt and pepper shrimp and mushrooms... Out of this world!!
author: David G.

description:
I am from NYC and this is still the best Chinese cuisine I have ever had. And I mean EVER. They have limited wine selection but they have legit CALIF wines (which is cool for a tourist like me). 

My wife and I went on a 9-day excursion from San Francisco down to San Luis Obispo and this restaurant was the best. My wife thinks Magnolia Brewery was.....so go there if you are not near Nanking.
author: Walter B.

description: Don't waste your time or money on this place. While it is reasonably priced, the food is fair at best and the service was awful.
author: Scott K.

description:
After a long day of touring we decided to head over to a locals little hole in the wall and found The Nanking House. We were a group of six so we had a 10 minute wait. Once we got seated we were assisted right away. Okay here's the funny/odd part of our visit, the waiter didn't let us order what we wanted. We were set back at how we ordered the food and he kept saying it was too much.

So here's what we ordered
-calamari: no too much food
-shrimp cakes:no too much food
-wonton soup:okay
-sesame seed chicken: replaced for another chilen plate we never ordered. 

It was all just a mess but the food was VERY good. I can't get over that wonton soup! 

All in all, the food was good but I do t know about the customer service.
author: Marlene Z.

description:
I split the sesame chicken and the house noodles with my fellow diner. 

The sesame chicken was pretty good, but overly crunchy on the outside. The sauce and the sweet potatoes that went with the chicken were excellent.

I didn't care for the house noodles too much. They were bland and had no sign of the garlic that was listed in the dish description on the menu. The portion size also seemed on the smaller side for the price.

Inside the restaurant, the atmosphere was busy with many shared tables among guests. The service was quick, though curt. 

In short, there's better Chinese food in San Francisco.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Staying nearby since its a pretty cheap area, by SF standards, and I'm not on an expense account, and this is just down the block, so I figured what the hell.

1. This is a typical SF Chinatown restaurant. Do not expect attentive service. Expect no-nonsense service. They want you in, they want you out, food will arrive quickly. If you want a white tablecloth restaurant with a solicitous maitre'd, what the hell are you doing here?

2. This is not an "American-Chinese" restaurant. It's an authentically Chinese one. You will likely not be familiar with most items on the menu. That's a -good- thing; it means you're eating something you would not likely find in McKinney fucking Texas, or Salt Lake, or wherever the hell you're from. Go with the flow and experiment.

3. I read some other reviews and found people whining about parking. Parking? Seriously? This is San Francisco, why the hell are you tooling around in your ecologically catastrophic death machine? You never heard of public transit maybe? And ok, North Beach is up a hill, but Kearney is an adequate cycling street, and it's in the SF bike share area. If you want parking, stay in McKinney and eat at the goddamn Panda Express, god help you.

4. I had the fried onion cake as an appetizer, which I found interesting, but don't recommend. Interesting because it's not a stereotyped scallion pancake; a different texture and substantial chunks of onion. I don't recommend it, because it was covered with a thin peanut flavored gruel. I would either have preferred a soy-and-vinegar dipping sauce, or something more like sate; edible, but unsatisfying.

5. I also had the scallop tower, which was fantastic: a citrus-flavored brown sauce, a watercress-like vegetable I am not sufficiently knowledgeable to identify, underlaid by a root vegetable. Totally delicious, and worth going there for.

6. But I'm sure some Americans would consider the portion size small; scallops are an expensive ingredient, of course, and I also doubt any European would balk at that.

So you know: Fast in, fast out, don't expect elegance; authentically Chinese, some dishes better than others, if you need to park don't come to SF, I walked away happy.

What more do you need to know?
author: Greg C.

description:
I can't believe I'm giving the House of Nanking a two star rating after all of these years of it being one of my favorite restaurants in SF...    My romance with this once cool Chinese restaurant hole in the wall gone commercial has now ended.

I first visited this place about 15 years ago, back when it was about half the size and about 4 times as cool.   It was really cool having the owner/chef come to your table telling you what you should order, especially since it seemed like he was always right.  

Every time I would visit SF, I would go out of my way to visit HoNK.  However, on my most recent visit this week, I finally realized that this place has gone too commercial and just doesn't cut it anymore.     

To  be slightly fair, I should point out that the owner/chef guy wasn't there, which may have something to do with my 2 star rating, but that can't explain the bland food, the generic atmosphere, and the overall bad dining experience.     I suppose if there was a way to give 2.5 stars, I would, but in this case, I'm rounding down... all the way to China Town!
author: Todd F.

description:
As a newbie to San Fran (for business), I had heard of all the amazing food, so my yelp side was very excited.

I read the reviews on House of Nanking - it said, worth the wait.  Wait?  One hour. Outside.  SF is cold, btw.  I would totally do it again, and again, and again.

Nan-King has me dreaming of their delicious dumplings and FAMOUS chicken.  Yes, it should be famous, it melted in my mouth and had me eating until I could not anymore.  Ah, the food was so good, the fried rice paired really well with the chicken, and the plum wine was a great topper.  At $3.95/glass, you can't go wrong.

Also, do NOT leave Nan King without getting the calamari. Freshest/tastiest/deliciousest stuff ever.  If in SF again, I will be torn but will likely be back.  YUM-O
author: Anjali K.

description: Stopped in for dinner on a Saturday night, the place was busy but not too crowded. ordered a plate of steamed pork dumplings (potstickers) which were supreme. Salt and pepper mushrooms and the special sesame chicken with sweet potato were delectable. Note, the menu is simple and I couldn't find sweet n' sour anything or some of the "staples" you might expect.
author: Brad S.

description:
Plain food and stingy portions.   We ordered the fried shrimp packets:  They were basically fried rice paper with 1 little shrimp,1 pea (in some), and green onions inside, with peanut butter mixed with soy sauce on top.  Save your money and go to the legit places next door and down the street.

What I gauge from other reviews is that if you don't know good Chinese food, you might like this place.  However, if you know what you want and hope for some real flavors for your buck, I don't think that this is the place that will satisfy.
author: Bridget C.

description: A gem in the rough!  This place is nothing to look at but very good!  We started with the fried shrimp packets, fried pork pot stickers, calamari and house noodles. Food came quickly and we devoured all of it in no time.  So glad we got the house noodles instead of defaulting to chow mein!  We were still hungry so we ordered sesame chicken, scallop tower and some rice. All great and we left very happy!  Don't come here for decor or cordiality. They point you to a table, take your order and bring you your food. That was all we needed!
author: Diane D.

description: Sesame chicken is good.  It doesn't taste like any other "authentic" chinese food that I'm familiar with, but Americans seem to like it.
author: Niniane W.

description:
Great food!!
Their Sesame Chicken, Onion Cakes, and house noodles are a must!
While the food is unbelievably amazing, don't expect great service. They are most often curt, rude, and will forget parts of your order.
author: Marisa K.

description: This is a great Chinese restaurant that is really quick at serving; within 5 minutes. This is underrated and I'm not sure why. The Salt and Pepper Shrimp w/ sautéed mushrooms were amazing as well as the honey sesame chicken. Along with the fried rice and dumpling w peanut sauce! Definitely worth a try!!!
author: Felipe H.

description:
We came to SF on family vacation and a friend of mine who lives here recommended the place, so we decided to try it. It was the WORST decision. 

After we walked in, a waitress asked us how big the party was. I said "six" in both English and Chinese. She pretended that she did not understand me, and responded "One person? You can sit in the corner then." She was really rude and arrogant, and just turned around and left without seating us anywhere. Then someone else came and pointed us to a table.

Our waiter who took our order seemed to be just as rude and racist. When we asked them anything in Chinese, they would reply in English even though they were speaking Chinese to each other. We ordered a soup to share but they would not bring any additional bowls, although the table next to us received bowls with their soup order. We had to ask for rice with entree orders, and our waiter did not for once refill our drinks. They penned a gratuity onto our check. Some restaurants mention this may be added on the menu, but we saw no such warning. The waitress just stood by our table and watched us when we signed the receipt to make sure we paid the tip, which was very intimidating.

Overall the experience was just awful. The whole time we felt like we were treated with disgust and disdain. I would NEVER go back there and would advise anyone who wants a pleasant dining experience to avoid it at all costs.
author: Justin H.

description: If you think you know what kind of Chinese food that you want, don't eat here. However, if you are open to waiting and exploring some food that you probably would not normally order then eat here. We waited in the long cash only line for about 45 mins. When we were ready to be seated (there was 7 of us), the waiter asked if we had any allergies...  No but does a vegetarian count? Whoosh server disappears. Ten minutes later food starts coming out. Wft?  Did we order this?but who cares. First a Bok choy dish, next some rice and tofu dish (who eats tofu, but the vegetarian) he only got a taste, the rest of us scoffed this dish down.  next a fish dish and chicken dish Wow   What a whirlwind. The food the tasty and fresh. I am not sure what each dish was but it sure was delicious and cheap.  The bill was split 7 ways. 17 buckaroos a piece seriously.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Zagat-rated and we're the only Asian diners in the entire (albeit small) Chinese restaurant. Two warning signs from the beginning.  I grew up eating American-Chinese and Chinese food so I have definite preferences for my Chinese food. It's similar to how my classmates hated cafeteria food but I thought it was great because I had no reference for how meatloaf, spaghetti or pizza should taste. Well, I've realized that I never agree with Zagat reviewers on Chinese food.

The food is greasy, edible, but nothing special.  Our first dish was the garlic fried fish dish. Rather than garlicky as described, it was very sweet. I can't recall eating such a sweet fish dish before and was not fond of it. The house noodle dish was boring yet too salty (keep in mind, I'm on a restricted sodium diet). Just sauce and noodles with a bit of greenery. Eggplant dish was ok and glistening with grease. They were very prompt in bringing out the first two dishes.

The main thing I remember is how they rushed, rushed, rushed us. We came on a Wednesday after 9pm so I understand.  While growing up and working in a Chinese restaurant, I hated the latecomers too. However, you can't be so blatant about it and you can't rush us when you're the reason for the delay.

First, after asking if it was our first time, the waitress said, "Ok. Chicken, fish, calamari, pork!" and tried to clear away our menus. I'm indecisive so I was somewhat ok with this but my friend was completely flustered. We said it was too many entrees for 4 people, so the waitress said, "Ok. Chicken, fish, pork. No? Chicken, calamari, pork!" We asked her to come back for our order.

Second, we ordered three entrees and rice. They gave us entree 1, entree 2 and the bill. I thought it was strange to receive the bill before all the food. Apparently, they forgot entree 3. If you're trying to rush us, bring out all the dishes so we eat in a reasonable amount of time, i.e. before closing. Since there was a delay in the food, we stayed past their closing time.

Third, they mopped the floors, moved the tables, and turned on the bright lights as we were finishing with dinner (I did not note if it happened before or after their closing time of 10). I found the whole situation hilarious and joked to my friends, "Excuse me. I'm going to use the restroom before they lock that up too." Another point of hilarity: a piece of the handle flew off the bathroom sink when I turned on the water. I screwed it back into its divot, so easily fixed but watch out for it.

IN SHORT, this food is edible but I wouldn't make a special trip to eat here if I were a tourist. When I moved here from the Midwest (via San Diego), I was ecstatic about the availability of so many things I couldn't readily get before such as dim sum, steamed buns, whole steamed fish, roasted duck. House of Nanking, on the other hand, is Americanized Chinese food. It is no better nor worse than any Chinese restaurant you can find across America. Unless you are homesick and are seeking comfort in the familiarity of home, eat somewhere else. Try something you can't find at home.
author: Yan E.

description:
Finally I can die happy. I got to eat here!!!! didnt have to wait one and a half hour like my last two attempts!!!! 

Now the question is...Did it worth it?Would I trade my girlfriend and my dog for a permanent no waiting seat? Would I suffer through a Justin Bieber & Britney Spears concert singing duet for 3 hours???...Without any kind of hesitation and wishing I had some background music right now , I have to say Hell to the YES!!!

Their food is OUTSTANDING .. went with 2 people that dont eat chinese food and they were ordering like it was their last meal!!! Everything was packed with flavor!! The eggrolls were intense , so was the chiquen and chow mein.

Why am I not giving it 5 stars? Because it took me 3 times to be able to eat there and also because not only the food is very authentic but the employees as well. With that said, it was a little challenging to communicate with them sometimes (took 5 minutes to get an empty cup request completed  because the 1st time I got water, the 2nd time I got coke and the 3rd time I didnt get anything)

Other than that , this place is where its at for chinese food. Numero uno in my book
author: Raul T.

description: What a disappointment.  I ate here on a recommendation of a co-worker who grew up in San Fran. We compared Nanking and Brandy Ho's. No comparison, Nanking is just average. No lunch menu, more expensive mains, and a very small menu with limited selection. I had a salt and pepper shrimp meal which WAS good but not worth the price. Sorry House of Nanking, you don't measure up to Brandy's.
author: Tim L.

description:
This is the one of the worst restaurants we've ever been to. The boyfriend and I were visiting SF during the first week of December and this restaurant was recommended by a couple of people.
When we got there the restaurant was packed and the lady wanted to seat us in a large table already packed but which had two empty seats. Nope. That doesn't work for me. Cramped in a large table between other people? Not acceptable (-2).
We were then given a small empty table in the corner (+1).
We ordered one hot and sour soup and the sesame chicken dish. The hot and sour soup had a foul taste. It was horrible. The chicken dish had just a handful of chicken pieces and lots and lots of soggy sweet potatoes. Seriously? (-2).
Apart from all this, the servers were handling money and food at the same time. Really??? (-10)!! 
I was sick to my stomach and could not wait to get to the hotel.
When we left, there was a huge line outside. I felt like telling them all it was not worth it.
author: Rennie M.

description: Food good, service was terrible!  The wait staff very short with attitudes, our four entrees ordered came to the table in phases.  The only thing that didn't take long was our check, we asked,we received and quick.  Service not included....you can say that again.
author: Moose G.

description: This place used to be great. Super yummy and fun. Now it just seems that it is a greedy shallow shell. Incredibly rude  service. Small portions and ridiculously over priced. This is not the same place used to be. Avoid it all costs.
author: Edward D.

description: Fantastic food. Service not so much but you can't eat that. Had the fried onion cake, house noodles, sautéed pea tendrils (amazing!) and the sesame chicken. I have been craving good Chinese food for a long time and this is by far a standout!  Can't wait to come back. Maybe for dinner later tonight?!
author: Steve W.

description: This restaurant does not take reservations which I normally avoid. I'm glad I came as the food and service were excellent. The meal was served family style and was a great value for the money. Very affordable!
author: Stacey B.

description: Being a SF native, I always wanted to try this place since I see long lines most of the time. I was always skeptical since I know it usually attracts tourists. I came with a friend around 5:30ish on a Friday and was seated right away. It was quickly getting busy. My friend spoke to them in Cantonese so the waiter assumed we could read and gave us a secret Chinese menu! They have a secret menu and the dishes are different than the American menu. We ordered the stir fired tofu with pork and shrimp and the dry fried-spare ribs, which was what the waiter recommended. The dishes were definitely very flavorful but a little salty for my taste. The dry-fried spare ribs were too vinegary for my taste but my friend liked it. It is supposed to taste sweet and sour. They definitely provided better customer service for us since we were Chinese. I felt bad for the table next to us who was ignored by the servers. I had to flag down the server for them!!
author: Rosanna T.

description: Recently we went this place. It was dirty, almost no service. Very dirty handwriting manual. Dishes had nothing special. We ordered three that should be around $40, but checked out each one over charged more than $3 dollars.  Overall, bad, disappointed.
author: Fuji U.

description:
Hahaha this place is so crazy! It's so tiny and everyone just gets in this huge line on the sidewalk that wraps around the corner. My ex and I lived a few blocks away and were constantly wondering what the big deal was so one day after months of curiosity, we stood in the queue and were shortly (25 minutes later) seated at a tiny table bumping elbows with fellow patrons. I'm pretty sure our server didn't bring us exactly what we ordered but am pleased to report that whatever we had was delicious. 

There's an old myth about this place saying that if you don't order food fast enough they bring food out to you and then charge you for it. I kinda wished that happened. Maybe I'll go back and be indecisive until they just bring out mysterious plates for me.
author: Christina S.

description: This is the best Chinese restaurant for vegetarian in town.. The owner Mr. Fang is amazing host and you can rely on him to serve you best dishes.. My personal favorites are sizzling rice soup and onion cake..
author: Parthiv T.

description:
Don't be put off by the location. I was eyeing up the area whilst in a taxi and felt like I'd been tricked by my friends into going to a massage parlour as thats all that surrounds the place. When I reached it, I was relieved to see it was indeed a restaurant - but not a high class looking one. But that's cool, I'm a more of a hole-in-a-wall kind of guy anyway.

Got in and was eyeing through the menu trying to decide what to order when the waitress promptly took all the menu's away from us and basically asked us to 'trust her'. I mentioned I would be going for vegetarian dishes which she kind of acknowledged and disappeared.

The experience over the next hour was a real joy as dish after dish of delicious food was bought out. I don't know what half of it was called, but I do know it tasted great and our group had a great time. 

I don't think some of the dishes were 'true chinese' but, even then, they all tasted fantastic and just ate and ate until we had to plead with our waitress not to bring us any more. 

Will definitely be going back next time I'm in San Fran.
author: Javvad M.

description:
Just learned one of my friend went here recently, can't believe this place is still around.  It is the definition of a tourist trap.  The food here is worse than Panda Express.

If you don't have PF Chang or Panda Express where you live, and you feel you must have over priced chinese food when you're in SF, try Yank Sing.
author: Shane L.

description: Really good food, I liked everything including my tea that had a handmade ball of flowers and leaves that bloomed in my tea.  It's not trendy or even nice really, but the food is good.
author: Sarah S.

description: This place is super good!!! The food is bomb the restaurant and the service is ok. If you are look for good food and don't care about the staff or restaurants ambiance this is your place. I ALWAYS bring friend and family to House of Nanking when I visit San Francisco.
author: Juan M.

description: Love this restaurant......great dumplings and fried noodles. It is not fancy but the food is awesome!! I love real Chinese food and this place is spot on! I can't wait to come back.
author: Shelley B.

description:
Simply ask the owner or waiter to bring you food for the table. Sesame chicken and beef were awesome. Eggplant was great too! Fantastic!

*Disclaimer: I had more than a few beers when I came here. But my friends came back and confirmed that it was equally as good sober.
author: Jonathan C.

description: The best Chinese food we have ever had. A must if you are ever in San fran. One of our new favorite restaurants.  Amazing. I ordered shrimp and mushrooms with rice and we had egg roll appetizer.  Every bite was incredible.
author: Amber G.

description:
Not to impressed. A friend took us here after he had a great meal. Even he thought this time was not so good. It's very busy so be prepared to wait, and to share your table with strangers. Not a big deal till we had to get up twice for other people to get into the table. Kinda annoying, but not the worst thing ever. 
The flowering blossom tea is really cool, but for the price only once is good. The food portions are good sized and you can share easily which is the idea. You order dishes and do family style. The food was just mediocre. I'd not chose to go back again, but would if someone really wanted to.
author: Stephanie O.

description: Hands down one of the best chinese food places.  my freinds and i went here a while back.  the food was so good.  I always forget the name so i must pester my freind.  therefore i am writing a review so that i can remember the name.  they place is very small and crowded so make freinds with the people at the table next to you.  i had the sizzling rice soup that will come back again
author: Shontai C.

description: Inattentive, horrible service with not giving you a chance to ask for additional items or drinks, focused on volume and not quality.  Cab driver said it was fresh with a rotational menu...false.  Place was unclean with open glasses of water sitting in glasses right next to the bathroom entry with a line of guests standing in front of it. Food was bland!  Scallop dish was okay overall.  Given the high expectations I had in visiting china town in San Francisco, I was heavily disappointed.  Save the visit for a place more worthy...where?  Somewhere else.
author: Glenn P.

description: I'm only giving this place 4 instead of 5 stars so that hopefully it deters some people... Food is excellent service is... Erm? Brisk.
author: James A.

description:
Health alert!  No soap in Bathroom!! 5% soap 95% water in the soap container. If that!!

Diluted soap water doesn't even make suds. The cooks and waiters use the same bathroom. 

Cant sanitize your hands without soap. Hella nasty.


Unfortunately for me I had already eaten before I saw this.

I even recommended them to replace the non existing soap, They did with watered down barely any soap in the bottle soap.

Ok i hI guess I should sorta expect this sorta thing from a chinese restaurant in the city. Surprisingly the food was decent and I didn't get  sick
author: Max m.

description: I was in the mood for a hole in the wall,Munich usually means cheap and good. House of Nan did not let me down. Had the hot and sour soup, which had a very nice kick to it, the sesame chicken which was perfectly crunchy, and a shrimp special with a white garlic sauce that was also great. Stay away from the house wine, would have been better off with water!
author: Swinda P.

description: Food arrived very late and in wrong order. We asked for rice but they completely forgot about it and we tried to get the waiters attention while he ignored. When I gave the tip for the service, which I shouldn't even have, the waiter looked at me and yelled "scum" at me. Don't come here unless if you want bad service and insults
author: Mahyar Z.

description:
The Setting:  Dinner with my cousin and her bf, Wednesday night 815p, no res, sat after 5 min.

The Food:  3 Stars
The Service: 2.5 stars
The Vibe: 2.5 stars

The GOOD:
1.  Sesame Chicken - probably the best Sesame Chicken I've had anywhere, much less SF!  We all liked it so much, we ordered a second one.

The OK:
Everything else (Fried Tofu in Blackbean Sauce, Panfried Gralic Fish, Pork Dumplings).  No amazing moments to be had by these dishes.  Sauces were standard, everything edible but nothing memorable.

The Bottom Line: This place has a lot of hype and reputation, so I had likely unrealistic expectations.  The vibe was crowded but not in a particularly fun way.  The service was a bit too quick, but regulars seemed to know how to pace it.  Lesson learned.  But this was a solid, inexpensive ($95 with tip for three people and two beers each) dinner for a weeknight.  The better options (House, Chotto) are more expensive.
author: Kevin S.

description: Food was very good, but if you want to enjoy your food don't bother with this place. It is just like a mill. They want to get you in and out. The moment you are close to being done with your meal they put the check in front of you and stand there until you pay and leave.   I don't think that I'll go to this place again.
author: kambiz m.

description: We come here every time we come to the City over the past 23 years. Never disappoints! The pot stickers are what we measure all others against.
author: Shay C.

description: If u are looking for the best Chinese restaurant in SF then u gotta check this place out. The best time to come here is before lunch time or before dinner time otherwise u'll be waiting in line for an hour or more but it is so worth it! My advice, don't use the restroom before eating. Remember u're in China town.  Almost all of the restrooms in this area is not really clean.
author: Marjorie U.

description:
This is a fantastic place. We learned about this place from our cab driver who not only told us about this place but also thought this was one of best Chinese place in town, considering he is from Mongolia, that sounded to me more authentic. 

This is a place not very fancy and intact close to a neighborhood with bunch of adult entertainment. Once we went inside for a late lunch, the place wasn't really very crowded but there were plenty of customers. We were seated and wondering what to order, then came the chef. He asked us whether we eat spicy food and eat all kinds of food. Then he said he will make something for us that we would like. He took the menu and went to instruct the cook the meal.    

First, we received onion pancake as an appetizer, that was not even on the menu (I think). It had stuffed green onions in a pancake fried, and topped with a sauce that was spicy but too much. I had lots of Chinese food, but never this one. This was wonderful. Then he have us a chicken curry with broccoli and green beans with a bit of cabbage in it. This was just as flavorful and very tasty, the sauce was more like a Thai curry sauce.  Finally, we received a shrimp plate with apple, both the shrimp and the apple was similar to that you will find in 'Bang bang Shrimp' by Bone Fish only milder, and more tasty. For these with a beer and a Coke, the bill was only $36. Can't beat that. If I get another opportunity I will certainly come here.
author: Partha B.

description: It was good tasting food yes but it took them average 20 minutes to bring each item out . Kids food was brought out last, we had to constantly remind them about our food . Their servers were rude and payed more attention to other tables . There were about 3 other tables who came in after us and they got all of their meals and ate before we got our second plate of food . The restaurant is tiny and their chairs were falling apart , they wanted me to sit on a metal stool while everyone sat on a regular chairs  . The owner kept trying to rush us to order and ended up just ordering our food which I heard is what he normally does . We tried the dish he recommended and we didn't like it at all. They brought out the check and the dish he recommended was the most expensive thing on the menu . We asked them to take it off because we only tasted it the plate was pretty much full , the server gave us a nasty attitude and was just talking badly to other people working there . When we paid my friends decided not to tip because of such a horrible service , I'm all for tipping but you can't expect a tip when you practically forgot about our table . When the server saw that we didn't leave a tip she started making a big deal and was getting angry over it. We had three kids who just wanted to go home but she wasn't trying to let us leave . When we finally left the owner tried to follow us out . Never have I ever experienced such horrible service in my life . I do not recommend this place whatsoever .
author: Adriana S.

description:
After hearing about House of Nanking from a friend we decided to try it out when we had a guest in town.  Worst experience of her entire visit.  I can live with no atmosphere but the food and service were horrendously bad.  We came for lunch on a Friday.  My husband ordered the short ribs which were so fatty and gristle riddled they were inedible.  He pushed the plate away after two bites - not that anyone there checked back, noticed, or even cared.  My sister-in-law's meal was just okay.  My meal never came.  Apparently, serving a table all their meals at the same time isn't a high priority.  When I asked the waiter where my lunch was, he was very snotty and said they cook the meals one at a time and it would get there when it was ready.  Alrighty then.  By this time we were all eating off of our guest's plate.  Can't remember what it was but it was unremarkable.  I eventually canceled my order since everyone was finished eating and by this time I was afraid the kitchen or the waiter would spit in it.  Terrible experience and very disappointing for our guest who wanted so badly to eat good Chinese food in Chinatown.  The manager did begrudgingly take my meal off the tab but still didn't mention my husband's untouched ribs.  They may have been good back in the day but you can only live off your reputation for so long.  Horrible..

Heard from the manager.  First said she was "shocked" then told me it was my own fault that I had an expectation of decent service since it's not "traditional."  Noticed she's made that same comment to many other unhappy customers.  This is the first time I can every remember not leaving a tip.  I was feeling bad about that but now I'm not.
author: Marcie B.

description: There was a line as they don't take reservations, but it moved quickly because the service was so fast. The food was delicious and the dumpling soup reminded me of home cooked food. I'd definitely recommend this place to friends!
author: Steph P.

description: This was a great restaurant! We ate several dishes, sesame chicken, egg rolls, chicken fried rice and a stuffed mushroom dish. All of them were delicious. I would recommend this place if you want good food and atmosphere.
author: Amy H.

description: Great food and great price. We only had to wait ten minutes for our table. We ordered rice soup, fried rice, onion pancake and garlic fish. If you like to go to a restaurant which serves good food  but have minimal expectations from the wait staff, then you should definitely try this place.
author: Devanjali L.

description:
House of Nanking deserves a solid 3 stars- that should simply be stated up front. Does it deserve the crazy amounts of hype it gets? Well, dear Yelper, I'll leave that decision up to you.

The two of us arrived around 9:00 p.m. on a Friday night, and we're told the wait would be about 5 minutes. There was a table for two clearing, and we were told we could have it once the current patrons cleared out. INSTEAD, they ended up pushing this table with another one, and sat a party of 6 that ARRIVED after us! (We also learned you can pay boatloads of cash to buy pass the line and get seated immediately.) POINT BEING: There is NO rhyme or reason to this place and their seating system. You can stand in that line for days, and it will SERIOUSLY have nothing to do with when they choose to seat you.

The service is fast and brisk, and hardly friendly. These people are all about pumping people in and out of that place. The entire time you're there you're going to feel rushed- and way it may sound negative, I don't mean it to be. It's just all part of the experience!

As far as the food it concerned, it's pretty bomb.com. We ordered:

Won Ton Soup (This is like none I've ever had before! Lemon and cream based with the most AMAZING won-tons I've ever had. Seriously, if you could just order wontons, I would.)

Crispy Chicken (Delicious! Lightly fried to perfection and oh-so-flavorful!)

House Chow Mein (Meh- I wasn't floored by this dish.)

I've been told the crab won-tons are TO DIE FOR, but they are no longer on the menu. I'll probably be back- because this time around I know a delicious meal awaits beyond the chaos.
author: Annalise F.

description:
I'm surprised this place has lower ratings then what I would have expected after I went there last night with a group of 6. We arrived around 9pm and the place was packed.  Getting a group of 6 in a crowded restaurant quickly in this city can be tricky at best but within 5 minutes we were seated with menus and drinks were ordered. 

Despite accidentally bringing us 6 beers rather then 4 waters and 2 beers, they were quick to fix the error and take our orders. Given only one of us had had experience with the restaurant before the waitress, after we had asked what she recommended, basically suggested an order for us. One of our members was gluten free AND Vegan and they didn't even blink an eye.  SO nice!  

The food came out quickly (though my only complaint is that it would have been nice to balance the vegan with the non-vegan dishes so our vegan friend didn't have to wait and watch us eat). And the food was amazing!  So fresh that we joked that they must have live animals in the back they killing and preparing as we order. The flavors were unlike anything I've tasted in Chinese food in the past. One dish combined fresh raw tomatoes, cooked shrimp, crispy rice, and basil which seems like a weird combination but "OH MY!"  My mouth still waters for it. So yummy. There was a crispy beef with bok choy.  It melts in your mouth.  Fried calamari that wasn't tough and chewy but rather soft and almost melted in our mouths.  Everything was amazing and absolutely delicious.  Extra added bonus for supporting both Vegan and Gluten free needs.  Loved it and would totally return!
author: Renata P.

description:
1) Food similar to Panda Express. 
2) All the dishes were sweet . 
2) Angry Man served the food. 
3) I can make better fried rice.  
4) I was told by veteran foodie that the quality has really gone down. 
5) First time and last time, never again
author: Aaron P.

description: I went the 16 of july. The servers were mean, rude, and unattentive, one even denied some foods. My brother wanted a fruit tea but she said no fruit tea just berry, but the previous and next customers got fruit tea.
author: Kosta S.

description: Good food. Fast service. Fast moving line. Sesame chicken and pork dumplings are good. Staff not friendly, but not mean. At least their food backs up their attitude.
author: Emma M.

description: I love this place and can't wait to go back. Sure, it may not be the most authentic Chinese food, but this Chinese American also doesn't feel it veers very far off either? There are several vegetarian/vegan options, and the eggplant/sweet potato dish is definitely delicious and perfectly sized. I ate here once before and had an assortment of things, but don't quite remember well enough to commit them to paper. I'm also a fan of the branding, décor, and general styling of the place. It's what I wish Chino would be! I also had no issues with seating, as there was plenty of space when I arrived. The staff were perfectly fine!
author: Shendi X.

description:
Really wanted to love this place.  Close to where I live and great location to pickup dinner on the way home.  Was very disappointed with lunch experience about two weeks back.  

Service from the beginning was less than satisfying starting with menu's that appeared to be designed for tourist (about a dozen items on laminated page).  After we ordered, noticed others asked for the standard menu which appeared to have greater selection of food options.  Waiter never offered  other menu option.  

When food arrived, appeared to be warm but as if it was made sometime before and put into a food warmer (buffet style).  Came to the table within five minutes of our ordering.  We had the house Chicken and the mushroom dish.  Both were average in taste and not memorable.  Regarding the rice, Wow! Came on a flat dinner  plate and was not warm (also slightly over cooked).  

Finally, when we arrived (around 2pm) place was about 1/2 full (would expect service to be pretty good).  Waited about 5 minutes for someone to come to our table.  About half way through our meal place filled up quickly.  This is when the person that seated us (may be owner) started hovering near our table and within a few minutes put the cheek on our table.  We were still finishing lunch!  Tried not to pay attention to her or the older man that also was hovering near the door (looking our way).  Finally finished lunch and plates were gone.  Guess they were trying to move us along (we were only in the restaurant for about 35 minutes).  Know there was a wait but I guess they forgot we were also paying customers.  

Unpleasant experience and food was just ok.  Will never return.
author: Steve F.

description: I've been here a handful of times and it's going downhill. The waiters are rude and inattentive. When I ordered my food they forgot my beef in the dish and it took me forever to get someone's attention to correct the order. Tables and cups are a bit dirty too. Still love the fried onion cakes with peanut sauce.
author: Av K.

description:
Crowded, fast service but they kind of throw the plates on the table and disappear, and reasonably priced.  Stopped on recommendation of friend that likes to Nanking.

The Calamari was not as tender as expected, cooked a little to long.  Others in our group really enjoyed their meal. 

Now you can just ask to give whatever you think is good but we did not try that.   Table next to us did that.  They enjoyed the meal and waiter explained their meal to them.
author: DJ J.

description: Go to the House of Nanking - what more can I say?  The two thousand plus reviews speaks for itself.  After stopping in for a quick bite during the lunch hour, I was thoroughly impressed with the fast service and savory food.  Sure, I can go on about the sounds of 'mmm, mmm, oh so good!' echoing from the table behind me (I am not kidding), but what's the point?  If you are in the mood to have an experience, stop on by - it may very well be the best you've ever had!
author: Cam D.

description:
My friends kept saying that we need to eat here, but to hurry because we might have to wait in an hour line to get in. A lot of fellow yelpers also mentioned the long wait to get in, but luckily there was no line when we arrived, and were sat immediately.

It is family style, so we all picked a few dishes and had a little bit of everything. We ordered the famous sesame chicken, which many people have said is the best item on the menu here. We also ordered calamari, chow mein, shrimp fried rice, and something with beef in it. Like another review had mentioned you literally tell them what kind of meat you want and they bring something amazing out! 

The sesame chicken was so amazing! We all loved it and thought it was delicious, so good and tasty, couldn't get enough of it, lol. The Calamari was also awesome, but a little spicy for me, but I ate it anyways, because it was so yummy. I love fried rice, so I was pretty sure there was no way this one would let me down, and I was right! Totally yummy with lots of shrimp in it, yummmmm. 

The chow mein was a huge disappointment! The noodles were super thick, slimy and yucky. The noodles were also way too spicy and just lacked any real awesome flavor to them. If they had been less spicy I might of enjoyed them a bit more. The mystery beef dish was also really good, and I did not have high expectations for it at all. I usually find a lot of Chinese beef dishes mediocre, but not this one. The beef was very juicy and tasty and came with veggies. 

Service isn't great of course, like most Asian restaurants, but the food is awesome. We also didn't wait that long for food to come out, but they sort of bring one dish at a time, which can be annoying sometimes. I would definitely agree that this place is great, and will for sure be back next time I'm in town.
author: Jeanette S.

description: My favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco! The house noodles is the best! Food is very good!
author: Lorencito D.

description:
Amateur cooking. One of the worst tourist traps around. 
Dirty. Sticky. Gross hole in the wall. Even the forks are disgusting. 
They like to rush you out ASAP. Not very cheap either, considering the cheap quality of "food". Service is rude, and the waiters act like they do you a great favor. 
I had diarrhea from the oil drenched bok choy salad and the over salted wonton soup for the rest of the day! Health hazard!!!
Usually I don't write reviews, but this place grossed me out so much and made me so sick that I had to post a comment.
author: Jul L.

description: Can I just say HILLLLARIOUS!!!!!!!! Seriously, for those who have never been to China or just need to understand, that the Chinese mean business... Hell, they make everything and we buy it here. So when you come to an authentic Chinese restuarant, don't expect the waiter/waitress to say " hello, my name is Lee and I'm going to be your server today" Here... Your lucky if you get them to let you order. Which happened to us. First of all, there is a wait.. not too long, but you stand outside and patiently hope there is a table enough to sit 6 of you on a Saturday night. After 15 minutes, we sit... woman comes by and quickly says " What do you want to drink?", better be ready. Now, as for ordering, Peter.. THE OWNER, BIG BOSS, and CHEF, whose picture was staring at us above, comes by with his little pad of paper, nothing comes out of his mouth, so, I do the thinkable, ORDER and I try to order fast, he looks at me and starts to take our menus from the table, YIKE, did I offend him? and he says " I'll order for you", WTF? OKAY, are we going to argue with the BOSS. LOL!!! AND HE DID, every 5 minutes, another dish came out, with every different taste, not like in China where all the dishes start to taste the same. We started with the sizzling rice soup, the infamous sesame chicken, the beef was by far delicious, it actually had an Indian spice flavor and the Walnut Shrimp with apples, yes, apples, which clearly made it sweet and flavorable. Some noodle dish, which apparently looks like another signature dish, since I saw every other table ordering and eating it too. It was a fun experience too, just watching and hearing them screaming back and forth, don't expect a quiet, romantic dinner when your here. Part of the enjoyment of going out is not only having a delicious meal, but having an experience that you'll be able to write it on Yelp and hopefully have the enjoyment of reading! :P
author: Alice K.

description:
This place does not deserve the hype it gets. The food is edible, but it wouldn't say its amazing. The restaurant itself is nice and clean and the staff moves quickly, but are still the typical Chinese waiters. 

Most of the dishes are offshoots of traditional Chinese dishes. The calamari was decent, but lacked a flavorful sauce, the fish was cooked well, but also lacked seasoning. The egg plant was good. I recommend that if anything. 

The chow mein was average quality, but for the price was not worth it. The restaurant is right in Chinatown, but was filled with only tourists. That says something about it. Do yourself a favor and cut up and alley or two and try something a bit cheaper and a bit tastier.
author: Danny L.

description: I went there at about 3pm and was surprised that the place was packed and had a line as well. Since it was the 2 of us it was easy for us to get a seat. Ordered the sesame chicken which was crunchy and had a generous amount of sauce on it, together with sweet potatoes and cucumber which added a nice touch and crunch to the dish. We also had the hot and sour broth that wasn't too spicy and was delicious with chunks of meat and tofu. Would be better if there weren't any peas in there.. Which were still undercooked. Overall a pleasant experience with delicious food!
author: Heather C.

description: The worst restaurant I have ever eaten in my opinion, I did not get past the soup. My wife and I ordered two wonton soups. My wife!s came along with my main dish. I requested they take it back and they did. The wanton soup then arrived and looked more like oatmeal and had some ingredient that  I could only compare it to sand. I asked for mustard and was advised they had none. While I was  struggling with the soup, my egg roll arrived and I sent it back and asked for my bill. I had eaten two spoonfuls and that was enough, for besides not being to my liking, I was afraid I was going to crack a tooth. When I order initially fried rice, I could not ascertain whether it was with pork or chicken and could not  get an answer. I should have left then, for the manager and waitstaff were rude , bordering on arrogant. When we were seated,we were placed with six strangers and fortunately they were delightful. I am giving this restaurant 1 star for I cannot  give a minus. I do not understand why people wait in line; but, I didn't understand why Seinfeld waited in line for soup from the soup nazi, even though he had good soup.
author: Paul H.

description:
Of course I waited 10 minutes outside this place for a table. Totally worth it!

Here's what was sampled:

Sesame chicken: Super good! Lots of flavor. 
Chow mein: Best chow mein that I ever had! Lots of sauce, thick noodles. Yum!
Onion cake: Never had an onion cake before so I had no idea what to except. It was really good though!

So overall, really good food. 

Service SUCKED! I had to ask several times just to get my water glass refilled. Really now!

BEWARE: MSG!
author: Cindy B.

description:
First off I'll start with the food. 

Starters:
We started with the seasonal greens which turned out to be Bok Choy and it was really good. It was drizzled in olive oil with chilli and garlic and only lightly grilled which meant it had plenty of crunch (good when served cold). We also had the prawn dumplings which were nice but there was something in the sauce that I personally wasn't big on - it had a certain tartness that lingered on my plate and unfortunately I revisited a few times when I served up another dish on there.

Entrees:
Now for the best part, their classic sesame chicken did not disappoint - I would highly recommend this. We got the the pork stuffed mushrooms too, which were a bit boring in my opinion however my girlfriend really liked them. I think all the garlic from the Bok Choy must've ruined my pallet as I found the mushrooms a bit tasteless. 

Service: 
Was great right up until I asked if I could get change back for the cheque as I didn't want to give an excessive tip (over 30%). This seemed to be a huge inconvenience to the waitress and she proceeded to throw the change (literally) on the table in front of me. It made me laugh but also want to tip less than I'd planned, however in light of the great food and the previous waitress who'd been fantastic all night, I didn't. 

All up:
Great, reasonably priced food and drink. I'd recommend a visit here, but maybe just remember to bring the exact change for the tip and meal and you'll be fine (or just flat refuse to be served by the angry lady!)
author: Mason F.

description:
Please don't go to  this tourist trap.  Otherwise you may run into the "Chinese food" nazi.  She's scary. 

Also, look around.  See any Chinese people?  That should be clue #1 on how "authentic" it is.
If  you like American Chinese (orange chicken, kung pao chicken, which admittedly sometimes I like as well-you're better off at Panda Express).
author: Christopher K.

description:
My fiance and I visited San Francisco last Oct. for my birthday. While there, we had a craving for asian food. We somehow ended up in this little hole in the wall - and im SO glad we did!

The place is very small and not fancy by any stretch of the imagination. Its in the middle of chinatown and parking can be tricky. DO NOT LET THIS DISSUADE YOU FROM GOING. The food was amazing. We had sesame chicken and steamed rice. The plate was big enough to share, and we left satisfied.

The food was very cheap and the service was great. If we ever go back to San Francisco we will definetely go here again.
author: Rosario P.

description: A great experience in China Town!  San Francisco has a great part of the China culture there, and you are able to taste it in House of Nanking.  You are able to identify if a place is good by seeing if there is a line out of the door, and this San Franciscan favorite had one to the corner.  Such a delicious place to enjoy China food without having to jump on a plane for 20 hours.
author: Tess I.

description:
I love House of Nanking and have been going to it from back when it was a bit of a hole-in-the-wall with white and green tiles and we were the only white kids in it.  I'll also say that I still love the food and always leave satisfied.  Last night we had the pea shoots and they were fantastic.

But I'm writing because of how bummed I was at our bill.  $8 for tea.  $8 for a 12 ounce Tsing Tao.  Each.

I feel a bit petty for writing this, and I realize the power of Yelp, but it just sooo bummed me out.  To be charged like that for just a tea, for just a beer, it felt like a real slap in the face, as though the place were just relying on dumb tourists to come in the once and be happy to pay for the experience.

I will, of course, go back.  It's still one of my old favorites.  I still love the food, the begrudging but speedy service.  I'll say the techno music playing was new and not quite right but, whatever, we had a good time, but please don't tell me it's reasonable that more than half the cost of our meal was for two beers and two teas.
author: Modern S.

description: The first time I went to House of Nanking I was impressed with the menu and flavor of the dishes we ordered. The second time we went a year later I got sick, extremely sick. I struggled to get back to the hotel. It was horrible. My husband and I ordered many of the same dishes, but this time around I had a horrible experience. There are so many restaurants that are more consistent, friendlier employees and no lines. I have moved on.
author: Maureen C.

description:
nom nom nom!

It's cramped, it's busy, it's crazy. But this is china town (this part of the sidewalk anyway). I had it to-go, so can't talk about service. I would imagine their service is efficient; spend as little time as possible per customer.

It's probably 3-stars, but i'm a fan, which according to yelp is 4 stars.
author: Frank L.

description:
It was more than 10yrs ago i was there for the first time.
I still remember the old man the owner who ordered for us some food since we were not deciding what we want.
At that time we were kind of bothered by his action but later food came we were like shocked and thankful to the old man the owner who gave us that food.
So good so unique and beautifully seasoned..

We were there after 10yrs the old man wasn't there anymore since ha has a new restaurant and works there or something.
Food was still good without him but i really miss him there.
I will visit his new restaurant and hope to see him again.
author: sera k.

description:
We went yesterday and ordered sesame chicken, chow mien and the salt and pepper shrimp and mushroom. On the menu, it does not mentioned these dishes are spicy at all.
When the dishes came, we tasted it and we found they are too spicy for us to eat, I cannot even eat the shrimp. Therefore, we raised our concern to the waitress and hoped that they can do something for us.
The waitress replied" how come you cannot eat the food? Babies can eat our food, why can't you?" She started to raise her voice and asked why I cannot eat the spicy dishes. I was really upset, because it is not my fault that I cannot eat spicy and the menu did not even mention the sauce is spicy. 
The owner then jumped in and mentioned that she would change the dishes to no spicy. I thought we were lucky to have someone to help, but to my big disappointment, the owner kept blaming us that we cannot have spicy food, we are tourists who will not return so just make whatever that is not spicy then it would be okay.

So she made some cucumber with chicken to replace the sesame chicken, to be honest, I can eat a better cucumber with chicken at anywhere with cheaper price. 

I don't like the attitude of the waiters and waitress. They are mean, rude and not professional. If you would like to pay a high price and enjoy rude service, you can go to House of Nanking. I felt like I need to pay to be insulted.
author: Emilie W.

description: Will never go there again. Food not tasty at all. Tried duck, tofu, and dumpline. Do not recommend. I know in Chinatown, you can not require a good dinning environment, but at least the food can be a little bit better.
author: Joy L.

description:
Not sure why this place is always packed. My friends and I were just walking around and saw this place was not packed on a Wednesday night, so we decided to go in.
