It's not quite soup-nazi-esque, but close.  They like to usher you in like they are herding sheep, take your order as fast as they can, feed you, and kick you out before you know what hit you.  That said, the food is incredible. We ordered about six dishes to share, all of them stellar, and reasonable on the wallet.  I'm sure a lot of people just get up and leave without even ordering, but swallow your pride, Yelper, you will be glad you did.
author: Andy O.

description:
Wish I had taken a picture but I didn't even think of it cause the food was so delicious! We stayed at a hotel in the area and the front desk recommended two places. The first one had a line out the door and we didn't want to wait so we came here. They seated us immediately. 
Cute place! Dimly lit, good for a date or family and friends. We ordered the pork dumplings (recommend by our waitress), the melt in your mouth calamari, sesame chicken and the pork fried rice. Our waitress advised against the fried rice cause it came with steamed rice and it would be too much food. She was sooo right lol the food came out quickly and was fresh.
All of it was delicious! And you can't beat the price. After ordering from regular Chinese places (Friday night take out...) it was great to get some real Chinese!
Also, when we got there there was no wait but towards the end there were a couple of people waiting outside, it didn't take them more than 5 minutes to be seated. 
Go here!
author: Jeni S.

description:
After you've lived in the city for so long you tend to think you're immune from making bad restaurant decisions. Against my better judgement, I allowed my friends to talk me into coming here, which we only did because  we were strolling around looking for a quick bite to eat with vegetarian options. 

The bottom line is that I would not recommend this overpriced restaurant - not to Chinese people who know Chinese food, not even to foreigners who don't know Chinese food. For a cheaper meal, service that isn't rude, no line, and higher quality food, try ANY of these places which are within a 5 minute walk:

-R&G Lounge
-Z&Y Restaurant
-Great Eastern (seafood)
-Loving Hut (100% vegetarian)
-Capital Restaurant (fried chicken wings)

If you're willing to go outside of Chinatown, head to Koi Palace or San Tung
author: T. B.

description: We have been eating here, on and off for more than 20 years.  When I first came, the food was great, always a line out the door, but lots of grease on the walls, and a very crowded small environment.  Over the next several years, the restaurant doubled in size, and cleaned up some, but the hygiene of the work and eating environment continued to suffer.  Two weeks ago, we returned.  The owner was there, and as usual recommended dishes for us to order.  Unfortunately, the food was as close to inedible as any I have ever eaten in my world wide travels.  I don't know what has happened over the past few years to the kitchen, as many of the staff are the same. But I cannot recommend eating here, the food just isn't good.
author: Carol F.

description: Word of advice: If asked if it's your first time, just say No! Choose your own food on the menu. My friends and I (6 of us) made a mistake of saying yes, and the lady working there immediately took our menus and said to trust her and she'll take care of us. Meaning, she gets to choose what we eat. One by one our food came. They were small portions and the taste was just okay. We've had better food at regular Chinese take-outs. And when we got our bill we couldn't believe we spent $150 and we were still hungry. We could've gone to a buffet and ate our hearts out--our choice of food. This place is small, overrated and expensive. I won't  recommend this place to my friends and family.
author: Bords B.

description: Not happy.  Totally overrated.  We waited over an hour to be seated.  Staff was not helpful or friendly once we sat down.  Food came before drinks and was cold and overly saucy.  I am not someone who leaves reviews often but I am sorry to say this place simply is not worth it.
author: Michael B.

description: I would give you NO STARS if yelp has it.  We came from South San Francisco and got to the restaurant at 8:30pm, only to be told that the kitchen is closing and they can't take us in.. Really? You close at 10pm  on yelp and you can't accommodate 2 people at 830pm?  The owner (old guy in the picture)was so rude when I was trying to explain myself.. Oh well, why would he care, he makes so much money... NEVER EVER AGAIN!
author: Cil G.

description:
The food is awesome. I'll lay it out there right now-- you don't go for customer service or ambiance... It's great food. They pack people in as best they can... As a result, you *might* be asked to move/move over in order to accommodate another party. 
Go, eat well ,and enjoy.
author: K. H.

description: I came for a birthday dinner the night of the Chinese New Year parade in SF - I made reservations for a party of 10 a few days before and though it was very busy, we were seated on time and served promptly. The waitress ordered for us so we were served 8-10 dishes one after the other, making for a great experience. The calamari and butter beef dishes were stand-outs. The atmosphere is very cozy, though it was loud the night we went and tends to be so inside as well. Being direct and clear with the wait staff goes a long way - checking on reservation, etc.
author: H C.

description: Biggest tourist trap and I got sucked right in. Looking for authentic Chinese? Stay away. Their sesame chicken and dumplings are like something that you would get at panda express. My Chinese instinct failed me.
author: Chris C.

description:
Terrible.  This place has such long lines, but if you look, no asians.  Bad sign.  Our hotel recommended this place since it was around the corner.  I wanted a bottle of the plum wine, and the waiter said, 'no, too sweet'.  Well, if you don't want my money, that's fine.  So I only got one glass.  i probably would have come close to finishing a bottle if I had gotten it.

So any place that charges $1.50 for rice is not really a real chinese place.  And add to that insult, they didn't even ask if we wanted rice, just brought it and charged us $3 for 2 bowls of rice.  Seriously?

An the rice was terrible, it wasn't cooked properly so some of the rice was still uncooked.  

Makes me just mad thinking about our experience.
author: Linda W.

description: Delicious and original Chinese food.  I would recommend LITERALLY ordering either "fish", "chicken", and/or "beef"; do NOT order off the menu.  If you can't resist you can order their famous chicken dish and honey crispy beef.  These items should impress you.
author: Douglas S.

description:
I used to live three blocks away from House of Nanking. I would go there often and always to take visiting guests there. Just thinking about the Nanking fried pork and sweet potatoes makes me want to drive 1100 miles to get it. crispy rice noodles in sauce, sesame chicken... I've tried to cook these favorite dishes, I can't. 
  nothing more do i want that to wait an hour in line for a table, take abuse from uncaring, abrupt waiters, sit cheek to jowl with SF hipsters. Yes! to eat that food!
author: Jim W.

description:
First, the food was great. But three issues will prevent me from ever going here again. 

1.  I ordered the fried rice. On the menu, it says that any rice or noodle dish can have chicken, beef, or pork added for 2$. I asked the waitress if she would recommend beef or pork with it. She said beef and then left. Come bill, an extra entree of beef for $16.99 was on our tab. I asked our waitress about it and she got quite combative. Saying that I ordered it as a "side". And since I ate it I have to pay. My dish was $9. The menu says beef can be added for 2$. Why on earth would I want something that is almost twice as much as my meal as a "side"? Clearly there was a misunderstanding. Instead of trying to clear this up she raised her voice and then walked off while grumbling about it some more. Her scene even got the attention of multiple tables near by. 

2.  Two water glasses had dried food on it. And when another person at our table received more water there was a red floating "thing" in it. 

3. There was 10-15 minutes between each guest at the table getting their meal. 

I'm sad because I want to like this place. The food is good. I could possibly overlook the second & third issues. But I've never been treated so rudely before.
author: Tyler C.

description: It was CRAZY DELICIOUS. Best part (as always) was letting the waiter order for us.  Worth the 45 minute long line out the door.
author: d w.

description: Suggested by the concierge at the omni, house of Nanking did not disappoint. Dumplings were really good. Wonton soup was excellent, Green beans and bok choi were fantastic.
author: Jessica B.

description: This place is very bad, its just a big tourist trap - ordered the porkchops and sesame chicken and both were fairly horrible. Food was bad, prices were high, and service was nonexistent.
author: David Z.

description: This place has some delicious dishes. I wouldn't miss the onion pancake or the famous chicken. Taking off a star due the the grease factor.
author: Rob S.

description: Really excited to experience this but we showed up at 2:45pm and they are closed. The worker said they open at 5pm. No hours on the door and yelp says they open at 11am. Nope. After paying for parking and having to relocate to a different restaurant we won't be back.
author: Brandy B.

description:
Disappointment! Fried rice was very salty. Very Very bad service, so rude
Sesame chicken dish was good. This is not any extra ordinary hotel
author: Sarun N.

description: Great hole in the wall joint. Fantastic food, lady that took our order was rude and direct to the point-I loved it!  Definitely try this place if you want good Chinese food.
author: Ray C.

description:
Giving this place one star is like a compliment. Unauthentic Chinese food. Once you enter, you'd see that the floor and walls are dirty. Once you sit down, you'd notice there's no chopsticks, and the menus look grimy with sticky bits of who-knows-what all over them. Once you look around for the inexistent chopsticks, you'd then notice that this "authentic" Chinese restaurant lacks Asian customers. If this doesn't compel you to get out and find a better place to eat, then wait till the food appears. For example, the pork potstickers have the outside texture of old cardboard. Add the slightly bitter peanut sauce which is covering them, and you get the sort of meal that a mediocre cook would create in his/her bouts of infantile culinary experimentation. 
The low mein looks like something one could buy from Costco and heat in a microwave. 
The wonton soup has old fish chunks inside, and it has too much salt added. (Maybe to mask the old fish flavor)

Once you're done gagging on your meal, the check appears. To top off the whole unauthentic "authentic" charade, they also like to sneakily add in extra items to your bill. So, if you do still decide to try out this dump despite my warning, then do pay careful attention to the bill.
author: Nick L.

description:
Me, my husband and two teens were staying in a hotel near Chinatown and we decided on Chinese food for lunch.  House of Nanking was crowded (usually a good sign) but we were seated immediately.  While we were looking at the menu one of the servers came along, asked us if it was our first time there, and yes we said. Then she asked what type of food we liked.  She took the decision-making off our hands.  She brought us a beef dish, chicken dish, seafood (calamari) dish, and chow mein dish for us.  All of it was delicious and I think there were just one little calamari piece leftover.

It's not a "cheap eats" restaurant but doable and well worth it.  Loved the cozy atmosphere.
author: Laura B.

description:
I always take my out of town visitors (if I like them) to House of Nan King. I was introduced to this quirky establishment 7 years ago and I will not forget that first time. It was the Sesame Chicken with sweet potatoes that did it for me! 

During my most recent visit, the place had been remodeled since my prior visit 4 years ago. It is no longer dipped in red and white tile but has a much more calming natural wood look. The only decorations on the walls are still the restaurant's many awards and celebrity autographs. The owner still sits in the corner, discerning ever customer that walks through his door. Fortunately, some things never change.

Please, if it is your first time, don't insult the chef and order for yourself. Allow a culinary master to bring out the most inspiring dishes of the day. You will NOT be disappointed! Earlier today our meal consisted of pork won ton and crispy rice soup, potstickers in a sweet glaze, honey tempura green bean and shrimp, Sesame Chicken, a delicate beef, tomato, and mushroom salad, and a large bowl of steamed rice. Every time I have eaten here "family style" as they call it, the Famous Sesame Chicken has been served, so no need to worry there.

If you are visiting the city or have yet to explore this exceptionally fantastic restaurant, take the trek downtown and eat. here. now. House of Nan King is now side by side with Fisherman's Wharf, Alcatraz, and the Golden Gate Bridge as a default tourist attraction in my book. A special place in a special city.
author: T W.

description:
I don't know why a lot of people like this place. Usually it's a huge line in front. Totally overrated. 

It was Friday night somehow we didn't hit a line. But insight we got a really rude service with an attitude and very unpleasant manners. Mediocre food. Also they overcharge my card 6$. That completed my overall experience with this restaurant.
author: Valerie S.

description: Quick service and good food. Started with Pot Stickers and both of us agreed they were dry and underwhelming, but the entrees made up for it. The sesame chicken and calamari were excellent.
author: Mark E.

description: Mmmmmm. Portobello mushroom appetizer was perfect, followed by chicken and pork. I will definitely be coming back. There's not a lot of seating, so you may have to wait for a table.
author: Kevin G.

description:
Worst restaurant I have ever been into in the world. 

Hotel recommend to come here. Food was just ok, service was horrible. Wanna be waitress was very rude never smiled or listened to what we said and was sick and kept coughing and blowing her nose. Never checked on us, refill of drinks or removed dirty dishes when we were done eating. I had to get up 3 times, once to ask for chop sticks, once for an extra dish then once for to go boxes. 

Now the best part. Then she asks if we are done yet and brings the bill and asks for my credit card and stands there and waits for me to get it out of my wallet. Then comes back with the receipt and pen and points to the tip line with her finger and stands there watching me fill out the tip. She was lucky she even got a tip. Then she freaks out on me for a 10% tip and says it is supposed to be at least18%. I then said, do you see our table, every empty dirty dish is still here non of our drinks have been refilled you never checked on us once and I had to get up 3 times to get help. You are lucky to get anything. Then she gave me a dirty look and stormed off with my receipt. This place was not worth the $70 we spent for dinner and there are plenty of other places to eat in Chinatown that are much better in SF. 

I have had better food and service in Ningbo China for a fraction of the cost, this is one SF Chinese waitress that has lost her native roots and does not represent her country very well at all. She must be the owners daughter to still have her job because she also got some raised eyebrows from customers at other tables as she "served" them.
author: Jihn S.

description: After all the hype about this place and the line which often greets you at the door, I was thoroughly underwhelmed by the House of Nanking. We let the manager just bring us dinner. We were a party of 6. We kept waiting for a great dish but were constantly disappointed. Like most Americanized Chinese places, they fried the meat rather than cook it with aromatics in the wok. Their "melt in your mouth" Fried Calamari was a starter and it was chewy and saturated with lemon sauce. The glazed eggplant was nearly tasteless. Their "Famous Sesame Chicken" was fried pieces of gloppy chicken. Their House Noodles were more appropriate at a North Beach Italian joint . . only not as good. The rice must have been sitting around all day as it was a glutinous ball of rice starch. Yuck! Will not return to this place soon. It's simply a tourist trap.
author: David M.

description:
Non-authentic but delicious Chinese food. This is the place I go to for dinner in Chinatown with friends visiting the Bay area. My favorite dishes are:
- tender sauteed calamari
- crispy honey beef
- fish soup
- sesame chicken
which are all very tasty and affordable. Other dishes are probably good too but I didn't get to try them since their menu offers so many options to choose from! Overall the food feels very refreshing and healthy.

The line is always long but we never waited over 40 min.
author: Jerome T.

description: So good. We had the egg rolls, famous sesame chicken, melt in your mouth calamari, and Salt & Pepper shrimp. Do yourself a favor & order like that exactly. Each item was better then the last & the portions are huge. Been here twice & I'll be back again.
author: Joel D.

description:
Amazed that this place continues to be open, but I guess cheap food has its own methods.

I think this was the first place where I ever as able to witness the cups and cups of MSG getting added to the wok. Inspiring, but not very tasty.
author: Joseph S.

description:
I'm not quite sure how places like this pass health inspections. I just picture them slaughtering chickens right behind the makeshift wall that separates the dining room from the kitchen area. Boxes strewn all over, looked like a Chinatown express shipment just got delivered and they had nowhere else to store it ...seriously a fire hazard. My friend & I were basically sitting at the same table as these 4 guys, could hear every word. Might as well have been sharing their food. 

I really do enjoy little neighborhood places like this, but when food & service don't live up to hype I get a little frustrated. Got seated right away on a Thurs night, but waited probably 10mins just to order drinks (aka glasses of water which should have been brought out immediately). And then our waitress forgot about us. Maybe? Had to hail her down to order dinner. Tried the house noodles - nicely spiced fettucine noodles with clovers(?) & zero veggies, dry braised green beans, and sesame chicken (really the only menu option for chicken). Overall tasty, but @ $10+/dish, only one with meat and no side of rice, that seems overpriced. 

To top it all off, we tried to split the bill on 2 credit cards. She comes over, looks down, and says "$25 minimum credit card". No apology, no workaround, no nothing. ok then ..one card it is. 

"Fun" dinner experience if you're in the mood to socialize with strangers and take attitude from angry Asian servers. PF Chang's gets 10 stars in comparison.
author: Natalie H.

description: I was super excited to try this out on my trip to San Francisco. We were seated quickly around 5:30 then a grumpy old man who clearly had no idea what customer satisfaction was came to take our order. He didn't say anything and just looked at us we would have happily given our order but we had not even gotten menus. He came back in like two minutes and we gave him our order. They forgot my tea :( but anyways the workers I had encountered had no idea how to treat the customers. They practically just threw the food on the table and never came back to check on us. Plus I know generally Chinese food is not healthy but I found it very hard to find any that wasn't fried on the menu
author: Megan K.

description: The Mushu is not on the menu but if you ask for it they will make it for you and it is great. Let just say this food is the REAL thing.  Not your standard Chinese like you find in most US-Chinese restaurants.  We loved this place!!!
author: Doug G.

description: Ever on a downward slope. The food was mediocre at best and I still feel a bit sick and off almost 24 hours later. Bummed. I used to love this place. Service was terrible too. I so miss the old owner being there and truly overseeing the place. 2 people, 4 dishes, no booze - $70. Really? Never again.
author: J K.

description: If you're looking for an authentic Chinese food don't go there. This place is well advertised by the tour guides and it's totally popular among tourists. Food is just average and nothing special.
author: Lana G.

description: I use to come to house of Nanking on each visit to  San Francisco when the line was long and the food was delicious. It's been years and House of Nanking has gone downhill. They drenched every meal in the same sauce. Some of the food  was piping hot the rest was cold. Yuk!  The service was awful and the have a mandatory 15% gratuity which can ensure their bad service. With all the amazing food in San Francisco I would not go here again. Tourist trap:(
author: Marilyn F.

description:
Overrated. 

Probably some of the worst Chinese food I've had in a while. 

Sizzling rice soup: decent but was pretty salty 

Sesame chicken: super saucy and not special at all. At one point my coworker stopped to look at the chicken he was eating because it tasted so funny. 

Lettuce wrap (tofu): probably the only decent dish we got. Not too saucy and flavor was good. 

Onion pancake: just awful. It was like a fried quesadilla with a fat layer of green onion in the middle and sweet and sour sauce poured on top. Tasted like it wasn't fully cooked all the way.

Fried rice: flavorless and the rice was mushy. 

Lastly this was not cheap, small place, crowded. No bueno.
author: Linda J.

description:
Came here last Saturday ( 6/6/09 ) for my friend Alvin's Birthday dinner around 9ish. Waited in line for only 10-15mins for a group of 5. This isn't your typical chinese food, which is greattttt !!! cause sadly to say i'm not much of a fan of chinese food...don't hit me please...=x *hides* BTW ! 

ahaha the food here is delicious, lots of flavor, different spices, i'd say the only down side is this place is a bit on the oily side... other then that it was yuMmy~! Our bill came to $100 for table of 5 which is cheap. The owner of the resturant even came to our table and asked how we were doin that night and if we enjoyed the food which was really sweet of him. My favorite dish was their garlic noodles and omg ! their tea is sooo cool !! it starts of as a small ball then grows to a flower and springs up slowly as your tea cools down. =D neattttoo ahahha i was all excited about the tea that night ahah left like a little kid =x 

be sure to check out the photos i posted !! ^ ^
p.s. sorry i left out 2 dishes =x got hungry and forgot to take pix lol
author: Trina M.

description:
In short, this place fell far short of my expectations.

Initial analysis: they had people in line waiting out the door in the cold, the small cozy restaurant packed to the max, and "top"reviews and rewards plastered all over their windows and walls, usually all signs of a good eats.

The experience: we were seated fairly fast but we had to flag them down multiple times to come take our order. The foods were overly seasoned in sugar and salt, and came in small portions suitable for only one person - not a family style place.

I've never had so much trouble trying to pay for my meal. We spent over 10 minutes waiting and flagging waiters to bring us our bill. 

Ordering once entree (and they were small) per person, our bill came out to $16/person, which is steeper then than what you could be getting at any other chinese place with more authentic food.

Points for their set up and decor though; the place had a nice vibe despite the sub-par food and service.
author: Mike C.

description:
Simply put - best Chinese I have ever had!!!  
We were visiting from out of town and looking for authentic, good, Chinese food in china town.  This place did not disappoint!!  Everything we had was outstanding!  Onion cakes with peanut glaze are absolutely amazing!!!!  Iced fruit tea was really, really good!!  Lots of very fresh vegetables and many vegetarian/vegan options on menu.  I consider myself a foody but this place has set a new standard for me on Chinese food...  We will be back here for sure when we visit again soon!
author: Thomas R.

description: Food outstanding! Service iffy but what do you expect that's is there reputation.  I have been here in the past but ordered about 6 things from the menu.  They were all excellent except the five spice pork chops which were horrible. My favorite dish was a garlic chicken cooked with squash!!' The green beans side excellent and shrimp and mushroom dish is a must this is the way mushrooms should taste it was awesome!!!
author: Abbi B.

description:
I've never paid the bill at a restaurant and told the server to give me the change to the penny as there was no tip.

Ate here last night for the second time and I'm done. First time there the service sucked. Food was great.... But service.... You could lobotomize a monkey and you'd get better service than you do from the staff here. However, I had family in town and decided to give the house of Nanking a second chance.

Big mistake. If it had just been our table complaining I'd have not been so annoyed... But watching a glass of red wine literally be thrown at the woman seated near us (her expression was classic), the number of times the idiot waiters bungled orders, brought out entrees for one person while the rest of the table were served their first appetizer and the other numerous ways the staff showed how inept they were baffled
Me. I've never had to send food back to the kitchen either.

Again, if it had just been our table it would be one thing.... But when 3 other tables are audibly complaining and are greeted by a shrug of the shoulder and a "like I give a s**t" look from the staff ....

AVOID!!!
author: Phill R.

description:
Best Chinese food ever! Every time I come back to the city I ALWAYS go to Nanking! I love their fried pot stickers, sesame chicken, sizzling soup (the list can go on..) but my favorite is their fish in vinegar sauce NOT garlic sauce, no longer on the menu, but if you ask for it they will make it :)
Never had a bad meal here!
author: Barbra S.

description:
The Sesame Chicken is really great!

Also the pork eggrolls are really tasty.

When it gets busy and crowded, they literally fill every seat in the house. This means that complete strangers will sometimes have to share tables. But I really like this (^_^)
author: Anthony N.

description:
If you're even thinking of trying this place because "you heard this restaurant was good," don't even bother.

This place is a sham.  The House of Nanking is not authentic, nor is their food tasty. 

We got a few dishes and the green beans was the only good dish.  I got the black sesame noodles with pea sprouts.  The dish seemed like something that would be produced on of a Food Network Challenge: put items that don't go together, throw them in a wok, and hope to God some idiot thinks it tastes good.  Well, by the looks of the 1000+ reviews, it looks like they were able to fool somebody and keep 'em coming in the door.  If you want Chinese food, go elsewhere.
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
I read a lot of reviews where people bash this place for not being authentic, food is too starchy, blah blah blah and who cares? The food is delicious and thats all that matters. My sister lives in San Francisco and every time I go out I make it a point to eat here. You usually have to wait outside for 10 minutes or so because it's always so packed but they do a good job of moving people in and out. 

Once you sit down they will take your order, but if you order things that don't pair up then they will kind of take over and order for you. This might turn some people off but everytime the server has ordered for me I have loved everything I have gotten. The fried onion cakes and rice chowder are incredible. Just remember to bring cash though because they don't take cards.

I would urge anyone to at least give this place a shot. It may not be the most authentic food in the world but its good and that is all that matters.
author: Brian M.

description: The best Chinese in San Francisco, hands down.
author: Mike P.

description:
i don't see what all the fuss is all about. It was pretty good, but there was WAY too much sauce on the food. 
Servers were pretty rude. We did see one guy chatting it up with the customers but he looked like he was the owner. 
Overall just "Eh".
author: Katie B.

description:
If you are looking for authentic Chinese food, this is not the place to go.

Tried Wonton Soup and Onion Cake. The Wonton soup had cream in it and the Onion Cake wan't in a form that I could recognize.
author: Bei L.

description:
If you don't like to sit next to strangers, don't eat here. My husband and I were seated at a table and then surprised to find ourselves sitting next to three other guests only moments later. This didn't bother us but something to be aware of before going in if that would make you uncomfortable. 

If you don't like everyone at your tables food coming out at different times, don't eat here. My meal (sesame chicken with sweet potatoes - yummy my mouth is still watering) came out first, good thing my husband and I had the intention of sharing each others meals we ordered as his meal didn't come out until my was already gone. In fact we even received our bill before his meal even came out.  Again, this didn't bother us so much but I know lots of people who would hate this.

We didn't wait for a table, there was no line but we came late Thursday afternoon. 

If you want ice in your drink, don't eat here. My husband ordered a diet soda and got a pop can with a straw. I ordered a water and got a warm glass with cold water in it, no ice.  

If you like that 'super clean' type feeling at a restaurant, don't eat here. I never saw dirt, felt dirt, etc... just didn't feel super clean when I left.

If you like really awesome delicious real Chinese food, EAT HERE. It was delicious :) We would definately eat here again, the lack of stars really for the lack of 'clean' feeling I got when I was there and the drink thing. Everything else didn't bother me at all just more wanted to write a review as a warning for others who may be bothered by it.
author: Jenny D.

description:
I was very impressed with the food! I absolutely loved the green beans which drew me there a second day for lunch since I was in the city for two days for training! I also tried the Nanking chicken and the chow mein which were also good. Would go back again however, I would recommend an improvement in service. 

I felt pressured to use my card, although I did not want to. The first day, I did use my card but had cash on hand to leave a tip. The server demanded that I place the tip on my card...okay??? Maybe they wanted the bill and tip in the same form of payment. The next day I knew I would order more food to go since my kids asked for me to bring them some because it's hard to find good chinese food where we live. 

The next day, I went again and had the same server. When it was time to pay, I had enough cash to pay for the food plus a tip. She demanded I pay by credit card again! Now, this is getting ridiculous. Don't most businesses prefer you to pay with cash anyway? I insisted to pay with cash and then she adamantly told me "No, pay with card". For the sake of drama, I paid with my card. As I'm reading all the other reviews many have experienced the same thing...I wonder if it is the same server? Oh, after I gave her my card, I heard her demand another customer to pay with cash. What is going on here?!?
author: Patricia T.

description:
I walked up to the House of Nanking with a few of my coworkers during lunch hour. We simply sat down, and asked the waitress to bring enough food to satisfy eight people with a request to make a few of the dishes vegetarian: Nanking came through with a vengeance. All of the dishes that piled up on our table were swiftly consumed by our voracious appetite for authentic Chinese cuisine.

I can honestly not even tell you what we ate on the menu, but every dish was deliciously unique.
author: Mark O.

description: Delicious dumplings.  When it comes to vegetarian dumplings, I've found nothing better.
author: Anand A.

description: Nangkin chicken and chow mein taste great! Their service was far from fabulous but their food was decent. Hot and sour soup was also very unique we really liked it.
author: Asuka S.

description:
BAD!!! BAD!!! BAD!!! WHY has the health department not closed this restaurant? It is a public health hazard. I WILL NEVER EAT AT ANY RESTAURANT IN S.F CHINA TOWN AGAIN!!! I saw a server (KATHY?) serving Brown liquid, looked like diarrhea, from a bucket on the floor into a bowl and serving it to customers, Unfortunately, this was as I was leaving. When  I reached the sidewalk, I vomited and needed to be hospitalized. I was diagnosed with food poisoning as a result of SALMONELLA poisoning. 

I ate the sesame chicken  steamed rice and spring rolls. Who would have thought that something so simple could be so dangerous. In the interest of public safety, i would advise anyone not to eat here. The food quality and lack of cleanliness pose a threat to customer safety. PLEASE TAKE CARE NOT TO EAT AT THIS RESTAURANT!!!
author: K W.

description: I wish I could give this place more than two stars because the food was great but the service was TERRIBLE. When my friends and I walked into the restaurant we were not greeted or even noticed by the staff, so we continued to seat ourselves and when the waitress noticed us she dropped menus on the table without even saying a word, rude much? As a table we order the steamed pork dumplings and the honey chicken and they were both very delicious. When we were paying, we were filling out the tip portion on the receipt. My order was only $8 but I still tipped the 15% because that is the respectable thing to do. While filling out the receipt, the manager or owner came over and looked at our receipts and told us we needed to tip more. ARE YOU KIDDING ME? "It is an American tradition" he said and we told a tip is not mandatory and is based on service and he argued with us for about 5 minutes. After arguing with this man, we got up and left. I have never been treated so disrespectfully in a restaurant and I will not go back.
author: Megan C.

description: I'm not a big fan of Chinese food but this place was really good. Our group got several dishes and we shared family style. We had the Sizzling Rice soup and it was my favorite part of the meal. Rice, chicken, corn and other veges in a chicken type broth with a kick. Awesome! We also got the house noodles which weren't my favorite. There was a salad with vinegar on top which over powered any other flavor. We got the house fried rice and it was ok. The fried eggplant was really good. And finally the sesame chicken was awesome! There was a lot of sauce on it but super good. Overall great meal for good price.
author: Monica P.

description: Greasy - yummy food. Just let your waiter/waitress bring you whatever they like. It's all good here. Such a level of competition for food in Chinatown SF... they have to be great to survive. The lines can be long... the wait is worthwhile. If you want dim sum... go up the street on Jackson to Great Eastern ... peace.
author: Tommy Nicholas V.

description:
Wonderful!! This great restaurant was referred to me by a friend and while my husband and I were leaving the hotel to walk over I overheard a few people talking about The House of Nanking!! 

Needless to say we were excited to try out this well talked about restaurant. 

Truly a local gem! Traditional Chinese style eating best when you have larger groups. 

We started with the rice porridge with chicken, with dish was absolute heaven. The chicken had a bit of spice to it which added a flavor that burst in your mouth! I also loved the house specialty sesame chicken! 

Will definitely make another trip to this fabulous small mom & pop place!!
author: Jennifer C.

description: Don't truth the waitress. Don't order the food without the price. Honey beef something is really expensive and cold o_O
author: Orange S.

description: We visited House of Nanking during our San Francisco trip in 2011, so I apologize for the delayed review.  It was so amazing that we went back a second time during our trip and we dream about going back to San Francisco just so that we can go to House of Nanking!  We have recommended it to a few friends that have also taken trips to San Francisco and they have all given it rave reviews as well!  There was a bit of a wait for a table, but it was totally worth it.  We were sat at a larger table along with some other patrons.  We had our server order for us - we were brought a plate of amazing, blow your mind calamari.  It was so moist and tender, with a hint of lemon.  There was also an entree that I think was sesame chicken with some sweet potatoes.  Out of this world.
author: Ray R.

description: Came here once and tried two different dishes: some fried rice and a chicken entree. Both dishes were bad and I didn't want to eat anymore of either one. I was hoping for this place to be good, but I left very disappointed.
author: John D.

description: The food used to be Good when Kathy's husband ran the place but since then it simply sucks. Kathy, I understand your soul has been overtaken by greed but really, count your blessings, just because you have the customer base now, doesn't mean it will stay that way forever--just saying.
author: Art Y.

description: Best Chinese food I've ever had!! Love this Restaurant! Can't wait to go back again! When the server asked us what we wanted, My friend replied "whatever you want to serve us." I was so amazed of how great the food was. Absolutely delicious!  The owner came up to us to hear what we had to say about the food. He was very nice.
author: Itzybitzy S.

description: This is one of my favorite chinese restaurants. The inside is very cozy and cute. Lots of people so not great if you want privacy with a date. The staff is crazy bc they don't listen to you but you still end up getting what you need & they're fast-- Also fast to get you in and out of there. I didn't mind at all. The food was amazing. Garlic noodles and sesame chicken were soooo good!!  And the food comes out very hot & steaming which I like. No need for reservations.
author: San C.

description: A beautiful location for those who are too lazy to walk five minutes to Chinatown. No shortage of vegetarian options, which seems rare for "Americanized" Chinese food.
author: Marcus B.

description: Came here on my first trip to San Francisco. Was with a group helmed by a regular who told the waiter to just bring a bunch of the chef's recommendations and to "keep 'em coming" - and indeed, every dish was more fabulous than the last. To me, at the time, and maybe still now, this was the best Chinese food  that could possibly exist outside of China. I was young and naive and had untarnished taste but the memory I have of this perfect food celebration is among my most pleasant. I almost don't ever want to go back for fear that it wouldn't be as good as I remember. But I do recommend that YOU go.
author: Kelly D M.

description:
Great for groups of friends :) 

I came here for an early dinner in the city after doing a group project. One of my group members swore this was the best Chinese food he'd ever had, so of course, I had to try!

As someone who has eaten tons of 'real' Chinese food in China, I can definitely say that this place has pretty authentic food. I really liked the fish soup that the boss gave us (even though it was really pricey...) and also enjoyed the chicken. I think that this place is on the pricey side if you want to eat until you are full (our groupmates paid $15 each for a total of $60 for dinner) but it is worth the experience and quality of the food.
author: Jenny M.

description: Waaay overrated!! Had the Egg Rolls, hot& sour soup, fried eggplant, Sesame chicken, Salt'n Pepper Shrimp w/ mushrooms& the House Noodles. The noodles were the only good dish. The rest...well...they all tasted the same...it felt like they literally used the same sauce from appetizers to the main dish...the shrimp wasn't that bad...but still...I really cannot understand all these ppl waiting in line for 30min and saying that this is the best food ever...really? And let's not talk about the service...they r very rude to you...none of the servers ever smile or talk polite to u! Try asking for a refill on your water...or ice...& you'll see what I mean. It made me feel like someone just stole my money...didn't like the food...& service was poor.
author: Iulia A.

description:
I was a bit worried about coming to House of Nanking after reading some of the reviews mentioning long wait times and dirty dish wear. However, one of the good things of going to Nanking on the holidays is that we didn't have to wait in line nor did we have dirty dish wear. Our evening started out great, having the manager bring us a diverse selection of dishes from the menu so that we could get a taste of what this restaurant has to offer. I gotta admit the food was good but in a very predictable sort of way. Not only that, but it always saddens me to see the wait staff eating food from another restaurant that serves the same type of cuisine. HINT: If you are a waiter at any restaurant doing this PLEASE hide yourself in the kitchen. 

So, is it good? Yes. Is it a must-go-to? Not exactly.
author: Jorge G.

description: Food was ehhhh and the service/atmosphere has a lot to be desired. Plan to be ignored, rushed and unable to have a conversation at your table unless you're a party of four or more. You're sat at a table with other diners so it's a little awkward to have any type of conversation. All in all, I was disappointed.
author: Nicole C.

description: Hands down the best kept secret in SF. Always come with a big group ready to eat and ask for the managers special, the owner will bring you exactly what you've been searching for in Chinese cuisine!
author: Nikki F.

description: Horrible service! Do not go there. When we asked him what there was to drink he rolled his eyes and stated that it was on the menu. When we told him that he hadn't given us any menus, he grabbed one from another table and tossed it on ours and proceeded to walk away. Horrible service, he had no manners. Later on he ignored us when we told him that we were ready to order. Rather than making a scene we simply walked out and went to another restaurant.
author: Sarai F.

description:
All I can say is Whatever.....

After years of seeing this place with people lined up outside- I HAD to try it!  Well, I did today, and all I can say is I have had WAY better Chinese.  The menu was limited, and the owner suggested a plate that was SUB PAR and five dollars more than everything else we ordered.   

Try something else- the city has sooo much to offer in the way of tasty Chinese ;)
author: Melissa P.

description: This is the second time coming to this place and both times I loved it... The second time our waiter just took charge and picked out our meal and we are everything. The food was fantastic the place is pretty cool... The beer selection is great.
author: J T.

description:
I ate here frequently when we were both young, in the early 1990s, and the restaurant invariably had a line out the door and halfway up the block. The chef would take our orders personally, and object if we ordered too many chicken dishes. At one point he'd suggested the "lettuce wrap" dish, which wasn't on the menu, and we subsequently ordered it every time and felt like insiders for doing so. We didn't mind the brusque service; the place only had about 8 tables and there were 200 people waiting to get in...

Times have changed. The restaurant more than doubled in size, apparently back in 1996 or something. I ate there yesterday for the first time in about 18 years. Everyone in my group loved it. It was lunchtime, with a moderate crowd and no wait. The service was friendly and quick. The potstickers were great (my picky son ate two orders); the "Green Lettuce Wrap" (it's on the menu now) was very tasty, if a bit oily, and other folks really enjoyed various fried rice and mushroom dishes.

This place was a destination 20 years ago, and won more than its fair share of "best of" awards. I haven't  been there enough to say whether the food has kept up with its original high standards, but I will say I'd go back there without hesitation.
author: sayo n.

description: Been to many Chinese Restaurants around the country, as well as in S.F.  House of Nanking came as a recommendation to us by the doorman at the St. Regis.  It did not disappoint!  There were 6 guys, we were sat immediately, the waitress asked if we'd ever been there before.  Since the answers were no, she ripped the menu from our hands and said, "I'll take care of it..."  She definietely did!  I can't remember all that was brought to the table, but everything was beyond delicious.  That is my type of dining, just feed me your best, and make it good.  I can't wait to return to this place.  The atmosphere, being packed in, no b.s. atmosphere, and food quality made it a memorable experience.
author: Mark A.

description:
Hole in the wall & it looks dirty as hell (atleast before they remodeled?) And, the servers (especially the women) are rude like they get paid to be rude.

BUT.. THE FOOD IS AMAZING!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

EVERYTHING, I mean EVERYTHING is amazing here! It's so amazing that I'm still giving it a 5 despite the look of the establishment and the rude women. I'm willing to eat their shellfish entrees and get an allergic reaction it's that amazing.

I would drive allllll the way here and deal with the parking and the people just to order to-go (and dont forget boba from Wonderful) and picnic at Golden Gate Park. 

But then again, it's just my opinion..
author: Christine M.

description:
Chinese food is very hit or miss with me. The House of Nanking gets 5 stars in my book, simply because it is some of the best Chinese food I've ever had. I have seen many reviews calling this place a tourist trap and that the food is Americanized, but I am completely fine with that because the food is delicious. 

I tried the sesame chicken and several other dishes, including some kind of lettuce wrap. As far as the service goes I agree that it can be mediocre but the tasty food makes up for it. If you are in the neighborhood I would make sure you stop by and give it a try.
author: Michael C.

description:
I've been coming here for +15 year, putting up with the staff which is incomompetent at best and rude and petulant at worst, all because I loved the food. After my last visit, I can say I will never eat here again and intend to direct anyone who might want to eat there to save themselves the trouble, and just punch themselves in the stomach instead.

I had their sesame chicken last Friday night and became violently ill about 5 hours after I ate there. When asked about whether anyone else had complained, they were beyond indifferent, and the woman who was asked about it just shrugged and walked away in the middle of the conversation. 

I hope they enjoy the complaint to the Health Department.
author: Raum P.

description: This place is delicious. Seems like its always crowded. Will certainly visit again. Awesome food.
author: Paola W.

description: Love the food in the great little restaurant close to  Chinatown. Love cation can get crowded and tables are tight. However, it is all worth the wait.
author: Clark H.

description: We were less then impressed with the spring rolls that we ordered. Everything else was pretty tasty; Sesame Chicken, house noodles and the green beans. The reason for the low rating was the awkward service we received. It was not that packed for lunch on a Sunday and they rushed us the whole time. I wont be going back.
author: Kelso H.

description:
Incredibly flavorful food and a unique atmosphere make this place a must-try.

I'm not a huge fan of Chinese food but if it all tasted like this, I would be. Whereas most Chinese I find to be bland, salty and filled with overpowering single flavors, House of Nanking offers dishes that are spiced and prepared with a variety of different textures and tastes.

The fish dish I ordered was excellent.
author: Matt M.

description:
I came about the House of Nanking by a suggestion from a friend. He told me, no matter what you want to eat (either beef, chicken, pork, or vegetarian) they will impress you. He told me not to order anything and let the waite staff order for you, you will be impressed. 

I came here on a Sunday at 4:30pm.  I read previous reviews and was informed the service was hit and miss while the food was good. I also read that there was a long wait. I was expecting long lines but there were none. I was seated immediately as I entered. 

I went to the restaurant with two other friends which were vegetarian. I was hoping the restaurant would cater to their needs of vegetarianism.  I decided to join their quest of vegetarianism. 

For starters we ordered the fruit tea and blossom teas due to the chilly weather outside. Our waitress seemed in a bad mood to start but 
when we told her we wanted her to order for us, she had a huge smile. We told her we wanted vegetarian food and no fish. She asked if we were hungry or starving. We told her we were starving. One of my friends wanted to order the onion cake and the waitress obliged.

Within minutes we were served our food. The onion cake came out first and it looked similar to a crepe with red and green onions inside with soy sauce drizzled on the top. It was very good and not too oniony. 

The second dish we received was the fried tofu in black bean sauce.  The fried tofu was crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. The sauce was not over powering and we loved it. The second dish we received was the egg plant and greens. This was the house vegetarian special. It was flavorful and impressive. The last dish we received was sauteed thinly sliced greens and red onions. This was also very good and not salty at all. 

I was very impressed by the food and service. The waitress explained every item that was served to us. The only reason I did not give the restaurant five stars was due to the fact the waitress was rude to other customers but not us. If the waitress' friendliness to us was spread throughout the restaurant I would have given The House of Nanking five stars.
author: Pete N.

description:
I'm really sad if this is the best chinese food in SF... it might be and perhaps that's why there are so many good reviews- its all relative to what else is around. 

I had the sesame chicken and the bf had crispy beef- which was not at all crispy, in fact it was quiet soggy and a lil chewy, with no flavor or sauce. 

The sesame chicken wasn't great quality (you know, the kind of chicken where the few chunks of actual meat are held together with fatty ligaments that no matter how much you chew just never dissolve so you have to spit them out- yuk!)... the sauce was just ok. 
The sweet potatos were the best part, but I've had better. 

Don't get me started on the crappy, rude service from our waiter... 

Also, They get pissed if you want to pay by card (like any asian place) and at first will refuse it, but once you tell them you have nothing else they reluctantly accept.- So if you must go, pay by card even if you have cash. 

Bottom line- if you've ever had good chinese food (like the kind in NY) then you won't like this place.
author: Layla L.

description:
Who new Chinese food can be THIS good? This is by far one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I've always heard about their long lines that wrap out and around the restaurant, but luckily I didn't have to endure any of that. We were promptly seated the moment we got in.

Started off with the "Melt in Your Mouth Fried Calamari," which literally melts in your mouth. The batter is not too thick nor crispy, and the vinegar sauce makes it all the better. We also ordered onion pancakes, pea sprouts, and sesame chicken. My favorite dish was the pea sprouts, and not because I'm all about greens. It's really, really worth the try. There's something about it that you will not find in any other Chinese restaurant...guaranteed. The sesame chicken is also very addicting! I couldn't stop eating it.

This place is CASH ONLY. It's a bit of a tight squeeze in the restaurant, and all the tables are pretty close to one another. House of Naanking gets really packed and busy, so it made it very difficult to have a conversation without listening to parties left and right talking, too. Overall, one of my favorite restaurants to date.
author: Linda T.

description:
Finally succumbed to all the hype, waited in line (which moved very quickly by the way, on a Friday night) and was promptly seated about 10 minutes later at one of the now ubiquitous communal tables.  Ordered a bottle of very, very reasonably priced wine (and not too shabby either I must say), grabbed some delicious pot stickers, and then shared the calamari and the sesame chicken.  The calamari, while "famous," wasn't quite an entree portion despite where it was on the menu, which would be my only complaint.  It was basically you standard calamari appetizer, with no rice, veg, or anything else.  

Otherwise, the pot stickers and sesame chicken were both off the charts good, fresh, and totally worth a lot of the hype.  This isn't your standard run of the mill Chinese place with the 20 page menu that seemingly gets circulated around the world.  This is a unique, original menu full of lots of goodies.  I need to come back to sample more of the menu.
author: Sean H.

description:
I was a little worried when reading about the reviews, but I had a great time here. My boss was trying to get all us accountants and our significant others together for a meals and we ended up coming into the City for it. He said it's a great place and not to worry about anything really. We arrived around 6:30pm on a Monday and it was quite empty, but 7, the place was packed. 
 
Damn the food was good. Since there was 5 of us and we couldn't decide, we asked for suggestions. The person taking our orders (the owner of the place) said that he would take care of it. Asked if we had food allergies or anything we wouldn't eat due to religious reasons. We didn't have any of those so he just did his thing. 

We ended up getting 6 different dishes that the chef-owner chose for us.
The first one that came out was the soup. It was a fish noodle wonton soup. I'm not exactly sure what it was called, but it was so flavorful and delicious. The second dish was the onion cake type thing. It was like fried tortillas filled with scallions, onions and some other stuff. We also got the calamari. It was delicious. The was so tender and the sauce was just so complementary. The fourth dish was one with rice that kind of tasted a savory rice krispy and mushrooms. If you know me, I hate mushrooms, but this was decent. Fifth was the sesame chicken. It was pretty good. Not the best I've ever had, but the sweet potato slices were a nice surprise. They were nice and sweet and great with the sauce. The final dish was a pork chop I think. There was some delicious and fresh cucumbers as well. 

It was a delicious dinner. For the 5 of us, around $120 - yes I did look at it. The service was what I expected from a Chinese restaurant. Perhaps, because I was with my boss who knows the owner, I had a good time. Regardless, it was some good Chinese food...with Chinese service.
author: Nina Y.

description: Very friendly little hole in the wall. Fantastic pot stickers, best chow mein since I left New York and sesame chicken with yams was fantastic.
author: Frank L.

description: Best Chinese food I have ever eaten. The flavors are wonderful, and not like regular Chinese food at a restaurant. There's always a line to get in. The atmosphere isn't great. Usually you sit at a big table with other people you don't know. The service is OK at best. But the food is totally worth it, and if you don't mind casual eating, this is the best
author: Seann O.

description:
Sesame chicken, onion peanut cake, pepper and spices shrimps. $40. 
Very tasty, fat, a little expensive
author: Johann R.

description: Besides going to eat in China, this is the closest thing to it in California.  I came here not knowing what to expect, and the waiter asked us if it was our first time.  He asked us if we wanted him to pick our menu.  We told him that we like seafood, beef and chicken.  Man, everything he gave us was soooo good!  My favorite was the calamari!  Everything is really good here, and cannot go wrong!
author: Bernadette M.

description: Wow the sesame chicken was sooo yummy, the batter was light and crispy, the sauce wasn't too heavy...scrumptious! Worth the wait, thought we were going to have leftovers-NOT! Clean plate club :) pros: food not greasy, fast service cons: waiting in line out the door! And very tight fit inside seating area.
author: Sally and J.

description: Excellent food!  Many vegetarian choices.  Always a line waiting out the door.  Definitely will go again!
author: Chris J.

description:
Do not expect to linger here. No leisurely meals served!!! You're in, you're fed, and you're out. It's cramped, loud and busy.  It can be a bit chaotic and unnerving. But...

The food is soooo GOOD! Favorites are the Sesame Chicken and Calamari. Everything is inventive and traditional at the same time.

If you can deal with the chaos, give it a try. Not for the faint of heart. ;)
author: J. C.

description:
Right at the bottom of Chinatown, right at the very bottom, on Kearney is where you'll find the some of the best, most delicious Chinese food you'll ever stuff in your pie-hole. 

Sure they're not the cleanest, or the friendliest, or the easiest (what with their wait-list and all), BUT OH MY HOLY TASTE RECEPTORS is it freaking worth it. 

The sesame chicken is so saucy and sweet. The crisp on the chicken is a great vehicle for the sauce, and also keeps an interesting texture. The chicken, underneath the sauce and breading, tasted as if it had never seen a freezer, it is plump and juicy. So often does the actual meat get lost in the added flavors, but no, this time there it was punching me in the tongue and raising it's hand as if to say "HELLO, YES I'M IN HERE AND YOU ARE ENJOYING THE SHIT OUT OF ME!!" 
Also the sweet potatoes in the dish are a delightful addition. 

The boa bing beef wraps are interesting and a completely different flavor, GREAT JUXTAPOSITION!!!  Hello lemongrass, and ginger, and curry, and cumin. The beef was I think grilled? I don't know. It was accompanied by cabbage and onions and other veggies and tortillas.... 
When the server brought them he assembled the first two, I think to make sure we incorporated all elements. 

Oh I almost forgot the onion cake! I was expecting something like a Chinese Latka? Hahaha, I guess to a degree it was a somewhat accurate. The cake part was  very very very thin deep fried dough. It was crispy. The inside was, surprise surprise, full of green onions. It was yum. The sauce was good too. 

The interior is a bunch of long tables, so you're sitting with people you don't really know. If you're an open person its fun! 
While tile, red beams. 
Again not the cleanest, but isn't that what amazing hole-in-the-walls are about???
author: nicole r.

description:
Sigh. Real Chinese food at last. We live in Las Vegas and sadly it is the wasteland for anything resembling Chinese food. Having lived in Chicago and New York I was used to excellent Chinese food on every corner. We had the egg rolls, sesame chicken, and a ad hoc crab dish my GF ordered. All very excellent. We were tempted to lick the sauce off the plate from the egg rolls and the chicken. The crab dish was tasty and had lots of garlic. 

Service was fast, efficient, and they were turning over tables without pushing you out the door. Had to wait a little but it was well worth the wait.

We will be back!
author: John K.

description: Pretty decent food for a place on the tourist stop. Sesame chicken is fried perfectly crisp and sauce balanced and tangy. String beans are well cooked. Pot stickers aren't really 'pot stickers', these are more the Chili's or Applebee's style. They are completely deep fried and rather tasteless. Must be the influence of the tourists since these things can't possibly stick to any pots. Not much peanut taste in the 'peanut' sauce. Next table over got the steamed pork dumplings and they looked like the better bet. Service could be a lot better. Once they serve your dishes, they never come back to your table. No water refills ever. Next time they see you is for your money. Typical Chinatown eatery decor... boxes of Tsingtao and cooking ingredients stored openly in dining area.
author: John H.

description: Wow, i love this place! I have been here about 4 times. Always the food is very good. The Sweet potatoes are amazing and i have never had anything like it anywhere.  It is right downtown, in between China town and North Beach. A tiny little restaurant that at most times has a line outside waiting to get in. Yes, you will wait in the cold and wind to eat in this place it is that good. They  have big giant wood tables which you may have to share with many others. But, hey that is part of the fun! The menu is quite extensive and the blooming flower tea is not only Delicious, but also so Beautiful!  It is such a unique experience you have to try it.  You must have a sense of adventure and do not be stuck up about your dining experience.  It is great and you will love it. But, try the Blooming flower Tea!!  x x x
author: Teresa S.

description:
I can't really explain it, I just wasn't a fan. Lots of hype about this place, huuuge line out the door when were leaving.

Ambiance: has a hole in the wall feel to it, but all the tables are (almost uncomfortably) close to each other. The 4 of us sat incredibly close to a couple who wasn't talking much at all. I bet they heard every bit of our convo...not the business. We got there on the 4th of July at around 5:30pm so there wasn't a wait at all, but as we were leaving there was a line out the door. Crowd was more touristy, but could be attributed to the holiday.

Service was fast, which was a plus. The food came out like within 10 minutes. 

Food: We ordered the famous sesame chicken, green beans, and a veggie chow fun. To be honest I was sort of disappointed. The food was really greasy, came in small portions, and honestly didn't wow me. Not sure if Ill be coming back, considering all the other options around town.... (if I do perhaps I'll be adventurous and try other dishes).
author: Adele Z.

description:
What happened?

I know to expect horrible service, but the food at least made up for it.  I had such a horrible experience last time that I gave exact change for a $72.11 bill on my last visit.  I would have given them a negative tip if I could have.

I think the problem is that the owner is no longer there to supervise and the staff doesn't give a F.

Service sucks.  We all know that.  They throw food at you, never listen to your requests,  and act as if they are doing you a favor for stopping to listen to your request if you wave at the frantically.  Given that tips are about service, I really do not feel bad at the $0.00 tip.  But I used to tip because the food was good.

Nothing was good this time.

The rice had so much water in it that it came out as a giant blob.  The grains were not distinct from each other and it was more of a paste.  The peanut sauce pot stickers used to be fantastic but now they taste like they are from trader joes and covered in syrup (what happened to the peanut sauce?).  The nan king chicken was sitting on sauce, rather than being covered by it.  They are getting so lazy.  And it used to come with some green things that tasted great, but no more.  Burnt tasting on top of it all.  I could go on about the rest of the problems, but suffice it to say that it's no longer what it was, and it's a shame.  I wish the owner would come pack and whip them back into shape.

Oh, and they used to take credit cards, but no more.  I wish they had mentioned that to us at the start as we had to scrounge to find enough cash.  It's embarrassing when your trying to treat someone and then you have to ask them for money.  

The only thing I enjoyed was the look on the hostess' face when she counted my $72.11 in cash for a $72.11 bill - hopefully they got the hint.
author: reza n.

description:
Best Chinese food in the city.  If your looking for sweet and sour chicken head elsewhere.    

Pea shoot salad and stir fry sweet potatoes are unbelievable. 

Service makes you feel rushed, and if you look like a noob the will probably snatch up the menus, ask about allergies and order for you.

Go with the flow you wont be disappointing.


Looking for more of an ambiance? Head to Fang their sister restaurant.  Service is more manageable with no communal tables.
author: Bruce P.

description:
I've had Chinese in just about every city I've been in.  I love it.  This place is the real deal.  Here's the all-star line-up: 

Shrimp packets, Fried pork dumplings, Hot & Sour soup

House noodles, Scallops, Sesame Chicken, Eggplant w/ Chili and Garlic

Every one of those is incredible.
author: Charles W.

description: horrible service. Average food dont know why people stand in lines here..
author: Abhi S.

description: Went here after the wait at Hunan Homes was too long. Got the sesame chicken. Crispy chicken with the sweet soft texture of the sweet potatoes was fantastic. The fried rice was good as well. Crunchy cabbage and big chunks of egg made it very flavorful. I guess the thing to do is go in and ask them to cook you whatever is fresh that day. The table next to us had pea shoots, shrooms and baked fish. Looked great. The hot green tea has goji seeds in it and was slightly sweet.
author: Kelly B.

description: My boyfriend has talked up this restaurant to me ever since we decided to go to San Francisco for the weekend.  I went in hoping to prove him wrong, just to give him a hard time.  Fortunately for him (and me too!), it was absolutely delicious. Try the apple and shrimp dish.  Simply glorious... We craved the food so much that we decided to go back for lunch the next day.  We ordered completely different dishes than the first day and were just as happy.  I don't know what people have to complain about.  It is consistently a satisfying meal.
author: Kathy R.

description:
Been there with my French friend.
Really nice restaurant, even better than most restaurants in China.
We met two nice girls there. After dinner, my friend said to me it's a pity that we did not change contact. :-)
author: Yu S.

description: Excellent food, just like i remember from 15 years ago, but now a menu! Enjoyed salt and pepper mushrooms thoroughly.
author: Bryan G.

description: Get the house special noodle.  The other food is also delicious, but this is a must.  The only downsides to the place I found is that the people who work there are not very friendly.  Gets got a bit of a get in and get out attitude.  Try to examine the menu before you sit down.  We got 4 dishes for 3 people and that was a bit too much when you factor in the rice, but very tasty none the less.
author: Matthew L.

description:
Rude, and expensive for mediocre food. This is the first place in my life where I paid without leaving a tip. That bad.

We only went in b/c the vegetarian place down the hill was closed. I'm not vegetarian but this place is really really good, clean, and friendly. Plus, you know it's good when you're the only white person in the room.

I wouldn't say all the service was bad (another waitress went out of her way to explain to me where the ATM was) -- just that one particular head waitress, I think you all know who I'm talking about. 

We found a hair in our dumpling sauce, our "tortillas" were given to us without being warmed up. We ordered steamed pork dumplings and bing bao wraps. Maybe we should have ordered the house special -- the sesame chicken and fried calamari -- but I'm not going to come back to find out. 

How the hell does this place stay in business? I suppose it caters to people they never have to serve twice! -- tourists.
author: Rachel C.

description: Really great. Slightly rushed service as widely discussed. Great food and atmosphere. The scallops in garlic and ginger are just superb.
author: Al B.

description: The food is good but the service leaves a great deal to be desired.  I hate the lady who hoovers around until you pay your check. I wonder how many dine and dashers they've had to warrant that?
author: Ayele A.

description: Highly recommended! Very very tasty!!the line seems long,however,it doesn't take long to get in.The serving is really fast. The owner/chef is so nice and professional~!make sure you ask for the chef's choice~
author: Lan G.

description:
Favorite Chinese Restaurant since I started attending Berkeley in 2004. 

Being a freshmen in college I was introduced to House of Nanking and was blown away. This restaurant has been my favorite Chinese place to eat at. It's affordable and anything with the Nanking sauce is delish.

In most of my visits, the chef came up to my table and ordered for us. Its such a homey feeling to have the chef come up to you and just order. Its a great find in San Francisco. You can look at the walls and see all the famous people including Keanu Reeves and people from the Food Network come check the place out. 

Loved:
Sweet potatoes, Nanking Sesame Chicken. 

Decent: 
White fish with spinach leaves, Nanking Beef, Calamari, Pea sprouts

What people may not like:
Always a line outside
Sharing a table with strangers since it is always packed
author: Erin M.

description: If you are not familiar with how some Asian cultures are, then you will probably think the service is really bad and extremely rude... lol seriously. But honestly, this is THEE BEST Chinese food I have ever had. I have to come here and get my fix every time I visit up north.
author: Chloe F.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!!! 

Now be forewarned...the waiting staff here is rude. If you don't order fast enough, they might ask to order for you. Plates might get thrown at you. You might be rushed to the only available seating in some corner of the place and have to share a table with a family from another country...awkward? Yes. Worth it? You better believe it!

If this is your first time going...just let them order for you. Put your pride aside, tell them what meats you like and let it just happen. Be sure to order a hot tea and let it sit too....a garden grows in your mug...no really! I promise. 

Order the scallop tower, waive to Rachel Ray's picture and make a friend with the dude from Nigeria eating next to you...you 2 are going to need to negotiate elbow room!
author: Gabriel C.

description: I had high expectations for this place because everyone has raved about it.  Totally disappointed.  I can handle the mediocre service and lack of cleanliness however I thought the food would make up for it.  It didn't.  As I write this review I still feel nauseous from my meal.  The sesame chicken, labeled as the "house special" was cold, extremely overcooked and bland.  It tasted like it had been fried and then fried again, not in a good way.  The shrimp pockets were okay.  One shrimp per pocket and the wonton tasted stale.  The only decent dish was the house noodles.  They appeared to be fresh and had a good garlic taste.  Unfortunately 1/3 dishes will not cut it and I won't be coming back.  Still feeling very sick...
author: Allie Y.

description: My friends and I had a summer trip to Californian and made a stop in San Francisco. I had heard nothing but amazing things about this place from friends and family so I knew we had to give it a shot. I was not disappointed! We were a rather large group, about 8 people, we were seated fast and with friendly service. None of us could make up our mind's about what we wanted to eat so the server asked us what we like and picked up our menus and brought an assortment of different food, each dish better then next. I will have to make the trek back when I return to San Francisco.
author: Matt Z.

description: Definitely a place to try if you are in Chinatown.  They are known for their Sesame Chicken and it really is amazing.  The egg rolls are really good as well.  Usually very crowded place and don't expect much in the way of service but the food is worth it.
author: Rob S.

description: It makes me sad to have to leave such a low rating. I love the food here, the Mu Shu tofu is outstanding, the sauce for the sesame chicken is delicious, and the chow mein is so unique. Unfortunately, my positivity ends there. I make effort to visit the restaurant everytime I'm in the city- a couple times a month. Yesterday around 1pm the door was locked, and the hours of operation sign was removed, yet there were people dining inside. I phoned the restaurant and no one would answer. All staff also ignored me outside the door and wouldn't open it to speak to me. I returned today and again, the door was locked, hours of operation sign removed, and no one answered the phone, yet people were dining inside. Finally a woman delivering produce showed up and one of the workers opened the door for her. I basically had to stick my head in the door to get the workers attention. When asking what the deal was she responded, "we open later- like 5" and went to shut the door as I tried to ask if they would be opening late the following day also. She closed the curtain in my face and left. If they are closed for a private event, multiple days, they could simply place a sign on the door to avoid confusion. Her behavior was very unprofessional, and this woman was so impolite I question whether I will ever return. The serving staff has never been friendly at this establishment, but I have excused it because the food is good.
author: McKenna P.

description: Very authentic and lively. Tables quite close together but not a problem. A locals' hangout as well as some tourists. Food quite flavorful and plentiful portions. Line to get in moves quickly. No reservations accepted. Best meal of our trip!
author: Mark D.

description:
This was the first recommendation by the luggage porter at the hotel - they generally tend have more honest opinions than the concierge. And he was damned right. This place, very popular for their rude staff and incomprehensible menu, is really good at the food part.

Yes you're shoved into long benches for tables on a first come first serve basis (no idea whose elbows are going to jab your ribs), and yes the menu-dish-bill triangulation will make little sense - but again the food part is going to be fabulous.

I sat down, got myself a beer, and then the waitress sort of decided what I was going to eat. Out the kitchen flew out this enormous onion pancake, drenched in a really tangy sauce, and then we negotiated on chicken as the contents of my main course.

Quite frankly I still don't know what it was, but it was really good.
author: Rahul J.

description:
Major bummer for my girlfriend and me. Went here because three and a half stars off 1700+ reviews is pretty much the same as four, right? Not so. If these guys are good, they sure are inconsistent, because it was The Worst Chinese food we've had in forever. 
I don't mind a line out the door for a busy restaurant, it's actually a good sign. I don't mind rude lots-lost in translation service either when the food is good.  but when you wait a long time for a miserable old mama-san to literally drop plates of super salty, non imaginative slop and forget the rice and still put it on the bill I start fidgeting. 
The spicy wonton soup was more French than Chinese, lots of butter and cream and LOTs of salt. The bow bing rolls (five hour beef my ass) came with a pile of  flour tortillas out of a package to wrap up into a gross cat food burrito. The fried appetizer was also lame and the side of palette cleansing greens was the only tasty thing on the table. The beer wasn't served in a cold bottle or with a cold glass and waving down a server, any server, was arduous. Especially disappointing because chinatown has so much good food everywhere you look.
Just walk around. There are so many good smells and menus on every corner one should speak to you. That is definitely what I'm doing next time.
author: Simon I.

description: I've been going to this place for about 20 years.  Went there last Friday and had a terrible experience.  I ordered the Beer Chicken, which isn't on the menu anymore.  The person said I'd need to pay $3 more.  Fine.  We ordered the Sesame Chicken and Fried Calamari.  The Calamari was soggy and we didn't eat it.  When I told her it wasn't good her reply was "well, other people seem to like it" and she wouldn't adjust the bill.  The Beer Chicken was OK, certainly not as good as before, but they charged me $4 more.  When I pointed it out, she shrugged and said it was the computer's fault and she couldn't do anything about it.  Lastly, the Sesame Chicken was supposed to come with yams, but I don't know what was on our plate.  They were so hard I couldn't chew them.  And, the amount of chicken was a lot smaller than before (and smaller than what the people next to us got).  I guess it was a good run, but I'll never go back there.  I'm done with the place.
author: Kevin L.

description: Heard great reviews so stopped in for lunch.  Was seated promptly.  The staff was good, mad some good recommendations.  The food was above average, but not worth making a trip for this food... worth a stop if you are in the area at lunch/dinner time and crave chinese food.
author: M T.

description:
We have been fans of this place for years.  And all that came crashing down this weekend. 

It had been a while since we went there, and so, noticed a drastic difference in the taste and quality of our favorite dishes

We are certain that that cooks have changed.  We could tell that probably the recipes passed on to them are the same but they messed them up.  Fried calamari came in a puddle of water, it was soggy and had the generically available Sriracha hot sauce on it.   The fried onion pancakes also came with Sriracha.  The noodle tower was missing the flat noodles, it only had a heap of crispy thin ones.  We also noticed the amount of oil, salt and sugar in everything - yes it was always there, but it was noticeable this time because of bad preparations

We have bid a farewell to our favorite restaurant with this visit.  Not interested in going all the way to SF to eat Sriracha, oil, sugar and soggy calamari

The old gentleman who is the owner was missing from the scene this time. I guess he is at the new branch.  With him gone, gone is the quality.
author: kd w.

description:
