This place never fails to amaze me. One of the best chinese cafe's near the financial district. I had the crispy noodle tower with chicken. Portion was generous and full of flavor. The chicken was soft and well cooked (not like those rubbery ones ive tasted).

My food always goes well with a nice hot glass of flower tea. I call it my magic tea. It looks like a mini aquarium in a glass only lacking of a fish and a scuba diver ;)

Its my 2nd time and i will definitely be back!
author: Rachel L.

description: In the heart of San Francisco House of Nanking is dishin' out the best chinese in the bay. Last time I stopped into this city street refuge I kicked it off with there potstickers, whcih is a tantalizing approach before the entree arrives. Next I ordered up a plate of there suculant & savory house special sesame chicken along side some delectable yams, this was a sweet addition to the dish. The chow mein was delightfully exquisite & the white rice... was white rice. The place is small so you always have a neighbor next to you, but who the hell cares when everyone is just enjoying the same flavors this divine establishment is puttin on the table as you. The service is great & very prompt. Now kick your BM double shoes into gear & hoof on over to Nanking!
author: Keith D.

description: Decided to try this place based on my brother's advice since he's the Elite yelper. Saw a line when we drove by and thought it must be good. Maybe we came on an off day but here's my experience. First, our wait wasn't that long for a table, maybe 10 mins top - good thing. Second, it was very busy so it took longer for someone to take our order - I was cool with that, I tend to give the benefit of the doubt. There were three of us and we ordered: sesame chicken, salt and pepper shrimp with mushroom, house fried rice, house noodles, melt in your mouth calamari, and spicy dumpling soup. Plenty of variety and food for us! However, we could have just gone with the first three dishes that I listed because everything else was mediocre or less. It was disappointing that the flavor was so subtle for the latter dishes that it was almost not even there. Lastly, as we paid for our meal and were getting up, we were spoken to, by someone who never helped us, as to why we didn't give more tip. I think they clearly don't understand that a tip is for good service and that's extremely lacking here. We left a tip and it was generous considering we only had our order taken and then food dropped off at our table. I was shocked at this person's direct questioning so I looked at him and said, "Because your service wasn't very good." Then walked out. Never coming back. Honestly, do your taste buds a favor and try some place else.
author: Ang P.

description: This restaurant is one of those places you go for good food, period. It's located in the city where parking is hard. I've been going to this restaurant for over 10 years and I still always make a point to go every chance I get. The Nanking chicken is a must! Just don't expect much in terms of ambience or service
author: Marta L.

description:
When we arrived we were seated pretty quickly, however since the place is so popular you get to sit right next to other patrons who you have probably never met. An older Chinese man who seemed to be in charge came out and asked us if it was our first time there, which we told him it was, and he then took the menus and said he'd "take care of us". This seemed like a nice gesture but I was a bit worried nonetheless. The first thing to come out was potstickers with a peanut sauce. These were very tasty, but I felt like I could have made them on my own pretty easily. Next, however, was the sesame chicken with sweet potatoes. This dish was easily one of the best servings of Chinese food I have ever tried; so flavorful. Lastly, a chicken and mushroom dish was brought out that neither of us enjoyed much.

The sesame chicken alone was enough for four stars, but if you go and have any sort of idea what you may want to eat, make sure to order it for yourself.
author: Matt S.

description: Have been coming here since 1992, and thought the rudeness of the waitstaff was forgivable because he food was pretty good. This time though they have lost us for good. The waiter (may have been the owner) was rude, unprofessional and condescending. Our food was cold (3 times sent back for same problem). The four people (speaking Chinese) who came in after us had their order taken before us and got piping hot food. We could see the steam coming from their rice.  First, our iced tea came out hot. Then our tofu came out cold. Then our rice came out cold. Our kid's food was the correct temperature. Then he started getting snarky when we showed him how soggy it became after the 3rd attempt. He made us a new one and brought out the old one just to show us he wasn't trying to pass off the old one on us. Like we are so picky we would accuse him of that. What a  jerk.
author: Donal B.

description: Arrogant service ruins this experience for me as I ordered off the old menu (at 2:30 no less) and got overruled by our server who wanted to serve us family style varieties instead of what we asked for. Fuck you, I'm not some idiot from the Midwest who won't know the difference - give me what I ordered.
author: Scott S.

description: We were walking around to find a lunch place, when we happen to notice there wasn't a line. Glad we had the opportunity to try out  this small, infamous hole in the wall. This place has some very unique flavors that you won't really get at other Chinese restaurants. You must order the sesame chicken and house garlic noodles. We ordered the onion pancake and that was okay. Get used to sitting so close to others that you literally could take your fork and eat off of their plate. This particular day it was not as busy, but if you are visiting the Bay, I think you must give this place a try.
author: Jennifer A.

description: The peashoot salad with Napa cabbage is the only salad I have ever seen my husband scarf. The famous sesame chicken and sizzling rice soup were also delicious.
author: Julie R.

description:
This was hands down the best Chinese Meal I have ever eaten.  

We had on a scale of 1-10
Apps:
Steamed pork dumplings 9
Pork eggrolls  10
Fried Eggplant  10 (this was a unique and delicious dish that is big enough to be an entree)

Entrees:
Sesame Chicken  10
Bo Bow wrap  (similar to mu shoo)  10
House Noodles 10
Seasoned Pork Chops  (fried)  7

Only one beer offered, Tsingtao, served chilled but not cold.
Servers are short with words, and can seem standoffish, but I loved it.
Food comes out in waves.  DO NOT WAIT FOR EVERYONES ENTREE TO ARRIVE AT THE TABLE TO BEGIN EATING 
Plan on sharing and taking your time with this unique and delicious dining experience.

I will eat here anytime I am back in San Fran.
author: R H.

description:
My bf took me here for dinner and I flipped out. I like my Asian food as authentic as possible so seeing that there wasn't a single Asian customer I wanted to run out the door. Strike 1! (my family always say, "if you go to an Asian restaurant and there's no Asians eating, leave immediately.") Bf convinced me to give it a try.

Do not order the hot and sour soup. When they asked me what kind of meat I want I was confused as hell. It was so catered to the American tongue, I couldn't find a hint of authenticity in it (ingredients and taste). Yuck! Strike 2.

Totally overpriced. Strike 3. I made the same pea shoot dish at home for less than $3. Go figure. 

Despite all these strikes, this place leaves me craving for their "Melt in your mouth calamari." So damn delicious. It's the only reason I want to go back. They don't have the slightest Chinese tasting food here, but they do have extremely delicious calamari. Okay so I hate this place but I love their calamari. =\ 

In a nutshell: Non-authentic Chinese food, overpriced, delicious calamari.
author: Annette S.

description: The wonton soup is great, and the sesame chicken is obviously some of the best.
author: Joe K.

description:
I was in San Francisco with my wife on our honeymoon and we decided to try some authentic Chinese cuisine. I must say, it may have been the best Chinese food I've ever had. I highly recommend the "Melts in your Mouth Fried Calamari".

BUT... the lady that helps runs the restaurant was absolutely awful. First of all, she shoves you outside with her arms before you even get in. Nothing she did was even remotely polite and respectful. It is like she didn't want you in her restaurant. When we got sat and she took our order (she seems to do a lot here, maybe the owner's wife?) my own wife's request was denied. I can't recall what drink was ordered, something like an iced tea, and she said "you don't get that, no". Before I can comprehend what happened, my wife changed her order and the lady walked away. I've never heard a server tell someone they can't have something that is on the menu. That rudeness was unacceptable.

I must say, the man who appeared to be the owner was very polite. Again, the food was excellent and the kind of place where the server just orders for you. Which is fine, but I just think that the CUSTOMER should dictate that, not the other way around. I can't get past the rudeness.
author: Evan P.

description:
The long lines, tourists, super tight seating is all worth it.  Now I'm not an expert on regional Chinese food so I can't speak to that... but I can say that the food we got melted in my mouth and was delicious.  I think it is some of the best, unique Chinese food combinations I have ever tried.  The prices are reasonable and the service is fast.  

It's a win for me!
author: Jessica G.

description: Oh my god I am ruined for Chinese food! I have never tasted such flavors!
author: Jesse A.

description:
Though the negatives you read here are true (you will be subjected to everyone else's dinner conversations; it's positively chock-a-block in there!), House of Nanking still is a great experience. I've been lucky; I've never had to wait for a table. Though, I have seen the lines going out the front door as I've left the establishment a few times. And I appreciated the subtly of the flavors. What is that herb in the sizzling rice soup? So delicate! And, get the tea. It just complements the meal perfectly. It may not be authentic, but it's delicious. 

My Chinese-American friend was impressed by the sesame chicken. So much so, he wants to bring back his father. I guess it's hard to get it crunchy on the outside and moist and tender on the inside. 

So, despite the detractors, I say give this place a whirl. Try to time it so you don't have to wait, and you'll be even happier with your experience.
author: Tree S.

description:
I went around 9:00 on a Saturday night not knowing what to expect line wise, because I had passed it many times seeing a long line out the door.

The staff was very accommodating, allowing the two of us to take up 4 seats while we waited for our other dining guests who ended up being almost 30 min late. 

The food itself ranged from good to very good. The appetizer soups are huge and have 4-5 servings easily. The hot and sauce soup was very fresh and tasty.

The main dishes were pretty good too (except for this order of Mushrooms that tasted as if salt had been spilled all over it), but there was nothing especially memorable or unique that would make me come back for it,.

Overall I had a good meal and felt pretty full after, but there's nothing special that would bring me back.
author: Jordan C.

description:
Recommended by my friend from the Richmond District, we went to House of Nanking and walked out feeling less Asian than ever. First, the restaurant is located in SF Chinatown, but we were the only two Asians eating in a packed house full of tourists. The entire theme for the menu conveys the message: "You order it, we'll fry it." I was shock at the possibility that you could go into an expensive Chinese place and the only food choice presented was all fried--even the green union pancakes. 

Their tea was... strange: it is filled with leaves, roots, and other "colorful" exotics that I couldn't tell what it was. The table nearby asked us what was in the tea and I wished I could exoticize it further just to mess with their minds. By that time, I wasn't even in the mood for humor knowing that I had to pay for that piece of deep fried green onion pancake with brown sauce slobber all over it. By this time, I was wondering whether there were anything left in the restaurant that actually captures the flavor of Nanking.

One of these days I'm going to stop listening to that friend of mine. If I were to rate this place on its fried food, I would rate KFC higher for being honest for what it sells. As for the sesame chicken, I could get it at any restaurant named Panda and pay less for it. On that day, I deserve to be punished for committing the crime of going into a Chinatown restaurant filled with non-Asian customers.
author: Daniel L.

description:
We ordered:

Melt in your mouth calamari
Sesame chicken house special
Ginger scallops

All dishes were delicious, and as a whole, lots of salt. 

I was hesitant coming in, but left feeling like it was pretty decent food. Certainly not the best Chinese restaurant by any means, but it wasn't disappointing. Service was abrupt unless you knew how to speak Chinese. They seemed to be more receptive when I spoke the language. 

Still, I gotta say, I was maybe one out of two Asian people there by the time we left. Not sure how I feel about that. The menu is what I call a "safe" menu, tailored to a Western palate...so if that's what you are looking for, then by all means, House Of NanKing is your place.
author: Grace F.

description: Hurray! It's taken me years to find a Chinese restaurant that matches the criteria I'm looking for. I loved our country rice chowder and my garlic sesame noodles. I can't wait to go back. I would give five stars, but felt annoyed with the waitress, who rushed us in paying the bill while we were still eating.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description: I've been several times and always get the stewed beef bao bing wrap and it's usually wonderful, but sometimes it'll be chewy.  I wish it was a tad more consistent with this particular dish.  I love it!  All their dishes are pretty delicious though.  Their typical things like sesame chicken and potstickers are solid choices.  The soups are good and so is the calamari.  I love the environment and the casualness of it.
author: First P.

description: Definitely different than all other Chinese restaurants you have been to. The wait is too long, but worth trying once.
author: Siavash N.

description:
I enjoyed the food here. It was really good, I hate seafood but I managed to eat a fish dish and a calamari dish here and enjoyed them both.

I gave this place 4 stars because I don't like how close all the tables are to each other and I thought it was a BIT on the spendy side. I suppose that's just a San Francisco thing though.
author: Jim P.

description:
this had been a must on my boyfriend's to-do list for awhile. when in the area one sunday afternoon, we decided to see if there was a long wait. we were quoted 10 minutes and decided to stick around.

they move fast, you're in, expected to know what to order almost as soon as you sit down and you're out.

the food was surprisingly fresh and high-quality for a chinese restaurant in the heart of chinatown. we thoroughly enjoyed our meal here and would definitely come back. when a chinese restaurant has fresh eggplant [as opposed to over marinated and anything but fresh] in a dish, you know you're in good hands.

definitely reccommend house of nanking if you're in the mood for authentic chinese food.
author: Mandy A.

description: My friends recommended this place. It was very busy. After waiting in line for 45 minutes we were seated. The food was amazing, and I could here all the tables around me raving about the deliciousness as they ate.
author: Michael A.

description: Delicious food with okay service. I went here while visiting from Denver, where there is a significant shortage of any good, authentic Chinese food so this place was off the charts for me! I am a vegetarian and there were plenty of options, I ended up getting chow mein, and fried rice, my boyfriend got hot and sour soup and sesame chicken.The rice was amazing, not greasy and heavy feeling, the portions are huge on everything too! Even though I didn't eat the chicken it looked amazing, unlike many other restaurants I've been to, you could tell it was actually chicken, it looked lean and tender, my boyfriend didn't complain--he ate every last bite. We had tons of leftovers and ended up eating them the next day for lunch! Absolutely delicious, I will definitely be back!
author: Callie H.

description: Absolutely delicious dining! Trust your server to bring you the goods of the day. Their menu is fantastic and incredibly affordable.
author: Joshua c.

description:
I used to come here all the time when I worked near by in the pyramid in the 90s.  Stopped by today for a little meal with my husband and found it to be just as enjoyable as I remembered.  

We ordered the steamed pork dumplings and the eggplant in the chili garlic sauce. The dumplings were quite tasty, with a good sauce.  The eggplant was extremely good.  

We tried to check out what other people were having, but it looked like there were lots of folks ordering fried rice and sesame chicken, which didn't interest us much.

Service is quick, but aside from that not very notable.
author: Lisa B.

description: Our first visit here was a few years ago and we loved it.  Now, not so much.  First, they didn't have any tea- at all.  Ok, that happens.  Then we ordered their house specialty, sesame chicken. It was so bad I couldn't eat more than a couple of bites. My husband had hot & sour soup and calamari.  The soup was not good.  The chicken in it was tough and super greasy.  The calamari (according to him) was good, but he left with an upset tummy, as well.
author: Lori K.

description:
Vegetarians beware!!!!!!  Of my 4 vegetarian dishes ordered, two of them contained rogue pieces of meat in them!  When my husband kindly and quietly brought this to the attention of the crazy woman who seated us, she said, "Not possible, we use separate woks for meat dishes and vegetarian dishes, it is impossible that your dishes contained meat!"  She would not accept that this was a possibility and stomped off.  She was so adamant that I actually had to laugh.  She was loud, rude, and brought attention to herself causing other customers to chuckle.  After she stomped off, we called her back and asked her  to identify the hunk of meat that was in my napkin.  She took the napkin to the kitchen for identification only to return to our table without admission or apology.   She simply and rudley placed our bill on our table telling us that she removed the two dishes that were questionably contaminated with meat and stomped off for the second time.  
I say vegetarians beware, but I can't help but wonder, if this place is so careless as to drop several pieces of  meat into a vegetarian dish, what grody bits might they accidentally drop into a meat dish??????
author: Ann S.

description:
Delish! This restaurant marked by a techo-color sign in the financial district is a must. 

The food is great and once your order is in, it arrives at the table at a border-line too fast rate. I highly recommend: 
-peashoots
-glazed sweet potatoes & eggplant
-seasame chicken (house fav)

The waitresses are more like dobermans, but ask them for recommendations and they warm right up.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Food. It's all about the food? Isn't it? I don't need a reveiw to tell me about the ambience (I can't afford ambience) or unfriendly staff or even slow wait times--what's most important is the FOOD--we went Sunday; and I felt like this was the Fried Rice, Sesame Noodles, and Pea Shoots I've been waiting to eat the last 15 years in San Francisco--delicious, fresh. yummy. I don't need the waiter to be super nice to me or fancy table cloths, etc. I'm a poor working class schmuck in SF--looking for great food for a good price--we found it here!
author: Lisa K.

description: Awesome Pork dumplings in delicious brown spicy sauce....so good!!
author: Foodie G.

description:
Ok, so I was doing the San Francisco touristy thing and my cousin, who lives right down the street from here, recommended House of Nanking as an interesting and highly regarded sanfran Chinatown Chinese attraction.

First, the food was great.  We got garlic fish which was awesome - lightly fried whitefish with spinach and onions in a light garlic sauce.  Sesame chicken was great, and the scallion pancakes were awesome as well.

The people were *not* friendly - you can tell these people are proud of the fact that they are a local landmark and make no attempt at good service.

On to the reason this gets 1 star - my wife found a RUBBER BAND in her noodles - I took it up to tell our host and he said he was sorry, then handed me a 61.50 check and didnt offer to comp anything.

UNACCEPTABLE AND UNHYGENIC.

Lame.  Steer clear.
author: John M.

description:
After finding out that the Thai restaurant had been shut down I decided to check out House of Nanking because of the awards on their window.

Right away I was taken to my seat and handed a dirty menu. The prices on the items were few and expensive. (Rice is separate and tea is extra) Maybe with these prices the food would be plenty or extremely tasty? Incorrect, the portions are incredibly small and the taste is nothing special. I got the 13 dollar calamari (the menu says highly recommended!) and the 10 dollar eggplant. 

The calamari was an incredibly small portion and it tasted okay. It was lightly fried and vinegar and pepper was used for taste. Nothing special. The eggplant in chili sauce was cooked right, but the sauce was more sweet than spicy. 

This came after quite a bit of waiting and when it came, the incredibly rude waiter just left it on the edge of the table. Instead of rice in a bowl they give you a big bowl of rice to put it on dishes set for you. Amazingly enough, my first dish was dirty and was rudely replaced with no apology. While eating the food I could see the waiters touching the food after constantly wiping their hands on a dirty rag. What's wrong with that? They accept cash only. 

Unlike other Chinese restaurants, House of Nanking has no sides (such as hot sauce, soy sauce, and etc), so I asked for some hot sauce. The waiter did not respond and when I asked again he started yelling about something and got the hot sauce. Unlike the usual Sriracha hot sauce, the hot sauce was a dark brown color with chili seeds in it and was incredibly oily. 

I don't see why this restaurant received so many awards or why people line up to eat at this restaurant. Avoid this place to save yourself from terrible service and overpriced food. Oh and if you do, don't go to the bathroom. The lighting is dim in order to cover up how dirty it is.
author: Colin C.

description: If you like fried , sweet and sour Chinese food this is the place to get your fix. Expect a line outside so bring a jacket as the SF weather has 4 seasons in one day. I say try the place once or twice if you have tourist in town because the place is full of them. :-)
author: yin t.

description:
Eh, the food at House of Nanking is nothing exceptional.  Don't get me wrong, it's tolerable, but it isn't spectacular by any stretch of the imagination.  Also, the lady serving me started to walk away before I had finished my order and I had to stop her and get her to come back and take my drink order.  Not that it mattered, though, because they never brought me my damned drink despite putting it on the bill and trying to charge me for it.  I'll look somewhere else next time.

Edited on 13 July 2014 to add the following:

Kathy, my review concerns only my most recent visit to your restaurant.  I've been there before.  The previous time, I left underwhelmed by the food on that occasion as well, but the service was much better the first go around.  Thank you very much for your follow-up and for your interest.
author: Yo U.

description: What they provided are absolutely no original Chinese food. The only same part is the name. Try other Chinese food restaurants.
author: Roger W.

description:
Big Food in Little China. You have to luck out on getting a seat, but don't worry the wait outside wont be long. The look of the place makes you feel they have not touched anything since 1987. Then the food comes out and you realize why everyone is here. One of the best places in Chinatown.

Its a great dining experience if you have a date or a group of 4 because you will end up having othere couples sitting right next to you. 

Remember CASH ONLY
author: Justin C.

description: just ate there.  had the sesame chicken and pots tickers.  both tasted okay but consistency was as if the had been cooked earlier and just reheated.  very chewy when they should not have been. my table mate had the onion patties appetizer and they were very good.
author: Pete C.

description:
We tried sesame chicken and calamari. Food was good, but not typically chinese food don't use cucumber or yams in stir fried dishes. Portion on the chicken was reasonable, calamari portion was like a left over dish.
This place seemed like visited by tourists and folks who used to live in the area and came back to find their child memories. We came on Friday evening, they already locked the front door at 8:30pm. Service was okay, it was a bit weird when the wait person stand next to our table and stared at us while eating.
author: CY L.

description:
I lived in San Francisco for 10 years and never knew of this place.  Shame on me because I missed out.  I was visiting SF for business and decided to take a client there per their suggestion.  My first thought was "eeack, I don't want to eat Chinese for lunch in Chinatown.  It will be busy and loud and messy."  I was wrong.  I truly enjoyed every bit of the place including the waitress suggestions, authentic ambience, and exciting vibration that fast paced environment gave off.  Oh, and the food was excellent!!  

We needed to discuss business so we asked the waitress to come up with our meal choices.  She asked if we liked fish, meat, calamari, etc... with one exception, we ordered all and a veggie dish for our Indian vegetarian friend.  The tastes were excellent, the service was excellent and the price was a good value for what we recieved.  I think we all wanted to curl up in a ball and go to sleep afterward because we ate too much.
author: Gary H.

description:
I won't comment on the authenticity of the food.  But then again I don't think food has to be 100% authentic to taste good.

Yes, it's probably Americanized.

Yes, it's probably more expensive (although I have real problems with those who think Chinese food always has to be cheap and divey).

But the food was yummy.  

Maybe I'm a poor judge because I came here after a recent Yelp event so I was very hungry at 9:30 PM and a little tipsy still.  We showed up and even though they were soon closing they seated us and proceeded to serve us family style with dishes selected by the chef (never had that happen before but what could be better than having your dinner chosen by mom/dad at a Chinese restaurant?).

The ingredients were all fresh and everyone seemed to be enjoying themselves.  I think we ate everything on the plates.

And even though we were the last ones there, they were pretty nice and didn't give us the evil eye about it.

Meal for 4 people included 4 dishes (unfortunately since the chef picked them I don't have exact descriptions: asparagus w/ garlic, some kind of pancake crisp, a beef mushu dish wrapped up for us and a fish dish).  Total was $57 including tax (but not tip).
author: Jean K.

description:
Came here today with a couple of friends on a recommendation from a random black gentleman on Market Street. He claimed it was the best "Chinese" food in the city so we thought we would take his word.

Place was definitely not as bustling as previous reviews have indicated, but that's because we were there on a slow weekday. Lady waitress gave us some complimentary potstickers for no reason and service wasn't bad. She even gave us a $4 discount at the end because we were all 'kids'. 

Food was definitely good tasting, (fried rice, chow mein, sesame chicken) but didn't quite strike me as genuine. I suppose this was reinforced by the fact that I was the only Asian, much less Chinese, fellow in the restaurant.
author: Tran S.

description:
Don't come here expecting awesome service! You'll have to be aggressive about placing your orders but you won't be disappointed by the food. 

Their food is delicious, although I remember it being much better about five years ago when the owner still actively ran the restaurant. He used to ask us what we wanted in a dish and would make it especially for our table with the ingredients we asked for. Those days seem to be over. 

BUT the food is still excellent. I especially love their Onion Cakes, Nanking Chicken, Panfriend Garlic Fish and Peanut Eggplant. You can't go wrong with anything on the menu because it's all amazing.

Notes of caution: 
Make reservations or show up early if you want to get a table during peak eating times! 

Check your bill at the end to make sure nothing was 'mistakenly' added to it. The servers do get very busy and sometimes lose track of what they put on the bill; at least I hope that's what is causing such discrepancies, I'll give them the benefit of the doubt. 

I HIGHLY recommend trying this place at least once, I'm sure you'll become a fan like me.
author: Raha G.

description: Used to go to Chef Jia back in the day, which has now closed.  We avoided the seemingly touristy House of Nanking.  Until now.  Have been there twice and flavoring is superb.  Salt and pepper mushrooms were fantastic, lettuce rolls with shrimp and diced veggies were excellent, had a great fish dish--and in case, the flavors were excellent without overwhelming the food.
author: Bobby D.

description:
Clearly this place has the hype, but I feel like it just doesn't quite deliver.  Food is a bit pricey for what is it (and where it is) but nothing really stands out for being great or mediocre.  They dish the 'tude to you but also can take it back.  Fun spot to take people that can't handle the true Chinatown but still want to experience something.

They definitely aren't trying to keep your water glass filled - that is if they even supply one for you.  Worth trying once but definitely not in the rotation.
author: William B.

description: This place, on its reputation, is riding. Poor service and pathetic ambiance may trick a few into thinking the food must be good. Trust me, it's not. My wife happens to be Chinese and she was the ONLY Asian in the fully packed place. That should tell you something. For starters, it tells you that it is overpriced and, as a follow-up, it advises you that the food is entirely lackluster. Sorry...
author: John D.

description:
Undoubtedly the rudest, most incompetent service I've ever experienced.
 
To be fair my Chicken Chow Mien was excellent (albeit a bit overpriced) which accounts for a two-star review instead of one. Still, there are WAY too many great places to eat in this town where you can get a nice meal AND not have to put up with an angry bitch of a waitperson. Wow, what a concept!

It started off just fine, we were promptly seated immediately upon entering. It was all downhill from there. A couple of minutes later a woman with a very tired and dazed expression on her face shambled over and just stared at me, not saying a word. At first I assumed she was one of San Francisco's many colorful "Street Characters" who had wandered inside the restaurant but after awhile I realized she was waiting for me to order. Look, the last thing I want is for a waitperson to lay on a lot of phony charm, I have no problem with curt, efficient service but jeez, at least identify yourself and ask me what I'd like to order!

The food came pretty quickly which was nice. However once the plates were plopped onto our table that's the last we saw of any of the staff, no return visits to fill a water glass, no "everything OK?", nothing. Once again, I'm NOT PICKY, I could have easily overlooked this (especially since Chinatown is famous for it's "brusque" servers) but after waving my credit card around for about 10 minutes in a vain attempt to flag someone down I was getting a bit annoyed. Fast forward ANOTHER 10 minutes and, realizing I've been forgotten again, I go up to the register to see what's up, only to be snapped at by the Chow Mien Nazi (who had taken my credit card) saying "I don't know, not me, ask her over there!"

I guess this is what happens when the double-decker tour-bus guides tell their riders how great a place is and literally dump them off on the curb at the front door, perhaps when you've got a racket like that going you don't need to try anymore.
author: Mike J.

description:
Food: 
house Noodles: clean and seemed lighter (large portion but fresh and vibrant) than i had expected = fantastic
shrimp packets: good, but could have used more than one little shrimp in each packet
pork dumplings: great and so was the sauce that came with them
sesame chicken: good but didn't care for the sweet potatoes because the sesame sauce was sweet enough
calamari: different/weirder than any calamari I've had in the past, but i kept going back for another bite...tangy! 
salt and pepper shrimp and mushrooms: no real "sauce" with this, but seasoned nicely...good for an additional dish if you are sharing family-style and the mushrooms were best part!
Service: hilariously "brusque" staff, but i didnt take it personally...they run a tight-ship  and the food is fantastic so there is no need to charm you with pleasantries. They won't say more than 4 words to you, but once you start eating, you won't give a shit!
Bonus: cold Tsingtao is cheap and goes well with EVERYTHING!
author: Robyn K.

description:
Don't do it...don't go.  Just say hell no.  The food isn't good and I'm not going to ruin your appetite by telling you the horror story of what I saw crawling through the kitchen the last time I ventured there with an insistent out-of-town guest filled with guide book hype.  Suffice it to say, the freaky thing wasn't what we saw, but that they spray painted over the window to the kitchen immediately after we complained.  Scary.  

Oh, and they really do only have one sauce for everything...
author: Ted R.

description:
Good American Chinese food in Chinatown. 

Food Highlights: Get the sesame chicken. Chicken is moist, sauce is great, and it comes with the most delicious sweet potatoes. The scallops in the ginger soy sauce with spinach was great - fresh, cooked well, and tangy. 

Not so great food: The calamari was a bit greasy for my taste and needed more seasoning, but they definitely know how to get calamari tender - it did melt in your mouth. Chicken dumplings were good, but they were again a bit underseasoned. The shrimp packets were underwhelming but came with the best peanut sauce. 

Price: very reasonable.  They pressure you to pay cash, but don't feel like you have to go to an ATM. We paid card. You just have to bust their balls a bit. 

Service: LOL. Typical for Chinese restaurants - they won't hold your hand, so speak up when you want something!
author: Andrea B.

description:
I just saw Rachael Ray's $40/day show on SF. She ate here. 
but you know what? whenever i eat here, i am the only AZN in the restaurant. And this place is located in Chinatown.

Enough said.
author: Jeff W.

description: I come from Nanking, almost all of food, I don't know what they are. I never see them in Nanking.
author: Zixuan L.

description:
Hopefully, my sister won't read this, as she and her boyfriend LOVE this place and are always attempting to drag my feet in through the door.

I've had better Chinese food in the ghetto of Sacofpotatoes than here.  Our initial visit was because Nanking was advertised in Sunset magazine and there was this line going out the door.  Once inside, you can't help but notice the grease sliding down the acrylic panel separating the dining area from the wok pit.

We were seated at the tiniest table imaginable for 3 people, and of course, I was seated in the aisle.  Every time the waiter walked by, I was bonked on the head by an elbow or tray.

The menu was vast and interpretation was impossible, so the waiter recommended the best items.

The chow mein arrived on a dinky plate that was nothing short of being mediocre.  It lacked substance and any taste.  The vegetable dish that followed would have been better if it were not for the amount of grease it was wallowing in.  The meat dish that followed was too salty and fried....I did not even touch that.  In the end, I sneaked over to a Mediterranean joint for their hummus and baklava.  Which reminds me, have to do a review for that place!

Tourists, please come this way.  I suppose it does not help that Nanking is still listed on cheesy tourist maps as Top Places to Visit.

Not.
author: Miika M.

description:
I'm not Chinese, so this is in no ways a judgement of how authentic House of Nanking is. 

My buddy invited me here and since he's chinese he wouldn't take me to a tourist trap. I was wrong. Despite it being completely "faux-chinese" he swore that it would be great. It was. 

We had the Nanking chicken and the crackling beef. Both were excellent.

Service was so-so since I asked for water before I received my meal and didn't get it even after I asked twice. I got my water once I was done with my meal. 

The line was pretty insane. We only waited about 25 minutes and lucked out it was only two of us. Good luck if you're in a big party. Oh, and this was on a TUESDAY night!

All in all I would go back. Loved the food. Great location.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Generally good flavor.  Had to wait 45 minutes.  Not worth the wait.

The Good:
Potstickers
Egg roll
Sesame chicken

The Bad:
Calumari (advertised as melt in your mouth, but not so much)
Hot And Sour Soup (so vinegary it was inedible)
author: Paul M.

description:
The pork eggrolls were good. 

Food was too salty for me. The Sesame Chicken would've been great but the salt took over the meal.
author: Noelia R.

description:
I used to live in San Fransisco and one of the main things I miss is the House of Nan King.  If you go, you must get the mu shu. They use zucchini and basil instead of cabbage.  AMAZING!  Other than that I always got what the waitress recommended, something with chicken and yams.  

If you're visiting SF:
Tip number one, bring your jacket and gloves, summers are freezing
Tip number two, visit the house of Nanking after the lunch hour or before the dinner rush, that is if you ever hope to get a table...cause its always packed in there!


The decor is non existent and its too loud to talk there, but who cares, the food is that good.
author: Jasmine W.

description:
We walked by this place while ambling around aimlessly looking for a place to eat a delicious and unique lunch (we're tourists). It had an alluring curb appeal so we entered and were promptly ushered to the best seat in the house. To top it off, a picture of Keanu Reeves posing outside this very place, hung above our window seat.

Order the vegetable dumplings (deliciously fresh and incredible dipping sauce), salt and pepper shrimp (easily some of the best shrimp I've ever had), and house noodles (you've probably never had noodles like these before...). I ordered hot tea and was brought a generous mug of green tea with fresh goji berries in it. Delicious and nutritious!! 

Overall the food was fantastic. The staff could definitely be a lot more friendly though.
author: Leslie M.

description: There are a couple things we really like about this restaurant-- the amount of vegetarian options, the owner (not sure his name), and being able to tell the waiter that we are vegetarian and he just brings out food until we tell him to stop. My family and I have been here close to a dozen times, and it has historically always been great. We were disappointed the last couple times, and I think it is because their main owner (the guy) is no longer there. I hear he is now full-time at his other restaurant (Fang's). I have not tried that one yet. Overall, House of Nanking is a hole in the wall, but still clean and much larger than what it was before. I wish the cups were cleaner, as it is kind of scary to drink water from them now.
author: Veeral S.

description: After our painful experience at House of Nanking I read the Yelp reviews on the restaurant.  Apparently we were not the only ones who felt the service was inexcusable.  The manager lady who replied to the reviews kept explaining that they were treating their customers the way authentic Chinese restaurants do.  I hope that their replacements show a bit more love for their fellow man.
author: Fred N.

description: Don't go here unless you are a vegetarian.  They only had two dishes that had meat on it.  Good layout of the restaurant and they serve beer.
author: Earlane S.

description:
Face....itching....MSG overload. Gack. *scratch, scratch, scratch*

But the pea shoots were tasty, if not exactly vegetarian (I think they came in a pork broth). 

Was told to get the potstickers. They were good, but the one's at Brandy Ho's around the corner are MUCH better.

Best moment: Tourist couple from the midwest saying "Now this is REAL Chinese food". *giggle* *giggle* *snort* *hehe*

Put in less MSG and I might be back. Mebe. Just to see the tourists.
author: Danielle L.

description:
Place is still good, but I've been there twice since my glowing review, and I have to say I was disappointed for the first time ever. Once, in the past year (Aug '10) I took my mom there, and everything we ordered was just kinda junky. Not even ok, kinda bad. But all restaurants have off days.

Went back after that (this July), brought my brother there, and it was slightly redeemed, but felt like the magic was gone. Or maybe my expectations had been so built up in my head that there was no way to meet them, who knows. 

But it just doesn't seem the same as when I first went there, some 12 yrs ago.

It's  still fine, but I miss head guy just pulling that "swipe the menus" move like he used to do.
author: Ches W.

description: Probably not somewhere you should go on a diet.... although it can be done.The food here is saucy and extremely flavorful. The chow main is unreal. The sauce is addictive. The noodles are round and they seem house made. The sesame chicken appears to be their specialty. It is fried, saucy and looks decadent. There are some really gourmet delicate dishes as well. The sliced scallop dish we had was light, complex and amazing. The pea shoots had another light, extremely good sauce. Amazing. They have the neatest flower tea, in which they steep the whole, gorgeous flower right in your glass. There is also a spiced fruit tea, served iced or hot that I love. Servers and owner are no nonsense but nice enough... and fast. There is always a cool crowd.
author: Ari R.

description: Nanking chicken was a standout...pea pod salad was different to say the least.  I'd come back to try other things on the menu.
author: Kelvin S.

description:
I'm not sure what the chef's boner for yams is all about but those bastard orange tubers seem to show up in every dish. I'm saying that and I like yams. But there's just so much yam a girl can take.

They say to come House of Nanking and let your server order for you. That 's actually code for "Let your server be surly to you and bring you more yams." Whether or not you blindly let your server make the decisions for you, be sure to order their fantastic veggie dumps (vegetable dumplings).
author: Kathleen M.

description: Wish I could leave no stars, right from the beginning the waitress was rude and in a big hurry, we asked for 3 sprites and a lemonade, a guy brought 3 cans of Sprite and a can of Minute Maid lemon...  He gave us 4 straws that were opened ( not singly wrapped). the food was ok, they brought the check when they believed we were done. We asked for desert and they said "no desert" and rushed us again, we went to pay but noticed a total of $72 with tax and all, at the bottom of the receipt with pen it said total $85, yes she added her self a $12 tip ( even though she never once came over to see if we needed something). the bathroom was also right behind us. It was a unisex single person tiny bath room... Overall awful experience...if you're not use to authentic Asian food you will say it's good when it really tastes like Panda Express...
author: Rodolfo V.

description:
First off, the food was excellent.  I had the walnut prawns and the sesame chicken.  Both were full of spices that I could not recognize and I enjoyed experiencing something new.   I was deceived with the lack of Asian authenticity that the name, "House of Nanking" seemed to indicate.  

The line was out the door, service was slow, and they were cash only.   It was also extremely tight inside the restaurant with hardly any elbow room and I doubt the fire marshall would approve their seating arrangement.  I would give them an F on service.

The food was exciting enough that I want go back to try some of the other dishes.  If you don't mind a long wait and uncomfortable seating, go for it
author: Jacob S.

description:
I really liked it, came with a group of 10 and the Waitress ordered for us.
We had a variety of dishes and everyone of them was a hit with the crowd.
Right in the middle of China town and I'd go back again and again.
author: Fumi I.

description:
Ever since I was a kid I always wondered what the buzz about this place was.  Every time I would pass by it there would be a long line of people outside waiting to get into the cramped little restaurant. 

I think that it's pretty unanimous that mainly white people love this place and most Asians hate it which is pretty evident since a vast majority of the patrons are white.  Being half white and half Asian, I really wondered which side of my heritage would dominate in terms of my palate.  My dad (white) use to rave about this place when I was a kid.  My mom (Chinese) never liked this place and referred to it as Americanized Chinese food.  In this case the old adage of "mom knows best" played out true to form as evidenced by my two star rating. 

First of all, I thought it was hilarious that they don't even provide you with chopsticks, only forks.  I'm really curious if they even have chopsticks here for the patrons.  A buddy and I ordered the pork dumpling appetizers, salt and pepper shrimp with mushrooms, and the obligatory order of the famous sesame chicken.  The pork dumplings, covered in some kind of sludge that I think was supposed to be a sauce, were probably the worst dumplings I've ever had!  The shrimp was okay, but the rest of the dish wasn't very good.  The sesame chicken was decent, but was very interesting in that it was served with sweet potatoes.  The rice they gave us also did not seem freshly cooked, but much more like day old rice that was reheated. 

In sum, this restaurant is like an overpriced Panda Express and by no means should be considered Chinese food.
author: Erich D.

description:
My boyfriend took me to this place because he loved their sesame chicken. I was skeptical at first because it seemed like Americanized Chinese food, but it wasn't entirely. It seemed like a hybrid of traditional Chinese food mixed in with American influences, something an ABC (American Born Chinese) like me would cook up if I decided to whip up something relating to my heritage. I really enjoyed their "Country Rice Chowder," a dish my grandmother would frown upon because the ingredients are all scrambled in, making a colorful mess, but that's something I always did with my food.

Their dishes are geared towards a more westernized palate, as they offer "fried calamari" and "mushu pork."

My last visit wasn't as memorable as the staff can be a bit rude, but I think it's worth visiting at least once. Hopefully the tastiness of their food will make up for their service. However, right before I left, I witnessed the waitresses struggle with guests upon separating the checks. It made the staff seem inexperienced, and the customers seemed really frustrated and I doubt they will come back. Unfortunately, that was the last impression they left me with, but I will return for some country chowder in the future.
author: Jeane C.

description:
Sesame Chicken, mushu beef, their mushroom dish.... that was what I first fell in love with when I visited House of Nanking in 2008 with my mom and my aunt.  We were blown away by the delicious flavors. 

Since then it's been my go-to and when I have guests from out of town, I make sure to take them to House of Nanking.  BUT, it has since been going downhill since the first time i've been.  I don't think I've been getting desensitized because I don't go that often but it seems like the quality of the food isn't as great as it used to be.  

Needless to say, it's still a good stop if I'm downtown and is my preferred restaurant when I'm down there, 

They definitely serve an amazing tea though and if you eat there have some tea with your meal.
author: Erica G.

description: Amazing Chinese food. If you are looking for a fun, authentic, delicious, San Francisco experience come here!! I saw a lot of people complaining about the service, but I look at it from Nanking's perspective. These people see hundreds of people each day and work very hard to get you in and out very quickly. One of the many things me and my family loved was that the food came out instantly (and still hot and fresh). When you come here don't expect service from the Waverley Inn in Manhattan. The service is a part of the experience (and I am one to care about service). Their food is amazing: each dish has a slight Nanking twist to it which makes it unique and special. This restaurant is an example of what San Francisco is known for: character and good food!
author: Leslie S.

description: This is coming from a Chinese foodie who has lived in sf for twenty years. This place sucks. Lettuce wrap for $12 and it taste bitter, not worth the price. Sesame chicken was too salty and the yams that came with it was under cooked.  And they water down the soap in the bathroom until it's mostly water.  Wonder how clean their hands are?  Definitely will not be coming back again.
author: Gordon C.

description:
Waste of money for sure. A lazy lazy drunk/hungover asian (and poor) college person cooks better food (and I don't just mean me in college).

Check the awards on the wall - all old. Check the clientele - all tourists. Perhaps this is the ghost of something once good.

I was tricked into coming here by a well-meaning friend who I suspect likes this place due to sentimental value. Can't hate on that. But save yourself the pain of sitting though the terrible service, food, presentation, and even broken dishes and just go to any other restaurant in Chinatown and you'll probably be better off.
author: Eric P.

description: Every time I visit the Bay, I find another reason to go back, and this time it was House of Nanking. This place has the BEST Chinese food I have ever had. Two of us shared the Sesame Chicken, Pork Potstickers, House Noodles with Chicken, and some steamed rice and were STUFFED for about $30. It's conveniently located walking distance from Union Square - or an $8 Uber ride away because it was unusually cold last weekend. It's a tiny place with a lot of oomph. Can't wait to go back!
author: Tamar S.

description:
If you gave this place any less than 5 stars, you probably should stop getting really drunk and licking the beer you just spilt on bar floor off the ground, because it obviously ruined your taste buds.

The popular thing to do here is to tell the server to just take care of you.  Then they will ask you if you want vegetartian, beef, chicken, or seafood. And if you want an appetizer.

If you want tell them to mix it up a bit so you can try a little bit of everything.

Then sit back, well actually you probably won't be able to move because it is so crowded, so go ahead and get comfortable and put your arm around the random strangers you are sharing the table with and LET THE MAGIC HAPPEN.

This first dish will come out, they have a few different appetizers.  They all will cause a total meltdown of your brain. That means its good.  Try the onion pancake with peanut sauce for an appetizer if you want.

During your appetizer the server will begin to bring you an aunslaught of about 5 dishes.  You will only be a few bites into a dish and the next on will be coming for your table.  

WARNING: you may get nervous and start eating like a redneck at a buffet, but slow down and enjoy your dish.  Take your anxiety pills before you eat so you don't freak out.

All dishes look and taste amazing.

THIS IS MY FAVORITE CHINESE RESTAURANT ANYWHERE!!!!!!

The House of Nan King is small and you always have to wait to get in.  But trust me, it is well worth it.
author: Joyce D.

description: I read many reviews and decided this is where we were going to eat for our 1 trip for Chinese food in Chinatown. My wife and I arrived there about 15 mins ago at exactly 840 pm.  We were told they were closed and could not eat there.  Yelp says they were open till 10pm.  The guy at the door told me 9pm.  Either way we made it by 20 mins. We looked through the window and there was plenty seating.   Thanks for nothing.   I hope for nothing but failure for your establishment.
author: Andy W.

description: Excellent food - eggplant is good and their onion cake is to die for. Ambience is OK but food makes up for it
author: Parth S.

description: I've been going here for 10 years.  It used to be a tiny hole-in-the-wall place with mismatched plastic plates/cups and the only decoration was the wall to wall awards for best Chinese food.  Now it is much nicer in appearance and only slightly more expensive, but still a good price.  The food is still fantastic.  You must have the Nanking Chicken and Bo Bing Wraps.
author: Brandon J.

description: The food is great, cheap, and comes very fast.  Just a little wait, and little packed.  Still worth it!! Everything I ate was good.  The rice chowder soup was unique and the best of what I had.
author: Bob L.

description: A good location in North beach. For appetizer, we tried fried potsticker which was served with a house special peanut sauce. I really liked the sauce. We tried Nanking sesame chicken which was served with sweet potato. It was tasty but very greasy, but good. We also tried green lettuce wrap with beef, it was a nice dish but fried, so not the healthiest. There was nothing special about the service, lots of room for improvements.
author: Sasan A.

description:
One of the first places I ever ate in SF ... has changed over time but it's still a staple in my American'ized Chinese Food eating regiment when I'm in town.

Get some onion cakes to start and some Nanking Beef and Five-Spice Chicken as entrees and wash it all down with a Tsing Tsao.

Figure out what you want quickly after sitting down, better yet beforehand even, or bare the wrath of the staff.
author: Mike J.

description:
Whats the hurry ?

When we went this place was not crowded there were ample seats open still the atmosphere created in this restaurant is that you need to sit down order eat and go. 

The food tastes like PANDA express and there i think panda express orange chicken is better than the sesame chicken served here because atleast i can have it at my own pace without getting rushed into. Most food is cooked in same sause with no variation at all.

service is poor. This place is overrated and i would not go here again.
author: Y U.

description:
The owner comes and orders the food for you.  And it's not a scam.  How does that work?

We got the "spicy everything" menu, and it came out awesome.
+ tsingtaos x4
+ diet coke so someone can sober up
+ cauliflowers with twice-cooked pork
+ spicy spicy soup
+ spicy beef thingy with veggies
+ beef and scallion wrap thingy that the waitress wraps for you at the table
+ some other chicken dish that we ordered

I think I don't remember the dishes because I had a giant food coma afterwards.  But that's a good thing.  Can't wait to come back again!
author: Jenny L.

description:
Pretty amazing, although after going there 15 times, the small menu has gotten a bit rusty.

If you've never been there I'd recommend chef's choice for your group.
author: Michael E.

description: Saw the reviews and looked forward to going - was very disappointed.  We got in pretty quickly, sat down, told the server what we liked and got a bunch of stuff.  Specifically we had the dumplings (which were the best thing we had), a sesame chicken that tasted like leftover cuts of chicken with Sirachi sauce (really I don't get it at all, not sweet, not flavorful, not good) and a beef and broccoli thing that didn't taste like or have the texture of beef.  Sorry guys, but that was terrible.
author: John R.

description: Been a few times while traveling to San Francisco. Good food, sweet spot. Definitely would go back.
author: L L.

description:
Finally came after hearing about it from a few friends. Not being able to put your name in was a bit of a bummer, but at least it wasn't a cold night.

I don't need to talk about it being good, so I'll just tell you about the specific menu items we got.

Bok Choy (under the chinatown veggie thing menu item): Absolutely fresh and crunchy, probably the best prepared bok choy I've ever had. Super garlicky and very refreshing. Onions were very oniony, and beware the giant chunks of fresh garlic.

Pork potstickers: Solid. Very good, great sauce. I think there were 6 or 7 to the order.

Sesame chicken: the least interesting part of the meal.  Looked like orange chicken but way better than Panda Express, but there were better things on the table. These came with sweet potatoes that were very good but sliced so thin that their flavor got dominated by the sauce when eaten alone.

Melt-in-your-mouth calamari: lightly fried with a milky-looking, thin, lemony sauce. Best fried calamari I think I've had. I don't know what made the sauce milky but it was a great flavor combination. Good portions, too.

Five-spice pork chop: Lightly fried also, and very good. Very thin cuts. Look out for bones.

Mushrooms stuffed with pork: Good, but not the best dish we had. Served on a bed of perfectly sautéed, garlicky cabbage.
author: Misa G.

description: We enjoyed our lunch - my aunt is vegetarian and the server recommended off the menu - a tofu with blackbean sauce dish which wax very good. I had the Nanking sesame chicken which I also liked a lot. We went in early - as in when they opened , as we were in the area walking around and famished, and was seated very quickly. Service is on slow side, but I didn't mind.
author: Cat D.

description: The food was just OK, more like home cooking. I don't get why this place is so popular. It seemed to be all tourist eating there when I went.
author: Eve D.

description: This place was unbelievable!  The food was absolutely amazing and fresh.  I will come back here any chance I get and am already trying to find a window of opportunity to book a flight to SF to get there.  We didn't even look at the menu, just had them give us their recommendations, and they really took care of us.  Every dish was clean by the time we got through.
author: Brian O.

description:
They have that tea that opens up like a flower!

Get that chicken thing that everyone said!

Get two of them!

Why not 5 stars? Service was a little lacking. Some places, when they get popular, put service on the back burner because they're so popular they feel like they don't need to give good service to every customer, because there's fifty more waiting to take that table. The food arrived sporadically; for example we were long since done with the chicken when the chow mein arrived. Also, be aware that they are...

CASH ONLY
author: Rachel H.

description: Nanking chicken and Sichuan chicken were fantastic. Very fresh. Steamed pork dumplings also a must
author: Ian B.

description: Terrible service. Very rude and they are cheating visitors into huge tips. There are plenty of great restaurants in this area and I would not recommend this place to anyone. Food itself is OK.
author: Sam R.

description:
I come to this restaurant every single time I'm in San Francisco and It has always been good.. The last two times though I have been not satisfied at all and I think yesterday was the last time I stepped in it. Food was average, service poor and they raised their prices too! I used to have a feast for around 10$, yesterday it was 25 a person, that for Chinese is really high. 
Sorry Nanking, there are way too many more Chinese restaurants around you worth exploring..
author: damiano M.

description:
Any place that has a line outside waiting to get in is worth a look.

Best Calamari I have ever had, and at a reasonable price. Also try the scallop Won Ton soup...excellent ! Very informal, but nice clientele. By far the best Chinese food in San Francisco if you can stand the wait.
author: Roger L.

description:
This is a great place to take guests from out of town if they want some local flavor. What it is lacking in esthetics (decor wise) it makes up for in food. Its a turn em and burn em kind of restaurant but worth it. This is a very casual place so don't plan on going here instead of Acquarello or Boulevard! Oh and this restaurant is not one that you sit for hours drinking at with your meal, it is sit down grub it up, feel Thanksgiving full and then get your butt out of there before they give you the eye. 

Calamari, Sesame Chicken, Beef with Green Beans are my favorites. 

Oh and I LOVE their house tea and the goji berries they put in it. I could drink that all day.
author: Tsuni S.

description: No matter what if you call at a busy time and say you have a to go order. They will hang up on you. Literally hang up on you without giving a reason. No business no matter what their food should treat their customers like that. Terrible. Pathetic.
author: Neil B.

description:
The only reason I have ever eaten there more than once is because my dad always wants to dine here when visits San Francisco.

The food is pleasurable (no doubt) but I get the worst migraines after coming here.  All the MSG?

The people working there are downright rude and inattentive.  You have to wave them down aggressively to get any service.  They avoid eye contact on purpose.

I once asked if I could have the food made without MSG and the server practically ripped my face off for asking.

MOST IMPORTANTLY, the cleanliness.   The place is N-A-S-T-Y!  You know what I'm talking about.  You know no one is washing their hands.

The first time I went there, as I was waiting for the restroom, I saw someone drop food on the floor and throw it back into the vat.  Ok, so I'm sure this happens in restaurants all the time...............BUT............does this happen all the time?

I'm here over Thanksgiving break (dad in town) and I'm waiting for the bathroom again (yep...got a small bladder) and I spot the owner's wife do the following:

Touch her shoe.
Walk over to a big pot of something soupy and steamy.
Reach her hand in the pot.  A full fist into the very hot pot.  Grab a handful of some mushy looking stuff.  Put into her mouth.  Then she grabs some salt or spice or something, pours the spice in.  Then with that same hand (that now contains the mushy stuff, her saliva and her shoe germs) puts the hand back in and continues to eat like that - like a damn animal.

PATHETIC!  SICKENING!  

And it wouldn't be so bad if the people that worked there, particularly the owners, didn't have such a nasty attitude.  But for some reason, it just makes the disgust even worse.
author: Sasha B.

description:
Three stars may seen high to some who've been there, but this venerable SF Chinatown standby is consistent and still going strong. It isn't the best or most authentic Chinese food you'll ever have, but that isn't why people go there. You know exactly what to expect from this place and it's signature dishes like the Onion Cake, Chinese Eggplant, fried or in Black Bean Sauce(Glazed) , Sesame Chicken, Boa Bing Wrap, House Noodles, it's all good and it's all exactly the same as the last time you were there. Some are put off by the brusque pace and cramped tables, or by the "ok what do you want" attitude of the staff, I say it adds a welcome touch. This isn't fine dining, it's, "welcome, sit down, eat, see you next time!" ,and Peter and Lily will anytime I'm in Chinatown, and hungry and I want the familiar comfort of their food.
Go
author: Thomas M.

description:
This review is based on our lunch at House of Nanking a couple of weeks ago. The food was so good, that I wasn't worried about the fact that service was a little on the slow side. We ate the following:

Steamed pork dumplings: These were average. The dumpling wrapper is thick and doughy, so you taste more of that than the filling. Sauce = gooood.

3 tiered baby peashoot salad: Fresh, crispy, delicious! The waitress suggested that we add crispy rice and mushrooms and these additions really took the salad up a notch.

Panfried garlic fish: Clean, flavorful, mouthwatering! Sweet and savory!  We have been craving this fish ever since..

We did not try to sesame chicken, but it looked awesome and a lot of other people were eating it. The atmosphere is casual and comfortable. Some people were hanging out, taking their time and enjoying a bottle of wine with their lunch and others just came for a quick bite. They serve a couple different teas and also have a very small wine and beer list. I will be returning to this place on my next trip to SF :)
author: Mollie E.

description:
Worst dining experience I think anyone could imagine. I have no clue why this place gets this much hype. 

The employees are disgustingly rude and snap at people willing to give their restaurant business. Our waitress even had the nerve to stand over me while I was writing the check. Only then do they smile and ask how our food was. 

The food was decent, but not worth the horrendous service. We should have walked out the minute the manager rudely snapped at us for our drinks.

 The place is cramped, freezing, and loud. I would not wish this experience on my worst enemy.

Plus if you really feigned an interest in your "valued" customers, you would not have so many people ranting about your little establishment.
author: Melanie H.

description:
Seems like a tourist trap, but the house noodles are great (I asked for them spicy with shrimp, yum!).  The "famous sesame chicken" tastes like something I would get from PF Changs.  The chicken is gristly dark meat, lightly breaded and fried (which was a plus) and a sticky sweet sauce (which they were very heavy handed with).  The sweet potatoes with the chicken and cucumber garnish were good, though.  

I recommend the house noodles, spicy.  I do not recommend the sesame chicken.  

I question the cleanliness of the establishment, and I would not recommend going to the bathroom here unless you really need to...

CASH ONLY!
author: J L.

description: First dish had plastic in it, Second one had hair in it. Enough said.
author: Melissa P.

description: house of N-king is DELICIOUS.  i've been stunned every time i've eaten there & of all of those times, not once have i seen or ordered from a menu; the (seems to be) owner or manager just tells me what i'm eating.  it's awesome.  fresh vegetables, cheap tsing-tao, every food item i've had there is spectacular.
author: Kris B.

description:
All four of us concurred that this was the BEST Chinese meal we've ever had and we've had many.  It was our first visit and they suggested we let them put the meal together for us based  on a few questions about our likes and dislikes. 

The stage was set for a great meal with the cold shrimp and tomato salad which had exquisite flavor and texture.  The sautéed pea shoots were extraordinary!  The scallop dish had the largest scallops I have ever seen in a restaurant.  The sesame chicken and yams was delicious and reason enough to come back,  but I would rank it behind the shrimp salad and the pea shoots!

The fruit detox tea is wonderful and served hot or cold.  The hot flowering tea was delightful.  $1.95 for a can of soda seemed a bit out of line.

We came about 8:30 on a Monday and had no wait.

This place is a MUST when visiting Chinatown!
author: John C.

description:
Great Chinese food.  Just ask the chef to "give you what's good today".  He'll ask you a few questions about what you like and don't like and then says "I'll fix you up."  You'll love what be brings you.

We had a soup appetizer with fish, crunchy fried fish dish and a crispy shrimp with crispy rice.  Everything was totally unique and delicious.  Its not much to look at on the inside, but the food is great and prices reasonable.
author: Steve S.

description: I LOVED THIS PLACE. I wasn't expecting to. I had heard the name but didn't think chinese restaurant food could vary much. At least that had been my experience. WOW. What an eye-opener! The Hot and Sour Soup was as visually beautiful as it was delicious in a layered, complex and just the right amount of heat - way. The Steamed Dumplings in a Black Bean Sauce were .... divine. Why didn't I think of this? Of course, it makes so much sense to pair these wonderful dumplings with a wonderful sauce rather than serve them plain with some soy on the side. Brilliant! The Sesame Chicken was delicious beyond belief and the Tower of Noodles with Braised Fish was more subdued but equally delicious. I felt guilty at the price we paid. NOT ENOUGH !!!! The service was consistently chinese restaurant style - in that "I cannot care less that you are here" but who cares? The food was amazing, and I recommend that you go at an off-time to avoid the crowds - 2 pm was perfect for a late lunch. MUST GO BACK. SOON.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Honestly I can't remember too much about what I ate b/c basically we had a nine course dinner between seven people under 15 minutes FLAT!!! I came with a bunch of medley of international people (French, Moroccan, Czech, Texan) to this place on a Sunday Night. We were all starving, cold, and looking for something to EAT goddamit. I had heard of House of Nanking, how it was good (some white person told me that), and that the lines were always out the door. So when we got there and there was no line and no wait for our party of seven I was like wtf ok.

So we sit down and before we could glance at the menu, the supposed "head chef" comes over and says "First time here? (all of us nodding) OK I Create the  menu for you! It will be good no worry!" He didn't even ask us if we liked seafood, what kind of meats, no MSG (ha), no dogs or cats, etc.

What came next was a barrage of dishes like I've never encountered before. At first came one dish which was gobbled up quickly b/c as mentioned above we were fucking STARVING and COLD. Then, came three more, then two more.. As the speed of the dishes came crashing down faster and faster the eating frenzy among us became more frantic. Eyes were darting back and forth, food was flying everywhere, eating sounds resonated..  and before we knew it we had completed nine dished within 15 minutes. It had to be some kind of world record we wondered. 

As for the same sauce comments, I think I might have to agree.. the sauces were very interestingly close in taste..  but that might have been from combining nine dishes together within 15 minutes. I wanted to give it higher stars but the food was really just so-so and the head chef dude wasn't even cooking.. I think he was the janitor.
author: Henry W.

description:
Get the giant stein of tea - just a bit of sugar and very pretty to look at

calamari was cooked to perfection

fresh veggies, nice flavors, not bad!  

only complaint is the price : (
author: Kevin C.

description: I suggest you come here with a small group 3 or 4 people max. Went with 2 friends and we were seated in 5 minutes, while bigger groups were forced to wait quite a bit. Pretty cramped inside, not aesthetically pleasing, fast service. We ordered the steamed pork dumplings, sesame chicken, mushu tofu, beef crispy rice noodle tower, and a few beers. Best dish was the tofu. It came with these soft rice tortilla shells to wrap it in; the seasoning was amazing, very tasty. Everything else was made very well too. Great place to go to if you're looking for a quick bite of some awesome Chinese food at a reasonable price!
author: Daniel P.

description:
:-)

I loved this place.. 

but it was so tiny AND busy..

My favorites Sesame Chicken... 

Chow Fun and yes.. the potstickers too. 

thank goodness there are plenty 

other places that serve just the same

in quality and price... sans the tourist crowd.

4 woofs.. still, I'm a fan.. 
of this place and others.
(I'm a ho like that.)
author: JöHnNy A.

description: I generally don't like it when staff give me attitude in a restaurant, but in this case, I didn't mind so much. The menu is simple, which is often the case with small, hole-in-the-wall places. We ordered something from the menu with our waitress and in a few minutes the owner/chef came over to our table and said: "No, you don't want that." He said "Trust me, I'll order for you" and walked off. We looked at each other in shock at what had just transpired. Good thing our food was delicious. Space is tight, but we had a fun time.
author: Rebecca E.

description: This is my favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco.  They make a beef with baby bok choy that is very delicious, and a pork egg roll that is impressively filled with meat.  I enjoyed the large glass mug of flowering tea as well on a chilly day.  The stuffed scallion pankcake is righteous.
author: James L.

description: The food was so good. A mix of traditional and flares of their own. It wasn't the best chinese food I've ever had but it was very fresh and definitely a place to try out in China Town.
author: Alissa N.

description: Food is unique and atmosphere more upbeat than its counterparts around the corner in the depths of Chinatown. This place has been a bit oversold over the past 20 years, it's good but it ain't all it's been built up to be. I wouldn't sit in line to make the visit. BTW - the jasmine tea ball that seems to grow over the course of the meal like one of those little sea monkeys is definitely worth the $4 investment, but I'd gander you can buy them for $0.25 from your local chinatown shop around the corner.
author: Andrew S.

description: Ate at House of Nanking again this week. we're happy to live closer to SF now, and H of N.  waited for a table and worth the wait.  this is really a standout restaurant in a City with many, many good ones.
author: C T.

description: This was my first visit to HoN.  It was not the most inviting place but the food was tasty. I had the noodles with shrimp. The vegetables were fresh. I also had cold tea, which wasn't bad. Overall expected more being from New York. I guess I'll wait to go home and have a New York Chinatown experience for real.
author: Michelle M.

description: 4th star for the owner for great Basil Fawlty impression. Food sound enough and decent value. Improves with beer accompaniment. Worth a visit, probably not the queue
author: Dean B.

description: My friend recommended me this place.  We went here hungry and not knowing what to order and this awesome lady came and ordered fish soup and beef with bok choy dish for us in 3 secs and they were so good!  I will definitely come here again if I'm ever in SF
author: Fenny L.

description: So we basically had the chef, who was waiting our table order for us. The pot stickers and the sesame chicken was excellent. I should've ordered myself because the other dishes were fair. Overall, not bad. The prices were very reasonable for SF.
author: Ron L.

description: More of a tourist trap than anything. The overly rude waitstaff is a funny experience, but the food just isn't good. Shrimp packets had one tiny shrimp each; calamari was soggy and chewy; and sesame chicken was no better than what you'd get at your local Chinese takeout joint.
author: Dana S.

description:
Actually I would give this 2.5 stars if I could and my friend who immediately exclaimed "this is the BEST ever" would give this place 10 out of 5 stars.  We disagree.  We had been walking around ChinaTown, as tourists, that was the thing to do.  We had heard about this place and then heard another suggestion about it from a local.  We found it and the food was good but the atmosphere was pretty terrible.  Crowded, loud and very chaotic. I just wasn't all that impressed, call me prissy if you want but I like to be able to walk to the rest room without bumping into every person along the way.  I am glad we went but I won't be back.  I might recommend to someone but not everyone.  

Yes, we had to wait behind the velvet rope as well, and we did not feel that important, but we found it ironic we were waiting outside for a chinese food place at 4 o'clock in the afternoon in Chinatown- yes hilarious.

Food was good- I'll give 'em that.
author: Rachel P.

description: I have been going here for around 8 years now so I figured I should write a review. I would say that I have been there over 30 times. The food is amazing and I would recommend Nanking to everyone... Especially the calamari and stuffed mushrooms. Please don't be alarmed if the staff doesn't seem happy or nice. Just talk to them like you've known them for years and let the food do the rest!
author: Jeff C.

description:
We were a group of 5 people. All vegetarians. A nice old man came by. He looked like he ran the place. We looked through the menu and then started to tell him we are vegetarians. That's all the info he needed. He asked us about allergies and if eggs were ok. He then brought us all the food (appetizers, entrees et al) The quantities were PERFECT and the food was phenomenal! 

A place you shouldn't miss if you're around!
author: Vinay V.

description:
I get a great sense of satisfaction when a place lives up to its hype.

Things I ordered and loved:

- Melt-in-your-mouth calamari: Standout of the meal for me.  Light and hearty at the same time, not overly breaded, in an interesting and tangy sauce.  Would definitely order again.

- Famous sesame chicken: Actually quite standard (which is not to say it wasn't tasty, but I stand by my opinion that it was kind of generic).  Like that they pair it with sweet potato.

- Braised green beans: A perfect complement to the other dishes.

Things we ordered and they forgot to bring:
- Chow mein.  Which ended up being okay, since what we did receive was plenty of food anyway.

Would definitely come again.
author: Allison B.

description: The best Chinese food in Chinatown!!! Always long line, and that means it is so worth it.  The guy that came out from the restaurant said to people in line, "so worth it."  Must try their hot tasty tea! YUMMMYYY!!!!!!
author: Linda C.

description:
