Not as good as I remember it.  It was nice that they let us in 2 minutes before close (bright green neon clock read the time nice and clear) and the food came quickly... almost too quickly.  You know how somethings are better when they don't cum too quick?!?

We sat down and within 2 minutes received our "hot teas" all around... there are 4 of us at $2/pop didn't mind paying but also kind wanted a strainer as the Goji berries although tasty were finding nice cracks in our mouths to nestle in.

Sisters wanted the Onion Cake, a tiered fried tortilla looking thing stuffed with scallions and what not, the potstickers in a peanut sauce and their popular Mandarin looking chicken served with their famous sweet potato slices.

Everything seemed saltier than what I remember and the sauces tasted very similar (although different) in all 3 dishes and the presentation lacked hardcore... a lot of browns and not enough green.  

In and out in under 20 minutes... quick but only because I'm sure they wanted us out.  The place was still half full when we peaced out.
author: Shiho F.

description:
I love the House of Nanking and here's why: When I first visited SF in 1999, my cousin took me here and told me to let them bring me whatever was fresh.  And let me tell you, it was amazing--and still has yet to disappoint. You have to be prepared to let go of your idea of what food is "supposed" to taste like (especially from dubious points of reference like P.F. Chang's).  I have *never* had a bad meal, always have been served something new, and it has always been well worth the price.

I just say, "I'm a vegetarian, bring me whatever's good."  They size you up and bring exactly the right food and the perfect amount.  For me, that's included super yummy pea shoots, green onion pancakes, tofu thingys and other unidentified yummy stuff.  Go ahead, make the line a little longer.  Devotees can handle it.
author: Cassidy P.

description: Gees! Feeling discriminated against! Came to China town & stopped to get a bite to eat. Not even half way done, they bring us the bill & say "You pay NOW!" Others sitting next to us are enjoying their meal comfortably without being rushed. Is it because they're all White & more trustworthy than us Mexicans?WTH? Food was tasty but never coming here again!!  Feeling so disrespected!! Giving no stars (zero!) but cYelp won't let me post without giving one star, although there really should be the option of not giving any stars!Can't believe the treatment we obtained at this place! FYI, I am a well educated math teacher with a Master's Degree, so there was absolutely no reason to treat my family & friends as if we were criminals! Shame on you!! Plus your waiter was a complete a-hole!! We were asking if the sesame chicken tasted like orange chicken and he yelled at us saying "it's not orange chicken!!"Well yea, we knew that, but we were only wondering if it was sweet like orange chicken. No need to get upset/impatient with us! Therefore, totally disappointed!! Don't go to this place if you come from a minority background!!
author: Rosa G.

description: Very rude service last night - found a hair in the recommend garlic beef. No apologies or anything. We left right then and there. She grabbed the bill and cash the while I was still looking in my purse for the rest of it. R and G lounge is by far the better Chinese restaurant on the block.
author: jennifer m.

description: Food came fast and was delicious. Service was abrupt. There was a long line to get in, but this went quickly. Despite being put off from some recent yelp reviews, we were quite pleased.
author: Tim H.

description:
Okay so i HATE chinese food.

This place made me a believer. We came here last weekend and I was hessitant to go. But after a persistant sister we got in and got seated.

service sucks
so does the size of the place

doesnt matter in this case though.
totally worth all the bad stuff.

we had the orange chicken
rice
house noodles
and eggplant.

AMAZING!

eggplant was to die for.i will deff go back.

its missing a star cause this place was too small.
author: Fatte N.

description: One great dinner place had pot stickers had sesame chicken and a beef dish with string beans all were top notch made places in Chicago look bad. I would highly tell everyone to go here. I can here on a recommendation from a friend who was here 2 years ago. Place is a top place to go.
author: Herbert S.

description: Lovely place, comfortable seating. I had a view of the street. Just what I like. The chicken Nanking and the pepper shrimp with mushrooms was amazing.  Good price, tasty food.
author: Ash P.

description: Disappointed. If you're looking for true Chinese food, don't come here. The waiters were not very welcoming. It was very American, the dishes were unusually sweet, and lacked the flavors of true Asian cuisine. I had a friend who came here years ago, and recommended it, said the dishes were very Chinese, and so I came here. I realized that they used to be a real Chinese restaurant, but after it got popular, it started to change their style to American-Chinese food. It lost its authenticity, and even as American-Chinese it wasn't even that great, not going back. I'd rather go to Panda Express. Not happy.
author: Emma P.

description:
My fiancee told me she heard this was one of the best Chinese places in the city. After eating here, I can only conclude that the people she talked to must not be Chinese.

To me, the food was only so-so. It was also very Americanized. We ordered the sesame chicken (recommended by everyone on Yelp), along with a small order of the eggplant. I actually thought the eggplant was pretty tasty and tender, but the chicken just didn't taste like anything you'd expect from an authentic Chinese food place. It was way too sweet and didn't have any kick to it.

If I wanted Americanized Chinese food, I would much rather prefer Panda Express (I'm dead serious) than this place.

The only thing authentic about this place was the service. That is to say, it wasn't very good; as in, they don't really care about service. When they brought your plates around, they would just drop them on your table instead of setting them down gently.

I think tourists like this place because it's right between North Beach and Chinatown; it's convenient. It's certainly not that good.
author: John C.

description: Best Chinese in SF. Super authentic and reasonably priced. Service isn't spectacular, but I'd guess it's because they're normally pretty busy. Let them order for you--they're won't steer you wrong.
author: Caitlin B.

description:
Worst place ever!
The food is ok but what a terrible service. The waiter brings you the bill when you are in the middle of the main course. He cleans the table when you're still drinking your glass of wine. If you like fast foods, this place is for you.
So ok, people were waiting outside for tables, but come on, you cannot kick people out like that.
author: Emilie P.

description: Best Chinese-American food I've ever had. I love the fact that you can walk in and just tell them what you don't want, and the waiter'll take care of things from there. No idea what we had: a meat-filled dumpling, a crunchy-ish chicken, a tasty beef, but it was all delicious. The blooming flower tea is really something special: hubby's bloom was impressive (see photo)! I remember visiting this place back in the 1990s, and it was no more than a narrow stretch of white paint, cracked linoleum, and not much else. Well, they've really upped the ante aesthetically, doubling the size and adding some ambiance; unfortunately this means that the food is no longer the bargain that it once was. But it is still an amazing dining experience, even if our food ended up costing upwards of $70 with tip. I'd highly recommend stopping in, enjoying getting to know your fellow man at the semi-communal tables, giving yourself over to the expertise of your waiter, and savoring the entire experience.
author: Brittany B.

description: House of Nanking! Love this place! The food here is Amazing you can't go wrong with any of the dishes! I feel so good after I eat here and can't wait for the next visit. The place is a little cramped but it doesn't matter because the food is so good! Also the service if that's what you want to call it doesn't really exist, but whatever I don't come to be pampered or treated nicely.... I came to eat damn it and the food here is the mad note! I suggest trying it at least once.
author: Stephen B.

description: Yum! In terms of Chinese food, this is my favorite thus far.  The staff can come off as rude as they are non-nonsense and need to flip the tables fast in order to accomodate everyone who is lined up outside, but the vegetarian options are very very tasty.
author: Vanessa L.

description: I used to love this place - I only lived a mile away and was always glad to take the walk. On my recent visit, the staff was still rude and wanted to get my wife and I out of there asap - which was o.k. because you come to expect this here. What I did not expect was the burnt mushrooms, the cold potstickers, and a dish they forgot to serve us but not bill us for. What a shame - it used to be so good and now - shameful.
author: Michael C.

description:
After enjoying a happy hour drink in the financial district on a Monday night, my group was headed up to North Beach for some dinner when we passed House of Nanking with NO LINE! I had been wanting to try this spot for a while but have been deterred by the line. 

We had a great time. The portions are perfect for sharing. Our favorite orders were the sesame chicken with delicious sweet potatoes on the side and the crispy (not overly greasy) pot stickers. 

The table next to us had some sort of button mushroom side dish that looked excellent and I meant to add it to our meal, but by the time the food came out we had so much eating to do that I knew we wanted nothing to do with another dish. 

The bill for 4 was really not that bad. The waitresses aren't going to win any awards for being chatty and friendly, but they are efficient and helpful.
author: Meagan C.

description:
You can imagine the surprise of the sweet Midwest couple behind us in line when the host seated us all together at one table. They giggled nervously at the thought of sitting next to another duo- current San Francisco residents to say the last- ordered a drink, then peaced out.

They were definitely missing out! I can see why the crowds and blunt service may turn some off (I'm from Michigan, and we seem to be more about about warm fuzzies and personal space, especially since half the year we're stuck alone in our cars due to in construction traffic)... however, they totally missed out.

The Sesame chicken seems to be what House of Nanking is known best for, and it's some of the best I have had. We also shared some shrimp lo mein as well- also superb. Top it off with some seemingly mystery wine, and we have a party. It's well worth the line, and the company is just as great as the food.
author: Kristin F.

description: Let me start off by saying if I could give this place negative stars I would. The service there was horrific. For a split second we all thought we were at dicks in Las Vegas because of how rude they were to us. They might has well hand out dunce hats when you walk in. We walked in and they looked annoyed that we were there. They put us at a table that still had food on it. Gave us menus, asked what we wanted to drink and what we wanted to eat all in one go. Beers were warm, got our appetizers after our entrées but the best part was when we got our check. We paid and I put down the tip. We hadn't even left when he comes up to our table and grabs the money and the receipt, looks at it and has the nerve to argue with us for more of a tip. When we said no and got up he yelled something to his coworkers. The food wasn't even worth the terrible service.
author: Aragon J.

description: Damn I love this place and I miss it like a girl you caught a glimpse of and can't shake her out of your mind.
author: Jin J.

description:
I found out about this place from watching a travel episode.

I wasn't expecting a little more authentic chinese food. The service was okay, I felt like I was being rushed to order and finish eating. The price is reasonable  but can be a little cheaper
author: SHARON L.

description: Mediocre at best. Flavorless, ill-prepared, everything deep fried, even Potstickers. Yuck.
author: Amy P.

description:
I love this place.  I was taken here for a business lunch some years ago and was told it was whacky.  

My friend said "Watch I'll order a Tsing Tsao beer and they'll bring it to me.  The I'll ask for another and they'll bring me another brand and when I complain they'll say "Same thing!  Same thing!"  

It went down just like that.  Quite funny.  The scallops rule as well as their signature chicken dish.  Big lines at times.  Beware.  

World famous to some degree.  A piece of San Francisco history.

I don't believe they take credit cards
author: Kevin D.

description:
I don't know what happened three years ago when I came here for the first time, but it was not good first impression. I never came back, and never thought of it either. 

But tonight I am feeling like Chinese food, and standing at Columbus left me with not many options. So here comes another try...........

This time, I loved it! One thing I hate about some other Chinese restaurants is that... everything taste the same. But here, everything I had is tasty in its own way. The interesting thing is that you can tell the server what you like, and he/she would order everything for you. Tonight we chose two items, and let our server picked the other two. Her picks were my favorite among everything else.

First starts with fish soup... a little hot and sour with basil leaves, cilantro, onion, and fried fish, and wonton. Then comes the spicy chicken with dried chilli and string beans. DELISH! We also had the pan fry fish with garlic and mushrooms. The only thing that I didn't care was the five spiced pork ribs. 

Service is still the typical Chines place. I didn't understand the line, and I still don't understand. I think this place is a little overhyped and overpriced. But I look around the diners around me and I understood why. Will come back again, and make sure it's early evening, 'cause I don't wanna wait!
author: Marlis T.

description: over rated.. unfriendly staff bordering on just plain rude.. pot stickers were hard and had bad sauce, tasteless, won ton soup terrible, pepper/salt shrimp very fishy. could not eat..
author: Michael D.

description: Recommended by a friend. Says it's Americanized Chinese food. We had the chef's family special; they pick out what to make you. We had sesame chicken, beef, fish and some other assortments. All good. I would def. say it's Americanized, but that doesn't mean it's not good. The added Americanized flavor actually enhanced the traditional Chinese taste. Thumbs up.
author: Scott N.

description: One of the best meals I had in San Francisco. Walking through Chinatown I was constantly bombarded by restaurant workers shoving out fliers for various Chinese places and it would have been easy to get sucked in without the proper heads up. But just the line to get in this place alone should be taken as a sign - it's very good (and very popular as well apparently). The inside is nothing to speak of and seating arrangements are at long tables where my friends and I were placed next to a random uppity couple who didn't seem to be enjoying themselves (a word to the wise, don't come in here with an attitude).The food was phenomenal! I had the crispy noodle tower, a dish rarely found on the east coast...the sauce was mouthwateringly delicious! I can't wait to come back just for this food. I only held back from a full five star rating because we were made to feel kind of rushed, they don't seem to place much emphasis on hospitality here, even getting a pair of chopsticks to eat with was a little difficult to flag a server down for. The meal was absolutely good enough to outshine that however; I couldn't get enough!
author: Joey P.

description: I tried House of Nanking my last visit to San Fran and left speechless! I had never tried real authentic Chinese food and wow this place blew me away! The place isn't set up in some fancy way but it has so much character! I recommend their Blossom Tea and Sesame Chicken.. but anything you try will be amazing! Also the service is great, even with their broken English the servers are so attentive and nice! Can't wait to go back to SF to eat at House of Nanking again :)
author: Diana A.

description:
I've been going to House of Nanking since the mid 90s and have never experienced such a low.

Avoid the house noodles:
bland boring and too fucking expensive.

Fang's Garlic Fish was mushy, undercooked and not as described in the menu. 

Pot stickers were to die for on past visits but today they were overcooked...kinda like pork samosas. BOOTY!!!

Won ton soup was tasty and probably prevented me from sending it back and refusing to pay but also had a crudely cut  ass of an onion in it. Who wants to see an inedible piece of barely cooked onion bottom their the soup? Not me!

Also, the employees were seated in the dining room, chowing down on take out from another chinese place. How clowning is that? Their pigs feet did look better than my pot stickers...

My meal was 45 dollars and filled with disappointment in every course. 

Everyone else's food looked better than mine.
Next time I will just say chicken or beef and let the cook decide.  
BOOOOOOOO

I have loved House of Nanking in the past so I'll be back and it better be good next time because it was awful today.

Maybe they took the good cooks to Fang's new place on Howard...
I WANT A REFUND!!!
author: Charles F.

description:
Years ago our friends in SF (who now live in NY) introduced us to House of Nanking.  Didn't know what to expect for such a small 'hole-in-the-wall' type of place, but often to my utter amazement, these places are the best food joints you can get for your money.

Food was superb and non-fussy, service was okay, sure a little grumpy, but so the hell what....everyone says the service sucks, but people are WAY too sensitive these days.  Seriously.  Travel to parts of Asia and you'll experience a similar thing...open your eyes, your heart and get over it!

Here's a piece of advice: don't be fussy, and don't be a primadonna.  Order your food, eat it, enjoy it, pay then go.  Food is great, your belly is full, be happy and roll home.
author: Isao K.

description:
OMG!! This is the best Chinese I've ever had. Salivating as I sit in MD and think of ways to get back to San Fran. So glad we went. Sweet and sour soup was great. Hubby loved light freshness of shrimp cakes. The sesame chicken was AMAZING. And we topped it off with the green beans! They were right-lot of food for 2 people but we went to town anyways and so glad did.
-did feel slightly rushed and had to ask for some things but no biggie. The star of the show was the food and it shined:)
author: Tiffany R.

description: The wonton soup is UNREAL. They make it with coconut milk and crispy rice...it's sooooo amazing!!!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
When a place has 1300 reviews, you know you aren't going to have anything new to say.

I have been going to House Of Nanking for about 15 years now, and it seldom disappoints.  If you happen to have the owner as your waiter, the best meal is the one he picks for you.  If you are choosing for yourself, there are a couple of things not to miss:

Fried Potstickers (the peanut sauce is fantastic)
Nanking Chicken (don't miss the sweet potatoes)
Crispy Shrimp (perfect flavor, perfectly cooked)

I could eat those as my daily diet for years without losing my taste for them.  At this place it isn't all about the meat.  The treatment of the veggies in the dish are as important as the chicken or shrimp that is the centerpiece.

Don't worry that there is a line, it is worth the wait.  Try to get them to bring you a beer while you wait (they used  to).

You will be elbow to elbow with other people in the restaraunt, that's just the way they do it - share a dish and make a friend.

The place has doubled in size over the years, which has led to a slight lowering of speedy service and sharing your rice with your neighbors, but the flavors have remained the same, and that's what I go there for.
author: B-rye H.

description:
They have remodeled since the last time I was here. The prices of the food has gone up slightly, and the portions have been reduced significantly(they use much smaller plates now).    They used to have a line every night of the week.  But tonight they had some empty tables during the dinner rush hour!

The sesame chicken is not as good anymore--their heavy sauce used to taste so good but now It is too salty and the yams are cut thinner and tastes like its deep fried.  I would not recommend this place for the price anymore.

And their service sucked!  Three wait staff were standing around talking and looking straight at me but when I waved at them to come over, they just ignored me.
author: C t.

description:
Cash Only?  I don't think so.

Been coming here for years and love it. My only reason for writing the review is because I keep see all the cash only comments.  Been using a Visa here for years and just paid the same way not 2 hours ago.
author: Michelle J.

description: Yum. We've been here at least 6 times now. We usually have to wait in the line, but it is worth it. If you don't know what you want to order, they will decide for you and bring out dishes until you are stuffed. I didn't love the honey shrimp as much as I should for the price. There is a beef and bok choy dish that's not on the menu but it is delicious. Ask for it. The sesame chicken is their signature, so are the onion cakes. I love everything. It's the kind of Chinese food that you can eat a lot of without going home feeling like a piece of lead is in your stomach. I will come here a million more times, if the fates allow. Yeah, the service is pushy but you would be too if you were so awesome.
author: Halley S.

description: My experience is pretty much the same as other yelpers described: no order required. The owner took away our menu and asked us to trust him. We didn't get the sesame chicken that everyone talked about. We got a duck dish and a soup with fish, wonton, and noodle in it. Very tasty food. If you always have difficulty in choosing what to order at a restaurant, this is the place to go. Definitely not for the control-freaks.
author: Shawn Y.

description:
I've made it a point to eat at House of Nanking every time I visit San Francisco over the years and I was sorely disappointed on this last visit.

The menu was smaller and more expensive. The owner was not present and talking to customers this time around. Service was generally disinterested. The sesame chicken was gummy and was of Panda Express quality. 

It has the makings of becoming a real tourist trap.
author: Adam B.

description:
This is probably one of the most overrated Chinese food restuarant in the history of Chinatown. And I stand by that statement anyday. They can fool the tourist from Europe or that lady with a camera around her neck from South Dakota, but you cannot fool me!! This place is absolutely an insult to Chinese food. I have 3 letters for you... M.S.G. 

I would even go as far as saying their food is fraud. Used to come here for lunch when i worked over at the transamerica building. There would be a long line of tourist thinking they are eating authentic chinese food. Everything here is salty. If I am ever at war with my Kidney, I would come here to finish the job. 

We tried their fried calamari and it tasted like MSG. We had their mongolian beef. It tasted like MSG.. we had their spicy prawns.. guess what it tasted like.. MSG!!! This is a disappointment all the way around. I feel sad for all the other yelpers that had their taste buds fool. This place is also quite dirty. Their fancy plates and awards from the 70s do not make their food better.

I mean, there's a reason why there's no chinese people eating at this "chinese restuarant." Because its not chinese food. it is as Mexican as a burrito and as japanese as a california roll!
author: Charlie W.

description:
Great service, Great Food, Great Atmosphere(Not too loud, not too quite, just right)

We ordered the Famous Sesame Chicken, Lettuce Wraps w/ Shrimp, and Calamari. There is a reason the sesame chicken is famous...yummm! Lettuce wraps had some nice veggies with them and a tasty light dressing. The calamari weren't out of this world, but a good appetizer.

Also very cool they take AMEX...not many hole in the walls these days feel like they need to take CCs.
author: Jorge G.

description:
This is not a bad place to have a meal. The food is good & the waitress was feisty.

 The only drawback,  you have to share the tables with strangers.....
author: A. B.

description:
It all depends on what you're looking for.

If you're craving dishes with a lot of dense flavor, HoN is for you. 

If you're seeking more traditional Chinese flavors, HoN is perhaps not the place.

We had the popular Sesame Chicken ~ crispy chicken with yams (or is it sweet potato?) - I enjoyed it.

We also had the 'Tower of Scallops' on top of eggplant - I think this is a special appetizer. It was also good, but I'd say falsely named. It wasn't a tower in my book.

Very popular tourist destination. Expect a line. I noticed they have remodeled from my initial visit a few years back. It's now a tad upscale with dark wood, still shoulder-to-shoulder seating.
author: Cathy K.

description:
I've never tried this place, but one day my coworker and I had tried to yelp for a place in the fidi, and this was the only thing that came up on her phone. 

The sesame chicken was SOOOO GOOOD. The other stuff could be a bit better though. The rice was too chunky. I really wanted to try the onion pancake, but then I realized there was too many dishes we had ordered already. 

The restaurant was PACKED though. When I looked around, it wasn't a average Chinese restaurant, because everyone around me was NOT of Asian race except for my friend and I, the workers, and possibly one - two tables. (NOT that it mattered, and I don't mean to point out the obvious) But I noticed that the taste of this "House of Nanking" was to cater to tourists...majority people in here were tourists. 

Don't get me wrong, it wasn't bad, but I did feel that it tasted different from all of the other place's I've been too that sold some of the dishes I had that day. This Chinese-fusion place is pretty popular though. 

I'd def recommend the Sesame Chicken! 

happy eating! :)
author: Liberty C.

description: Everyone needs to dine here at least once in their life. The place is one-of-a-kind for over-the-top rudeness. It's like they had planned out a skit and executed it in front of their customers. It was so bad that I can only remember it with fond memories and I'm glad I had the chance to experience it.
author: Ziad N.

description:
H of N is a very popular city spot, so expect to wait for a table.  If you observe the countless dining-hopefuls loitering outside & clogging the sidewalk, no doubt you'll hear the disgruntled complaints of some hungry hungry hippos. Tom Petty put it well when he said, "the waiting is the hardest part" but I found that given this place's prime location, it doesn't have to be.

My party of 5 put our name's in on a Friday night and were told the wait could be over an hour. Bitchin'! That gave us at least 60 minutes to hit up as many surrounding watering holes as possible before dinner. We walked up to Vesuvio's (Columbus @ Broadway) grabbed drinks and made "amici" with some Italian tourists. Grabbed another beer at Spec's across the street, then made our way back down to Francis Ford Coppola's haunt Cafe Zoetrope where we sat at the bar and split a bottle of wine in full view of our buddy Nanking's House. Right on time for our open table, we staggered back across Kearny for some great cuisine after working up an admittedly more-than-buzzed appetite.

When life gives you lemons, make lemonade. When Nanking bars your entry - makeshift bar crawl!
author: Kitty C.

description: Okay I had no idea about this place and what a big deal it was...Some family was in town so I drove in to meet them- and someone had recommended this place to them. Luckily yelp saved the day- I read someone's review about telling them it was your first time, and the waiter just started bringing us a bunch of amazing dishes; One of my cousins who was with us was vegetarian so he accommodated that as well. We also got our food much faster by not ordering off the menu- but maybe this isn't for everyone. I'd love to come back.
author: Julie H.

description: I love this place. Ordered the wonton soup to go last week and it was SO good! Going back today for sizzling rice soup. YUM.
author: Holly R.

description:
The Re.net is on the way.. March 5th for lunch.  Order more noodles...

Now really.  I have been here before with guests from out of town but usually shy away from places in the city with lines.   My experience before involved a really good...really LARGE plate of noodles with a friend from Paris.  She had never seen such a thing.   The sauces on the dishes I had were terrific, which is what I base my Asian food critiques by and I'm looking forward to giving the House another shot soon.  Cheers :)

3/6/08 addendum:  We had lunch for 6 here yesterday.  11:30am. Great time to go, the line formed shortly thereafter.  My friend Jeff said to let the owner order.  (at least I thought he was the owner based on the framed pic above our table with Sean Penn)  They graciously took care of us completely bringing out appetizers, soup, and I think a variety of 4 or 5 different dishes that knocked us out.  I now would have to say that I will return with out-of town guest or not.   Thanks for lunch Jeff.
author: Brad C.

description: I work for a major airline and have frequent SFO layovers. We stay near Chinatown so there are obviously a ton of restaurants to choose from. I tried this restaurant a few months ago and was thoroughly disappointed. Today, I decided to give it one last chance in hopes that I would be impressed. That was not the case. Rude staff, bland food and cramped seating was enough to discourage me from EVER returning here. The menu said "world famous sesame chicken". Perhaps it's famous for being over-fried and bland.
author: JR G.

description: Visited this great restaurant on the outskirts of Chinatown while traveling in San Fran. Great food and reasonable prices. The beef that came with the pancakes was melt in your mouth tender. The staff made sure we were enjoying our food and wanted us to have a good experience.
author: Jackson C.

description: when they remodeled and enlarged the place, for some strange reason they took a few of their best popular dishes OFF the menu. i had asked the owner why, and he smiled and shrugged his shoulders - i have never been back since that one visit after the remodel - before that i was a regular customer - no need to go here now, plenty of other places to discover around this city - especially if you're willing to check out sunset and richmond areas.
author: Misa A.

description: Fresh veggies, well-prepared, authentic Chinese food. Gets crowded and servers rush around so ambience feels a bit hectic and cramped, bc they're so popular.
author: Christina V.

description:
Every time I make a visit to the city i make sure to stop by this amazingly authentic restaurant! Each time have ever gone to dine at the House of Nanking the server always orders for us. It must be some type of thing that they do. At first I was reluctant and wanted to order for myself, ut after being as many times as I have I think it only adds to the experience and allows for me to try new things!

This last time I went I had the seafood soup to start and my goodness!! It was the best!!! This place is a must if you are ever in China Town!!
author: Todd R.

description:
Yummy fish and wonton soup. Having said that, the waitress strongly suggested this soup which came out to 25 bucks! Whoa! I don't think that was necessary at all. Also, hmmm... MSG!!!!! I left this place with my allergies and breathing difficulties. Sigh, I used to love this place so much. 

I will give this another try someday.
author: Eva Y.

description: the food is great hence meriting 4 starts. only problem is that they operate like a production line and very subtly try to push you out of the restaurant as fast as possible. service was poor and only available for the check so I docked them a star sorry!
author: andrew c.

description: We have been coming here since the late '80s and love their food even though the service is on the rough side.  Their spicy wor dumpling soup is absolutely amazing even at $7. We shared an order for dinner and the next day we each wanted our own for lunch.  The guy said to order one and share.  No thank you.  But what he delivered were smaller bowls than the night before but still charged $7 each.  We also asked for two orders to go to take back to Sacramento. What we got was one order in two small containers, but they charged for two orders.  Basically we paid $35 for $21 worth of soup.  Service and cost aside, the food is worth it.
author: Janet R.

description: I judge chinese restaurants based off of hot and sour soup.  This bar non is the best I have ever had.  For the main dish I had the calamari which was also excellent.  If your in chinatown SF then put this on your to do list.
author: Caleb R.

description:
Friends wanted to take me to chinese food in Chinatown and had a little bit of a concern - the line was long. The place next door had no line, and one of the party checked her favorite place around the corner and there was no line. "Trust me", I said," It's worth it."

The line moved quickly but be warned - there is usually a line for dinner. I had the sesame chicken, egg rolls and pot stickers. From the first bite they were thanking me for convincing them to stay in line. dinner even got kind of expensive, but they said it was worth both the wait and the bill. 

So keep that in mind if you find waiting in the line daunting! Stick it out! It's worth it! 

PS I also reviewed sister restaurant Fang, just as good. Not a line there when I went!
author: Darren M.

description: It's cramped and busy but the food is phenomenal.  The service is hectic but friendly and efficient.  Be warned, there is almost always a line down the sidewalk and they will move you to make room for larger parties.  The draw here is the food so don't bother coming here if you're the kind of person who needs their ass kissed by their server, you will only be disappointed.  If you want to eat some crazy delicious food in a crazy atmosphere, this is the place for you.  My only nitpick, and the only thing that kept me from giving five stars, is that when you add chicken to a noodle dish the chicken is a little on the dry side.  But that doesn't stop me from ordering it because it's still damn tasty.
author: Blevins L.

description: 1st time and it was recommend by a friend.  It is a very limited space, there was even a line when we got there.  When the waiter found out it was our groups 1st time he took our menus & said he would bring us good stuff.  We ended up getting a wide variety of dished and all were great!  The calimari was not that fried and tender/not chewy!  The best! Also the hot tea was perfect on a cool day and pretty!
author: Megan E.

description:
1300 reviews. Nice job mr. Nanking.

All I gotta say is the seed to flower green tea was pretty gnarly to watch, the sesame chicken was awesome, and who doesn't dig a decently clean yet solid food Chinese restaurant?
author: Ronnie G.

description: I ate here for lunch, it wasn't too busy. I tried the potstickers with peanut sauce they were ok. They seemed deep fried which is weird... I am a potsticker aficionado I order them everywhere I can say this was just ok. The sesame chicken was too saucy and sweet and all dark meat. If I go again, I'll try something else. I'm not overly impressed, I don't see why people wait in line for this. I will only go again if my fiancé  wants to try the strangely famous house of Nanking.
author: Courtney M.

description: Food was just ok. It was certainly not worth the wait and complete lack of service. Would not go back.
author: Jon K.

description: I am really torn between a 4 and a five star - but, I think I finally settled for a 4 for now at least.  The food is always awesome.  My favorites are: The always terrific sesame chicken, the yummalicious pork egg rolls and the tea that blossoms as a flower as it seeps.  The place reminds me of a traditional chinese restaurant in China with it's dim lighting and "rude" (for the lack of better word) servers - see, it's not like, it's ill-intentioned - that's just their culture/tradition, I think.  This is what I come to expect when I go to Nanking and I really wouldn't trade it for a better service as it might make me feel out of place all of a sudden.  If I want great service and great non chinese food, there's always Boulevard or Gary Danko.
author: Erika S.

description:
had dinner last night with 5 adults 2 children ordered sizzling rice soup which was watery.  Ordered 6 other dishes Nan King meat and chicken, egg plant, green beans pot stickers,calamari (barely enough for one person) very greasy.  sauces had no flavour.  Complained about soup waitress comment was you ordered it!  Said they added coffeemate so there was no milk..hard to believe but if you tasted it who knows.
They have big reputation with tourist...There are so many great Chinese places to eat
dont waste your time or money.  Gave them $150 cash no thank you just give me the money.
author: stephen b.

description: Worst food and service I ever had. I have tried many Chinese restaurants, but this one food was very oily and tasteless. We ordered fried rice and we had to wait for almost 1 hour for it. We were done with our fish and didn't receive our rice. When we requested the server, We were told rudely, chef is little slow and they have only 1 person cooking for everyone.... Kitchen was very small and didn't look clean ....
author: Mary T.

description:
We ate at this place this past weekend and I think it is the best chinese food I have ever had.  The waitress was not that friendly and there was a line to get in.  A little cramped inside or I would have given 5 stars.  The food was 5 stars, but the wait and confined space was 4 stars.  I also had the green tea that had a bulb at the bottom of the cup and bulb ends up blossoming into a flower in the cup.  Very cool and the hot tea was good on a cold day.  

The hotel recommended the restaurant.  Very good.
author: Sarah N.

description: The food was great but we came after 6pm and the attitude of the staff was terrible. The waiter was in such of a hurry at all the times.
author: Victor M.

description: Tonight House of Nanking was a busy place but staff manages to serve some very good food in record time.  Tofu and black bean sauce was super.  Even though they were busy, staff managed to make me feel welcome.
author: Philip S.

description: The food and service was great and quick.  I ordered the Chicken Pad Thai.  It was a huge dish filled with noodles and fresh vegetables.  For dessert I ordered the fried bananas.  They were great!  I would recommend coming here anytime.  They are open late and they serve pretty quick.  ENJOY!
author: Kenric S.

description: Amazing pot stickers with peanut butter sauce and rice was amazing! Super friendly and seemed pretty popular among locals and tourists alike!
author: Alyssa D.

description: I used to love this place 10 years ago.  Not one of our 4 dishes was yummy. I'll never go back
author: Jonathan W.

description:
The service here SUCKS! We got seated in a corner where my fat ass had to squeeze through to get to my seat and had to wait for almost twenty minutes for our waitress to take our order. The food though is pretty good. Not your typical Chinese food. More like a Chinese/American fusion. Their pot stickers are very delicious as well as their specialty sesame seed chicken. Fried rice though isn't really fried rice, it tastes more like steamed rice with soy sauce, still good though. Only reason this place doesn't get a higher rating is the service was awful. 

I recommend East Lake Seafood Restaurant in San Jose. Very nomish.
author: John V.

description:
I just can't wrap my mind around it.  I've been coming to this gem of a place for some epic and tasty chinese cuisine for years.  Never noteworthy for service, the turnaround time was sick, and the food delectable.  Until today...

After tearing through the onion cakes with a peanut sauce, three quarters of our fried rice, and almost our entire Chicken Nanking...we met our little friend.  Nestled in the fried rice like sweet baby jesu on a bed of hay, and undoubtably as  flavorful and robust as the surrounding constituents, a COCKROACH.  The girlie saw it first, immediately turned her head and began fitfully dry heaving....anndd up and out of the restaraunt.  Im left to consider whether or not she might be pregnant, or perhaps my occasional flatulence at the table was unsettling for her...but then I glanced down and saw what the ruckus was all about.  I brought the detritus to the traditionally cantankerous staff.  We usually accept their poopy pants disposition in leiu of high quality cuisine, but today...I couldn't find the space.  After some significant deliberation and cantonese banter, it was determined that they would change their abusive disposition to only moderately offensive, and remove 'said' rice from the bill.  After she lost her lunch, she lost her restraint, and stated that 'We won't paying for anything within a ten foot proximity to the cockroach fried rice'  and furiously departed the restaurant.  In the fury of departure, we left my messenger bag at the table... and after retrieving it, I am left with a latent fear that some of the cockroaches made it into my messenger bag to colonize our apartment. God help us and save us from the beasts. Take a look at photo 92 and 93!
author: Matthew M.

description: Stopped in around 6 and great timing (no wait when we got there but line developed while eating). It's a small place and the tables & chairs are super close to each other (get friendly with your co-diners!). Tried the shrimp packets & potstickers to start with (thanks to the waitress who let us split the two so we got to try both). Went with the fried rice and the sesame chicken for entrees (we were going to get a noodle dish & the fried rice but the waitress steered us to a non noodle/rice dish). My favorite part of the meal was the sweet potatoes that were with the chicken - delicious! Not the best chinese food i have ever had - but quite tasty.
author: Karen S.

description:
You need to get past the rude service...I'm still keeping an open mind and hoping that the challenges in service are due to cultural differences

Anyways,
I had to go there for round two before I wrote this review to try other items on the menu.

To start, I would recommend the fried calamari (the menu actually says "recommended')
The house noodles won't let you down. These pack a powerful and tasty garlic dose onto your pallet.
The sesame chicken was a bit on the heavy side and a little too much on the sweet side.
The lettuce wraps are unique and delicious.

Oh yeah, don't come here expecting typical chinese. Bring an open mind and stomach and see the difference.

Oh yeah, this second time they were not accepting credit cards :(
author: Raul H.

description: Definitely a fan of the House of Nanking although it's super crowded and the service is usually a little strange I love some of the dishes so much that it doesn't really matter. My absolute favorite is the eggplant, and though I know there is better Hunan food out there to try chances are I will keep returning to House of Nanking as it's kind of a San Francisco tradition for my family at this point.
author: Guenn J.

description:
On business again in SF and happen to be staying at the Hilton Chinatown ( they call it the Financial District, but lets get real, people).

Was last here 3 or 4 years ago and, basically, got the bums rush out thedoor at the end of the meal.  Having been to HoN in it glory days in he early 90s, that experience was not so satisfying.

No lunch plans today, so after a quick perusal through City Lights Books, I popped in for some Sesame Chicken.  All in all, it was "fine", but nothing to write home about.  I went around 2 pm and there wasnt a wait.  Got in and out quickly, but no bums rush this time.   


Do I need to go again?  Probably not ...prices seem a bit steeper than I recall and I can get just as good or better elsewhere.

Might try Chef Jias next door ....it was just as busy and looked to be a good del cheaper by about 1/2 for the 6 buck lunch special.
author: Paul W.

description: The food tasted quite bad and I felt quite sick after.  I would go to another place that doesn't have msg.
author: Vitaly W.

description: Everything was way too salty, plus my husband received both his appetizer and his entree so far ahead of mine that he had already completely finished his entire meal 15 minutes before my meal even came! Not impressed, will not repeat.
author: Rachael T.

description:
In summary: OVER HYPED & OVER PRICED.

To me, the food in an average-good Chinese restaurant is not fancy but of good quality and taste--and the prices are reasonable.  Yes, price( as well as quality)  is my basis for evaluating the restaurant.

I was quite happy to try this restaurant because I had heard raves about it (from Caucasians, actually).

Just because the food is "different" (even"authentic") & "delicious" doesn't mean the prices need to be this high.  A base of soysauce, sugar, garlic, vinegar, & chili peppers with maybe fermented black beans thrown in is no big deal.  Fresh?  well that's a minimum  expectation in San Francisco.  The portions here aren't overly generous  (for the price).

A quite viscous seafood soup with a fried fish & 5 won tons thrown in was wierd.  And $24.  Skip the blossoming Flower Tea @ $3 ea.  i wasn't impressed.  A pot ot tea to share would've done just fine.  Or order beer.  Their signature onion cake was overwhelmed by a sweet peanut sauce.  No, not good.  Their fried calamari did not show any hint of "fried", much less "crispy".  It was unremarkable!  Three other dishes and rice completed our lunch.  (Total bill for 5 diners including tip was about $150).

My guests actually enjoyed the food.  But then, they're from the mid-West and don't know  the difference with Chinese food.  And didn't see the bill.
author: Vera P.

description: excellent selection of chinese dishes from a variety of regions, good service.
author: Cymba C.

description: My girlfriend and I hit up this place after a bunch of rave reviews from friends. Being from out of town (Vancouver, BC) we figured this place would be a great bet. We ordered an appetizer, chow mein and sesame chicken. We were actually surprised that the portions were so small. It was tasty but we aren't big eaters and the bill was $36. I wasnt even full. I don't think the value was there. Tons of places back home that have more quality and more value overall.
author: Tyson M.

description:
There was a line when I got here. Very crowded and tight inside so you're sitting side by side with other groups. The person who sat us forgot to give us menus and it took us a while to get someone's attention for some menus.

Tofu with Black Bean Sauce - the black bean sauce was amazing! I don't know what more I can say to describe its awesomeness. Tofu was soft and yummy when drenched in the amazing black bean sauce!

Honey Beef - We couldn't decide on a fourth dish so the waitress recommended we get this. It's like honey walnut shrimp but with beef and no walnuts... The beef was very tender and thick. The sauce was amazing and rich. It came on a bed of bok choy.

Calamari - I believe this was called "Melt in Your Mouth Calamari" and it's true! It was amazingly soft and practically melts in your mouth. It wasn't over-covered in batter either. The sauce was citrus-y and yummy but eat the calamari quickly cause it slowly gets soggy if you leave it in the sauce too long.

Sesame Chicken - slightly crispy, yummy sauce, came with sweet potatoes which went well with the chicken.

Fruit Tea - good. not the best tea I've had but it's up there. I'm going to try the blossoming tea next time cause it looked interesting with a flower at the bottom.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
I've been here a number of times.  I find it to be very consistent.  It is Chinese food but not your corner restaurant traditional Chinese food.

What's to like?
1.  Nanking Sesame Chicken - spicy, tasty, tender, and served with very good sweet potatoes that are not like any sweet potatoes I've had before.
2.  Calamari with lemon sauce.  Always tender!
3.  Beef with green beans - mmm, mmm, yummy.
4.  Everything else I've ever ordered there.
5.  Once you are seated, quick service.

What's not to like?
1.  Very busy and there can be quite the lineup.

Overall, I love this place.  The food is worth the wait.  I also like the open feel of the room.
author: Mark D.

description:
I frequent Nan King every time I visit the lovely SF. Though the interior doesn't quite match the explosive goodness of this Chinese restaurant, it's a must try. It's not your traditional Chinese food - a la from the country (ick!).  I've tried almost everything on the menu and every single dish is full of flavor, delish and mouthwatering. I always order the "Melts in your mouth lemon calamari" dish - a MUST HAVE!

Family style indeed, so it's nice for big groups. Nan King boosts a warm atmosphere - nook like. Great food and doesn't break the bank! Service is....mediocre.
author: Thao L.

description:
Even though it was crowded and people were waiting on the street to be seated, neither the food nor the service was near to satisfactory. After it took forever until we could order, they finally brought us one of the entrées, but no rice, nor the other entrée. We asked for the rest until we got some rice after 10 minutes (when the plate was already cold), and the second arrived again 10 minutes later (when also the rice was cold meanwhile).

We ordered sesame chicken (which was good, but nothing more), and melting calamari (which were definitely way overpriced for what it was). The couple next to us asked the waiter to take care of them, but he couldn't tell them the name of the dishes he served them each time. 

All together a really disappointing, annoying and far too expensive experience - nothing to recommend!
author: Kathrin S.

description: Delicious food! I wouldn't call it Chinese food, but all of the dishes we ordered were yummy. I highly recommend the onion pancake and sesame chicken. Service is basically nonexistent and you are squished at tables with strangers, but it's worth it for the food. Fortunately, there wasn't a long wait when we were there. We went for lunch so I would recommend going earlier in theft to avoid the crazy wait.
author: Nicole P.

description: Good food in the heart of Chinatown.  Like other reviewers mentioned, the sesame chicken is delicious.  We arrived right when it opened, so we didn't have any problems getting a table.  My only complaint is that it felt very touristy - the crowd was entirely white, non San Franciscians.
author: Lauren P.

description:
PLEASE DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME! I've spent many weekends in San Francisco lately, and according to 2 different tour bus drivers and 1 tourist on the street, I was told that I HAD to try this place for the "best Chinese food in San Fran"....I should have known something was up because both drivers(same company) mentioned the same restaurants in town.
The staff could definitely use some anger management training, we (approximately 15 people waiting in line outside) were basically yelled at by a rude little waitress asking "How many?", then getting confrontational when people answer her, weird! We were then hustled into an EXTREMELY crowded (hope you're not claustrophobic) room to a tiny table, asked "WHAT YOU WANT DRINK?!?", then left to watch other people eat for 23 minutes before they returned to take our order finally! In hindsight we should have left then.
Our food was even more disappointing than the service. The Fried Pork Eggrolls had NO meat in them, the best I could say is that they were fried up nicely. I ordered the Famous Nanking Sesame Chicken thinking I couldn't go wrong with the house specialty, boy was I wrong, FLAVORLESS! I could taste sesame seeds, but the sauce might as well have been water, bleh! My wife ordered House Noodles and again a miss. It was like they took the noodles out of 2 ramen soup packages, threw a little soy sauce on them, then said "$8.95....enjoy!", TERRIBLE! 
Believe it or not, this review is in no way an exaggeration. We were SO surprised at the lack of quality/flavor in the food, that when the family sitting right next to us(elbow to elbow) asked us what we thought of the food, we asked if they would like to try what we had ordered, as we could not even finish the food we had ordered (strange for a big guy like me that's always hungry). They had ALSO heard what a great place this was and were excited to try the food. After the husband and wife had both tried our noodles and sesame chicken, they agreed with us and bravely ordered something else. Not sure if they liked their order cause we left before their "food" came out.
This place may have been great at one time, but don't waste your money, its a tourist trap now. I have had MUCH better food at hole-in-the-walls around town there, go explore!
author: D S.

description:
If I had to sum up this place, I'd say it's inconsistent.  The first time I was there, it was awesome.  The server/manager said "we'll take care of you".   We were loaded up on more great tasting Chinese food than we could handle.  Plus the service was extremely fast and friendly.

Fast forward a couple of months and I go back ready to wow my friend with authentic SF china-town fare. I gave the whole spiel about how people wait in lines for this place because the food is so good.  It was a big disappointment.  The service was slow and impersonal, the food was extremely salty and sloppily displayed and the bill for two was almost as much as it was for a group of 4 last time.

Maybe you just need to tell the manager that its your first time, every time.  I'm thinking that is the secret.  I'd be willing to give this place one more try. Everyone deserves a second chance.  I know what they are capable of on a good day.
author: Jeff G.

description:
First of all, I have had a lot of chinese food in my lifetime and just based on that alone I can say I have definitely had better food than that served at house of Nanking. Everything was super over powering, if it was salty then it was really salty and if it was spicy then its really spicy. I just can't take a meal with all kinds of extremes. 

My real problem with this place is the service, it was really bad! Our server for some reason would not let us order the house chow mein but instead convinced that the house noodles were the same thing. It wasn't because it was satayed noodle and not stir fried noodle which is what chow mein is. They ignored us for a long time before serving us food and took forever bringing us our water. I would not recommend this place.
author: sherry w.

description:
Famous chef? hmm..

Apparently the chef would made this restaurant is famous and opened another higher class chinese food restaurant. My coworkers and I came here for lunch. The menu was small and limited. I was expecting lunch specials but this is not how they do it here. Immedietly we were routed to a table and we ordered the sesame chicken, house noodles, and shrimp/mushrooms. The sesame chicken was good but it reminded me of fast food places deep fried flavored chicken. The house noodles were a bit bland. The shrimp and mushroom plate was small and there wasn't anything special about them.

This place is for tourist and it wasn't authentic chinese food places. I try to avoid this places because there are a lot of family run chinese restaurants who can make better for half of price they charge you here. Food here was filling but not satisfying. I wouldn't come here again.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Second place we ate at in Chinatown this trip. Even better than the first place, which we really enjoyed. We were trying to figure out what made it better and it all comes down to the sauces. They really do make the dishes taste all that much better than the other joints. 

Good food - I'd rate it a 3 1/2 stars. No higher mainly because its not the cleanest place I've ever eaten at. Even the other place was spotless compared to this place. Just to be clear - it wasn't gross dirty or we would have left without eating. It just needs a good scrubbing.
author: Tony R.

description: This is our personal favorite stop every time we are in San Francisco.  Let the wait staff choose your meal.  You won't be disappointed.  All six visits were fantastic.  Lunch is the best time to go.
author: Darren Q.

description:
I would have given this a 5 on the account that TB suggested to have lunch here. I yelped it and was surprised to read not only mixed but extreme reviews.

Now I know why. 

There is actually no customer service, the Servers are just there to sit you, no pleasantries, no smiling, no nothing. The place is filthy and I dont understand why one serving cost $13.95, you could have a great meal somewhere else just with that and tip included.

The food is good but not that great, but again it would have been different it at least I get a pleasant experience.

TB got upset with me for complaining...I said that this is a typical Chinese Restaurant...We agreed that next time...no more Chinese except for when he gets them at Jade Restaurant and order it to go.

I am definitely not coming back and will not recommend.
author: Malou C.

description:
Sometimes there's a downside to being a New Yorker (and worse, a New York foodie!) -- because your standards are set WAY too high. 

I really wanted to love House of Nanking, but while I enjoyed the food, I found myself longing for the scallops and snow peas at my New York Chinatown haunt, Hop Kee. I think the bottom line is that the food here is simply different -- let me emphasize that word, "different," not "bad." The flavors weren't my thing, but judging from the line of people waiting to get in, the flavors certainly work for plenty of other folk. We sat next to a local family who regularly recommend House of Nanking to their friends, so maybe it just wasn't my speed. 

There was one dish I loved though -- the salt-and-pepper shrimp with mushrooms. You must get that if you're there. 

And the decor, while no-frills, certainly puts the plain walls at Hop Kee to shame.
author: Sarene L.

description: Have been coming here since I worked at Levi's and used to LOVE LOVE LOVE IT, but the last few times it's been "meh"   Went there today and I think this will be my last time.  I usually come here several times a year, usually whenever friends are visiting the city as part of my standard North Beach/China Town tour.    It took a full 20 minutes for us to get food.  My Sesame Chicken was mostly breading with no chicken and the sweet potato was hard.  The hot tea was expensive--one of those exploding flower numbers-- when all I wanted was some plain hot tea on a cold day.  Had the same "meh" experience last time I was here in August so am thinking I need to find another "go-to" Chinese spot.  The Onion Cake and Pea Shoot dishes were good as always.  My kids love coming here so will leave it on my rotation but not if I'm picking where we eat.  Good food for the most part but not worth the wait in line and additional wait once seated in my opinion.
author: Gia B.

description:
I've been coming to house of nanking since i lived in sf in 1996...  Its always been good.  Never disappointing.  Every time i'm in the city, I'm here... a few times just to kill the craving I get....

The crowd and tourists aside, I could care less!   The owner still comes by the table and takes my order;  I've gone with his requests when I'm wishy-washy and also I ALWAYS have the potstickers w the peanutsauce drizzle.  Makes me wanna move back to SF.  

Time and time again, this place makes me happy;  I'm unsure as to all the bad reviews, as I think it has to do with tourists and the crowd. But, you can't blame the restaurant for being popular;  its a sign that they are doing something right.

My service has always been quick; and I'm unsure why people feel its over-priced? Even when I made pocket change, a plate of noodles from h of nanking makes me feel like a rich man....
author: Vladmiri D.

description:
Service = Terrible
Ambiance = Grungy
Food = 1 Star

I live nearby and see the crowds lined up and waiting out the door.  Why?  Got me, cuz the service is crappy and the place is crowded and a bit on the dirty side.  We didn't find out they only take cash until after the check hit the table. This required one of us to go across the street to withdraw money from an ATM...guess what that $3.00 charge from the bank meant no tip for the less than attentive or caring staff.   How about placing a sign or putting somewhere on the menu that you only take cash?

The only saving grace for this place is the edible food, but is it really worth the wait?  Not really.  There is a Thai restaurant two doors down that has better food, cheaper and never a wait.  

Next time you find yourself in line at this place, reevaluate and hit-up the Thai joint.
author: Charlie B.

description:
Sorry to kill all the buzz about this place. I don't get it, this place was recommended to me by so many people and seriously, I still don't get it. I was warned about the service so I feel I don't need to mention anymore than has been said. 

The sesame chicken was soaked in sauce and such a starchy meal. 

We also ordered noodles and same happened with that plate as well.
author: Keidi K.

description:
The food is out of this world BOMB!
Service is fast, only thing is there can be a bit of a wait sometimes but  usually it's pretty quick. 

I get the bok choy, breaded fish, oh man i don't know what else EVERYTHING is good. 

Everytime I go to SF this spot is 110% necessary to hit up.
author: Deanna G.

description: We finally found this place after walking around chinatown for 45 min looking for a nice sit down restaurant. There are so many to choose from! Ordered the pot stickers and the peanut sauce was delicious. The egg rolls were alright. For the main dishes me and my boyfriend ordered chow mein and sesame chicken. Wasn't amazing. Tastes very average. Then my boyfriend asks how come there are no beef entrees to choose from? Our waitress says "I will order you beef!"  Ok why not. So glad we did. The beef melts in your mouth. We both were like WOW! I have never had anything like that before. It was crispy on the outside and very soft on the inside. It melted in my mouth. It was on a bed of bok choy cooked to perfection. Had the perfect bite to it. Overall it was above average but not quite amazing like I thought it was gonna be.
author: Michelle B.

description: The menu was a bit short of variety, but what we picked turned out to be delicious - Salt and Pepper Prawns and Chow Mein.  Other dishes looked even better and we will be back.  Surprise when the check came to find out it was cash only.  Service was good but had to ask for water twice.
author: Mark P.

description:
NOT A PLACE FOR VEGGIE FOLKS. Spend you money on the VEGAN chinese places around ChinaTown. 

Ordered:

Onion cake: Was OK, but the sauce on the top kind of killed it. Other onion pancakes in Cantonese places had better crunch and zip to them. 

Eggplant chilli: Really bad, its really really bad

Zucchini salad: Some kind of sauteed mushrooms with zucchini and crunchy rice I guess, but it was a rip off. Would not order again!!!

Fried rice: This was the most disappointing item. The rice was not Chinese by any degree at all. Rice was long grain - like Basmati, not what I expect in a Chinese Place. 

Overall spent $55, and was utterly disappointed. Will never go back....
author: Sirish G.

description: My favorite Chinese restaurant in SF. Long lines, but worth the wait. If you don't know what to order, just tell them and they'll bring out all sorts of things to try,  you'll find something you like!
author: Justin G.

description:
Woah. What a colossal failure. Food was mediocre. Fast, but completely unmemorable. Service, mediocre. Ambiance, nothing special. The point where this went from 2 stars to 1 star was when we wanted to pay the bill. We put our cards down and were told "Cash only." "Wait, what? I saw someone pay with card like 5 minutes ago!" At that the waitress walked off and brought back what I'm guessing was the manager. ""$35 minimum per card." "WHAT? But our lunch bill is $65?" I paid for it with my card, which isn't a big deal if they weren't so awful about it. Just straight lying about what they accept. Mediocre would be a step up from this place. Try somewhere else. I think the only reason this place is known about at all is that it has been around for a while and for some reason the tourist books write about it. 

Thumbs emphatically DOWN.
author: Jamie N.

description:
A friend suggested we try this place since every time he drives by it's super crowded. 

We waited about 20 mins before we got seated at a table with another group of 3 and the waiter [owner] asked if we'd been here before. Since it was the first time for all of us, he said "no worry. i take care you." We heard that that's what he does so we were anxious to what he ordered for us and he did the same for the other group too.

We ended up with an array of dishes and we all agreed that it was all good! We loved the Sesame Chicken! The other dishes were good not great. We were so stuffed from 4 dishes that we didn't have room for dessert. It's quite expensive for Chinese food but it was a good experience. I'd come back again just for the chicken. Yum.
author: Mimi N.

description: We came here for the first time 10 years ago and loved it... Back to San Fran and had to go back... What a change...food was just ok and service was horrible... After food was served, no one ever checked in on us.. Servers congregated with each other and ignored their customers.  Had to track someone down to get our bill... It takes a lot for us to complain.  Will not go back. So much competition out there, I'm sure we'll find great Chinese in the city elsewhere...
author: Sherrie T.

description:
CASH ONLY. The service is abrupt and may come off as abrasive, but definitely attentive.

Definitely try the rice soup (we had the veg) and green lettuce wrap (also veg).

The boyfriend warned the famous sesame chicken was a little dry, and lacking sauce.
author: Despina T.

description: Best chinese food!  Really delicious!  Our daughter is a student in SF and introduced us to this place.  Loved the food.  Staff is not very friendly and service was so so.  We felt a little rushed but the food is worth the visit  and we will go back when in SF again.
author: Katherine K.

description:
This was my first time back since they remodeled the place years ago when it looked like a divey cafeteria. I'd never been disappointed then and am happy to say this time was no different. Plus our long-time SF friend had never been here so I looked forward to her verdict. 

The service is a little weird. I felt a bit rushed in/out and they seat you at big tables next to other diners and try to squeeze as many people as possible in. An older guy took our order and seemed to be scowling at every choice. Reminded me of the Soup Nazi, like 'oops, did i order the wrong thing? Does he not like vegetarians?'.  It's all kind of amusing and not a big deal if you take it all in stride.

The food made up for any inconvenience in service. It was remarkably consistent with what I remembered years ago. Everything was universally praised by the 3 of us. I swear there's something dangerous in the sauce (msg??). It's totally addictive and made me crave every bite. The eggplant/sweet potato dish was the best. Our SF friend was duly impressed especially with the scallops she ordered. It's too bad that it's a big touristy spot now, but i guess they're just too good to be kept a secret.
author: Roger a.

description: My friend ordered a bunch of vegetarian stuff that wasnt on the menu. At first i was a bit scared but. The first thing that arrived was this really spicy mixed vegetable salad like item that had asparagus and tons of other stuff. Then can this soup that was better than watching Lindsey Logan driving drunk. This soup reminded me a bit of thai tom yum soup but had so much more including a crunchy rice. Then came the plate of dumplings. Not sure what was in them but on top was spinach coated in a sweet honey sauce also topped with slices of roasted red pepper. Then came the fish. Wait. Maybe it was the fish that had the spinach and red peppers. Who cares. Finally my friend ordered us a slightly spicy noodle that we couldnt finish. All in all. It was pretty fantastic. Only problem was that we had too many servers and 2 of them were confused. Otherwise. 5 stars
author: Damien K.

description: There is always a line outside for a table, part of the charm I guess!  Food was alright, the house noodles were good, I did not care for the veggie steamed dumplings ( they used a lot of peas! ) yuk!  Service is swift, but they don't return to your table to ask if you would like anything else, or a dink refill.  It was a fun & different experience though.  This place is very popular. So be prepared to wait.
author: Winny S.

description:
When I first moved to this neighborhood, I'd walk by House of Nanking and always see a line out the door. Being the lemming that I am, easily influenced by other people, this meant that I had to try this place.

I also hate waiting in line, so I came at 3 PM on a random weekday. No line, yay! But it was still full/cramped inside and we had to share half our table with other people. Half star off for cattle-herding us.

The food was great! The sweet potato and eggplant dish is the best thing ever! Oh man it's really different and amazing. The garlic noodles are really good, too! This place is not your typical Chinese place. I like that they put a twist on Chinese food.

However, another half star off for the price. It does not need to be that expensive considering the ambiance and portion size (not that portions are small, but not $13-14 worth). 

I'll definitely be back often. I dream about that sweet potato/eggplant dish. It's a good thing it's close by so I can conveniently sleepwalk there when the somnolent craving hits.
author: Keli B.

description: Very authentic. Wait staff is abrupt, authentically :) I ordered soup and am entre and she only brought the entre... Telling me it plus the soup was too much food. Food is great. Cost is sane. Try the flower tea and the crispy noodle tower... And am for a little extra spice.
author: Timothy S.

description: Service was fairly cold but the food is great!  Love the sesame chicken, the light flavors from the fish and dumpling dishes, and the fast output of dishes.  I am a picky Chinese food eater but no major complaints here!
author: Anon M.

description:
Don't eat here!
I've been coming for 7 years and the quality has drastically dropped in the last year. 
The food is more expensive. 

The quality of the food has gone down. 

AND I FOUND A ROACH ON MY FOOD. 

I'm done. I miss the owner! He wouldn't have let this happen to such a formerly great restaurant.
author: Nic B.

description: Absolutely terrible. The lady at the door refused to seat me and my friends for no apparent reason at all. We said we would wait until a table would open up and she repeatedly said no and refused to seat us.
author: Matthew G.

description: House of Nanking is yummy, and well worth the often annoying wait and the semi-chaotic nature of the line and crowded interior. Go in a small group (2 is best, and definitely not more than 4), order the sesame chicken with sweet potatoes, the eggplant, and the scallops. Those are great! We expanded our choices this time with the Spicy Wor Dumpling Soup, and the waitress suggested getting it with fish instead of shrimp - there was a whole fried fish in the soup. It was delicate, flavorful, and a great suggestion.
author: Deb G.

description:
While adventuring in Chinatown, my cousin and his roommate wouldn't stop talking about Nanking. SO! Of course, my virgin buds had to have a taste. It was crowded, but we were lucky to beat the massive line that formed literally ten minutes after we were seated. It was crazy, busy, noisy... But this is all expected, seeing how popular this joint is. 

The waitress sat us down immediately, and though she seemed a little rude, I'm sure that was just her trying to get us fed fast despite the amount of people present. After some deliberation, we decided to order the Melts In Your Mouth Fried Calamari, the Famous Nanking Sesame Chicken, Chow Mein, and steamed rice. The calamari was lightly coated with Asian spices, fried, and served in a lemon garlic sauce. According to the menu, this item was "highly recommended." Being a huge fan of calamari and finding it necessary to order it wherever I go, I didn't particularly love the calamari at Nanking. However, I did appreciate the fact that there were two calamari options, the second being Tender Sautéed Calamari. I'm fairly certain that I did not like the Melts In Your Mouth Calamari because of the lemon garlic sauce, which distracted the normal taste and made the calamari somewhat soggy, which is not to my liking since I love love love crunchy calamari. Thus! I will wrap this up and say that the calamari was alright, but not to my personal liking. I am however looking forward to trying the Tender Sautéed Calamari. The Famous Nanking Sesame Chicken consisted of crispy chicken bits soaked in honey sauce and served with sweet potatoes, and some sort of strange fruit that tasted like apples. Two words: Absolutely delicious! The Chow Mein consisted of thick round noodles sautéed in soy ginger onion sauce with seasonal veggies. This too was absolutely delicious. We collectively came to the conclusion that these two entrees (the chicken and chow mein), were very authentic and individually deserve five stars. Though the rice seems very insignificant and is rarely mentioned in reviews, I will however say that the steamed rice at Nanking tasted quite good, and not like the overly plain and boring rice I've eaten at other Chinese restaurants. 

Though the environment and atmosphere at Nanking was for the most part busy, I did however appreciate the very quaint setup and homey feel. Though it was not located in the very center of Chinatown, I did like how it was somewhat far from it, but a walking distance away, and surrounded by beautiful buildings. Our only complaint was the portions, and how they did not equate to the prices of the items. We felt that compared to other similar Chinese restaurants, the portions could afford to be a bit larger.

Our overall rating is 3.5 stars with potential, but we are willing to give Nanking the benefit of the doubt and go ahead with four stars on Yelp instead of three. Yay for rounding! And happy happy eating!
author: Mari H.

description:
My husband and I just went there for dinner based on reviews here and other places on the Internet. Should have known better when there were only young white hipsters there. And there were forks on the table instead of chopsticks! I'm Chinese so my white husband always tells me to find a good restaurant when we go to Chinatown. We were quite possibly the oldest patrons in the restaurant and we are not that old. But on to the food...it was not too bad, certainly better than what I was expecting. The spicy wor won ton soup had 4 very large wontons and shrimp and fish in a spicy, creamy, lemony broth. It was different but quite tasty. The other dishes we had were vegetarian since my husband doesn't eat meat. He enjoyed the fried tofu in black bean sauce which was slightly spicy. It was a big portion with lots of pieces of fried tofu. The house fried rice was also pretty good. The only thing I didn't like was the onion cake. We thought it would be more like a scallion pancake. Also it came soaked in some kind of sweet sauce that I didn't like. 

All in all, an interesting experience. Tables are really close together so it's almost like community seating.
author: Sue May S.

description:
It was good.  I've had better Chinese elsewhere in Chinatown.  We tried quite a few items and wasn't blown away.  We were told we had to get the calamari, so we did.  It came about 20 minutes after we got all the rest of our food.  At that point we were over it and hoping to be blown away since we waited so long for it.  Eh, not so much.  
I left feeling full of sodium.
author: Maribeth E.

description: HEAVEN for chinese food (Szechuan style). just ask the server to bring you their best based on your preference of protein.
author: Harveen K.

description:
After reading the reviews about not being able to order what you want, we were nervous about going, but we were pleased when we did. We were seated and given menus and then a woman came over and asked what proteins we liked. She offered 4 dishes for 4 people and took our menus. When we queried what would happen if we didn't like what she brought, she said "you don't like, you send back".

We were glad we listened. The food was amazing. It came in 3 minutes. It was the best chinese I have ever had. And we tried dishes we might have never otherwise ordered. 

There were no chinese people in the restaurant which is usually  a bad sign in chinatown, but its well worth the trip!
author: Christina W.

description:
The food was amazing, the staff was anything but amazing.

Strike 1
My girlfriend is a vegetarian and ordered veggie dumplings and they gave her pork.  They didn't say anything when we said something, walked away with the pork dumplings, and then threw the veggie dumplings at us.

Strike 2
Ordered two sodas with my waiter, waited 5 mins.  Ordered with another waiter, waited another 5 mins.  Then this large table was sat next to us, their orders taken and their sodas brought to them before us.  Tried to get a waiters attention for our sodas, they wouldnt give us eye contact even when I called for them.  Finally I stood up and went to the waiter station and the guy said he'll bring them right over - realizing that he had forgotten - and then he only brought one.

Strike 3
Party of two seated at a two top.  There was a four top directly next to us.  They came over and told us to move over one table to the four top as they needed our table.  The four top was of course two two tops put together.  We went to separate the four top so we weren't sitting with strangers and the staff said there was no space.  So we had to sit with two awkward old ladies from the mid west who were clearly very bothered that we were sitting with them.
