And then the wait staff continued to favor and bend over back wards for this larger party who they gave our table to.

Food was good and cheap, but definitely not worth putting up with this staff.  Never again.  Oh, and I'm from New York so I was looking for a New York egg roll.  I heard Nan King's was good... but it wasn't.  It was just a crisp egg roll skin with gross dry and fatty pork in the middle and a sauce all over it.  I don't mind the fat but not when the fat is dry and doesn't give any flavor.  Guess that's why it's smothered in sauce, to hide the dryness of the pork.  It wasn't appetizing at all.  Skip the egg rolls, especially if you're from New York and looking for a New York egg roll.
author: Noni A.

description:
If you're craving fresh-tasting Chinese, a casual atmosphere, and are okay with dishes that are off the Chinese-American-Kung-Pao-Chicken-Fried-Rice beaten path, this is the perfect place. Family style dishes, so it's nice to be here with more than two people, and at about $10-$12/person pretty affordable.

Certainly not a dive-- you get that in the quality of the food. Service is pretty in-your-face and you might share a long table with other people, but I found that added to the collage-like character of the restaurant.

Plenty of options for vegetarians-- the eggplant and sweet potato dish is killer. If you order tea, they will bring you a big glass mug of blossoming tea which has been sweetened by honey-- if you don't like sweet tea, tell them not to sweeten it.
author: Jen N.

description: If you're in the area you should stop in and get some food.  This is a funky little spot that does not disappoint.  It is cafeteria style seating but we've always had a great experience!
author: Lauren M.

description:
this place is absolutely divine...
came here for the first time for dinner with some family visiting from out of state after my dad could not stop ranting about it for weeks on end.

i personally love the intimate setting and the small, cramped space of the restaurant.
so typical of some of the best eats here in the city.
claustrophobics beware!

my recommendations: 
sizzling rice soup: tangy with a little bit of crunch!

chinatown market greens: i absolutely love the kick and how crisp the veggies are 

nanking sesame chicken: a bit on the salty side but can be made to order-- take everyone's word for how delicious this dish is! you'll regret it if you don't.

bao bing wrap: the beef is so tender and cooked to perfection...

house noodles: an amazing yet simple blend of flavor 

we usually ask for steamed rice just to tie all the different flavors together and to calm our overwhelmed tastebuds.

service was good, but i found that we were sometimes rushed and not attended to as frequently.
i guess i kinda saw it coming since this place is ALWAYS packed.
author: Kirstie A.

description: Hadn't been here in years - and did not disappoint - thankfully as I had my in-laws in tow. Got a few dishes  - their new pepper ap was good. The tofu with black bean sauce and lettuce wraps were excellent. Had only one high chair so had to hold a kid (seemed odd to have only one).
author: Paras P.

description:
For the price, this is really good food, but ja, sometimes it's pretty oily.  If you've never been here, just tell the guy what you want (veg/pork/beef/seafood/chicken/all of it).

I recommend coming in a party of four, keeping each other while you wait in line, and then ordering family style (order a bunch of dishes to share).

They used to sell HUUGE beer mug looking things of blossom tea - those are no longer.  Now it's just a subpar but fashionably wrapped tea bag.

Seating is usually pretty tight, so wear some deodorant.
author: Dmytro A.

description:
So...average. 

It feels like this place thrives solely on hype because I was expecting a great deal more taste-wise when we dined here. My wife and I were visiting from out of town and I was really excited to come here because of all the great things I had heard. Unfortunately, it failed to impress. Granted, I am not Chinese so take my review with a grain of salt, but I have had better Chinese food elsewhere. We ordered the Fried Pork Potstickers which were actually decent, followed by the House Fried Rice. The fried rice was pretty unspectacular but it's fried rice so I was not expecting to be blown away. My wfie was raving about the Pork Wonton Soup before we arrived because she had eaten here previously. She ordered that and once again I thought it was whatever. As you can tell, we did not order a lot of food since I was not overly hungry due to the meal I had a couple hours earlier, so maybe I need to come back again and give this place a fair shot. But based on what I had it did not nearly live up to the hype.
author: George V.

description:
I love this place. My cousin's and I have made the field trip over from the East Bay for 14 years. This is not your typical Chinese food. The style and flavors is very different so if you are looking for broccoli beef or sweet and sour chicken, this isn't a good place for you. 

The BEST pot-stickers! Of course they are fried but they are covered in a chili peanut sauce. So GOOD! The Nanking Chicken is staple for us. The calamari and house noodles are also very good. the hot tea is amazing. I'm not a tea person but I like this one. It's the owner's own blend. We tried buying some and he wouldn't sell it to us. 

The location is a little cramped and not always the cleanest. But what good hole in the wall is super clean? 

The service is a whole different story. The wait staff aren't very friendly or patient. Just make sure to ask for water when your glass is half full since it might take a while.
author: Elo N.

description:
The 5 star rating is for the food only. It's amazing! We've noticed that the best time of day to get in here without waiting in line is before or after the lunch crowd. It's small and you will probably be sharing a table with another group, but if your OK with a more intimate setting then give this place a shot. The signature dish is sesame chicken and it's DELISH! 

Always our first stop when we visit the bay area.
author: Nicole S.

description: Not worth the long wait.  Bad attitude and food with no flavor.  Very disappointed.  Both tables adjacent to us were not happy either.  I guess I don't get the hype for this place.
author: James L.

description: After reading the reviews, I was really expecting more from this place. I have one word for most of their dishes, "sweet". I've had a lot of better chinese food in the east bay for less. I doubt we're coming back here again. The service was decent but I really didn't enjoy the food for the money I paid. This place reminds me of american chinese food.
author: Alfred K.

description:
I've gotta say I'm from New York and I'm used to above average Americanized Chinese food.  This place was terrible.  The signature dish, the Sesame Chicken with Sweet Potato, was utterly inedible.  It was literally like they made sub-par Sesame Chicken (which was tasteless mush) and just threw a couple barely boiled slices of Sweet Potato on the plate and smothered it in sauce, not even caring to cook it IN the sauce or combine the parts of the dish in any way possible.  

Just like all other reviews say, the waitstaff is terrible at their job.  They sucked on a Wednesday at 4...they're gonna be even worse on an intense day.  Also expect to sit next to people (if that's not your thing, do not go...)  The scallion pancakes were a joke since they were basically just barely even baked dough with scallions on top and the WORST dipping sauce.  I would never suggest this place to anyone hoping for chinese...go somewhere that actually has worthwhile chinese.  The only thing they have going for themselves is their branding which, while it looks like they threwup colors on a shirt, is intriguing but not even that worthwhile.
author: Andres W.

description:
I don't think I've ever NOT tipped at a restaurant. Our party of four was seated quickly (but we only got three menus) and our delicious appetizers came quickly. We needed more time for our entrees, but we had to flag someone over after at least 20 minutes. One person in our party received his entree relatively quickly, and waited patiently for everyone else to be served. 

Well, I then got my plate 15-20 minutes later. We sat as table after table of people who sat down AFTER us got served. One more person in our party was served after another FORTY MINUTES, and we had to go up to the kitchen window to inquire about our fourth dish. The waiter accused us of only ordering three dishes, when we were a party of four and obviously ordered four dishes. 

All in all, the food was okay, but not worth the experience. I work in customer service, and know the customer is always right, so I did not appreciate the waiter's attitude. And getting dishes at different times is annoying, but I'm willing to let it slide for about 10 minutes at the most. I'll never go back.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Why do all awesome restaurants in SF start with House of...? 

Well, even though I don't think their sesame chicken labeled "special" is actually very special I really like all their food. The garlic fish was amazing as well as the veggie chow mein. I mean the best I had as far as chinese food. Just make sure to down the food with a bucket (approx 32 oz cup) of their awesome unfiltered fruit tea and leave with their rediculous t-shirts. 
I saw a dessert which was a pastry set on top of a small cup of plum wine, heard it was good but didn't try it yet (always too full by the end of the meal!).
author: Allen Y.

description:
This restaurant deserves 5 stars from me.
It changed my view on Chinese food. 
We came here with a bunch of friends and had a selection of food to share. EVERYTHING was fantastic.
author: Melinda T.

description: Multiple people told me to check this place out next time I was in SF, so I did.  I didn't have any issues with the service or the atmosphere as many people posted.  I was, however, a little underwhelmed by their most popular dish, Sesame Chicken.  I did like that it came with sweet potatoes, but I guess it was just too fried and gloopy for my taste.  The menu doesn't have standard Chinese fare...I'm not sure if the items on the menu are House of Nanking specialties or if they're more authentic dishes so my ordering options were pretty limited based on my lack of experience in trying the other things on the menu.  Price was good and food was decent, but I'd probably try somewhere else next time I'm in the area.
author: Sushi X.

description:
Alright, so I am not a Chinese food connoisseur by any means, but throw me some "Americanized" stuff that is hot and delicious, and I'm a happy woman.

I think that is exactly what House of Nanking does, and they do it very well, and very quickly.  Is it worth the price compared to the zillion other similar restaurants nearby?  Probably not, but since I only go to San Francisco for business and I can expense my meals, I think the price is great!  ZING!!

I got wonton soup, and the udon noodles with chicken.  The wonton soup had 3 big wontons and was also full of rice, an unexpected surprise (they don't do it like that on the east coast!).  I definitely could've made a meal of that and an appetizer.  The udon was delicious.  It was a large portion and spicier than I thought it would be.  I loved the texture of the noodles.  I don't remember what my coworker ate for his entree, but he enjoyed it too.

We ate late, around 2:30, so there was no line, but I can definitely see why people would line up for this place.  I'd definitely come back next time I'm in town.
author: Lindsey N.

description:
We were on a bus tour of the city yesterday and our tour guide suggested that we hit up House of Nanking for lunch. He says that most restaurants in Chinatown are just expensive Panda Expresses, so we needed to go to this place.

Most of our food was great! I loved my wonton soup and eggrolls. The wonton soup is not your normal wonton soup; it has lemon, cilantro, rice, and chili oil in it. The eggrolls had big chunks of pork in them and a nice peanut sauce. Both unusual, but very good.

Mom got the corn rice chowder with fried potstickers. The corn rice chowder looked like porridge and didn't taste like much. The potstickers were great! Dad and my brother got the sesame chicken and it was great because it had a great sauce and came with sweet potatoes and chayote (I think). My other brother got beef chow mein and quickly inhaled it.

Bill was $65 before tip, so it was really reasonable for 5 people to have lunch. Great place to visit if you are looking for Chinese food that is a different from what you usually get.
author: E B.

description:
House of Nanking--What happened?

I used to go to this place all the time back in the glory days of SF. There would be a line going out the door, the service was kurt, everything on the menu was delicious, and when you ordered chow mein the noodles were thick and explode in your mouth with spicy goodness.
Today I decided to revist the old Nanking'. I was lucky enough to find a meter, but there were garages on every block, so parking wasn't the issue. I wish I could say the same for this dining establishment. I came in around 3pm, there were a few patrons sitting around, but most of the place was empty. I had to go looking for my server, and when I found her she sat me at a filthy table without a menu.
After about 15 minutes I had to flag her down again, and explain that I was in a hurry, so she complied by giving me a menu. I ordered the Chicken Chow Mein, and a water.
I had to hold my purse on my lap because the table was too dirty for me soft leather bag. After another fifteen minutes, I flagged down another lady, who I believe may be one of the owners. I asked her to wipe down my table. She said for me she would.
The chair opposite mine was still covered with food, but I tried to be zen and not focus on that. 
My chow mein had finally arrived, and my first thought was what happened to the thick noodles? It was still good, but not worth $11 bucks, especially for lunch.  My waitress never came back to check on me or refill my water. I had to waive my wallet around to get them to bring me my check. With the many other Chinese Food Restaurants in the area, crappy service should not be on the menu.
author: Tatty G.

description: Do not be deterred by the line outside this excellent restaurant!   I love coming here when I'm in SF and craving Chinese food.  I always try to request that the chef make a dish for me (just choose what meat or veggie you want).  THE best way to get great food here.  Otherwise, their Scallop Tower and Fried Calamari is amazing!  Service is quick but make sure to ask for what you need; napkins, chopsticks, water.  Also don't forget your cash!  No cards accepted.
author: Jeannette S.

description:
Growing up my mother always told me, "Jackie, you know when you are in a GOOD Asian restaurant if you see a crowd of Asian people eating inside"....she said the same thing about Italians in Italian restaurants, Filipinos in Filipino restaurants, etc....

Whenever I drive past House of Nanking (normally at night on the way to some club/bar), I would always notice the line spilling out the front door.  Hmmm, if it's so damn busy, it must be amazing! 

Booyy, I was disappointed.  After finally stepping foot inside and ordering my sesame chicken and calamari dishes, I look around and realize..."SHIT!  Where are all the Asians?!!?!"  I then realize that the tables that surrounded me were full of tourist.  

The food was blah and a bit on the oily side.  Honestly, I think I can do a better job making the same dishes I ordered at home.  I felt like both dishes were missing some type of ingredient, it just tasted so plain.  I mean, I get it, I'm in a Chinese restaurant catered primarily to white people and tourist.  Sorry but it's true.

+1.5 because the service was good and I had a good time playing a game with my boyfriend.  We both talked about how tourists are shitty tippers and tried to place bets on how much the tourists on our left and on our right were tipping.  Poor waiter, she got a shitty $2 tip from the French couple on our right.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description:
I went here  maybe about a year and a half ago and they were filming some documentary or something there.

Don't know what the big deal about this place is, it's just decent in my opinion.  Pretty overpriced from what I remember.  The blossoming tea is pretty unique and cool, but everything else is just whatevs.

I don't care if this place has 1300+ reviews, its still 3.5 stars and still an overpriced average chinese restaurant to me.  Many other options nearby with a likely comparable quality of food for dirty cheap.
author: Ngoc N.

description: Very good food but service is weird, kind of abrupt. I undestand that that's part of it's quirk
author: Thao L.

description:
It's true, the sesame chicken is a dream. But even with the small space, line out the door, and bevy of Chinese restaurants nearby, House of Nanking is clearly a standout venue. 

We (a party of four) opted for chef's choice which exceeded expectations. Calamari, sesame chicken, pork ribs, and some kind of fish salad hit our plates and stomachs in just the right spot. And total cost for a party of four? $70. Not bad. Not bad at all. Five stars.
author: Katrina R.

description:
Okay, House of Nanking is going to be a problem.

So I know I just updated my review yesterday, hahah but I did the unthinkable and had Nanking for lunch again today (on the boss man of course).

This time, Salt and Pepper Shrimp.  OMG.  Amazing.  Wonderfully seasoned skrimps with lots and lots of whole button mushrooms.  And I'm a girl who likes her shrooms, so this is a huge plus for me.

Damn you House of Nanking, for being just too tasty.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
I first ate at House of Nanking in 1995.  I have heard that this is the best Chinese food in the country, and I'm inclined to agree.  Where else would such a place be found but in China Town in San Francisco?  

The food is unique to Chinese cuisine and always exceptional.  The flavors are bold and the preparation refined.  The ingredients are as unique as the flavors the create.

The service is very competent, but a bit harsh.  The culture very much dictates that you sit down, order, eat and get out.  No frills here, but you won't wait long for anything.

The restaurant is a bit cramped, and not terribly comfortable.  Don't be surprised if you're seated at the same table with complete strangers.

Go for the food, not the amenities.
author: David G.

description: I haven't read the 1200 reviews if this place, but if I did I would expect every one to mention the calamari. Why? First, it's fantastic. Second, they don't really let you order here but instead bring you what they want. The system worked because everything was awesome!
author: Stephen S.

description: Delicious - the food was so fresh and the staff was very friendly. Stopped in for some lunch while strolling down Kearny, definitely recommend the steamed dumplings.
author: Bryan J.

description: Grease filled food is not the food that i like to eat . This place is a place for the tourists to enjoy if they had to get a glimpse of Chinatown.  Our group ordered the chicken and string beans , pot stickers , stuff mushrooms and the sesame chicken. The fried pot stickers was the best out of the bunch and the chicken and string beans was the worst. It left my lips all greasy . It is really bad when you need a drink after leaving the restaurant.  The price isn't great either .
author: Michael T.

description:
First and foremost, I would not say that this is "authentic chinese food".  The food that we ate here was nothing like what I have ate anywhere in China, Macau, or Hong Kong.  The food that you will find here is Upscale, Gourmet Americanized-Chinese Food.  If you are wanting a more legit taste of Chinese Food, don't eat here and go to one of the hole in the wall places. 

There was a line outside the door and it was fairly long at that. I think we waited about 15-20 minutes, so it wasn't too bad.   The restaurant was packed.  They don't have high chairs, so just keep that in mind if you have a little one in your party.   Also, the service was terrible. It was scattered and did feel like we were being somewhat rushed.n

The restaurant appears to be very vegetarian and allergy friendly. If you tell them what you can't eat, they seem to work with you. They also had alot of veggie options on the menu, so that was much appreciated.  The blossom tea is really cool, and has a good taste.  The braised tofu with broccoli was outstanding and had really awesome flavor. The tofu was cooked perfectly. Hot and Sour soup was some of the best I have had, and it was just the right balance of hot and sour. The house noodles were okay, kinda plain and didn't feel like anything to write home about. My husband loved the seasame chicken and it came with some yams on the side. He said the flavor was great and the chicken was cooked to perfection.  He also really liked the salt and pepper shrimp. 

One thing I absolutely did not like. The server brought a dish to our table and set it down. It didn't look like what we had ordered, but we weren't sure, so person in our party poked it with their fork (yes it was unused but you still don't know someone hadn't ate off the fork and then poked the food). The server realized she put the wrong dish on the wrong table, came over to us, saw that we had poked the food, proceeded to take the dish back and gave it to another table where it should have gone originally. This to me is not okay and I think should have never been re-served to another table.....

The price was kinda steep.  For 5 of us, with teas, soup, and 4 dishes, it came to 107$.  I didn't feel the price matched the portion size, which was somewhat on the smaller end of the spectrum.  Also, we wanted soup for the whole table, and instead of bringing a large serving and dividing it up as most places do, they charged us per a bowl.  This was also questionable since the other tables near by all had large bowls of soup, but this wasn't on our menu......The other tables all were also of asian decent, so maybe that's why since from other reviews it sounds like there is either a secret menu or one in chinese with more options?  In any event, even tho it was slightly more on the expensive side and wound up being about $25 a head after tax and tip, I suppose it wasn't that pricy.... The decor is plain inside, and I guess if you went to the same restaurant but with fancier decor, the price you would have spent for the same meal probably would have been more expensive, so it was a good value considering that. 

However, with those few things aside, the food is really tasty and stands out from the crowd. It is definitely worth trying!
author: Stephanie L.

description: The flavors were something that I didn't expect from House of Nanking. They definitely had some very interesting combinations. The Sizzling Rice Soup was fantastic and Panfried Five Spiced Pork chops were worth try. Again I want to reiterate, the flavors were definitely not something you'd expect from a Chinese restaurant so that surprise throws you off. Definite recommender and a place I'll try again.
author: Daniel K.

description: Great food but questionable service. The waitress took our order without saying a word. When our food was ready she dropped the plates on the table as she was passing, again not uttering a word. Our bill was also dropped on the table as she said cash only over her shoulder. I had the salt and pepper shrimp and himself had calamari. The food was great but not somewhere you would go for the service. Also saw one of the girls in the kitchen cough and sneeze on the dish she was cooking....she didn't cook my dish and I'm not sick but wow it was gross!
author: Heather R.

description: By far the best Chinese restaurant in China town. A little hole in the wall. Food ALWAYS cooked to perfection. The service was fast, each dish brought out separately  or all to share in a timely manner
author: Paul T.

description: Came here yesterday.  Absolute the worse Chinese food I have ever had - too salty, greasy and unrefined.  Don't quite understand why people were giving so many stars for such mediocre, non-authentic food.  Service was just like most people described, atrocious.
author: Alex L.

description:
brought my visiting relatives here to celebrate my moms bday. i go here A LOT, but tonight:

1. the waitress was impatient and yelled at me
2. the waitress did not answer any questions about the meals i had
3. the waitress brought out the wrong food
4. the waitress brought out appetizers LAST
5. the waitress refused my payment, and threw my card back at me and took my uncle's cash payment instead
6. all the white folks sitting around me, even the ones that came in after me, got their food on time with no problems JUST FINE

This new waitress is awful, and i will never eat here again.
author: Aleta R.

description:
Don't believe the hype..
While I admit that the food here does have a lot of flavor...everything tends to taste the same. 
We stopped in here last night after the BB Lounge event and I ended up taking home the food I was unable to eat since I was already full from the delicious apps at BB Lounge. 
This morning I took the food out of the box to examine the contents..and was shocked to find the fried mystery meat in my so-called "Special Seafood Noodle". 
There are a gazillion of great Asian Restaurants in the area...I wouldn't recommend this place unless you are craving stir-fry Fried Meat with a heavy dose of MSG.
author: Mimi T.

description:
I actually went back to this restaurant as my colleague, who's leaving town's strong wish to try this place. We are a group of 12 people, had to split in 2 groups which we weren't told. The food was better than I remembered, but too salty for my taste.  We requested 3 dishes and the owner gave us other 3, which he thought the best. The ribs were tender, but way too greasy for me, I had to wipe them off with a napkin. The peashoot green was good. The bathroom sink was broken, by the way.

I still would prefer going to my favorite Chinese in Oakland Chinatown for their home made dumplings....
author: Yoko S.

description:
I don't know about Bella W.'s review about not seeing a Chinese patron here. Late at night, I was guided by a "Chinese patron" to this restaurant because 2 other places had closed promptly at our arrival. But seriously, I do not think we're that scary of a bunch!

Anyways, the "Chinese patron" recommended this place after The House and another establishment was closed for the evening. And we were not disappointed. The food was delicious and priced well. The service was prompt and food brought out quickly. And it's all quite impressive considering that the food came out in a nice presentation as well. It is one of the better deals to be had in Chinatown, that much for sure.

Of course... the free white rice was pathetic. Order something so you won't have to taste that white rice!
author: Jordan N.

description:
I have eaten tons of bad Chinese food in search of my favorite cusine.
Few well known places in the Country have generated as much CGM (consumer generated media) as this place.  Let me resolve this once and for all...IT IS GOOD.  This is not the best place, the cheapest place, the coolest place, the most emo place, BUT IT IS GOOD FOOD and if you are planning on it--DO IT
author: AV G.

description: Great sesame chicken. Loud communal atmosphere. Fun for large groups
author: Martin R.

description:
I bring friends and family here when they come from out of town.  If you stick to the SESAME CHICKEN, you'll be fine.  In fact, I don't think I've ever tasted better. 

So here's the good, bad and ugly.

GOOD:
SESAME CHICKEN
MO SHU CHICKEN
PEA SPROUTS

BAD:
SOUP (CHEF SPECIAL WITH FISH- NOT ON MENU) you get this when you tell them you're there for the first time
NOODLES- we got there at 9PM and they were sloppy with chopping up the ingredients.  The garlic was so big, that is all I really tasted.
SERVICE- they are pretty friendly for a chinese restaurant, but when you scrape below the veneer, it really isn't that good
TEA- wow this was expensive.  It comes in a really big glass, but honestly it isn't worth the $2.75 per glass.  

I told the owner that I wasn't pleased with his recommendations and he was taken by surprise.  He recovered quickly enough and gave me the card to his other restaurant.  I don't think I will be visiting it anytime soon.
author: Melanie O.

description: Don't bother. But, if you must, get the sesame chicken. It's good, but definitely not worth the wait to get in, the bad service or the price.  This is a perfect example of a good place resting on it's laurels and letting itself go. I'm not exaggerating my disappointment. I "discovered" this place over 20 years ago, before the reviews, the lines and the expansion. I made it a point to dine here the 4-5 times I made it to San Francisco. This time I brought family & friends. I was so embarrassed after talking it up for so many years & waiting outside in the rain to get in. The waitress (not server) practically ripped the appetizers out of our mouths after we questioned her since they didn't look like what we expected. She had brought us the wrong (but similar) order. It went downhill from there. The one plate, out of all that we ordered, slightly worth the effort of eating, was the sesame chicken & whatever that appetizer was that the waitress practically ripped out of our mouths.  Again, nothing to brag about & certainly not worth the price.  Everyone courteously picked at their food until I did the right thing and announced the place sucked & we were leaving in search of decent food. My attempts to express our concerns about the "horrible, horrible" service & food were completely ignored. I figured my time was too valuable to waste it making a scene. So, I paid the entire bill (I didn't let anyone else contribute for that!) including, I think, the appetizers brought to us in error.  Not a penny more. Not a single penny towards gratuity!  I'll never go back.
author: Otilia D.

description:
OK...I use to love House of Nanking.  I think this place is much better for adults than it is for kids.  We arrived with 4 adults and 6 kids.  The server told us she knew what we wanted and to trust her.  We told her our kids were a bit high maintenance and she said don't worry about it.  We told her a couple of must haves.  

Needless to say out kids were not fans of the appetizers and soups and just the adults had them (with plenty left over so we wasted some $$).  One of the main course for the kids came at the end so by that time they were a bit cranky.  

Lastly to make matters worse...we found two different plates with hair in them.  We notified the server (who was also the manager) and she looked at the plate and took it away.  She never said sorry about that which was the most disappointing.  We then found another hair in our soup and showed to another server.  He saw the hair and took it away and never said sorry.  It was ironic at that point the lights in the restaurant were then dimmed.  We talked to the manager about it and she showed very little remorse and said it wasn't a problem with any other tables and made us feel that we were being too demanding.  We pointed to the kitchen and the staff and there was one in particular cutting up the food with long hair and a long braid so put two and two together. 

The manager did give us price concessions but the bottom line is there was no remorse on their side.  The kids didn't want to eat the food because of finding hair and it was a miserable dinner.  Recommendation...watch for hair and don't let them order the food for the kids.
author: Jeff M.

description: The food is amazing! The restaurant is small and crowded but the food makes up for all the little flaws.  Fish soup, mushroom appetizer, beef, noodles, were all amazing!  If you don't know what you want, just tell them what you're craving and they will order for you and you'll love it.
author: David Y.

description: This chinese restaurant is special. You will have total different experience than other chinese restaurant. Their food tastes rich and awesome!
author: Wing L.

description:
Ate here today for the first time with a coworker, at the recommendation of a friend.  Oh my god!  This place is f'ing great!!!!  Best Chinese I've ever had!  It seemed like pretty standard fare, meaning you'd recognize the items on the menu, but there is a bit of a twist thrown in to keep it interesting.  The sesame chicken is to die for!  It's served with sweet potato and, I think, asian pear.   Incredible.  

Yes...the servers are a bit gruff, but I think it adds to the places charm.  Don't take it personally!!

House of Nanking....mmmmm, get it my mouth!!!!!
author: Matthew T.

description: As a long time Fan of this place, I have to say this place has gone down hill.  The food is just not as good as it used to be.  Not sure if it has to do with their new store opening.  Either way, I have 86 this place.  San Tung is the best spot in the city.
author: Henri W.

description: Food was pretty good but service was not so much. Rude employees. Kids loved the potstickers with peanut sauce
author: Yari Z.

description:
The food was great, fast and rather inexpensive for the quantity you get.  Remember to bring cash as they do not take credit cards...

I can't say it is the best in the city, but for the americanized asian food we have grown accustomed to then you will probably like this place.  If you are looking for a more traditional chinese dining experience than you need to go deeper into china town and avoid this place.  I like both...and for this place seemed to hit the spot quite nicely.
author: Mark M.

description:
ingredients are pretty unique for a chinese restaurant.

not your typical chinese menu.  but most of the items were good.

sesame chicken (not sure what the hype is about, i find this at all kinds of restaurants and i dont find it that unique)
crispy beef (just okay, i dont think i would order this again)
house noodles (egg noodles is kinda weird, but the greens make it taste unique and tasty)
steamed tofu (very delicious)
black bean eggplant (off the menu but very tasty)

maybe you should try dining in cuz the signs recommend that the owner order for you.  seems a bit of a tourist trap but my asian friends said they also liked it here.

but me being chinese id spend a little more and go the r&g lounge 2 blocks down the street on kearny.
author: Addison P.

description:
I've been going every time I come to San Francisco for years.

Every time I think it can't live up to my memories.

It does every time!
author: Scott S.

description: Wow. Surprising to say.. It was really bad. Worst service I've had in years. Atmosphere was chaotic and disruptive. Rude staff. I won't be back.
author: J D.

description:
The food here is AMAZING- I am number 1 chinese place in SF. I am not the biggest fan of chinese but if I ever have the urge I come HERE. I always take my guests from out of town because its a great place for tourists and its so tasty. Also, good thing is they have lots of vegetarian stuff, too.

Only bad thing, service isnt great. They are not personable or
author: Jessie A.

description:
Ever since I came to this countries years ago, this place has been in business and always packed with people waiting outside. 

Once we got in there ourselves, it was pretty obvious why so many people went. The taste was very original, not like anything I have had before. It is a little towards the spicy side, but acceptable to most people. Oh yes, do not order dessert cuz it really sucked. Price is a little bit more expensive than average, but acceptable.

For anybody who has never been there, it is strongly recommended.
author: Jun W.

description:
While visiting friends in SF, we asked a business owner in Chinatown for a chinese restuarant recommendation. He said House of Nan King. 

The interior is packed with little room to walk. You have to be tall and thin to squeeze between the tables.  I'd hate to think what would happen if people had to get out of there in a hurry!  

The waiter was neglectful, had to ask repeatedly for things, and our food arrived plate by plate, not all at once, so we basically ate in shifts.  

The food wasn't great ... for example the chowmein noodles tasted like noodles with brown sugar sauce on them.  The orange chicken was tasty, but not plentiful.  I will say they have the best veggie fried rice I've ever had.  The fried rice is the ONLY reason I gave this place 2 stars. And for the first time in my life in a chinese restaurant, we were never given a fortune cookie at the completion of our meal! Kids were dissapointed, needless to say.  

So if you go, I suggest you order the fried rice for take-out.  Or better yet ... find a different chinese restuarant with room to stretch, better mannered waitors and a better menu.
author: Ann B.

description: Decent food, terrible service, over-priced, and looong waits. I don't understand why tourists line up out the door to go to this place. The Vietnamese place that's just next door on the other hand has delicious food, is way cheaper, is never crowded, and gives you free tea! and still the tourists wait blindly for their mediocre dining experience - don't let that be you!
author: Charlotte C.

description:
Deeeelicious!  My favorite dish is the sesame chicken...digging the crunchy, tender goodness of it all.  The house noodle and egglant with garlic ain't so bad either.

I had to give this place a try and maybe I got lucky and came on a good day.  Maybe having lunch with two of my best girl friends help make the meal more enjoyable?  Also, I didn't witness any uncleaniness or dwell too much on the fact that I just paid for a very overpriced meal.  But really, this place is not that bad compare to other hole in the walls in Chinatown.
author: Lisa Z.

description: One of my to-go places in chinatown for a great meal. Food is delicious and flavorful. I loved all the veggie dishes as well as their detox tea. Onioncake appetizers hit the spot. Definitely a place i would recommend for anyone wanting delicious chinese food.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Great spot for authentic tasting Chinese food! A couple of things we didn't know that are helpful tips:
They want cash only! Although it does not state that anywhere in the restaurant, that seems to be the preferred payment method; they said they accept ATM, but no credit cards; to be safe, have cash.
It's a small place and you have to wait outside; we were a party of 5 on a Saturday night, we waited about 30-40 minutes; once seated, had very prompt service.
We tried the pepper shrimp, home made wonton soup, scallop tower, sesame chicken and combination low mein: wow! Everything was delicious!
Definitely would go back!!
author: Veronica E.

description: Just went to this restaurant, absolutely terrible service and they actually wrote in the tip for us. VERY presumptuous and extremely rude considering we had to chase them down for water and menus. NOT a good move-
author: Jas Y.

description:
Big Fan of this place!

Don't come here if you want great service. I went on a Saturday night. Naturally, the line was out the door. Waited about 25 minutes to get a table for 6 and they accomodated us fine. I was near the door though and it got a bit draft.

Warm beer, poor service, dimly lit, GREAT FOOD. That's the only reason I gave it 4 stars. Now this isn't the most authentic places you could eat. Especially being in China Town you can walk up the block and get something authentic. This was kind of a Neo-Chinese-American-Fusion type thing (if I could put this in a genre). I really love meat, but I would come back here for the vegetables. The scallops were good, chicken good, but the vegetables amazing. Whether they were the star of the dish or just an accompaniment, amazing. THe pork chops weren't my favorite, but the spinach that came along with is was GREAT
author: Will L.

description:
I have always heard good things about House of Nanking but today was the first time I actually tried it. I give it two thumbs up! The place is really cute and authentic looking. I like how they gave me a big giant glass of tea, the tea leaf blossoms into a flower. 

The house noodles is a must order, it was very tasty!! :) 

I also had the chicken rice chowder ( not bad) 
Sesame chicken ( also not bad) 
Potsticker...made different than usual and very tasty 

I would definitely come back again. I have also heard that the lines were long, but there was a lot of seating. I think they just recently remodeled.
author: Sandy L.

description:
You can never listen to a white person rave about Asian food.  So my cousin and I had to wait in line outside when it was frigid outside.  So we thought, although we were suffering, "This place must be good if people are willing to wait out in the cold."  

While waiting in line, a girl tells us how good the food is here.  We took her word for it, and even ordered one of her recommendations (i.e. Nanking Chicken).  It was pretty good.  Came with sweet potatoes, squash, and this sort of sweet sauce.  Also ordered the sizzling rice soup, rice, and this shallot and scallop dish.  I was not impressed with these.  Sizzling rice soup is so much better at other Chinese restaurants.  I like my sizzling rice soup kinda clear, not murky.  Maybe it's because I'm not Chinese, but it was not my cup of tea. 

Service - the waitress was REALLY good about splitting up the items on the bill.  Cousin kept asking her to take this and that off his tab so that he could expense it and she was really nice about it.
author: Hanna Y.

description:
Second time here. Last time was exactly 1 year ago. 

The Good:
Food is simply outstanding. Simple, but refined. Some of it unusual, some of it crowd pleasing. Fried Tofu in Black Bean Sauce is very good, Sesame Chicken with Sweet Potato is the best there is, and the Fried Calamari is perfect. Blossoming Tea is bizarre and frankly, alien. 

The Bad:
Bathroom is filthy. Service is prompt, but without a smile or interest. It's like Eddie Murphy's bit on Raw: "Hurr-yee up! Whet yu want?! C'mon, I got lotta peeple here!" Crackling Spicy Beef taken off the menu, which was a disappointment. Parking is beyond a bitch (like most of SF). 

Worth the headaches? Yes. It might be some of the best Chinese food in the area, especially for the price (party of four, 1 beer + 2 apps was $80). I recommend it, and we will go back.
author: Jason S.

description:
Blown Away By This Meal!!!

I give this place my HIGHEST RECOMMENDATION to all my family and friends.  If you're ever in San Francisco, follow these specific instructions when hungry:

1. Walk to House of Nanking ignoring the China Town restaurants and their representatives on the street trying to coax you into their place.
2. Sit down and act like it's your first time.  (If they do not come, ask you if it's your first time and take the menus out of your hand and serve you their best...just order what we had)
3. Order these things: 
Hot Tea
Bok Choy
Shrimp Cakes
Calamari
Sesame Chicken
(We ordered Fried Rice and Chow Mein as they frowned...it's not what makes House of Nanking special...so don't expect to be blown away by the rice or mein.)

Every single morsel of this meal made my palette explode with joy.

It's not only the best Chinese I've ever had, it might be one of the best meals in my entire life.

Don't let me overhype it for you though...try it for what it is.  But TRY IT for sure. I will always go back there when I'm in SF.
author: Dave S.

description:
Greasy.  Grim.  Gross.  

The best thing about Nanking was the jovial taxi driver gentleman we had to share a table with who shared his eggplant appetizer.    If you are reading this Mr. Taxi driver, NanKing should thank you for an additional star!!!

Service is unattached.  
You are a pawn and the servers want to move you and remove you.  You are a sardine in a dark, dark can. 
I had a beautiful view of a green recycling trash can in the kitchen...at least they recycle?  

Food is drenched and dripping in grease, rice is hard and dry.

A sad sight for foodies everywhere.
author: Jane L.

description: Terrible service. If only I could give no star to this not-so-fancy and friggin' dark place. It was my first visit to this place and definitely will be the very last one because when I got the menu, which consists only vegetables and desserts and other menu that is not contain meat. I asked the waiter for other menu but they keep on telling me that the menu is in Chinese. Since I can't read mandarin, I asked them again about what other menu that they have, but they were still insist that the menu is in Chinese. I am so pissed that I asked, "so if I can't read Chinese, that means I can't order?" And the waiter is just waived his hand and left. That was really rude and I am not pleased with that kind of attitude, so me and my family left our table without ordering anything and none of the waiters cared about that. The worst restaurant I have ever visit and I hope none of you guys experience the same.
author: Rosita O.

description: I just mentioned what I ordered.. Aside from the gross food, the main lady in charge was extremely rude!! You're right no one should have to deal with that.
author: Gaby O.

description:
I think this is my favorite chinese restaurant in bay area. in this restaurant you do not have to look at the menu. the staff are very friendly. just tell the staff INDONESIAN MENU they will understand. if you like spicy this place should be perfect. my favorite food here is the tomiaw (vegetable dishes), the chicken i forget the name, and the calamari.
Parking is horrible if you want to at this restaurant
CONCLUSION = RECOMMENDED!!!
author: Aris L.

description: Quite possibly the only Chinese food I've ever enjoyed.
author: Jon K.

description:
I was incredibly impressed with my dinner at House Nanking.  What they lack in curb appeal is made up for tenfold in taste.  The restaurant is composed of two dining rooms composed entirely of communal style tables.  After sipping on my Tsingtao for a few minutes the steamed pork pot stickers arrived.  They were served over the most savory black bean sauce.  The sauce didn't overpower the dumplings as the pork taste really shined through.  It was at this point in the meal, I realized that we were in for a real treat.  If the rest of the meal was a good as the first course, I was going to go back to my hotel room, content and very tired.

Minutes after finishing the pot stickers the entrées started to roll out.  So the timing here was very impressive. I never felt rushed but the food came out real fast.  First the salt and pepper shrimp came out.  U20 sized shrimp lightly fried and accompanied with mushrooms and onions were seasoned wonderfully.  Then the sesame chicken came out paired with sweet potato slices both of which covered in a soy/ fish sauce that was very addictive.  To round out our dinner, we also had the house fried rice.  It was light and full of flavor.  It wasn't greasy as most house fried rice's are.

I would recommend House of Nanking to anyone looking for a great Chinese dinner.
author: Ben G.

description: Best Sesame Chicken ever because it comes with delicious sweet potatoes.  I didn't even want to order it bc I thought it seemed to ordinary, but it was totally delicious.  That's what I'd get every time I go back now.
author: David P.

description:
I took my mom here because she loves Chinese food, and it was a super successful trip! I LOVE HOUSE OF NANKING. PERIOD.

We got three dishes between the two of us - the peashoot salad, veggie mushu, and the house noodles. Oh my god, the peashoot salad was to die for. How can Chinese food be this good? Everything was sooo well prepared. My mom thought this was the best Chinese food she's ever had - this is such a San Francisco staple - everyone should go here at least once. I've been here about 4 times total now, and when I went yesterday, it was the best I've had so far - everything was so amazing. Their veggie mushu is deeeeee-lish. The vegetables are sauteed so well and the pancake/tortilla thing you put them in was really thin and light. The house noodles are recommended over the chow mein also - that's what one of the waitresses told us. Great decision. 

My mom and I are both vegetarian, and we were highly impressed. You can find so many dishes for vegetarian people. I also love how hole-in-the-wally it is. It adds so much character to the place, and it's hustling and bustling. We got there around 6:30 and it was packed - we were lucky because there were only two of us and didn't have to wait. When we left around 7:30, there was a line out the door. I don't recommend going here in big groups unless you're willing to wait. Going here with 2-3 people is probably easiest.

House of Nanking, thank you for a fantastic meal. 

P.S. I don't think this place is as oily as some people think it is.
author: Priya G.

description:
I never have left a review however, this place is waaaay overrated and rude.
 I keep seeing them respond to negative reviews on how they are going to improve there service.  However,  we were there last week and the service was extremely rude.  we had to ask for water four times, finally I had to get up and ask someone else in the staff.  

Sorry but your sugary, syrup covered, salty overcooked food is NOT that special to garnish the attitude and lack of any customer service.  
place was half empty not surprised in this age of public opinion, word gets around fast with your mediaocrity and bad food.
author: Njones B.

description:
Attention to all House of Nanking newcomers: Before you go to eat here, you have to first decide what kind of Chinese food you like. Authentic or Westernized? If your idea of good Chinese food is Panda Express and egg rolls with sweet & sour sauce, then you'll LOVE House of Nanking. It has everything you'd ever want from a Westernized Chinese restaurant -- overly sweet and thick sauces, overly deep-fried meats, non-spicy spices, and starchy soups. It has a very bustling, crowded atmosphere that will make you feel like you're truly in the night districts of Chinatown.

So why do I only give House of Nanking two stars? Because, personally, I'm not a fan of Westernized Chinese food. Actually, for me, I feel like House of Nanking serves food that is just a tad better than Panda Express, but around 4 times the price. It was way too much sauce, probably to cover the subpar quality of the actual meats and vegetables.

In addition, the waitstaff is very pushy -- they seem to think they know what you want even though you clearly say you don't want it. We wanted to try the Country Rice soup, but the waitress told me that she thought I would be much more satisfied with the Spicy War Wonton Soup. We went back and forth about 3 times, before I just gave in. The problem was that when the Spicy War Wonton Soup came out, it was luke-warm, too salty, and had way too much pepper in it. When you say "spicy", I expect spicy from chili, not spicy from being over-peppered. Thanks Waitress, you're wrong about what I want -- and I now I have to pay for the $7 soup that I didn't like and I didn't even want in the first place.

The sesame chicken was okay -- pretty comparable to Panda Express's (which is sad, btw). The glazed eggplant w/ sweet potato is pretty good -- a little too saucy.

I should have known that "Zagat-Rated = Non-Authentic" when it comes to Asian food. The entrance is covered with Zagat stickers and awards proclaiming it to be the best Chinese food in SF (probably voted by non-Chinese people) -- that should have been my first red flag to not enter. Especially when just a block away, there are streets littered with truly authentic, much-more delicious Chinese restaurants.

Don't get me wrong though, I'm not dissing those who love Westernized Chinese food. To each his own. Just make sure you love it, before you fall victim to all the raves and awards.
author: Roy C.

description: Nice food, love the Chinese version menu
author: Ji C.

description:
Probably pointless to write a review of this place since its already got over 1,000, but it is AWESOME!  The way to go is to just leave yourself in the hands of the owner!  We just tell him what we like and don't like in terms of meats and he starts bringing out things we wouldn't have thought to try.

They seem to know their proportions too... cause I've never left hungry or with too much left over.

If you're out for a nice romantic dinner, this ISN"T the place, but if you're okay with waiting outside in what seems like a disorderly fashion, the food is worth the wait!  It's noisy, causal and tasty!!!! :o)
author: Suzie S.

description: Food is excellent. Sesame chicken, pork dumplings, fried eggplant. Service not so much. To be expected though. Ignore the whole "tourist trap" feedback. Food stands on its own.
author: Eric B.

description:
I'm often not much of a Chinese food person, it's definitely a mood thing and I almost always prefer Thai instead but this place is fantastic!

The atmosphere is a bit fast paced and there's always a chance that you are going to be sharing a table with people you don't know (for some this is annoying but I find it charming).  

The food is great.  While there is a fantastic menu to choose from, I believe we said something like "Can you make us something with mushrooms, shrimp, and basil?"  They did and it was amazing.

If you're not usually a Chinese fan, you should consider checking it out, it might change your mind.  If you already consider yourself a Chinese fan but haven't been here, you're in for a treat.
author: Nicole G.

description:
It is with a heavy heart I update this review.

It had been years (like 7) since my last trip and things have changed. Feng has left to open a second restaurant. Gone are the counter seating with the cooks stir-frying behind it. Gone are the metal serving plates. There is even friendly service and no lines to speak of when I swung by at noon on a Tuesday.

The menu is still a quirky, short list of original dishes that riff on just a few primary ingredients (peanut sauce, asian pear, yam...). They do things like serve water in these huge glass mugs and serve a hot tea with hot peppers in it. They like to create dishes with a few big contrasting flavors...which wasn't as charming without the more hectic and improvisational spirit of the past.

I had the Nan King Chicken and was underwelmed by what was fried chicken in a sweet sauce...the addition of sliced asian pear was nice. 

Much better was the wonton soup which was a big bowl of tasty dumplings, a odd looking but decent cloudy, white broth, and an entire stalk of a crudely chopped green onion. It was topped with a lemon slice...unique in my experience and about as complex as the House of Nan King gets while still being conceptually chunky if you will.

I couldn't try my favorite dumplings or scallop dishes because of allergies that have emerged since my last visit. I saw the scallop and eggplant on another table and it wasn't what I remember.

I will stay out of the Nan King hating and bickering about how popular it is with tourists.

I would probably give it 2.5 stars if I could. 

Time passes.
author: Erik F.

description:
Best calamari I have ever had. Who knew it could be ordered outside of an Italian restaurant. 

You know what, might have been the best Chinese I have ever eaten. Chicken dish was excellent, spinach dish tasted better then it looked, fish was just okay but it may have seemed that way compared to everything else. Did I mention the calamari! Sorry I can't describe the dishes better. Told the waitress what we liked and she ordered for us. I recommend this. 

Only downside were the tight seating quarters. I saw a couple sharing the end of a table with a family of five. Maybe not a destination spot for first dates but good enough for groups, great for a loner. Either way, expect some very tasty food.
author: Michael C.

description:
This is plain and simply not the same restaurant as it was 20 years ago when the founder first opened. In those days the kitchen was up at the front of the  place, bordering the sidewalk. They had a two burner stove for the woks and a rice cooker. Period. 
How they managed to turn out such scrumptious food is a mystery but it was truly, truly great in those days.I ate everything on the menu and went back the next night for more, night after night..
Three days ago my wife and I stopped in for a little nosh. Service was impersonal as if the server was disgusted (with us? the food?, who knows, very unpleasant) still we held out hope for what we experienced long ago. But it was not to be. 
The bottom line goes like this, the metallic aftertaste from the over seasoned food that was slapped down on the table lingered in my mouth until I got home and brushed my teeth.
I can't tell you what a relief it was to get that taste out of my mouth.
To say I was seriously displeased with the food and the entire dining experience would be a mild understatement.
It's bad enough when you go to the movies and the floor is sticky from spilled soda but it was the same at the House of Nothing and not Nanking anymore.
author: John B.

description: I heard about this place on 40 dollars a day. This place as ok.  I just though it was weird that we had to share a table with other people who you don't know. Food was ok. I ordered the fried rice and the orange chicken. The soup was ok too.
author: Jeanie Ann D.

description:
I love this place, but it's one of the first places I ate when I came to CA about 10 years ago, so maybe it just has that special place in my heart..... but we ate here last night and it was great.  We ordered the shrimp wonton appetizer things, onion cake, hot and sour soup (it was REALLY good), Sesame chicken, black bean tofu (also really good), and string beans.

Not sure why everyone is saying it is expensive.  We had a table of 6, ordered all the above, actually each of the shrimp appetizer and sesame chicken, and bill was only $96.  For 6 people!!!!!!  

Yeah kind of touristy, I haven't noticed it being dirty and that is something I typically would notice.  Servers are pretty bad though, except when the owner waits on you (he'll order food for you if you dont' know what you want, which can be cool, but I can see how some people would not like that).

I dunno, last night when we got home we decided it's a great place to eat once or twice a year.
author: Lauren S.

description: Best Chinese food in San Francisco! Sooo fresh, so delicious, and you don't walk away feeling unpleasantly full.  There is an incredible fusion of various cuisines that makes the food very unique. The calamari is amazing!!!! Definitely worth the wait.
author: Sarah A.

description: Would be five stars except the friendliness, or lack thereof, keeps their rating lower then it should be. The food is fantastic but harder to enjoy when stewing on the servers attitudes and lack of service.
author: Anthony R.

description:
A few pointers to start off with: for those of you who are going here first time know that the menu is pretty useless. The way to order is to figure out what type of meat and what type of vegetable dish you'd like. We ordered green beans, chicken, beef, house noodles, and scallops. 

The chicken came out as sesame chicken - although it was ok I was a bit surprised that ''sesame chicken'' was something considered innovative and fusion-y. Disappointed. 

The beef was this interesting dish - the large pieces of beef were deep fried (almost tempura like). The flavor was so-so. The bok choi however was cooked to perfection. Just enough to cook it without losing the crispiness. 

The house noodles had interesting flavor but I wouldn't say they were amazing. Not sure if I'd order this a second time but it was still good. 

The green beans were probably my favorite - cooked perfectly once again. Crispy yet cooked with very good flavor sauce. I would order these again. 

The scallops were prepared very simply with a mild sauce and spinach leaves (also cooked perfectly). 

Overall I thought the products were fresh but I was a bit disappointed with the protein dishes. The chef does, however, know how to cook veggies. 

Another issue with this place is price - roughly $14 a dish? At a Chinese restaurant?? The prices don't really match the quality as most dishes are similar to take-out but cost twice as much if not more. 

Overall thoughts - eh
author: Sasha B.

description:
I tried this place today with my coworker.  Not sure why anybody would give it a 4 star.  Food was nothing worth mentioning.  Service was bad and the bill was more than i expected.  
Things we ordered:
1. potstickers (they just dumped it in the frying oil and serviced it up).
2. Hot and sour soup.  Yucky.. soup was such a disappointment.
3. Sesame chicken - ok this was the best dish out of everything i tried.
4. Pork chops with cabage - not worth the 14 bucks.... all fried up.

My opinion.  stick to chinatown for real chinese food.  This is not the place for good chinese food.
author: BSC L.

description: OMG.  The worst Chinese I EVER had.  The Mu Shu Veggies were all peas and onions and black pepper.  NO typical ingredients for Mu Shu.  The Mongolian Beef did not resemble what that dish should be like AT ALL and the sauce was horrible, I literally spit it out.  I am baffled how anyone could like this place.
author: Martha M.

description:
I ate lunch here today.  I had the sesame chicken and mushroom and shrimp.  Now, the funny thing is that we ordered the salt and pepper rice at least 2-3 times while being told that the mushroom rice was really good.  Oddly enough, we ended up getting the mushroom shrimp instead of the salt and pepper shrimp.  Well, it was REALLY good so we just went with it in the end.  My only tiny issue with this place was that the rice was really over cooked.

Highly recommend and really looking forward to a return visit.

Be aware.  CASH ONLY.
author: Kent L.

description:
I have one word to describe what used to be a really fun, delicious, inviting, culinary adventure playground in the 90's. 

Inedible.

here is a second word.

meltdown

which is what my friend had after we were, I can't use the word served, because that would imply service, maybe slung would be a better word,  some salty sludge with raw vegetables thrown in, masquerading as hot and sour soup.

I remember how good it USED to be.. in the good ole days when you could sit at the counter and order off the menu and have it cooked in front of us.

If the oily rag they used to wipe the table off when we sat down is any indication of the hygiene in the kitchen, no amount of succulent sweet potatoes  ( this is why it gets a star) can compensate. 

Utterly awful. Save your money and your tastebuds.
author: Beth N.

description: We were asked how hungry we were and the chef sent out his picks for us--this is part of the experience here and I have yet to get something I didn't like this way.
author: Shyama G.

description:
This place is really wacky, but the food is really good. I hit it up once every few months, and have brought friends and family who are up for a pretty unique dining experience.  There's usually a line out the door, which moves pretty quick, so bring a jacket and they might even hook you up with a beer while you wait.
Be prepared to sit next to people you don't know, be treated like a number (turn 'em and burn 'em style), and have some damn tasty food. It ain't cheap, but some soup and 2 entrees is good for 2 people. I recommend the sizzling rice soup, calamari, and sesame chicken.
A fun spot with no class. Dig it.
author: Ben G.

description:
This place deserves 5 stars for their ridiculous service. Normally I would get offended and would have a mouth full to say about the crappy service. After working in the service industry for 7 years, I expect nothing but the best service! But this was something else...

So we come in somewhere between 5 and 6 pm on a Thursday! We ask to sit in the other room, no sorry other room closed... ok fine can we sit over here from the door- no this table taken! So- we ended up sitting by the door! I am still trying to squeeze myself in to sit down, and the server comes over and say ok... ready to order (while snapping her gum in her mouth loudly) - umm.... we haven't seen the menu's yet! Ok! brings over menu's say's ok ready to order... so we nicely ask for another few minutes!

Let me start with the fact that I love chinese food- growing up in san francisco, I have been exposed to the best and worst of it! But the downside of me eating chinese food is I am always sick! :(

Anywho- we ordered the hot and sour soup- which was extremely fresh and delicious, it tasted completely different that I have had it anywhere else, I didn't even as for pepper or hot sauce! incredible!!! we also ordered general tso (Sp) chicken which came with crispy sweet potatoes- yummmy, it also had some sort of pickle apply looking ordeal on the plate which I was absolutely loving! we also had the sizzling beef which was also extremely delicious! I had a glass of their house merlot, which was great...

overall the food is great- I liked the ambiance, the service is so ridiculous that it's hilarious. 

will definitely be returning again!!!
author: yana Z.

description:
If you're looking for authentic Chinese food, look elsewhere. 

In fact, take your silly expectations not to the Richmond but to somewhere else, like Rowland Heights in Los Angeles or even better, Vancouver, BC, because you'll get real Chinese food there. Not in San Francisco's Chinatown. Maybe something in Richmond will be close. 

Whatever, yo.

However, if you want something bad for you, yummy, and satisfying, this is the place.

We walked in, and she ordered in Chinese. Me, being the white, semi-literate English guy (I dictate these reviews to my dog, who is a very literate Jack Russell Terrier) watched in confusion when the food order taker said something in Chinese, and walked away.

The "she" said something like, "The server said, 'I know what you want, I'll bring it out to you'," and laughed. 

(Recommendation -- if you find a restaurant where you can go off the menu, you go back, period.)

Out came a beef dish with noodles, and some vegetable. Dark green, I think.

It was LOADED with MSG. 

It was LOADED with Garlic. 

It was GREASY.

It was SOOO GOOD. 

Bad for you GOOD.
author: Patrick N.

description: just tried the house noodles with pea shoots for the first time last night; delicious
author: Beth P.

description: Don't waste your time or money!  Service is ABSOLUTELY HORRIBLE!  Food is nothing to write home about.  They even added the tip to our bill which is illegal. We were only a group of four.  We caught this.  They later redid the bill but buyer beware.
author: Deborah F.

description:
Meh, decent food, not so great service. I ordered the self-proclaimed "famous" sesame chicken with sweet potatoes (I believed their menu's proclamation because it was corroborated by Yelp reviews). It was pretty good. The chicken was the standard deep fried and drowned in sweet syrup sesame chicken you would get at any chinese restaurant. The sweet potatoes were a nice twist: a "vegetable" fried and drowned in sweet syrup.

The service left much to be desired. The only phrases that were uttered to me the whole time I was there were "how many?" (twice) and "what you want?" They largely ignored me, especially when I wanted to order and pay. They also gave me some rice that I didn't ask for; I assumed it was included but it showed up on my bill, albeit only $0.75.
author: Adam B.

description:
God dammit I love chinese food.

i really wanted a good cantonese meal, and not have to pay more than 15 bucks or so. 

So Misha S. took me to this spot. Which I love.

It's cramped, loud, and fast. Just the way I like.

We ordered way too much food, 5 dishes total. Ate it all, and was EXTREMELY satisfied.

Would go every week if I lived in this city.
author: James H.

description:
Disappointed. This USED to be my favorite Chinese in SF. I always got out of my way to dine here when in SF. No more. They lost the mojo. This is not what it used to be.

Sour staff, mediocre servings. The eggplant sweet potatoe appetizer came without sweet potatoes. The house rice with chicken was supposed to be fried rice but was mooshy.

Do not accept waiters who throw the plates at you as if you bother them. I think a little smile is needed. I can find this food in many strip mall Chinese places and I am looking for my new  favorite Chinese in SF.
author: Ari t.

description: this place is delicious, we ordered the house fried rice, garlic fish, sesame chicken and broccoli beef (not on the menu). my favorite was the broccoli beef, very flavorfull and tender. the sesame chicken was very good as well, it had sliced sweet potatos which is so tasty with the sesame sauce. Although there were other kids there, this place is very crowded and not really an ideal setting for kids, but my kids did enjoy the food.
author: Rachel K.

description:
THE SOUPS!!!!!

Seriously the soups are so goddamn good here, I find myself thinking about them all of the time! I have no idea which soups I'm referring to, because every time I utter the word "soup" they get so excited and run off to the kitchen and bring me back something amazing-- I don't ask questions.

I love you House of Nanking!!
author: Honey T.

description:
I don't really care for Chinese food. That being said, this is the best place in the city, in my opinion. I haven't eaten here in YEARS because they never really had any vegan fare before, but they do now and it was flavorful and delicious! 

As usual, the service was very quick and exceptionally rude, but that's their shtick. I don't mind it. The owner's wife asked me twice to pay with cash but I wanted to pay with a card, so she begrudgingly took it. This is the kind of place where you get in, order, eat and get the hell out. No lounging around after your meal, they will not allow it. In fact, they once turned the lights out on my cousins and I then proceeded to drum their fingers on the counter and glare at us until we finally left. Again, it's their gig, that's what they do. If you have a problem with snippy service, I do not suggest going there...maybe get take-away or something.

As bad as this all may sound, it is EASILY the best Chinese food in the city, and if you don't mind rude service, sit down, get a drink and enjoy your meal...you will not be disappointed.
author: Susie D.

description: Bay far the best Chinese food in San Francisco. Love the modern flare in the restaurant. However, as an trained cook myself I would suggest to use less sodium in the food. I would go back again.
author: Tanya G.

description:
My favorite chinese food in SF....never disaapointed! Pork Chops n sweet potatoes is my favorite dish....

LOL previous post about cock roach fried rice wont stop me from going back this summer!
author: Mista N.

description: I'd give them 5 stars based on their pork dumplings and sesame chicken alone, but their house special fried rice and chow mein were very disappointing. Fried rice lacked flavor and was very mediocre. Chow mein was too saucy for me and very salty. If we didn't order those two things I would have left blown away by what we ordered. The pork dumplings were simply to die for! I loved how crisp the outside was and the peanut sauce was amazing. Sesame chicken and sweet potatoes were amazing as well. I'm a sucker for sweet potatoes so I really loved this dish. Definitely recommend those two amazing dishes!
author: Rochelle I.

description: Small, busy, good, and reasonably priced. Don't go for atmosphere, go for the food. Not sure why so many people down-grade it for the service and size; know before you go! Lot's of reviews are "I used to go way back when, but now it's popular and not as good" which is not true. Reminds me of people who like Band X, then Band X gets popular, and suddenly they say "I listened to Band X when they were just starting out, but now they've sold out and I are not good anymore." Food is just as good as always, it's just been popularized and some people can't handle that. I will still be going, just a bit earlier to beat the crowds.
author: Adam O.

description:
I was recently asked to recommend a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown & decided to go to the House of Nanking. Although it might seem a bit touristy & violates the "If you're looking for true Chinese food, go to one w/ mostly Chinese patrons" rule, but I do recall enjoying their food the last time I ate there about a year  & a half ago.

Owner/chef Peter Fang opened his diminutive restaurant on the edge of San Francisco's Chinatown in 1988, & lines quickly began forming out the door for his accessible, homey cooking.

Since then,  the restaurant has doubled in size, & the quirky Fang works the front of the house while other cooks prepare the food. Visits from Food Network luminaries such as Jamie Oliver & Rachael Ray, whose smiling mugs adorn one wall, have helped maintain Nanking's popularity. Lines of tourists & locals alike often still trail out the door, rain or shine. Often, his more traditional neighboring Chinese restaurants sit near empty in contrast.

To eat at Nanking, one must be aware of how Fang operates. He delivers a brusque attitude (in part to keep the busy flow of customers moving in & out) that can take some by surprise. He likes to size up the tastes of the customers after a quick hovering & observational recon & tends to prefer to recommend, no -- decide what you'd like, if you allow him to.

And more times then not, he'd hit the mark. This most recent visit, he delivered a chicken chow mein & a beef wrap dish that met both our approvals. 

Although there is no mention of it anywhere at Nanking, I recently found out that Fang also runs & owns a sister eatery, the Fang Restaurant on the 600 block of Howard Street.

Santa's yelper sez: "If you let Peter decide what to eat, you won't go wrong (especially if he has served you before), but the 12oz. Cokes for $2.00 a pop (no pun intended) was steep!"
author: Tadashi Y.

description:
Westernized greasy chinese food.  

The first impression when seeing the line out the door is this place must be good...  Then taking a second look inside I noticed there is not a single chinese person actually eating here .  
Bad sign #2  no chopsticks on the table- hinting this is an americanized place.  Then I am rush by a rude waiter to place my order.  
       We ordered some of their famous items: sweet and sour chicken, lettuce wraps, chow mein, garlic eggplant, scallops and garlic and spinach fish.  My overall comment is everything was very heavy and nothing really stood out as wow!  The portions are big and the prices very affordable making this place great for sharing if you want a GET IN GET OUT eating experience.  If you are looking to have a nice dinner and linger in a nice atmosphere you better choose somewhere else to go.
author: Daniela J.

description: Stopped here for lunch on a Friday. The place was packed, but we got a seat within 5 minutes.The food was great. I had the fried onion cake with peanut sauce. Very tasty. My entree was the eggplant with sweet potatoes, it was very good. I like how the sweet potatoes were added to the dish and the sauce was very flavorful. My friend ordered the fried shrimp with whole mushrooms, the shrimp was crispy and if you like mushrooms, they cook 'email fresh for this dish. The calamari looked and smelled good, but I was too stuffed to try it. I will go back here sometime, so next time.
author: Cali N.

description:
Try the wonton soup! 
You won't be disappointed with any choice you make here.
author: Jill S.

description: Incredible lunch!!! Calamari, Potstickers & Dumplings were all amazing!  Super fast service too. Loved it!
author: Elise F.

description: For a group of 20 on a Saturday afternoon, we were accommodated in about 15 minutes with a telephone call heads up to the restaurant. Our server wanted to bring us a sample of the menu, so we had to insist that we choose our own items to share family style. I would recommend Fang's Pan fried Garlic Fish, Pan fried Five Spiced Pork chops, Beef & Broccoli, and the House Fried Rice. Keep in mind this place is packed to the bone with people, no chair is left empty, ever!
author: Brandon L.

description: Food is great, service sucks. The rude employees completely soured the meal. A simple smile goes a long way. The waitresses and waiters asked us a minimum of six times if we were ready to order after only viewing the menu for less than five minutes. A bit overbearing, don't you think? Then the waitress dropped the plates at our table. She didn't PLACE them down at each one of our seats, but she DROPPED them at the end of the table. So much sass and attitude here. No idea what the reason is, but definitely not returning.
author: Brian C.

description:
The BEST chinese in SF

This place is no longer a secret. I'm sure other people have already told you how fantastic this place is.Just try the Chicken NanKing and thank me later
author: Christian C.

description: Nice environment. Chinese food for non asians. Can feel the msg. Good tasty food.
author: toan n.

description: House of Nanking is a treat not to be overlooked.  Arrive early or you'll stand in line.  This place is a hole in the wall, but well-worth it.  Once you are in, do not look at the menu.  Simply tell the waiter what you like (beef, chicken, seafood), and let them bring you dishes.  Dishes are large and delicious.  This is one of the best Chinese restaurants I have been to.  Don't count on great service, but you will come back again and again.
author: Eyal D.

description:
I'm usually a little skeptical when asking a concierge for advice on restaurants that are (a) affordable, (b) delicious, and (c) nearby. I figure if they're anywhere near the hotel, the concierge may or may not be getting a kickback for sending people that way. 

Even if the concierge was getting money under the table, I'm glad we took his advice and tried House of Nanking! 

Even better advice was from the gentleman who called a cab for us -- after asking where we were going, he told us, "Don't order anything from the menu -- just tell your waitress what you don't like to eat and let her decide for you." Best. Advice. Ever. The only thing I specifically ordered was my Tsingtao beer and glass of water. 

I can't remember what the food was, specifically, but I do know that it was DELICIOUS. We had spring rolls, some chicken, garlic fish, some beef, and I think maybe more chicken? Whatever it was, it was delicious (in all fairness, the waitress DID tell us what each course was as she brought it to the table...I was just so engrossed in my meal that I hardly paid attention). 

If you find yourself in/near China Town, you definitely want to check this place out -- and honestly, just tell the waitress to bring you anything. You really can't go wrong. 

Minus one star for the space, though. We had a party of 8 and we had to split up so as not to wait outside for 45 minutes for a table to open.
