Sure, you could argue that you know it's a good restaurant if it's that busy ... but when I'm starving for some good Chinese food, that's typically not the first thing on my mind (for those of you who are wondering, the first thing on my mind is usually, "Hmm...I wonder if they have hot and sour soup here...because I could really go for some right about now.").
author: Andrea R.

description: I like this place a lot for one main reason. The white garlic fish is FANTASTIC. Most people rave about the nanking chicken, but honeslty you can get decent chinese style chicken anywhere, even at panda, however the fish is phenomenal. I always come here for lunch and the white fish, some hot and sour soup and a tsing tao beer. it's unbeatable. The price is average, the service is bad (but that's a good thing, remember you are in a Chinese restaurant in China town, not at a Marriott). The atmosphere is great for China town. Overall I really like this place. GET THE WHITE GARLIC FISH! Another fun fact, the bathroom is tiny and super dark, watch out. Also this place claim the don't take credit cards, but if you have nothing else they will take your visa so don't be shy.
author: Alex Y.

description: opposite to many's comments, I think the service here is great but food is very not iyt taste.  honey sauce is weird to be added to any food in my opinion.  very Americanized Chinese food with everything more or less fried.  greasy too.
author: Shuting Z.

description:
I was just here the other day and this place is as consistent as they come! If you've never been here I'll give you your order, you can thank me later...
Garlic noodles, scallop tower, calamari strips, battered shrimp and mushrooms, and definitely get the eggplant! OR you can literally have them choose your food for you. Can't go wrong either way.
This place is intimate...you sit where you can even if it's squished in between strangers, or against a wall. 

Worth it though. A must if ur visiting SF
author: S R.

description:
Q:  If you go to a chinese restaurant and there are no chinese people eating there, what does that tell you?
Q:  If you visit a city, and no local people are eating there, what does that tell you?

That's the best way to sum up this place.  I mean, it's not bad (unless you are stuck in line for a long time).  But, it's not so amazing that I would go out of my way to come back.  We had a chicken dish with beans, and a mushroom dish.  Both were served fast, and everything was fresh.  But, there was no outstanding tastes.  Nothing that makes me say, "wow, I've never had anything like this."  Given that there is frequently a line, it's a major discouragement.  However, if you only have two people, they'll pick you out of the line quickly.

ok, I plan to come back to check it out again.......and, to be honest, it's not so bad post happy hour!
author: Sameer D.

description: David, David, David (and other similar reviewers). One goes here for the entertainingly acerbic experience served up with the best Chinese EVER!! If you don't get it, that's OK. More precious seats for those of us who love this place.
author: C S.

description: I don't know why so many people rave about the place. It's one of those "deep fry it and they will come" restaurants. When you put in enough oil and salt, the food will taste decent, I suppose. The food here reminds me of P. F. Chang's, very Americanized and it seems everything has the same sauce. I do like the inclusion of sweet potatoes (deep fried, of course) in the dishes.
author: Alice W.

description: You know how divey places have a special flavor all their own? That is Nanking. We got the recommendation to go here in a roundabout way, my friend thought he should call a Japanese American friend for a rec in Chinatown LOL but he was right... go to Nanking. We just beat a long line, had sesame noodles and famous sesame chicken and a type of fried rice. All were delicious and the dollar value is excellent. After this I see lots of recs for Nanking, I concur!
author: Lesley P.

description: Always yummy ...Rough service, long lines, questionable cleanliness but tasty food
author: Wes N.

description:
YUM! House of Nanking has been around for decades. I have fond memories of eating here. Love the cramped dining room and spaztic service - it's all part of the vibe. 

Everything on the menu is delicious, but the Seasame Chicken rocks above and beyond.
author: Celia H.

description: Not as expected.  Their version of Hot and Sour is not it.  A big miss on serving Mongolian beef.
author: Marc M.

description: I went in here with three others late one evening. We browsed the menu and were indecisive for the most part.  The server came over and we asked him for a recommendation.  He took our menus and said he would be back. Maybe it was because it was late and he wanted us out of there,maybe he wanted to show us their skills.  But after a few minutes out came fresh delicious food. One by one they delivered us some of the best Chinese food I've ever had.  The bill was not too bad either, especially when your friend wants to play credit card roulette and loses and has to cover the tab. We will definitely be back next time we are in SF!
author: Derek V.

description: My family came from out of town for a day for my parent's anniversary. We were in a cab, and told him to take us somewhere for good, authentic Chinese food. Unfortunately, he brought us here. When we walked in, it was packed, which we thought was a good sign. They seated the 4 of us and were rude right from the start. When my mom received her flowering tea, she asked if they had sugar (she likes her tea reeeeally sweet) and the lady said "No, it's sweet already", again my mom asked to please bring her sugar, and the lady claimed they don't have any. My mom had to dig in the bottom of her purse searching for a sweetener packet or 2. When the lady brought our food, my mom asked for a spoon. The lady asked "For what?" and my mom said she wants to stir her tea. The lady said she doesn't think they have any (what?!) and about 10 minutes later, brought my mom a plastic spoon. That was the last time we saw the lady. We had to ask someone else for our check, and it was almost $100, ugh. Small portions and not good. My poor mom had the worst meal on her anniversary.
author: Kaila I.

description:
Really great place and food. Feels authentic and we let the waitress look after us - which she did, brining out plate after plate of fantastic food at a breakneck pace!
It can get real busy here so get there early.
author: Simon O.

description: I'm not a huge fan of Chinese food, it's just not my thing.  I absolutely LOVED eating here.  Why do they even hand you menu's?  The servers just start bringing food which makes me nervous (I'm not only vegetarian but pretty picky too).  Everything they brought was so delicious, the fried tofu and asparagus salad were memorable.  I'll be back again for sure.  OH, bring cash!  No cards accepted.
author: Jill K.

description:
Best enjoyed in a party of 4 or more, with family style being a must.  The head chef or his wife is usually in the front of house & will help you create a meal (and may even create a dish or two) for your party.  The dishes are slightly Westernized: heavier on flavor, sweetness, sauce consistency.

++ | Spicy Wor Dumpling Soup |
Chinese soups are usually very light and almost.. too simple.  However, this broth is clear while still managing to be -unusually- packed full of flavor.  The pork dumplings and soft morsels of fish are never overcooked.

++ | Calamari |
Fresh, with no fishy taste at all.  The lemon garlic sauce offers a surprising sour and salty touch to the unconventionally long and lightly-fried strips of calamari.

++ | Scallop Tower |
BEST dish here.  Perfectly seared scallops with a carmelized crust over a slice of lemon and simmered eggplant.

++ | (Any beef dish) |
The beef at Nanking is unbelievably succulent.  We had a custom dish with scallions, Chinese veggies, & a dark rich chili sauce.

-- Fried Shrimp Packets
One giant deep fried wonton skin containing one shrimp and a pea.  Yes, a pea (singular).  It's sopping with oil and tastes just as it looks.

Decent, though unremarkable:
Stirfried Baby Peashoots
Panfried Garlic Fish
Fried Onioncakes
Fried Banana w/Iced plum wine

Dinner for 7 w/drinks: $25/person
author: Christina J.

description:
Hadn't had Chinese food in months, and wanted to hit up an authentic place in Chinatown. This place came as a recommendation from a friend, and I have to admit, I was not disappointed. 
The wine was cheap and good; the food was delicious, reasonably priced, and the portions were huge. 
Started with the steamed pork dumplings - a standard yet great app. My boyfriend and I ordered the Sesame Chicken and the House Noodles...silly me, I thought that wouldn't be enough (I was REALLY hungry)...we ended up taking some to go.
The Sesame Chicken was amazing. Honestly, it was so crispy that it tasted a little like Chicken Wings and since I'm from Buffalo, that was a great thing. The sweet potato on the side was candied and delicious. The House Noodles were simple but again, SO good. It definitely wasn't that greasy Chinese food where you're not sure what exactly you might be eating.
All in all, House of Nanking was bomb and the next time I get a craving for Chinese, I'm going back.
author: Rachel M.

description: Had lunch with a group of eight (including two vegetarians).  We handed our menus to the server and they took brilliant care of us.  Tasty onion cakes, pork dumplings for  starters, and all of the entrees we shared were excellent, especially the ones we never would've ordered on our own (some shrimp and green bean dish, and a squid plate).  Go with a group so you can share a bunch of different dishes.
author: pat t.

description:
A garlic lovers heaven but a germaphobe's nightmare!

I went here because everytime I host speed dating in the city, I pass by this little hole in the wall & it's always packed with people. Finally trying it last night. We were seated right away but expect to share tables w/ strangers. Oh the chairs behind you will be touching your chair so you have to get up each time to let people out.

Don't be star struck by the previous clients. Rachel Ray, Jamie Oliver, etc (Pictures on the wall)

It's pretty pricey for fried calamari $13.95 that was soaked in vinegar, sprinkled with raw garlic (that's where the one star comes from)

Also ordered the scallops that were hidden in a pile of spinach leaves & spring onions. One scallop was cut in 3 or 4 thin slices so it's not worth what you pay for $13.95. There must have been 3-4 in total. Very sneaky. Both tasted great but I could get more elsewhere for the same quality & taste.

Getting to the germaphobe part. I'm a people watcher. I watched the servers. The same lady that took our order, handled several different pens, the fridge door, a cash transaction, 2 credit card transaction, used the computer and several plates, used her bare hands on the lettuce leaves!!! She was serving the family next to us. She took each lettuce leaf (cupped in her hand), put the meat inside then put it one in each of their plates. The family of 4 did not even care. I don't understand. 

The same lady then continued on with her job then later went to another table & did the same thing. This time with tortilla looking things & once again, using her bare hands then putting the meat inside, folding it then serving to every person on the table.

The same lady went back to the food area, she put the back of her knuckles on this dish she was about to serve (to feel if it's hot enough i guess)  then she spoke to another server who did the same thing! The lady then put it back under the warmer. 

By then my stomach had done a full routine of a triple back hand spring & I wanted to get out.

The place is a mess. They don't seem to have any storage so boxes of this & that are scattered everywhere. 

The only star is for the tea served in  giant beer glass and I had no choice (frankly I would give this place a healthcode violation!). It looked pretty. The tea, that is. It looked like a tiny bouquet of flowers soaking in hot water.

Not coming back ever!!!

And wish people were a bit more observant. . .
author: Spooky E.

description:
(1/30/10, Lunch) I just ate at House of Nanking for the first time living in San Francisco for 20 years. My dining companion was eager to alleviate his HoN-nostalgia and we decided to pay a visit to the most hyped Chinese restaurant in the city.

Surprisingly it's not crowded, maybe it was a Saturday. We seated ourselves and studied the menus closely. I have been aware of the hype and fame of this joint, which is not popular among local Chinese. From a quick once-over of the place I realized I was the only Chinese person!

My dining companion and I quickly decided upon pot-stickers, an eggplant and vege dish, and the house signature sticky sweet sesame chicken with sweet potatoes. Presented beautifully on long rectangular plate are pot-stickers with peanut dip. That was the first time ever in my life that I see pot-stickers deep-fried. The batter must cater to American palette and the dip coordinate fairly well with the flavor of the dumplings! Off the tangent in authenticity but the taste isn't bad.

The eggplant vege dish tastes more like one you'll have in a Thai restaurant. It's simmered in basil and garlicky sauce. The sesame chicken is my favorite of all the dishes. For what it is, it's done perfectly in taste, texture, and coordination with the sweet potatoes. Perfect dish for white rice.

The overall verdict: House of Nanking might not dish out the most authentic Chinese fares, but at least they serve delicious American-Chinese food and have done it right. (This is meant for P.F. Chang's ear). One star off for thin service.
author: Matthew Y.

description:
At what point do you judge an eatery based on it's service?
It's a question we've all pondered, and my experience here definitely made me think about it even more.

You see, the house of (spa)nanking is somewhat famous in San Fransisco for its amazing asian cuisine. However, my experience there was extremely surprising in it's shittiness of service. 

After being seated in very cramped quarters with two of my friends we proceeded to be rudely yelled at in an accent that was hard to understand to "hurry up and decide". Mind you, we had been seated for about two minutes. This waiter was like Triumph the Insult Comic Dog wearing a human suit. 

In addition, my hip got firmly smacked by the skull of the (possibly inebriated) busser as he fell to the ground next to me. How shocking/sad/weird that was for all the customers. 

The food, however, was amazing.
The service was worse than being asked for money outside of 7-11. 

If you can tolerate the rude, go for the fude. Otherwise order it to go and get the hell outta there.
author: Daniel N.

description:
everything was oversalted to perfection! it was fun to eat with complete strangers but just not my gargantuan jar of flowered tea. i have to admit the saltyy salad was amazingggg...

try the sweet chinese pancake == especially if  you don't mind greasy oily fatty foods... it melts in your mouth (i guess that must be what the oil is for).
=)

**god, i hate when they bread shrimp! another salty mess...! gahhh!

The House of Salt
author: D R.

description: You go in.  You say " just take care of me" .  Life is good.  What's so hard.
author: David W.

description: This restaurant was recommended to us, but we could not have expected how great the food would be, until we tried it.  Doesn't matter what you get, it is all great!!!  They are fast, friendly and the food was delicious.  Get the won ton soup, it's scrumptious!
author: Jack D.

description: Best Chinese in the city!  The sesame chicken with sweet potato is out of this world!
author: Carmen V.

description: Good was awesome! There was a line out front but it went very quickly so the wait was no problem. Do not expect top notch service the servers will barely acknowledge you, they are hustling to get the food out. Killer good food the people next to us ordered sesame chicken and offered us a taste it was unreal! Noodles were great and potstickers were really good too. Would go back for another meal In a heartbeat
author: Andrea D.

description:
Came here with a group of 5 for dinner last week. Located in the heart of Chinatown, it is one of those longstanding Chinese restaurants that has withstood the test of time. They usually will not seat you until your entire party is present, and you will likely have to share a table with another group unless you have a huge party, or you're a party of two. (This is just a consequence of the layout of the restaurant.) Instead of choosing/ordering things off the menu ourselves, we asked them to bring out a good combination of foods

Here's what we got: 
- vegetable dumplings
- sesame chicken
- fried calamari
- stirfried baby pea shoots
- salt and pepper shrimp with mushrooms
- white rice

The food here is solid. The restaurant doesn't try to be all fancy, and obviously, they serve generic Chinese food. But I think they do it pretty well. I really like that their food isn't overly greasy. Even the calamari, which is straight up fried, didn't leave a filmy/oily sense in my mouth. The vegetable dumplings are delicious. You get about 8 per order - they are filled with really fresh veggies and pop perfectly into your mouth. They were maybe my favorite part of the meal. 

Bottom line: good food! reasonably priced. I would definitely come back, esp for those dumplings!
author: Kei N.

description:
The food was good, but definitely not worth the price of not being able to stray more than ten feet from a toilet the next day.  I'm talking all day, 24 hours, and no, Immodium didn't help one bit.  

For the record, I had the sesame chicken / sweet potato thing.
author: dan d.

description:
The restaurant is certainly overrated in every possible way, from the taste to the price and service.  We believed the waitress when she told us to trust her in selecting the best dishes for us.  As we waited for our food to be served, I looked at what other tables have ordered and I knew right away that we have picked the wrong place to come for dinner.  There was nothing Chinese at all in the food they served.  Almost all the dishes, other than vegetable dishes, were so "shiny" as they were drenched in tons of grease.  The onion pancake ordered for us was so unappetizing and bland that I could not bring myself to finish my share.  The beef dish we ordered also looked and tasted crappy.  I definitely felt guilty feeding my stomach with such poor quality food.

Although the restaurant may have catered to the Caucasians, I think that it still has cheated them of the Americanized Chinese food experience with the poor quality, extremely greasy, tasteless but expensive food they serve.  By the way, while we were there, one of their own waiters walked in with take out (which looked better and more delicious) from other restaurant and enjoyed it at one of the open tables.  This may not mean anything but I can't help but wonder why the Chinese waiter did not have the chef cook up something for him from the kitchen.  Panda Express is certainly better than this place.

I have eaten at many authentic Chinese restaurants in which the service was horrible but serve excellent dishes.  However, the lousy service at those places was nothing compared to the rude treatment that my party and other customers received here.  We were not served the drinks we ordered until I went up to the waiter to demand for our water and soda.  I was also yelled at by the rudest waitress ever when our soup came and I accidentally moved the bowl soups.  She yelled, "Don't move the bowls!".  IWe also saw the same waitress spill beer on another customer and instead of apologizing, she walked away!! 

In short, this place is not worth visiting despite of the number of stars it has received.  It is overhyped and the quality does not meet the price it charges.  Speaking of charges, the waitress has told us it's a cash only place (there was no sign at all in the restaurant, mind you) but I saw with my own eyes that she allowed credit card payment to a Caucasian customer!!  Not honest at all.

I normally have no complaint about the small space a restaurant is in, but I can't help but wonder if the place met the fire department regulation.
author: Annie C.

description:
Despite the fact that its touristy and deemed overly "visible" by some discerning locals, I happen to think that House of Nanking is just what I need in a Chinese Restaurant--a place where I can get good food without reaching the MSG LD50.

I'll tell you that Mongolian Beef, and Sizzling Beef are the best things on the menu.  If you don't want to take my word for it, Peter Fang, the man behind House of Nanking, will "take care of you," meaning that he will order something for you that you will undoubtedly enjoy.  You should take his world before mine, though, when you are looking for recommendations.  After all, he used to make all the food.
author: Thomas M.

description:
EXCELLENT food..the green onion pancake!
These people are here to sell food and feed you-well.They're not here to be your friend or provide some kind of validation to you and have you meander through a meal for an hour--the food is served PIPING hot because that's how it's meant to be eaten-hot!So do yourself a favor and eat it while it's hot.
I find them to always be accommodating and great with suggestions-ask them!
I think it's one of the best Chinese restaurants I've been to..but it is what it is..which is eat and go, there are others waiting ......so be polite to your fellow man...I'm not saying bolt your food and run,just don't whine about it if you read the reviews and know the drill.
You will LOVE the great food though
author: Chris D.

description:
What an original experience compared to LA Chinese food.

Lots of fun if you don't mind sitting next to strangers. 

BBQ pork egg rolls - 3
Noodle dish with the thicker type noodles and beef - 5
Sesame Chk - 4
Pot sticker - 5 (best I've ever had)

Will be hard to try a new Chinese place because this was so good and fun.
author: lance i.

description: House of Nanking is always a must have when I go home.  Personally I never trust a restaurant that has pictures of their dishes in the front window.   But I do trust a place that is always packed with a line around the corner.  I have never tried anything I didn't like...tea, fried tofu with peanut sauce, noodles it is all amazing.    You leave feeling satisfied with out the jacked up stomach Chinese food can give you at times. (Well me that is!)
author: Marie E.

description: Food was excellent. Price was very reasonable and lots of food. Service so-so but who cares when food is this good. Sesame chicken rocked and had sweet potatoes that were so good.
author: Tommy C.

description: Tasty. Especially crunchy rice soup thing.
author: Bollu P.

description:
House of Nanking, being a block from my old San Francisco office, was a favorite lunch spot for my coworkers and me. The food is excellent, elegant Chinese food -- definitely nothing you would find in your average take-out place. Here are some favorites I enjoyed over numerous visits:

Onion cake! The onion cake is genius. Flaky, sweet, tangy. Amazing. Eat it.
Any noodle dish -- they're all a little different and most can be made vegetarian. Peppery, cabbagey. Delightfully slurpy.

The downside of Nanking is that it is really popular. If you see the velvet rope outside, they're preparing for a rush. The service is quick, but the restaurant is small and crowded. It can get both hot and loud. But if you get there before the rush, you'll eat some amazing things.
author: Stevi C.

description:
Yelp says that 3 stars is "A-OK", while 2 stars is "Meh, I've experienced better." I think my real rating is 2.5, but I'll give the benefit of the doubt & round up.

I first went to House of Nanking a number of times about 1991-1994 or so. People were standing in line down the street, the dining room was cramped & a little grungy, but the food was awesome and inexpensive...I especially liked the Tsing Tao prawn dish, made with Tsing Tao beer. 

It's been a while, but I happened to be in the neighborhood and stopped in late on May 13, 2010. A good point is that they were open until 2200h, which is about 30-60 minutes later than restaurants in my neighborhood. The dining room has also doubled in size (they lost the counter & opened up next door) and there was no line that late. A number of people were eating, but no chinese folks. (bad sign?)

I was by myself & seated at a table for 6 with 2 people just finishing. I'm fine with the "community table" concept. The gentleman that came next left after he found out that everything on the menu contains MSG.

Tsing Tao prawns were no longer on the menu. I asked about them and were told that they would still make them for me. Great! I also ordered hot tea & a cup of rice. Too bad I was by myself, as I would have liked to try the house noodles and other dishes.

I first got an inkling that something might be amiss when I had to ask for chopsticks. Hmmm....catering to tourists? The Tsing Tao prawns arrived -- a bowl of zucchini with a few shrimp cocktail prawns (6 or 7?). The sauce was tasty, although I thought I could taste more MSG than Tsing Tao. But otherwise the dish was not as appetizing as when I had previously been to the House of Nanking (they opened in 1988). I was surprised when flower tea arrived in a beer glass...a little hot to hold. The cup of rice seemed OK.

I was a little shocked at the bill. $13.95 for the Tsing Tao prawns, and $2.95 for the tea! The cup of rice was 75 cents (within expectations).  When I ordered hot tea, I had expected it to cost about $1. The entree somewhere between $8.95 - 10.95.

With tax and tip, this ended being dinner for $21.....definitely not worth the price.

Wish I could have sampled some more dishes, but I'll probably won't be back.

By the way, they don't like to take credit cards. 

Longing for "the good old days"....   :-0
author: N. F.

description:
Went to San Francisco for my buddy Umair's birthday and came here on the recommendations of a dozen friends.  And, boy, they weren't kidding when they said this was the best Chinese food they've ever had!

No kidding, you sit down and they tease you with menus and then take 'em away only to say, "Okay, I take care of you..."  Next thing I knew, plates of delicious food were coming out and going into my belly.  A restaurant where you don't have to order, but they know what you want?  Count me in!

What makes this place so much fun is that you have no idea what's coming next.  It's like a constant barrage of surprises and tastes! 

I'd call this the most perfect restaurant in the world if I was also spoon fed, massaged, and provided with an easy-to-clean up happy ending.
author: Jimmy N.

description:
I can't believe this place averages only three stars!

The first time I came here was with a group of friends several years ago.  I remember waiting for a little while, nothing too unreasonable, and sitting shoulder to shoulder once seated.  It was a tiny little space.  The owner "took care of us" - I'm vegetarian so that didn't really work for me (I imagine it could, you just have to specify up front).

Most of their dishes have meat, but there are a few that don't - the eggplant (which I'm not a fan of in general) and the tofu.  The second time I returned, I ordered the tofu - which is excellent and I will get every time I go back! I can't imagine anything tastier.  I also ordered the egg-rolls, which are vegetarian.  They were delicious as well.    The space has been expanded in the last several years, or maybe they just weren't seating in the second room the first time I went.  You may share a large table with another party, but generally won't be eating shoulder to shoulder as previously.  

Fun area of town, very lively.  Great prices, delicious eats.  I'm a fan.
author: Anj M.

description:
This place is quite the experience. I had heard about it from my boss who raved about it so I wanted to check it out. We went there at around 730 on a Friday night. Seating was immediate but it was HOT inside. Not just stuffy...like, HOT. I read reviews about bad service but it seemed that the younger waitresses were all really nice. The older ones don't even give eye contact - at one point I wasn't sure she remembered she was at our table. However, we told her we liked chicken and beef and off she went. She brought back the best sesame chicken I have ever had. I mean...so good. She also brought some type of cut beef with tomatoes and onion which was good, but I'm not a big beef person so I don't know if I could rate it well. Back to the chicken...o-m-f-g. It was perfect. 

Aside from the food, the ambiance is very chinatown. You have to be prepared for a lot of tourists and a lot of not staring. For example, there were open windows in the front of the restaurant. People would walk by and literally put their head in the window to look at what you were eating. Thankfully we were not by the windows but we were entertained by the people who tried to pretend like nothing was happening so they could continue eating. I will try to upload an action shot of this happening, as it was the funniest thing I have ever seen.
author: Emily N.

description:
very, very horrific food.

i started coming to house of nanking in 1989. for years, this was the place for chinese in chinatown. it had about 4-5 tables and a few spots at the counter. the owner was a jerk and told you what to order, the place was dirty, but the food was fantastic and there was always a line out front albeit all non-chinese folks. 

so i took a few years off and came back today. the place has changed. it's covered in tile, much cleaner and triple the original size. service is about as it was - bearable. but, you come for the food, right?

not so. the food was H O R R I B L E. 

first, we ordered the onion cakes. they were deep fried FLOUR TORTILLAS with green onions (scallions) inside. there was a faint taste of peanut in the runny sauce. peanut butter mixesdwith terryaki sauce maybe? with some MSG? i ate 1/2 of a slice and was through. 

second, we ordered the lettuce cups. the menu described it as "zucchini, peas, onions in a garlic sauce on top of crispy rice noodles." we got zucchini, frozen peas, chopped tomatoes and chopped pineapple in our dish. pineapple? obscure! and the lettuce cups? nope. the waitress said they were out of lettuce and gave us "mu shu wraps" instead which were really FLOUR TORTILLAS again. we told her we did not want the dish without the lettuce, and she returned a few minutes later with unwashed lettuce purchased from up the street. 

third, we ordered the nanking special chicken served with sweet potatoes.  sauce was decent and dish as described on the menu, but the chicken was very fatty and bouncy and the cabbage on top was wilted and unappetizing. 

fourth, we ordered the house noodles. they were listed as thin mein noodles but tasted like boxed linguine. they had a shrmp paste/msg/sesame sauce to them. no one at our table could eat them. 

i was so embarrassed to have taken out of town friends to House of Nanking. they said "we want to eat chinese in chinatown!" and it was a huge mistake to chose House of Nanking. my guest said her coke was the best thing we had for lunch - just a can and a straw. 

there are so many great chinese restaurants in the city. i am from SF, i have travelled to china several times, my kids speak chinese - i am not clueless. i am prepared to pay more for less quality in the touristy part of town, but this lunch was inedible (AND overpriced AND without ambience AND with mediocre service). it pains me to say this, but i will never, ever return to House of Nanking. this is coming from someone who regularly craved the place and drove across town from the inner sunset to Kearny street for take home. 

if you want chinese food, travel to the sunset or the richmond districts and yelp a local place.
author: Irene I.

description:
I've been a repeat customer of House of Nanking since 2002.  When I can make it to San Francisco that is!

Yep, it's true that it is not true Chinese cuisine.  If you want that you aren't far from plenty to choose from.  But does have a great American/Chinese style in it's own.   It seems like the menu has become a bit more simple and you don't get the guy coming out changing your order.  The order Nazi I called him.   Yep tourists are coming but so are the locals.  And everybody seems to love it.  You can't go wrong here.  You won't get a lot of guidance from the service but really anything is good.  If you want to play it safe go for the steamed dumplings and the Orange Sesame with Sweet Potatoes.  I am not a Sweet Potato person, but I love these!
author: Bill C.

description: As soon as we sat down a server asked us for our order. It was our first time there. The servers were pushy the entire time, but when we needed things like water refills we had to ask at least three times. The food was good (sesame chix ok, eggplant in garlic sauce good, garlic fish great), but service was really lacking. They also pack ppl in like sardines there. Quite crowded.
author: Laura N.

description:
Cost/person to do it right: $20

So this place is a bit weird.  It's in Chinatown, but it's good Chinese food. I know, right?  Anyway, wait in the line, go in with a small-medium group, and don't order.  Instead, let Peter "take care of you."  You're just about guaranteed to get salt and pepper mushrooms and their sesame chicken w/ sweet potatoes, which are both very good, as well as a few other dishes.  He'll stop when you tell him or he's pretty sure you look full.  It's an excellent, stress-free experience with well above average food (esp. for the area).

Unfortunately, like just about everywhere else around there, it can be a bit sketchy outside, lines form, and parking sucks.  The service also tends to be relaxed/slow, but still very friendly.

Verdict: No complaints and several compliments.  Check it out if you're in the area.
author: Troy M.

description:
Overpriced tourist trap.

Half the food was pretty good and half just meh.  I might give the food three stars if it weren't so damn oily.  If you like your food to glisten and gleam under the trendy lighting, go for it.  I did like the eggplant side dish however, despite the glistening.

The service is so atrocious that it will either make you really mad, or laugh hysterically, depending on your mood.  I usually don't pay that much attention to service-  I really don't care if my server is abrupt or even rude, as long as they appear in the general vicinity of my table once in awhile so I can order a drink/pay my bill.  But at this place they only come to the table to drop off your food and then they literally RUN away so you can't ask them for anything.   You may be able to stammer out one request --water perhaps? or eating utensils? -but you only have time to pick one.  If you have more than one, (another beer? your check? a box?), good luck, I don't know.

However, I will say that I might still recommend this place if you actually are a tourist and are looking for a place to go with a group of friends and you don't care about getting ripped off for westernized Chinese food because you're just looking for a fun atmosphere.
author: L C.

description:
Ok. If you really, really want authentic Chinese food here is what you should look for:

1) Whole roasted duck and chicken steaming from being under heat lamps
2)  As many red furniture and decoration as possible. It's for good luck!
3)  Handwritten Chinese menu on the wall with the only understandable (to me anyway) characters being the cost. I'm SOOOO tempted to throw a dart at it and order whatever the dart falls on. =D
4) Free mystery soup with your meal. It seems like the soup is whatever leftover that they have in the kitchen - spinal cord, chicken feet, carrots, mystery meat - and then they boil the mess out of it. The soup itself tastes good if you don't think too much or look too closely at what's inside the soup.
5) Chili, soy sauce, vinegar, ground pepper condiments in little containers in the middle.
6) Freaky (to an American anyway) menu items: frog, pig intestine, sea cucumber, hairy mushroom, etc.
7) The waiters are there to take your order, give you food and drink and give you your check. That's it! Don't expect anymore from them. 
8) Sticky tables. Ewwww...

If you don't believe me just walk around Chinatown with the above checklist and see how many restaurants fit the checklist above. With that being said, House of Nanking has #2, #7 (although the waiters are a bit friendlier than my description), & #8 (sorta... but for the most part the tables were very clean). So, yeah, the food is Chinese but it's different. I want to say it's Americanized Chinese but it's not quite that either. 

I've been going here for years and the food has stayed consistently decent throughout that time. Here's the secret to getting a good meal: tell them what you want (I love beef. I don't like seafood. etc.), and how much you want to spend per person and they will definitely take care of you. Try the blossoming flower tea for an interesting show during dinner. They deliver the tea with a closed flower and it opens and blossoms during the course of your meal.
author: Don D.

description: Worth a trip. The food is good. Tell them you have never been there and the staff will order for you. Neat experience.
author: Hu Lee A.

description: Had a great lunch there, the waitress asked what we liked and came back with food for our table.  The seafood was cooked just right, everything was flavorful.  We would come back again.
author: K A.

description: This used to be my goto place for chinese food in SF. Their onion pancake is great, and so is the chow-mein. It has been falling in quality though, the mushu veggies used to be awesome, but now they are just ok...
author: Gautam G.

description: I know I keep saying I don't like Chinese food but this place was pretty good. Now, I don't know why everyone is obsessed with the sesame chicken you can pretty much fry anything and make it good.  The soup however was so so delicious I am still dreaming about since I have returned home from San Francisco. It was the perfect blend of coconut, rice and broth and I have been attempting to recreate it ever since. The other dish the stuffed mushrooms and shrimp (the salt and pepper version) was delicious and amazing as well.
author: Lindsay G.

description:
i just don't get it.  This place has been horrible for 2+ decades and, after my first visit there in 10+ years with out of towners who insisted on going there, it is still bad.  While the decor has been updated, all the wall decorations appear to be part of a shrine to "Fang", who I can only assume is the narcissistic owner.  

The service is non-descript, the deep fried food was "over-fried" and the sauce was flavorless. 

Somebody please explain to me why this place is an attraction.  i just don't get it.
author: Allan B.

description: The other reviewers hit the nail on the head when they expressed that the food here is definitely above-average Chinese fare, but hardly worth putting up with the lousy service. I feel like House of Nanking falls into the category of over-hyped restaurants that lose sight of decent service because there's always a line out the door anyway. I live in the neighborhood, and since their prices are very reasonable, I'll use them for take-out in the future, so I can enjoy the awesome food without the attitude.
author: Johnny W.

description: Genial. A developper
author: Julien D.

description:
This is the very worst sort of San Francisco tourist trap, long in the tooth and living on past glories when Orange Chicken was the height of Chinese cuisine in the US, all sugar and oil. It is telling that one sees almost no Chinese diners here.

The service varies from unctuous to patronizing and one is rushed to complete one's meal in unseemly fashion. The space is cramped, cluttered and reminiscent of the alleys behind most restaurants where one finds the dirty bric-a-brac of the kitchen trade.

With so many outstanding Chinese places in SF, and the Bay Area in general, why waste your life here? And the waiting in line with naive tourists is simply ludicrous.
author: Sempro S.

description:
Got lucky and sat down right away, And then watched a line form around the block. 
Sizzling rice soup was awesome, and though I may not have ordered a couple of the dishes that the chef recommended, having them just bring it all out family style and not having to decide what to order was fun.
Price was ok, a little cramped and grimey but new flavors for me which is awesome..
author: g f.

description: Great Food! I got the crisp noodles with veggies!!! One of the best Chinese food ever!
author: Cynthia G.

description:
If your looking for the best chinese food you ever had. 
The House of Nanking in my opinion is the best in the Bay Area.

The food is so good... it will leave you licking your lips on the way out.
No doubt... do not sleep on this joint. The line does get long and out the door..... but its well worth the wait. TRUST ME! 
You wont regret it.
author: Joseph J.

description:
I used to swear by this place. Granted they were running some renovations if I remember correctly, and it was always chaotic, messy, sacs of rice piled up everywhere, but the food was good, and it was impossible to wait patiently outside in line without drooling all over your shirt whilst staring down the people in the window with their mouths drenched in tasty tasty sauces...

This past Sunday we were craving Chinese food. Without even thinking about it we found ourselves outside this joint and decided to wait in the small line that formed outside. The people in front of us were raving about how they had driven into the city all the way from the peninsula just so they can eat here. The people behind me were SF residents. Given that demographic, I was sure the food would have been as tasty as it was 5 years ago.  I also wasn't expecting hoards of tourists.

Wrong about tourists. Wrong about taste. Wrong about HoN. The menu had very limited dishes. It didn't even list Mongolian beef. I wonder if it was just the menu they use on weekends or when tourists are in town? Possible?
We asked the boss of the joint if they did have Mongolian beef anyway to which he nodded. When it came out, it was a few pieces of beef sitting on this puffy, huge, gigantic bed of fried cellophane noodles. The vegetable of choice was a few string beans. My elephant memory remembers the "vegetable" bit to consist of more than just string beans
The un-cleanliness didn't bother me, as I never remember it being particularly clean. What I found particularly shady was the Sharpie-written sign that said "cash only today" Judging by the grease stain and dust glued to the sheet of paper, their today lives perpetually. 

It breaks my heart to realize that what had been my Chinese restaurant choice by default every time I craved Chinese food, is not even top 10 these days.
author: Eloïse A.

description: I thought this place was wonderful. I stumbled upon this place one of the first times I had come to San Fran. I walked in and I thought, oh boy this place is cramped. But what do I know, I'm from Visalia where there's plenty of room. But I came here with my mother, and we knew absolutely nothing about this place. We just picked some things off the menu that sounded good. And they were good. Some unique flavors, I really liked it. I've been here three times, and every time I've ordered the potstickers, that come with an awesome peanut sauce, sesame chicken that comes with killer sweet potatoes, the chow mien (??, excuse my spelling) that was minty, and some of the best blossoming green tea I've had in my life. I think the staff is a little confused, but hey, it was good food.
author: Kayla M.

description:
When I told my coworkers I was flying down to San Francisco for the weekend, they insisted I go here.  So I dragged my five friends over, and it didn't disappoint! They made me believe in tofu again. They found potsticker perfection. The chow mein was laden with delicious stir-fried veggies and fat, freshly made noodles. 

Be warned, we did need to wait in line for a seat so it's not fast food, but it was worth it. Thanks, coworkers!
author: Cassie W.

description:
The situation was as follows: We needed something quick and dirty (I had a flight back to New York to catch), but we didn't really want it to be that dirty. Being a New Yorker, I'm sort of incredulous when I'm told there is anything remotely acceptable as far as Chinese food goes outside of New York City, but thank God my friend knew what was in order. 

As we walked up to House of Nanking, we were placed behind a velvet rope-type thing to wait and the hostess assured us that we'd be seated in a matter of minutes. She wasn't kidding. We were seated quickly, served quickly and given the check without asking quickly. It's very efficient, but in a good way. 

My two friends and I shared the fried calamari (which was so-so, but semi-chewy, so I'd say pass on that), the sesame chicken (which was great) and the stuffed mushrooms (which I had never had in Chinese food form before, but were delicious and something unique). We also each ordered a "serving" of rice which came in a massive heap, so they don't skimp on portions here. The prices are pretty reasonable, and we had some Tsingtao to go with our food, so it was a complete experience.  

The atmosphere is that of a very busy, popular and great Chinese restaurant. People running everywhere, overall high decibel-range and little in the way of friendly service, but I know that's not the reason to come here. So I am redeemed and have learned that yes, you can get good Chinese food outside of NYC. Thanks for that, Nanking. I'll be back.
author: Justin S.

description:
I would have rated this much higher as everytime in the past i have gone it has been almost perfect. The lines never bothered me nor the cheap look of the place.

My problems is the last 2 times i was in there my blessed sesame chicken and salt and pepper calamari were not the same. The calamari was not as crisp and was a bit chewy which shocked me. It just seems like maybe they are letting their standards slack
author: Easy G.

description: I have to say this is one of the worse places I have been.  Service is bad. And the price is way over rated  the food is nothing like I was expecting. I'm really disappointed and I want my money back :'(
author: Faboo H.

description: Very touristy place. Food is average. They have two sets of menus. Be sure to ask for authentic Chinese food menu, otherwise you'l just have Americanized Chinese food.
author: Danlu H.

description: The food was awesome - this was my first chinese restaurant in SF - they just asked if we were hungry and brought out a bunch of food - it was very crowded, but we were there for the Chinese New Year...
author: Steve N.

description:
For a hole in the wall, this is the best I've ever had. The best calamari EVER! A must have. I think it's the vinegar sauce that makes it so good.

Plan on the servers ignoring you..it's part of the charm.
author: Loren P.

description:
Okay so i'm a fan....Loved the Lemon Rice Soup! However our experience was much less then fantastic

The service blows. We ordered 6 dishes for 6 people, family style was the originally thought...BUT received one dish at a time! 

Again food is good, but I recommend this for dinner with 2 maybe 3 at most... but yeah, check it out.
author: Vivian G.

description: If you like long waits, mediocre food, dirty surroundings and crowds of tourists then you might like House of Nanking. I'd read something about it being good and we'd been walking by and seeing the lines for a few years when we decided to give it a try. Big mistake. All the food seems to be drowning in plum sauce, it's expensive, you have to sit elbow to elbow with strangers, the list goes on. We had a dish that required assembly and the owner (host, kitchen manager?) started assembling it without even asking if we knew how or if we wanted him touching our food after he'd been handling dirty menus and dishes. Gak. The people next to us found a hair on one of their plates and asked for a clean one, their food came before the clean plate showed up and they had to wait far too long for that clean plate. This place is a joke, we could hardly wait to get the heck out of there.
author: Elaine S.

description:
The food is great, but I cant say the food is somewhat excellent compared to the actual shanghai and cantonese cuisine, but guess what. You can hardly fins them in USA. So i highly suggest your visit the restauran and tell Fang(the owner) where you are from and he will make his special menu for you.
The teas are both great
author: Darren G.

description:
Chinese...but with a twist. Let's just say that I had a dish that included tortillas-definitely a first! Let them choose your food for you and you'll be a fan. Service is quick, I can see why people may not say friendly--but tends to be a lot friendlier, if again, you let them pick for you. I usually have a hard ass time picking what I want anyway, so I don't mind!

Oh also let us come in just minutes before closing and didnt rush us one bit.
author: Afton T.

description: My parents love this place, I think it is great if your walking by. The server didn't really understand our order and consequently decided to bring out whatever he wanted. If your easy going, that's great. If you go in for something specific, make sure he clearly understands your order.
author: Hayley H.

description: One of my friends suggested this place, and he said the best thing to do is ask what's best to get. I did just that, and got the orange chicken, couldn't have been happier. Such a friendly staff. Good service!
author: Melissa D.

description:
This place got me all excited....until we sat down. The waitress tossed the menu on the table. Granted, I know it's busy and she has a ton of tables....she doesn't have to start our experience off with a "bang". Anyway, I read the reviews about the sesame chicken. Our friend with us told the waitress to just find some stuff for us to eat....so they brought out the sesame chicken as well as some other dishes. They weren't my fave, as was the sesame chicken. 

All in all, I would've given it 4 stars, but the waitress took forever with the check as well. Bad wait staff.
author: Stina I.

description:
Hmm...  I don't get it.  Ignoring the fact that everyone in the restaurant is non-Asian, and ignoring the other Yelpers' warning that this is a tourist trap, I came here for lunch with a couple of co-workers.  I had the salt and pepper mushrooms.  It was nothing special.  The mushrooms were whole and not too flavorful.

So many places around Chinatown to choose from.  Haven't decided if I would go there again if I was on my own.
author: Yuan W.

description: No No No I don't want to be squished in the middle of a bunch of strangers where I have to sit and stare at how they eat and hear about their life's woes. It was uncomfortable and annoying. The food isn't even that great!
author: Debbie J.

description: I really enjoy eating at this joint. There is almost always a line, but I am continuously amazed by how quickly the staff gets people in and out and manages to accomodate big groups. You can order off the menu, or even better, just tell them what you like and what you don't and they will serve you dish after dish of delicious Chinese food according to your guidelines. Fun and tasty.
author: Mo A.

description:
Hmmmmm, One thing I can say about House of Nanking, "AMAZING" the crispy sesame chicken is to die for as well as the prawns. Every time we go with 6 people or more Peter the owner waits on us, he just does his thing. the waitress does not even bring a menu, a sheer plus....

Why you ask, ??

Well, he wants to give you one hell of a meal, it's a sampling of everything you can imagine. Delightful my Mom is coming next week and she loves this type of tasty and wonderful food. It's going to be a treat.

I always love going to HON. any day or evening no matter when you go you know its going to be good, friendly and fun.

The staff always attentive, the cooks 2 thumbs up, and Peter keep doing what you do, 

This is a great place for clients, a date or even a weekly or monthly place to enjoy a great meal. Always amazing,

And many Thanks to the many people who make the food.
author: William B.

description: Is it dirty? Yes.  Is the service rude? Yes. Is it an incredibly long wait sometimes? Yes.  So why the high rating? Because the food is GREAT!  Granted, I haven't been in a while but can't wait to return - I always ended up with an amazing, inventive fish dish from Peter. I loved the Nanking chicken, sizzling vegetables & onion cake but it was especially fun to have Peter make an off the menu dish for you...assuming he's still there :)
author: Sandra Q.

description:
Ugh!  I was there 12 years ago and thought the dumplings were awesome.  Today, not so much.

Decor improved leaps and bounds.  Service, you don't go for chinese food for service.  Food sucked big time.  We ordered the dumpling with sauce, house noodles, friend tofu and sesame chicken.  Dumpling was aight, skin was a bit thick for my taste.  Noodles were tasteless and soggy.  Now the fried things, were downright wrong.  Tofu was fried beyond fried and the peanut sauce tasted nothing with peanuts.  Now the sesame chicken was ick!  It was like fried 3 times, it was hard to chew and it tasted like burnt popcorn with a sweet and hot sauce.  Can't taste the chicken people. Panda express at the mall can do it better. 

Now here is the killer part, my friend was flipped and still won't let it go.  THE RICE!  It tasted like 3 day old rice.  We have never had such big clumped rice.  

Not nice.......
author: germaine n.

description:
If you need or want wait staff to make you feel special, this is not the place for you.

If you want excellent food period (I struggle to call this Chinese), GO.  

Walk in and hold up the number of fingers for each person in your party.  Whomever sees you will point to a table (which may bump elbows with a random stranger), take it, sit and review the menu.  If you have a question, most of your fellow patrons will be happy to help.  We have not been disappointed on any food item.  Yes, the woman who takes your order will make suggestions and may even order for you.  You can choose to be pissed off or go with it.  My favorite dishes are ones she recommended (or a random table suggested).  It's an experience.  Highly recommend:  Sizzling rice soup, house noodles, pork dumplings, calamari, sesame chicken, beef wraps.  Blooming tea is fun (when it blooms), wine is about as inexpensive as you will find.  Enjoy the experience and fall in love with the food.  It is excellent.
author: Michele L.

description:
I stood at the velvet ropes 30 minutes before closing time on Sunday night (9:30pm).  It was as if we were trying to gain entry into an exclusive night club.  I was paranoid that we would not be let in, that we would approach the door at 9:31pm and be turned away in disgust.

At 9:29pm, we reached the front door and eagerly awaited the next available table.  After being seated, we quickly decided on five items to be shared between the three of us. 

Even though the reviews here are almost universally positive, I was not impressed with the food.  We started out with little chinese burritos that had some type of beef and cabbage inside.  They were sweet.

We also ordered the pot-stickers, which were awesome.

We ordered chili eggplant, which was sweet.  Also, we ordered the famous sesame chicken, which was sweet.  (Can you see the theme.)  Contrary to the experience of other reviewers, our sesame chicken was not crispy; it was quite soft.  And sweet.

Finally, we had the garlic noodles, which were very good.

I think that I will have to give this place another try and order something else, just to make sure they weren't having an off day.  But until then, I say this place is Meh.
author: Adam R.

description:
12:45PM: Inside House of Nanking
12:46PM: Menu's arrive
12:46 1/2 PM: Waiter asks what we want in a hastily  fashion. Okay I get it, asian lady wants us  IN and OUT (we order right away)
12:51 PM: Food comes. holy shit that was fast.
10:00 PM: Still burping this shit up!

Good tasting food.  Ridiculously oily. "House Noodles" are oil slicked noodles in a bowl of grease with awesome flavors of basil. 

Go in there with a strong stomach & no expectations of "service" (which is fine by me). Saved me three dollars on the tip =)
author: Jess V.

description:
I was visiting San Francisco and my friend recommended House of Nanking. My family and I were sorely disappointed.

I usually find it charming when the owner says "This is your first time? Trust me; I'll order for you." But in this case, when the owner ordered for our table of four, we ended up paying at least 25% more than we expected and wasting a lot of food.

Turns out, that seemed to be his trick to get you to order (and PAY) more for your dinner there. He sent out at least two more dishes than my table actually wanted or desired.

I also felt the menu was limited, as we were craving a more traditional menu, and too few of the dishes stood out. The one good review I'll give is for the thick and hearty hot & spicy soup. It made my mom smile.
author: Amanda D.

description:
Wacky place.... Great food.

The first time I came here was for lunch and it was friggin packed.... PACKED! You have to share tables sometimes with other folks cause thats how they roll in Nanking apparently. No big deal, but interesting. The guy came over and asked if we had ever eaten there before, since we had not, he proceeded to rattle off a bunch of stuff we would be eating and off he went. A few minutes later.... boom... some damn good food landed on the table as if it were out of the ether.

Next time I went we arrived later in the evening somewhat near closing, same outcome. It was all cooked to perfection, just to the point where it is not raw anymore, very fresh with no soggy overcooked vegetables. No thick gooey sauces, just very flavorful healthy food.

I am only in San Francisco a couple times a year, but it is now a destination for me. We don't have Chinese food this good that I can find in SoCal. I wish I could remember what I ordered, but it was a couple weeks ago and I just wanted to make sure people new this place existed.
author: Court P.

description:
Um, I just wanna throw my two cents on top of the 800+ other yelpers.

1) The homemade egg noodles topped with greens and garlic were so authentic that they reminded me of Shanghai and the man on the corner who made pulled noodles by hand and then served them in broth. Noodles ARE the meal, not the stuff floating around in them. These won my mouth hands down. Could kill the extra oil though. 

2) The tofu in black bean sauce was savory but didn't come with any other veggies. It was boring in its lack of variety but tasty.

This place is always packed and has a line out front. This is not necessarily a bad thing. You get to chat with your date, eyeball the other patrons and tell the newbies the scoop.

THE SCOOP:
Generally, when the waitstaff comes to your table they are not there for niceties. They may not even be nice.

If you want you can order like this, "first time here, we are vegetarians, no more than $30 please". You will get whatever they think is good. It will be great. 

Don't plan on sitting long after your meal. It probably took a while to get it which means the people outside are chewing their nails to the quick. Besides, if you overstay your welcome, you might find you get bumped a lot by the servers, no, really. 

If you have time afterwards, walk west on Washington street past Grant to Spofford Alley. Stop in front of #36, the red building on your left, with the Chinese Freemasons insignia above the door. Turn on your ears. All that racket? the clicking of mah jong tiles!
author: Miel H.

description: Kathy. ..The food was good, but left a horrible after taste after what happened.  I was there on vacation from an  8 hour drive ..trying to enjoy myself with the family and it was just plain wrong what your staff did...I am seriously thinking of contacting the BBB...my kids all felt harrassed!!!!
author: Isela C.

description:
I just got back from a trip to San Francisco and this was one of the places that my boyfriend was told to check out.  Apparently, the food was supposed to be amazing. 

We were the first ones there, before they opened at 11 so we were there to see more people arrive.  First off, they throw the menus on the table and give you some sort of hand gesture to sit.  If this would have happened to one guest, then perhaps it was ok, but being the first ones there, we quickly noticed that they did that to everyone.  Our service was decent, the wait to get our food took a bit, but overall, it was ok. 

The sesame chicken was good, I don't know about amazing.  I ordered chow mein and the server told me to get the flat noodles instead, they were better.  I doubt they were.  They were topped with some sprouts and the flavor was just... interesting.

Overall, it was ok.  I would have been upset if we had to wait.  Maybe my review is biased because we only ordered two dishes, but at least the beer was good.  They couldn't have screwed that up.

I'm giving them two stars because the food was ok, but the service weighs this place down.
author: Andy G.

description: Attention New Yorkers visiting San Francisco! This restaurant features surly, but very efficient, service, reasonable prices and, most importantly, AMAZING Chinese food! You will feel right at home! The Sesame Chicken is not to be missed!
author: Christopher J.

description:
Man, this place is GOOD. Like, seriously good. We told our server, on the advice of others, to just bring us whatever was good. This was a fantastic idea.

We got two dishes, and both were finger lickin delicious. The salt and pepper shrimp with red onion and basil was as beautiful as it was tasty, and the tofu in black bean sauce was the best I've ever had. The perfect mix of fresh, exotic flavors and just the right amount of oil and sugar we all know Chinese food has but don't like to admit it. 

We had a plane to catch later, but couldn't bear the thought of wasting any of our meal that we had it wrapped up and devoured round two mid-flight.

The only reason I'm not giving 5 stars is because it's a little pricey. Just a little though, and really, so worth it. HOLY YUM.
author: Betsy R.

description: Nothing special. This was recommended by a few people but I wasn't overly impressed.
author: Top K.

description: If you are looking for great customer service, don't come here. If you want banging noodle dishes and don't mind the absense of a smiling wait staff, this a solid bet of a good meal.
author: Adrienne F.

description:
The FXXXin' Rachael Ray came here and eat the Shit, $40/day show on TV few years back.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mkiC01FqWbo&feature=related

Rachael Ray is American version of Yan can cook.
She is so lame.
She knows Nothing about cooking and she is nothing but a big mouse $10 Bj for crying out loud. 

Wake-up white people! 
House of Nanking is killing your sense of flavor!!!

Tell me why this place is popular?
Sweet deep fried, I saw Roaches. Dirty sticky tables.
I wonder how their kitchen is like.
This place is a dump.
Food is screwed up.
Overly-sweet and heavy.
It's just sweeter and deep fried.
Typical Americanized Chinese.

Real Chinese food is Nothing like it.
I don't think this place is special.
I don't get it.
I can not go there again.
So FXXXedUP!

Ken k said, "Well there you go, she's the $40 BJ girl."

It was a TV show called $40/day. not a porn.

But, Who wants to pay 40? Anyone?
I'll pass on that.

Tsada K said, 
"I think $40 is what she charges for the BJs she gives behind the Food Network dumpster at night."

OhYeah!!! No wonder the owner guy kept sayin' "I'll take care you!"

Btw, Lolia S asked, "Didn't you review HON before?  It's awful!"

Yes, i did, but this is the original review before edited.
author: Nobu K.

description: New Favourite in San Francisco! The restaurant is quick and inexpensive with great portions. If I had another night I would have gone back for dinner again and tried the tiger prawns with mushrooms. All the dishes were flavourful and consistent. Definitely worth the wait if you want traditional Chinese with a hint of fusion.
author: Sabine C.

description:
I simply love the place. The food is great (delicious sesame chicken with caramelized sweet potatoes...). The service is nice without being obsequious.
Great place to share dishes among friends and discover new tastes.
author: Brice R.

description: This food is excellent. The waiters/waitresses can be hella rude, but if you know that going in, you'll be fine. I have taken all out-of-town guests here and they all love it. I am not a fan of Chinese food, but love love the food here!
author: Jasmine B.

description:
Probably one of the best chinese food I have ever had. 

The onion pancake yummmmmmmm! 

Chicken and fish dishes were super excellent... THe way the fish was cooked was really amazing. 

Unfortunately if you like to choose from a menu is this not the place for 
you. The Chef does it.  And does it real good. 

Its a hole in the wall, but a real good hole!
author: Kiran N.

description:
I ate here a few times when I used to live in SF (and YES I lived in SF! Not in SJ, Fremont, San Bruno, South SF, etc.....). I lived downtown SF!

Anyways., I was never that impressed with Nanking so I decided to give them another try.

Sesame Chicken is their special so I ordered that with a hot tea.

The sesame chicken tasted great. The chicken was cooked perfectly with yummie sauce that goes perfect with steamed white rice. The accompanying sweet potatoes were a nice touch.

So why only 3-stars?  
-- They charge you $1 for steamed rice. How the heck are you supposed to eat your sesame chicken with? No asian restaurant shold charge for white rice!
-- The service sucks! The only time anyone came to my table was to take my order and bring out my food. 
-- Most people rave about this place as a great budget place but $15 for sesame chicken, steamed rice, and hot tea is not budget.. 

I think House of Nanking has great tasting food and it's a place worth trying but it's not as memorable as people make it out to be. It'd be a good place to go with other so you can eat family style.
author: Byoung Kyu S.

description:
I ate here based on a coworker's recommendation - I'm so glad I did! I walked from my hotel at Market/4th, which was nice and level - you get to the restaurant right before Kearny becomes a giant hill.
It's loud and packed, but totally worth it. My friend and I were sat in between two other 2-person tables, which was interesting at first, but you get used to it. The food was delicious - we got the house noodles and sesame chicken. With the dumplings we got as an appetizer, we couldn't finish! It's a lot of food, especially the noodle bowl.
Highly recommended!
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Looking for authentic, high quality Chinese restaurant with a comfortable atmosphere and reasonable prices? ..... You may want to look elsewhere. Perhaps a friend over-hyped this place for me, but I just want not feeling it. It felt super touristy and service was notedly not their specialty. I've had better quality Chinese food at better price points. 

I have heard that this place can be hit or miss, and unfortunately my first impression was a miss. Maybe next time, folks.
author: Michelle C.

description: Probably the best Chinese food I have ever had. The owner stopped by as we were deciding on food and just took the reigns family style. He didn't disappoint. Steamed pork rolls, to shrimp, sesame chicken, to beef, to noodles, and on...  Excellent food and service.
author: M U.

description:
This place was on my to-eat list for quite sometime, but then it got closed down for health inspection/remodel (this is some years past), and when it re-opened, it was as popular and exciting as ever.  

This is a really good, tasty place, but once you've done it, I don't think you need to wait in line for more (and there is reliably always a line).  Sure, sure, bring your friends when they visit, but I'm saying once you've done it, it won't be as tasty the next time and it won't be worth it to stand in line if you're ravenous. Two other suggestions I have are R&G Lounge and Honk Kong Clay Pot (now we're talking). Do the price fix at Clay Pot.  I'm mostly sad it's become less of a locals spot and more touristy. 

2 things
- get the FLOWERING hot tea
- have Peter order for you - the whole meal.  don't be shy, and don't be a baby.  it's not going to be that adventurous of food, but if you think it is, then it's high time you tried "new food," especially chinese food.  It will be like $20/ person.
author: Leia K.

description:
House of Nanking was the place to go........ in the '90s. It was less than half the size it is now, twice as dirty and the line to get in wrapped around the corner. The food was different, inventive sauces and ingredients giving traditional dishes a new perspective.... and then the tourists found out about the place.
Since then, they've modernized and expanded the space. The service is still pretty much what it was back then (expect your appetizer to show up 20 minutes after you've finished your meal), but the food does not live up to the memories of the '90s. As people have mentioned numerous times, many dishes use the same, or similar sauces, so when you go in it is best to know what you want and not let the owner order for you. unfortunately, this will often be met with a snide attitude...

I wouldn't avoid going back to the House of Nanking as long as there was no wait and someone in my party had requested going, but I'm not likely to pop in of my own accord anytime soon...
author: J. Scott H.

description: Sesame chicken with sweet potatoes was the best dish we've had in all of San Francisco on our vacation. Five spices pork chops and house noodles also great. Only downside is a party of 2 can end up sitting with strangers.
author: John S.

description:
I had a friend of mine in LA suggest that I go here as it was her favorite place in all of Chinatown. I went and have to say that I really don't understand what all of the hype is about. I am a huge fan of tiny, hole in the wall places, so I wanted to like this place a lot, but it didn't do it for me. Having said that, the place is always packed, so maybe I'm just missing something. 

Seating is community style, the servers were bristly and the food (although plentiful) didn't knock my socks off. It was good, but not great. I feel I need to revisit it to see if I went on an off night, but overall it was just ok in my book.
author: Angela M.

description:
I really like the salt & pepper fried tofu I had here. Its the dish I often think about when I think about wonderful Chinese tofu dishes. I can't say I felt the same about the vegetable dishes we ordered, they were good but maybe not best I have ever had. Don't bother ordering from the menu. At House of Nanking, you simply tell the owner, "I'd like tofu (or meat, or chicken) and he'll whip up something that will make you happy. I like how they can make pretty much anything on the menu vegetarian. Very impressive!

Also the fried tofu dishes have the most perfect texture; crispy (not oily) on the surface and all melty, soft in the middle.House of Nanking takes Chinese cooking to a whole other level. The servers are sort of snippy and rude but the good food makes that OK with me.
author: Shannon Z.

description: I've come here 4 times over the past ten years.  I'm okay with the horrible service, they had amazing food.  This time was different, they changed, the menu and food.  It was horrible!  After hyping this place up to my girlfriend and the endless, amazing places to dine in SF, it was such a letdown!
author: Jaime C.

description:
To sum up everything I CAN say about this place, let me be brief and say just one thing:

The last time I was there, there was a used and crumpled up paper towel in the bowl of white rice, all cooked in like.  Wait, but the real kicker? Our waiter wasn't the least bit appalled, or even terribly apologetic. 

Spoke volumes...
author: Nikki F.

description: Food absolutely wonderful. Seating tight. Difficult to understand that everything is is a la carte. But we got past all that once the food arrived.
author: Janette M.

description: Great food but terrile service. Could not get any servers attention for refills on drinks. Dont ask questions because if your not ready to order they will walk away. Staff was not friendly
author: Andrew S.

description: Definitely liked the family style feel of this place.  On a recent trip we ordered the potstickers, shrimp, sesame chicken, rice soup, and rice.  My favorite dishes were probably the sesame chicken and the shrimp dish.  The potstickers were good but felt like something you could get anywhere, and the soup was a tad salty.  The delicious sesame chicken and shrimp made up for it though!  I love that the sesame chicken comes with sweet potatoes too, soo good!  They also have good house red and white wines, especially for the price.  I recommend getting here before 7pm for dinner, since it really seems to fill up after that time.
author: Kathleen F.

description:
This place is terribly over rated!!! I get it, its in North beach and occasionally some one famous will come in, but let me tell you everything from the service, to the food, to the ambiance is bad. We had a group of 4 and thankfully there was no wait as we showed up at just the right time. We ordered the following:
Plum wine - This shit is delicious! BIG problem was that they did not have a bottle and when we asked to order a bottle they gave us no option other then saying it wasnt available in a small size only the $64 large size... WTF? If they cared about service they are easy solutions to this problem.
Chicken Mu shu - OK this is crazy. I love mu shu, and one reason I do is because it supposed to come with plum sauce. This Mu shu cam dry with only rice  wraps. Also the mix of veggies they use was strange.
Sesame chicken - Very good. By far the best thing we ordered.
Veggie Chow mien - pretty good nothing special
Beef fried rice - was not good, just not.

So the food was so so. The service was terrible. A nice man sat us and took our drink orders and then a woman took over for the food  and the rest of our visit. She was moody and inhospitable. Our food all cam out at different times which made enjoying dinner as a group and celebrating my friends Birthday difficult. This was especially difficult for my friend who is a vegetarian because two dishes came out that she couldnt eat before hers arrived 15 minutes later. The waitress missed the appetizer I ordered but that was probably for the best.

By the end of the night my guy friend was nauseous and indeed had to pull over while driving because he felt so ill. I believe a small bout of food poisoning followed. I would never go here again. There are plenty of great places in North Beach (Brandy Ho's was next door) and absolutely fantastic places in China town which is like three blocks away.
author: Vero V.

description:
I really want to like this place.  It really screams out -- please love me and come back again!  There's a line out the door, the staff is mildly entertaining, the service is relatively good.  I really want to say enthusiastically -- "YES! I LOVE YOU TOO!" but, this relationship fell short of a connection.

Well, you may ask, what is the missing piece?  What caused the lack of a love connection?  And the good o' and true -- "WHY DON'T YOU LOVE ME BACK?!"  Please allow me to explain.

First of all, upon closer inspection, this place is a tourist trap.  I would say at least 80% of the people who were dining were from out of town.  Yes, they've had celebrity chefs like Jamie Oliver and Rachel Ray to visit and eat their food.  That should be enough of an endorsement to say their food is great.

Ah, there's the sore spot!  Let's go further -- It's the food!  I do agree, they do use fresh ingredients -- they get away by throwing fresh basil into every dish.  The party that I dined with left the food order up to the owner.  What an opportunity to take advantage of those who have no clue how to order!  We had a total of 8 dishes for a party of 6.  

With the exception of the stir-fried sugar snap peas, everything else was either fried or completely drowned in this syrupy sweet sauce.  We were fed well, but I definitely felt a ball of lard forming in one corner of my stomach as the meal progressed.

Well, that couldn't have been too bad -- but here's to add insult to injury, the bill came out to $180 (including tip).  $30/person?!  For mediocre "fusion" chinese food?!  I don't think so.  I've dined better on $30/person at any other chinese restaurant with a full banquet meal which included jelly fish and other exotic dishes that were not fried and drowned in syrup.

I'll have to say House of Nanking, you might be a beacon of light for out of towners but you're no home in my book.
author: Mei C.

description:
4 stars for overall experience....every dish was up to par. Just sit yourself down and soak in the smells and sounds.

5 STARS for their sweet potatoes - def the most memorable part of the meal and a must have. Slightly crispy on the edges with a sweet delicate sauce. Too bad they don't have this dish a permanment side item! It's only available as part of the sesame chicken order...
author: Charlene A.

description:
I really enjoyed my dinner here. It was packed full, but we only had to wait about 5 minutes to be seated (and it would have been considerably less if our party had been smaller). The service was a little confused at first, but not about anything important. We had to ask for water 3 times and somehow wound up with 5 glasses for 3 people. But they made up for that by bringing our food incredibly quickly.

And the food was wonderful. The sesame chicken was, as other commenters have said, the best I've ever had. I would also recommend the house noodles. I would even recommend the melt-in-your-mouth fried calamari, and this is coming from someone who has a pretty strict "no mollusc" policy (exceptions usually involve chowder with bacon).

All-in-all, it was an excellent experience. Contrary to what other commenters have said, despite the packed house and high turnover rate, I never felt rushed. And after a few communication difficulties were resolved, the service was quite good. The prices are not terribly cheap, but for what you get, it's a fantastic deal.

One note - all the dishes I had were very heavy on the garlic. This wasn't a problem for me, as I love garlic, but that might not be the case for others.
author: Morgan M.

description: Just the owner makes it the best. Why look at the menu when you'll get the perfect dish just by asking what they recommend or more important what they can bring you. The flower blossom tea is also very refreshing and pleasant,
