author: John R.

description:
I've Been here a couple of times when I was young and remember it being this great Chinese food place.
I  always drive by and see this place packed with crowds waiting outside.. 
So I wanted to try it again..
We got here around 11:40 am and there was hardly anyone in here and we sat down and they didn't even give us menus or water..
5 minutes go by and i get the menus myself.
Nobody took or order for like 20 minutes.
It took forever (like 50 minutes) to get our food..
The garlic fish is amazing!! Best fish  at a Chinese food I've ever eaten.
So if you like great service DO NOT COME HERE..But if you can honestly not give a damn about service and know that the food here is great than i suggest coming here.
author: Isabella E.

description:
Dropped in here for dinner.  I hadn't eaten here in 5 years due to a move across the country.  I was looking forward to the colorful mugs and good service I had the last time I ate here. Guess 5 years changes things.

The fried calamari wasn't quite melt in your mouth (it was a bit chewy) but it was lemony and spicy--both good things.

The fried tofu I ordered was ok. The black bean sauce was the winner in that dish.

Even though the food was tasty, the service was substandard. I sat for at least 10 minutes before I flagged someone down to pay for my dinner. They weren't that busy--at least not that busy with customers. Rather, the talked behind me for the entire 40 mins I was there without regard to anyone else. Rude is just one word I could use. I won't even go into the rude girl who 'greeted me' witha gruff "one? Sit here" too ba I didn't get the other girl who was very nice and personable.  

Oh and the stars? For the service alone.
author: Lorie W.

description:
Skip the noodles - they're just too plain, try everything else.  

The dishes here taste great!  Try the squid.
author: jump h.

description: Came here after the Chinese New Year parade since it was right behind where all the tv stations were. Good thing I went here early so the line wasn't too bad.  The only reason I went here was because it had really good ratings on Yelp and it was really close to where we were standing.  It's a really small place. Only one person could walk thru the aisles at a time. The waiters had to wait for each other to go first before they can go. I should have known it wasn't good from the moment I stepped inside. It was full of foreigners.  Not a single Asian, not to mention Chinese person in sight.  Me and my peeps were the only Asian people there. The line started forming right after we got seated.  And again, only foreigners. The waitress pushed the special fish soup that's not on the menu, and we order the sesame chicken and calamari. The calamari was my fave out of the three.  However, it was not "melt in your mouth" as it claims on the menu.  The sesame chicken was really salty, and not as good as Panda's Express orange chicken. The soup (I still have no clue what it was) was very funky tasting.  The fish was not fresh, the broth was white like milk and had a lemony taste to it, and there was way too much vermicelli in it. If you're really asian, I don't think you'll enjoy this place.  It's seems more like a tourist trap. Skip the lines and go somewhere else.  Plenty of real Chinese food in Chinatown.
author: Yenn T.

description: AWESOME! We got there about 9:00 on a saturday night and there was a HUGE line! But we only had to wait about 20 min. to be seated, The place was crowded but the food was great! We order the hot and sour soup (delicious!) Sesame chicken (also delicious, better than the soup!!!!) steamed rice, always good, and pot stickers and egg rolls (they were okay) but the peanut sauce was pretty good. The best thing we ordered though was the house chow mein. Not your ordinary type of chow mein but boy was it good. We even ordered extra. The staff were friendly and attentive. I will definitely be going again!
author: Cristina G.

description:
I went here with some friends visiting and the line was actually enjoyable.  Nothing wrong with standing outside for a minute and catching up before you stuff your mouth so full you can't be bothered with conversation.  We went family style and let one of our party who knew the menu well handle the order.  Everything we got had no chance of survival.  I felt like a caged wolf.  The service has no time for small talk and I kind of like that.  On the way out, I couldn't resist snatching up one of their super fresh black hoodies!  I'll be back very soon with an appetite!  

ps After dinner suggestions:  Spec's or Bow Bow Lounge for some stir fried karaoke!
author: kevin t.

description:
I love House of Nanking!!! It's much nicer since the last time I was there, and now they have menus, which is nice. Cramped tables, and you always end up talking to the people next to you, if not sharing each other's dishes.  Sizzling rice soup was good - very fresh veggies, with lemon zest. Fried eggplant in black bean sauce was almost like a great dessert - eat it all right away, when the texture is at it's crispy zenith. Sesame Nanking Chicken comes with thinly sliced sweet potato and a cabbage salad topped with a lite ginger dressing.  Sweet, savory, gorgeous, and complete. Tried a beef bao wrap that was surprising tender and good (presentation was lacking). All in all, not the same hole in the wall, aggro-service, street food gem that I remembered, but still pretty awesome.  Four and a half stars, but gave it five due to the miracle parking spot that opened up right in front of restaurant as I pulled up. Go Irish!!

P.s.  Just remembered that I totally forgot to order the crispy onion cakes. Damn Tsing Tao!!
author: Sean N.

description: Excellent Chinese dive.  Everything on the menu is good.  Ignore the owner, his attitude and the lack of proper restaurant hygiene.  Pretend you're somehwere in China, eat a few different dishes and drink a few Tsingtao beers.  I think they have ALWAYS included the tip, but since I don't read/write Chinese, I'm not so sure.  Want Indian lunch buffet?  Go next door to Tandoori Mahal.
author: Anthony D.

description:
Eat here once and you will never forget it. In a good way. I came here by myself the first time and had such a great time that I brought my friends here the next night.

Despite the noticeable number of guidebook clutching tourists and eerie absence of local Chinese, the food is top notch. The dumplings were exquisite, and having grown up in a Chinese family and traveled all across Asia, I'd have to say that these are probably in my Top 3. The sauce is delightfully tangy, with a touch of vinegar and a hint of sweetness. The beef noodles are good too. Of course the best part of eating here is that it is so much fun--if you don't know what to order (or even if you think you do), the waitress will enthusiastically suggest something (or tell you you were wrong and bring you something better). Just tell her what you don't eat. Service is unconventional but friendly and warm. Ordering off menu is welcome, which is an obvious sign of a good place.

Purists may complain that the flavors of the dishes tend to be a bit sweet, but I found the change of taste delightful and masterfully done--any more, and it would have been too much.
author: Michael C.

description: I came here because every time I passed by there were always long line. But when I tried the food was just ok, nothing special. But still it's a good try because there is nothing bad about it, it just not that impressive.
author: Suabot J.

description:
I walked a mile after my long long day traveling for this restaurant since my bf said the food is really really good here. I was so disappointed. OVERRATED!!!!!! 

My family and I were starving so any food would taste better in that situation but not for here. After almost an hour waiting, with the food there, I wanna cry.

It was our first time so we believe the lady there to set up a course of food for us. I regretted doing that! My bf was the only one that has been there before and that agree with me that the food the lady picked was terrible!!!. She ordered us the calamari, one beef dish, one soup and a fish dish. No alcohol just 2 orders of soda... The bill came out $100+ 

I went there from LA and couldn't wait to come back and have some cheaper and better Chinese food down here.
author: Rungsima V. T.

description: This little Chinese was recommended to us by locals years ago. Sometimes they cue up on the street, but tables are served very fast, so it is o.k.. Since I have not been to China yet, unfortunately, this is the best Chinese restaurant in the world for me. The waiter just asked us: Hot, not so hot or not hot? I ordered not so hot, my wife had not hot and we had a whole meal with specialties of the house. For our European tastes it was hot and spicey like hell but really delicious. I wish I could go there again some time next year.
author: Gar N.

description:
Its not typical Chinese food, its a different style of Chinese food

The quality of the food vs its price: 
Although its a little pricey for Chinese food ($10-$15/plate), its quality justifies its price. The portions are large and the food taste great. The Famous Nanking Sesame Chicken is a must - its a great mix of tangy and sweet and it comes with sweet potatoes and veggies. The Bao Bing Wrap is another great dish. Its sweet with a little bit of spice, but the complemented well with green onions and a this crunchy vegetable.   You also can choose to have either beef, chicken, pork, fish or a few others. I chose the fish and beef. The beef was better. 

Service: 
Quick, friendly, efficient, especially for such a busy place. 

Ambiance:
The restaurant is not very large, and the lightening is on the darker side. It is always busy and packed so you might find yourself sitting very close next to a stranger, although you will still be with your group. Its a very casual place to go with friends or family, but its not a first date type of restaurant. 

Useful Tips:
Cons: Only one bathroom for women and men, the lines can get long. 
SF parking is not easy to come by near this restaurant, so look a few blocks away.
author: John A.

description: The food is delicious and the decor is cozy. Not a typical Chinese place but the food is great.
author: Tony G.

description: The flavors are great. The menu is somewhat limited as is the seating but worth a try!
author: Cecilia M.

description: Update: I was extremely appreciative that the manager reached out to me about the experience I had on Saturday nov 14th. I definitely can respect when a manager goes the extra mile to do their best to rectify the situation. And honestly I would not mind if they did not offer take out I just would like for their to be a sign or some kind of clear policy so I don't get mixed messages from different servers.
author: Jordan J.

description: The Sesame Chicken is insanely good. So succulent and tasty! I dream of this when I am not here.
author: Alison W.

description: A fantastic lunch.  I had the shrimp packets and the sesame chicken with sweet potatoes.  Everything was excellent, including the service.
author: Jim G.

description:
I don't even like Chinese food, and I destroy my plate every time I go here. Nuff said.

It can be really loud - not really a date place since you'll probably end up at the same table as other parties.
author: Kate S.

description:
I had heard so many great reviews of this place that I was expecting something pretty decent while on a trip to San Francisco.  Located in the outskirts of Chinatown, there was a line out the door just to get into the restaurant - something you usually don't see unless the restaurant is something awesome.  We decided we'd head into here on our first night, and tried a few different dishes.

I understand that this isn't supposed to be traditional Chinese, that it's supposed to be fusion between Chinese and American, but the two flavors just didn't mix well at this restaurant.  I've been to other places that bind the two effectively, but this was just poor quality on many levels.

A lot of the dishes were too slobbered with sauce to bring out the flavor of the actual dish.  We ordered the grilled calimari, but they brought out deep-fried, so we had to send that back.  When the right one finally did come out, it was over-cooked, making it too rubbery.

We didn't want noodles on the side, so we got some rice.  The rice was under-cooked, like it was going to be used later to make fried rice.  We returned it, and asked them to please bring out some fully-cooked rice that we could enjoy with our meal.  When they came back, it was cooked a little bit longer, but it was still very under-done.  I would think with a restaurant that goes through so much rice, they would know how to at least cook it.

Overall, I wasn't very impressed with the dishes.  If it was delicious food, I'd have no problem waiting in line and paying a bit of cash for the meal, but as it was I feel that I wasted time and money for something that wasn't good at all.  I hope my experience was just one random bad one, because I can't understand why so many others give this place such rave reviews.  I definitely won't be returning here, though.
author: Garrett P.

description: I ended up at this place as it was highly recommended by a friend. Let me talk about the house favorite sesame chicken first- all that it is is fried chicken with a strong taste of sesame. I definitely didnt understand why the dish became so popular. The sizzling rice soup on the other hand was extremely good. The crispy rice added an extra dimension to the dish. Our waitress recommended the onions cake and we got a plate of that. They were greasy and just about average. The fried calamari is best termed bland, the not so great sesame chicken actually shone in comparison to the calamari.
author: Minu M.

description: Crowded, noisy, and not the friendliest place but once you start eating you forgot about all the negatives. Bottom line focus on the food and you'll be happy.
author: Toren A.

description:
Got to eat there twice during my recent vacation in SF.  I saw comedian and actor Hal Sparks leave as I was going in. He was doing a show at Cobb's in nearby North Beach. Hal has great taste in music, and apparently food, too. 

Everything on the menu is good and they've dressed the place up in recent years. It's authentic enough to keep the local population happy, and visitors from around the world know it, as well. 

Never mind the line, they get through it quick. It's cramped inside, and the service is as good as any Chinese place I've ever been (not saying much).
author: Andy C.

description:
food: two stars (* *)
I had heard this was one of the best places for Chinese food in the city, so imagine my disappointment when I received chewy, bland sesame chicken and dumplings that tasted the same as the giant bag from Costco?  The simmered beef wrap was tasty, but the presentation was poor and it was wrapped in a flour tortilla!

environment/service: one star (*)
Rarely do I leave restaurants angry, but this was one of those occasions.  The service (or lack thereof) was astonishingly terrible, even for how crowded it was.  You had to yell several times to get the attention of any wait staff.  I thought I was going to go into a coma from the lack of hydration during the 20 minutes of the salt-laden meal I was trying to get a glass of water.  Just to get the bill at the end took 15 minutes and the waitress was snappy with me.  The fact that I gave her 9% for a tip was overly-generous thinking back on it.

value: two stars (* *)
For how basic the food is (both quality and quantity), I think it's expensive.  Appetizer dumplings for $9?  Come on.

average of
food: two stars
environment/service: one star
value: two stars
================
averaged grand total: two stars

estimated price per person (excluding drink):
$15-20

would i recommend it to others?
No.  Absolutely not.  Completely over-rated.

would i return?
No.
author: Benjamin L.

description:
OK, so I've been a long time yelp reader, and I've just gone to the trouble of creating an account and writing a review because this place was so incredibly awful.

Everything, like other reviewers had said, was covered in some variation of sweet sauce...even the chow mein...it's chow mein for god sakes. The noodles used were unlike anything I've ever seen in a Chinese restaurant, short & thick (reminded me of worms). It cost two extra dollars for them to add a meat to the dish, so something that would have cost me $5 in a normal edible Chinese restaurant was around $11.

The sesame chicken was ok, not fantastic or extraordinary... just tasted like regular sesame chicken, but the portion of that was much smaller than i would have expected and also didn't match the price.

I had a bad feeling about going here after reading yelp, and I should have stuck to my guns.  It seems out of towners love it and locals not so much.  So, my advice is this: you might want to give this place a shot, but do yourself a  favor and avoid the pain in your wallet and stomach.
author: alita c.

description: This place was ok. Seems like a tourist trap to me. Standard American-Chinese food, don't get me wrong, it was good. But there were no Asian's in here eating so that was my first sign it was not traditional food.  I think you could get some more traditional food in Chinatown than this!!!
author: Andrea N.

description: Good food, odd service from my point of view although I'm told it's the norm for the culture. Dishes come out when they're ready not as a table, but don't let that upset you. I enjoyed my meal and the place is just hopping busy! When you're done you are expected to get up and leave immediately to make space for the next group.
author: Steve P.

description: It was good but not great.  R&G Lounge is much better in my opinion.  Also I do not know about the reviews saying that they do not take credit cards, they took mine with no issues.
author: Jamie B.

description: Food was not memorable. Service was horrendous. Water was given grudgingly. My husband was nearly reprimanded for asking for a one time iced tea refill, "No refill!" We werent even given the option to pay for another iced tea order. The place is an acoustic disaster too. You can barely hear each dinner companion above the chaos, the platters, and the yelling (!) servers in the middle of the restaurant. Entrees were served 10 minutes apart so with four of us eating it was not great. I ate my entree in my appetizer dish because no one bothered to serve me or another companion a clean dinner plate. One of the servers (the tallest woman) served plates of food to the next table while chewing some food. Stay away...
author: Carmen e.

description: The food was OK. Not real authentic Chinese from what I have experienced. I tried to order sizzling rice soup and the waiter strongly recommends house special soup. I end up with a $14.95 tab for it when my original request was a friggin $6.95. The guy was unapologetic, food was more of a Chinese American fusion, and $2.25 for a bowl of white rice? And I was charged for 3? A definite tourist trap. I would avoid this place at all cost. There should be lot more authentic, better tasting, reasonable options in Chinatown. Nuff said.
author: Jun P.

description:
If it weren't for my boss picking up the tab, i probably wouldn't eat here. Not a chinese person in sight (my chinese manager doesn't count...he came with us as a group) no chopsticks and we paid over $100 for 5 dishes (boss forgot his glasses). The food itself is...eh, ok. It's great for a free meal but otherwise...meh.

Do yourself a favor, walk 3 blocks into Chinatown and spend $5 on the best dim sum around, make sure to give your leftovers to a homeless friend down the street.
author: nina B.

description:
This place certainly isn't  traditional Chinese food ~ I would say it is a fusion of Chinese and Thai.  I found the food to be delicious. We had a mixed green salad of fresh vegitables that included snap peas, red onion, basil, loads of fresh garlic and a lemony fish sauce.  I absolutely LOVED it.

We also had their prawns with mushrooms, fried calamari, a chicken wrap (similar to mushu pork) & Chinese noodles.  Eveything was delicious.

Service was spotty. Prices are a little higher then your standard hole in the wall,  but less then R&G lounge.

I'm sure there are plenty of tourists that come to this place, but today it was just the usual lunch crowd.  I will definately return with food cravings.
author: Colleen B.

description:
I came here on recommendation from some friends who were from out-of-town who were raving that this place was a hole in the wall that served authentic food.  I found the place to be greasy and dirty (almost intentionally to keep up the schtick), the server annoyingly impatient and the food to be edible, but very overpriced and not at all authentic as my friends claimed (sorry guys, adding a goji berry to my hot tea does not give this place street cred).    

If you want good chinese food, head to the avenues.  You'll find the places with the same greasy spoons, but they'll only set you back $6.
author: Ernest S.

description:
I would classify this as a Chinese themed restaurant and is a solid 4 in that genre. Obvious we all know the lowest and it's little sister "Express". Anyway, san francisco is known as much for good Real Chinese food as it is for Chinese themed food. Our city even invented the fortune cookie and we should embrace that.

I came here for lunch and it was such a fun experience. Coming in a lot of people tell you too ignore the menu and just tell them how hungry you are. This was so much fun and we were quite hungry. They even took into account that we had a vegetarian with us which was nice. The food that came out was delicious and though I am sure you would not find dishes like these in Hong Kong, Taiwan, or Beijing (somebody fact check that for me) It was absolutely delicious. 

We had some crispy chicken with sliced sweet potato, perfectly tender fried calamari, and a delicious mushroom dish with onion. The tea was also a Silken Pyramid Whole Leaf Tea Bag which again was not authentic but fit the theme I thought. 

It sort of reminds me of all of the places in hong kong that do the "American Breakfast". A place called cafe coral (popular HK chain), comes to mind where all of the American themed dishes have obvious HK twists. It just happens to be that people there like certain flavors but want that style of food.

I had so much fun here and I will be back!!!
author: Eric G.

description:
We're still trying to figure out why there was a 20 minute line outside this restaurant from 7PM to 9:30PM.  My friend Benna had been here before a few years back and said it was really great, kind of like a hidden gem and it looked like it had gotten discovered.  We agreed to go and braved the 20 minutes outside on Kearny St.  
Meal Progressed As Follows:
1. Get seated next to a bunch of overgrown frat boys.
2. Pouring over the menu, we asked the waiter which chicken dish he preferred, and answers, "Don't worry.  I take care of you."
3. His waitress returns with the local equivalent of crispy fried orange chicken, large bowl of bleached rice, and asparagus.  This apparently "special" order was actually what everyone else had in the restaurant.

The bill was $20 over what we ordered and had to ask for it in English.  The waiter and staff was rude.  Food was decent if you expectations were low, but was definitely high in MSG or something because I had a nice high after eating it.  Wouldn't go back, ever.
author: Humbleford S.

description:
Bummer...

We were so excited to for dinner hear after reading all of the amazing reviews!  But it really didn't live up to many of them :(.

It wasn't an issue sitting close to others that you didn't know but our waiter walked away before we were even finished ordering?!  I hate when you feel rushed or you are inconveniencing them...not right.

We ordered the chicken pot stickers..not sure if there was an option to get them steamed or pan fried but they came steamed and they were OK...i think we would have wanted them pan fried.

I ordered the famous Sesame Chicken...and it made me a little sick. People LOVE this dish but it just wasn't for me.

My boyfriend had the white fish and loved it!

Either way it was cheap, quick and we didn't have to wait in line (although there was one...maybe bc we only have 2 people?)

Being in chinatown there has to be a better restaurant from my perspective.
author: Annie V.

description:
Literally the BEST chinese food I have EVER tasted. I know this is a bold statement, but very very true.  I've been here three times now and each time every dish I tried was super good! (I'm shocked I didn't write a review on it before) I love the eggplant with garlic and chili sauce (Mmmm), the chow mein (so good, different from other more generic kinds and much better), the sweet potatoes, the onion pancakes...etc. The flower blossom tea is really cool and tasty as well! One of the reasons I love this place so much is because they put a lot of garlic in their dishes as well as a lot of yummy sauce and spices! The prices are reasonable and the portions are large. The service is not the best, but I don't even care because the food definitely makes up for it!
Can't wait to go back! :)
author: Sonya D.

description:
Service: crappy. The owner and servers are incredible arrogant and pushy! The server had so much attitude. She told us what we ordered wasn't good enough and that we should try this other dish (that was much more expensive, not that it mattered to us). In fact, she was so pushy that even if the dish sounded good, we refused it on principle. Also, she never returned to the table after we got our food. Even when she sat other customers near by us, she still didn't bother to check. 

Food: Horrible and amateur! It all tasted the same. They used basically the same super salty brown sauce in everything.  The sesame chicken tasted the same as the noodles. The white rice was barely warm. It was super super salty too!

Atmosphere: Meh

Basically, there were no Asians in the restaurant besides the wait staff. That should have tipped us off that this place is far from authentic. We will NEVER return.
author: tkemomq n.

description: Sesame chicken got sloppier, bathroom got bigger.
author: Inigo M.

description:
My parents came to visit me and my dad walked by this place so we went to check it out. I like that there are no reservations, just a line outside and you get a table when it's your turn. 

We started off with the egg rolls and wonton soup. The soup was delicious and perfect size for three people. The egg rolls were a little... mm.. meaty. Maybe I was looking for more of a spring roll but they were OK. Then we tried the lemon zested, lightly fried calamari. Yum but could have been a little more fried, just saying. 

My dad ordered the sesame chicken and the chow mein. I thought both were good, my parents both loved the sesame chicken. 

Overall a decent meal. The cuisine not authentic but the Chinese attitude was definitely real... loved it. Almost like dim sum pushy but with a hint of respect. I'd go back.
author: Tyler J.

description: This is a great place to go with a larger group of people, great for family-style. Tip: let your server know what you would like in a dish (i.e. a "fish dish" a "veggie dish" a "pork dish" and a "chicken dish") and let them decide with the chef what to give you.  It's always a delicious surprise and a lot of fun at the same time.  Plates aren't always consistent; however, I can't really judge since we have the server/chef decide what to send us.
author: Shayna C.

description: Went here one night because of a recommendation from a friend, I have to say that I was extremely happy with it. I had the sesame chicken and the dumplings and both were great! The service is fine, it was packed but I was seated pretty quickly and found that everyone was nice, even though they mixed up my bill with the table next to me, it was OK. I think that some people expect 5-star service from a 2-star restaurant, if you want good food at a reasonable price (hard to get in SF) this is your place.
author: Pablo R.

description:
I tried it because everyone raved about it. 
It was busy, filthy, had bad service and the food was incredibly below average going down.  However, the food outdid itself in making me very very ill with food poisoning.  I even tried calling the next day to tell them but the phone rang and rang and noone picked up and no voicemail...so I gave up.
I am amazed that yelpers like this place...is it just because its cheap?
Now when I pass by and see people inside, eating the food, I get a little nauseous, remembering what it did to me...
Yuck, never again.
author: Nilu r.

description: The first time I went here, around 2002, this place was grungy, but bomb!!! The waiter was an overpowering, opinionated Asian woman, who tried to tell us not to order what we asked, and instead get what she recommended. Once I conquered her and placed our order, everything was great. Now, over 10 years later, I will visit again over New Year's weekend. We'll see how it goes...
author: Vince A.

description:
This ranks high on my list of "The World's Most Overrated Places to Eat".  My wife and I decided to go and we felt good about the confirmation of a well attended little hole in the wall.  After being seated I thought, "It's pretty dirty in here, yet crowded.  The food must be really good."  I generally DO NOT like places that don't keep themselves clean.  

Then we looked at the dirty little menu left on our table.  WOW!  The prices were high.  Again, I reasoned, "They must serve amazing dishes to justify these prices."  So I ordered a calamari dish - my favorite food and one mentioned on the menu as "highly recommended".  The price was high, I believe $14.  Keep in mind, the best Calamari in SF is at Betelnut (a clean, upscale place) and it costs less.  

So I got my 10 pieces of calamari, fried and then dropped in olive oil and hot sauce.  I swear it tasted like calamari drowned in Texas Pete hot sauce from Albertsons.  It came with rice that looked and tasted two days old... 

Quite frankly, I just didn't get it.... For the life of me, I cannot reconcile my experience with some of the postings on this site.  I would not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Todd S.

description:
My usual plan of attack: [1] Wait for the owner.  [2] Order the sesame chicken and stuffed mushrooms.  [3] Tell the owner to hook us up with whatever he thinks is good that day.  [4] Chat with friends over tsingtao until the food comes.  [5] Utter silence once the food shows up; everyone is too engrossed with the flavorful flavors to do anything but 'flavorize'.

Look.  Some People Hate.  And if they're hating, that means your doing something right.  It never ceases to amaze, people find so many things to nitpick about.

Lets lay it all out there.  House of Nanking is not a fancy restaurant.  It is small, crowded and often has a line.  The service is not the best.  But were you really expecting anything different?  This is a cheap 'hole in the wall' chinese food place that got famous because the food is really really good.  Again, it got famous for the FOOD.  Not the service.  Not the ambiance.  Not anything else.  With that in mind, when you come here don't sweat the small stuff, the food will be worth it in the end.

Just in case you missed it the first time around.  GET THE SESAME CHICKEN AND STUFFED MUSHROOMS.  You wont be disappointed.
author: Justin B.

description:
Onion Cakes! Onions Cakes! Onion Cakes! Onion cakes are now what soars through my dreams at night... Dammit! Why did I listen to my Aunt and actually try them! These Delicious fried, green onion pancakes of perfection are smothered in a mouthwatering peanut sauce, which I am fully convinced contains crack sprinkles. 

This restaurant is truly one of a kind. It is a small, whole in the wall that usually has a line out the door! The walls are filled with years of culinary accomplishments, every award fully deserved as evidenced by the tasty masterpieces that are brought to your table. 

I recommend having the owner (who will be your waiter) pick out your meal. He usually asks what you normally like to eat, and will bring out something completely magnificent. Have an open mind and this restaurant will not disappoint. 

I recommend the scallops and egg plant dish , their sweet plum wine and of coarse, those deliciously addicting Onion Peanut cakes.
author: Stephanie R.

description:
The food made me melt. 

It is a little sad to see the contrasting one star reviews, but this place gets 2 of my thumbs up. 

My friend and I were advised to have the chef cook us whatever he/she wanted. The waitress asked us if: 1) We liked seafood, and 2) We liked spicy. YES TO BOTH! 

First dish: Calamari type deal with a milky, slightly spicy, vinegar sauce. Very light and delicious! Great crunch texture in the batter contrasting the squid.

Second dish: Roasted duck with cucumbers/green onions wrapped in a rice "tortilla" that can be dipped in a sesame sauce. Again, creative and delicious. The duck was cooked just right and the veggies had a nice crunch. 

Final dish: Chicken in a orange/general sauce with pan friend sweet potatoes and a chinese type cucumber. What a colorful and yummy dish! 

Overall, although this a more "modern" version of Chinese food, they have great textures and flavors that I have never experienced before. 

Worth the wait and the slightly crammed sitting arrangment, but go with good company and the food will melt away your worries.....
author: Geneva X.

description:
Ok, so the food was okaaay...  We had heard a lot about how great this place was, so we thought that we would try it out.  The food was OK, but the service was terrible!  Shortly after we ordered, we were asked to move to another table to make room for a large group that arrived after us..  this was not a problem at all, especially as the people in the group were very nice and thanked us.  It was the fact that we were then seated at another table which already had another couple dinning there already, so we were essentially dinning with these strangers at a table for four.  The other people were nice, but as the table was against the wall, we had to keep getting up in middle of the meal if they needed to go to the bathroom etc.

None of the waitresses had time to stop to take your order and it took several attempts to get their attention.  when we finally waved one down, she started taking our order, and while we were still ordering, she started walking away.  We finally got our order, but one of our orders never showed up at all.  After having waited 15 minutes after we had finished our last dish we decided it was never going to show up (despite us having asked for it twice, both times being told they would find out where it was but never coming back with an answer), and asked for the bill.  The waitress then looks up at us as annoyed and says, "but you still have another dish to come"

We may have just caught them at a bad night, but it really did spoil the experience.
author: Roza Y.

description: I'm so disappointed. I used to love this restaurant. We stopped in during a recent visit to SF. There wasn't a line and our party of 4 sat immediately. However, no server came to us for 10 minutes. We had to flag one down and then felt awkward like we were putting that person out by getting us drinks. The real kicker was that we asked them to please not use MSG for our meal (half of us are intolerant to it). They said there was no way for them to remove the MSG from their food; that everything was already prepared with it. Yuck!! I really can't believe this. I equate the use of MSG with low quality food. This is supposed to be the best restaurant in Chinatown SF. Me thinks not.
author: Kathy M.

description:
Ate dinner here on a Tuesday and I was surprised there wasn't a crowd outside the door waiting to be seated. The service was fast and the food was good.

We ordered the Sesame Chicken which I enjoyed. The sweet potato was an unexpected accompaniment to the dish, but it was really good. We also had Fang's Garlic fish and I loved that they topped it with arugula. The portions were a good size for two people, we had our fill and boxed the rest.
author: Zona P.

description:
To those who said this is barely better than Panda Express, you have no taste buds. 

This is certainly not traditional Chinese food - but it is insanely delish and i love to take all my SF visitors there.  

It's fun and adventurous as you can allow them to choose the "best of the day" for you. I love the sesame chicken with sweet potatoes. Yum!
author: Kathleen A.

description: Disappointed.   We ate here all the time in the 90's and occasionally the 2000s, but it's been 5-6 years since our last visit.  I've never minded the service--which is more amusing than anything else--but the food that once justified the long waits has now become bland and mediocre.  For example, the hot and sour soup--so amazing in the past--was almost tasteless this time.  Same with most of the other dishes, with the exception of the poached scallops.  Not sure how to explain the decline, although I know the owner now spends his time at Fang (his daughter's restaurant) and may be less involved in upholding the quality at Nan King.  Whatever the reason, the food was completely unimpressive and not worth the trip.  Sad to see this great San Francisco gem slip into total mediocrity.
author: Paul W.

description:
Totally inconsistent food!
We USED to be a huge fan of this place! The previous 2 times we've been there for Saturday lunch was great. This time, we decided to visit on a Sunday and it was AWFUL! So disappointing .... Maybe they have a different chef on Sundays, so avoid going on Sundays!
author: Ren K.

description:
YES YES YES!

Awwww, poor nancy boys cant wait in line for a meal? well then be my guest and go somewhere else for dinner. Listen, stick with this place- once you're inside they will treat you right. Dont bother ordering from the menu, just let the owner hook you up. The man knows what he's doing and will ensure that you have a great night. 

The only con about this place isnt the line, or the food, its the kind of people that go here. I suppose Zaggat can be thanked for this, but come on now! Because of the tiny size of the restaurant, you are forced to sit next to other parties in a way that suggests that you are all together. while this would be jim dandy if we all had manners, I and my GF were forced to sit next to a couple who left their manners at home. They barely tipped, sent their bill back because there was a .75 cent over charge for rice they didnt order, and they never used "please" or "thank you" a single time to the server who while busy, still got every single thing they needed quickly. 

Oh, then to top it off as I was walking out the door I called the guy who was at my table a "tool" underneath my breath. He heard me, and then proceeded to call me out and have me come back and call him that to his face....I did. I also kindly explained that where I come from you say "please and thank you". The man was stunned. Never have I seen someone go from ready throw down to being outright embarrassed to be alive. Hell, at the end of the conversation he said "i accept your criticism." 

Maybe there is hope for the world after all. 

k.
author: kenton y.

description: This place caters mostly to white people/tourists with small twists on the usual Chinese fares, but that doesn't mean that the food is not good.  Possibly the best hot and sour soup I've had in the City.  Their sesame chicken and eggplant dishes are great too.  There's always a line out the door every time I walk by so beware before you go as they don't take reservations.  Oh and cash only, per Ctown customs lol.
author: Khanh N.

description:
Whoa, what just happened in there?

That was the question I kept asking myself upon leaving that psycho restaurant known as House of Nanking.

For starters, I had mom and grandma visiting.  Wanting to show them a complete tour of tried-and-true SF restaurants, I kept Nanking on my shortlist.  On the last day of their visit, we decided to give it a shot.  Our idea was to split ONE DISH since none of us were very hungry.  

We walked in at 12:30, the height of the lunch rush.  No worries, we were seated immediately.  So far, so good.  But that was where the good times ended.

We had looked at our menus for about 7 seconds, when, all of a sudden, Ms. Crazy Nanking lady approached us.  "First time here?,"  she asked us.  We replied "yes."  GONE were the menus, locked up in her tight little fist.  "How hungry are you,?" was her next inquiry.  Speaking for the group, I replied that we were just "a little" hungry.  Then she asked us what we like.  Unsure as to where this was going, we agreed: Shrimp, Beef, Chicken, we like everything.  VHOOOSH.  She was gone.

1 appetizer, 3 huge courses (one shrimp, one beef, one chicken) and 1 weird flower tea thing that didn't taste like much, and $53 later, the three of us sat there, stunned.  Were we just totally railroaded, or what?

The worst part was that none of us liked the food!.  Mom and grandma each tried a piece of chicken, but put it back.  When we complained, crazy-girl just said, "oh really?  most people like it."  Too bad for us, I guess.

I know this place has a cult following; we could tell by the line outside the night before, and the lunch rush that day, but look, what's the point in yanking away the menus when it's clear that your patrons are new to the game, and don't yet "get it?"  

I wasn't amused, and we all left hungry and ticked off.  Thanks a lot, NanKing.  You made me look bad in front of grandma, and that's just not cool.
author: Jessica H.

description:
The few times we've been here we just let the waiter order for us.  It's a scary process, but we always leave happy.  

Try it out!  Let the waiter know that you're not too sure what you'd like to order and he will take care of you (do be sure to tell him about any food allergies before hand).
author: Crystal R.

description: My food was drowning in oil. Drowning. They charge for tea and then don't even strain it so you're picking jasmine leaves and other things out of your teeth and off your lips every time you sip. It's pretty telling that there were no Chinese customers there... actually, not even any Asians of any kind. Not a good sign.  The service wasn't great, but was normal for this place. The bad service is sort of part of its character. But when the food was good, then that made up for the service. This place was good ten, fifteen years ago. Now, no thanks. Really. Not even for free.
author: M N.

description:
Let me start by saying we don't eat a ton of Chinese food - mostly because good Chinese restaurants are hard to find.  That said, we have eaten at several of the restaurants in Chinatown and this is our favorite one -  by a long margin.

The staff isn't all that friendly, the seating is kind of crazy (you'll probably be sitting really close to a stranger) - but the food is wonderful and easily makes up for the other shortcomings.

This isn't Pick-up-Stix or PF Chang's.  I'm not sure how authentic the food is - but I know it tastes great and I haven't found anything comparable anywhere else in California.
author: Honest A.

description: Place gets a lot of hype.  The food is tasty, but it's relatively expensive for small portions.  Chinese food should be tasty while being super cheap/easy.  I definitely feel like it's lost it's status as a "gem."  There has to be better, more authentic places hidden away in Chinatown.  I won't say House of Nanking "sold out," but that's what it feels like with the type of Chinese food they serve.   If you let the owner/server order for you, you'll definitely end up with the most americanized items on the menu.
author: Derek L.

description:
Every time I go to Cafe Zoetrope across the street, I see people lined up around the block in front of this joint. So I finally check it out. 

9pm on a weeknight, no waiting. Rude, aggressive waitress? Check. Cheap, durable decor? Check. FOB staff all speaking Mandarin with back-country accents from eight provinces? Check. I order two of my standard test dishes: guo tie and suan la tang. The potstickers are crispy, deep fried, porkalicious, served with a peanut sauce instead of the usual soy-vinegar mix. So far so good. But it's the hot-sour soup that really blows my mind: big chunks of pork instead of the usual shreds, various vegetable surprises (peas?!), and so much lajiayou (chile oil) that the bowl shimmers like a bright red oil slick on top. It's hot, it's sour, it's quite possibly the best suan la tang I've ever had. While we eat, we scope the plates being delivered to nearby tables: everything looks epic. 

Generous portions, uncompromising approach, about as authentic as it gets. I'll be back.
author: Stuart M.

description: This is the best Chinese food I have ever had! Let them order for you ... You won't be disappointed.
author: Ericka C.

description: This place is the BOMB!!! You have to try it... expect it to be very busy. Make sure you order something that has the Yams.
author: Meikee M.

description:
The Sister thought she remembered House of Nanking from her college days. I Yelped for a Chinese restaurant where the owner is very bossy and orders for you and House of Nanking came up. When we went, however, it was very different. It's rather dark inside and the doors are covered by a curtain so don't be deterred. 

We ordered the sizzling rice soup, fried calamari, sesame chicken and sauteed eggplant as well as some hot tea. The rice soup was not what I was expecting as it had many more ingredients in it than I was used to and the rice didn't sizzle as it slid into the soup. =T The fried calamari was delicious and tender. Chinese-style fried calamari is not your typical calamari with golden-brown batter. It's very lightly fried and allows much more of the natural flavor of the calamari to come through. The sesame chicken wasn't anything spectacular - it tasted much like other sesame chicken I have had but I did love the fried sweet potato squares that came with it. Last but not least was the sauteed eggplant. It was delicious! Flavorful, tender and moist, it might have been my favorite dish.

The coolest part about this restaurant is the hot tea. I was expecting typical Chinese tea but out came three ginormous glass mugs (they almost looked like beer steins) filled with amber liquid and with a plant floating on top. However, after a few minutes, I noticed that the plant slowly sank and was opening up. And a few minutes after that, the flower (as we found it to be) blossomed! In the tea! And it didn't just blossom at the bottom but spread out a stem and blossomed up into the mug as well! Awesomeness. The tea itself is very sweet so if you're not into that, don't get it.

If you can find street parking, it's free after 6 p.m., but if not, there are several public parking lots nearby that are reasonable.
author: Christine P.

description:
Forget all the haters, this place, and MSG are delicious.  Now normally if I walked into a restaurant and saw photos of Rachel Ray and Jamie Oliver, I'd run for the door, but the smell of this place reminded me of a lot of the Chinese places I went to with my parents growing up in NYC.

The food is sticky and delicious and you'll totally get a headache later and it's so freaking worth it.  I love food that kind of makes me hate myself as I'm eating it, once in a while.  As I kept saying to my wife as we ate, "I'm in my happy place".  This is my comfort food on many levels.

The service is really funny in that if you don't order food THE FIRST TIME THEY ASK YOU, then your ass is gonna wait til they feel like asking.  This kinda pissed me off, kinda amused me, as we didn't even get two menus when we sat down, only one.

All in all, everyone who doesn't like this place is totally justified, as I feel justified in loving it.  It's full of white people eating trashy Chinese food, that totally delivers.  I honestly can't wait to go back the next time I'm in the city.
author: Joseph W.

description:
I feel that, if I have to wait in line to pay for the privilege of eating, the food should at least be interesting. This food was not exceptional in the least; we shared a number of dishes at our table and not one jumped out at us as being memorable.

A week later we went to nearby Hunan Homes and found it much more interesting and much more satisfying.

We won't be returning to House of Nanking.
author: Hunni B.

description:
when i say "Over", you say "rated!"

"Over"....
"Over"....

when i say "Not", you say "worth it!"

"Not"....
"Not"....

when i say "In", you say "authentic!"

"In"....
"In"....

when i say "Under", you say "whelming!"

"Under"....
"Under"....

when i say "Marginal", you say "at best!"

"Marginal"....
"Marginal"....

when i say "Tourist", you say "trap!"

"Tourist"....
"Tourist"....

when i say "Too much", you say "hype!"

"Too much"....
"Too much"....

when i say "Medi-", you say "-ocre!"

"Medi-"....
"Medi-"....

when i say "There's", you say "better Chinese restaurants elsewhere in the city, especially further in the heart of Chinatown, ones that you don't have to wait 45 min to eat rather drab and ordinary food; you might as well drive to San Mateo and dine at a Chinese restaurant there because it's the same amount of time and the same quality of food."

"There's"....
"There's"....
author: Nathaniel J.

description:
We came here around 9 or so the other night to avoid the wait. There's almost always a line outside for the place, so I decided to come later so we wouldn't feel so rushed and have to wait. 
We split a large order of the Sesame Chicken with rice, which was totally enough for two, and it was SO GOOD. It had sweet potatoes in it too. Yum! Splitting a large order is enough for two people that aren't super hungry, but want something good to fill their tummy. I'll be back for sure.
author: Julie F.

description:
This place gives Chinese food, even Americanized Chinese food, a bad name.

If it weren't for the birthday boy at work wanting to eat here, I would never pay good money for low quality food.  This place is dirty - everything from the table to chairs to the floor felt sticky.  The wait staff is rude.  The owner of this joint is probably laughing all the way to the bank!

1 star is too generous.  Unfortunately, yelp doesn't allow zero star.
author: Joan C.

description: Not bad Chinese. Sesame chicken was decent. Pork egg rolls and baby pea pod shoot were good.
author: Jason P.

description:
Meh is perfect to describe Nanking.  

Like others I had confused a line out the door with meaning good.
But seriously, nothing special about this place. DO NOT believe the Zagat!!

And whats with all the raw onion?
Onioncake, peasprouts had it....did they get too much onions from their produce delivery?

Beef was chewy, sesame chicken was soggy, and pork was really old tasting.

Garlic noodles were the only thing good and not even that good.
Plus this was pricey! Save your $$ and go elsewhere and get actually GOOD FOOD.
( about me: I love authentic & westernized food but would seriously go to panda express over this place lol)
author: eliza k.

description:
Good: 
Calamari, pea sprouts, Nanking sesame chicken.

Okay:
White fish with spinach leaves, Nanking Beef.

The 3 good dishes are 4.5 stars. The 2 okay ones are 2.5 stars.
The service isn't the greatest. You don't go there for the service, tho. And you'll want to know what to order before you go. The calamari, pea sprouts, and sesame chicken are the 3 dishes that we've really liked. We've travelled an hour to eat here just for those dishes. If you ask the waitress what to order, she'll tell you to get the white fish. It's just okay tho. In the past, the Nanking beef was a really good dish, but it's not as good now...
author: Doug O.

description: The chef gave us a very good meal! Excellent service!!!
author: Allie C.

description: This place was mediocre at best. We had the clamari, braised green beans, shrimp pockets, and the beef wraps. It was fine. Expensive and fine. There's much better food to be had in China town.
author: Kent C.

description: I am giving 4 stars just because the food is so damn good! I love the pea shoot salad with chicken it is mouthwatering goodness! My family has been coming here for over 20 years no matter how long the wait. Although the staff isn't really that friendly, it is always good to catch Peter in there to order for you. I highly reccommend trying this out. So worth it!!
author: Juliana O.

description:
I came here on a date with a Norwegian guy I was seeing.  He told me it was the best Chinese food he's ever had (having a Scandinavian guy tell a Chinese girl that is a bit ridiculous, but I gave him the benefit of the doubt).  He later told me he heard of this place from the hotel concierge when he first got to SF (poor guy got scammed).

First of all, the place was packed with the wrong type of crowd you'd expect at a good chinese restaurant (non-Chinese people or Asians who can't speak their own language).  No offense, but it's true.  

I could cook Chinese food better than this place.  The taste of the food could definitely be considered "Americanized Chinese food" (and full of MSG). I might describe it as one level higher than Panda Express.  

I subsequently decided to take this guy on a date to a real Chinese restaurant in Richmond.  After tasting the food there, he admitted to me that he was a little embarrassed for taking me to House of Nanking.  Well, I sure wouldn't claim that I knew a good Norwegian restaurant to take him to....
author: Jen Z.

description:
This is one of those restaurants that I bring EVERYONE to - whether it's a friend from out of town, my parents, or buddies in SF who somehow haven't ever been.

The "famous" sesame chicken is famous for a reason. Order it.

The potstickers are also great. The peanut sauce packs a bit of a punch so if you have a low spicy tolerance, go light on the sauce. I don't love spicy stuff but I can deal with the peanut sauce and love every second.

The bao bing wraps are also great. And if you're a fan of mushrooms, go for the mushroom dish. I don't like mushrooms but everyone else at our table loved the dish. Plus all the food came out SUPER fast.

If it's your first time, let them choose your food. They know what's the best!

This is a no-frills restaurant. You wait in line, sit, order, eat, pay and get OUT. If you want ambience, don't go here. If you want the best Chinese in the city and don't need waitstaff kissing your ass the whole night, Nanking is for you.

Also, bring cash. No credit cards. 

Enjoy!
author: Paige E.

description:
Great food and not expensive.
Note that this place could be quite packed so you might need to wait for a table.
author: Shahar N.

description:
I feel so obliged to hate on this place, given that it looks like such a tourist-y type place.  I just can't.

I sat and ordered the sesame chicken and some calamari.  I don't care much for authenticity, but if it tastes good, then the authenticity goes out the window.  Both of these dishes were good.  Very good.  And I did like how my tea was served in a glass designed for a pint of beer.  

Color me surprised.
author: Ren L.

description:
Chinatown is a bit intimidating at first. House of Nanking is reassuring with a full house of happy people. After waiting in a short line, the girls sharing our table (HofNanking is cool, casual and you just share tables) said, "just tell them what you feel like, don't look at the menu." That concept really threw my mom off and she deliberated over the menu for 20 minutes while everyone else around us who'd been seated at the same time ate. In the end we did a blend of chef's choice and menu research.

But, I digress. The pea shoots and their house chicken were delicious. I'd get both again, but also try the eggplant and house noodles. The wines and beers are cheap choices, but they stay cheap for the customer. It's not a place to go drink anyway, it's the place to get your chow on. This is my new 'go to' in SF Chinatown.
author: Lora B.

description:
I was very curious to check out this place; as any place that has as many 5-star ratings as it does 1-star ratings is very intriguing.

This place represents everything that's wrong with the Americanization of Chinese food. I'm not trying to say that all Americanized Chinese food sucks; there are some solid places around, like Great Eastern. And ultimately, gastronomy should not necessarily be about authenticity, but rather how well someone interprets a dish and adds their own creative element to it, which I've seen done very well with Americanized Chinese food.

I got the beef with the beer sauce (definitely not authentic Chinese, but an intriguing concept! I was so excited!) but the sauce was way too salty and overpowering, and then they just filled in the remaining space on the rest of the plate with as many leafy greens as they could fit, mostly to absorb the flavor, and an enormous bowl of rice. So if you just care about portions and not taste, this place might not be so bad.

To me, a two-star review means it's edible, and when I've had a lot to drink, I often am craving portion over taste.

But I am not reviewing this as a late-night place to go after drinking, I'm reviewing it as a restaurant. There is much better American Chinese food in Chinatown, go somewhere else.

But if you do go here, make sure to order the tea, a flower blooms in it, which is pretty cool.

Service was quite prompt.
author: Mark A.

description: It's a little disappointing the overall reviews have gotten this to an average restaurant - it's not.  Even though our sesame chicken (which I've never normally been a fan of) was warm and not hot, it and everything else was delicious - the veggie steamed dumplings and scallops salad - the highlight was this blossom tea that started out as a giant green acorn, and blossomed into a white beautiful flower - all in our tea!  The food is MSG ridden and salty - the service does appear semi rude/non nonchalant, but isn't that the Chinese way?  I even got to try someone's fish dish which was mistakenly delivered to our table and it was awesome too (I thought it was the chicken since it was breaded!).
author: Paul K.

description:
If you come here, it's for the experience and touristic value.  Really delicious food, but not a lot of healthier options.  

Must haves: the corn/rice chowder and the sesame chicken.  The chowder is thick and smooth, and has very nice flavor.  The sesame chicken is sweet, deep fried, and comes with some fried sweet potato on the side.  Definitely amazing.  

If you're trying to watch what you eat, this isn't a good place for you.  Most meat dishes come with little to no veggies, and the veggie dishes are mostly fried.
author: Sarah M.

description: Great experience.  A large group of us went here knowing nothing about the place.  We didn't even get menus because the woman who seated us simply asked what we liked, if anyone was allergic to anything and she would take care of the rest.  She was right!  8 different plates of food showing up one right after another until we were all stuffed and happy.  The service and ambiance was excellent and the food was fantastic.  If you are nearby, stop in, sit back and let them take care of you.
author: Andy O.

description: Good food, recommend going with a few people so you can try a variety of the great disches.
author: Honeya O.

description:
When the super cool old guy asks, "Do you trust me?," JUST SAY YES!!!!!!!!!! Put your dining fate in their hands; you will not regret it. I mean, Sean Penn has even done it...if this place is good enough for Sean Penn*, then it is $#@%ING good enough for YOU!!!!!!!

The peanut sauce is super amazing. Not convincing? I %$#@ING HATE PEANUT SAUCE!!!! I may not be as petulant with peanut sauce as I am with mustard (the writing prof told me to see a therapist about it...it's that bad); but pretty damn close. Therefore, when I say "Yay Peanut Sauce!" I sincerely mean that you should %$#@ing try it.

The mushrooms are also super amazing. If you are a fungusphobe, get the $@%# over it and try these mushrooms. Seriously.

Ugh, I ate so much that I felt seven months pregnant.

Eight of us ate for $150. I didn't see if gratuity was included in the bill (I fortunately did not have to pay); but there were two bottles of (kinda shitty) wine in the tab. Whatever. It was totally worth it.


The proximity of the bathrooms to the kitchen creeps me out a bit though.

*Is "Milk" still playing in the theatres? I forgot to see it. Who wants to see it?
author: Zulu Q.

description:
I went here with my boyfriend while we were visiting the city.  It had decent reviews and we were looking for some good Chinese food so we thought we would give it a try.

I must say we were most impressed with the egg rolls.  I ordered the pork fried rice (very touristy I know) and it had far too much egg on it to enjoy.  My boyfriend had a beef dish that was decent, but nothing remarkable.  Reading the reviews more thoroughly now, I wish I would have had the Sesame Chicken.

The service was what we expected to get at a restaurant in Chinatown.  Slightly pushy and the made us move tables in the middle of eating our entree so they could sit a family of 4 at our table.

Overall, it is a safe bet for tourists, but not extremely impressive.
author: Ann B.

description: A hidden gem for working people prices in San Francisco. Best Chinese food I have ever had, ambience is community style, friendly and the vibe is comfortable and casual. I love this place.
author: Glenn T.

description:
If you walk into this restaurant wearing socks on your feet, prepare to have them blown right the hell off. Well, that's after you wait a few minutes in a line that begins up the street and ends in heaven.

I was introduced to this joint about a month and change ago, and my life hasn't been the same since. I like the idea that you can walk into the place as a group, get jammed up against another group of people at one table, tell the waiter that there are four of you and you prefer to not eat red meat, and the food will magically appear at your table, as if from the ether.

We had the fried onion cake drizzled with awesomesauce, mind-bending fried calamari (which is nothing like the kind you can buy at your local pub), life-changing sesame chicken with sweet potatoes, and DNA-altering fried tofu with black bean sauce.

The service was SUPER quick, but not what one may qualify as "polite," "not rude," or "non butt-hurtious." They do, after all, have a volume of people to move through the space in a relatively short amount of time. 

And the blooming flower tea... You. Must. Drink. It. It's a chrysanthemum flower that blooms inside your cup, and needs the help of no sweetener on this planet to be perfectly palatable.
author: Paul T.

description:
Touristy and Overrated

I've been dragged here several times by out-of-town guests. I tried convincing them that there are much better Chinese restaurants in town, but they were determined to come here.

After waiting over 20 min each time, we get seated and I know the drill. Don't even bother reading the menu b/c the waiter has already decided what you're going to eat. These "chef's recommendations" often come doused with some orange sauce.

This food is fine, and you'll feel full. It's better than Panda Express and not as fancy as P.F. Changs. However, look elsewhere if you want truly authentic Chinese food at a more reasonable price.
author: Mike L.

description:
This might have possibly been the worst meal I have ever had. I have lived in China, and should have trusted my instinct about going to Jia Palace next door. Anyway, the wife convinced me this is a San Francisco institution, so what the heck...

Rule #1 about a Chinese restaurant: NEVER go in if not a single Chinese person is to be seen among the customers. I failed to follow my own rule and paid the price. The litany of disasters was unbelievable:

1) Nasty, greasy onion pancakes doused in a sweet, nasty peanut sauce that doesn't exist anywhere in China
2) A mushroom, basil and onion dish that tasted overwhelmingly of onion and used button mushrooms instead of the wide variety of delicious fungi used in Chinese cuisine.
3) Green beans that had never met garlic and were made in the same nasty peanut sauce
4) Awful moo shu beef that were mostly fat and stuffed into a pancake.

I am appalled that this place merits a line outside in a city with so many wonderful dining options, and dares call itself Chinese. Do yourself a favor, leave the line outside the door to the tourists, and go to R&G Lounge further down Kearny or Koi Palace in Daly City. You'll spend about the same amount of money on a real Chinese meal that is not only edible but also delicious.
author: Vikram K.

description:
I have something truly horrible to confess:

I JUST ATE AT THE WHITEST FUCKING PLACE IN CHINATOWN!

KILL. ME.

Ugh, last time you-know-who chooses the place for our office lunch. BARRFF!

Also, I think Panda Express should sue the fuck out of House of Nanking because it's clear they were serving the same sauced and shiteous food years before HoN was but a twinkle in a lardy, twitching eye. Yeah, I said it: I'd rather eat at PANDA FUCKING EXPRESS. At least the Panda doesn't try to convince me that my meal will be exceptional.
author: d s.

description:
First Time at House of Nanking ...

I was buzzed off of two really strong mimosas served up by a friend.  We were to rendezvous with the boss to have lunch and when we got there the folks seemed to know the boss and proceeded to fix up a special meal for us.  I forgot what we had, but damn, it was GOOD!  Or maybe it was good because I was hungry and buzzed and trying to keep a straight face on since the boss was there?  I had two more beers, btw.

Second Time at House of Nanking ...

Brought my parents over.  The owner saw us deliberating over the menu and suggested he'd put together a special meal for us.  Whoa, deja vu!  We had chow mein, garlic fried shrimp, stir fry beef, fried rice with some interesting spices, and tofu veggies.  I liked it but mom said it was just okay.

Third Time at House of Nanking ...

Celebrated the end of a project with a group of coworkers and, yes you guessed it, got a special meal whipped up for us again by the owner.  Kung Pao Chicken, spring rolls, Mongolian Beef and that fried rice with interesting spices again.  

Notice the trend?  

I'd give it 4 stars were it not for the "rustic" atmosphere and the windows that always seemed to be wide open no matter how friggin' cold it was outside.  Flavor-wise, it's good, inventive Chinese.  That''l do for me.
author: Eileen P.

description:
WTF?!?!?  THIS PLACE SUCKS ASS.  How can it be anything more than 2 stars?
The FOOD SUCKS--crappy americanized chinese.  Let me say that again.  IT'S CRAPPY EVEN FOR AMERICANIZED CHINESE. This restaurant is an insult to Nanjing, and to Chinese food in general.  It's NOT shanghai style cuisine.  It's SHIT STYLE CUISINE.   I only ever came here because my caucasian friends insisted. Greasy, fried, syrupy, MSG laden, lots of fried noodles and frickin WATER CHESTNUTS.  You know, WE DON'T put fried noodles and water chestnuts everywhere.  ESPECIALLY the light, sweet flavored Shanghai style.  The food is perhaps what Mr. Chau strives to be.

You want shanghai food?  check the richmond.  Shanghai noodle shop is OK.  shanghai dumpling house is mediocre.  Jai yun near chinatown is ACTUALLY nanjing style food (which is similar to shanghai style), and is AWESOME.

The Place sucks--I have to squeeze into this little hallway between tables because there was like nowhere to sit.  And I'm not small.  Lighting is so bad I can barely see my food--probably intentional, considering how bad the food looked and tasted.  Tables were sticky, which is typical for cheap chinese, but not for the amount I was paying.

The Service sucks--I walk in and at my place setting, guess what:  a plate, and a fork.  Yup.  So I look for a waiter cause I just want a bowl and a pair of chopsticks.  No one in sight.  I can't even flag one down when I get up and walk around.  So I just grab my own bowl and chopsticks from the waiter area.  And then proceed to force-feed myself my meal.  And then pay like $15 for it.  Split between 5 people.  THIS IS JUST WRONG.  $15 at a good chinese restaurant would get me an above average meal that would fill me.  THIS WAS SHIT.  I had to go get a pastrami sandwich around the corner afterwards, to get the taste out of my mouth, and to fill me.

If this were the last restaurant on earth, I wouldn't eat here.  I would fight my way into the kitchen and make my own meal.
author: Fong L.

description:
Executioner:  Do not let the prisoner touch the menu. I will enchant him by ordering his meal and make him regret his defiance.

(After much resistance, Ted has finally been imprisoned within the walls of H.O.N.K. having been betrayed by his out of town travelers. He sits dejected at a wobbly table, cornered by loud tourists on each side. His threshold of bad chinese food being stretched, he closes his eyes and forces himself to swallow the browny grease-laced noodles served to him)
  
  
Executioner:  Pleasant, yes?  Kneel and kiss the royal H.O.N.K. emblem on my cloak and you will feel no more.

(Ted stands but gives no response)
  
  
Executioner:  Rack him. Feed him the fried-battered chicken with secret browny sauce. Tourist love it.

(As he gulps the gruel down his throat, Ted's eyes widen and grimaces as if stretched in mid-air by ropes tied to his hands and feet)
 
 
Executioner: Enough? Do you want fish or pork or bachoy with secret sauce? Taste just like chicken.

(Ted resists. After several minutes, the executioner decides that Ted will not be broken in this way. He rudely quotes the praises of tourist magazines who have bowed to the grip of H.O.N.K.  Finally, the executioner hails his minions to rush him another bowl of mystery msg. The prisoner clutches the table while digesting the food placed in front of him. No water to ease the hurt. His face now shows that he is in serious pain as if being disemboweled. Still he does not cry out.)
  
  
Executioner:  What good is your brave heart? Show me allegiance. It can all end, right now.  Peace.  Bliss.  Just say it. Cry out mercy.

(diners repeats "mercy")

Executioner:  Cry out.  Just say it.  One word.  Mercy.

(the prisoner dry heaves in his chair)
  
  
Nish:  Mercy, Teddy, mercy.

Jessica T:  Please, just say it, mercy.

(diners chants louder "mercy")
  
  
(shaking violently, the prisoner gazes at his tormentor)
  
  
Executioner:  Silence! The prisoner wishes to say a word.
 
 
Teddy:  mm..mfuhh...ffrrFF...... FREEEEEEEE-DOMMMMMMMM! ! ! ! !
author: Teddy B.

description: Yummy food....liked everything from potstickers thru soup and entree...everything was just perfect. And we being majorly the group of vegetarians, the chef cum owner of this restaurant took special care for our preferences and made a his special dish for us which was not even menu..loved it overall and will definitely go back there.
author: Neha G.

description:
Over-rated tourist trap. 

You'll get more better and more authentic Chinese food at a P.F. Chang's in Des Moines, IA...
author: Stinky M.

description:
I gotta give a little background with this... House of Nanking has been hyped up to me since I moved to SF in June. And I have been meaning to try it since then, but every time I walk by there is a line out the door that freaks me out. I never really "plan ahead" for a Chinese food craving, so House of Nanking just always seemed like too much of an effort.

Recently though, it dawned on me... take out. Duh. So I ordered take out expecting it to be the best Chinese take out of my life. And well... it wasn't. I ordered: cripsy beef, sesame chicken and potstickers. It wasn't bad. It just wasn't great. Not too different than any other of the million Chinese places close by. The crispy beef was definitely the stand out dish. I would for sure get that again. Overall, it just didn't meet the hype.

I am sure you get a better experience from dining in. Get a couple Tsingtao's an order of the crispy beef and I can see this being bomb.com. Definitely not what everyone makes it out to be though. I feel like it's one of those places that has a recognizable name and is now everyone's "go-to" when recommending Chinese. Unless you're looking for a scene and a line, you're better off which a local Chinatown spot.
author: Natalie T.

description:
There was an article in the San Francisco Chronicle not too long ago talking about the exclusion of African-American musicians from an East Bay jazz festival and from the Yoshi's first ever CD.

Local saxophone player Howard Wiley commented,

"It is like going to a Chinese restaurant and there are no Chinese people."

The first thought that popped into my head was:  He's talking about House of Nanking.

This place is a joke for anyone considering real Chinese food.  If you want to stick to the neighborhood, try R&G Lounge.  Otherwise head out to the avenues for some much better fare.
author: Justin C.

description:
This place warrants a rewrite:

My trusted Yelper friends, many of them gourmets in their own right, have more or less spoken about this place. Enough to scare me away. I can taste their anger and food through their reviews. (No thanks to you trolls thinking I'm not being fair.)

If you abbreviate House of Nan King you get

H.O.N.K.

Nuff said. This just in from Ed M.....it looks like Chelsea Clinton ate here recently. They must have given her the full velvety red carpet, red tape, and dark red special sauce treatment and maybe shut down the place to the public. I wonder if the Secret Service had to take one for the team and shove the stuff down their pipes? That's hopefully not on our tax dimes...

But wait, there's more.

Maybe someone can tell us if they saw a picture of Martin Yan C*nt Cook inside, schmoozing with the owners and having sum REAL Chinese food and not stuff like Cream of Sum Young Dude, Hawt Miso Hawny Sour Soup, Sweet N' Sour Same Sauce (insert meat of your choice), Moo Shizzle Jizzle Thrice Cooked Pizzle? Whoops! Martin would only be seen in places like Joy or Chef Wai or gasp, his cohorts that advertise and write articles for Asian Gourmet (like the guys who own The Kitchen, Asian Pearl etc!) 

I wonder what Detective Carter would say about House of Nanking?

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aAtlmmWQMio

Shame on me for rehashing jokes and plagiarizing myself, for House of Hoisin Sauce.

I wasted two great words on the Crystal House review, which should have been reserved for H.O.N.K.

Fugly

Shideous

Insert your favorite fusion word here.
author: Ken K.

description: Order everything on the menu except... orange juice, which we ordered tonight for our two small children. We didn't think to ask the price when they offered it, and it appeared on our bill as an "open item" valued at $4.95 per tiny glass. So we spent more tonight on Minute Maid (we watched them pour it) orange juice than beer. Thanks, House of Nanking, for reminding us that a good dining experience is not just food-inspired. We will not be returning.
author: E. B.

description:
I am not sure why everyone flocks to this place like a moth to a flame. Well, not everyone. I beg for forgiveness from the Chinese community because we know what is good food and what tastes like...like...slop? Yeah, slop is a good word. 

The most important rule that I have lived by and made up A LONG TIME AGO and most likely shared with many other people is if you do not see a line of CHINESE people lining up outside of a CHINESE restaurant or is packed with a majority of CHINESE people, then you know something is wrong with the place. If you see a majority of OTHERS, ie. White, Black, Mexican, etc. etc., then you are in for a treat. Well, not really a treat but more of a menu of MSG induced food. And make sure to order a pitcher of water before you try to eat anything because you're gonna need it.

Now, I must admit., I may be a little spoiled because I AM CHINESE and I happen to know what the hell I am eating without a picture menu and pointing at the pretty little pictures taken from a cheap digicam that are plastered on a cheap Kinko's menu. And I must admit, I might be a bit biased because I happen to love food without a whole lot of MSG. Or maybe it's because I tend not to dive head first into what other people think is good and try other spots in Chinatown. I don't know what this place does to get such a following. My relatives say they have great feng shui. I think they sacrafice a live chicken which they later put on the menu as a stir fry or flavored, your choice.

Stop drinking the Cool Aid! Stop sniffing the paint! And put down that crack pipe! Sober up and go look for another restaurant to eat at because there's places in Chinatown that are a whole lot better than this joint! Trust me! I'm Chinese! I know what I'm talking about!
author: Anthony L.

description:
One of the best Chinese restaurants I have ever been to. We had them get what ever they recommended and it was good!
The onion pancakes are amazing, and the chicken dish (off menu) was great! Spicy too! And the shrimp and mushrooms was great. 
All in all, it was like no other Chinese food I have had before. Location looks kinda weird, but highly recommend!
author: Amit S.

description:
I almost bought the t-shirt.

It was THAT good. I went the first night I was in San Francisco. Co-workers in tow. Half the people in our group hadn't been there before, myself included. And when the white haired waiter, who turned out to be the owner, found out, well, he quickly confiscated our menus and handled it. He ordered for us.

Then, dishes of food just kept coming out...to our table...shrimp dumpling this...soy sauce fish that...fried tofu the other. Oh I just wanted to eat everything on every plate. Nevermind that I was with a group and had to share.

The trip to the restroom wasn't totally unbearable. The floor was wet so I hiked up my pants legs. And even though the swine flu was going around, the water never did seem to get hot enough to kill any germs. Neither did the soap, which appeared to be a watered down mixture of clear liquid soap and hand sanitizer that never did lather up.  Oh well.

The "treasurer" for our table, you know, the guy who just happens to be at the end when all of the money and credit cards come his way, was doing some major accounting and in the end decided to put it on his credit card and pocket the cash. Suddenly, some female waitress who we'd never seen the whole evening (not even when we asked for water three times) came over and said "you pay me now...in cash". Wow. Talk about bedside manner. And they didn't even have any fortune cookies left. Excuse me? A Chinese restaurant out of fortune cookies? Huh. Whateva.

Well, we paid and left and talked about the experience all the way back to the hotel.

I hadn't had Chinese food in a lonnnnng time. And the food made me want it again and again...soon. But the restroom and the cranky waitress made me want to stay away.
author: Kelly G.

description:
