I first came here with my mom at the recommendation of the concierge lady at the Palace hotel and it totally didn't disappoint.  We waited in line for a bit as is the usual, but as soon as we were seated a lady comes and I ask her what's good on the menu, and then she asks in a very  pushy Chinese lady way, "You Japanese? No? You Chinese? No? You Korean? Yes? OK, I know what you like."  Hahaha, my mom and I thought that was really funny so we gave the lady free reign to make the decisions and it was great.  We had the Nanking Chicken and some beef salad type dish and they were both really good.  

I've been here 3 times since then, and now that I live in the Bay Area, I will definitely be going back again soon.
author: Sarah C.

description:
My sister and her 3 kids were in the city for the day so I met them for lunch.  The House and most of the places in North Beach were closed due to power outage so we started strolling down toward Fidi.  My niece and nephews are sheltered suburbanites by nature and were freaked out at the idea of eating in Chinatown.  Oh, alright, we can eat at the House of Nanking, said the good aunt.  I have not eaten here in nearly a decade and it was my plan to never again but family obligations overruled my good intentions.

The chef/owner/now the dictator front of the house guy told us that he will order for us.  He knows what Koreans like, he said.  I was kind of impressed with his balls.  I do occasionally appreciate a bossy person taking charge and relieving me of that duty for a change.  Despite my past experiences there,especially after having been away for so long, and being famished, I found a part of me getting a little excited about the possibilities.  Then the food started to arrive and the memories flooded back .  BLEH!

The "special" soup was little more than some lukewarm water with hot oil floating in it containing a mishmash of what looked like leftovers from the party before us.  No one went further than the first sip.  The sesame chicken was WAY too sweet, overpowered by that famous namesake sauce (sauce #1).  We got a fish dish that had a slightly different sauce (sauce #2), but we remembered it as the sauce that topped the wontons served earlier.  The noodle dish had sauce #1.  The mushu pork was okay but tasted a lot of sauce #1.  And so forth...

I could tell even the kids were disenchanted with the place but politely thanked me for a good meal.  Despite my best efforts, my sister beat me to the check which I think was three times that we would have paid at a better joint in Chinatown.   The prices have increased a lot since my last visit - most entrees now hover around $12.  I now think the "I'll order for you" is a gimic that allows the owner to ensure a hefty bill for each party. 

I really needed this.  I need to give a place a re-look every decade or so to confirm my love or hate of the place.  CONFIRMED!  I still hate this place.
author: mia s.

description:
Being from Texas and Arizona, we don't have real chinese food.

The House of Nanking was like a full mouth orgasm.

The sweet potato dish, the egg rolls, everything about it was so good. I can't believe how tiny the kitchen is for how big the restaurant is. I also enjoyed the 'velvet rope' line outside to get in. Made it seem much more posh than it really was.

This is the place to go in Chinatown.
author: Jimmy M.

description:
I am aware to the fact that House of Nanking is located in Chinatown. Yes, some would argue that you don't go to House of Nanking when there are restaurants that serve more authentic Chinese food in the area. The fact is that some don't like authentic Chinese -- and would rather feast within the culinary safety/bounderies of Americanized Chinese food. And though I am part Chinese, I am one of these people! 

When my friends and I first arrived, we waited about five minutes for a table to free (this restaurant is very busy during mealtimes). We immediately noted the surly staff. The service began with our waitress throwing the menus down on the tables, then taking our orders a few minutes later. We ordered Wonton soup, combination fried rice, "Sizzling Noodles," "Nanking Sesame Chicken," beef broccoli, and steamed rice. I also ordered their Green tea. 

The food was actually very good. Everything tasted freshly prepared. We especially enjoyed the sesame chicken. The sizzling noodles were also very good... especially with their spicy chili sauce. However, I must say that our Wonton soup only had three wontons! WTF is up with restaurants cutting down on wontons in their wonton soup!?! Nonetheless, it was cool that their green tea had a little flower in it; though it was also a bit sweet (not sure if the sweetness was a result of added sugar OR the flower). 

Aside from what some people may consider surly service (I'm sure it's just their personalities), I would probably return in the future. Most items are about $10 to $15 each. My two friends and I split everything, including the food and the bill. Everything cost about $60.
author: A B.

description:
The food and service were terribly short of what we had expected. This place is damn pricey and quantities were really less. If you really want to get some quality Chinese food for a reasonable price, stay away. This was the best rated restaurant, but it was all false hype.

I am glad that it was not my first Chinese experience in San Francisco.
author: Aussfchi R.

description:
My best experience of Chinese food ever. The lunch I had in House of Nanking really makes me feel the profound culture of food. 

I was amazed when the first cup of tea was served. With a large piece of flower blossoming in the water. 

Then the chef asked us whether it's our first time being here. We answered yes and told him we did not know how to choose from the menu. The chef immediately said that he'll made us something special according to our likes and dislikes. He then asked do we like something a little spicy or numbing,  do we have any dislikes or something that cannot eat, did we want to just a big lunch or just want to have some small meals? and so on...

Then the first dish surprised us all. It was rice noodle served in well-stewed soup stock with wonton and a fish that is fried for a little bit. The soup was so delicious that it opens our appetite entirely.

The second dish was the sesame chicken, which, I have to say, is different from any sesame chicken that I had tasted. I believe that the chef added something special in the spicy seasoning to make it taste so good. 

And the last one is fried beancurd with chives and minced meat. The chef explained the recipe for us, telling us how he added a little bit of shrimp paste in the beancurd to make it tastier and how he controlled the amount of shrimp paste to make the taste not that strong. This was really impressive.

Anyway, I give a five star to the restaurant and will sure go there again the next time I visit SF.
author: Michelle D.

description:
Whoa Damn! 

My cousin and I went here for dinner one night. At first I was afraid...I was petrified...kept thinking we'd never get in 'cause of that line outside. But then we stood there for a bit, and got offered a place to sit, and I was wrong...we got menu's and it was on...

The food is awesome. Period. I was a little sad that the place was small, and that I got smacked in the head when the woman behind me put her coat on...but that's a small price to pay for bomb ass food! If you're in a hurry, this is not the spot for you. But if you have the time, go for it. Your stomach will thank you for it!
author: Ron M.

description:
Off the beaten path but well worth make the journey through China Town for.
Came with friends who have been here before and they took care of the ordering.  We basically said 'We would like a dish for each: chicken, beef, scallop, tofu, fish and veggie. And soup'  
Everything was amazing - nothing was too spicy or too salty.  It was exactly what we needed at the end of a weekend of partying.  Can't wait to come back!
author: Jennifer C.

description: Pretty tasty and reasonably priced Chinese food. Not super special but good enough. Very fast! Three people ate until stuffed for $50.
author: Pig E.

description:
I used to like this place, but I have come to the point of just being grossed out... and the interior is dirty, the wait staff sucks, the owner pushes way too many dishes if he orders for you, and it is not what you want.  Everything tastes the same - I believe they only use one type of sauce on every dish.  The presentation sucks, as the plates are larger than the tables, and the dishes are cracked and broken.  They need to seriously clean the place.  I am not even sure you are eating chicken, when you order chicken, as it is so deep fried that you can break a tooth on chewing it - and you typically find grissel.  Should I continue?

The tourist can have this place, as this has fallen off my radar.
author: Benjamin B.

description:
Don't be fooled.  Just because there's a rope line outside and loads of celebrity photos on the wall, doesn't make this a remarkable restaurant.   We arrived for lunch at 11:45AM - a handful of customers just about to order.  The waitress flings the menu on the table and within 30 seconds say "first time?"   I know we're in trouble when we see only tourists, Caucasians and no Asians seated.  

Ordered the chicken/green bean dish and a beef noodle dish.  Nothing to really write home about.  The rice was reheated from the night before - not steaming hot and some in the bowl was actually cool and hard.  (In the old days before expansion, the staff was known to throw served rice back into the steamer - recycling obvisously still practiced here).   Chicken dish was $10.95 - would Rachel Ray pay this amount on her budget lunch? I doubt it.
The beef noodle dish was unremarkable - the taste, well actually amateurish.

When it came time to pay the nearly $30.00 fare,  I noticed the American Express card welcomed sign on the door.  Took out my card and the waitress said - "no - cash only - machine bloken."   No Chinese restaurant will tolerate a broken credit card terminal - not when tourists and Cacausians are eating there....  Total BS.
author: Joe R.

description:
Ugh! I refuse to go there unless I am practically dragged by my out of town friends who are "dying to eat there". (More than likely they will end up bad indigestion from all that oil they use than dying.)  I walk by there all the time and all I see is tourists lining up to eat "authentic Chinese food". But how many locals will actually eat there? None.   How many Chinese people have you guys seen eating there? Next to none.  Service is horrible and I am comparing this to other Chinatown places.

As someone suggest screw Nanking and go to Chef Jia's next door..
author: Chris C.

description:
Brought 10 friends here last night. Most were from San Francisco but we had a few out-of-towners. I had always seen the long lines outside this place so I assumed it would be great! It was close to where everyone had parked as well. We only had to wait a few minutes to have eleven people seated which I was already impressed with. Once inside, the first thing everyone noted was that it doesn't smell like a Chinese restaurant! It was fresh and modern. Cramped, but what popular place in Chinatown isn't?

Food is a bit pricey but SO delicious! Everything was seeping in flavor and went so well together. We ordered almost everything family style and still- delicious! The only dish we wouldn't order again is the crackling beef. It wasn't what we expected when we had ordered it- it comes out like deep fried beef pieces tossed in mayonnaise. We were all expecting slices of beef, sizzling in a clay platter or something.

Service is pretty good as long as you're aggressive as well, i.e. raising your hand and saying "excuse me," though most of the time their many, many servers are on hand. Again, you're in the middle of Chinatown, so you have to remember you're never going to get 5-star service; it's just not what we do anywhere in Chinatown!

I'd take out-of-town buddies here again, but as a native local, I wouldn't eat here regularly, only because of the prices and how far it is from where I currently live.
author: Noreen S.

description:
After a long hiatus, I thought it would be fun to stop by my old regular lunch joint for an old favorite or two.  For a Wednesday evening, right after work, this place was crawling with tourists and left me with a look of despair on my face as soon as I walked in.  I ignored my flight/fight instinct which told me to get the fuck out of there and sat down at a wobbly table.

Everything that pro-HON Yelpers have said are exactly what I hated about it.  

1)  "It's great for groups!!"  No.  It's not.  Stay home.  You groups are annoying!  Tell your friends to go somewhere else with more space.  There were groups EVERYWHERE.  Co-workers.  Families with children. Large groups filled with overly-exuberant tourists.  Why did they decide to invade HON?  Could it be because ....

2) "Rachel Ray, [the most annoying women on television], ate here [and told EVERYONE with a stomach that it was fabulous?]."  I was eating among Ray-ophiles.  That sucks.  I have better taste than that!  Everything she promotes turns to shit in my mind as soon as that association has been made.  Remember how people used to love Katie Couric?  Just you wait for Rachel's turn ...

3)  "The owner takes your order!" It's great to have that sort of intimate touch, but the man has the tendency to hang out.  Don't hang out with one group of one-timers (tourists) for 20 minutes while starving couples or regulars begin to gnaw on eachother for sustenance.  Not good for repeats ...

4) "I love Nanking Sesame Chicken."  Used to be mind-blowing, but now it's just a messy, sticky, mound of fried sweetness on a fancier plate.  What happened to the thicker slice of sweet potato with the steamy inside lightly tossed in the special sauce?  My dish was soggy, and the sweet potatoes were mere slivers.

I'll miss you HON.  We had some good times.  Some REALLY good times.  I'm just not that into you...
author: Jenny K.

description:
Been coming here for years but came here recently with a group of my bachelor friends. The master chef a.k.a Grumpy Gramps wasn't working that day but the food was expectantly great. The service was still a little on the snooty side but the food came out prompt and delicious. As usual give the menu back and get the house choice meal. I feel like there's something new every time. The bigger the group the more stuff comes out, so try it all if you can. The cracklin beef= Crackin! tasted like crunchy, buttery goodness. The cod fish was cooked perfect and had the perfect amount of sweet and acid. They definitely have Wok masters back there but I still think the owner is an elitist. But its OK cause when it comes to food so am I. 

Atmosphere: Can get crowded and have a long wait. Touresty
Service: The owner and staff can be grumpy
Food: tastegasms and  a great introduction to the Nan King region.
Overall Score: 4.3

Quick Tip: Flower Blossom Tea and a Singtao
author: Sean B.

description: Our favorite chinese food eatery in SF.  Not the friendliest staff, but they are helpful in choosing great dishes, and the food is top notch.  You will always find locals eating here, which is a sign of a fantastic restaurant!
author: Mrs. T.

description: This was my worst food experience in a long time.  Many friends recommend this place and yelp reviews were good. DONT GO! The service was non existent, the drunk guy next to my girlfriend passed out on the table. I asked to move to an open table but they couldn't be bothered.  The food sucked the rice soup almost cracked my tooth. The chicken dish was low quality and crispy fat chunks. Overall, a disappointment and surprise.
author: Mike B.

description: Love this place the staff ordered for our entire group and didn't even let us look at the menu. All of the items they chose were amazing!
author: Leslie D.

description:
Despite the mixed reviews, I have nothin' but love for this SF mainstay. I'd even go so far as to say this is not only one of my fave Chinese joints in the Bay Area, but one of my fave anywhere.

Let me just say, loving this restaurant is a lot like loving hot sex with someone you'd never be caught dead with. (You all know what I'm talkin' about here).

This is the epitome of a hole in the wall, grease pit, sweat shop, dive. On my first visit, we went in one side of the restaurant, were led thru a narrow space thru the kitchen in the back, and then out to the other side of restaurant. Quite literally. Bizarre. 

I'd only go at night and eat by the glow of the hot pink neon so I couldn't really see the layers of grease caking the walls, floors and the cardboard boxes lining the windows in front where one of the chefs was doing his thing standing on top of an old foot stool to hover over a wok. 

I've heard they've done some work on the joint in the last few years, but I still prefer to go the take-out route and suggest you do too.

Disclaimers aside, the food has rocked every time I've been there over the last six years. Just thinking about the pea shoots (something you don't see often enough on Chinese menus) makes me salivate. Don't even bother looking at a menu. Tell your waiter how hungry you are and let them do the rest. Don't look down, don't think about all of the health codes you've just witnessed being broken - just enjoy!

Tip: Two words. Take-Out. Period.
author: dawson s.

description: A must when visiting San Fran! Just don't let them order for you "family style". $$ everything on the menu is great, just don't expect super friendly service. You can tell they're there for "business". In and out! That's there motto. It's worth it.
author: Nicole C.

description:
Okay, I have been lucky enough to find parking near here on three occasions.  Don't know if I can say the same for everyone.

The food is pretty damn good.  The best part is how they ordered food for me.  Here I was looking looking at the menu and a guy walks up, snatches the menu and gives me this "Don't trip, I got you covered fat boy" look...

The prices are pretty reasonable, but I'm always afraid I'ma end up paying more than I want since that guy is doing the ordering...LOL

Oh, I do wish the portions were a bit larger and that there were more space...I'm not anti-social, but for things like eatting, I would prefer not to share a table with strangers...

=)
author: Mike V.

description:
C'mon, really!

Can you say "Tourist Trap"? 

The food next door at Chef Jia's is way better. 

And NO WAITING!
author: Jacob L.

description:
The reason some Yelpers give this place a 5 star is beyond me.
First of all, the service at this place suck, the crackling beef is tasteless and over price. However, I did enjoy their non-traditional hot and sour soup, but even that will not bring me back to that tourist trap ever again.
author: SaSa L.

description: This place is crazy busy! It's like a gas station! don't eat inside.. take out or choose a different place to eat. I personally need to enjoy the food in a nice environment.
author: T I.

description: This place came recommended from a friend of a friend native to the area.  She claimed it was some of the best chinese food in Chinatown.  As soon as we got to here, there was a line which is usually a good sign that the place is legit.  However, I kind of only think that there was a line because the place was so small.  Anyways, the good was pretty good.  I got an order of the sesame chicken (WOW, damn good) and chicken fried rice.  The chicken fried rice didnt taste like any chicken fried rice I've ever had before.  If anything, it tasted like it was more authentic than something you get at the chinese place in the mall.  All in all, the food was great, the service was average, but the experience was memorable.  I'd probably try another place the next time I visit but its worth a stop.
author: Zach M.

description:
You might think the House of Nanking is one of those hidden gems:  on a dirty street that smells of sewage, with a cheap, no-frills sign.  The inside is the same, with crummy tables and chairs, grumpy waitstaff, and generally dirty conditions.  The line out front will absolutely convince you that the House of Nanking must be a diamond in the rough - why else would people line up to eat at such a crappy looking restaurant?  The food must be excellent!

Well, you''d be wrong.  If it looks like a duck, walks like a duck, talks like a duck, guess what.  It's a friggin' duck.
author: Alicia A.

description:
Oh gawd, are you kidding me?  Can you say tourist trap?  Any Chinese restaurant that has pictures of Rachel Fucking Ray on the wall and whose patrons consist of Europeans and Midwesterners clutching their SF guidebooks is lucky to get even 2 of my stingy stars.

So why did I eat here?  Because the ignorant dolt at the hotel said that good and fresh dim sum could be had here.  Hello?  No dim sum at theese placee!  Jus legular Chinee food!  Sank you beddy much!

So who puts Thai basil and lemon slices in wonton soup?  This place does.  Who puts a thick red sauce over pork dumplings?  This place does.  And who douses pork-filled mushrooms with a thick brown sauce?  I'll let you take a guess at the answer to this one.

Hmm ... now that I think of it, maybe the sauces are supposed to cover up the cardboard.

For what it was, the food was just eh.  Filling, but a little wierd.  Maybe it's authentic to people like Rachel Ray or the guy at the hotel, but this place ain't what Chinese food is about.  In fact, it ain't even Chinese food at all.

2 stars (because I was really hungry and the food came out fast).

P.S. Kelly I. claims that this food "explore[s] the outer limits of Chinese cusine [sic]."  Indeed, it's so far out that it's pretty much beyond the pale.
author: Paul L.

description:
I'm almost embarrassed to say it, but - I like this place.
I know that a score or more of Yelpers I respect hate this place (sorry, Ed!), but I really like it.
Last night was my first visit since becoming a Yelper. Having read the Yelp reviews, I thought to myself  "Self, Could you be wrong? Do you remember it being good, but, now that you've been schooled by the Yelp masses, will it be bad?"
I still liked it.
I like the fact that they throw plates at you. That has been my experience at most places in Chinatown. They are rude - but, again, I don't think that is unique.
As for the sauce, I'll give you that it all kind of tastes the same, but I don't care 'cause its GOOD.
Anyway, I'm going against the crowd and saying 4 stars.
author: Jamie M.

description:
Rule #1: If you consistently see long lines outside a restaurant (especially one where the decor is obviously not attracting patrons) , the food must be spectacular.

Rule # 2: NEVER EAT AT A CHINESE RESTAURANT UNLESS THE MAJORITY OF DINERS ARE CHINESE. 

Rule #3: Rule # 2 Beats Rule #1 every time!
author: Johnny O.

description: Recommended by my hotel's front desk, I set out for House of Nanking and inadvertently walked up (pun intended) an appetite. So, with a growling belly, I asked for Homemade Pork Wonton Soup, Bao Bing Wrap and hot tea. (P.S. Before ordering hot tea, first determine that you REALLY like tea because they serve each order in a VERY large beer mug and you have to pay $2.95 - which BTW caught me off guard since hot tea is generally complimentary at Chinese restaurants.) The tea was flavorsome - chrysanthemum, I believe - and their pork wonton soup was heavenly. The Bao Bing Wrap, however, was an upset and had made me wish I ordered two bowls of the soup instead. For me, the Pork Wonton Soup is this restaurant's saving grace and I'd definitely return for another bowl of it or two.
author: Patricia L.

description: Look, the people lined up out the door don't come here for moo goo gai pan.  It's authentic California Chinese food, in a bustling but completely down-home, family-friendly setting. . (Any noise comes from the people actually present, not the muzak popular in many trendy joints these days.) Had the best-prepared portobello mushroom, ever.  Great fish. Yum!
author: Ellen S.

description: Oh the House of Nanking! Bypass all the tourist-oriented restaurants in Chinatown and don't miss Nanking. Be patient and just know there will be a line to get seated, but once seated the service is quick and the food is unforgettable. Be sure to try the eggrolls and potstickers for appetizers. The Nanking Sesame Chicken...fantastic...we ended up ordering two servings it was so good! We also had the sautéed calamari, pan fried pork chops, and a couple other dishes that I don't remember the name. It was my second time and first for my friends. Not a fancy place, but a memorable experience with unforgettable food!
author: Rich F.

description: You know the food is good when the line goes out the door and people are willing to wait in the cold wind to get inside.  We had the Melt in Your Mouth Calamari which is a must-order.  Other delicious dishes are the pan-fried potstickers (allergy alert: peanuts in the sauce), sesame chicken, and the flat noodles. While the food was out fast, the below average service is tolerable because the food is so good.
author: Geraldine L.

description:
I use to love this place before i moved to the city and now rarely go there...only when i have friends visiting who want to try.

It is super crowded with white people..should be an alarm signal when eating in asian restaurant in the city.

They use lots of sugar and spice in there food so it is going to taste "sensational" but in a very americanized way.

I am not into crowds and sitting close by to fellow diners...but those who are into happening places...this place is happening.
author: Eric H.

description:
Know what you're getting into when you go to House of Nanking: Chinese in a no-frills, hole-in-the-wall environment.  You'll be rushed.  You'll feel cramped.

And you'll like it.

Peter Fang knows what's up.  Check out his many awards and profiles that adorn the walls.  He's good.  I don't even look at a menu when I go in; I just ask him to make me something good, or I'll tell him whether I want chicken, fish or beef.  He's never failed to impress.  The Nanking Beef is killer, so is the chili fish.  Don't neglect the hot and sour soup, which is also fantastic.

Five enduring stars.
author: Freccia S.

description:
I love this  place! My dad came here a few years back and now every year when we come to san francisco we come here! The staff is really nice! They remember us and make a special dish for us that isn't on the menu! 
  We always get the shrimp packets, which is very good! It has shrimp and veggies in it! I love the peanut sauce that comes on it! I could drink it is so good! 
  We get the sesame chicken, it has almost no breading on it but crispy on the outside! I love it!!! It also come with sweet potatoes which aren't my favorite...
 Really i think you should get what you love every time and then get something different to go with it! 
  I also love how when you come in you sit down and you don't always have your own table you sit next to other customers, one time i met a write that has lived ll over the United States. Another time I met a restaurant owner the lived in Washington, it is so interesting to meet these people and eat amazing food at the same time!
author: Darby H.

description:
The people who complain that "there aren't Chinese people there" as a negative are really just too much. It may not be the most authentic Chinese food in the world, but it's very good. The difference is the fresh ingredients. And they are cooked to perfection, so as to not be soaking up tons of oil and sauce like in most Chinese places.

Peter, the owner, will "take care of you" based on your party and based on what type of meat you like. If you like ordering independently, you might have trouble convincing him. Be assertive.

My recommendations are the sesame chicken, and the eggplant tofu, as well as their warm, flaky onion cakes.

Only reason it's not a 5-star place is the service is hurried and often rude. But I'll put up with subpar service if the food is good; better than good service with subpar food.
author: Brian B.

description:
I don't recommend this hole in the wall to anyone...we were told this place had the best Chinese food in town - not so.  We walked past this place the first time because it looked dirty and uninviting.  We stood outside for a minute and saw the Zagat survey taped to the window that gave this place great ratings.  We were seated and given menus - before we even had a chance to look at the menu a rude lady
came over and blurted out that she was going to bring us chicken, beef and pork dinners.  What the hell!!! We sat there looking in disbelief - we had been steam rolled!  When the food came it was very greasy and covered in tons of sesame seeds.  The dishes were horrible.  Thank goodness the drinks came in cans and bottles - it would be scary to drink anything from a glass there.  There are much better places than this to eat - don't waste your time here...It's gross!
The atmosphere sucks - staff is rude - food is disgusting!!!  When I went to pay the cashier she was eating a boiled chicken foot - nails and all and handling the money at the same time.  Barf!
author: Krys G.

description:
Came here for lunch sadly and was very disappointed. 

Granted it's a very touristy spot, but the staff were overly rude here.

I paid $8.95 without tax for their Sizzling Chicken with Vegetables.

There was nothing sizzling about it and that was the whole meal, it didn't even include rice.

My vegetables were soggy and I didn't really care for the sauce. The table lacked condiments that could have helped my entree like white pepper.

Over hyped and overpriced! Will not be visiting this place ever again.
author: Ericka A.

description:
I strongly got the impression that they got a bunch of awards several years ago, put them on the wall to show off, then gave up caring.

Crowded. Dirty. Rude, cold staff. Scallops were fishy and dry. Chicken was not healthy tasting or meaty and also a bit dry. Tea had a whole garden floating in it and was impossible to drink. And it's not included.

We were shoved into a corner and rushed to order, then forgotten about after being served.

The bathroom was flooded and disgusting. Plus it was right next to where the waiters were pouring the water for tables... and plucking dry lemon wedges from an uncovered bowl... with fruit flies all around. YUMMY. I'm sure a biology classroom could have used them, but they didn't belong in there.

I will say that the plates are impressively large and the presentation is very unique and interesting. But they don't make up for the bad food I got. The only thing I really liked was the sweet potato sidedish with gravy.

Seriously avoid this one. It is for tourists without a clue.
author: Aaron W.

description:
You have to understand what you're going for at House of nanking. 

Its not the service. No one will pamper to your whims. If you go for dinner, you will wait in line for a long time. if you don't like to queue, go before 6pm and you can walk into a table. Its early I know, but you can always go to Globe for 4th meal. Or do a brunch there on the weekend, you can usually walk in. (brunch is between 11am and 4pm, if its before 11am its still breakfast - you knoe that right?)

Its not the decor. Its SO not the decor. This place isn't retro cool, its retro - all cheap tables and chairs are still there from 1970s without any maintenance. 

Its not the company. Seems like everyone eating here is a fanny-packed, shorts-wearing (its summer in SAN FRANCISCO people!), guidebook-toting out of towner. (Gentle readers excuded of course)

Its (i)the food and (ii)the experience.

On food, I'm a Chinaman so I regard a Chinese restaurant with no/few Chinese patrons in Chinatown with a certain level of suspicion. Nanking is not authentic Chinese food. But it is GOOD chinese food.  Not fusion, but its been influenced by an American palate. The Mu Shu featured peas instead of cabbage last night when I was there. No authentic Chinese place would make the substitution, but I think HoN does just because thats whats cheap and fresh at market. Its still good though. Everything is really tasty and served very fast. I might take some exception at the tea ($2 a mug! And I'm not a big fan of the floating flowers) but I haven't had a bad meal here. The To Miou (Pea Shoots) with minced pork is particularly good, as is the scallion pancake with peanut sauce, but I think its hard to go wrong.

The Experience is all about brusque servers who know what you want better than you do. You HAVE to order off menu. Don't even bother picking it up. The people I see ordering potstickers and General Tso's chicken then complaining that they don't see what the big deal is have only themselves to blame. Stick to Panda Express. Give them some guidance  ("chicken, not too spicy, and maybe something green") and open yourself up to the adventure. They aren't going to put pig knuckles on your plate if you look like you're from the pastier parts of the midwest - they know their audience. But they'll serve you up something that you'll like and wouldn't otherwise have ordered. So give in to the uncertainty!
author: jeremy l.

description:
If you praise lame chinese food based off the misleading Zagat Guide, then I believe that grass is tastier for you. 

NOTE: The Zagat Guide does not list local food joints that serve great food. They only list the idiots trend guide to lame dining and some good places. But mostly trendy.
author: Joseph N.

description:
Despite all the hypes, this place is such a disappointment.  Half cold dishes, dirty wall, terrible service.  It's not worth standing in the line.  It used to be a decent place - however, they did not do a good job keeping up their quality and reputation. 

If  you want to smell dirty street and eat pre-prepared food, try here.  Otherwise, there is no reason to eat at this place.
author: Rie H.

description:
This place is Craps. Pretty presenation- but that's about it. Granted I am not a tourist, nor did I grow up in the midwest 'burbs, nor do I have a fear of spices- but come on. I don't mind the ghetto dive-ness and the brusque wait staff (hey I had to work food service at one point too, so I know what its like to deal with HUNGRY people), but when the food can only count "deep fried" as its sole culinary endeavor, it's time to call it what it is- "It was beautifully presented slop only good to those born in the year of the Tool." The BF couldn't put it any better!

Guy, now I'm a part of this bitchfest Matrix. Thanks a lot House of Nanking!
author: Hell G.

description: I love the food here. I've never ordered a dish I've been dissatisfied with. If you're looking for an inexpensive dinner with no frills, this could be a great option. If you don't mind communal seating and rude waitstaff, then you should definitely give it a try. They also tend to lock the door erratically. The hours might be until 9 or 10pm, but they'll lock to door so no new customers an come in well before the close time, which can be disappointing if you wanted to order to go. Stick with beer if you want to order an alcoholic beverage, the wine is Franzia:)
author: Natalie D.

description:
Wow is this place controversial!  Let's address the issues.


1) Some say that the food isn't good.  Rule #1 at  the House of Nan King.  Do NOT order off of the menu.  The menus are difficult to read for a reason.  Just tell the server what sort of item you would like. ie. chicken, vegetable, etc.  No good can come off of the menu at this place.

2) The food here is not authentic.  That is true.  Do not go here if you are looking for "authentic" Cantonese, Hunan or whatever.  There are plenty of other places in Chinatown if you are looking for that.

3) Long lines.  Make sure to get here before you are hungry.  However, the lines tend to move pretty fast.  

Basically, the House of Nanking is a unique dinning experience.  Let them decide what to serve you and you will get tasty reasonably priced food that is unlike what you have ever had before.  This place has little to no ambiance.  There isn't much decor, and they have such a long line that you will not be encouraged to linger after eating.  It is definitely worth checking out though.  If you let the chef be creative, the food is really yummy.
author: Kate B.

description:
We went here one night they told us they were closed at 9pm here in yelp they said they closed at 10pm. Came back the next day they didnt want to accept us because we had a big party. We told them we didnt mind waiting and we didnt mind seating on different tables but they still didnt want to accept us. Thats so sad because we walked all the way from union square just to try them out and were not from the city

Update: 
So it turned out my uncle knew the owner when i told him about that old lady who didnt want to accept our party he went inside and spoke to the owner and in 10mins they were able to sit us in 2 tables. One table was enough for our party but i had my 4month old baby so i had to have some place for her stroller/carseat.so me and my husband sat on a 4chaired table. The other servers didnt mind. My husband and i were seating across each other and i had my babys carseat on the chair on my left side.our partys bigger table had 2 vacant chairs at the end.this old lady came up to us and asked us howcome we just couldnt take those 2 empty chairs? we told her we needed a place for the carseat, so we can put the baby there when we're about to eat. She asked this about 3 times! She wanted us to move so another party can use our table. Keep in mind this was the same lady who didnt want to accept us earlier. As we were looking at the menu (since it was our first time there) this same old lasy grabbed our menus and said our uncle already ordered! What a rude person! Didnt she realiZe she has been harassing us the whole night already? I dont know if this is the owner' wife or what ...but still,  it doesnt give her the right to be this rude. Despite all this i still gave them a good tip and 2 stars because i liked the food and the owner was really nice. I hope they get rid of this lady, shes not good for their business.
author: TP J.

description:
Part of Nan King is the food, and a part of Nan King is the service/ the whole experience.  This is the sort of place that you should go to at least once a year, but it's not an every Tuesday type of place

If you want someone who will cater to your every whim and fill your water after every sip........go to another spot.

If you want a cranky old Chinese man who will tell you which things go good together, then come to Nan king
author: Nikki c.

description:
Pfft.

I used to be enchanted with this place. Back when I was a freshman at UC Berkeley, San Francisco to me consisted of North Beach and China Town (my friends and I would laugh at the tourists who went to Fisherman's Wharf... that was before I realized that Fisherman's Wharf is just a place that San Franciscans go to get away from the San Franciscans who are trying to get away from tourists). 

I had heard about House of Nanking from a friend who spoke in low, grave tones about this leetle hole-in-the-wall on Kearny. He told me that Francis Ford Coppola ate there. He told me that Herb Caen (who?) immortalized it. Well, if Herb Caen (who?) immortalized it, then it must be Really Something. 

I loved the packed-tighter-than-sardines-in-a-telephone-booth delirium of the place. I loved the little spiky-haired, no-nonsense chef-owner who gave us our order. I would later tell all my friends and new initiates--with the same low voice and arched brows--that THIS was the proper way to order. I loved being in on something. Conspiracy = quality.

Now, a decade later, I have dissed my enchantment. The gauzy film of inexperience has been liften from my wizened eyes. Or maybe it was a gauzy film of burnt sesame oil. But House of Nanking is a smirking fraud.

I'm not saying the food sucks ass (though it can, on occasion); it's just that the hype stinks worse than yesterday's cabbage, and there is a uniformity to the dishes that is not surprising, just...well, not up to the hype. In fact, I could go to Becky's Chinese in Rockridge (see my other review) and gaze at the awesome wooden model boats hanging from the ceiling as I slurp up my PACF (perfectly average chinese food) and save $6 on BART fare.

My cousin is still under the spell.

Save yourself a trip: go to Eric's (you heard me) in Noe Valley instead.
author: Zak N.

description:
Good food every time.  Really like the soups they have alot of flavor and the Nan King Beef is a must very good one of a kind and great Sweet Potatoes with it.  Service is okay.  Be assertive if you want to order, get water or anything like that.  Overall a very good meal and will keep coming back.

It is good food when you order but dont let the owner order for you. He thinks he knows what everyone likes which is BS and you end of liking half the dishes and paying for them all.  DO NOT LET THEM ORDER FOR YOU.  BE ASSERTIVE ON THAT.
author: Harry E.

description:
HOUSE OF NUMB
HOUSE OF PAIN
HOUSE OF OH-MY-GOD-AM-I-ABOUT-TO-DIE?

The tea glass was sticky on top with I-don't-know-what...then the "food" came...then the pain...yes, pain...I felt slightly nauseated at first, then thirsty, dizzy, woozy, my hands felt a little numb, and then there was the sensation of heat creaping up my shoulders...this sensation intensified and I looked at the person next to me, noticed they had stopped eating and were guzzling water....I asked how they were feeling and HE DESCRIBED THE SAME SYMPTOMS I WAS HAVING!  I swear we were dosed with something - my guess is a giant mega dose of MSG and possibly some extreme artificial sweetner......I guzzled water, went outside and gulped air, and have lost my appetite for "Chinese food" for over two months now!
author: Murry t.

description:
This is the most overrated Chinese restaurant on Earth!  The people in the long lines are dumb tourist with their Fodor or Zagat books.  They use five or six basic sauces to cook the meat & veggies.  You can get better Chinese food at Panda Express.

But what tick me most about this restaurant is the old fart running
the place.  One time when I ordered a take-out, the old guy
told me to wait outside and get out of his way.  He was RUDE!
No matter how good or bad the food is, customers should not
be treated this way.
author: susan g.

description:
My friend and I were looking for great chinese food. People that we know said House of Nanking was great. Boy, has that place changed. The decor and family style got us exited but when the food came, not so much. 
We first had potstickers, but they were drenched in a weird sause made from peanut oil. Then we had sizzling rice soup. Usually, it is broth, but this time it looked like coconut milk with hot sauce on top. It had lemons and other ingredients not good for soup. Then we had sesame chicken and it was OK.  The mu shu pork was not mu shu pork at all. it looked like deluxe nachos with out cheese and chips. 
Also, the waiters aren't very fast. We asked for water seven times until we finally got it. Some of our food didn't come before we got the check. 
NEVER ever go to house of nanking unless you want bad food and service
author: Deborah B.

description:
House of Nanking isn't what it used to be, but it's still the bomb.

I'm truly amazed that HoN has 511 reviews on Yelp - wow - but about 30% are either 1- or 2-stars.  Huh? 

So HoN is not for everyone, but consider this: how many other places in San Francisco have over 250 reviews, let alone 250+ 4- or 5-star ratings?!

I've been going to HoN for 12 years now.  No, the place is not Tommy Toy's.  No, the service is usually just adequate at best.  Yes, its gotten more expensive, but the food is still delicious and unique.

Don't worry about having Peter Fang (Chef & Owner) order everything for you.  That used to be a good call, but now it just means you'll end up paying too much.  If you're a HoN neophyte with another diner, your best bet is:

Shrimp Cakes appetizer
Nanking Chicken
Mu Shu Beef*

* If you're feeling a little adventurous, and don't mind paying for it, substitute the Mu Shu for a dish of the chef's choice, i.e. tell them a fish, beef or chicken dish.  You'll definitely be surprised and pleased.
author: Daniel S.

description:
=============
RJR - ISSUE #6 
=============

DINE DATE: A couple times. And that's it.

I heard about this place on the food channel or was it the travel channel? I forget.

While shopping for some ASIAN import dvd in Chinatown, we decided to scope this place out and give it a try.

The first time, the wait wasn't too long about 10 mins standing outside - the place was a bit crowdly cramped, you definitely won't be to dazzled by the atmosphere of the restaurant as it only inhabits a small two-room dining space.

We sat up in the front next to the open window. We ordered our food - Nanking scallops , Nanking stuffed mushrooms , and some Combo fried rice.   The food is not your traditional chinese food - we thought it was very tasty and had a very "unique flavored sauce"  that we enjoyed. - At least we thought it was unique...

The second time, we waited about 20 mins - competing with tourist for tables on a busy Saturday lunch hour.   This time, we sat in the far back near the kitchen.   We placed our order:  Pork chop nanking style and the Nanking stuff mushroom, again.

As we were waiting for our order - we watch the service crews do their thing - picking up the orders and - what do you know - pouring the same sauce on nearly every plate.  

Digging into our order during this second round, we realized...hmmm, it taste the same...the same "so called unique sauce" is on everything!  - "Wat Da'HELL!?!"

Only later did I learn that place was called "House of Same Sauce"

TOURIST TRAP - "And I fed into it, LITERALLY!  Dee Dee Dee!!"

*SPECIAL BONUS FEATURES*

- I'd say you have to give this place a try a least once - it was good the first time - and once is all you need.   It's the only place you can actually say you sampled the entire menu all at once - in just a single sitting.  Now that's unique.
author: Ron Jeremy R.

description:
If you are a local, you know that Henry Hunan is the place to go for Chinese food in EssEff.  What, is this place in every tour guide of San Francisco?  I was so unbelievably underwhelmed by this place.  It is kinda like the Fior D Italia of Chinese food.  I.e. only tourists eat there.

House of Nanking is the classic example of some place being on the tourist hit parade.  Please friendly tourists:  there are thousands of other Chinese restaurants in SF.  Why wait in line for marginal food?
author: Sam P.

description:
I'm not sure what House of Nanking is trying to sell...the funky colored sign outside, the no-nonsense business model, or the crowd.  But what it's certainly not selling is its food...at least, not Chinese food.

I went here with a friend from Texas who had received a recommendation from friends.  After waiting in line for about 20 minutes, we were quickly ushered inside to a cramped table in the corner, next to the kitchen.  We had a short chance to look at the menu before someone came over and asked us what kind of stuff we liked - seafood, shrimp, beef, chicken.  Well, that was that, after giving what basics we wanted, and knowing we would have a mystery menu.

The soup was interesting...a wonton soup that had wonton skins that were much tougher than they should be, with a little bit of chili oil and herbs that I would usually associate with Vietnamese cuisine.  Then came the food...a sesame chicken, a braised tofu, and some sort of braised beef.  While tasty and certainly not bad, by the end of the meal, I found everything tasting rather similar - a little vinegary, a slight taste of salt and other flavors.  Overall, it really just seemed to fall flat.

And surprisingly...considering we only had four dishes for three people, a total of $20/person including tax/tip seemed a little steep for Chinese food.  As my friend's girlfriend remarked, it certainly wasn't Chinese food by usual considerations.

In general, I don't think I'd recommend this place to anyone - there are better places in Chinatown, and most certainly in the Richmond or the Sunset.  So save your time, money, and aggravation, and head somewhere else.
author: Mark C.

description:
You go here for food - really good, flavorful, fresh tasting food. 

I went here after hearing amazing things and figured I'd be underwhelmed due to the hype but it was surprisingly delicious. Started with lemon rice soup that was one of the best soups I've had - the combo of chicken, crispy rice, veggies and spice was incredible! Then finished off with the Nanking chicken (ehh not mind blowing, but definitely great) and salt & pepper shrimp (fantastic! The mushrooms were out of this world - pretty big deal for mushrooms.)

FYI:
1. You'll get anxiety trying to get a table, and will feel like herded cattle when being seated, but it's worth it. 
2. Get the green tea - its not your usual Costco matcha green tea, it's a blooming flower.... What more could you want?
author: christina c.

description: So so Americanized food. The Bao Bing veggies are mostly just cabbage. Their specialty - sesame chicken - is just regular orange chicken, although the sweet potatoes are a nice tasty touch. Still, all the white folks should have tipped me off....
author: Kevin L.

description: Awesome Chinese food. Usually a small line but it moves quickly
author: Wyatt D.

description:
Hmm is this Chinese Food or another tourist trap?

I tried out the place during lunch and I can't justify the price on the quality of the food. Honestly It used to be better(more than 10 years ago). Now it's just a San Francisco attraction that you have to go to but you're not sure why.

They also seem to use the same sauce in most of their dishes. I guess people who don't know Chinese food just generalize it as "Oriental Sauce."
author: Bert T.

description:
My (Chinese) other half brought me here with memories of, well, memorable dishes. Alas, they failed to deliver. There is still the fun, cheap, share-a-table attitude I enjoy after my years in Shanghai, but the food was bland and boring. Neither the fun sweet, flavour-ridden (ie bad for you) flavours of American-Chinese, nor the authenticity of actual Chinese. 

Home-made pork dumpling soup was water, totally overpowered with Thai basil (not generally used in Chinese food, btw) had a lemon in it (so not chinese) and had thick, chewy dumplings (not a good thing - they should be thin) with strong (read cheap) tasting pork inside. Bad dish. 

Next, sesame chicken that so many yelpers 'yelp' about - Hmm - not bad. Chicken nice, sweet potato good, if overcooked, cucumber garnish totally tasteless - big miss on this part (and even I can get it right cooking at home!) 

Finally, sizzling beef. Chewy, cheap, and flavorless. Ergh. 

BIG plus points for the nice-cold-ice-cold tsingdao and the fun interior.
author: Caroline R.

description:
Awful.
Greasy. Salty. Crap.
I should send them a bill for the 187 bottles of water I had to buy on my walk home.
author: Sharon G.

description: I came back here and have a few more thoughts. The problem is that the food is inconsistent. I got the shrimp cake and the shrimp had a VERY strong seafood like taste that was not fresh. Also I asked for a recommendation beside the sesame chicken, which is really good, and they suggested a disgusting greasy fried fish dish. If you come here, get the sesame chicken and some kind of vegetable noodle.
author: Laurence S.

description:
so it isn't pure authentic Chinese - does that really matter when so much of what they offer is pure food of the God's?  The fried pot stickers in a spicy peanut sauce are unique to the House of Nanking and would be my appetizer of choice if I had to design my last meal.  Just amazing.  The house specialty sesame chicken is wonderful, and this is the only restaurant I ever go to where I can relinquish control and just tell the staff to bring us a variety just specifying the protein ingredient we want.  

I always take visitors here, and they always demand return visits when the come to SF.  I was first brought here on a visit to SF in 1991 and it has been a staple for me since.  As a 12 year resident now, it is always on my short lists of favorite places to eat.

The service is hurried and abrupt, but is appreciated when you've waited outside to get in - how else are they to turn over tables.  The atmosphere has been improving over the years and went from very sketchy to actually a tiny bit stylish (emphasis on tiny bit).

If you are obsessed with purist authenticity and silly observations like "too many white people" then Nanking is not for you.  But the crowds are there for a reason - it's wonderful.
author: Curtis J.

description:
-30 min wait at 6pm on a tues which i found astounding
-you know its not authentic asian food when the waitresses are too nice.  our waitress even asked us how we are doing.  comn...i want asshole too-busy-for-you waiters i am use to at authentic chinese restaurants.  o yeah, they pretty much spoke fluent engrish
-the house chicken dish had major MSG, i loved it.  its not a real asian food experience if im not finishing 4 glasses of water.  MSG makes the world go round.
author: Paran Y.

description:
I am in love with the sesame chicken.
so crispy.
But I gotta give em' only 3 stars for the shit stuck on my silverware, and forgetting my water.
author: Karlee D.

description:
PreScript 8/07   The sauce is not all the same. Dammit!

If god, allah or Charlton Heston playing a religious icon were going to order Chinese food in San Francisco, it would be at House of Nanking.  
     The sesame chicken defies definition. But do yourself a favor, go all the time and specify only how hungry you are and what genre of food you want. Por ejemplo:
  "A chicken dish and a noodle, We are really hungry."  or;
  " Beef garlic, a soup and a squid appetizer" 

Leave the rest in the hands of Nanking's Magic. This place has only exceeded expectations, great in all aspects of greatitude. Kearny and Clay, border of China town and FiDi. This is the real deal, folks. Recognize.
author: Jonny C.

description:
I've never had a problem getting seated right away at lunchtime at this popular restaurant. I ate here recently for the 2nd time, and both times were awesome! 

The first time I went, I came with a friend who's standard fare is the green onion pancake and the sesame chicken with sweet potato. Both were very good.

The second time, my lunchmate knew what to do - she ordered directly from the owner "off menu." He asked us what we liked, to which we replied seafood. Jotting down in Chinese, he whisked off and soon after we were delighted with a shrimp wonton with a light peanut-soy sauce, pan fried shrimp presented on a bed of fresh spinach and pan-fried eggplant, and finally delicate scallops in a soy-lemon-garlic broth. 

The interior and service is unpretentious and food phenomenal. Definitely a must for a local or visitor.
author: Vera D.

description:
Red Flag #1 popped up when I opened the menu - prices we 50% higher than they should have been for this grimy, C-Town joint. But there were a lot of awards along the wall (circa 1994), and I seem to remember something special about this place (circa 1994), so thought I'd splurge. 

Red Flag #2 - My hot tea order contained little rose buds floating at the top of the glass that said "You just bought some expensive-ass tea you assumed was gonna be free".

Red Flag #3 - The wordless waiter brought and charged us for side orders of rice without asking (I got a salad - did I need rice?).

Red Flag #4 - We were overcharged, which I suspected would happen after #1,2,3. I would never have known I was ripped off except I made the cashier go over every line (or is it column) of the scribbled-in-Chinese bill.

The food was Chinese standards (potstickers), a few with a creative twists I guess. But only a masochist would endure the Gordon Gekko ethos permeating the House of Nanking.
author: Nick C.

description:
DELICIOUS!!!    It's like i ate for the first time.
we were taken here by a friend and, at first, i didn't think much of it. small place, lots of people, and waited about five minutes. we were a table of five, so we ordered everything and WOW! Each and every dish was SO F**KING DELICIOUS! (excuse my french) The hot tea was amazing. The head chef was the waiter, which showed me he had a touch of class. I will definitely be back.
author: MICK E.

description:
It's just not the same restaurant I remember eating at back in the early 90's.  Oh yeah! I know why...

BECAUSE I WAS SO FREAKING BAKED OUT OF MY GOURD WHEN I ATE THERE, ANYTHING & EVERYTHING TASTED GOOD WITH THE KIND OF MUNCHIES I HAD!!!!

Drug test all the positive reviewers for this place & I bet  you'll see an interesting pattern develop.

I mean, c'mon.  There's sooooo many better places to eat if your that stoned.  Have you no shame?

House of same sauce...I love it!
author: Bill T.

description:
*yawn*

When I first moved here seven years ago I was so excited about this place.  It smelled like pee, but who cared when you got an "authentic" Chinatown experience.  The food wasn't great, every item had sweet potatoes in it, and the wait staff was rude... but this was city life, right?

I went again last week.  It still smells like pee.
author: Will S.

description:
Not what I expected! I was raised on Chinese food so eating out Chinese is mediocre and boring since I can probably make it better. But holy crap, I've been out done! 
The Hot and Sour soup is much different than I've ever had. Peas and cucumbers? Not usually found in this soup, but they made it work. It was the perfect amount of vinegar to pepper! The chicken was cooked perfectly, although I much rather prefer tofu in my soup.
I usually don't eat scallops or calamari (don't like the texture) but my boyfriend was insistent on ordering it. I'm glad he did! The flavors were wonderful, and the sauce was the right consistency. (Most places will drown the dish in an over starched sauce.) 
The scallops were my favorite, they melted in my mouth!

The best part - portions. Quality over quantity. A concept most places don't get.

Service is to be expected from a Chinese resty. Don't take it personal, the Chinese are just not the most hospitable people. The line out the door is worth the wait.
author: Leona C.

description:
Soup Nazi meet Nanking. Nanking, Soup Nazi.

Most people are put off by the service, but you have to chalk it up to it being one of those places where you're paying for the food, and you laugh off the abrupt nature of the staff. Like, Dinosaur BBQ in Syracuse, people come from all over for the food with the expectation you're going to be cussed out by the tawdry waitresses in fishnets and biker's leather.

If you're lucky, the wait in line outside is short. Once seated, sardine style, in one of two sections of the cramped restaurant, you are promptly presented with menus. 

When approached by the staff to take your order, you have to know what you want ALMOST immediately. Otherwise, anticipate that they will ORDER FOR YOU. This is how the conversation goes if you pause for slight internal deliberation on a menu choice:
Waiter:  What you want?
You:  Um, we were thinking of the ...
Waiter:  What you like? Chicken, shrimp? 
You: ... umm
Waiter:  *sigh*
You:  Shrimp and chicken
Waiter: (scribbling) you want both? 
You: ... umm ...
Waiter:  (scribbling)
You:  ... sure
Waiter:  (surveying group) okay, I help you out. Appetizer?
You: (catching on) yes!
Waiter:  okay, good.

After your first time or it's explained to you, this is how a mutually pleasant conversation goes:
Waiter:  What you like?
You:  We will have the ONION CAKE WITH PEANUT SAUCE ...
Waiter:  uh-huh (scribbling)
You:  ... and SESAME SHRIMP ...
Waiter:  okay (scribbling)
You:  ... and what's in the 3-vegetable dish?
Waiter: Good vegetable, I fix you up good
You:  Great, but no mushrooms, I'm ALLERGIC
Waiter:  Yep!

Everything I've tried here is good. Except the tea. It's a little weird with the floating roses, but the flavor's acceptable.
author: Carrie S.

description:
We need to get this average rating above 3 stars. It should be a solid 4 at least.
Been coming here for almost 20 years and don't mind crossing the bridge, spending the gas to eat at this cheap, yummy dive-of-a-place.
Tourist trap? Maybe--but the tourists aren't getting ripped off and the diveyness gives it some authenticity doesn't it? Hard Rock Cafe --now that's a tourist trap and lousy, overpriced food to boot. But not here.

I know, just the whites eat here, and no Asians. Good! It will keep the lines down if they all went here, too! They doubled the size of the place maybe 6-7 years ago so that's helped a bit. Service has never been real friendly but they get you in and out in good time and that's all I want.
Shrimp cakes are awesome and the Nanking Chicken is huge, tasty and cheap compared to other places in the area.
author: Jim K.

description: Best chinese food I have ever had!!! I specifically came back SF just to eat here after I had so many people tell me about this place. It was totally worth it we ate here twice in two days! i loved loved loved the potsitckers both fried and steamed and the seseme chicken was to die for!!!!
author: Angelina A.

description:
What do you get when you add mediocre food to rude service, uncomfortable seats and a long wait? This joint.

Unfortunately I have to walk by it every day after work and I'm amazed that it gets so much business. Bad news for the many really good Chinese establishments in town.
author: Denny S.

description: Don't do it. We did it because we wanted to eat in china town. The walk there was dirty, smelly, and full of homeless. Not their fault. We waited outside for about 15 minutes on a Thursday night. Seated alongside 2 dudes, and proceeded to get sensory overload. Clanking plates, short waitstaff (and I don't mean their height) very limited menu. Wife's wine was totally watered down. Who does that?  Now the real review. I'm used to Chinese food. We pick or favorite neighborhood restaurants and when we find what we like, we tend to order again and again. Some places make some dishes better. I would never order here again not when visiting San Francisco, go a second time. I'd find somewhere better. The food tasted greasy. Yeah greasy food tastes good unless you realize your eating greasy food. The food was ok. Heck the 2 pot smelling dudes next to us said it was the best egg rolls they ever ate. Good for them, they must have been hungry. Don't be fooled tourist thinking this place is the bomb. It's not. But I don't have an alternative yet so keep searching yelp.
author: John M.

description: Best Chinese food ever! Try the beef wraps.
author: Lisa P.

description:
Beware, they DO NOT TAKE CREDIT CARDS. 

Well, we had received a recommendation that this was a place we HAD to stop at. Having read the reviews, I was excited to go. We lucked out that there was not a huge line when we went. The communal seating was OK, but it was a bit annoying because we kept having to get up as people came and left (and for some reason a party next to us, came and chose to leave right away). The service was no-nonsense, and that's fine --although our waitress seemed to think it was ridiculous that we wanted rice, which we found a bit odd. The food was ok, but I would have liked more menu options, as the menu didn't seem to have many unique items. 

However, after we got our food, we started noticing that they were telling people that their machine was broken and they didn't take credit cards. I was extremely angry because they advertise as taking credit cards, and had they warned us at the beginning of the meal I would have made sure we wouldn't have gone beyond the amount of cash we had. When our check came, I gave them my credit card, they took it, but then came back to say the machine was broken. I know that happens, but I didn't believe them. They seemed in-genuine, and more like they were scamming people. We were able to scrounge together the exact amount of our bill with change, and left without tipping them (and needless to say, very unhappy with the experience).
author: s b.

description:
This a must visit and eat 'til you drop kind of place. I asked for a Gluten Free meal: No Soy sauce (wheat), no MSG (very important, because they use it in their food) and no other gluten ingredients... They were so aware and careful and accomodating about my request, each of the 3 waiters knew about it and told me which food I could eat( i was with my 1 year old) and a group of friends)
The food was superb, asian fusion. You have to wait in line for a table but is worth every minute in the cold !!!
author: Mr. T.

description:
My husband and I went to this restaurant based on a LA Times travel section review on China Town.  The writer wrote this restaurant up for cheap/good digs.

Well, it really wasn't cheap, and it was far from good.  I would say that we have pretty good taste in food, having lived in some of the most culturally diverse cities--Chicago, L.A., and have tasted our fair share of different cuisines, but the food here is far worse than a Panda Express (in fact, I would prefer that).

To begin with, was the ambience of the place.

This is a little hole-in-the-wall type of place, and the interior is bare bones, w/ metal picnic chairs, grimy tables and cracked dishes.  The dishes come pre-fingerprinted and the rice bowl looks like FIDO's water dish.  

Your drinks arrive in cans, no glasses, which I was actually thankful for, as I could wipe off the tops.

Then there was the manager.  Upon sitting down, she approached us and brusquely asked if this was our first time here.  When we said "yes," she started interrogating us as to what foods we like--"You want soup? You will eat the special Won Ton Soup! Do you want chicken or beef?  Chicken--then you have to eat the Sesame chicken."  I tried to pipe in, as that was not what we wanted, but then she rushed off with our order.  

When the soup arrived, we receiced a bowl of WATER with bits of fried chicken that were soggy (flavored like KFC) and some won tons.  The won tons were ok, but literally, the broth WAS water.  No chicken stock, no salt/pepper.  Water.  

Then, came the sesame chicken.  I'm not sure what part of it was sesame, as there was no sesame flavor/seeds/etc.  It was basicaly a mound of gristly fried to death chicken bits (if there was a shred of chicken in the batter) smothered in a heavy orange/teriyaki sauce that was very heavy.  Accompanying this were sliced yams that would have been fairly tasty, had they not been smothered in the same sauce.  

The whole meal, you could hear the staff yelling back and forth in the background.

The sesame chicken came to $8.95 and the won ton soup was also $8.95!!   Just down the street  (1 block) is R&G whose rice plates start at around 6-7 bucks.  

In sum, very abrupt, rude staff, horrible atmosphere (worried I may contract something), and the worst food in general I have ever eaten and I've eaten Chinese/Vietnamese food for over three decades.  Don't go here unless you're bringing someone you really don't like...
author: Tommy L.

description: This food is to die for! I've never had better Chinese food. I don't order from the menu, I simply tell them what kind of meat I'm in the mood for and let them surprise me. It's always crowded and I've had to wait to be seated a few times but the wait is never overwhelmingly long. It's worth it!
author: Cindy P.

description:
My brother heard about this place so he took the family here. It's tight and cramped inside, loud, dirty and not to mention hard to find parking.

When we finally got in, we sat at a table and basically had the owner (?) order us everything. Service was non-existent and the food was, eh. I do agree with Jason G. that if you're not Asian, you'll probably love this place.  Don't expect to have traditional, home-style Chinese cooking here when most of the diners are reading from their tour books.
author: Janel Y.

description:
I was hungry.
Craving Chinese food.
Saturday night.
Before 7pm.
Party of three.
Long line.
Wait took 30 - 40 minutes.
Once seated, service was quick.
Food came out fast. 
          + Hot and sour soup is to die for.
          + Nanking sesame chicken was crispy on the outside, but tender inside.
          + Crispy noodle with beef is tasty.
Definitely all very delicious.
Drank Tsing Tao to wash down the yummyness in my mouth.
The long wait was worth it.
But I hate waiting.
Will probably order take-out in the future.
Hot and sour soup...GOOD.
I want more :-)!

P.S. 
Just an observation.
Bigger parties (+5) seem to be seated quicker than smaller parties (-4).
author: Celeste M.

description:
We will begin with the admission that there really is no such thing as a "bad" chinese restaurant in San Francisco...

That being said, it becomes a question of which ones are "better."

I resent the current Yelp average rating for this restaurant (3 stars for this place is bullshit.)  This is one of the "best" chinese restaurants I've been to across America... and that is a bold statement.  

I have never tasted anything like it nor experienced a chef/ owner greeting me and taking my order... wait... he didn't take my order... he told ME what I what I was going to eat.  I had no say or choice in the matter.  It was kind of like a sick joke.

But low and behold, every piece of food he served me and family was delicious.  In fact, it was incredible.

This restaurant is a casual dining experience located in Chinatown.  The cost of your meal at this restaurant is a bargain considering your typical SF fare.  The service is fine and waiting for a table or your meal is minimal.

I would highly recommend eating here if you have not already.  There is a reason why this chinese restaurant has stood in the streets of Chinatown for as many years as it has.

Enjoy.
author: Steven F.

description:
So I know, I can't help it I know I'm half Asian but I am white washed as hell yo.  My friends just considered me tan.   haha.  Anyways, back to my review. I know House of Nanking is not the epitome of authentic but.....

I just can't help it, I love House of Nanking.

I don't care if they pour the same brown sauce on everything they serve!  

It's damn tasty.

That sauce is like a magic potion everything it touches turns to Chinese food gold.  

I mean really what's not to like? 

Stuffed mushrooms with sliced apples?  GOOOOD!
Orange flavored chickie boom chicken?  GOOOOD!
Cooked veggies?  GOOOD!
Top it all off with the brown saucey stuff?  Oh ya it's GOOOOD!

Best cheap, easy, reliable Chinese in the city.

But expect a wait at this local tourist trap.
author: Kat R.

description:
So bland. 

So americanized.

They should call it as fusion asian food.

Don't bring your chinese friends here and tell them they serve the best chinese food. It's that bad. 

Not worth the wait or the money.
author: Rhapsody I.

description:
House of Diarrhea.

I enjoyed my crispy fried beef with sesame vegetables, but not as much as my toilet.

Pepto Bismal, not necessary - colon cleanse, complimentary
author: Lauren G.

description:
We went here for my birthday and it was phenomenal. 

If I read one more review from someone talking about a restaurant in this city being "inauthentic" I swear to goats I will stick my chopsticks in my eye. Unless you're in China, it's going to be somewhat inauthentic. Get the fuck over it. I'm Norwegian. I don't tell people how to make sweaters or fish.

But IS THE FOOD GOOD?

Yes. Damn good. 

Is it touristy? 

If you found out that the soup nazi of Chinese food was going to decide what you eat but you would leave happy, you'd be into the novelty too. I know my friends and I were when we decided to give it a try for my birthday. And by the way, we are locals. 

It's not really set up for groups, but they accommodated our party of 8 with no problem and the food portions they brought out were perfect. Everybody left full, happy, and curious to try them again. It was a great way to celebrate my birthday and I would definitely go back.
author: Kat E.

description:
This place wasn't really chinese food. The food was tasty however, but doesn't really live upto the hype as a lot of the reviewers pointed out. The lines are long, the space is crammed and the food is pricey. Chinese food isn't supposed to cost you 17 dollars a person, we ended up paying 8 dollars for a snowpea shoots dish (that cost about a dollar a pound in china town down the street). 

If you really want to experience the place, sure go for it. If you want some good chinese food (without the wait), I would skip it and go someplace else.
author: Girish P.

description: Some of the best Chinese food I have ever had. The staff will sugfest what you should eat to get variety and I was iffy about the fish until I found out how great it was. The calamari is awesome as is the egglant too. The only disappointment was the pork eggrolls...was suprised to find only pork inside and I was missing all the veggie goodness. Will return and recommend to others.
author: Amanda P.

description: So, I was standing at Kennedy Airport Friday, March 1st waiting to be screened by the TSA. It was early in the morning and I was a bit irked, but managed to smile at the TSA agent standing by the machine and said, "good morning, how are you?" To which he replied , "I'm doing just great and how are you?" so I replied, "I'm just fine and dandy." He laughed and said that my "fine and dandy" was about as sincere as his "doing just great," and then asked where I was headed. When I replied "San Francisco," the agent beamed and said, "Best place to visit in the world! You MUST visit the House of Nanking!" He proceeded to write the name and street location (Kearny Street) on my boarding pass and handed it to my husband as I went into the machine. I posted a photo of my boarding pass on Facebook, and no sooner had I done so, when half a dozen friends said that I MUST go to House of Nanking! So, the TSA not only screens you now, but gives you decent restaurant recommendations. Well, I was very happy I took the TSA agent's advice and made the sojourn to House of Nanking. I had a delicious dining experience: I would definitely recommend ordering the onion cake (a tasty take on a scallion pancake, but more crisp, fresh and served with a yummy peanut sauce) and the flowering tea (a lovely flower opens from a little ball of leaves floating in a beer stein-sized glass). The onion cake was so compelling that a couple dining next to me asked me what it was and I obligingly gave them slices to taste: the portions were so generous, I could not finish it by myself. Further proof of the onion cake's allure is that I was sitting in the window with my back to the street and a man came into the restaurant and said to me, "Excuse me: I was walking by and had to ask you what you are eating--it looks so delicious!" I told him it was the onion cake and that he should try it, as it was indeed delicious. The man proceeded to sit down at another table and ordered the onion cake. The service was perfectly pleasant and obliging and I was very happy to have had my very delightful House of Nanking moment. As a matter of fact, a week later I wound up sitting next to a San Franciscan at Cafe Sabarsky (at the Neue Galerie) and asked her if she had ever been to the House of Nanking: as it happens she had not, but she wrote it down and said she would go. Thanks, TSA agent: you made my trip not only safe to San Francisco, but very tasty, too!
author: Kim G.

description:
Boo-urns.  After having our guidebook hype this place, I was disappointed.  The food is solid, but overpriced and under-quantitized.  I was suspicious from the get go as there were strictly non-Chinese (mostly whites; Gwailo () ratio approaching infinity) in the restaurant.

My wife ordered the scallops ($15) in garlic sauce.  They were tasty, but few and sliced thinly (for deception, I might posit.)  I ordered the house noodle specialty which was solid, but a little pricey at $10, given that many Chinatown places (if they served Shanghai-style noodles) would sell a larger portion at $6-8.

Overall, I was very underwhelmed.  The quality was fine, but higher prices & low quantity explains the lack of Chinese and why I won't go back.  Go eat at the nearby Broadway Cafe for cheaper & more food.

(This might be a good 'safe' place if you want to take a friend that wouldn't otherwise eat ethnic food.)
author: Ward W.

description:
We were suppoesd to eat at Chef Jia's based on our tricycle driver's suggestions, but Chef Jia's was closed, and we were running late for an engagement.

We go to House of Nanking instead, and are not very warmly greeted!  We did enjoy the fried rice, and the sesame chicken very much.   I enjoyed the sweet potato a lot most especially!

But the service reminded me of the service at Chinese Restaurants in Hong Kong where they practically throw the dishes at you.

I don't think I'll be back.
author: Anna V.

description:
My friend and I went for lunch and ordered the Sesame Chicken and shrimp cake appetizers.  Both were delicious!  And everything on the menu looked good, we had a hard time deciding.

I will definitely be going back for more.
author: hag a.

description: Hadn't been here in a few years and made a point to go here after great experiences... in the past.  Has gone downhill from its heyday.  Service was fine but out of tea... of any kind. In a Chinese restaurant? Seriously? Recipes were nice but the quality of the chicken was terrible. A shame as this place used to rock.
author: Manny K.

description:
Hrmm for a place that supposedly has a Michelin star, I'm not super impressed. There's always a ton of people and a ton of buzz. I would say it rivals San Tung but definitely loses.

It's still worth a shot if you're out and about in North Beach and feel like Chinese food, though. Make sure you order the sesame chicken!
author: Han C.

description: Best Chinese food I have had in my life! Great service, unique choices, and even a good vegetarian menu! The vegetarian person who spent 5 years in China, and the guy who "doesn't really like foreign food" all left happy. Loved the pork dumplings and the green beans. Price was reasonable as well. I will definitely be back!
author: Maxine N.

description:
I love the food and the service here - or at least the atmosphere of hustle and bustle. It is not a place for first dates or finicky eaters. But it's a convivial restaurant with superb food.

I brought some friends from out of town here, and took the advice of other Yelpers to ask for recommendations. The waitress asked if we were ate everything - seafood, pork, etc. We said yes. She asked if we were hungry. We said yes. She asked if we were VERY hungry. And after a day of touring the city, we were!
author: Corey T.

description:
ALL HYPE!  |  This is not real Chinese or Hunan food.

*Service - rushed to order and pay due to the long line outside
*Seating - Nothing like being able to eat off of your neighbor's plate
