*Food - I had the signature dish with beef which fast food quality (too sweet), but the tea was good. My girlfriend ordered another dish and what do you know the same sauce.  Dishes are tailored for the American pallet.
*Over priced (Go to Panda Express)
*Not worth the wait 30-45min (Don't get suckered by the long line in front)
*Look who's eating there, Are there a lot of Asians?

Waiting + rushed + price + expectation of food quality + Brown sweet sauce = 1 star


Don't get sucked into the long lines in front of the restaurant as I was.  Long lines do not equal good food.  I asked the owner what was good and he said to me, "I'll get you something special, what kind of meat?".  "Beef" I replied.  The signature dish came out which was this fried battered beef, available in chicken and fish, drowning in this brown sweet sauce.  The food is nothing to rave about as there is no range in flavor.  Hope you like brown sweet sauce as it is on a lot of dishes.  Save yourself the wait and cash and get the same quality meal at Panda Express without the wait, price and being rushed.  General Gao's Chicken anyone?

I have heard the House of Nanking use to be good back in the day, but now that he has all these suckers get sucked into the hype they keep coming back for more. Brown sauce for all!
author: Po L.

description: Wow this place has some of the best Chinese food I have ever eaten. The server offered to do the ordering for us and she did not disappoint. Extraordinarily fresh food and delicious flavor combinations utilizing both traditional and nontraditional ingredients (like sweet potato and spinach). We had the Pork Wonton Soup (amazing -- I had a second bowl), Sesame Chicken, Panfried Garlic Fish, Ginger Garlic Poached Scallops, a crispy sesame-beef dish, and the Bao Bing Wrap. I want to go back for more today!
author: Chuck B.

description:
Not for the weak stomach.  Read.

I used to frequent this place back in the day until one bad day.  That day started with an appetite for greasy spicy chinese and ended with a roach (yes, a roach) dropping down from the ceiling onto my face and grazing my lips.  I then witnessed the chinese workers chasing it and trying to kill it with a broom.  I was nauseaus and never returned.  Would you?
author: dizzle d.

description:
Okay food is good but service horrible and this place is not clean.

What we ordered:
Appetizer- onion pancake = delicious
Entree- sesame chicken, good but they didn't give you much

Now for the gross part.  There is a sink near bathroom.  I and some others made the mistake of washing their hands their since the bathroom wasn't open.  Noticed some knats on the rim of the glasses near the sink.  Then a lady comes and yells at us not to wash our hands there.  We didn't know and apologized but she kept on being angry.  She only rinsed out the water pitcher once. Soap in water likely.
author: G A.

description:
Delicious delicious garlicky brown sauce. You could put that crap on a shoe and I would eat it. Nothing else matters.

My friend told me a story about bringing a guy that was visiting from Germany to eat here. He had some serious "personal space" issues and he just about had a meltdown being packed in at a long table with a bunch of drunk strangers elbowing him and spitting while they talked and ate.

Awesome.
author: Chris E.

description:
BIPOLAR YELP:
I am 100% ethnically Chinese (+/- some for accuracy).  The food sucks orifice.  But white people like it.  It has been Americanized in the most efficient manner possible.  They identified the specific taste profile that suits American tastebuds then reapplied that to all their dishes.  If culinary science had buzzwords, this would be MSG 2.0 Everything there tastes the same, yet soothes whitey into thinking it is authentic comfort food.

I highly recommend it if you grew up on traditional American cuisine.  If you dig the authentic then duck, roll and run as your foodie platoon give you cover fire.
author: H C.

description:
This place is wildly inconsistant. I recommend ONLY taking your waiters recommendations, seriously. No matter what looks good on the menu. Once I ordered Cashew Chicken and I'll be dipped if it wasn't made with salted cashews. Like they ran outta nuts and restocked at Walgreens. What's next, Dry Roasted in the Kung Pao?

When next I ate Chinese on this block, it was at Chef Gia's, next door. Where I heartily recommend the Honey Chili anything...
author: Jeremy W.

description: Food is good but portions are small. Four stars, really, for the environment. We had a great time. The fast service and succession of plates were ideal for a get-together with family
author: Jo N.

description:
Is it bitchy to be picky? Or is being picky considered close minded rather? Hmmm... Well, I dont like to be seen in either category, but for the way I feel about Chinese food, it may come off as such.

Chinese food is by far my most undesired meal. As I sit in my office this morning, I still feel like I ate my Chinese food 5 minutes ago. Yes, I brushed my teeth twice in between then and now... I have even had a cup of coffee and wheat toast! But still my tummy is full and my mouth has an after taste of grease.

I know, sounds delicious! 

After all my Chinese food talk, I have to say Nanking served us well! Our family style plates were great. We started with a mushroom dish soaked in flavor. Then we had a Sesame Chicken plate with Sweet Potatoes and a weird beef dish (It had hard noddles, like uncooked topromin), Ooohhh and I cant forget the pork pot stickers! Those were the best, but I found myself only eating 2 of them. They looked and tasted like a heart attack waiting to happen. 

This kind of meal you can only eat once in awhile, for health reasons. For real authentic Chinese food, I'd highly recommend House of Nanking. Not only do you get great service, but the style of the restaurant makes you feel as if you're in another Country. There are tables packed together and they seat you on to other party's tables. I thought it was interesting, but not if it were my table. Luckily we got a spot by the window, the only table for two I noticed. 

Also, before walking into this place you know there must be something good about it walking into a crowded restaurant on Monday night at 9:00PM.

It's a rarity, but I like this one!
author: Dee C.

description:
If you're a banana or not Asian go here. If you're an egg or Asian, don't go here.

Signs that the restaurant would be terrible:

- Non-asians say they love the restaurant
- Upon entering you realize you're the only Chinese in the restaurant.
- There were no chop sticks unless you asked for it.  
- They give you huge plates and no bowls.  
- When asking the owner not to put MSG in the food, she replies that some have been steamed in it and would be impossible to remove.

Things that verified the restaurant was indeed terrible:
- The rice was dry
- Food is fatty.
- Taste like Panda Express; atleast Panda Express is cheaper.  
- The cong you bing looked like orange chicken!  Really!?

Really!??
author: Dimitri Y.

description:
The key to dining at any restaurant is to be nice to the host/hostess. Give them a $5 tip as you leave and introduce yourself (this is different from your server tip). Your name will remembered the next time you eat at this establishment. Well, even if they don't remember your name, it's key to mention their name the next time you dine to confirm that you've already established a business relationship.

If you're lucky, the host will be the proprietor, Peter, or his Dragon Lady ("DL") for a wife (is it just me who notices that there's always a DL that runs a tight ship in well-established Asian restaurants?). More reason to get chummy with the owners if you want to be a regular at this place.

Another sign of a good restaurant is when you notice that their cooks have very greasy hair. Luckily, they've recently implemented baseball caps for their cooks at HNK. 

I suggest ordering any of their Nanking dishes garnished with sweet potatoes, mu shu anything, vegetarian and tofu specials. You can also just ask Peter or DL to fix something off the menu. Ask and thou shall receive. I guarantee you'll be pleased.

Sidenote: For those who compare Chef Jia next door to HNK , there is no comparison. Chef Jia needs to take lessons on how to add flavor to their food. Bleh. My disappointment at Chef Jia is not even worth Yelping about.
author: Miles G.

description:
I haven't been here in awhile mainly due to location and lack of parking, but the last time was memorable, our mother daughter dinner. 

The dish I remember the most looked like cooked grass with ground up meat topped with extra spices. My mom liked the dish so much that she figured out the recipe and we have it home cooked style like at least once a month. I vouch for letting the restaurant decide what you want to eat too, it works here. 

Pricier than most Chinese restaurants in the area, because of the buzz and Zagat ratings. Use the golden rule when it comes to Chinese restaurants, count the number of white people in the restaurant and walk that many blocks... (JOKE!)
author: Sara D.

description:
I like this place, but the wait... *sigh* the wait.

Ask for the appetizer pancake looking thing that's fried. I also love the sesame chicken here. BOMBDIGGITY. 

The negs are that sometimes, the owner will order something for your table, but it will be pricey and not what I was looking for. If you are a picky eater, I suggest ordering on your own. The decor isn't that great either, but they DID remodel a bit inside.
author: Ginger G.

description:
I never understood what the big deal was about this place.

When I've gone it's been like this - a long wait followed by having plates of food flung at you while smelling the scent of urine from the bathroom.

Yuck.
author: Shannon W.

description: Fabulous Chinese food in my favorite city. Don't bother ordering from the menu -- just ask for dinner. They will take care of you. Miss you, Nanking.
author: Brian P.

description:
I suspect Nanking is getting knocked a few stars simply because they enlarged, updated the decor beyond "hole in the wall" and are successful. But the food here is great. Much better than most, and well worth going back. The unsmiling owner (?) nevertheless has treated us well on many occasions, helping to ensure that we've got a good blend of recommended foodstuffs.

Best to come here with 6 people or so (preferably off the rush hours) and share lots of different items.
author: Doug B.

description: This place was super disappointing. The hype should have been a warning, but we ate here against our better judgment. Not good. Everything was way too salty, even for Chinese food.
author: Cami J.

description: A unique spot... metal tables and chairs, tables so close that you're essentially sitting with neighboring tables, plastic laminated menus, a line outside to wait for a table... BUT delicious food! I really love the sizzling rice soup, tea, chinese greens, stuffed veggies, and mu shu. The owner is also happy to order for your whole table which can be really nice if you have a big group. You would just let him know if any of you are vegetarians, etc and he'd bring out all the yummy dishes. This food is unique and not your typical chinese but I really like it!
author: Meghan P.

description:
I have been eating hear once/year for the past 13 years.  The place has gone through 2 renovations, but you probably wouldn't have guessed it, since it still looks like a cramped dive.

The thing to do is to let them order for you, with some suggestions as to what you want.  I always say seafood and very spicy.  That does the trick.

I go with large groups and on off nights since a crazy line will build outside.

Sure my Chinese friends all say its not traditional, but they want to go back with me every year anyway.

The prices have steadily increased, but that feeling of complete culinary satisfaction has not changed.  As long as I will be visiting San Fran, I will be making a stop here.
author: Andrew N.

description:
Attitude without expertise. Getting seated after a half hour wait outside, we were given two menus for seven people. They might as well have given us none, as our waiter refused to allow us to pick our dishes. Through a strange mix of aggressiveness, unintelligibility, and our unwillingness to brave the streets - he persuaded (or rather forced) us to submit to his will. We tried to get in at least a couple of instructions - no beef, no sweet sauces etc that were marginally respected.

The food arrived quickly, I suspect, because they were just serving whatever was being cooked up by the kitchen. That being said, the sizzling rice soup was great, and unexpectedly spicy. The rest of the dinner (onion pancake, deepfried potstickers, some fish dish, sesame chicken, mushrooms with onions, shrimp with spinach) was hardly impressive. The one exception was mushu pork which was unedible - spare yourself please.

Definitely not an experience worth repeating.
author: Looja T.

description: This place needs to be bigger.  With the amount of foot traffic they have, you would think they would expand.  They squeeze people in wherever they can...I'm sure there must be some sort of fire safety code violation there.  The food was good.  We had the waitress just order for us, and if you go there for the first time, I think that's a pretty good idea.  They know what's good...and we basically just told them what we liked and didn't like....and BAM!  Food came out.  I liked the food, but I'm not sure if I'd go here again because it was sooooooo crowded.  I know it's very big in the San Francisco area, and everyone says it's a must-go place, but I think once is sufficient.  It's not worth being crammed like sardines into a small room.  My chinese mom can make that stuff.
author: swang l.

description:
I loved this place!  We stopped in here for our second lunch just because we had to try this place.  We ordered a couple dishes and shared them among the 5 of us.  I only wish I could have had my own dish, that's how good it was!

We didn't come here during peak lunch or dinner hours though, so finding a table wasn't a problem.  The service was very quick here too.  I'd definitely come back, although I don't think I would wait too long to eat here for dinner, as it has a more diner like atmosphere (unless that's what you're looking for).
author: Cathy S.

description:
Only expect good food, which is what House of Nanking delivers!  The honest key to House of Nanking is to not order: just leave it up to the waiter.  They know their food and what pairs up well!

Second key to House of Nanking?  Get over the service (see my previous rant about Chinese restaurants and service).  They do what Chinese restaurants (not PF Changs) do - squash you in a row of tables, never come back with your change, throw dishes at you.

And here's a tip: come early.  Maybe 5ish.  It fills up quick!
author: Wendy T.

description:
I have mix feelings about this place.   It's like they have two cooks, one that makes really good dishes, and another one that makes crap.  

I like how the owner will order for you, although this may get annoying if you eat here on a regular basis.
author: Tinou B.

description:
House of Nanking is pretty awesome. 

Located in the limbo land between North Beach and the FiDi, House of Nanking is hard to miss with its multicolored neon sign and velvet rope outside keeping the eager patrons at bay.

Cramped, dark and hectic, House of Nanking is certainly an experience. The waiter comes, he may or may not ask you what you want, but he'll probably just bring you a few plates of food. Either he has psychic powers, or all of Nanking's dishes are excellent, maybe both, but whatever he brings is always perfect.

Definitely famous amongst SF locals, and worth all the hype. I'm a bit surprised by the low reviews...House of Nanking is great!
author: Sophie D.

description:
This is really difficult for me to review. I have a lot of mixed feelings for this place. At first I love it, then I realize its not so great. 

First of all, it's sort of expensive for me as a college student. To get enough food to fill me up, it will take some $$ at this place. It is only around $10 a plate, so at first you think it is only a tad more expensive than your normal corner chinese place... but oh are you wrong. You'll have to order at least 4 plates to feed you and one other person.

The food there is really good, but don't expect variety. The chef / waitress will treat you to what he thinks you will like (as long as that's what you want him/her to do). However, this is easy for him as they only have 5 main entree dishes (IIRC). And they all use the same sauce. However, I LOVE their sesame chicken, and the soup I had there is the best soup I've had in my life.  Perhaps this should warrant 4-5 stars? I dont know, because like I said, there are only 5 main dishes, all with the same sauce.

Service isn't the best in the world, but I wasn't expecting much from this type of the place, and so I haven't removed any stars due to this. Just remember you wont see any smiling faces if that is what you are looking for. I will mention though that I celebrated my birthday here with my parents when they visited me. My parents gave the owner of the place a birthday cake, he turned off all the lights in the place and had everyone sing happy birthday to me. That was pretty cool for a birthday present.

I don't know why the wait is so long to this place (another downside). Chef Jia's next door is just as good in my opinion. In fact, I make a trip downtown one to three times a month to eat at Jia's. At least there I can get some cheap, good chinese food with variety.
author: Aaron M.

description:
I love Peter and Cathy Fang. They know how to treat their customers well. I've been on several occasions and have told Cathy how much we'd like to spend and just let her order for us. She'll even come back to check on you and see if you have enough room if you've not met your limit. 

Went again this past Saturday night and Peter brought out a salad for us that we didn't order, complimentary. The meal was delicious, as always, the service was hectic, but it's a crowded place. At the end of the meal Peter brought my date and I a couple of the blooming flower tea buds "for brunch tomorrow."

I can't recommend this place enough. Get to know them and they're the best hosts you can hope for.
author: Joe R.

description:
Oh my, Nanking style = honey/basil/??? yummieness.
Small, not fancy at all. Service is fast rude and to the point.
But the best Chinese food I've had anywhere.

They've cleaned up their act some, it's amazing what some paint and new lighting can do for a place, but it's still a tiny Chinatown hole in the wall.

We make a trip to Chinatown and circle the block praying to the parking fairy every time we visit SF just for House of Nanking.
author: Eric E.

description: This is a watered down version of Chinese food, but tasty nonetheless. My gourmet crew agreed that MSG may help, and they sure don't marketing themselves with big ole banneres like Brandy hos saying they dont use MSG. My friend happened to go to college w/ the daughter of the owner, so they ordered us some really good dishes. I especially like the fish fillet and fried mushrooms.. thats a good thing considering i normally abhore mushrooms. Prices for dinner were reasonable, but definitely get here for early dinner or else risk waiting in a long line. Service is mediocre, borderline inattentive.
author: Thomas L.

description:
The food may well be decent, but the service absolutely condemns any legitimate review to death...

The old man, who probably runs the place, was the only semblance of decent service around, although today he was dressed as if he was working on his car...

The rest of the staff was rude, and more concerned with mopping the floor then taking orders or otherwise serving patrons.  One server was even talking on her cell phone while she took some couple's order!!!
author: Nathan W.

description:
Nanking has definitely gone downhill over the past 5 years but I still enjoy it from time to time.  10 years ago when this place was 8 tables and a counter the food was spectacular and would have rated 5 stars.  Now that they've expanded, expanded and expanded again (including the prices) it's not nearly so special, walls of awards and signed chef photos be damned!  Bring tourist friends here whose Chinese food experience is limited to LaChoy out of a can or take-out eggrolls and chow mein.

DO NOT LET THEM ORDER FOR YOU!!!  This is a quaint, carpe diem experience that you can leave to the uninformed, scared tourists.  Definitely order from the menu and insist on what you want.  If you let Peter, the owner, order for you he will bring you the most expensive, most common dishes on the menu.  Counter surly with surly - it's not like they need the repeat business or will treat you any worse!  Part of the secret is learning the "Code of Nanking" which includes knowing what you want when Peter comes to take your order (if you don't know right then he may never return), expecting the food to be thrown on your table (part of the charm) and not being afraid to speak up if you want something (they won't accommodate you otherwise).

As for the food, the Nanking Chicken is the signature dish and is a must-have.  Other things I recommend are the fried tofu with pea shoots (they only serve this in season), the sizzling rice soup, the mu shu beef and the shrimp puffs served with a peanut sauce.

While there are very few Asian patrons, it helps to go with someone who speaks Cantonese so you can be assured of slightly better service (which isn't saying much).  There are certain items NOT on the menu that seem to only be available to those who can order in Chinese.  Go early to avoid the line, although it always moves quickly.  And don't be afraid to yell out to a server if you need something - it's the only way they'll give you the time of day between getting seated and getting the bill.
author: Jon B.

description:
For this Chicago boy this joint is the truth!

you San Fran snobs can walk up another hill to different restaurant if you like
author: Ron R.

description:
Before I moved to San Francisco, a friend that used to live here exclaimed "OMG! You've gotta go to House of Nanking. Best. Food. Ever! And Let the owner order for you". So naturally, I was excited and followed directions.

If you've heard anything about the owner, you must picture him to be similar to the Soup Nazi on Seinfeld, at least I know I did.  I went to have lunch with a friend and finally check out House of Nanking.  We asked the owner for suggestions which meant he just wrote down what he was going to send over. I've got some food restrictions so I asked for shrimp only entrees, at which he tried to convince me for a moment to get beef or chicken instead (to mix it up a bit), but I politely declined (hoping not to anger him and get banned from the restaurant! haha)

Everyone sits pretty close to each other, whether you know the people next to you or not.  Somehow it's not too awkward though, except when you stare at each others food wondering what it is... The food he sent over was pretty good, and the few times I've been there he's surprisingly sent over different entrees everytime. The food is good, but I will say that around my third visit I felt like all the hype was a tad bit overrated.  The food is good though so check it out, the Sesame shrimp is pretty yummy!

The only part I wasn't too crazy about is that althought I really like that the owner sends over an entree he thinks you'll like, it made me a little hesitant in asking too many questions about ingredients entrees since it was never really "approved" by me at the time of ordering.  This has resulted in sometimes getting veggies we're not too crazy about or sauces that we thought were just okay, but I guess it's also the opportunity to try diff entrees we might not otherwise order. 

Oh and the service (especially getting rice) is a bit slow... We've gotten our entrees many times before the steamed rice made it, and by the time the rice gets there, the food is a little cold... not too happy about that.
author: Shafaq C.

description:
If you're in the mood for a massive MSG blast that leaves your mouth tingling all night... then this is the place!
Anything with the yams is awesome! And I think almost everything there has yams in it. (Honestly, I just want to learn how to make the yams.)
It's definitely not "real" chinese-- kinda caters to tourists and such but, still it's kind of a fun place to go because it's so hectic. But, it's not amazing.
More of an unforgettable experience, really. And you end up having cravings for it later....  I rec'mend going for lunch during the week. Get the yams.
author: RuffNReddy R.

description:
The wife and I were in Frisco recently and checked out Yelp for the "best Chinese restaurant in San Francisco." This place was much recommended and close to almost everything.

Located on the edge of Chinatown and walking distance from Union Square, this place has everything one could ask for in casual, low-cost dining. Even the brusque manner of the servers shouldn't scare off those in search of a good meal.

We liked everything we ordered (yes, the waiter will order for you if it appears you're a newbie).  Especially the blooming flower tea.  Wow! That was extremely cool.  Gotta try that!
author: Dan D.

description:
it's got a line but it moves fast. they cook fast and surprise you with great food after asking what you don't want. The space is twice a big as it used to be, and that's great! you are still packed in bumping into other folks, but that's part of the excitement...

you haters may not like it, but I have NEVER had a bad meal there.... EVER!

I have eaten at several other Chinese restaurants in China town with much less service or taste... House of Nanking is my go to choice. So I'm a white boy... it tastes great to me!!

there is a line for a reason. it's damn tasty!
author: Robert B.

description: Perhaps the other dishes are better but the house noodles with vegetables and garlic were too rich and heavy for me.  Kept asking myself, is there butter in Chinese cuisine?  Not sure what was in it giving the heaviness, couldn't figure it out.  I will say that the baby greens mixed in and piled on top were delicious.
author: Eric Z.

description: EXCELLENT!  While on our dorky San Francisco bus tour, our driver told everyone that this is the best Chinese food in Chinatown.  He was likely right.  We ate there the next night, arrived around the beginning of dinner time before 6pm.  There was a line out the door 15 minutes later.  Sidewalk gawkers admired our two-topper window seat as we feasted on steamed potstickers.  My hubby had the hot and sour soup.  I had one of the others, I don't recognize the name from the menu now, but it had cilantro, and it was divine.  I then had chow mein for the entree.  It was authentic and yummy.  My hubby had the Nanking sesame chicken.  Don't come expecting uber-friendly service; you wont' find it here.  They are quick and to the point, efficient.  Don't let that ruin your experience though.  It's in a great part of town and you won't leave disappointed, I promise.
author: Cameron H.

description: I have been eating in this restaurant since the 80's.  For people whom think it's not fancy, you should have seen it then!  It was and always is about the food.  They have their own distinctive dishes.  The house Chicken Sesame being my favorite.  I go when I am in S.F. which is sometimes 5 times a year and I am always pleased.  Yes, they can be abrupt in their service if you are looking to be coddled, it's not that kind of place.  But, it's S.F. tradition and I loved that my friends that now live in S.F. knew about it as did my friends of 25 years ago.  That says something.  The locals eat here!
author: Kim P.

description: Was in today.  I will have to say that the service is NOT so good. But the food is good and after that I didn't even care seating next to strangers.  We had the sesame chicken some vegetable and some rice.  I will have to say that for a quick luck it was good... Oh don't get water get a soda or bring your own water (strongly  recommend you to do that)
author: Rj A.

description:
This place is where the MMM MMMMMM yummies are!

I've been here twice. Both times I had to wait for a table, both times I was crammed in with other customers, and both times I left very pleased. 

My first visit here, the Grandpa/owner ordered for us...dishes just kept flying out one after another and every single one was as good as the last. They do a very good job at incorporating sweet potatoes into their dishes and it never seems too greasy. 

The house chicken is very tasty, the mushrooms are onion-tastic, and I HIGHLY recommend the calamari. LIIIIIKEEEEE WOAH! It will be garlicy-msg explosions in yo' mouf. The squids/octopi come in this garlic broth which has extremely overwhelming (but amazing) flavors. My Mexican brother in law even loved this place and he barely eats anything more adventurous than red meat, rice, and beans. 

The only reason I won't give this hole in the wall 5 stars is because of its authenticity. Definitely NOT "CHINESE Chinese" but good nonetheless. Keep it up, House of Nanking.
author: Sony M.

description:
I don't get the lines at this place. It feels like its more of the case of "people see lines of people waiting to get in, so it must be good" mentality. At best, its an above average Chinese food place. At worst its an overpriced tourist trap with sucky service and dirty bathrooms.

My recent experience: we rolled in with a group of 7. From other reviews, we asked the waiter to take care of us. Never mind the cramped setting - I've been to and love dive restaurants. Now, not getting served water, that's a first. In my group of 7, only 4 we're lucky enough to get water. Um, ok.

Based on other experiences, we asked the waiter to take care of us. I can't remember what we got (we had a few vegetarians), but the food was above average. Some dishes were really good, others were really salty. Objectively speaking, I'd classify it as above average Chinese food. The bill came to something like 150 bucks. Not crazy, but definitely way more expensive than the food and service we got (again, only 4 of 7 of us were fortunate to get water).

To end the evening, we were told that the restaurant only takes cash. No credit cards. Makes you wonder what kind of operation this place really is.

My take:

Service? Sucky
Ambiance? Dirty
Food? Moderately tasty

Overall: a sketchy place and definitely not worth the effort of waiting in line and having bad service. Being generous, I give it two stars at best. Pass - nothing to see here.

ps: Regarding the dirty bathrooms, unless the employees are not human and don't need to use the bathroom, it makes you wonder where those hands preparing your food have really been. Food for thought.
author: Rick P.

description:
me and my friends were anxious to eat here at the house of nanking. i've heard alot about this small chinese resutrant; from tv (racheal ray) to other friends. we waited inline outside which was okay for us. when we got in, we told the chef that it was our 1st time in the resturant  (as sugested by my friend) and he told us he will take care of us. my gf wanted a hot and sour soup though but the chef insisted on a better one. 

first the server gave out the soup which looks like a wonton-like soup with seafood. it was okay, i had better. then they served some calamari. again it was okay, but i had better. then they served the stuffed mushroom. i like the flavors of this dish, but i didnt really wow me. that goes the same with the crisy beef, it was even a little too salty. becasue my gf didnt want the soup we ordered their hot and sour soup. turns out there's no 'hot' in their hot and sour soup. it broth even tasted like a pho which was kinna weird.

thier food did not live up to thier name that i was expecting. i isnt an authentic chinese resturant, more of a chinese fusion theme. alas, fusion or authentic, we were somewhat dissapointed with nanking.
author: Paul V.

description:
i'd actually give this more of a 4.5... the only thing i don't like about this place is the cafeteria style seating- you don't really have any privacy to carry on a conversation. there's usually a HUGE line here but we came on a wednesday night and got right in. major plus.

this is my 2nd time here and everything i've ever eaten has been fantastic. last night we got the flower tea, pea shoots, sizzling rice soup, and sesame chicken. the pea shoots had great flavor and i actually enjoyed them even though they were way too healthy next to the calamari i really wanted to order... ;)

sizzling rice soup was full of veggies and chicken and had some crunchy rice in it- very good.

my favorite was the sesame chicken with sweet potatoes. the sauce was tasty without overtaking the dish, the sweet potatoes were cooked just right and the chicken was awesome. the outside was crispy but didn't taste too greasy.

it's definitely some of the best Chinese in the city and i'll be back- hopefully to try some calamari next time!
author: Tami W.

description:
Touristy (no chopsticks) and pricey for what you get. 

The neighboring table of three people had a check of $82! You can usually feed a family of 8 in a real Chinese restaurant!

I went just to see if it was really worth the hype, etc. Not sure which tourist books recommend this place but the food was just "aiight".

After I asked for chopsticks I was given more attention--and speaking Chinese was a bonus. I think the staff was nicer to me because of it.

Ordered the rice soup (porridge with stuff in it) and the famous Nanking Chicken. Equal amounts of chicken and yams, but not much squash. Taste was okay but not great--nothing to make me want to get my grub on.

Check total=$18.50!
author: Kat H.

description:
You've Been Served!

First off if you're only a P.F Chang-er then don't hit this spot.  Also as far as i'm concerned there's only one way to Nanking, that's menu-less. 

Let me say this: If you got in a car with Mario Andretti would you ask to drive? No, you'd sit down, strap in and let the man do his work.  That's the approach one should take when dining at House of Nanking.  

If you go on a weeknight, a little later (after all the mid-westerner tourists have eaten) at about 7:30 you should be in good shape. Sit down, attempt to order a drink and let the man of the house start bringing you dishes.

The food's good, plentiful and will run the range from the standard chicken / shrimp dishes to some of the more exotic items like jellyfish. 

The best part is that once we were ready to roll ourselves home we got the check and split it 6 ways.  $20 a person.  I've not eaten that well for that much since..well...never.  

It's not fancy, but it's good and now earns a place on my top 10 list now.
author: Derek D.

description:
+ spicy, good

- small ass establishment = long ass wait.
author: Ladi Da A.

description:
Damn good food with unimpressive decor.  I always recommend this place to visitors, they are the ones who are willing to wait in line.

Usually I'll get mine to go to skip the line - I love the crispy beef and chow mein.  Also the peanut sauce that comes with the fried potstickers is delish.

If I'm in there - hopefully the chef/owner is there.  Peter Fong, I believe.  Let him do the deciding - he knows what is fresh and good.   Last time we were there we got some yummy calamari - the texture was perfect and the flavor of the seasonings were both unusual and delicious.

Of course, this isn't "real" chinese food - just a very good and fresh California variation on it.  I'm proud of this restaurant - people never come away saying "well, that was disappointing."

Service can be rushed and indifferent.  Occasionally, for some weird reason, they ask that you pay in cash rather than with credit - I've seen this happen twice.  I'm still trying to figure it out.

Bottom line: Great food, Great price.
author: Suze C.

description:
RACHAEL RAY!!!!!  HOW COULD YOU HAVE DONE ME WRONG?!?!?!?!?

after watching tasty travels ith rachael ray, i decided to check this place out.  my friends and i went on a sunday night and we waited in line for about 30 mintues.  the line was almost all white people which should have been warning sign number one (no offense).  also, i went to go see kathy griffin on her comedy tour a few months ago and she raved about this place also.  she made fun of the owner who never lets you order what you want and just brings out food to you.

well, knowing about the owner, my friends and i decided that we're going to just order off the menu.  i eat pretty healthy and i'll do a fried dish or two but i have to have one vege dish.  so we agreed to get one entree each.  the owner came to take our order and we just asked a simple question, "what vegetable dish do you recommend?".  and he said, "don't worry, i'll take care of you".  oh god.  now i knew we entered unknown territory.

overall, we had 4 dishes.  don't get me wrong.  they were tasty.  but 3 out of the 4 were fried.  a fried calamari in a vinegary sweet sauce.  a plate of fried wontons and fried potstickers.  and a chicken with some kind of sweet and sour sauce (not the generic hot pink kind).  the last dish was a mixed meat noodle dish.

so we ended up with tasty food, but none of them were vegetarian (which was what we wanted) and the bill came out to more than we anticipated.  if we had ordered just one entree each, it would have been about 10-12 per person.  our actual bill came out to 18 per person but the thing is that i think they made smaller portions for us since we had only 3 people.  

overall, the food was good, but not exceptional.  the owner's menu was not a good variety of food.  i mean, anything can taste good when its fried.  go to san tung in the sunset.
author: Thom Y.

description:
I admit I was wary of the House of Nanking when I first ate there.  It's a bit dingy (a plus for those looking for real food) but also proximal to lots of touristy shopping areas, which can mean that a place doesn't have to work very hard to survive.

I went with my wife and two friends, and I have determined that 4 is always the optimal number for dining, particularly family style.  We sat down, got our handwritten paper menus, and tried to order the things which sounded good to us.  The waiter asked us point-blank if we had ever dined there, and we admitted to being neophytes to the house of nanking.  He declared that he was the chef and just ordered for us.

The food was some of the best I've ever had (and I have never been shy about spending money on food).  We had a sizzling rice soup with lemon slices as garnish, mushu pork, stuffed mushrooms, chow mein (the real kind), and some dumplings.  It felt like a luxurious multicourse meal and the final bill was $54 for 4.  I've paid that much for just myself and had worse food.  

People complain about how expensive it is to live in the bay- but this is one of the reasons why people complain too much about cost of living.  Housing can be expensive but you can save in so many other ways, from taking mass transit, to having amazing cuisine for less money then it would cost in the Midwest.  Cal cuisine is fresh but boring, I'd pick a dingy chinese place any day of the week!
author: Nick N.

description:
I am not a fan of Chinese food but this one I feel obligated to recommend!

I am not sure when exactly HON got so popular.  In the old days when it wasn't always crowded, the owner (the friendly cool guy who walks around talking to customers in the restaurant) would come to sit with customers (those who can speak Mandarin would have a big advantage) and ask them what they'd like to eat.  Then he'd get up and either give the orders to the chef behind the scene or he himself would prepare the dishes.  These dishes were nowhere to be found on the menu.  I love this style!  It's also known in Japanese as "omakase", meaning chef's choice for the whole meal in English.

In recent years, there has never been a time that I don't see a long wait line in front of the place.  I doubt the owner has time to take care of the cumstomers on such intimate level anymore.  But what do I know right?  I am just a guy from LA.  Maybe the locals have more insights.  It wouldn't hurt to find the owner/chef and ask what's good for the day.  You'll be surprised.

Finding a parking space is a painful process, especially when hunger and downtown SF are both present in it!  Last time I was there I parked 3 blocks away by a parking meter, and then I had to run to a local Chinese market to buy some fruit to get coins for the meter...and it was raining!!!  Welcome to SF!  Bring your piggy banks with you.

Anyway, this place is a "must go" in SF.  Oh, I almost forgot.  Do order its Tsingtao Beer chicken (not sure if it's on the menu but that's what I always order without looking).  It's as tender as the famous Italian chicken marsala, but perhaps not as fatty.
author: Takechiyo L.

description: House of Nanking is a regular stop for me and my colleagues.  Be prepared for a unique social experience as you may not get your own table.  The noise level is way up there due to the number of guests, so I would not recommend for a business meeting / conversation - only for having a good time and enjoying some awesome and authentic chinese food.  I would recommend letting the server order for you and eat what comes out, you will not be disappointed.  Also, don't expect your server to wait on you, they are there to give you what you need, but you may need to get noisy and ask for it.  I see that as part of the experience.
author: Jason T.

description:
I've always meant to write a review about this place......quick and simple.  

Took a weekend trip to Frisco awhile back, had some of the best Chinese food of my life here.  Nothing fancy at all, but my fiance and I enjoyed the food so much here.  

You better believe that everytime I visit San Francisco I'm gonna want to come here for old time sake.
author: Crystal S.

description: I've been craving this place, which reminded me to write a review. This place is memorable in the fact that their food is that good. My parents were in town visiting, and my Dad had remembered this place from years ago before I lived in the Bay area. With his excellent memory, I looked up the location and we ate lunch here. Don't judge a book by its cover, this place is worth a visit!
author: Heather C.

description:
We walked in yesterday around 4:30 and were seated immediately at a nice window table. The place has been updated a little since our last visit.

It's all be said here before. Above average, creative and over-priced non-traditional Chinese food. The Blossom Flower tea is tasty and watching the hand-made 'blossom' slowly open is spectacular! 

The service is downright rude. It must require a lot of energy for the staff to maintain their convincingly gruff demeanor until it's time to deliver the check ...
author: M. C.

description:
I liked this place big-time.  I'm not giving it four stars just out of selfish arbitrariness, specifically, to kick myself in the ass and get out to San Gabriel valley and have something to compare to.

but the tofu veggie dish is great, the chicken sesame thing and chow mein was way above average.

also, i like being abused by wait staff, as long as they're not aspiring Hollywood punks, which the staff here most certainly is not...
author: Lew H.

description:
There are so many Chinese restaurants in this city to chose from yet none of them come close to Nanking!  The chicken actually tastes like real chicken.  Thats not always the case at some places.  I would recommend the sesame chicken! AMAZING! 

Because the food is so good, it can get crowded, however dont expect to wait long at all to be served.  The owner and chef is all business, hes not very talkative at all, but gets the job done.  Ill usually go for lunch when im off on a week day.  This place never dissappoints!
author: david j.

description:
Chinese food. I don't love it. I rarely even like it. But this magical House of the "nan king" has changed my view forever. Damn.

So, nestled between the financial district, the boobie district and a little bit o' China Town, lies this Chinese place that normally wouldn't attract the likes of you-- until of course, you see The Line. Yes, this place gets one of those "lines" that in San Francisco can only mean one thing: in the know. You have got to check it out.

Although filled with many tourist and SF yuppies, the staff of NanKing will still shuffle you in and out as if you were inflicting European diseases on them by your mere presence in the restaurant. Get in, get the hell out. By while you're still in; by Jesus try the eggplant, mushu tofu and crispy beef. This place got me to love Chinese food, AND beef all in one meal.
author: Rachel L.

description: My wife raved about this place after coming here with a close friend from the Bay on her last trip.  We came for lunch and the place was packed.  The service ain't great, but the food was damn tasty.  We had the sesame chicken and the tofu and broccoli served in a black bean sauce, both of which were excellent.  The chicken was very tender and flavorful, and the breading crispy and fresh.  The sauce was not too sweet and was flavorful, but not overpowering.  The pork dumpling appetizer was served in a tasty black bean sauce.  The dumplings themselves were soft and light and were filled with well flavored pork.  We will be back on our next trip to SF.
author: Brian L.

description: This place gets mentioned a lot. I came here with a friend a few years ago and though it was alright. It's a bit pricey for Chinese food. It seemed like the place was filled with tourists and non Chinese people. There's always a line for it back then, probably because it gets hyped up like Burma Super Star. I agree with other reviewers that it's very cramped.
author: Helena H.

description:
I'm incredibly torn.

As the only Chinese guy standing in a line full of non Asians, I wanted any reason to pick this place apart and rip into it via Yelp review.  

But I can't :(

After passing this restaurant a few times and seeing a huge (predominantly Caucasian) line outside, I got really curious.  I'm definitely more picky than the average Bay Area guy, especially with "Chinese" food (see my PF Chang review), so after having so many prejudices floating around my head about this restaurant, I did not expect much.

We waited about 15-20 mins outside in line, and felt judged when the owners of Chef Jia's Chinese Restaurant glared at us with their heavy eyes.  Even after hearing some possibly remotely racist comments from those around me, the night was not starting off well.  The one saving factor House of Nanking had prior to eating their food was the fact that all the wait staff was Chinese, who actually spoke fluent Mandarin.

The decor inside is such that it's modern, and the menu is a very basic 2 page menu obviously written to cater to the masses.  With words like "velvety" used to describe fish, I already started to assert my premonitions about this being another PF Chang.

I'll echo what every yelp review here says in which the service is horrible.  After seemingly getting our "in" and street cred with the owner by speaking Chinese to him, we were ignored as those non Asians around us were being served first, despite ordering after us.  We bothered them 3 times to see about our food, and finally it came.

As I said before, I was really wanting to give this a walloping one star review, but the food was just that good.

Steamed dumplings, salt & pepper pork chops, and the sesame chicken were on our agenda for the night.  All definitely were more americanized with relying heavily on the sauce to make the dish.  I'm no expert on Nanking (or Nanjing, wherever you may be from) cuisine, but the modern dishes in which the food was served, the lack of chopsticks being offered, and just the overall ambience, hinted to me that this was not 100% authentic.

But no matter.  The dumplings were amazing and tasted hand made.  The chili/garlic sauce it came with was perfect.  

The pork chops were equally as good, if not a tiny bit repetitive, as the sauces between the 3 dishes seemed very similar.  They were crispy and well seasoned, to complement the chili/onion sauce that came with it.

The "House of Nanking Special Sesame Chicken" was the most disappointing.  While it was still good, it just didn't really differentiate itself from what I can get at Panda Express.  It came with sweet potatoes that seemed a bit of a stretch to mix with the chicken, however, still yielded a good taste.

In the end, my mouth was incredibly dry that night due to the expected overwhelming portions of MSG that were used, but I really can't knock it for that.  

As a Chinese American who loves food, I feel dirty for eating there and enjoying it.  I'm definitely going to check out Chef Jia's next door to see if I can redeem myself and support a more "authentic" establishment.

It's really confusing to see why there aren't more Asians in the restaurant, given the quality of the food.  My theory is that the more traditional ones get turned off by the demographic and the modern-ness of the restaurant, and as such, choose to avoid such a place.
author: Jeff N.

description: Skip this place! Our hotel recommended this restaurant and so we trucked there for dinner with 3 kids. They walked away while they were taking our orders and threw the menus at us and the kids. First question from my kids was what is wrong with these people? The food tasted okay but not worth the poor service. Went to the Oriental Pearl and had better food and much better service!
author: Kari O.

description:
I had heard good reviews about this restaurant and decided to give it a try. Well, it was disappointing.

Pros:
+ original menu
+ some interesting flavors in one dish we took, finer than usual chinese restaurants.

Cons:
- food was disappointing overall: on 2 dishes, 1 was way too salty & sugary, 1 was too oily.
- crowded and noisy, but that was not a surprise. I just don't like it.
- the guy who served us (the boss? according to the picture of him on the wall) was not nice, not welcoming, almost rude. The client is not a king at Nanking...
- given all the "cons", it was expansive ($12-14 for a dish)

Sorry, won't go back again.
author: Olivier C.

description:
Terrible, terrible service. Very mediocre, overpriced food. When we walked in on a Sunday afternoon, the hostess was not to be found. We were ignored at first, and then finally a busy-looking waiter pointed at a table. We ordered the green onion cakes, mushu tofu and lettuce wraps with stir-fry veggies. The green onion cakes were pretty good, but the mushu tofu and lettuce wraps were the exact same dish, down to the same vegetables and sauce (and not in a good way). I would have appreciated a warning from the waiter, who took our order and was not to be seen again. The mushu tofu was unlike any one I've ever tried, and was completely not what we expected. 
We received our bill about a minute after they put down the food, which implied that they wanted us out ASAP. The worst part, however, was the tip situation. We decided to pay with a card and put down the tip in cash. Literally the SECOND we put down the tip down, some random woman (who worked there but had not helped us in any way) snatched it up. We were shocked, as I was still waiting for the hostess to give me my check to sign. 
Bottom line, TERRIBLE SERVICE. Would not recommend to anyone.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Long wait and not the cleanest looking place, but the best Chinese food I've ever tasted. Think Asian night markets- it's almost as if the shadier the place looks, the better the food is.

However, in a departure from some of the comments, I was reasonably satisfied with the service I got here. It annoys me when waiters drop by every 5 minutes while I'm busy chewing anyway- refill the water and bring the bill on time and I'm pretty much happy. I hadn't been here in a long time, so my lunch party and I said we had never been there and asked our waiter (who turned out to be the owner) for recommendations. He grinned, told us he'd "take care of it" and left. We had some sort of dumpling soup to start off, mushu, and a couple other dishes. Delicious and at a very reasonable price. He didn't try to rip us off and bring a ton of dishes for a small group either. I'll definitely be stopping by here when I'm in Chinatown again!
author: Michelle P.

description:
Good food isn't hard to come by in San Francisco. I lived there for a few years and found something fantastic in every area of the city. Some became my favorites and I frequented them often (outback for steak, pho hoa for pho, naan 'n curry for indian etc) and some I gave props for having ok food, but couldn't bring myself become a regular.

House of NanKing is one of those fabled places.  The dishes are inventive, if a bit strange (they use spaghetti noodles and ingredients from many cultures in their chinese food).  The servers will offer "suggestions" (by that I mean tell you what to eat) and just make up dishes on the spot sometimes (I said I wanted something with chicken, prawns, noodles and snow peas and voila there it was at my table-half an hour later...).

Strangely, most dishes taste the same, and NONE are even close to authentic. I'm waisian, so I know (wannabe asian).

The service is frighteningly bad-indifferent and rude.  The two things that were the kickers for me were the facts that a) they often let people bring in their pets and b) there are always weird birds flying in and out (open front building) pooping on the floor. Yes, pooping.
author: MrsKimch I.

description:
Not what I was expecting in a delicious way. 

After reading the many reviews of the place I'm surprised by a couple of things on my lunch experience. 

1) We got a table immediately. There was no line and we walked straight in and got seated. 

2) The food was unique for me. I had not seen several of the items on the menu in the chinese restaurants I've been to. 

That being said the lunch was one of the best chinese meals I've had. We ordered the fried dumplings which were crisp and steaming with porky goodness inside. The peanut sauce that came with them provide the perfect sweet and savory flavor. The Onion cake was something I've never heard of and tried. It was a true guilty pleasure with a nano of nutrition. 

The main courses were ordered for us so we wouldn't be disappointed. The nanking chicken was sublime, especially the sweet potatoes that came with. The garlic beef was tender and delicious with the peppery greens off setting the sweet flavor of the sauce. The reason for the 4 star instead of a 5 was the Crackling Beef which I thought was bland and I was unimpressed with the stir fried puffed rice. 

The bill was just over $50 for the 3 of us. For my money that was well spent as I was stuffed and skipped dinner that night.

Tourist trap maybe but a type of trap I don't mind getting in to.
author: Heath A.

description:
Everybody in the free world has weighed in on this place, so I guess it's my turn.  

I've eaten here a handful of times and I've had a totally different experience than most.  There was never a line, there were always more Asian people in there than whites, the place always was nice and clean, the service was friendly, we've never been yelled at, we always ordered and got exactly what we wanted, the food was flavorful and despite having the plum sauce on a couple dishes, there were also other sauces used in other dishes.  

It's almost as if we ate at a totally different restaurant than everybody else.  I know it's not true, I have pictures of the sign to prove it.

I will say that one dish in particular has gotten worse over the years.  The first time I had the mu shu pork, it was one of my favorite meals ever.  But the next two times that I have ordered it, It was still good, but it wasn't anywhere near the quality as it was that first time.   They seriously tweaked the recipe on that one.
author: Brandon S.

description:
We sat, we were instructed on what to order by the chef/owner/dictator, it was all yummy.  I especially enjoyed the mushroom, basil and onion stir fry.  Wow, holy crap I love mushrooms almost as much as I love carrots and pork. 

Our mushu beef was also very yummy.  I think there was a LOT of sugar in this dish, so I mainly focused my time on the wildy and insanely yummy mushroom platter.  I was expecting complete crap after reading all of the reviews here, so perhaps the answer is to have low expectations going in?  

All in all, an excellent lunch in the FIDI experience.
author: Claire C.

description:
Some things I liked about this place...Full cans of soda, attentive wait staff, the fact that they just took the menus from us and told us that they would handle it. 

One thing that was average about this place.....the food.

One thing that sucked about this place....I felt crammed. Too many people and too small of a space.
author: Patrick G.

description:
I read the poor reviews here and didn't expect the food to be great when I actually ate here, but surprisingly, I thought the food was good.

Their vegetarian fare is quite tasty. I especially liked the eggplant topped with a sweet sauce (and I don't like eggplant--I ate this because I knew that there wouldn't be a lot of veggie plates). The sauteed mushrooms were good and so were the green beans. 

They served some type of garlicky + oniony + greens dish. That thing was so strong, my breath still smelled like garlic the next day.
author: Cookie Monster Z.

description:
So it looks like a lot of people either love this place or want it to burn.  So, here's my take:

When I first came here about two years ago, my buddy told me to judge it on the food alone.... but that was hard to do because they messed up my order and the girl i was with couldn't eat seeds and although they guaranteed her no seeds, it was covered... so she just sat there and looked pissed.

And that is where my lowered expectations came from.  So, years later, I decided to give this place a chance and judge the food on its merit alone, so I got take out for lunch (I only work 6 blocks away!), and I wasn't disappointed.  First off, all you nanking haters, remember, this is the Financial district, so most food here is pricey and sucks ass, so quite your bitching about price.  A huge beef of mine is when I receive food on my table that looks just like it did out of the SYSCO packaging, so points for looking like real restaurant food.  The menu is small, but the restaurant and kitchen are tiny, so no points off for that.  The staff is always in a rush and doesn't really care/understand what you say, but I got mine to go, so no points off.  

It was good and simple, a bit harder to attain than I'm usually willing to put up with, but this is San Francisco and it could be a lot worse without the reward of tasty food when all is done.
author: Josh Z.

description:
I was in China Town with my family and we didn't know where to eat.  I mean we've been there many of times, but we wanted to try something new.  So a CHinese taxi driver recommended this place to us.  It took us forever to find.  Every Chinese person in China Town that we asked would just say, "Nanking?!  Ahh, one more block over."  

We got tired of walking and decided to ask this Chinese cop where another good place was, nearby.  He said that he was sorry, but he couldn't help us because he "doesn't eat Chinese food."  WOW...

We ended up at an Italian restaurant.  We were about to go in, but we told the owner our story and he said that Nanking was just one more block down from where we just came.  We thanked him and left.

Well we finally get there and thankfully we didn't have to wait in line because we had reservations.  So we didn't know what to order.  The chef came and met us (there were 16 of us in total).  We just got course after course until we said stop.  The food was delicious.  Orange chicken with sweet potatoes, the best wonton soup ever, stuffed mushrooms, some sort of fried fish, it was all good.  

So I guess the farther you wlk, the better the food tastes.
author: Ryan T.

description:
Yuck! Please avoid it! After reading others reviews I should have totally stayed away, but sadly I did not :( My husbands boss loves this place, and they were talking about this place on the radio and in a comedy show I saw recently with ralphie may, so i assumed "okay if they are really talking this place up thre must be somethng good" WRONG!!!

rice chowder...yuck...flavorless execpt for the spicy oil they put on top
snowpeashoots...yuck...its like grass
calamari---yuck..drowning in vinegar and spicy oil
seseame chicken...yuck..didnt taste like chicken, and the sauce was really weird
chow mein..yuck, didnt taste or look like chow mein that i've ever had
fried rice...yuck!!! it was spicy!!! not exactly fried rice as I would of liked to have it.
potstickers..overdone, yuck!
eggrolls..okay

what makes it worse, is that Mr. Nanking himself told us "I will make for you, sooo good" and then we are served this? yea not so good Mr. Nanking!!

so 4 people and the tab was 102!!! as my father-in-law said afterward "I was so hungry I could have eaten anything, and I really did eat anything!" needless to say I had a really bad tummy ache afterward prolly from all the MSG!! AVOID!!!
author: Deirdre P.

description: We found this restaurant when we came to SF in 1999/2000 and loved the food because the owner made dishes for us.  He asked what we liked and the dishes were incredible. So, when we came back to SF today, we made sure to go House of Nanking for lunch.  The waitress chose the dishes for us and they were incredible again!  We had a crispy fish, honey beef, and deep fried tofu. Yummy.
author: Jim W.

description:
It's not hard to find Chinese restaurants in San Francisco.  It is much harder to find any that rate above mediocre or totally predictable.  House of Nanking is one of the best Chinese food experiences I've ever had.  There food is delicious - the menu is totally interesting and the prices are very reasonable.

This is not your typical chow mein, general's chicken, sweet & sour pork Chinese Restaurant!  The menu is thoughtful and the food is delicious.  The staff is great also.  It was a really great experience, start to finish.
author: Daniel H.

description:
I'm speechless.  I am at such a loss of wind over this place, I don't know whether to jump for joy, or just pass out on the sticky floor.  The chef discovered that this was our first visit, and he denied us the menus and performed the signature "Don't worry, I'll take care of you."  

Out came mostly unidentified vegeterian dishes (along with slightly dirty plates), including a scrumptuous mushroom dish.   Again, my cohorts are turning me into a vegetarian, but with dishes like these, veggie life can be pretty satisfying!   As tasty as they were, the waitress didn't reveal the name or the ingredients in each dish, as if we were there to indiscriminately dump food down our throats. 

We were warned profusely about the "flavor enhancement culture" of the restaurant-- MSG in particular.    I carefully poked and prodded the food for signs of this GRAS substance (Generally Recognized as Safe).  Regardless of what the FDA says, I refuse to eat anything containing even a dusting of MSG, but after inspection, I didn't spot nor taste any flavor enhancers.  

After we finished and squeezed our way through the crowd, I braced for the legendary MSG headache.   Luckily, I had no headache or side-effects from eating at Nanking, so why not try it again !
author: Daniel C.

description:
The secret to this place is not to order from the menu.  

There is a boss, let him decide.  Be general, just tell him, "chicken, pork, vegetables" and tell him spicy or not.

The management here are like good but tempermental artists.  They won't do your bidding, but when they do it their way, it comes out really nice.

Purists dismiss this place because of the tourist crowd, and the fact it is not traditional chinese -- and it's surrounded by traditional chinese places in chinatown.  But that misses the point -- it is something completely different from the bad brown sauce stuff you see in suburban shopping malls and the old school stuff you see at local chinese places.

(S)
author: M.S. C.

description:
Who would eat in House of Nanking when there is another restaurant in the next door that offers a similar menu and style of Chinese food, but cheaper, yummier, and with better services.  (OK, I ate there today because I found that Chef Jia wasn't open until 5pm on Saturdays, and we were starving!)

First thing first, their rice was served cold, crumpled together, and it tasted stale (I think that they use really cheap rice, and I don't understand this.  Can't they afford something better?  They make so much money out of tourists!)  Hot tea costs $2 per person, and they tasted funny (kind a sweet, not much flavors) and looked funny (what's up with those floating herbs?)  Eggplant in Garlic Sauce and Stuffed Mushroom are decent (coincidentally they used the same sauce for both dish), but the serving portion was so small, and I was still hungry.
So overrated.
author: Ryoko M.

description:
All of you House of Nanking nay sayers are high!  
My friend Jimmy Jatho turned me on to this place years ago & my husband & I fell in love with it.  He told us it was a hole in the wall, very cramped, noisy Chinese cooks, waitresses barking broken English at you, always a line at night, and great food. So we knew what to expect.  Our kind of place!
House of Nanking is the only place that I love eggplant, and a fried tofu with peanut sauce!  
We hadn't been here in a few years, so I looked it up on Yelp.  I couldn't believe people were complaining about the "rude staff" and the "cramped quarters" and the fact that you eat right next to the kitchen.  Come on people!  This isn't PF Changs!  Jake, it's Chinatown!
So we returned to House of Nanking recently and we found that the dishes we love are still great. 
And the place has improved!  They moved the kitchen out of the middle of the restaurant to the back wall and rearranged/added more tables.  It's still small, but not as cramped.  And yes the waitress still barely spoke to us & then continued to read the local Chinese newspaper.  Just like we expected.
author: D A P.

description:
Simply the best Chinese food I've ever had.

These bad reviews are utterly insane. One has to wonder if they're not trying to sabotage the rating so they get this place to themselves!

People just have bad attitudes I guess. If you're going here to be picky and whiny and needy about your food and service, forget it. You're not fit for this place. This is a Soup Nazi style experience. It is almost run like a communist society haha. You get what the master Peter Fang wants you to eat. Although you're lucky these days because he's gone a bit softer. He used to scold people if they weren't sitting perfectly straight forward or talking too much. You used to have zero say in your order, now you can generally specify chicken, vegetarian, spicy, etc. which is perfect.

Once you understand the system, the service is the best. It is uncompromising and efficient. You get your food almost immediately, and it's almost entirely new every time. Yet every time it gets better and better. They keep stacking platters of dishes faster than you can finish them. You're done with your meal in less than 20 minutes often, but you feel high off of how good it was.
author: Brett M.

description: First-class Chinese food, with lots of vegetarian options. Staff is busy but friendly and we were served promptly. The wonton soup is remarkable!
author: Jason S.

description:
3-star at best. The food tastes okay and feels fastidiously prepared, as the place appears.  They hand you the chinese character filled menu and since you can't read any of it, you just say, one meat, one noodle, one vegetable and they bring stuff out. 

The food was okay and actually had me eating some rarer vegetables that I usually wouldn't order.  But in terms of flavor, it was bleh, bland.  There is such thing as fine Chinese cuisine and I prefer that kind more than the slapped together kind, so I wasn't feeling House of Nanking that much. The line can get quite long on weekends and once you're seated, you're definitely shuffled out of there. I don't have much to say that negatively about this place; my palate just didn't match what they offer.  I'd probably visit this place once every 4 years...that sounds about the right amount.
author: Tsubasa O.

description:
This place is super ghetto in every possible way, and after a while, you begin to notice that practically every dish is the same brown sauce on different ingredients...

[You like chicken? Voila, chicken with brown sauce! Are you vegetarian? Then you'll love the eggplant  and yams with brown sauce!] You get the picture...

BUT what delicious mystery brown sauce it is! Yes, it's probably generously spiked with MSG and sometimes tastes so salty you'll want to go swimming in your glass of water, but hey, it's a tasty way to fulfill that "8 glasses of water a day" recomendation. =)

P.S. I'm Asian but I'm not a snob or purist about food. Who cares if this is real Chinese food or not, bottom line is it tastes good! Why does everything have to be categorized anyway? Let's start eating outside the box!
author: Yuffie G.

description:
I don't know what hole I've been living in for the 23 years I've lived in the Bay, but this is just about the best Chinese food I've ever had.

The place is small, they kinda skimp on the lemon in your water (which is served a huge beer pint), and the tables are real close together so it's a bit awkward to have to sit next to someone who's not in your party. But once the food comes, you just forget about that and focus on the deliciousness of the food.

A friend and I split the fried calamari, sesame chicken, stuffed mushrooms, and steamed rice. The description on the menu for their fried calamari said "melt in your mouth" and they really weren't kidding. I don't know what they do to their calamari because it was not chewy or tough at all. I do believe it was the best calarmari I've ever had. I can just imagine that everything on the menu tastes just as good!
author: Alexa A.

description: We tried this place on a whim, having eaten there more than 10 years ago.  We thought it was pretty good, but it was better years before.  Some of the dishes were very tasty while a few others just seemed to be dripping in 30 weight.  The sticky table tops added a certain charm, but the waitresses were great!  And I think we equally understood each other, which is to say neither of us knew what the other was saying.  But that added to the ambience and charm!  There was no line when we went early on the recent Friday evening, and we were in and out quickly.  Worth a try.
author: Christophe P.

description: Small restaurant and highly-oiled food, but the good thing about this place is that it's close to all the bars and the wine is very cheap.  This makes a very good pre-going out place.
author: Eric C.

description: This is the only chinese food I'm a fan of. My fiance will start to foam at the mouth when you mention the place. Yeah, the service is meh, you more then likely will have a line to wait in, and you are packed like sardines... I can overlook that since my experiences have never been that bad. The food then made up for everything else the place lacked. :)
author: Cheryl C.

description:
Food: Flavorless.  I've heard people say this place is "cool" because you'll order beef and the server will say "no beef...pork for you" or suggest 3 dishes you must have. Vunerable diners will roll over, feeling the server has their true interest for an authentic Chinese meal at heart. Just look around. You'll see that every table has the same 3 dishes. The cooks are lazy.  

Mood: Whatever mood grime can create.

Loot: Any money is too much money.

Staff: Ha.
author: Michelle M.

description:
A little China girl I am. Born and raised in cities throughout Asia, I thought I could count on House of Nanking to provide me with a little taste of home but it brought me further and further away instead.  It was just another joint serving its famous "Chinese" sesame chicken. 

Granted it has a fun crowd and the owner has a lot of heart. He actively interacts with his customers on the floor and it's definitely a place that you can pop in and out in an hour or so. Fast service, hot food, and little stress on that gorgeous wallet of yours.

Be sure to try the stir-fry baby snow pea shoots with ground pork. To pay tribute to Rachel Ray (since I was kindly seated under her photo on the wall) yumm-o!
author: Catsu H.

description: Finally getting around to a review...We frequented this place some time ago.  Just had to write a review for all those out there who visit SF. We loved this place, the food,  the jammed packed-no nonsense- just the facts (borderline rude) depending on how you interpret - service, decor all of it.. It's an "experience" for sure which we happened to love.
author: Sopla R.

description:
I have used Yelp for months now and have always wanted to post reviews of all the places I go, and have been too lazy to do so until eating at this place. It was bad enough that I want to make sure no one else eats here.

Came here with some co-workers for lunch and we ordered an appetizer and a chicken, beef and seafood entree to eat family style. After sampling a little bit of everything, I'm pretty sure it was more than I wanted to try. I recall returning to the office praying that my stomach didn't just drop out of me. The sesame beef tasted like burnt dung chips and the scallops were overly caked in oyster sauce.  I don't want to continue writing this review because I don't want to re-live that experience anymore than I already have.

I walk by this place every day on my way home from work, and I feel tempted to tell every idiot in line that they'll save a fortune by just going to walgreens and buying laxatives instead. Either way, laxatives or House of Nanking, you'll get the same result.
author: Eric F.

description: I never understood the appeal of Nanking.  They order FOR you.  They can supposedly size you up in seconds and know, just know, what dishes you would want to eat.  Really?!  Did I come to see a fortune teller, or are they the Seinfeld Soup Nazi reincarnate?  Plus, the food isn't even that good!
author: Kristen S.

description: Loved it! Calamari, lettuce wraps, almond chicken, and pot stickers were amazing! I think I will eat here a few times during my vacation. It is a far cry from the ore packaged Asian food joints in the Midwest!
author: Brooke C.

description:
It's funny that I have had 2 visitors come stay with me and want to go here.  I finally gave in last night as my friend insisted that it was her favorite place in San Francisco.

I went in very skeptical since I've never really heard anything good from anyone who lives here but it actually wasn't all that bad.

The service is weird, I'm not kidding when I say the only thing that was spoken to us the whole time from someone who worked there was "Is this your first time here?".  I said "yes" but they didn't reply with anything.

We had the "melt in your mouth" calamari, the pea sprout veggies and the sesame chicken.  I actually thought the pea sprouts were very good.  They were cooked just the right amount, no too much and not too little.  

The calamari was good as well, I've never had calamari that wasn't chewy, but as the menu said, these were soft - very unique and worth a try.

The sesame chicken was my least favorite - I thought it tasted like the smell of china town.

I'm not running back for another meal but if a friend in town that I couldn't convince to go someone else, I wouldn't put up a huge fight
author: Michelle L.

description:
You know what I like? I like tasty food. No, I don't care if it's not traditional. It is tasty, and it is food, therefore I like it. That is all it takes. 

I'll grant that I kind of liked the feel of this place more back when it only had one main room and was dirty and cramped, and if you wanted to get into the back room you had to navigate your way past stacks of boxes and trash to sit in dimly lit squalor. They at least have more table space now, except they don't have counter space anymore. That was nice because I could walk in by myself and grab a counter seat nice and fast while the rest of the suckers had to stand in line. Ah well. As long as they still have food and it is tasty, I will try to fight my way in here every now and then, just to make sure.
author: Tom H.

description: Succulent sesame chicken with a small side of green beans--yum!
author: C L.

description:
The ubersexual does not visit boring places. He doesnt even embrace food chains, but he usually makes an exception to popular haunts. The toxic bachelor stopped by House of Nanking again last afternoon, in an effort to please his voracious appetite. Satisfaction guaranteed. But he feels bad that the last time he was here (about a year ago), he wasnt a Yelp partner. 

Anyways, he knows he is going back again soon. And the sesame chicken with potato & eggplants score very high on his Chinese Food-list (well, since thats all he eats ...)
author: Sav B.

description:
Traveling to San Francisco with friends, we began a walking tour of the city from our hotel with one goal in mind - a restaurant where we could get good food and start a 2-day bender the likes of which the west coast rarely sees (we're all east coast boys). 

Giddily stumbling along, buzzed on the anticipation and not alcohol (yet) we asked a passerby where we should eat in Chinatown.

You can probably guess his reply.

West coast (or perhaps more specifically San Francisco) chinese food is a much different beast than east coast chinese food. And dare I say much better. And I can go to sleep satisfied tonight stating that opinion based on my visit to Nan King.

The outside doesn't offer much of a clue of the delicious feast that awaits you. Nor does the inside for that matter. But you must persevere. You must ignore those slight misgivings your mind might be trying to dupe you with. After all, the brain doesn't have tastebuds, what does it care what you eat?

Back to the review. We walked in. We were handed menus. We perused, and debated, and wondered what to order. A woman came to our table and seemingly picked up on our confusion.

"First time here?" she barked at us in staccato, broken English. 

"Yes," one of us replied. And like that, our menus were grabbed from our hand. Asked what we wanted to drink, we simply replied, "beer." A minute later, 5 green bottles of beer appeared. 

"You like seafood?" the woman barked at us again. We all nodded. 

What came next, between numerous rounds of unlabeled green-bottled beers were dishes of unbelievably good chinese cuisine. I wish I could remember what any of them were, or called, but since we didn't specifically order them, we simply dug in to each plate as it hit the table.
