I do remember at one point arguing over who got to lick the plate clean of the sauce a shrimp dish came in. 

I can't recommend Nan King enough. I beg you to do the same thing we did and leave it up to your server and chef to choose your food. You won't regret it.
author: Chris O.

description: Still some of the best modern Chinese I have had.  Don't expect the owner, Peter, to give you a hug or a handshake, but if he is there and takes your order, ask him to surprise you with his suggestions.  Its worth the risk, you won't be disappointed.
author: Mr R.

description:
I don't know why everyone is hating on House of Nanking. As Too Short said, "You can't hate on me / These diamond studded Vans cost 18 Gs." Really, why the hate?

Is it a tourist trap? Yes!
Is the Chinese food Westernized? Yes!
Is there always a line? Yes!

Knowing these three things, Nanking is still awesome! I mean, you don't even use a menu there. That's half the fun of eating at Nanking to begin with. I usually bring couchsurfers here and friends visiting SF for the first time. It's like a cultural institute of culinary fun. But whatever haters, I like the food and atmosphere. 

Tips for the Nanking n00b: Don't use the menu. Tell the chef to bring you "X meat dishes, Y vegetarian dishes and Z seafood dishes." My favorite dishes are: Nanking chicken, the fried noodles with beef on top (off the hook), mu shu pork, onion cakes and tofu in peanut sauce. 

If you can deal with waiting in line, tourists and Westernized Chinese food, then Nanking is where it is at. I think it is well worth the wait despite what others might think. To get the best experience at Nanking, make sure you go with a group to try as many dishes as possible.

BATHROOM REVIEW
-------------------------------
It is cramped and usually has a line. Some of the heavier dishes might make you wish they had a second bathroom. Batlleship!
author: Bathrooms Only ..

description:
Looking for an excuse to eat noodles I decided to welcome in the year of the Golden Pig at the House of Nanking. I hadn't been there since before they took down the seating counter and remodeled the place, yet the service was just as I remembered: whatever. But realizing long ago that it's nothing personal, I ordered some tea (a lovely, loose spring blend of green tea, jasmine flowers, and Chinese wolfberries), my favorite Tsing Tao Chicken and some veggie chow mein, you know, for good luck.  The server looked at me sideways when I ordered the Tsing Tao Chicken and said through narrowed eyes that had pegged me for a tourist, "You ever order zhing-dao chicken before?"  I told her that I had, and that it was my favorite. She shrugged, sort of smiled at me and walked off.  

This is the thing, while the Tsing-Tao is the only dish I order here, it takes some time to prepare. But it's worth the wait -- the result is velvety, thinly-sliced chicken breast and equally thin zucchini that has been marinated and cooked in the slightly sweet beer sauce. The noodles arrived shortly after the chicken, and were the thicker, chewy variety that are wok-sauteed with big chunks of broccoli, onions,  and cabbage. 

Everything was as good as I'd remembered, and way too much food for one!  At the end of my meal I happily packed up my leftovers imaging how yummy they'd be for dinner. It was really great to see that a place like House of Nanking, a place with almost surly service that has sustained such high popularity (for locals and tourists alike) over the years, could still be so good after I'd been away for so long.
author: Tiffinie T.

description:
My friend lives there, so he took us everywhere tourists would go and then some. Well this place is definitely worth attending and experiencing. I have been to San Fran several times, but this was in fact one of the best places that is surely not yet discovered by Chinese Food connoisseurs alike.

Going during lunch time might be bit of a wait, but I guarantee you, it's worth it. My experience was awesome. We were actually helped by the owner himself, so when my friend told him this is our first time here, the owner said "I'll take care of you.'

And the rest is history. I can't remember everything we had cause I went into a food comatose before,during, and after, but take my word...you won't be disappointed.
author: Caroll G.

description:
I went here with some friends after watching the emotionally-crushing Terps loss during the 2007 Emerald Bowl.  After standing out in the stands for 3 hours being bombarded with rain, wind, and insults from the Oregon State fans, this was a welcome reprieve!

The restaurant doesn't look like much and the atmosphere inside feels more like a crowded cafeteria than anything else, but don't let that deter you.  The night before we ate here, my friend and I walked past it and joked that a place that packed with locals must be good.  The meal we had attested to that and then some!

The food was fantastic; hot soup, delicious tea, and large portions.  The four of us shared three soups and two entrees and when the mound of food arrived we weren't sure that we'd be able to finish it all.  The sesame chicken was delicious and the rice soup that I ordered had a great broth.  The tea was very good and had flowers, spices, and tea leaves floating on top to add flavor.  

The price was reasonable and the service was attentive.  This is definitely a place worth stopping by if you're in the area.  If I'm ever in San Francisco again, I'll be sure to make a return trip!  I'm not sure why there are such negative reviews around - but my experience was the exact opposite.
author: Angela Z.

description: First of all, be careful saying you "like all meats and have no allergies" because the waitress will steal your menus and "bring you everything good on the menu." Literally she jerked the menus out of our hands and started bringing us random food items. It was so weird. Then she was rude to us for the rest of the time. Keep in mind, this is after we stood outside the restaurant waiting despite our reservation. The food was pretty good, but it was brought out one dish at a time. Overall, the experience was pretty bad. You would really have to be craving this food to want to put up with them. Actually, I would just suggest takeout.
author: Cami R.

description:
If I had to take a friend to any hole in the wall in SF, this would be it.  Few things I love: 1.  accolade surrounds literally the whole restaurant,  2.  Rose tea  3.  Demanding owner actually unique  4.  Ultimate guilty pleasure (Asian don't eat this)

Service = Your in Chinatown,  Don't even bother looking at the menu, just tell them you want a pork and chicken dish and the owner will hook you up.  Its disturbing but fun at the same time
Ambience = ultimate hole in the wall, puts all other to shame, watch your step, greasy floors!
Food = Amazing, but greasy which explains the greasy floors, ohhh
Price = $$
Crowd = Overall SF, Young
Personal Favorite = I love it all
Worst = Been there at least 10 times, never seen a line less then 8 ppl
Meal for two = $35, of course usually can't control myself
Final Say = Must try for all food lovers
author: M C.

description:
After moving back from LA, I decided to take my husband to House of Nan King.  Needless to say, I was sorely disappointed.  I first came to this restaurant back in the late 90's when I went to Cal and it never disappointed.  The portions were generous, the prices were great and the owner always took our order.  Many times we never even looked at the menu, we just said "we want chicken" and the owner would make something amazing appear.
But alas, long gone are those days.  The portions got smaller, the prices went up, and the pot stickers aren't as good as I remember.  The service has always been horrible, but everything else made up for it.  It makes me sad to write this review, because as I said, in my younger days, this place was excellent.
author: Elena M.

description:
I think people who give bad reviews to this place are just pretentious people who think they are too good to recognize a good thing if it's also a popular thing. Whether it's the biggest hit in town or whether its the hole in the wall, good is good and this place is it.

Yes, the line out the door is shamelessly long, especially in those cold SF nights but the food is good and I always have a great experience here. I love letting the owner order for me every time, he always surprises you (in a good way). The food is Chinese but it is like no other that I have tried. It's more upscale than traditional Chinese but its yummy!
author: Michelle H.

description:
I was SHOCKED to discover that NanKing has anything less then 5 stars. 
I finally got to go there (aka the line wasn't outrageously long). And yes the service isn't spectacular, but is attentive. 
The foodie said, $15 per person and yes to seafood. Off we went. 
The fish was amazingly fresh and almost tasted like the most tender chicken (the sauce was powerful thus only the texture of the meat came through). Calamari in lemon juice, the NanKing chicken, the simple mushroom with garlic, onion, salt, pepper, and the herbal tea were so good my mouth waters for them. 
Three YUMS up.
author: Terika B.

description:
I'm surprised by all the negative reviews and the low overall rating for the House of Nanking! I've been here a couple of times, and I must say it is definitely the best Chinese food I've had in the city!  Call me a foodie plebian if you want, but I just cannot get enough of the flavorful and inventive dishes here.  

The lemon noodle soup and the scallops are to die for! My mouth is watering from just thinking about it!  And I love how they don't have any menus, and the head chef takes orders by recommending foods based on whether you can eat meat or handle spicy food.  The chicken dish is very good too.  I don't remember the exact names, but just tell the chef you want the scallops and the chicken dish, and he'll know.  Such a friendly guy too! 

Chelsea Clinton was just here over the past weekend too! So you know it's good! 

Overall, House of Nanking is a very unique restaurant and experience, filled with tons of eclectic dishes to make your tastebuds rejoice in MSG goodness.
author: James C.

description:
House of Nanking!
This place is great if you just want a quick meal without the frills.
Went here last night after a LONG day, just to get a bite and hang out with a friend.
There was no line outside, which was unusual but nice. We ordered off the menu (usually we just ask for an appetizer, a chicken or beef dish, and some rice and let them bring out whatever they want) and were rewarded with some really tasty (if obviously 'nouveau Chinese') cuisine.
The service is brusque, sure, but you know what?  For an inexpensive, quick meal I don't mind that. 
We had beers, too, and managed to take home a couple of meal's worth of food.
Good stuff.
Plus you are right near City Lights and Vesuvio, Specs and Tosca so your after dinner plans are made for you already.
author: Rachel M.

description:
The service is terrible, it's a little expensive, yeah the plates are chipped, and it's a little too loud and congested to really sit back and enjoy your food since you'll probably be rubbing elbows with a total stranger.  So what IS good about this place?

Well, if you let them order for you, you'll hopefully end up with a great meal.  I find it amusing how polarizing the reviews for this place is.  The same people who complain about the "authenticity" of this joint are probably the same people who wouldn't be caught seeing authentic Chinese delicacies such as pork intestine, head attached duck, and beef tripe on their plate.  I feel that some negative reviews were from people expecting five star cuisine just cause they waited more than 30 minutes to sit down.  The same people who complain about MSG also probably have no problem plowing through a bag of Doritos.  Yeah, there's other better Chinese joints out there, but truth be told, the food is awesome.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
Dunno what the rave on this place is all about. Seriously overpriced bad chinese food. No wonder outsiders thinks this place is good...they don't know what chinese food tastes like.

Anyways, my friends recommended the place since they've been there before but it's not my choice for chinese. Go up the street, lots of other cheaper, better choices IMO.
author: Johnny H.

description:
I'm not sure this is actually a Chinese restaurant, but some of the dishes are pretty good......Problem is you have to park damn near in Daly City to get there.  A line outside hardly seems warranted. 

This is your typical Yan Can, with a longer line, crappier service, NO CHOPSTICKS, and the same sauce on every thing.  I have to say that I almost ate the plate it was served on since in took well over an hour to find parking and wait in line to be seated by the spectacularly inattentive staff.
author: Nicholas H.

description:
My girlfriend and I just visited SF this past week and found this place exploring the city.  I was driving around looking for the Good Fortune Parking Garage which is around the corner from the House of Nanking.  We were actually trying to make our way to bookstore City Lights and I noticed a line on the street:  People in suits, women in dresses, dudes in jeans and T-shirts, chicas in shorts...all waiting to get in this hole in the wall.  Being adventurous, we decided to give it a shot.  (But we did check the recommendation in the Lonely Planet book and yelp on the iPhone...)

Food is 5 star, while service is about 2 stars.  But the service isn't slow or horrible, it's just not a "Hello how are you?  Tonight we have a...." type of place.  You'll probably have to share a table, but the FOOD!  The Food makes up for it all.  I'll swear by it.

Sesame Chicken!!! A must.  The sauce is a perfect balance with the meat.  My girlfriend had the Mu Shu Beef and loved it.   I still think the Sesame Chicken is better.  We also had the Hot and Sour Soup veggie style, but it was a little too sour and not hot enough.  The beer was great:  Tsinghao I think.

This is a must if you want something different than the Panda Expresses out there.
author: Jeremiah V.

description: I work close and have had almost everything on their menu. It's all drool worthy. Staff is fast. Everyone shuts up and eat, that's how tasty is it. Warning: make time, it's always packed. Good luck and be careful, it's easy to over eat here:)
author: Bae L.

description:
mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm the dumplings and peanut sauce are WONDERFUL.

I think if I could only eat the dumpllings from this place for a few days, I would be a happy camper.

Can't wait to go back for more.

Only downside is it's a little cramped and if you get set down near weird people, your experience will suffer....
author: Annie M.

description:
Mmmh - Nanking's Sesame Chicken. It's sooo good. If you're at Nanking, that's what you want to get. Everything else on the menu falls short.

I also wished the place was a little bit better furnished: Some nicer tables and better decor would improve the Nanking experience by 80%. But for them, there's no need to: Everytime we come here, there's a line waiting outside.
author: Gabor C.

description: Came here since my husband's coworker highly recommended the place. We arrived to the restaurant about 10 minutes before the place was supposed to open and there was already a bunch of people waiting outside. We were seated immediately. The restaurant is family style so expect to be seated next to a bunch of strangers. The service was not the greatest but the food was definitely good. There was a lot to select from, i just wish i could have tried everything. i will definitely go back to try a couple more dishes.
author: Denise P.

description: I had the chance to try out House of Nanking this past weekend, although we didn't eat much we shared the Salt and Pepper Shrimp and Mushroom dish with white rice-- it was yummy! I would definitely come here again and try out more dishes! We were just there for lunch and didn't want to over indulge... only bummer is it is cash only!
author: Lynn C.

description:
I'd never heard of this place before we went so it's not the Christian Slater connection that makes me love it.
We had such a great time here. Yes, you have to wait a long time in line - but such a nice line, with such interesting people - and it gives you time to gaze through the window at what other people are eating and think, "Hm, that kind of looks like pad siu," which you can then attempt to order when you sit down - and be rewarded with something that isn't pad siu at all, but something else you've never had before that is *outstanding* in flavor, freshness and ingenuity.  A wonderful dining adventure. Cheap, too!
Not so much a place to come if you want to be intimate! A great place for a small, boisterous group of friends, tho'. Onion pancake - yes, yes indeed.
author: Marianne S.

description:
"OMG, if you like Chinese food, you HAVE to go to House of Nanking."

Yes, we've all heard it. I'm not against trendy spots, but for me there has always been a skepticism surrounding this place. What with the whole: "I just love how they just serve you whatever and you don't even have to order!" ... Yeah well I can think of another place where they do that: PRISON*. 

The dishes are tasty, despite being sloppily prepared and presented. The sweet and sour crispy beef dish comes to mind. 

My main point about Nanking has always been that this doesn't resemble any Chinese food I've ever had and I'm an honest to goodness Chinaman. See when Chinese food comes up, us Asians like to say that because we know a little bit about it. I grew up eating bizarre foods that would evoke looks of absolute terror from my friends over for dinner. Of course, my grandparents would proceed to talk smack, saying awful things like "those damn ghost boys dont eat anything!" (By the way if you are wondering if those Chinese guys at the corner store are talking about you, they are. )

My Chef Grandpa even had quasi-fusion phase, featuring such groundbreaking dishes as "hot dog fried rice" (sometimes even "vienna sausage fried rice" when funds weren't tight) and "breaded chicken cutlet with ketchup sauce". Still, I feel that those experiments were more catered to the Asian palate than the dishes at Nanking.

But on to the good things: I did enjoy their "tea with all the floaties in it"... whatever it's called. I also sorta liked the chaotic atmosphere, with the rowdy groups of twenty-somethings merrily gulping down overpriced Tsingtao, the budweiser of China. 

But who am I to talk. I speak caveman-grammar Cantonese and drive a Ford car. I got D's in Math 53 and 55. I must be the worst Chinaman ever.

*to be perfectly fair, you can ignore the draconian owner's suggestions if you want.
author: Vic W.

description:
This used to be my favorite place for close to 10 years. We were there this week and oh boy, things are not even the shadow of what the founder had running for so long. Really bad service, the dishes (ALL 5 dishes we ordered) had the same mix of veggies (zucchini, peas, onion, garlic and little tomatoes and carrots) and most of them also had the same kind of "crisps" as a way to create volume.  It was a great disappointment because we had to return 3 dishes out of 5 and the "mom" (owner now) came to yell at me that I had to paid even if we returned them but I was not the only table complaining so she agreed that we paid only for what we consumed.  The wine came from a box, the soups from a can and the lettuce wraps came with one 3 half leaves.  
It is very sad to see this place going down the drain in such short period (we found that the last time our meals were the best ever as always, was about 1.5 yrs ago).  I used to take people visiting the area all the time, but I guess that tradition is over.
The line used to be around the corner for the great food but I guess the reason it is getting shorter and shorter is because exactly that, the food and service are really bad now.
author: Sassi M.

description: My good friend and I came here because he said a few of his friends recommended it.  We ordered the sesame tofu, the house noodles, and the black bean tofu.  The house noodles were very tasty and garlicky, they were pan fried in garlic and seasoning but they were nestled in a bed of their own oil.  So were the black bean tofu and sesame tofu.  Everything was very salty and oily, although the flavors were good.  If anything, I'd recommend the house noodles and their flower tea, which is very interesting as its a million flowers in your cup.  A-ok but nothing spectacular.
author: Terry K.

description:
Ok - now I really do like House of Nanking.  It has definitely been my go-to place here in San Francisco whenever people are visiting or we want to go to a fun place for dinner.  But the last time I went, I just didn't understand why I continued to wait on line (sometimes for REALLY long times) in the freezing cold (welcome to SF) in order to eat chinese food.  Is it really good?  Yes, it is.  I love those shrimp pockets, and the garlic fish and the calamari.  But the wait is getting pretty old and I am starting to feel like I need to go find another legit chinese place that isn't so whored out.

But I've gotta say, I love their tea there, where the flower opens and grows throughout the dinner.  So pretty and so fun - but I can go to a chinese tea shop for that.  

Conclusion: Fun to go to, but I don't think I will be going unless I know its an "off" time and the line won't require me standing in SF's sucky weather for more than 30 minutes.
author: Natalie K.

description: BEWARE ~ CHECK YOUR BILL AND VISA CHARGE CLOSELY! Used to love this place but the last two time we have been there, they have charged more to our visa then the bill was.  The group of 4 behind us were charged for a plate they didn't order.  The food was good but the attitude was awful ~ it's as if you should thank them for the privilege to patronize.  With so many options, I would opt out on this one...
author: B M.

description: This is our favorite place to bring friends who are here from out of town.  I'm SUPER picky but love almost everything they serve.  I've had one thing that I didn't love, but it was still good!
author: Crystal W.

description: This is by far my favorite Chinese restaurant!  The food here is always delicious. I love having the flowering jasmine tea on a chilly City day (which it is more often than not).  The sesame chicken is their most famous dish and it is delicious, but everything I've had here has always been great! No complaints here. The customer service isn't the greatest, but totally worth it for the great tasting food.  Almost every time I've come here there has been a line waiting to be seated, but I don't mind because that just goes to show how good the food is here.
author: Diana R.

description: I have never had a bad meal here and have chef / owner order for you its always a wonderful food journey.
author: Scott G.

description: Not necessarily worth the wait and I can't stand the owner's hard sell and not letting you order. With that said, the salt and pepper calamari is excellent as are the mu shu wraps.
author: Andrew K.

description: Yummy Chinese food! When I walked in, I was a bit skeptical at first since I didn't see many Chinese peeps in the restaurant but the food didn't disappoint. Even better was when the owner said "let me take care of you" once he found out it was my first time eating here. We had a great dumpling soup, delicious stuffed mushrooms, and some stir fry baby pea sprouts. I can't wait to go back and try out some other dishes especially the eggplant one!
author: Helen Y.

description: Pretty over-hyped.  Above average Americanized food.  We had the scallion pancakes and Nanking Chicken.  Flavors were pretty good, moderate portions.  It is very much like what you would get at your favorite neighborhood takeout Chinese place.  Not really worth the drive to the city or the wait outside.  Line moves fast, but as others said, crowded and not relaxed.
author: Catherine W.

description:
i've walked by this place for the past 15 years and always see a line out the door.  i've never really felt a desire to go inside because the place looks a bit shabby and there was one time when i was walking by and a man and lady were walking out of the place outraged because she found a CIGARETTE BUTT in her food!  it totally grossed me out and i just kept walking by.

but last weekend, i was in the city and i was starving.  i had a major craving for chinese food and i was alone.  the place had a line out the door and everyone inside looked happy.  i figured i would give it a shot.

stuff i didn't like:

1) appetizer was a flat fried thing filled with shrimp covered in a brown sauce.  the sauce was way too sweet and the shrimp didn't taste very good.  the appetizer comes with 4 pieces and after the first one, i felt like throwing up.

2) sizzling rice soup - medium spicy.  the owner (seemed like a nice guy) asked me how spicy and i just said "medium".  he asked if i was korean (i am) and i guess that meant that i can eat really spicy food because it was super spicy.  the sizzling rice never actually had any kind of sizzle to it as it was basically just a mixture of hard (like a rock) and soft (like mush) rice in the soup.  it was pretty big and i ended up eating 1/2 of it.

3) some kind of chicken dish (menu said it was a specialty).  i think it had the same sweet brown sauce that was on the appetizer.  it was gross.

4) chow mein noodles.  the noodles were decent.

yes i was hungry and yes i ordered a lot of food.  the total was pretty cheap though ($34).

the service was terrible.  the seating is terrible (if you get stuck in an inner table, you can't get out...2 other tables have to stand up to let you out).  it takes forever to get your ice water refilled.

honestly...i think this was the worst chinese food i've ever had.  if you were to pay me to eat there, i wouldn't go back there again.

but i guess some people like it.  there were 2 indian guys sitting next to me and they were both talking to each other saying how good the food is.  

next time i'll walk into any of the other chinese restaurants in the area since it is chinatown.

RVD.
author: Dan P.

description: First and Last. Menu was SUPER american-ized and overpriced at that. Save your money go to a panda express found would be even more flavorful. Not many menu options at nanking.
author: R C.

description:
Here's the real deal:
-its DIRTY! dark and dirty, the floor, the plates you name it
-the service is quick, concise and without pretense.  Many people let the servers choose for them with some input from the table (which they do graciously take)
-they rush you in and out like cattle
NOW, that being said behold the stars.  THE FOOD IS THE SHIT.  It is greasy but glorious and nothing can take that away.  Don't come here if you heart Panda Express orange chicken or your heart yearns for PF Chang's.  Stand in line, bask in the joy of being called, eat what they bring and enjoy.
author: Malena D.

description:
My friends and I just stopped by since it was on our way to North Bay.

We are complete tourist suckers for lines.

It is horribly cramped and the food is alright. I've had much better, despite the pricetag they offer on their food.
author: Geraldine M.

description:
Ahhhhh, an old favorite. I made it my first stop on a weekend return to my old stomping grounds. 5 stars for it's unique food and the memories.

This place never disappoints and I never order from the menu. I always let them bring "food for 4." You never know what there going to bring and there is always something new.
author: Scott M.

description:
There isn't a lot to say about this place that hasn't already been said .  But after living in San Francisco for nearly two years and just now making it to House of Nanking, I feel like it's still worthy of a review.

This place often has a very long line (up to 40 minutes? wow) but I walk by this place a lot and know that if you time it right, you can get right in. We got in on a Sunday evening (pre-tourist season, mid-April) and were seated right away.  Like others have said- from the minute you are cramped into one of the tables, most likely only a few inches away from another party, you feel a bit rushed.  

We actually got menus and chose what we wanted... I had no idea before reading reviews just now that sometimes they just order for you?  Interesting.  That would have made for a whole different experience I'm sure.

We had the fried shrimpcakes (is that what they were called?), sesame chicken and the mu shu chicken.  It was all good, but nothing exceptional.  The mu shu was probably my favorite.

This place is worth at least one visit by both tourists and locals.  My advice would be to not plan on going to this place so you don't have to deal with lines.  Rather, stumble upon it during a random night in North Beach when you see there is no line.

Maybe I'll be back.
author: Derek B.

description:
If youre looking for a good chinese, not sure what you want, or want to try somthing new this is the place man!

You get no menus here the owner comes round and asks what kind of thing you like, fish, veg or whatever and he thinks for a minute and say 'oh you'll like this' minutes later he brings you the goods dish or dishes!

you know its good if the owner brings you what he think is good on the day!

def go to this place you may have to queue for a litte. my hotel recomeneded this place and ill def be going back.

Nan King rules!
author: Fazan K.

description:
This is the kind of place you either hate or love.  If you don't like the server trying to persuade you to order something different or changing your order for you, you'll hate it.  If you don't like seeing the ingredients of your meal stacked up all over the restaurant, you'll hate it.  If you don't like Chinatown, you'll hate it.

If you like good food, you'll love it.  If you like large portions, you'll love it.  If you're OK with the fact that they're supposed to take credit cards but they sometimes force you to pay with cash, you'll love it.
author: John S.

description:
The food was pretty good. I went with a lot of friends so we just ordered food and shared it. What I liked about this place is that the staff does not take bull from anyone. What I didn't like is that the restaurant is too cramped. Also, you need to get there early and get waitin' or you won't be eating anytime soon. 

Overall, it's maybe something to be tried, but not over and over again.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
My first time in San Fran and a friend recommended House of Nanking. I never heard of it, but I love Chinese food and it was in CHINA town. What could go wrong? Yikes!

My boyfriend and I showed up 5 minutes before they opened for lunch and there was a line outside. Figured "wow...hotspot, the food must be good!". When they opened we were quickly ushered into a tiny corner. I thought, "Cute!" Then looked behind me and saw a dead fly on the window sill. But I let it slide as it JUST opened for the day and it was by the window, it happens.

Then they came to put plates on our table and my plate had some dried food on it. Ok, I'm sorry, but that is one strike! (including the dead fly).

We ordered our food and were chatting. Then a different waitress came over and went to give us menus. So I really nicely said, "We already ordered". She said, "Oh, OK!" and continued to give us menus. I said, "No, we already ordered our food." she said, "Oh, hehe" and paused. It wasn't until I practicably pantomimed ordering food, that she understood me. Really? Two strikes.

I saw all the waiters quickly buzzing about and it looked like everything was going fine. It took about 20 minutes, but I got my appetizer, then soup (as my meal). My boyfriend shared my food as his was missing. Hmm. When we finally asked the waitress, she said, "It's coming". Not! We waited another minute or 2 and by that time almost an HOUR had gone by. We canceled his food order and then they tried to charge us for rice we never got. Strike THREE.

Before we left, I used their scary bathroom. There was one dim bulb in there and it was dirty. Sketchy. Do I even need to mention strike four?

I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone. I don't get what all the hype is about.
author: Erica N.

description:
I'm a local and so I knew the wait would be outrageous and made sure to come at an off-peak time (late on a Tuesday night). My party of 3 got in right away and absolutely LOVED it. We let our waiter order for us and were not dissapointed. The orange chicken was the best I've EVER had!!! Make sure to go at an off-peak time and let the chef/waiter order for you -it's a recipe for success!

I guess I should throw in that my husband who lived in China for more than 2 years wasn't impressed when he came with friends on a different occasion but he is pretty picky about all American-Chinese food.
author: Vanessa B.

description:
A true hole in the wall. I wouldn't take your in laws there to impress them unless they're true to food and not to the embiance. Good to bring your visiting friends from out of state. 

Let the owner make the recommendations for you. My faves: mangolian beef, stuffed mushrooms, and the jazmine tea served in their quirky pastel tupperware cups!!!

Veggies are fresh and crisp...
author: Genevieve J.

description:
i don't really know what people's issue is with this place is, the owner, Peter Fang always takes care of us, takes our order off the menu if we know what we want, or makes us something special if we don't. He'll make special orders for vegetarians, and is adventurous in his use of ingredients in his food, I've never had Chinese food with tomatoes but it was delicious every time we been. I've been 3 times now, and no one has ever had any complaints about what they've ordered, meat or veggie. The service is quick and efficient, the prices are a little higher that what i'd like for lunch but completely reasonable for dinner

who cares if its not "home-style" or authentic, nowhere do they claim it is. If you want authentic walk another block up the hill.
author: Jared Z.

description:
I went here  yesterday after work.
We ordered the Wonton Soup, Sesame Chicken and Calamari

Lets see, the Sesame was excellent. I'll give that a five stars
Lightly fried chicken pieces in batter with a nice sweet, brown sauce. Served with sweet potatoes and chinese cucumbers.

The won ton soup was only ok. I've had better elsewhere
Six wontons in a lemony, gingery broth with fish pieces.

The calamari was soggy and did not have any sauce. BOO HOO.

But the bad side that ticked me off. SERVICE

We had to walk and get our own forks, napkins, and refill our own water. COME THE FU*K ON!!!!!!! You better believe I was mad.
So whatever. The sesame chicken was good, but it's not that good that I would come back to serve myself. You might as well get takeout, so you don't have to sit in that mess.

Have I ever cursed in my reviews. NEVER
 Yeah I was that pissed. I had a child with me, so when my child gets ignored, you better believe I'll be irate.
author: Charlene C.

description:
You could wheel Terri Schiavo* in here, plop her down at a table, tuck a $20 bill behind her ear, leave for an hour, come back, and she would be well-fed.  Their service is that good.

I know people bag on this place as inauthentic.  I couldn't give a f---.  You walk in skinny, you drop about $15, you walk out fat.  Boom, done.  

I always take my relatives from the Midwest here when they visit, and they always rave about it, as well they should.

--------------------------
*If she were still alive, of course.  Even House of Nanking cannot feed the dead.
author: Paul B.

description: We went there bc we heard of it's incredible reputation over the yrs, it delivered. It's superb and I mean fantabulous Chinese food. It's too bad we've become jaded with the cuisine as just take out nowadays. But, this isn't traditional Chinese fare. It's rich, delicious, and original. It's not a fancy restaurant, but it's clean, cozy and always packed. Portions are huge, prices very reasonable.
author: Zinat M.

description: This place is awesome. Everything is good here.  I don't recall coming here and not liking any thing about their dishes. I was introduced to this place by my cousin from Belgium.  He knew this place all the way from Belgium.  I highly recommend here.  Fresh food and fast service.
author: Sammy G.

description:
OK, really it's a solid 3.5.  I went here twice in 2 days, once because I wanted to, and once because my group wanted to.  Once for lunch and once for dinner.  Both times we had the guy order for us.  

My first impression when I looked at the menu was "huh?"  It didn't seem particularly full of Chinese flavours or dishes, and it was depressingly short.  When the food came, we got the beef rolls, what seemed like baby sugar snap peas with chilis, and the shrimp/mushroom semi-spicy dish.  All were tasty, although I'd take a good rendition of mu shu before I'd take this.  So, tasty, but not fantastic, and didn't feel particularly Chinese except for the occasional chili pepper and the excellent looking jasmine tea balls.

The second time, I knew more what to expect.  We got almost exactly the same food, plus a whole lot more since there were 8 of us.  It was all very tasty again!  Some of it even felt more Chinese than the previous night, too.

I think the bottom line is that the food is good, although not authentic Chinese, and as long as your expectations are in line with reality you'll walk out a happy camper.
author: Adam G.

description: The food was delicious!! The Calamari and Homemade Pork Wonton Soup are AWESOME! The calamari has a nice vinegar drizzle which makes the calamari taste even more amazing. I could have eaten another plate or two. The servers are not rude, they are just more reserved than most people are used to. They do a good job at taking care of you and getting your food to you. The community tables make it a little difficult to move around, but if your neighbors are as nice as ours were, it makes the experience even that much better.
author: Deb S.

description:
Though there can be a wait depending on what night and what time you go and it can be quite crowded, the food here is very flavorful.

It's not your typical Chinese food in the city, where the majority if cantonese cuisine, this place does the spicy.

I've done a little bit of ordering on our own and having the waiter/waitress decide for us, both ways, the dishes came out superb.

My bf does not like hot and sour soup much but after the recommendation of the old man, who said it was a house specialty, my bf actually liked the hot and sour soup.  

We've gotten the onion pancake, it's different from others I've had.  It's thicker and crispier, the sauce they put on top is also delicious.

I've had the porkchops and we've asked them to add eggplant, which was delicious, it's a sweet spicy flavor.  There's also this vegetable dish that I always see people order, which unfortunately I don't know the name of, that is delicious, goes down great with just rice.

All in all, a great place for a different flavor of Chinese food.  The prices aren't as dirt cheap as your standard Chinese food in SF though.
author: Winnie L.

description:
How do you do, Mr. NanKing?
A Deano and TTT Production

TIP: For those who complain of the wait, tourist trap, etc. Go on a Sat night at 9:50-10:05 pm, they still seat people and they want to get you out of there too = Fast service, really fast. 

Time: 9:44 pm
Brian (In his room, screaming): Let's eat dawg!!
Me (In my room, half-dead, laying on bed, idly surfing internet): Word.
Brian: NanKing?
Me: Yelp says it closes at 10. We don't have time.

SIDE NOTE: Brian drives like a bat out of hell. Really. We went to LA once. In 4 hrs and 45 minutes. 

Time: 9:46 pm
Me (In Brian's car): We're not going to make it. 
Brian (Running red lights): Shut up, loser.
Me (Looking in rear view mirror): Did you just hit that pedestrian?
Brian (Going 90 down Golden Gate): I'm hungry. 

Time: 9:52 pm
Brian (at corner of Kearney): Get out. Get us a table.

Time: 9:54
Me (In NanKing): I need a table for 2.
Waiter (Points to table, grabs notepad): Order.
Me: Huh? I'm waiting for my friend. Do you have menus?
Waiter: What you want?

NOTE: At this point I call Brian to take his order. This visibly frustrates the waiter who says quickly 'Pork? Chicken? Beef? Seafood?' I contemplated responding for .12 milliseconds. The waiter just walked away.

Time: 9:58 
Food is brought to table.
Brian arrives from parking car. 
Food consumed in roughly 5 minutes.

Best Ever. No questions asked. Do I care if it's authentic? No. I'm not Chinese anyway, how the hell should I know. I barely even knew what I was eating. It was called delicious in my mind.
author: Tom C.

description:
Wow. The roach comment before mine summoned a gag reflex. Roaches are my archenemy and if I ever see one at a restaurant I can never return. However, the roach experience didn't happen to me, so I'm not personally traumatized--but if it did happen I wouldn't go back.

That being said, this place has been totally yummingtons every time I've been. I'm not crazy about deep fried things, and I love vegetables, so I've been very satisfied with the veggie quality and the fact that I've never bitten into a tendon or weird mystery meat zone. 

To be fair, I haven't tried any other Chinese places in SF so I've got some exploring to do.

P.S. There is a line all the time but fast-ish turnaround.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
We keep ordering fabulous food here and I don't think this is luck. Try the scallops. Be sure to order tea. It has flowers in it.
Ack. They changed their menu. Not as extensive (or good) as it used to be.
author: Vena V.

description: We waited about fifteen minutes to get in. Upon being seated, we simply told them to serve us three plates of whatever would be good, one pork, one chicken, and one vegetarian. The dishes that resulted were delicious.
author: Jonathan D.

description:
"All sauces prepared by chef Peter Fang", says the menu. 

Props to the chef, the sauces were actually all quite tasty. We got the cold noodles, which were delicious tossed in this garlicky sesame oil mix. Unfortunately the "bao bing wrap" was no good. Basically an $8 do-it-yourself soft taco. Tasty sauce though!

I got the sense that this was more of an asian-fusiony place than an actual Chinese restaurant. So if you go in with the expectation of lettuce wraps and orange chicken it'll be great. It's like taking the Panda Express menu and executing it with actual cooks.
author: Victor L.

description:
I am actually a very big fan of House of Nanking, and wouldn't hesitate to recommend lunch or dinner there to anyone who's in the neighborhood.  The food is good, fast, always tasty and rarely disappointing.  If you're lucky enough to meet the owner, let him pick your dishes for you - he won't let you down!

Over the years their onion pancakes have been a favorite of mine, so I was a little disappointed today to find them much more oniony and less pancakey than previous visits -- but they were still pretty great.  Other faves: pork stuffed mushrooms, sesame chicken, anything with pea shoots.  

Minus one star for my oniony cakes, and minus one star for our sour-faced server and the broken lock on the bathroom door.  Hello, my butt!
author: Katrina V.

description:
We were on our way to North Beach for dinner when we saw that this place didn't have a line, for like the first time ever, so we had to go in. I had never been but he had so I got a little info on what was going to happen before, which helped out a lot. 

We were seated right next to another couple, think elementary school cafeteria style. All I remember about them was that the girl kept complaining that her "tea wasn't flowering right"? Not sure what that means but ok. 

Anyways, I ordered the sesame chicken off of the menu because I had been told it was good. He went the more traditional route of telling the crazy lady that he wanted some kind of shrimp. After telling us that we needed an appetizer and that she would pick a good one for us she was off. 

The ap we got was some kind of marinated green beans and they were really good. I was surprised at how good. My chicken was good, but his mushroom shrimp was killer. Overall I was very happy with dinner. 

I got a plum wine, which I have never gotten before but when I asked which kind of wine they had and the answer was white and red I decided to mix it up a bit. I was happy, tasted a little like cough syrup but the good kind. 

I would go back, minus one star because I felt rushed and the tea lady next to me decided to use our portion of the table as an extension of her own.
author: Jen M.

description:
A bustling, bistro-like atmosphere with outstanding Chinese food that borders on California-fusion.  This is not a place to sit and chat all evening--the noise and rush to get customers seated will be a constant distraction, but indeed the food is delicious, and fairly inexpensive.  Simply, the sesame chicken is among the best.  Beware: flavors run very strong here, with lots of salt, sweet, sour, spice  The waitstaff service can be sporadic at times, but the owner maintains an good degree of vigilance over his customers.  The wine list could be a little better, but then again, this is Chinese... I think.

Update August 2006: Laughably bad service on my sixth (seventh?) visit and the food was cold.  Dear, dear, I hope this isn't a trend.
author: MScott S.

description:
I've seen this place always jam packed with a line waiting on the street so last night I went and check what the fuzz is about. 
Being a Chinese myself I had to say they did two things to seperate themselves from the usual chinese restaurant. 
- they use really nice and fancy plates
- their portion is a lot smaller than any other chinese restaurants you go to, make you still hungry after your meal and want to eat more, I'm sure they do this on purpose. 
- their price is more expensive than other chinese food, consider they're a 'hole-in-the-wall' 

Other then that what is the big deal with this place? The food is very mediocre and cold, just go to Clement and any chinese restaurants there can beat this place.
author: Kelvin Y.

description:
Food - above average

Service - the old man waiter asked if he could add a "couple" items to our order. we said ok, thinking he'd choose the best dishes. he added 5 dishes to 3 we had originally selected (there were only 4 people eating). some were good, some were not. quantity was too much.

Price - the bill came and turns out he chose the most expensive items for us. 

$83 is a ripoff for 4 people at some hole-in-the-wall.

Beware of letting the old man order.
author: Tuppence D.

description:
House of Nanking was dingy and loud at 5-ish in the evening and we were about to leave when we saw that duck wasn't on the menu, but the owner stopped us and fed us some cock-and-bull story about duck not being "in-season" (Don't they freeze it?). Anyway, he was friendly, but very authoritative: He TOLD us what we were going to have. 

The lightly fried calamari swimming in vinegar was the best I've ever tasted. The lukewarm noodle dish was nothing special. The Nanking chicken dish was sweet, delicious, and horribly fattening. My Grandpa was unimpressed (but the ardor with which he ate suggested otherwise). I'd come again.
author: Michelle G.

description:
You either like it or hate it.

You'll definitely like it if you like hole-in-the wall greasy type food. Almost everything is battered and fried, and smothered in a sweetish sauce. 

Must order:
- the stuffed mushrooms. unbelievable. 
- appetizer platter - a mix of fried goodness
- battered fish - delicious 
-let them pick a surprise dish for you, just tell them your dietary restrictions

Don't go here if you're a picky health-nut, and/or can't stand sticky tables or menus. But do go here if you appreciate roscoes chicken n' waffles..
author: Ema H.

description: Yuck. Very mediocre fare. Very frustrating service. I don't know if they think it's cute or kitchy to try and order for you, but I found it incredibly annoying and infuriating. I rarely get mad while ordering, and if not for the two co-workers who I was lunching with, I would have just walked out. The chow mein I eventually got tasted like it was prepared with MSG and sugar. Gross.
author: Milk and Cheese ..

description:
Liked:
- cleanliness / atmosphere

Disliked:
- heavy-handed food
- abrupt service

I can sort of understand the appeal of this place -- it does have a trendier atmosphere and is cleaner than a typical Chinese joint. It was packed with customers every time I walked past, so I figured it was worth a try (I didn't notice that most of the clientele were non-Asain, a bad sign, as other reviewers have pointed out!) 

The food was disgusting...every dish loaded with sauce, salt and spice, and devoid of any real flavor. A far cry from real Chinese fare. The waitstaff are competent but surly, and the place is way overpriced for the poor quality of the food. 

Other 'authentic' touches include forks and knives standard instead of chopsticks, paying extra for tea and rice, and being served green tea in gigantic glass mugs.

I really wish we had gone next door to Jia's.
author: Ginger B.

description: I go to San Fran not to often because i live far but every time i go i must come here idk if its authentic food but i could care less because they never disappoint.  A little advice never order i always ask the waiter to bring me whatever good and its just amazing. I am a VERY picky eater but this place is just amazing.
author: Alyssa V.

description:
The only thing keeping this from being a 5-star review is the hilariously awful service and the cramped quarters. Though I would give it an additional half-star if I could for the ink-jet printout of Keanu Reeves that was framed and positioned above my date's head. Alas, I cannot.

So I have been to SF twice and both times I have gone to HON. Both times I ordered the scallop tower, which was four large sea scallops lightly fried, each on their own platform of a lemon slice and an eggplant slice. It was topped with this fantastic spicy-garlic sauce and chinese greens. My date ordered the sesame chicken, which is the best I've ever had.

Beware that there is constantly a long line to get in HON. I was hungry and the wait was excruciating. So get there about 30 minutes before you think you will be hungry.
author: Justin T.

description:
I will join the House of Nanking Fan Club by saying that this is the best Chinese food I've EVER had!  The long line in front of the restaurant says it all.  

I think the only gripe is that its not as clean as I would like it to be.  But, the food is so good I could care less!  I come from San Jose, so the drive takes from 30-45 min.  It takes me about 30 min to order & finish my food, the drive is WELL worth it!

Everyone that is new to the Bay Area I always tell them about this place.  So far, no one has had anything bad to say about them!
author: Erin Marie B.

description:
Three stars is about right. 

First off, the ambiance is pretty awful. Very crowded (four of us were sitting at what was essentially an eight person table with four other people) and loud.

The service is no-nonsense, but fast. We were in and out very quickly. 

The food was good. Definitely not great. The baby pea shoots (in vinagrette) were pretty tasty. The shrimp and mushrooms were also good. The sesame chicken was excessively sweet and not something I'd get again. Everything was a little pricey for what it was.

It's worth trying once, especially if you like sweet potatoes, as those seem to be in almost every dish.
author: Ryan L.

description:
This is about the worst Chinese food you can ever get.
Whenever I think about it, I am speechless, I have no speech....

It is a terrible sin to cook/sell food like that.
author: Barry W.

description: Highly touristed? Yes. Curt, borderline rude staff? Yes. Absolutely superb pot stickers and onion cake? Yes!
author: Joe T.

description: This is one of those places I read was good years ago, but never got around to trying. Well I tried, but probably won't again. I called for takeout, 2 items, the woman said 10 minutes. I got there 15 minutes later, only to wait another 10 or 15. And it wasn't a packed place, so why the delay? The online menu is also out if date, as I learned when I got the check. It's more expensive now and the woman had nothing to say about it other than, "yeah, sorry." The food wasn't great, especially for the price. Disappointing.
author: Julia S.

description:
I used to love this place.  The Nanking Sesame chicken is amazing!

I would tell out of town friends "this is the best Chinese food in the UNIVERSE!"  And sure enough they would agree.  At least, they agreed until the last time I went there and sat right next to the kitchen.

After we had been served our food my friend (who was facing the kitchen) gasped and said "look at that!"  He was indicating that the rag used to wipe down tables after people leave was being placed on top of a box of tortillas (for the Mu shu dishes.)  Not so bad right?  WRONG.  I watched repeatedly as server after server LIFTED the wet table-wipe-down rag OFF of EXPOSED (out of the bag) tortillas and served them to customers.  All I could think was "OH MY GOD those boxes are IN the customer seating area, god knows what they do to the food where we can't see it!"

I have not been able to eat there since.   A real pity when you consider how good the food tastes.
author: Robert S.

description:
I miss the old days, when only locals knew about House of Nanking... When you didn't have to wait 10 mins to get served, the menu had more than 10 items, prices for entrees were almost 1/2 of what they are now, they served you quickly and actually brought you what you ordered, the food they brought you was HOT and FRESH, they did not forget to bring your rice with your meal, and they didn't forget to bring your BEER.

Now, I just avoid it like any other SF tourist trap.
author: Jonathan P.

description:
Was it good? Yes.

Was it good enough to stand in line for 1/2 hour for? Absolutely not.

It's definitely in the top 10% of chinese places in San Francisco, but that's not saying much considering it's ridiculous reputation as the greatest thing since General Tso whipped up some chicken.
author: Andrew L.

description:
this place is really over rated. first of all, the place is really dark and supppper tight inside.I have a tad bit of a pet peeve with eating at dark restaurants... ehh. we were seated in between two couples. We practically were apart of their whole conversation. My friend and I weren't that hungry so we just ordered the sesame chicken and the house noodles. it was alright. I ate better chinese food in LA.(visiting from LA).
We ended up not even finishing half of it, so we decided to pack it up and ended up giving it to a homeless man who was outside. 
so i guess, someone enjoyed it more than I did.
author: minna p.

description:
By far this is the BEST CHINESE RESTAURANT I've ever been to.  And I have been to a lot of them.  Great atmosphere and great food.  This is unlike any other Chinese restaurant I've been to.  Be prepared to be blown away by the variety of original dishes.

The trick is, let them order for you.  They will ask you about your preferences, ie, do you like pork, chicken, seafood, salty or sweet, etc.. then the food just keeps coming.  You tell them when to stop.
author: Cris E.

description: This place was awesome!!! Mothing but great things to say! The owner came to our table and asked if we had ever eaten here before, we said no and he completly took care of my whole family...Food and ambience was amazing!! Will be back for more dumplings!! Thanks Chef Feng!!
author: Todd R.

description:
Not for the faint of tummy. Food was mediocre. Service was efficient, but not exactly what you would go there for, so I'm not sure what is. The dishes they set out on the table were still wet and with something that looked like pink water. The silverware was spotty. The place is nothing to write home about and the photo of Rachel Ray really set me off. The prices were not cheap, regardless of rumours of this place being sooo amazing and really inexpensive.

The one good thing about the place was the crispy rice veggie soup, whos broth was tasty and clear. Everything else we ordered had a disgusting taste to it, even the white rice, which I didn't think could really be f*&^%$d up. It came out and was lumpy and overcooked; making it mushy and flavorless. Now I know. 

I feel bad writing this, but this is my honest opinion. Not about putting my dining 'fate' in the hands of some old person who probably doesn't give a damn in the first place. 

Not about the hype and I won't willingly ever go back there.
author: n b.

description: Horrible Tourist Trap. Yesterday's rice reheated with lumps, their "wrap" was a Mexican flour tortilla (we kid you not), and over all bland, mediocre fare with little respect for the food. The rave review for this place must be from those that have never had fresh, flavorful Chinese food before...it's all we can figure. You have been warned: In a food town as great as S.F., it's just a crime to settle for this crap.
author: Chuck N.

description:
Having diner at House of Nanking is a similar experience to buying a "I love NY" T-shirt at JFK airport. It's a bit embarassing and regretful, but it's part of an ordinary trip for ordinary people. 

So If you're a tourist who has no idea where to eat and ends up dining at House of NK blindly guided by lonely planet's recommendation , I won't blame you.

If you repeat here and think this is the best Chinese food you can get, you must be a gustatorial idiot or Rep. (editted)
author: yota L.

description: Tucked away in a small storefront in San Francisco's Chinatown district, adorned merely with the primary colored sign lies the best authentic Chinese restaurant in San Francisco by far. Our cab driver told us, If you want real food, the good stuff, forget the menu and ask the waitress for the "Chef Special." We did, and with her eyes questioning, she asked us "You trust me? I bring you family style food for all." Thus began the endless parade of plate after plate of oriental goodness. Every bite was amazing. Flavors I've never tasted before, tender, buttery seafood, crisp and spicy meats, perfectly cooked noodles. The space is small. No reservations or even putting your name in allowed. When you get there you wait outside until the waitress comes outside and calls out a number of open seats. If your party matches, you're in, if not, you wait. Seating is at long, communal tables. Be prepared to make friends with a stranger but it's worth it. Service is incredibly fast because they need the seats turned over quickly. Amazing! 5 stars only because I can't give 10.
author: Paul C.

description: What makes a legend?  How does a restaurant continue to have lines around the corner, and stand the test of time.  It is about the food, and continued excellence.  Whenever I am in New York or San Francisco, I immediately think of Chinatown, and certain restaurants come to mind.  In New York--the Port Arthur, Hop Lee, and Wo Hop.  In San Francisco I think of House of Nanking, and R&G Lounge.  I truly had a different experience last night.  House of Nanking has been truly adventurous with their menu, and has really created a new cleaner atmosphere unlike the traditional Chinatown restaurants.  A new sign, decor, tables, chairs, waitresses in uniform, and an open kitchen--can you imagine.  I had the wonton soup with sizzling rice.  It had a little punch to it.  The green tea is like a good home remedy.  My grandmother used to give me a small cup of tea like this when I was sick.  She told me I could only drink that much and no more.  It always did the trick, but who knows what was in it?  I also followed my waitresses recommendation and had the fish.  It was deep fried with a spicy sauce and served with some lightly oiled spinach and garlic.  It was wonderful.  I readily admit that I miss the old school metal pots, and their Nanking dishes, and congee style soups.  As I sat their I saw the celebrity pics on the wall including Rachel Ray, and Anthony Bourdain.  I do miss many of this restaurants old dishes, but noticed the many college students eating lettuce wraps, and mu shu chicken with apple slices!  The raved about their food.  We even had very friendly, customer service oriented waitresses.  Imagine that in Chinatown--I am still stunned.  Part of the reason I am giving this restaurant 5 stars is that they have done change well even for an old school diehard like me.  I do miss the old dishes, but these are obviously healthier dishes, with less salt, etc.  We are in California!  I hope Wo Hop and Hop Lee in New York never change, but if they do I hope they do it like the House of Nanking!  I was very satisfied and full from my meal, but not tired and sluggish.  I see that they have even opened a sister restaurant near my hotel--Fang's restaurant.  I may have found a place for my business lunch today.
author: Thomas W.

description: Really good asian food, they rush you in and out which sucks but they are known for this so deal with it! We had the calamari, house noodles and beef pancakes.. Really good!!
author: Julia B.

description:
I don't understand why people hate this place.  I had a magnificent time with friends and great service.  We arrived on a Sunday night and saw their was a line, so we went and got a drink at a local bar and as soon as we were done their was no line at all!  We had 8 people and got seated immediately.  A man came over and asked if anyone was a vegetarian and I told him that I just eat fish and veggies and was very nice.  Right after that large plates that had yummy yummy dishes started showing up randomly.  Some of the entrees were black bean asparagus, calamari in a garlic butter sauce, duck egg rolls (which i heard were good), fish and cucumber sauce, spicy vegetables, spicy prawns, egg drop soup (best i have ever had), sesame chicken, and a salad with meat and lots more.  

What is really fun about this restaurant is that you don't know what is coming next or what to expect.  It is a very communal experience and really fun with a big group.  Everyone I ate with was from LA and they were the ones who turned me on to it!  So stop the hate and enjoy the excitement of what will be next!
author: Jackie B.

description:
Came here with some friends yesterday and I was thrilled that everyone really loved the food, because I usually rave about how great it is.

One of the things I love about House of Nanking is the tea...they have fantastic loose leaf teas, which I love. Try the detoxifying herb tea...it's pretty awesome.

Sesame chicken was phenomenal, and the shrimp with mushrooms was a top choice, but we had ordered a tofu with broccoli dish for our vegetarian friends and that, above all, was the best.

In my opinion don't order the scallop tower...you only get 3 scallops for $13.95. Maybe some will say it's worth it, but I don't really think so.

Service is spotty, but I'd rather have great food with crappy service than the other way around.

I still recommend this place, and will probably be back.
author: Angela G.

description:
My first experience with House of Nanking was great. Big group of guys for a birthday, crowded table, tons of food to go around. I would have rated it a four on this day. A little on the expensive side for Chinese food, but I lived.

My second experience (for lunch) didn't go quite as planned. The play-by-play goes like this...

Waiter: What would you like to drink?
Me: Hot tea please.

3 minutes later, waiter returns with with a huge mug of tea and very fancy-looking teabag... I think to myself oh no... I frantically browse the menu to see if this tea costs a lot, it looks expensive... doesn't it? Much to my surprise, the tea menu has a few options, and the waitor graciously brings me the 2.95 tea. Wasn't tea free at restaurants?

I know, I know what you're thinking... stupid Asian goes to restaurant with tons of tourist hype filled with NO Asians and is surprised when he gets jipped... go figure. I guess you could say it was not meant to be from the beginning.

My entree was actually very tasty. I ordered a mongolian beef (probably the most tender beef I've had in this dish before) and a side of rice. The beef had a lot of strong basil taste... a bit overpowering and there was definitely a hasty amount of corn starch used to thicken up the sauce. 

Summary: 
$20 dollars for good (not great) meal
Could have been cheaper (the tea!!!)
Could have been better
Definitely shoulda found a restaurant in SF Chinatown with more Asians eating inside.
author: Michael M.

description: Wow!  Didn't expect ths experience at all!  I'm a more adventurous eater than some in my group. Nanking was recommended by our hotel. We only waited 10 minutes for a table. It was cramped quarters but the atmosphere s authentic. The owner, Peter , introduced himself and whisked away our menus after hearing we were first timers.  Then the food started rolling in!  First a giant mushroom in a brown sauce to share.  Next ,my favorite of the night was THE BEST  wonton soup I ever ate.  It was made with cream or milk, and had an incredible flavor. The wontons were fresh and plump. Then came dishes of crispy beef and baby bok choy, sesame chicken, pork, noodles, fish, each with different sauces, styles and flavors.  This was not gourmet or fancy but what a fabulous experience for this first time San Francisco visitor.  Experience is everything!
author: Elena C.

description:
I came here at the recommendation of my foody cousin and my good friend who live in NY. I guess if they're telling me to come and over 1K yelpers are giving it 3+ stars, it's worth checking out.

Unfortunately I came in thinking they served dim sum- why? I'm not really sure. I probably can't read or listen well when spoken to. 

Regardless, my friends and I weren't disappointed when we realized my mistake (lucky me). We got the sesame chicken, peashoots, sizzling noodles and some special beef dish the kitchen whipped up when I asked for the crispy beef but realized they actually didn't serve it anymore. I really have no clue what sort of beef this was or if it was the crispy beef dish or what but it was some seriously awesome PAN-Chinese food. 

"Pan-Chinese?" you ask. Pan-Chinese in deed. I didn't want to believe it but in reality, when my b/f argued that this tasted unlike any other Chinese restaurant, I was forced to really think about what I was eating. The food is a lot sweeter than any other Chinese food I'd have and the sizzling noodles was a dish I'd never seen on other Chinese menus. Also, because this restaurant is located on the edge of Chinatown and there is a dominance of non-chinese and American- born Asians here, I really must question the authenticity of it food.

Nevertheless, it is the best "Chinese" food I've had in a loooooong time and my friends, boyfriend and I agree, we'd crave it after wards; heck- we're all craving it now.
author: D N.

description:
Went there for dinner on a Sunday.  We were able to make a reservation over the phone, which turned out to be a good idea, as around 7:30pm there was a long line that went out the door to get a table.

From other reviews I'd read on Yelp I was expecting the place to be somewhat run-down inside, but actually I found quite the opposite.  The place looked like it had recently been renovated--very modern and clean... with the exception of the cheap aluminum patio chairs at the tables.  I will say that the restaurant is quite small and the tables are packed together pretty tightly.  If you're looking for a quiet. private romantic evening for two, this may not be the place.

Following the advice given by another Yelper, we let the staff order for us, advising them that one in our party (me) was a vegan.  She brought out a number of delicious dishes, and plenty that were vegan friendly too.  She checked in at intervals to see whether we had enough yet.  Many dishes later, the four of us went away very satisfied for about $22 each.

House of Nanking is a great place for groups of up to 6 people or even 10 people--the max I think I saw a grouping of tables could handle.  Chinese food in general is more fun with more people because you get a greater variety of dishes.  

As for specific dishes, I particularly enjoyed the onion pancakes (I am told the Chinese name is huang2 cong1 you2 bing3).  They also had a delicious tofu dish, which I can no longer remember the name of... though I believe there was only one or two on the menu.
author: Peter O.

description: This place used to be great. Quality and portions of food have gone wayyyyyyyyyy down.
author: Ken S.

description: Went early afternoon and was seated immediately and the service was fast and polite. Ordered the melt in your mouth calamari, sesame chicken, and chow mein. Ended up getting fried rice instead of chow mein but didn't say anything. Calamari was okay but I prefer a crunchier version and less of a soft version. Sesame chicken was the best and we wished we would have ordered 2! Definitely a must try! Fried rice was okay, but not a fan of the basil. Will come back to try other things:)
author: Gina S.

description: If I am going into the city I try to plan my day around eating here. The only complaint I have is the long lines pretty much all of the time and the owner is a bit pushy sometimes and orders what he wants to order for you. The line isn't really there fault because I understand they want to maximize the seating in the restaurant rather then having a waiting area. I never had yams prepared they way they are prepared at Nanking and let me say if you don't like yams this will make you like them. The flavors on pretty much every dish I have tried are clean and the veggies are crisp and even though have sauce on them really shine through. The meats are cooked perfectly and are tender and flavorful. A definite must if you are in SF!
author: Pierre M.

description:
Forget the haters.  I've had solidly better than average experiences here every time I went, and the last time I got some fish with green bean dish that was better than crack.  For real.  I want to dry it out, chop it up, and snort that shit.  Or wait, maybe I can cook it in a spoon and shoot it right up.  

As a matter of fact, I'm getting my next fix tonight.  When you see me nodding out, you'll know what's up.
author: Coco D.

description: So we went with a group and just had them order for us. The pot stickers were excellent and the seasame chicken was probably the best I've ever had. Definitely let them serve you family style if you have a group of 4+.
author: David W.

description:
This is a good place to eat, I don't know why people are hating on it.
Actually one of the better ones and there is always a line outside.

Def. go there if in San Fran.
author: Krock K.

description:
Excellent excellent excellent asian-fusion. Potstickers and General Tso's chicken you have to try to believe! Cheap, fast and on the way to a drinking night in North Beach. 
If you don't know what you want, but have a taste for a certain flavor, let the waiters be your guide. A must-go.
author: E.Mo. ..

description: Not sure why every trip advisor website had this restaurant listed. Was visiting San Fran from Chicago and wanted to try some Chinese food in the famous Chinatown. This is the worst Chinese food I had in my life, and I love Chinese food so it's hard for me to hate a certain Chinese food dish. The wait was abnormally long for no reason (had called to make reservations but that was a fail), the service was terrible (rude, no water refills, mistakingly not bringing enough plates or silverware and us having to ask 3 times before getting them). A couple of us ordered the one shrimp dish on their menu, and it was literally terrible and I didn't finish mine. I'm not a picky eater at all. A few of my friends got the sesame chicken and it was adequate, like at every other place, and nothing special. I would never recommend this place to anyone. Still so surprised that this place was recommended online for tourists.
author: K K.

description:
I was introduced to this place when I first moved to the bay area about 5 years ago.   I always bring friends and family here when they visit me.
It's totally worth the hour wait on a weeknight!
author: Allison S.

description: Awesome onion cakes, and flower tea.  Skip the plum wine,, excellent sesame chicken. It was worth the wait!
author: Joy E.

description:
moo-shooconfused by the folks that don't like this place. My friends and I were on a day trip to SF, asked a tour bus guy where the best Chinese food was and he said NanKing... so we went there. The owner (I think) asked what we wanted. After looking at him a little like 'uh, we don't know' he took our menus and said 'I choose, you like' or something like that... so we kind of hoped for the best (how bad could it be?) and said ok (not that at that point we had any choice, owner man was gone). It was fabulous! Chicken, beef, shrimp, some fried wonton appetizer things, mushrooms, rice, noodles, mooshoo stuff (my friend called them fajitas - she's so cute! wink), flower tea... about $80 after we were done. Kind of pricey, but so GOOD!! 

The only thing that was confusing was when we gave them our Visa card, the girl said 'cash'... like they don't take Visa? So we gave cash, but do they take credit cards?? Weird. I guess it was a good thing we had cash... sometimes I only go out with plastic money. But they take Visa, do they? Does anyone know?? They must... I just cannot imagine... 

I have some more friends coming up from So Cal in a few weeks and we plan to go here to try it again, make sure it was not a fluke. They are much pickier than the other group, so we shall see. ;o) I would recommend this place to anyone wanting some good Chinese food in SF. YUM! 

I gave 4 stars intead of 5 because the place could be cleaner, and the bathroom was a little scary with this long pole across the floor you had to step over (at least there was toilet paper), but I don't think that stuff determines the quality of the food... ;o)
author: amy m.

description:
"fist time here? don't worree.  i take good care of you".....*owner walks away*....and i'm like thinking..what the heck is going on here?..i didn't even look at the menu yet

i get a soup...the soup was pretty tasty...i get some glazed chicken with fried sweet potato...way over glazed....it was tongue numbing....i forget the second dish...i couldn't even taste it after the taste buds on my tongue were killed....and i get a $40 bill at the end

i gave it a 2nd try...but i yelled out this time that it was not my frist time..and i like to look at the menu.....the food was mediocre...over glazed and over seasoned....never going back
author: Hen A.

description:
I wasn't in a hurry to Yelp House of Nanking because it seems like everyone already knows about it but I just got back from lunch there and it was (as always) so good I had to review it right away.

Delicious food that is super cheap, fast and efficient service - what's not to love?

Even if you have been to House of Nanking many times you should still ask Peter to order for you now and then because he very well might surprise you with something that is not on the menu (like our yummy vegetables today).
author: lisa g.

description:
One of my friends, called up ahead of time and spoke to the hostess. She somehow got us in with minimal wait. No complaints there. The owner/ chef Peter Feng came out and spoke to us. He asked us what nationality we were. It was obvious we all were Asian.  I joked that we were all Mexican. That question always throws me off....who cares what we are..we just want to eat. Anyways, my friends spoke some Chinese half Mandarin & Cantonese. They worked out something. It was decided that Peter Feng master chef was going to order for us. WOW..food was fantastic.

It was very tasty. There was a mix of different Asian styles. I think I even tasted some Fish Sauce...whoot..whoot...shout out to all my Viet peoples.  Everyone at my table was impressed with the food.

Its a hole in the wall place. Not so clean and not so glamorous. Some questionable smells but overall a good place to eat. I didn't get a bad stomach ache and I left very full. 

Recommended to everyone who wants to wake up their pallet. My only question is..what if the chef orders for you and you don't like what you get...do you still need to pay? ...Fortunately for us..it all tasted good.
author: Jane D.

description:
I enjoy House of Nanking, despite it's lack of authenticity. Honestly, if I wanted authentic food, I would travel to the origins of the food I desired. This place has a neat idea with the ordering for you thing, and I think their sesame chicken is awesome! I love going with a big group and seeing all the neat things that come to the table. Not a fan of the Mushu they sometimes offer, but otherwise, i have yet to find a dish I dislike! 
It is fun to take 'tourists' here since most are not privy to fooding like this.  My family from Texas thought it was fabulous!
author: Amy J.

description:
Are you kidding me?! THREE stars? 

House of Nanking is not for weak hearted people! You've gotta be tough. You can't take anything personal. They want you in-and-out because it's such a bustle. Of course it violates some health codes, or else it wouldn't be a "hole-in-the-wall." 

The old man who runs the place has always been sweet to me though. I just tell him what I like/dislike, and there's some food on the table, and I love almost all of it.
author: Aromy X.

description:
You want hole-in-the-wall? You definitely get that with this joint. It's no frills, it's crammed, it's chaotic. You hear 15 other conversations going on around you. A party of three may be squished in the corner, trying to balance huge plates on a two-seater table. The wait staff doesn't really give a hoo-ha about you or your dining experience either.

But the food is damn good. And you rarely order from the menu. Ask for a chicken dish and the staff will give you their recommendations and whip one up for you. A week later, you can't remember what the heck you got the last time. So you try describing it to the server, but he gets agitated and orders a different dish for you.

Drop your pretenses and let the senses seep in. Definitely worth a try, particularly if you're an out-of-towner.
author: Ellyn N.

description:
We walked here from Union Station with a friend per her recommendation, although we were warned about the service and the propensity for lines.  We didn't have to wait too TERRIBLY long to get seated, but to actually get service, well, that's a different story entirely.  

We placed our orders and were somewhat surprised when our entrees arrived before our appetizer, which arrived roughly when were were about to ask our server if he had forgotten it - clever timing on that one!  Drinks consisted of water, no ice, and if you wanted to drop the $2, a can of Coke with a straw.
