That being said, the sesame chicken was pretty great; just the right size portion of bird chunklets, covered in a tangy sweet sauce which also adorned fresh green apples and fried sweet potato slices.  Really, the veggies were almost better than the chicken itself.  A great place for a quick bite, but not the best place if you want to hear yourself think.

If this is what passes for a tourist trap in Chinatown, you guys are getting off pretty fucking easy.
author: Sid P.

description:
Being 1/2 Asian, I have learned that good Asian restaurants have more Asians than non-Asians, thus, I was a bit worried when I only saw white people when I entered this restaurant. But, my friend who has dined at HON before, told me to relax and just go with it. 

We were seated in the 2nd room, quasi sharing a table with a solo woman. Now, the thing about HON is that you let the chef/owner order for you. 

Him: "What do you like?" 
Us: "Everything....shrimp!" 
Him: Writes somethings downs, and walks away. 

Moments later, an order of mushu beef comes out, and the waitress is wrapping the Asian burrito for you. Then came some sort of over sized shrimp fried wonton, and lastly (my fave), a shrimp/eggplant/greens dish and rice. I could have passed on the first two items, but the the three items were tasty, and having the chef bring plates out to you makes you feel a little VIP for about 5 minutes. 

Total: $37
author: Misha F.

description:
On Monday, my last and final day of my long weekend in San Fran, my BFF and I went to lunch with a couple of her friends who work across the street from Nanking. 

From what I understood of the place it has a great reputation for good authentic food, won a bunch of awards and isn't keen on handing out menus. With that said we let the "locals" order for us. 

To start we had spring rolls, a shrimp "quesadilla" (lol! I can't recall the name of it!) and mushu pork. All delicious! The spring rolls I believe had pork and eggplant (?) and were served with a tangy sweet and sour sauce. The shrimp dish had a wonton type exterior with shrimp and veggies in side. Light, crispy and flavorful! The mushu pork was a bit different than what I'm accustomed. I've had mushu and most often it's shredded pork and veggies. At Nanking it was sliced pork (mostly lean but some fat...ew!) and large slices of a veggie I can only liken to a cucumber. It looked like sliced green apple but tasted like a cross between a cucumber and onion. I'm not exactly sure what it was but it was good! 

For our main course we had the crackling beef and sesame chicken. While I didn't partake in the beef (I just don't care much for beef in chinese restaurants, so often it's not cooked well done enough for me and I find it to be a bit chewy) the sesame chicken was quite good! Lightly battered and served with sliced sweet potatoes in a slightly spicy and sweet sauce. DELISH! My favorite dish of the lunch choices!

I also just had to mention their tea. I didn't order the tea but there was a woman sitting next to us that did. It arrived with a lump of green tea leaves bundled together in a glass cup with hot water. Within a few minutes it bloomed into a mini garden in her cup! It looked too beautiful to drink! 

Overall the food was well seasoned, flavorful, not greasy and served in nice generous portions. The service was prompt and efficient. Not very friendly and hardly personable but not rude or discourteous. 

The food was quite good and there are other dishes I would love to try!
author: Syd M.

description:
It's changed!  It makes me sad. It used to be soooo good and now it's just NOT.

There was like one shrimp in our shrimp pancakes for an appetizer.  The sesame chicken was too gooey and sweet.  The side of cucumbers and sweet potatoes just seemed weird.  Even the rice was overcooked (unless we got the bottom of the rice cooker). 

I did not like it.  Gonna go to other places unless my touristy friends insist on going here.
author: Adrienne P.

description:
This is another review I have been putting off. See here is the thing...it used to be awesome...but the last 2 times it was such a let down. Where once I was willing to wait in line..in the rain..for about an hour - now..not so much. The last 2 times it smelled like rat droppings outside (yay - fun while you wait!), they changed several of my favorite dishes and not for the better, and a couple of things had different names but the dishes were IDENTICAL. The things I do like about the house:

1. Shrimp cakes with peanut sauce (Hot holy yum)
2. Fried Potstickers (with the same peanut sauce)
3. The tempura mushrooms and sweet potatoes that come with certain dishes
4. The fact that they use chayote as an accent vegetable..I love chyote..

Oh and they used to have awesome tea with goji berries, dandelion flowers, rose and a few other things...the past 2 times I got it it didn't come with a strainer (come on!) and it was different and lame. What gives? I want to give them another shot..but I'm still gun shy. 

Oh, it's loud, small, the bathroom is gross, and the wait staff is rude....before I would give it a 4.5 easy..but now...((sigh)) - and that's pushing it...
author: Natalie G.

description:
Pretty much one the of the best Chinese restaurants I've been to!  The wait was pretty long, but I think it adds to the mystique.  The long lines is what has made me want to come to this place, Ive been seeing the long lines for YEARS! Besides, hanging around the streets in the city is one of the reasons why it is so damn cool. 

I was pleasantly surprised from the moment we were sat at the table.  We had a great view of the Coppola building across the street and and the waitress or hostess was VERY polite(not even by Chinese standards!).  She took the time to explain to us the preparation style since I told her we just returned from China.  She told us the chef prepares in some "old traditional" styles with dry seasoning, not as much sauce.  A great departure from what we are used to.  Not only was the food excellent but the tea was the best Ive had since returning from China.
author: GourMand X.

description:
That is too funny regarding "House of Same Sauce". So, so true! 

======================
Long lines? Check.

Tons of tourists? Check.

Rude staff on top of everything else? Of course. 

So that brings me to, why oh why is this place so popular and in every guide book?! I absolutely don't think it is that great. The food is fine, nothing more, nothing less. 

If I want the same food, I'll go next door to Chef Jia's. Same type of food, probably a bit better food and not any where NEAR as overpriced as House of Nanking. Why locals still end up here, I haven't a clue. There are much better places out there --especially for the price.
author: Anita B.

description:
WORST SERVICE EVER- I live in North Beach and wanted to give a visitor a taste of Nanking and highlight what I had hoped would be a great experience.  BUT as usual they were rude, rushed us and would not stop to take care of our requests.  They threw food at us even though there was no room on the table, and were extremely reluctant to send it in waves so we could enjoy the dishes.  The answer we got was that they were too busy to care and brought our food back cold when asked to hold off.  The food was good but the terrible service outweighed the quality of the food.

I understand the need to make money, and the pressure on the waitstaff to turn over customers by management, but when you do not take the time to give the customer the time to enjoy, they don't come back.

Chef Jia's next door is just as good, if not BETTER, and they do not treat you like cattle. AND they have very reasonable prices.  As a local I recommend that you do not eat at Nanking until they listen to the customer.  Disappointed in North Beach.......
author: Florence l.

description: This place is really small but is very popular, we had to wait about 10 minutes in line until a table is free.the entrees were delicious, and packed with flavor. they use a lot of seasonings. it's not your typical Chinese food but rather something you'll pay for in a really fancy restaurant. it was rather pricey. it was hard to communicate with the servers. the guy taking our order was confusing and gave us a meal we didn't really order but was just asking a question about . they gave us the meals first and halfway down the meal, they finally decided to give us the rice we ordered. Apparently famous people go there too. the food is really good but i don't think i'll go back there again. we ended up buying some to go at a cheaper chinese restaurant down the road to take back to the hotel because our tounge was satisfied but not our stomachs.
author: Jill O.

description:
I'm just wasting my time writing this - everybody already knows that House of Nanking is the best, most unique Chinese place in San Francisco. Yeah, it's a hole in the wall, but you cannot get the dishes that they serve in any other authentic Chinese place (PF Chang does not count as authentic in my book - they just copied some of Peter's dishes).

The atmosphere is "small and cramped" so get there early and expect to wait in line most nights. If you plan on taking a group get there early or wear comfortable shoes because you *will* wait.

The one caveat is that you should stay away near closing time because more than once the kitchen crew has rushed my meal out to me and it was not perfect. They usually nail it the rest of the time. I've seen the recent bad reviews, and I hope that those are exceptions. I never had a bad meal in fifteen years.

If you see the owner, Peter (you can recognize him from his pictures on the walls), say thank you for years of exquisite cuisine. And if there's a problem, you should tell him because no way does he want the reputation tarnished.
author: Gregory M.

description:
The dining experience is just really different.  Maybe if I were forewarned on what to expect, things would have gone better.  

First off, it took us about 20 mins to get water.  Then we ordered appetizers, and the waiter looked at us and told us we did not want the eggplant, and he would bring us something better.  About 4 seconds later they came out with a plate of greenbeans or something.  The question I have is did they run out of the eggplant or are they just so environmentally friendly that they did not want to waste the order of greenbeans that were mistakenly made?  Then it came time to order, where he just told us he would bring us food after asking for dietary restrictions and then collected the menus.  Another question is why even have menus?  This is also the first Asian restaurant I have been to where they give you forks and you have to ask for chopsticks.
author: Jason P.

description:
This is not Chinese food.  For being inauthentic chinese, it's pretty good.  
Do they even use sweet potatoes in chinese cooking?  

Remarkably weird, everything tastes the same here... so probably best to come once every couple of years.  I think the space used to be half the size sometime in the early 90's, & always had the most ridiculous lines & was popular amongst tourists.  Definitely not worth standing in line for.   For an impromtu snack, yes.  Long line, skip.  Crazy tourists!
author: L. K.

description: Judging from all the gringos in line outside, you would think that this is an inauthentic trap. Not so. It's good.
author: Guillermo K.

description: The fish soup and sesame chicken is SUPER good. They put something crispy on top of the soup that really brought out the flavor and texture. This place is super busy. You'll be sitting very close to your neighbors bc the seats are right next to each other- very cozy. 4 star bc customer service can be better.
author: Princess N.

description: What a terrible experience!!! After looking forward to a night out of good food we were extremely disappointed.  After we were seated we were told to share one menu.  We asked for straws for our waters and they were rudely thrown at us as if we were a bother.  The shrimp appetizer was less than desirable and so was the calamari.  Our main dish , chow mein, was extremely spicy.  This place is extremely overrated.  The service is horrific.  After being recommended to eat here I will tell everyone I know to go elsewhere as we actually saw people walking out on disgust at their experience!!!!
author: Belinda V.

description:
thanks you fellow yelpers!!!


i was cruising by san francisco, with the hunger of a beast.

stopped in NANKING and was not dissapointed.   Sesame chicken with sweet potatoes on the side. delicious.

Hot soups, delicious
author: Jairo B.

description:
I've been eating here since I was a little girl and would daydream that the Coppola office building across the street was my apartment.  

The food is consistently good.  Saying I love this place is hard for me 'cause of all the haters who call me a tourist.  But I love it.  I love it, love it, love it.
author: Mz M.

description:
I had some great food here when I ate meat and now that I have cut that part of my life out I guess I can still find something good here.
Too many tourists, not enough dancing girls
author: Kim S.

description:
This is the best Chinese food that I've ever had without contest.

Their is always a line out the door, but the place is run so efficiently that it moves fast and you get served fast. The owner comes around and takes orders most nights. Ask him to order for the table (specify vegetarian/non-vegetarian) and he'll bring you a diverse selection of the most delicious food ever. It actually seems like an entirely different cuisine from the fried meat-centric food I'm normally served at Chinese restaurants.

I've ordered all vegetarian every time I've been here and I couldn't recommend it enough.
author: Matthew G.

description:
It's American Chinese food. Good flavors. There's a tasty scallop dish, but dont recall what it's called. Im a local, non-asian, it is a good place to take "out-of-towners".

Rude service? Have you been to Chinatown before? Seemed the norm. Plus isnt that part of the "charm'? Along with being crowded and loud.

Anyone recall Sam Woo's? Legendary rude service. Abusive even really. It's North Beach/Chinatown...we call that character.

If you compare it to the many truly awful Chinese food spots in this town, this place is really good. If you hold it against the best Chinese food in town, it's better than average.

Plus many non-asian's like that at HoN, the staff will gladly "order" for you. Have fun!
author: Matthew C.

description:
old trick: msg
new trick: aspartame?

that fake sweetness non-diet coke drinkers might experience as a shot of mouthwash to the jaw started with the zero dimensional tea and played like a one note banjo through our next four dishes.

no need to get into the lack of cantonese authenticity. good food is good food regardless of genre. but, sadly, this was not a good meal. and, sadly, this place was recommended by a fellow foodie with impeccable taste, so i must assume that something essential has changed in the Nanking kitchen.
author: Samuel B.

description: I had not been here for about 10 years, prior to the remodel.  Eating here last week was like eating at a completely different restaurant.  It was just simply disappointing.  We found the food to be fried and nothing special.  I miss the days when the food was heavy w/ garlic and simply fabluous.  I'm giving it two stars for the price and overall atmosphere.
author: Elaine G.

description: I have been wanting to go for years, and finally made it for lunch!!!  It was everything I hoped for and more...  Crunchy Rice soup and Sesame Chicken were both out of this world!!  I already cannot wait to go back!
author: Joe S.

description: If you are in China Town, go here! We came here on a recommendation from a friend and ordered/shared a variety of dishes. I wish I could remember what they were, but it was all delish! The servers kind of expect you to know what you want when you walk in, so if you are a tourist like myself, you must decide fast! It was a super fun experience and I'm glad we tried it out. I'll definitely be back!
author: Amelia O.

description:
Let me make it clear: Chinese food is not on my favorite foods list, although every other type of cuisine is.

House of Nanking has the best Chinese food I've ever eaten!!!  I was skeptical of the hype but went along with friends for dinner there because I was outvoted.

I've eaten Chinese in a lot of different cities, including Shanghai and Hong Kong.  This place has amazing food.

The service is crummy, but the food and lines (if you get there at peak time) is worth the sacrifice.  Try it out!
author: Jenny K.

description: I don't know what they put in their calamari entree , but it could in fact be crack because one taste AND I WAS HOOKED. Nice atmosphere although the waiters are a little pushy if you aren't ready. Their assortments of teas is awesome as well.
author: Lauren V.

description:
House of Nanking is the a manky tourist trap that benefits from the collusion between various tour companies and guide books proclaiming it to be the "best chinese food in Chinatown."

What awaits you instead is some of the worst food brought to you by its racist waitstaff.

The cuts of meat are poor across the board, with particular attention paid to its tendenous dark meat selection in its chicken entrees. Really? Dark meat? I'm usually okay with that but it would help if I wasn't spitting out gristle with every bite. The beef doesn't fare much better either.

At first I thought the waitstaff was making fun of my selection of your typical American-Chinese fried dishes -- scallion pancakes and their sesame chicken -- despite those items being highly promoted as its "signature" dishes, but the server's hostility vanished whenever he would wait on a table with a Chinese patron.

So okay, lousy food with a racist judgmental waitstaff.

Why are you considering going here?
author: Thomas D.

description:
Yes, it does live up to the hype.  The plates are oversized and you get tons of food.  Not sure what restaurant those complainers went to, maybe they went to the vietnamese place next door.

Onion cakes are to die for, and your best bet is to tell the owner what type of meat (or non meat) you want -- chicken, beef, tofu, veggie - and let him select the dish for you, as he knows what is best that day, which veggies are freshest, etc.

Forget about fortune cookies -- this is a Chinese restaurant with a westernized feel.  You can get tea and chopsticks if you ask for them, but don't be insulted when you're given a fork - everyone gets one.

While it can seem a bit jarring to first timers, just relax and go with it and you won't be disappointed!
author: H.A. ..

description:
I was so disturbed by the reviews I read about this place.  I drove up to San Francisco this past weekend and got to try this restaurant.  I left the sunny L.A. weather, stood in a long line in freezing, foggy, windy conditions, to go inside and be seated on chairs that did indeed resemble lawn chairs.  We were practically sharing a table with a couple we had never met before, the manager did order for us, and still I LOVED THE FOOD! and I had a great time.
I have to admit the three of us who went thought it weird and were somewhat speechless when the manager asked if it was our first time there and then asked for the menus back.  He said, "I'll take care of you, I'm chef," but he did ask what type of dishes we wanted.  Being the picky eater that I am, I managed to blurt out, "just no seafood or pork please." He repeated it, "no seafood or pork, ok, I'll take care of you."  The server came back with Sesame Chicken, Crispy Beef, and what I'm guessing was the vegetable chowmein.  The food was absolutely the best "chinese" food I've ever had.  I don't know how authentic it is, but I really don't care.  It was good, it was different, I had no complaints, and if I make that trip again I will definitely stand in line one more time.
author: Monica G.

description:
I give it four stars because my food was great and I'll go back on my next visit to San Francisco. I heard about it from locals who said, "Just go to where you see the line." Walking through Chinatown, I was suspicious of the places that had someone on the street begging you to come into a particular restaurant. If you're good, you don't need to beg for business.

LIke you read in other reviews, the service is awful--no genteel Chinese Mr. and Mrs. welcoming you into their fold. After waiting 30 minutes, I was seated at a nice table when suddenly I was evicted and told to sit next to four guys who had been ahead of me in line. I could tell they really didn't want to make friends, even for an hour, but when I asked the girl, "Do I really have to move?" I was told, "YES." So I had this awkward situation of sitting with four guys in town for the same event as I but trying to pretend like I was at a single table.

Back to the food. If you are looking for "something for everyone" like you see in every other Chinese place, forget it. What I had was fantastic. I started with the pork egg roll. Believe me, after eating a roll packed with nothing but shredded pork (tasted barbecued), I'll never go back to the standard number filled with cabbage and mysterious ground meat.

Then I had the moo shoo with shrimp. The shrimp were pan fried in a coating with ginger; I was trying to stay away from fried food but this was too good and not at all "fried-like."  I didn't really waste time on rolling into the Chinese pancakes because the shrimp and zucchini, which comprised most of the vegetables, were so good.

I did hear another table complain about the salt. My dish didn't have any MSG and was not overly salty or I might be writing a different review. The service? They kept forgetting my drink.

But I can't wait to go back and experience the great food and surly service.
author: John Divine M.

description: I have been coming to the House of Nanking since Peter opened the place decades ago.  It was at its best at the beginning when Peter was back behind the wok working magic.  Over the years, he has expanded and brought in other cooks.  The food has gone from "out of this world" to just pretty good.  Service and cleanliness were never strong points.  Cleanliness has improved, but the service is more surly than ever.  Peter, you used to know me by name - this last visit, you had other customers hovering over us to take our seats before we had completed our meal, telling them to take our seats when we left, and there were many other tables available.  It's not like we were trying to drag out our visit, quite the contrary.  Sorry to see how jaded you have become as your place has become more and more about the money versus the customer.
author: Martin L.

description:
Best Chinese food in San Francisco!  The menu is unique and I have never had a bad dish here.
The service is down right rude.  However this is part of the charm.  If the owner doesn't like what you ordered, he will bring you what he thinks you should have!  Service is quick and brusk.  They want to turn tables here.  No time to linger.  Eat and Run!
It's a bit dirty and very small - but darn it - the food here is like no place else in San Francisco.  THE BEST!
author: James S.

description: A taxi driver's tip took us here.  We usually go whenever we visit SFO.  It is worth a stop b/c of the awards they have won and there are plenty of locals.  It is cramp and the staff can be a little rude   My next visit I'll have to ask for "dinner".
author: Hugh H.

description:
This is probably the best Chinese food in the city, but don't expect good service. One time, after my boyfriend and I both ordered the same noodle dish, one with chicken, one with tofu, our waiter looked at us like we were crazy and said, "Bad order!" and shook his head. I think he was dissapointed we didnt order everything on the menu and share.(?)
At any rate, there will probabaly be  a long line outside, the tables are crunched together and the service is poor. But the food is worth it. get take out!
author: StephanieLauren B.

description: As most know you go for the food not the service.  Everything on the table was delicious.  I asked if they take credit card and the guy snaps back " You got cash??".  Since I know how asian restaurants can be it didn't bother me but I can see how some other folks could take him as being a pushy, rude douche.  Great food, a must if your in the city.
author: Neil C.

description: Wow shrimp packets are incredible, I am so happy I returned! You have to love this room it still makes you feel at home. The service is laid back and friendly and the food is great as usual. I always try to make it over here when I am in town.
author: Brian M.

description: It is funny how there is a variety of different opinions about this place...from I love it to "this isn't authentic chinese...".  Well, to those who say "I love it"....I love it too!  For those who say "its not authentic", a word of advice...check your history and educate yourself in the Nanking style of chinese food.  An easier way is to walk in, be very cordial to the owner with some small talk and ask him to hook you up with something tasty for the amount of people in your party and watch out!  This is what we do and he always comes through!!  The only thing we order ourselves is the Grasshopper Mojito which is awesome!
author: Dan Z.

description:
Obviously I'm delusional because I checked this place out thinking - ok so its supposed to be the best Chinese food ever! I was seriously disappointed.

The food is not good and its not even decent - my old roommate was Chinese and made legit Chinese food all the time so I know what real Chinese food is. I even know what good Americanized Chinese food and this was neither.

It was bland and boring and there weren't even that many choices. The line outside is full of tourists and makes you THINK that it's worth the wait....so not true.

Talk about hype and not delivering - try another place - not worth it.
author: Brittney E.

description: I visited House of Nanking some year ago and loved the food there. On my very first visit - the owner himself waited on us and brought us some dishes as per his recommendation! it was delicious!  After that I used to visit with my out of town friends and they all loved it. Fast forward to about a couple weeks ago... I had not visited this place in a while and hence convinced a friend to visit with me for lunch. Boy... I must say I was extremely disappointed!! Everything from the service to the food was sub-par!!! To begin with... the waiter was very rude and behaved like he did not want us there!! He didn't bring out our drinks for the longest time and came back twice to get our food order because he was not paying attention the first time. We thought that perhaps he was just having a bad day so we just decided to ignore his rude behavior. But the food that came out was a let down as well... We ordered a soup and had to ask for the chili sauce on the side just so that we could get some flavor in the soup. The onion cakes was so-so and the sesame chicken was just very plain...it did not have the same zing in it like it did about 4-5 years ago.. in fact the orange chicken at other fast food places tasted better.. the pork dish was bland and just left a bad taste on the palate. Sorry to say.. but this restaurant just got scribbled off my go-to places!
author: VVN M.

description: Food was pretty tasty, although portions were not huge. Sizzling rice soup was delicious, Scallops were extremely fishy! The mushroom plates were very good. Seating is Packed banquet style tables with random strangers at your table. Made for good conversation at our table, but others... not so much! One last important piece of information. There was not 1 Asian person eating at this restaurant. If the food was really good authentic Chinese cuisine, I think the numbers would have been different! Fun to try once, doubt I will go back given all the amazing restaurants right around the corner!
author: Merlin R.

description: Whatever kind of food this is, it tastes good.
author: Mike F.

description: This place is pretty much what the books say its like.  As far as atmosphere - I kind of felt like I was on a ship.  You just kind of sit down, then they want you to order asap.  Super salty, which was cool with me.  They do have a good variety of food.
author: Charles C.

description: I love a few of the dishes we've had here over the years, but I also think the reality doesn't live up to the hype. The prices are high and the portions are smaller than most places. The vegetables and fish are very fresh and the flavors are often delicious. However, a big deal is made of the owner "creating" dishes that he thinks are the best. One dish was outstanding but the other, a chicken salad, had dry pieces of chicken along with the fresh delicious vegetables. I noticed that the same dishes we had at lunch were served at dinner, when we returned for more of my favorites. Hopefully the chicken was better prepared later in the day.
author: Susan G.

description: Although the service was almost hilariously rude (almost as though it were rehearsed), it was quick and the food was delicious! We ordered twice as much food as needed, but still managed to finish it all (minus the house noodles- which surprisingly lacked flavor). I'll definitely be returning!
author: Amanda I.

description:
I'm personally surprised by all the bad to middling reviews of this place.  I love it here.  Admittedly, the staff isn't very friendly, but the food is very good.  Is it authentic?  I doubt it, but that seems to be missing the point - it is good and in my opinion fairly unique for a Chinese restaurant.  

For the true House of Nanking experience just let the waiter know if you need any vegetarian dishes, and let them work everything else out.  I personally love the sesame chicken with the sweet potato slices, and most tables are usually provided one plate of this dish.  Fresh vegetables, generous portions, and a unique atmosphere for such a hole in the wall type locale.  One of my personal favorite Chinese restaurants in the city (or anywhere for that matter).

As to the service: it can be pretty bad if you aren't willing to let them select your entrees.  They once actually refused to serve my brother the dish he wanted to order (fried rice only).  On another occasion the waiter walked away as if we offended him when we told him we wanted to order our own dishes.  In other words, go there planning on accepting the whole House of Nanking experience - and you'll probably enjoy yourself.  Otherwise, find another Chinese restaurant to dine at.
author: Matthew H.

description:
Does it need another review? No, not really, but here it is! 

Back in the day, when I was eight, a kind man took my family here for some of the best Chinese food of my life. The dumplings were outrageous, each dish kindly and thoughtfully prepared. For years and years no one could remember the name. Then one day, when searching the internet tirelessly, it appeared, as if from a distant dream land. 

And so the mystery spot of legendary food had a name, and it was Nanking, and for a couple of years after this finding, it was great. Sure the line was always present, and sure, the owner/executive chef is weird and kind of mean, and sure, they rush you through your food so they can sit the next patron down, but the food was SO GOOD. 

Then, one day, the house changed. They added new dishes, changed up aspects of their older ones, and it was good. But then we came back, and ordered different dishes, but they came out as the exact same ones we had ordered the last time we were there. We thought there was a mistake, but no, the waiter insisted, these were the correct dishes. 

Now I don't know about you, but if I want a particular dish, I'll ask for it. I don't need every scallop dish on the menu to be the exact same one, but for some reason, it was. And I haven't been back since. I love you House of Nanking, but like so many others, you changed.
author: Shannon F.

description:
We picked a good day to come here for lunch.  On a cold, rainy and windy day, not many people dared to leave their heated Financial District offices towards the House of Nanking.  The rope barrier outside suggested that Yelpers weren't lying about long lines at this place, but it was completely empty today.

I can't say agree with the name of the restaurant.  I think calling it the House of Nanking implies that they serve Chinese food, given that Nanking is, indeed, in China.  I think a name such as House of Newark, NJ or House of Naperville, IL might be more indicative of their food.

Sure, they have the same rude service and the same folding brown tables as you would find at similar hole-in-the-wall Chinese establishments.  What you won't find is authentic Chinese recipes, Chinese flavors and spices or chopsticks.

Don't get me wrong, the food is quite tasty, hence the 3-star rating.  Crackling beef, mushroom caps stuffed with pork, fried pot stickers and hot and sour chowder tasted great.  However, it's Chinese food Americanized for your protection.  If that's what you're looking for, bon appetit!  

For those of us living in San Francisco, it shouldn't be difficult to find a better Chinese restaurant.  I might come back, but I am NOT waiting in line!
author: Yan G.

description:
Good food, plenty of it, but too pricy, and while I don't mind waiting in line I don't like it we have a group of 4, there is a group of 11 behind us, and they get in first but are split up amongst tables - why do four of them get that table that we were in line first for?  Makes no sense.  

Certainly one of those places people hear they should go to when in the City.  We only went cause an out-of-town friend really wanted to.  I don't regret going once, but I won't be back...
author: Patrick W.

description:
We all know the Law of Chinese Restaurants: The quality of food at a Chinese restaurant is directly proportional to the number of Chinese people eating there.Tellingly, House of Nanking had no Chinese guests when I arrived.

Not to say that it was empty. It was packed.  I arrived 8-ish, and they had no tables for my party of two. So, they just seated us at a table for six, where a group of four was already sitting.  'Intimate' would be a euphemism.

The food is greasy.  I admit it tasted alright, but it sat heavy in my stomach yet left me unsatisfied and thirsty. The next day I felt what I can only describe as a greasy-food-hangover; I had to subsist on vegetables and gatorade to get myself feeling alright again.
author: K. B.

description: I heard great things about this place for many years so I finally tried it. The food was okay but nothing to write home about. I went for lunch and I was annoyed at the paper menus covered in soy sauce and the amount of flies buzzing around our table inside the restaurant. Maybe I went  on a lull after they were slammed with customers. Maybe I'll give them another try on my next visit to SF.
author: Steven S.

description:
This small restuarant gets packed quick.  There are often lines in front of it that extends towards other buildings.

I first noticed this place when I saw the damn line and then decided, I have to try this place right now.

Everything is quick and run smoothly.  Inside is not so roomy and you may sit next to strangers at the same table.

The male waiter (which is the owner - I believe) will order for you if you tell him what you like, which makes everything quicker and easier for the customer. 

Dumplings are a good appetizer - they're fried.  

The fish dish I ordered with green beans, on top of fried noodles -- was okay.  The taste was too salty.  I am sure other dishes are better, but that was not my greatest experience of the fish.  

For non-Asians that don't dine Chinese often, will probably think their food is GREAT and THE BEST (remember, I said 'probably').  But coming from an Asian, more specifically a Chinese, the food I tried, could have had a little less seasoning.  

They give you big portions, worth the money.  If I am able to try House of Nanking in the future, I will give them more stars.  I can only comment on the dumplings and fish.

[stars and comments are subject to change with each visit (^_^) ]
author: Alice C.

description:
Honestly I'm shocked how many people don't like this place.  Close to 400 reviews and seems to have a one-star vote for every five-star vote.  Love it or hate it and I definitely love it.

The last time I went there was about two years ago, but I still remember it as my favorite meal I've ever had.  You walk in, the owner/chef guy asks what types of food you're into, how spicy you like your food, if pork, beef, chicken, seafood is okay or if you're vegetarian.  Then he brings back the best multi-course meal I've ever had.  Can't even remember what I got, but it was different than anything else I've ever had.  The guy brought out maybe 8 or so courses, each one just as tasty as the next.  

If it was a little cheaper I'd go here every time I went up to San Francisco.  I think the price was like $20 a person including a beer or two.
author: Bryan R.

description:
The only reason this place doesn't get 5 stars is because of the service, with the waitresses constantly yelling at you and trying to get you out. But it's part of the experience.

Hands down the best Sesame Chicken I have ever had. The sauce is incredible, huge portions, and the sweet potato is an added bonus. I also love the country rice soup with chicken, and I add a little chili sauce to it for a kick. Definitely worth checking out, by far the best Chinese restaurant I have ever been to.
author: D S.

description: Even with the mediocre service this place was still fantastic. Everything we had (soup, vegetarian dumpling, mongolian beef, and sesame chicken) were great. Highly recommended. Server ordered for us and delivered on providing a great meal.
author: Keith K.

description:
The first time I went to House of Nanking was a surprisingly unbusy Sunday during the early afternoon, which gave me an entirely wrong impression of the amount of people usually cramming this small, storefront eatery.  Otherwise, the restaurant is insanely busy and I have often seen doubled-up lines on the sidewalk in front.  After I attempted to eat there on a Friday night with visiting relatives I learned to attempt it only during certain times where I can count on little to no wait time.

Every dish I've had at this restaurant, let me say, has been delicious.  I am not a conoisseur of Chinese food, but I've been pleasantly surprised each time by the quality of ingredients and the - at least to me - novelty of presentations and combinations.  My favorite dish that I've gotten there was a dish of battered, deep-fried shrimp paired with yams in a sweet sauce.

The main problem with the restaurant is that it is overpriced, probably resulting from its apparent popularity.  Based on this, I have decided that I won't go back unless someone else is paying.
author: Stephen S.

description:
Every time we drive down Kearney we see a line in front of Nanking, so we gotta this place. We come by for lunch, a lttle before noon and young women are cleaning the sidewalk and we ask "Are you open?" "No." We check the sign and it indicates they open at Noon. I think this is what they mean when they day "It's hard to get good help these days."

Anyhow, we alk aorund the block, and its worth the wait. My friend gets the idea she is a vegetarian for the day and the owners says he'll order for both of us. The first dish is a tofu and I'm guessing Daikon sprout affair, the kind of thing that would normally running for the BBQ shack, but damn its tasty! This kind of food, and I  COULD be a vegetarian.

The Nanking sesame chicken was more usual fare, but prepared well and also satisfying.  All the food at the nerxt table looked good, and we wished we had more people with us, so we could try more dishes.

Atmospherically, ain't nothin' special, but prices are pretty good, and the owner is cordial. We'll definitely be back.
author: Bruce K.

description:
GREAT Chinese food.  It's worth the wait in the velvet-roped lines outside.  

Everytime I have been there, I got the old guy serving us.  I always let him order for us and it always comes out tasting GREAT.  Kinda oily, kinda full of MSG, but tastes good.  Last time I was there, I got a sore throat from the oiliness.  Oh well.

Good prices, but they rack up easily cuz we always order so much.  LOL.  

Bottled Tsingtao only :(
author: Dong T.

description:
Whether it is "authentic" Chinese food or not, the food their is UNDENIABLY delicious and well made.

The lines may be long outside, the service may not be top notch, and it is certainly not a white-table-cloth spot. But there is a reason this place has lasted the test of time and has grown, expanded in size, remodeled and continues to bring swarms of people to it's tiled front doors!

If it's your FIRST TIME and you are fortunate enough to have the owner, Peter, himself, (and you'll recognize him since his awards and photos are posted all over the place) come up to your table and take your order... don't make the mistake of ordering on your own. TELL HIM what kind of meat, chicken, fish, pork, etc you want and he will have his kitchen make you the BEST DAMN dish with your ingredients that you will have ever had in a Chinese restaurant. Guaranteed!
author: John Eric S.

description:
This place is pretty amazing - on so many levels. It definitely has hole-in-the-wall dive down to an art, but you know you are in the right place because if you go down during dinner time on a weekend all the other restaurants on the block will be empty but there will be a huge line out the door. 

You also probably don't want to go there if you have really specific tastes. Because if you go with more than one other person, or if you hesitate at any point, the staff is ordering for you.  You *may* get to choose chicken, pork, or beef, but that's about it. That being said, if you're willing to be a little adventurous, the food will blow your mind. I highly recommend the sesame chicken.
author: Ben R.

description:
I just walked by this place and there is a long line of people waiting to get inside. C'MON PEOPLE! YOU ARE IN CHINATOWN IN ONE OF THE BEST FOODIE CITIES IN THE WORLD! WHY ARE YOU STANDING IN LINE TO EAT CHINESE FOOD? 

I first ate at House on Nanking in 1997. Food was OK and we went back the next day (one coworker from Dallas LOVED the place). For 4 people, we ordered 3 new entrees and one that we really liked from the day before. The food came out gross and greasy! And the 'same' entree was not the same as the day before. Different sauce, different veggies, but at least same chicken. 

Fast forward to 2003, decided to try it again. What a mistake. Place is a dump with a high 'ceiling' window broken and so the cold air came in. When we asked for water with our meals, the waitress begrudgingly brought out two glasses (in chipped plastic glasses) of water. We had to ask for two more since there were 4 of us. She also did not bring ice despite our request for ice water. The food, from what I remember, was OK but nothing spectacular. It was the service that really turned me off and I vowed never to go back. 

Well, I'm back in SF and I must say, my decision to never go back to HON was a good one. I've tried many more Chinese restaurants in the area, none with a wait, all with great food. I went to 'Fang,' sister restaurant to HON, close to the Convention Center . That was a disappointing meal also. 

So, to all the people standing in line to eat at House of Nanking, GET A LIFE! There are lots of great Chinese restaurants in San Francisco's Chinatown. Try the one next door. You won't be disappointed AND you'll be seated immediately.
author: Maria A.

description: Prettty good.....a definite stop by when I'm in town!! Good...no matter what you order....just be prepared to wait and don't be too picky.
author: Lisa F.

description:
Delicious. Delicious. Delicious.

On your first trip to House of Nanking, the owner (a no-frills kind of lady), will ask you: "Fish, chicken, beef, pork or veggie?" You choose and then she picks the specific dish for you. Moments later, three gorgeous dishes came out, one by one, that she had chosen for us. And they were all lick-the-plate delicious.

This isn't a traditional Chinese restaurant but you get the fast paced service with modern Chinese food. I can't wait to go back to House of Nanking for another surprising experience.
author: Sasha R.

description: Best Chinese food ever! The fried rice was so fresh and amazing. What ever spices they used made it so much better than any other I'd had. I wish I could come close to recreating the rice at home. The spicy black bean sauce made me incredibly happy. What a delight this place was. Busy, busy, busy inside. Shared tables packed together but amazingly the service was great. If you want a truly authentic and fresh Asian dinning experience this place is a must try... Oh and I left with my bill being the lowest one out of all my San Fran restaurants... Including the hotel!!
author: Kristi P.

description: House of Nanking has the best calamari! It's just so perfect. I always order it whenever I eat here.
author: Ria C.

description: there is very little customer service at this place...but the food is dynamite. love the ambiance and will have to say its one of the best chinese restaurants ive ever been to. but definately poor customer service...u cant ask for hot sauce or anything additional, without the server smirking at you or flat out ignoring you.. but overall its still my favorite :) they just have zero american values as far as customer satisfaction goes...
author: Tamana H.

description:
House of Nanking is perennial favorite amoung white people in the City and I can see why.....their food is mostly fried and have their famous "Nanking" sauce....it is comfort food and even I every so often (rare as it may be) have a taste for their food.....great for after a evening of drinking in North Beach....despite their expansion into another room about 4 years ago...it still remains a "hole in the wall"

Pos: Central Chinatown location, addicitive fried saucy food

Negs: this isn't really Chinese food, service is low (but hey this is a Chinese restaurants), tables are small and room is cramped (but hey this is a Chinese restaurant), service slightly ruder than your standard Chinese restaurant...
author: Laurence H.

description:
How cool is a place where you go in, don't order and they just start bringing you the best food you've ever had. That and the beers are $3! Fast and cheap!
They made it twice as big as it originally was so the line hasn't been too bad (I hear that it used to be).
If you haven't been, you have to check it out.
author: Scott K.

description:
I can't say enough good things about this place.  It's an eclectic, little restaurant that serves chinese-american food.  Every thing on their menu is delicious!

I HIGHLY suggest going with a group.  Your experience will still be good but trust me.  Your experience will be even better with a group.  I will bring a group of friends here and the owner will often order for you according to whether you like spicy food and/or if you would like seafood.  Every group I have taken has been happy and very full at the end of the meal.  The service is also very good.  Dishes start hitting the table within 10 minutes of ordering!

It's a little cramped and noisy but well worth it.  They have remodeled since my first visit but the prices and service have not changed.  

Zagat, SF Weekly, and numerous other awards line every wall of the place.  In 2007, I gave it a rave review and I'm still very happy with their food and service having visited recently.
author: Augie S.

description:
We had to wait on the sidewalk for 20 minutes, but I was pleasantly surprised: the pot stickers were good, the beef mu shu was good and the sesame chicken was kind of OK too. We had a couple of tsing tao beers as well and the bill was really light. 

OK, the place is cramped and the service is rough, but we just wanted kinda Chinese food (note the usage of "kinda") and we were happy there.
author: Lili G.

description:
Nanking ain't what it used to be. But it's not far from it. It's still good. This is authentic Chinese with some creativity thrown in. Not "fusion" but some creativity. The pork stuffed mushrooms for instance are fun. Not what they used to be though. It just used to be better - quality, size, price, bad service. Yes, the service used to be worse, which is better! They've lost their umpf. They used to be even pushier. You would order something and they would deny you and bring their suggestion to the table instead. This was classic.

Now they're bigger. They've changed the floorplan, moved the kitchen, lost some soul, raised their prices, withheld a little love. But it's still good because even though it lacks a little now, they had a lot of leeway. I guess this is restaurant evolution. The owner is probably getting a little tired. It's always slammed!

Anyhow, The mushu beef was a little dry. The shrimp with cashews was delish. We had pork with chayote squash. The chayote was good and so was the entire dish. Also suggested are the snowpea sprouts, served raw but warm. 

All in all, it's close to a 4-star rating as it stands... could be 3.5...
author: Aa-Ron L.

description:
Back when I myself was but a wee little tourist, riding the cable cars with overwhelming glee and prancing through the fisherman's wharf like Mary Tyler Moore, someone said to me "You have to try Nan King, it's so amazing"

Well, Ok, if you insist. So off I went, hubs in tow, to try this AMAZING Chinese restaurant. hmmmm. Not impressed, even with my happy with the world tourist goggles on. I saw right through this place.  The calamari was pretty decent. But we were rushed,  the table was sticky, the staff was rude, and the food was the definition of average. and we paid double what any other restaurant in Chinatown would charge for the same meal.  

I don't know who the heck they paid off to get the designation of "Best Chinese Food in Chinatown"  But there is a reason this place is only packed with midwesterners wearing fanny packs.
author: Melissa J.

description:
My $12.95 calamari entree and the Chinese chowder both easily warrant five stars. The squid was neither breaded (as in a photo) nor cut into ubiquitous ringlets. It was sashimi-like slabs lightly sauteed in brown sauce, along with tiny Chinese beans and leaf spinach.  Every bite was a pleasure. 

The chowder featured breaded chicken, which sounds soggy and awful, but was actually crunchy and delicious.  The soup base was thinned (and enhanced ) with sliced cucumber, lemon and god knows what else....just a lovely mix of flavors and textures. 

By western sit down standards, service is startlingly abrupt and potentially polarizing.  No water. Dishes and flatware arrive in a pile.  They really do scrunch you together with strangers, and sprint away immediately after sliding undescribed platters across your table.  I mostly enjoyed the quirky intensity and dont sense it's especially hostile or antagonistic, but it's also not the level of attention I normally associate with a four or five star joint.  

Just as we left the premesis, a hungry tourist in the outside line flippantly observed that "everyone leaving this place is a Jew." Well, I am not a Jew, my wife is not a Jew and my son is not a Jew - but I take his meaning....and Oy Vey, these chinamen can cook!!
author: Matt S.

description:
The food is delicious! The sesame chicken and green beans are a must. The wonton soup, fried pot stickers and chow mein were also all very tasty.  The blossoming flower tea is  very cool
Yes, there is always a line outside the door but in my opinion, the food is worth the wait. My party of three did have to share a table with another family, but i didn't find it uncomfortable as the other family was friendly. Our food arrived surprisingly fast and i thought the service was good. The experience did feel somewhat rushed and unpersonal but i guess thats what you get when the restaurant is serving so many people at one time. 
I actually found the food reasonably priced and we paid with a credit card.
So if you want some tasty chinese in San Francisco, i recommend this place.
author: Tim C.

description:
This restaurant is really good at squeezing money from their customers. But they can do it only once as no one will go back here. The wait staff was bad. They initially showed us a seat shared with another guest, while there was another table with nobody sitting? I can't understand this.

Plus they push stuff on you by saying "I will take care of you". I went here on a sunday night, which is slow so the waiter pushed his specials on us ( read left-overs expected to be sold on busy fridays and saturdays). I didn't want onion cakes but got a plate of it. And it came out so fast ( within 5 minutes of ordering). I seriously think this "special" was ready even before we were there and was just reheated and served after being pushed on us. He told us he will "give" us good vegetarian food but why do you charge us if you give us that especially since we had ordered 2 dishes for two of us. We managed to eat only half the food we were served. The food was ok but the restaurant was dirty and I've said enough about the service. 

Seriously avoid this place. I don't think I will go here again. I can't believe restaurant owner is so short sighted even in the age of yelp. This is probably a tourist trap.
author: saurabh S.

description: Good food. Had the Scallops Calamari and Sesame Chicken. All the food was fantastic. Service on the other hand... Leaves plenty to be desired Waitress came over 2 minutes after sitting and asked if we knew what we wanted. Then pointed at menu and said some items were good. Food came out as cooked. That is fine. But all was done over 10 minute period. One dish was done before another came out. Then while still eating the check was thrown down. Not even half finished with the third dish that was delivered. For the first time in forever I left a 10% tip because the service was so poor. Food is a 4.5 Service is a ZERO. Hence the 2 star rating.
author: Eric H.

description:
We went here based on the reputation, and recommendations from friends.  Ordered sizzling rice soup, salt/pepper shrimp with mushrooms,  a calamari dish with greens, and green beans.  

The place is very small, but we were seated immediately when we went for lunch.  Service is kind of surly, but mainly because they are moving very quickly.  Not the kind of place to just go and linger comfortably.  The food came out very quick and overall was pretty good.  The sizzling rice soup was unlike any I have ever had, as it was almost creamy and seemed like it had coconut milk.  It was spicy and flavorful, and we enjoyed it throughly.  The calamari was good, although I found it a little lacking in flavor.  The green beans were firm and crisp and tasty, so we enjoyed those.  The shrimp with mushrooms was very good, although it was very salty.  We enjoy salt, so we did not mind, but it was still almost too salty.  This was the same with the soup, so they seem to use a lot of salt here.  The dishes are different from your "standard" Chinese restaurant fare, where you get many of the same dishes in the same way.  Nanking definitely seems to be more of a creative restaurant in their cuisine, as opposed to a regular run of the mill Chinese food joint, where the food is more or less recognizable and similar.  Overall, we enjoyed it a lot, but would still give the nod to Hunan Home as our favorite.
author: A. L.

description:
It was a great place to eat real tasty food, but the wait staff is a little weak.  

My gf and I had dinner there one night for the first time, having no clue to the restaurants flow.  We were a little confused by the menu options and how they served food.  Tried to get help from waitress, but no luck.  We ordered a few things not realizing they serve meals home style.  So it threw us off with ordering correctly.

The food was great with great table service.  The food was full of flavor, large portions and leaving you wanting more.  I would definitely go back.

There is usually a long line, but I called 30 minutes before, got a name on a list and then walk past the line right to my table.
author: Christopher R.

description:
A friend showed me this place a few years ago when visiting San Francisco. We went as a group of 4-5. The first thing you will notice is that there is a constant line out the door.  You can't call ahead, so just show up, put your name on the "list" and wait outside. It's worth the wait.

I've now been there 4 times, never ordered off the menu,  and every time the food was amazing. For the best experience, just tell the waiter to "take care of us." That's what I've done every time and I've never been disappointed. They just bring you out dish after dish(usually 1-per person sitting) to your table. Everything they brought was amazing!

It's definitely not for a romantic date or business dinner, but the food makes up for it. For example, you get soda in cans and the tables are very close together. It's always pretty loud too from conversation.

Again, the best chinese place I've been in the country!
author: scott b.

description: Delicious garlicy won ton soup. Great calimari. Sesame chicken and braised pork dish with fried rice were all great. This supposedly is a locals place and often a line out the door waiting for a table.
author: Julie B.

description: I think the experience of dining here is just as fun and enjoyable as the food. My memories of going there about three years ago were tons of fun. My most recent visit we had to get it to go and got there close to closing time so it wasn't as fun of an experience, but the food was still delicious.  My husband doesn't like Chinese food usually, and he loved this place. My favorite memories are standing outside waiting for a table or a partial table to accommodate my party of four.  We sat down squished at this table like sardines in a can. Then we looked at the menu and this adorable old man came over and told us he would order for us.  He asked us our preferences (meat and veggies) and if we didn't like any certain foods.  Then he walked away and returned about 20 minutes later with the most delicious assortment of food!  One of my favorites was the baby bokchoy!  I will be back soon and it wont take me another three years to go back!
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
What I like most about the House of Nanking is fact that I have never ordered off the menu.. It typically goes something like this:

AM: Can I have a Tsingtao?
P: What can I get you?
AM: Something with (insert type of meat)
P: (shaking his head, nodding) yes yes.. I know what you want...

The food comes, I'm hungry, I devour each morsel like I haven't eaten in months and stumble home, stuffed and satisfied...

Each time I dine at the HoN, it's always the same, delish!!
author: Aimee C.

description:
Chinese isn't my favorite but smack my ass and call me Sally...this place is GREAT! Another "soup nazi" isque dining experience. And always get the dumplings!!

Update:
The dumprings are f ing amazing. I got to make up a dish and it was very tasty. this is one my favorite places to eat.
author: Anita C.

description:
This is my like eighth 4-star review in a row, but man, SF food is awesome.

This place rocks. I had spent a very unpleasant Saturday night the week before trying desperately to find a Chinese place that delivered after 11pm (hint: none of them do) and had been craving Chinese ever since. My friend Gabriel, a long term SF resident, took me here the week after. We ordered the onion cake, which you have GOT TO GET - it's fried and sweet and crispy, and is in no way healthy, and probably just increased my risk of heart attack by 15%, but it's so good, who cares. We also had moo shoo chicken, which was fantastic, and then we asked the chef to suggest something and he brought us this amazing all-kinds-of-mushrooms and garlic shrimp concoction.

GREAT stuff and $30 total for two. I would go back any day of the week. I stuffed myself and we had tons of leftovers. I'm not some hick who thinks Panda Express is awesome. I live in NYC and eat in Chinatown a lot and I am picky about my Chinese - my fave chinese place is the Snappy Dragon in Seattle b/c they hand roll the noodles. I grew up in the middle of nowhere and I know what crappy Chinese is like, and this is NOT IT. I am not sure what all these haters are expecting when they order, like, lo mein and fried rice and then bitch about how it's not out of the ordinary. 

Anyone know any Chinese that delivers after 11, though?
author: alice t.

description:
We had a friend in town this weekend who was visiting SF for the first time in four years.  He told us one of his best memories from his last visit was eating Chinese food at this restaurant.  I was horribly hung over from the night before and was eager to try to soak up some of the previous nights alcohol with some Chinese food.

If you are looking for a quiet, upscale restaurant with friendly servers this isn't the place.  But if you are looking for reasonably priced, great food make sure to stop by.  Everything we had was exceptionally good.  The chicken with the Tsing Tao beer sauce was my favorite.  The chicken was all white meat and tender accompanied with zucchini, mushrooms, and a delicious lemon --- beer sauce.  We also had crispy chicken that came with thinly sliced yams and a crisp vegetable I couldn't make out (tasted like a mix between an apple and a cucumber).  The shrimp fried rice was also delicious.  It wasn't too greasy and very flavorful.  Yum!

Oh, and by the end of the meal, my hangover was gone.  I'm looking forward to coming back and trying some of the veggie and seafood options.
author: Zoe H.

description:
San Francisco,

Yes, You have answered New york with your own Soup Nazi.

I have been to this place at least 20 times, twice in last month and the way the Chef/Owner handles your order just amazes me. I have still not found a way to order from the Menu. He insists what you should have.

Anyway, the Food is Fantastic, and worth every single mile drive up north. This is a classic Chinese with San Francisco flavors, amazing preparations.

These days, My order is typically, give me "Fish, chicken. Pork and Beef", and the owner/Chef  "woks" something that has not gone wrong yet!!
author: Jadya C.

description:
I have come full circle a few times with my fondness of H.o.N.K.  I used to really like it, then I couldn't stand it, then back to enjoying it, then loathing it, and now I'm back to appreciating it. 

I must admit, the Nanking sesame chicken with the yams is absolutely one of my favorite dishes there. So good! I have yet to beat this dish at another Chinese spot. 

The service is typically fast. The wait can be lengthy, just depending on time of visit. 

One thing to note, a few times I have let the owner "choose" for us, letting him "take care of us". What happens is we get a fairly nice dish, but it's invariably not on the menu, so you never remember or know what you got, and it's 1.5x more expensive than anything listed. Just be warned. 

Definitely a place to take people visiting from out of town.
author: j d.

description:
I only have 5 stars to work with??? why??? Well I was in the neighborhood with a friend and he suggested to go here. I thought....ugh Chinese food again??? well I was definitely wrong. House of Nanking is very different. It ain't no regular Chinese food place. You can taste so many different spices in their dishes that you couldn't anywhere else. The onion pancakes..mmmm..... the eggplant...mmmm... the sesame chicken if off the hook! 

IT ALL KEEPS ME COMING BACK FOR MORE!
author: Jeannine V.

description:
ALWAYS tell them it's your first time even if it's your 50th time there.........tell them it's your first time!  They will hook up a combination that hits the spot!  

The head chef and owner usually comes around to greet everyone.  Everytime I've been there he is the one that takes our order.


one word of warning.........MSG though proven not anymore dangerous than table salt, can give you a rush..........drink lots of fluids after!
author: Richard d.

description:
Average at best. There are so many more authentic and good places within 4 blocks that I cannot imagine why someone would wait in line for this.

Food 3
Decor [can I use negative numbers?]
Service 3
Other 4 owner ordering food. Maybe he does know what tastes best.
author: Allan H.

description:
I am shocked to see that House of Nanking has only three stars.  Let me provide a few tips to make your Nanking experience more enjoyable:

1)  You have to let your waiter order for you.  
2)  You have to be drunk.

Even if you follow one of these tips and not the other, I guarantee you an excellent Nanking experience.
author: Camilla R.

description:
Damn, I can't believe how much hatin this joint gets!  I've heard peeps rave about it in the world beyond Yelp but no real complaints. So I is very amused to see so much dissin and same sauce consensus.

So to go against the grain, most every time we been here its with chinese or viet friends who love it also, truth be told they may have been the only non white/tourists in the place each time but we all enjoy the food, a lot. 

Same cant be said for the overall experience tho.  The 'waiter" who sometimes lets us order, sometimes tells us what we want is actually kinda amusing now, feels like you in the soup nazi episode of seinfeld, and based on a few great dishes and a few reasonable ones we be kinda ok with whatever he brings mostly.  It's hella noisy and full or t'rists and some pretensious wanna be hip folks but every now and then its worth all that for some great dishes.  Mushu is tops, some tasty shrimp dishes (not super fresh but tasty) and some good noodle and fried item action.  Not overly impressed with dumplings tho. Give them a pass.

Go if you can tolerate an outta town crowd, take it for what it is and eat, eat, eat.
author: Steve S.

description:
I find the bad experiences people have had here fascinating.

I've been coming here since the 80s and my main objection is how expensive it's gotten over the years, especially for appetizers. 

You come here expecting the owner to be a "Chinese food nazi" and he is. That's just part of the package. I really hope people aren't getting ill from this food as I particularly love the use of yams in many dishes which I haven't had elsewhere. I've always had a good eating experience at Nanking.
author: Susie W.

description:
I got dragged to House of Nanking for lunch again by coworkers today. I never had any intention of going to this place to begin with, being aware of its massively (and inexplicably) popular tourist trap status, its reputation among Asian friends as being on par with Panda Express at twice the price, and the glaring (at least to me) lack of anyone Asian eating there.

My opinion of it was not changed by today's meal. A coworker who protested against going places serving "sketchy meat bits" seemed to massively enjoy the unidentifiable battered and deep-fried blobs of what I was lead to believe was at one time chicken. I was looking forward to trying something else from the "stuck in 1960's Hong Kong"-decorated hole in the wall next door to the office, ("New Hong Kong Menu" over on Commercial Street, FYI) which while not spectacular when I had a bowl of won ton mein there on Monday, was at least decent, the portions (including a ton of bok choy sum) generous and the price right at ~$5.50. Meanwhile, my share of House of Nanking's gussied up supermarket steam table Westernized Chinese food somehow set me back $20 and left me feeling like a bit of my soul had been sucked away along with my money.
author: Ian K.

description:
I love House of Nanking! I admit I was frightened by it about 6 years ago when I would pass it on my way to work, the dingy looking interior and cramped array of seating. But the line out front told another story. I gave in and went one night for dinner and have been returning with enthusiasm ever since.
You must put aside your desire for attentive waiters and a lush and clean bathroom. You won't find it here. However, the food is awesome. I can't go without rolling out the door without uttering
 "Look - I couldn't eat another thing. I'm absolutely stuffed. Bugger off." (MP)
You can pick from the menu, or just tell them to bring you what's good that night. I would suggest telling them how many of each thing you would like (I want 2 apps, 3 main dish and 1 side) or else you will likely get more than you can eat. 
Worth the wait.
author: Mel H.

description:
Ummm... I think that House of Nanking is okay, but talk to my fiance and he'll tell you he LOVES it.  But I'm writing the review and here's what I think.  Total hole in the wall with so-so service, lots of tourists,  and okay chinese food for about $10 a plate.  It looks a little dirty so I opted to drink a soda (which was $2) to avoid drinking the water in plastic cup.  The server scratches his head then he serves the food...ewww!  Not a fan of sitting really close to the people next to you... so close that the server will give you their plates to give to them.  Luckily we went early enough not to wait in line because I don't think the food is worth a 15 minute wait in line.

Oh and when I signed the bill, I didn't add the tip because we were going to leave it in cash.  When the server picked up my signed receipt, he noticed that I didn't leave a tip and mentioned that the service charge is not included.  I said I knew and that I would leave it in cash.  He left the check and then someone else came by and mentioned it again and then hung out around the table...  For crying out loud!!!  Finally when we left a few dollar bills on the table, they said thank you and finally left the area.  What the heck is that?!

Not sure I would go back... Maybe only if the fiance pays and we don't have to wait in line.  But then again we'll see...
author: Marjorie H.

description:
Pretty good Chinese food. It's not great but it's not bad. I've only been here once nd we didn't order from the menu because my friend just told the owner to bring out whatever. So it's gonna be hard to review this place since I had no idea what I was eating. But here it goes...we started with a seafood soup which was really good...then we got some root vegetable thing which was my favorite dish....then we got the nanking chicken dish (i only know what this is from reading other reviews) the sweet potatoes were sooo good and the chicken was good too. our last dish was calamari which was interesting...my friends liked it but it wasn't my thing cuz it tasted like tempura and i hate tempura (yes that's very non-asian of me).

So here is my poor review of this place. I wish I had known what we ordered!. I wouldn't ever think of coming to this place again but I'm not gonna object if my friends want to go.

Oh and whoever says to go to San Tung instead is way off because San Tung isn't authentic Chinese food...it's Chinese-Korean.
author: Jenn S.

description:
You know, I've eaten Chinese food in India, New Zealand, Hong Kong, and all over the USA and I have to say House of Nanking is the best Chinese food I've had outside of Hong Kong and probably the best Hunan style Chinese food I've ever had period. The hot and sour soup is definitely the best I've ever had anywhere and as far as the rest of the menu I can't say I've ever gotten a bad meal here and I've come here for many, many years. I don't care about atmosphere so I'm ok with the decor and ambient noise, but I do care about food and this place is amazing in the wonderful food they produce in a very short time. Well worth the wait even if there is a line. Excellent!

Hint: Get a room in the Hilton across the street on the side Nanking is on. That way you can watch out the window from your room until the line dies down and hop over for a quick bite.
author: Dan K.

description:
I consider House of Nanking a bit of a guilty pleasure.  I wouldn't consider the food regular Americanized or authentic Chinese food.  It's got it's own thing going on-- very tasty, lots of salt, spices and seasoning, and definitely on the heavy side.  This may sound like your typical American-Chinese food, but the tastes are different.   

You'll need to go at off hours or be prepared for a long wait.  The place isn't big, but it does turnover fast and they squeeze as many people as possible into the area they have.  The owner likes to order for you and he'll definitely pick out a good meal for you.  The down side to this is that if you have favorites that he doesn't like to pair together, you kind of need to argue with him to get what you want.  I'm willing to fight it out, others find it intimidating, personal preference I guess.

I really like the tofu here, any style is good.  Also, the Nanking chicken or shrimps are delicious-- heavy, greasy and delicious... and they come with sweet potatoes, smothered in that same delicious sauce.  The tea is actually pretty good too.  It's got lots of floating stuff in it.

If you're here for a visit or you live here and just never make it over to North Beach, I think Nanking is worth a stop.  The only caveat is don't come here expecting real deal Chinese food.  Also, I would only come here when you've got a big appetite.  It's not the kind of place for light fare or a little snack.
author: Zach J.

description:
My inner foodie is yearning to give House of Nanking a 5, but in deference to truly 5-star restaurants with bottle service - or frankly anything that I would call "service" I'll resist.  If you are looking for an authentic China Town culinary experience in San Francisco, this is as good as it gets.  Notice I said China Town experience, not Chinese experience.  You'll pass streets lined with empty Chinese Restaurants before stumbling upon the line of hungry locals that habitually inhabit the sidewalk in front of the restaurant (Read as: be prepared to wait). This excellent food, that the uninitiated may not even fathom is available stateside, is a treat for the palate not to be missed.  If you come in on a late afternoon or early evening, you may even be greeted by the owner and head chef (who's photos line the walls).  If you're feeling adventurous, let him know that this is your first time (whether it is or not), and he'll select food pairings for you.  

Be warned, although House of Nanking has expanded, table space is tight and you will share what feels like an Elementary School cafeteria table with other diners.  Also, if not allowing the chef to select your entrees, have your order ready including any side items or beverages, as you may not see your server again during the meal.  Service is short and demanding, but efficient.  

Hot tea is the beverage of choice (unless you feel inclined to try some Kikoman plum wine), and I highly recommend anything with their excellent peanut sauce including the Green Onion Pancakes or Egg Rolls.  Don't expect any of the homogenized western style fair that you will find at Nanking's lesser counterparts... this is a unique take on Chinese that feels like what "fusion" should be, but rarely is.

Happy Eating!
author: Katie H.

description:
OK, so why going to House of Nanking?  

1) You aren't with a date
2) You're with some friends.
3) You want to eat some tasty food for not a lot of money
4) You are not in a rush. 

Then .... yes. Otherwise, probably is not for you. Hike a little bit to the Italians !
author: Javi V.

description:
We were lucky on went on the 4th of July and there was no line for lunch. 

I thought the food was of good quality. Had the spicy Dumpling soup and it was nice.  Liked the egg rolls.  Wife had the eggplant dish and it was really good.  I asked them to make up a chicken dish and it  tasted delicious. 

 It was pretty entertaining to see how bad the service was.  Getting water refilled required an act of congress.  The bus boy guy maybe had the worst attitude of all.  

You know what you are getting......go for the ride.
author: Jason M.

description: I have a particular weakness for going to restaurants where the wait staff takes complete control over my order. Seafood or meat or veggie? Seafood. Shrimp or fish or exotic? Shrimp. Spicy? Just a bit? Very hungry? Yes. That was literally my ordering process. Highly recommend this joint as whatever came out was delicious.
author: Matthew C.

description:
This place has been hubby dear's favorite for the past many years but I got to eat here only last Saturday when we were in town to see the Chinese New Year Parade. There was a long queue outside the restaurant, but after having read all the reviews on yelp, I was not surprised. In fact, given that the judges' stand for the parade was right outside its entrance, I was actually expecting the queue to be longer! We had to wait for about 20 mins to get a table. 

We ordered the following:

- Sizzling rice soup: This was by far the BEST chinese soup I've ever had! It was everything that one needs when its 40 degrees outside - hotttt (yes, as expected, I burnt my mouth), tangy, flavorful and spicy (we'd asked for that). The veggies in the soup were all fresh and the rice was nice and crispy! The portion was large enough for two of us to share. I am definitely ordering this the next time I go, and the next, and the next! 

- Onion pancakes: Very crusty, with a yummy sauce drizzled over it. Must try! 

- Nanking sesame chicken: after reading all the rave reviews about this dish (and noticing both the tables on either side of us order the same thing), I must say that I was a little disappointed. Although the chicken was tender, it was not very crispy and the sauce was too sweet for my taste - I don't think I'll order that dish agian. However, I must say that the sweet potatoes on the side were delicious!

- Fried Tofu in black bean (or was it BBQ?) sauce: Now this was a pleasant surprise! The tofu was very well done, and the sauce hit the right spot - very flavorful with a slight tangy twist. Went well with steamed rice. 

In short, this is definitely my new favorite chinese restaurant. I can't wait to go back and try everything else on the menu!
author: Priyanka G.

description:
Best Chinese food I ever had!
The sesam chicken is outstanding! The service was ok and our food was served quickly. 
But I have to say that the pork we had wasn't  quite our taste, but everybody likes different things...
author: Benedict W.

description: Very tasty...a bit on the salty side... will want to go back when I'm in SF again :)  Was a little sad they didn't have that one famous tea though.
author: Jessica L.

description: the fish soup is very good for those who love fish and spicy food!
author: Rixin L.

description: We came here at the STRONG recommendation of a friend who lived in San Francisco. I didn't like that we had to wait in a line to get in, but it wasn't THAT bad. We waited about 20 minutes for 2 people on a Monday night around 6:30 pm. And I also didn't like that we were seated, smushed together with a table of strangers.
