They got us in and out of there really fast and weren't very attentive (had to beg for packaging to wrap up leftovers). But the FOOD was good. We of course got the sesame chicken and it was indeed good, but we were more impressed with these onion pancake appetizer things.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Lunch service was quick. It was pretty empty when I went. 

The beef fried rice was really good.  Minus one star for the egg shells that made it a crunchy beef fried rice.

Oh, and that hot tea....was I supposed to drink all that "stuff" floating around in there? I took two sips before I gave up trying to work my way around the floaters. Minus one star.
author: Melissa H.

description:
Man, I love me some Nanking.  I mean, you need to know what you're getting into.  It's like a quickie with a stranger.  You wait in line, out in the weather, watching the happy people inside, and the buildup is agonizing.  You're finally seated and the waiters treat you a little rough, but you like it.  You look at the menu, perhaps out of habit, or maybe to keep it civilized for just a moment longer, but you know you're going to get what they give you, and like it.  Then, all of a sudden, it's on.  A pummelling of sensations.  The most amazing tastes coming at ya, seemingly endless, and in no particular order.  You can't get enough.  You're completely seduced by the dumplings, the bao bing.  It's hawt.  But then something in the frenetic kitchen catches your eye.  Ooh, you'd rather not see.  You want to preserve the mystery.  You don't even care what's really in the sesame chicken.  Then, as abrubtly as it started, it's over.  Like literally 20 minutes later, you find yourself back out on the sidewalk, a little dazed, unsteady.  Just like that.  You feel cheap and uncomfortable...but you know you'll be back.  For the bao bing.  You will.  

Ok, but this time, no bang from the bao bing!  Total disappointment.  Where's that sauce?  I love that sauce!  I'd consider licking that bao bing sauce off an old shoe if the situation presented itself, so you know I was disappointed.  And the meat!  Where is the fall apart, perfectly shreddy, meat that I love?  This time the meat was so tough.  Totally inedible.  Either not the same grade or cooked for a fraction of the time.  Total bummer.  Complete disappointment.  Also, on this same visit I used the bathroom.  Big mistake.  I don't recommend that bathroom at all.  

I'll have to go back to see if it was a fluke or if they've made some cuts "in this economy."  Oh, I hope not.
author: Jennifer K.

description: Food was delicious. We had the stuffed mushrooms w some crispy pork! Wow was that good. Service was fast!
author: Luis A.

description: Omg!! This place was really good. I don't eat a lot of Chinese food...with that said: I would eat more if it tasted like what House of Nanking's got going on. Yum!! The pot stickers in the peanut sauce rocked and the chicken sesame with the sweet potatoes was the BEST!!!
author: Chrissy V.

description:
The food itself was delicious we had the "Melts i your mouth Calimari" Spicy and regular tofu. I was very satisfied with the food. we did have to wait in line to get in and the restrooms are horrid. i would go again just because the food was that good!
Enjoy!
author: Erika A.

description:
I was a bit apprehensive in checking out NanKing because it seems touristy. Being an Asian American I have high expectations of my Asian foods. ^_^

So six of us after a night of partying, woke up & craved for some sustenance stumble upon this restaurant by Kearny.

The waitress greeted us & asked if this is our first time, we replied yes and she said "don't worry I'll take care of you". As we look at one another perplexed, we took our chances with our waitress. Can you imagine we didn't even have to take a look at the menu. She had given us a bit of everything, veggies, fish, pork, you name it we have it.

As far as the verdict goes, the food was very tasty.  I recommend this place.
author: jubi l.

description:
A friend of mine recommended this place to me and although we had to wait in line, (no reservations, first come-first serve) it was well worth it.  The manager took over as soon as we were seated.  Being first timers he decided to choose the food for us and it was delicious.  The pricing wasn't bad either, especially split among the four of us.

It's also in a great neighborhood, nestled among City Lights Book Store and a stone's throw away from Zoetrope!
author: Aubrey L.

description:
This place was great! I am of the honest opinion that half the people on sites like these just can't be pleased by restaruant food- EVER. 

My parents were in town and we stopped in here on a busy Thursday night. My mother is the hardest woman on earth to please- and she couldn't stop raving about the food. Okay, so its not "traditional" tasting..but what is? I don't know. I'm not from China. I'm not even Chinese. 

Its def. no frills but worth the wait and super inexpensive. I am making this a stop for every out of town visitor from now on!
author: Jess W.

description:
Mmmm yummy!  Awesome americanized chinese food!  The nanking sesame chicken or whatever is hellllllla good.  Also the pancake appetizer thingies.  But I always feel bloated after eating there cuz its too filling / oily or whatever.  

Don't order too much.
author: Labonee M.

description:
A friend took me here a couple of months back, and I enjoyed.  He said he heard about it because Rachel Ray from the food network actually reviewed and ate at this restaurant.  We went on a thursday or friday night and it was pretty packed.  Luckily, we got there early and beat the crowd.  

It's kind of a hole in the wall.  I'm not sure about a lot of the dishes there, but I do know that their Nanking chicken (or whatever it was called) was really good.  It is like a general tso's chicken coupled with these ssliced sweet potatoes.  The sauce on it is kinda sweet, really yummy.
author: Kimberly F.

description:
Of course it's not "real" Chinese food, but as far as Chinese-American food goes, it's *alright*. I do have to say that, while it's not the best I've ever had, it is pretty good for SF standards (since I can't seem to find a place that sells *good* American-style Chinese food in SF) Yeah, this place looks like a tourist trap, but it's pretty close to where I live, so...

The dish I had was saucy and flavorful, and I was surprised to find that it came with an unexpected serving of fried sweet potatoes and some cucumber slices. I had a Tsing Tao with it, which was just under $3... Funny, I thought, considering you could get a whole six pack of that stuff for a few bucks more... Anyways, the food was fine.

What really killed it for me was the service, or lack thereof... Had I been in a hurry, I might have actually been upset. I waited at least 20 minutes between finishing my meal and getting my check... It might not have been so bad if I had a friend along to chat to, or something else to enjoy my time with, but no... I could only stare out the window and watch everyone else get on with their lives while I had to wait.

With the tip, my dinner came out to $15, which I felt might have been just a little more than I expected to pay, but whatever... When I took out my credit card, the cashier told me there was a $25 minimum. I was pretty surprised at this, considering the lady who seated me said it was okay when I asked her if I could pay with my credit card. I guess she forgot to mention the catch...

In conclusion- House of Nanking has some pretty tasty food, but it probably isn't worth the price, slow service, or touristy environment.
author: P A U L.

description:
This place was recemmended to us by a friend, so we tried it.  First thing to note, the place probably violates more than one health code.  Seeing the long line gave me some hope that this place was somehow "all that".  But it wasn't.  The food was decent.  However the person in charge who claimed to be a chef, but was not cooking at all, wanted to order for us.  He claimed to want to make us special dishes.  We were a little sceptical but went along with it telling him some prefrences.  Then the food came out in waves, soup, then 3 entrees.  I specifically told him no hot spice, only mild.  Well the soup was somewhat spicy but tolerable and one of the fish dishes was also tolerable but a bit spicy.  He bragged about the squid, but it was just ok, a bit overly lemony if you ask me.  I do really recommend the green tea though.  Very nice flavor.

The real kicker was when the bill came.  We happened to wonder where he came up with the prices for all of the entrees.  He said that none of the dishe were on the menu.  Where he came up with the prices is beyond me.  And of course the prices were higher than similar items that we saw on the menu.

My guess is that he was either trying to hurry us up or trying to get rid of the food that the restaurant had an excess of.  Either way the seemingly special treatment ended up coming across as shady instead.

And by the way, we noticed that many people were given the same "special dishes" that we were given.

Service was speedy but not anything special.  

The menus are pathetic.  I have seen nicer menus from children selling lemonade on the corner.  I think with all the revenue that they bring in that they could have something that borders on professional.

Would I eat here again?  Perhaps, but I will order for myself, and not go during prime time.  But I won't be rushing here anytime soon though.  This city has far too many choices to go back to a place that didn't really make the grade.
author: Scott A.

description:
Oh I miss going to House of Nanking. It's true, they'll order for you but you don't have to let them. I love the vegetable ABC (have them add sweet potato) and the crispy sole with Chinese greens.

It's a little crazy inside and usually loud so don't go here looking for a dark corner and romance, come for the greens and bring friends.
author: Angela K.

description:
I've eaten at this restaurant a handful of times, and I was never disappointed. There are usually lines out the door, but the wait isn't too extreme. They seem to turn tables relatively fast. 

The first time I visited House of Nanking was with my family. It's a memory I will never forget. They were visiting me in California, all the way from Pennsylvania. My Dad (being the globe trotter that he was) told us that this was the best Chinese we'd ever have. He was right. We did not order from the menu. The owner seemed to recognize my Father and treated us like family. My Dad told him to just bring out whatever he wanted, and it worked out wonderfully! SO MUCH FOOD. It just kept coming and coming. My Father passed away in 2007, and our meal at House of Nan King was one of my favorite meals ever with my family. I hope someday that my Mom, brothers and I will get to go back and enjoy another meal in honor of my Dad.

Now, when I go to Nanking, I never order from the menu...I simply ask the owner to bring out whatever he pleases...and it's always worked out in the end. You can feed like 8 people for 50-60 bucks and that's pretty cool for poor college kids. 

The service is fast paced, you are in, you eat, and you leave. Quick and painless. I'm not sure why this place gets bad reviews...Nanking has the best Chinese food that I've had on the West Coast. I'm not sure what the deal is, but it's really hard to find good Chinese. 

Oh, and they serve beer...so that's cool.

Parking is a beeech...per usual in San Francisco.


All in all...I love me some Nanking!
author: Rachel T.

description:
Although it looks like your typical Chinese restaurant, this restaurant does not serve your "typical" type of Chinese fare. 

As soon as my friends and I sat down, this very friendly waitress came up to us and asked if she could suggest some items from the menu for our group.  After interrogating us for about 3 minutes about our tastes and preferences, we were pleasantly surprised with several delicious dishes.   Their sesame chicken was excellent: hot, warm and crispy with a side of sweet potatoes.  The salt and pepper shrimp was delicious: the shrimp is dusted with seasoned flour and deep-fried and then stir fried with basil and mushrooms. The calamari was AMAZING: very light and tender enough to cut through with just your fork.  The black bean fish was pretty good as well: the fish was cooked just right and the black bean sauce was not as salty as other places that I've had.  

I would suggest two things: If you decide to order from the menu on your own, I would suggest avoiding their beef and green beans dish.  The beef, though tender, was seasoned with a wierd reddish sweet and salty sauce and the beans were overcooked. Also, their wonton soup wasn't too impressive either.

This restaurant is generally very busy and there are often large groups  on the waitlist.  You should try to get there before 6:00pm for dinner.
author: Mary T.

description:
Everything on the menu is good to great!  But half the time I've gone I got either a plate or a fork with a chunk of food on it, so this place is obviously not that clean.  

The last time I went with 4 friends and the server gave my friend major attitude about using a credit card to pay for the total bill, stating they didn't accept them.  My friend pointed to the sign at the door that said "we accept master card and visa" then the waiter made a dissaproving nod as he hesitantly accepted our form of payment.

Not sure if I'd go back again.
author: Ali G.

description:
Straight up, no frills Chinese food. The first time I came here (way back in the day) I burned my tongue on a piece of really hot broccoli. That didn't deter me, though. Their food is good and cheap, and so is their beer.

Yes, there will be massive amounts of tourists. Yes, you will most likely have to wait in line outside for an empty table. But the House of Nanking workers turn tables fast, so you won't have to wait long.

It's not a place that will blow your mind, but it will satisfy your stomach.
author: Ava S.

description:
This place is not for the weak hearted! It is a wild dining experience! 

I am absolutely giving this place 5 stars. Strange, because I can really be a SNOB and I like things classy, clean, and spacious.
Nothing could be further from the truth about this place. However, it was the only restaurant on the block that had a line. Shouldnt that tell a true diner something important? 

It is not a wonderful dining experience, but  it is GOOD FOOD. All you have to do is ask the manager to take care of you--and he brought our table of six 6 courses to try. Everything was superb. Maybe not truly authentic Chinese food, but it was flavorful and yummy. Almost American-Chinese. 

We had a blast all stuffed in to our tiny table, practically on the laps of the people at the next table over, with cans of soda getting slammed on the table when we ordered drinks...

But, the food and the fun experience made it a 5 star dining experience!!
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
The rating is a median between the 5 for the food and the 3 for the place.
The good:
Probably the best chinese food in the city, the first time you go there ask the bartender to have a selection of their dishes, is the best way to understand which things you like more for the next time.
The not so good:
The place is small and not very nice, let's say it's 'essential' .

The owner is very polite, the waitress pretty 'cold', but it's ok in the whole
author: Steve E.

description:
I went to House of Nanking for the first time this weekend feeling a bit scared.  The reviews here are so split, and I really do like the whole dining experience, so the thought of a rushed dinner in a dingy restaurant was a bit disconcerting.

I survived just fine, and found the whole experience to be quite pleasant.  We arrived around six and there was one party in line.  We were seating in about 10 minutes.  We were seated right in front of the window, so I barely noticed the rest of the restaurant.  I felt a bit like I was in a zoo as the long line outside peered in to see what I was eating, but I didn't mind, and quite enjoyed the little kids pressing their noses against the window to get a look.

I was prepared to make a quick decision after all of the warnings about how indecisiveness is not appreciated here.  We chose the fried shrimp cakes and hot and sour soup, and then left the chef pick a chicken and seafood dish for us.  

Service is not friendly, but lightening fast.  Our shrimpcakes were delicious, if you are in the mood for fried food, and the hot and sour soup was original and very tasty.  The seafood dish was fried calamari in a lemony spicy sauce, and sesame chicken which was friend with a nice sweet sauce and served with sweet potato.

At the end of the meal I was pleased with the food, but it is all fried and didn't leave me wanting more.  So, I would say go for the experience once, be prepared for grumpy service and a sticky table, and expect a good chinese meal.  But not great.
author: Lauren J.

description:
Just like many others have said, I came here for 2 reasons:
1. Friends from out of town insisted on it, and
2. I wanted to know what all the hype was about.  One guy at my work freaking creams himself whenever this place is mentioned, so I thought there must be something to it.

We beat the lunch crowd by about half a second so we got right in as a line immediately began to form under the candy-colored sign. The gals who were the out-of-towners said they can't come to SF without coming here so we let them do all the ordering.  

Apparently, the rude staff is part of the charm and draw of HoNK.  In fact, the highlight of our visit was that the server changed our order as we were making it, insisting that what we ordered was not as good as what he was going to bring to us.  I found this hilarious and cool, and having no choice, we went along with it.  

(Also, side note: it did feel a little like you had to order your water in a clean glass, and then when they brought out the waters for your group, they'd ask, "Ok, which of you ordered the clean glass?"  Seriously.  I'm just saying the place feels dirty.  And not in a sexy dirty way.)

Anyway, no chopsticks, no soy sauce, blah blah blah.  Way cramped seating for sure.  General feeling of dirtiness and un-welcoming staff.  But I regret to tell you that with all these components, I really liked the food. 

Right, the food we didn't actually order but what he brought, knowing we'd like it better than what we ordered. 

I don't think it was the best chinese food ever, but it was definitely good.

I feel like this review is going in circles.  I love it, I hate it!  I am confused!  

Overall, I would go back.  So three stars should be about right.
author: Dele P.

description: Wonderful food.  The place does not look like much but the food does not disappoint.  I had four meals at the House of Nanking and each meal has been wonderful.  Just tell them basically what you are in the mood for and let them work their magic.
author: Tim F.

description:
late last call for the kitchen ,very noise waitress was very rude and made us hury along with are order.Hot and sour soup was served after the entre.
Food and noodles were very good.
author: Rodney w.

description:
I have been going to House of Nanking since the second week it was open and have eaten there so many times over the years I can't count  the number.  Went again with a friend last night.  

First, I have read many reviews that complain about the food's lack of Chinese authenticity.  Get over it.  Chinese authenticity is NOT what House of Nanking is about.  It's about great food.  Also many, many SF and surrounding community residents eat here.  It's definitely not a 'tourist trap.'  While tourists eat at Nanking as well (don't know if it still is as I haven't looked but Nanking used to be on Michael Bauer's 100 Best Restaurants list) a lot of locals eat at Nanking.  Tourists read Zagat's, yelp, etc. so they come.  Plus people like me recommend the restaurant.   I do miss the old detailed menu and unless I missed it, didn't see a shrimp dish on the latest two page flip-over (scallops though), they did make my old fave Chicken in Beer Sauce.  The old dish used thin slices of tender chicken and the sauce was more subtle than what we ate last night however last night's dish was quite good.  Not as subtle a sauce & small chunks of chicken rather than thin slices.   I'm fair & honest so have to write it is not as good  as it used to be.  (Put it back on the menu and make it the old way please.)  The beef dish, Crackling was I recall (?) was very good as were the pork dumplings.  Hmmm...  

I have been eating at Hunan, Brandy Ho's, R & G and all the other great Chinese restaurants in and around SF for years.  Hong Kong Flower Lounge in Millbrae including the original many many years ago when it was a simple storefront but the food was fantastic.  I go to House of Nanking when I want their food, a unique blend of Asian and American cooking with a touch of other influences.  So screw that unauthentic criticism.  I know it's not authentic and do go to 'more authentic' Chinese restaurants like those named above that I really enjoy but House of Nanking is still excellent and last night's service was fine, Sat.  night line out the door when we arrived around 8:00 p.m.  Again, some tourists but many locals.  One converses while in line.
author: Joshua C.

description:
Every dish is incredibly sweet - almost to a fault. I will say, however, that the fried tofu is the best I've ever had. The side veggies are yummy. 

Worth going once or twice but there are definitely better Chinese places in the city.
author: Virginia S.

description: One of the many things I miss about San Francisco is this local favorite. I have no issues with the price - the portions seem very fair to me and the taste is to die for. Parking sucks (As it does most places in the city) and 9 times out of 10 you deal with a line out the door and some cramped seating with people you don't know. But when you take your first bite you feel like it's just you and your food. Sigh.
author: Anastasia T.

description: The service is utterly unacceptable.  Yes, it has its charm.  The sesame chicken is very good and many of their dishes are quite good, awesome even.  Too bad that the entire experience becomes defined by the terrible service.  Ironically, you feel both ignored and rushed, depending what part of your meal you're in.  When you're in the middle of your meal and you want more rice or water...forget about it.  The staff, however, will swoop in when its time to pay.  This is a shame given the restaurant's ability to attract tourists.  It is indeed evident from many of the reviews here that many of them were disappointed.  You might get lucky and get the owner in a good mood.  In that case, all you have to do is sit and he'll use his discretion and bring you dishes that you will love.  That happened the first time I came.  But my second, third, and fourth visit, I felt like the place showed its true colors, so it's unlikely I'll go back for a fifth try.
author: Angel S.

description:
Great Food, but you don't actually get to order half the time, they order for you
Crap Service
75 cents for an ice water
Don't understand the hype, but the owner has to be making $$$ it was packed
Didn't need to see Rachel Ray's blurry mug on the wall three different times, the first photo would have been enough. 

3 Stars
author: Michelle A.

description: My boyfriend and I dropped in for dinner last Friday night and thought House of Nanking was OK. The food was pretty good, not great, but you know when you just want to be comfortable when you're having dinner out? We weren't comfortable. We were constantly shifting our chairs around to make room for other patrons and servers to squeeze by. Everyone was tightly packed in there. I don't recommend the shrimp lettuce wraps but our sesame chicken dish was tasty. Regardless (and I hate to be a whiner), but I don't see myself going back there anytime soon with all the other Chinese food options in the city.
author: Leslie G.

description: Very good flavorful dishes.  I recommend the sesame chicken.  Limited selection and a bit pricey for Chinese food. Service is rushed. Also, cash only.  Beware the hot tea is served in a large glass (no tea cups - same type of glass the water is served in) with the leaves floating in it. It is good but a challenge to drink.
author: Matthew A.

description:
I left my heart in San Francisco, and it's on the table at the House of Nanking. I am totally a sucker for Chinese food, however I hate cheap shitty steam table chinese food. This place, however, I would not even describe as chinese food, I would describe it as a fucking experience. My friend Jimmy got me all hyped up about it before we even got there with tales of no menus and a wait staff comparable to the soup nazi episode of Seinfeld. They come to your table and ask you what type of meat you like, and you tell them. Then they ask if you're hungry, you say yes, and they say okay. 

Then magically plates of food start appearing family style for the table. Course by course, surprise after surprise, fantasticalness after fantasticalness. We started out with THE MOST DELICIOUS, LIGHTLY FRIED CALAMARI i have ever had. It was literally like pleasure in my mouth. Next came out some paper wrapped shrimp and pea quesdillas with a mango chile sauce on top, also very good and some chilled bok choy in a vinegarettey sauce. I've never had bok choy chilled before but I could have lived without this, you know I love my meats. So, then came out some bbq beef chinese "burritos" put together table side, also a favorite of the meal for me. This meat was moist and tasty and paired with excellent veggies and a finger lickin' chinese sauce all wrapped up in a hot tortilla, yum. Then there was some delicious chicken and sweet potatoes that both somehow stayed crunchy even though every morsel was engulfed in sauce. Then there was whitefish steamed to perfection with a glaze and a grip of fresh spinach on top, another favorite of the meal for me. After deciding we were all stuffed but still wanted to try more delicious concoctions we ordered mongolian beef atop crunchy noodles, oh my gawd so good and so flavorful. I know what you're thinking, god this girl is a fatty, but there were eight of us at the table and all this wonderfulness was only about 20 bucks a person.....with tip!!! Crazy! I would go back and order any of the things we got for lunch again, but I would also love to go back and do the whole thing again, over and over and over. 

They also have Tsingtao beer for three bucks and massively giant mugs of water, we're talking bigger than your head mugs, i assume because they don't want to have to refill them, but comical nonetheless. But I hear the wait can be extraordinary so watch out! We had basically no wait since apparently everyone in the city was at Burning Man, yay for us! 

P.s. If you are not hungry after reading this review, you are not American!
author: Jessica S.

description:
The first time I went to House of Nan King, I really loved it and suggested it to all my friends.  The service was good and the food was great! The second time I went was a huge disappointment!  I went with my parents, sister and her baby, and my Uncle.  The waitress had horrible customer service skills and acted like the Soup Nazi 
from Seinfeld.  After we made our order she was like 'That's it!  That's not enough! You need to order another dish!'  We actually ordered another dish after her tone of voice.

After waiting a long while, we noticed they didn't bring us our drinks, which was mostly water for our table.  We waited patiently and didn't press for it until it became evident that they were not going to bring us any water.  We kept asking, and the other waiter would quickly walk by our table and mumble that he was busy right now.  A complete lack of respect and lack of customer service. We asked several times and no water.  Finally they gave us our water. And finally we were given our bowl of soup, soup bowls and soup spoons.  They gave us one less soup bowl and one less soup spoon.  After asking for the additional soup bowl and soup spoon, they gave us the soup bowl, but no soup spoon.  Mind you, every time they gave us something, they would quickly run off to do something else.  They never gave our table any attention.  After asking several times for a soup spoon, after the fourth or fifth time, the waiter lost his cool with us, grabbed 10 silver spoons and THREW THEM ON OUR TABLE!  We about had it after that! 
My sister while holding the baby got up and told the waitress who originally waited on our table and they were going back and forth arguing.  I then told the waitress, we want our check for what we ate, we are leaving.  We are not happy with the service.  She then got all apologetic and said no the food is coming, sorry we are busy, and not enough workers. 

She then yelled at the waiter in her language.  She ignored my request for the check and later brough out the main dishes.  I told her no, I told you we want our check for what we paid for and we are leaving.  I had to say this 3 - 4 times before she would give us the check! 

I noticed a sign in the restaurant of a new branch of theirs that opened somewhere else.  I'm assuming that is where the owner was, since he was not at the restaurant when we  were there.  That is too bad that the restaurant we were at was failing in all areas.  It's not worth it to keep the minimum amount of workers on hand to save money (my assumption).

The food that we had wasn't even good. 

Honestly, I have never been so disrespected in my life.  I will never go back and will tell people to avoid this restaurant.
author: Lina H.

description:
You don't go to House of Nanking for friendly service, or a nice atmosphere.  You go for cheap, fast, delicious food.  Yes, the waiters can be rude, the place is far from spotless and you have to ask for water.  They push you to leave when you are done, and you are seated at long tables with complete strangers that you have to squeeze by to get to your seat.  But the food is AMAZING!

Never order off the menu!  I was "schooled" about House of Nanking by cousin Merlin.  Tell the waiter how hungry you are and what you don't like, then sit back as the plates start arriving.  It's always a wide variety, and it's always perfect.
author: Paige B.

description:
Ah yes....The famous...or should I say infamous House of Nanking.  I doubt there's a restaurant that is as simultaneously loved and hated by so many people as this restaurant.

Here's why people love this place: The food is incredibly tasty.  It is by no means traditional chinese food, but it is quite good. The chef (Peter) has added his own touch to everything and it shows. There is a tangy flavor to most of the seafood entries and most of the "traditional" chinese entrees are done quite well but with a twist. Overall, I would say the food is excellent.

Here's why people HATE this place: Never in my life have I ever been treated with such disrespect at a restaurant.  Most of the servers who work here are very rude...especially the owner Peter.  I've noticed an interesting observation everytime I've eaten here: Whenever I eat here with my Asian friends (I am Asian) the service is incredibly poor and disrespectful; however, whenever I eat here with my white or black friends, the service is good.....I will let the reader decide the implications of this.

Overall I want to give this restaurant 5 stars for the food, but because of the service I'm downgrading it from 5 to 3.
author: TT T.

description:
Tourists with maps? Let me play you a song from afar on my tiny violin, yee whining yelpers. In case you're still living nostalgically (as evidenced) in times 10 years past, take the time to cogitate and realize how much this city relies on tourism as an industry. Be thankful the blissfully ignorant still flock to our city in droves, or else our corrupt politicians would be spending more of our money instead of theirs.

Nanking is as authentic as it comes and it's not pretentious like so many other restaurants try to be.
author: Nate L.

description: I love the spicy rice soup and the crackling beef.  I try to go when there isn't a line, but don't mind waiting if absolutely necessary.  The service isn't anything special, but that isn't why you eat here.  A must, at least once.
author: Ryan W.

description:
Ok, i took a long hiatus home to texas and now i am back! I just went to the House of Nanking resturant and enjoyed it. Now it gets busy and they tend to forget your table (from the two times i have been there) and they don't regularly check up on you, but they food is good. Actually the food is great, it was some of the best semi-americanized chinese i have had. The sweet potatoes that come with dishes taste like heaven!!! The food is 5 stars, service, size of resturant, and decor is like 1 star... so i give it 3.

I had the Nanking Chicken, Something Another Shrimp... sorry, and the low mein. All AMAZING!
author: Preston B.

description:
I like it. I don't care if it's a tourist trap. I like sitting down, letting them bring me food they pick, and enjoying pretty much all of it. If you go with people who aren't into seafood or are picky, then it's probably best to pick something off the menu quickly before the waiter takes them away and orders for you.

Dig on the daikon radish sprout stuff- double dig on the shredded sweet potatoes, dang they're tasty!
author: Diane S.

description:
After going to a yelp event at the Bubble Lounge (which had plenty of good eats and drink to boot) my friend Mimi (Mingle owner) stopped by this joint because she said it was incredible. Was it?  It was pretty damn good.  I ordered the Seasame Chicken (with potatoes - yummy) and she ordered... well... we're not sure really what she asked for, but she got some seafood noodle dish and it was delish!  I brought the rest home for my wife, and while still fresh but a bit cold it was good as well.

Could it have been the bottles of Peroni at the Bubble Lounge?  Nope, this place just has some tasty eats.  Mimi speaks Chinese and perhaps that helped - not really sure.  We left happy - and that's all that counts in my book.
author: Matt D.

description:
There is better Chinese around (considering this place is pretty much in Chinatown).  There is better Hunan around, to be exact.  

But, I heard Warren Sapp eats here.  That alone, makes this place cool.  

If you beat the crowd, you can get a solid Chinese meal here for a reasonable price.  I let the waitress pick most of our dishes, and they were all tasty.  But the crowd, and the line make me hesitate to frequent this place.
author: Korey A.

description:
Ok, so it's a bit dingy looking, it's crowded, there's soo many tourists that go here so you get long lines out the door, and there's really no elbow room to eat since you're practically sitting on the other table's lap on metal tables that are unstable everytime you put your elbow down on it that you're afraid of spilling your drink....  

BUT I have to say they have the BEST chicken chow mein I've ever had in a Chinese restaurant (well they're not Crustacean's garlic noodles but these are FANTASTIC). They use udon noodles and basil and it is SOO good it makes my mouth water just thinking of it.  Their lettuce wraps are yummy also, although they do not give you any red bean paste to put on the wrap.  And, their hot tea is also VERY good, since it contains the whole dried flowers (not some brewed bag type) and is really sweet.

I agree, yes, the waitresses are quite rude, but they are a fast serving place trying to get as many people in as they are trying to get you out of there, BUT seriously, you can't go wrong with the prices and portions.  Please, this is freaking Chinatown, not the Carnelian room. 

It never ceases to amaze me how many people eat there, they are constantly busy.  If you see a line outside and seats open inside, go inside and ask to be seated! Especially if you're solo or only two people, they'll seat you right away.  The line outside is usually big groups of tourists who are just used to standing in line if people are waiting outside since they don't know any better....
author: SF Diner A.

description:
The rave about this place might have been its downfall.  So, before I tear into this place, I want to say that the dishes were wonderfully flavored and I would eat here again.  Unfortunately, it seems that most of the dishes are flavored similarly and eventually, you can't tell the difference between the dishes.  Even the tea started tasting like the food.  

The wait staff are unaccomodating, inconsiderate and semi-efficient.  Our particular waitress became agrivated with us because we said, " what?" once too often in response to her thick accented menu ramblings.  One waiter actually started mopping under our feet while we were still eating.  Not cool.
author: Darkie L.

description:
Eh...I can take it or leave it.  The Hot and Sour soup was really good...but yeah, they like to push their own dishes and never look at the menu.  

It's good to take tourists too for an experience, but don't come here that often.
author: Dan D.

description:
I came here for a friend's birthday dinner. I showed up late so i didn't get to order (there was 15 people). So as I sat down the plates were being served and all this amazing wonderful delicious food was paased down.

I don't know what I ate that night, but I ate everything that came my way. And I loved all of it. Crispy, peanut, seafood, tofu, sprouts.

The locale is cute and I will have to come back another time when i'm not late.
author: Sprout S.

description:
I'm surprised at the reviews for this place.  I went there with a party of six last week and the owner/exec. chef was cool and the food was great.  Listen.....
It ain't authentic Chinese.  If you have ever spent a month in China, you would know that few word pairings in the english language are as frightening as 'authentic chinese.'  You don't get the assortment of animals still wearing their heads here.

I can kind of see the same sauce thing if you order wrong, because some of the dishes do share similar (probably same) sauce.   When we went in the chef asked if we trusted him to order for us.  I was a little worried but went with it.  He brought out about ten or so dishes for about 100 dollars.  And the sauce was different on all of them : ).  This place is a great value, especially if you want prix fix type dining  where the prix is fix-ed at about 15 bucks each.

And the corkage fee is five bucks.  Werd.
author: Nahum M.

description:
Today my co-workers & I decided that we would go on a "business lunch," so we leave the office after failing to pick a lunch spot. We brainstormed a few places, walked by Myth Cafe and finally my boss said she knew of a really good Chinese place. After LITERALLY walking right past House of Nanking w/out seeing it, we took a detour, which ended up being about a half a mile out of the way, but we finally found it (with the help of an iphone)!

This is definitely what you would call a "hole in the wall," but the food definitely seemed much higher in quality than the traditional dive. The waiter came and my boss told him to "order us the best things on the menu." (apparently this is what most people do at this particular restaurant). We ended up with 6 dishes for 5 of us and almost finished all of them! The dishes were really good and were probably things that we would not have ordered from just looking at the menu. The plates had a lot of fresh vegetables on them, which made it extra good. I am not exactly sure what dishes we ended up getting, but we liked all of them.

If you can stand the small atmosphere and "hole in the wall" feel, then you will love this place, if not, then go elsewhere! Oh and I thought it was pretty odd how they didn't give chopsticks and the plates were various colors (blue, yellow, green), when have you ever been to a chinese restaurant that didn't have white plates!
author: Elaine S.

description:
We came here on a recommendation from a tour book, so we knew what to expect with the line and cramped tables. We were very lucky though- only 2 of us and got seated right away. They wanted to take our order immediately- whew, they really want to get you out of there quick.

We shared the spicy dumpling soup and sesame beef. 5 stars for the soup- sooooo tasty! It had fresh basil and some sort of very tender fish. Yum! Sesame beef was just alright: way too crunchy so that I could barely taste the meat. Sweet potatoes on the side were excellent.

A guy at the table next to us was very friendly and started telling us that he comes with friends often and they always ask the chef to choose. Never disappoints, apparently.
author: Alisa G.

description:
If I am in San Francisco, House of Nan King is a must for me. 

Want a great meal? Don't order for yourself. Have the waiter or the owner order for you. Guaranteed to bring you joy!
author: Jeff T.

description:
Pretty touristy Chinese joint in the North Beach, you can always tell by the line outside.

Beware of the owner taking your order.  He'll scribble on his lil notepad and say "Dun worree, I take care of you."  No he won't, he'll order a ton of random things to ensure you have a pretty bill to handle at the end of your meal.  

The only memorable thing for me here is the hot tea with some type of berry herbs in it.

...that'sallshewrote
author: C Q.

description:
Rounding up from 3.5*. 

For many years, I was one of those who passed this place by with my nose in the air ... ah, those tourists, falling for the tourist trap. But then, I started work nearby and went once when there wasn't a line. Now I visit on a semi-regular basis. It's really pretty good. I don't really know what Nanking style cooking is, so who knows if it's authentic or not, and yes, there is food enhancer in this stuff, but it's good. Ingredient quality is better than general Chinatown for sure, but I have to mark them down for the quality of their rice. Really not that great. Service? C'mon, it *is* Chinatown...
author: Bruce C.

description:
I will say I am a bit surprised to say this but I actually enjoyed eating here. We arrived on a Saturday evening and the line was a little long. I would say we waiting maybe 15 minutes. Not bad at all considering you could go to any other restaurant an easily wait 45 minutes. I always laugh when people are like ugh 15 minutes and leave! Good luck going somewhere else on a Saturday. Anyway, we are seated at little table by itself next to the window. I didn't mind the line of people outside staring at you wishing they were eating. It was nice not to have to eat next to other tables like most people.

When I said I want Chinese food this was exactly what I wanted. They had a great variety of vegetarian options and it had flavor. Authentic or not it was yummy and I recommend it.  We started with the onion pancake which came out differently than I was expect. Still good. Then I had the fried tofu with a peanut sauce which I enjoyed and Brian had the Sesame Chicken which came out with a side of sweet potatoes. He of course loved it. The one thing we didn't like was the house noodles with vegetables. It smelled AND tasted like wet bread...yeah not so yummy.

If somebody tells me they want Chinese food I will say go to House of Nanking.
author: Glenn M.

description:
After three visits, its clear that House of Nanking is a winner. The best Chinese food in Chinatown by far- not too pricey, not too greasy, not too sketchy. The tofu at Nanking will turn meatlovers vegan- try the snow pea shoots tofu, its amazing. 

Consistently good food, unfortunately does not always mean consistent service- the wait staff may as well be an order counter, because all they do is take your order and bring your food and check. Boom, that 's it, you're done. But I mean who really cares, the food's great!
author: Cody E.

description:
Drove by once, saw the long line waiting for dinner and that left an impression.  This place is supposed to have good crab.     I came for lunch on a weekday and Chinatown was really crowded; it took half an hour to find parking (garage on Kearny was full).  The restaurant was 80% full so we didn't have to wait.  My first observation when I walked in was that every single--and I mean every single--customer was Caucasion (well 1 African American).  Then every subsequent customer who came in was also Caucasion.  As crowded as Chinatown was that day, there was not one single Chinese customer in this restaurant.  

The food was served on plates and cereal bowls.   Even though we talked to the owner and servers in Chinese, we had to ask and wait for chopsticks.  We were served ice water with a small slice of lemon.  The tea I saw being served to other customers was ice tea.  The spring rolls were full of pork and served covered with sauce!?  The wonton soup included pork won tons, fish, and slices of lemons!   Needless to say the tastes were American and not Chinese.  

The food itself was only so so, 2 stars.  We were not treated badly in any way at all.  In fact the owner and the wait staff were pleasant and gracious during a very busy time of the day.  However be aware that this restaurant caters to Americans and not to those looking for a Chinese dining experience.
author: Matt L.

description:
I don't know if this is authentic chinese food or not, and i don't care - this one's a keeper. One of those places where you already know what to order and already know its going to be so good. 
In my case - Hot tea, Crispy rice soup, Onion Cakes, Sesame Chicken & Salt & Pepper shrimp & mushroommmm.....

PS: Don't expect much on service, but rest assured it will be fast & no-nonsense.
author: Miki N.

description: No offence to anyone but as far as Chinese restaurants are concerned I thought this place sucks.  I was in San Francisco for a training class with my coworker.  Our instructor recommended this place so we tried it.  I should have known as soon as we walked in.  The place was full of non-Asian tourist type people.  The food was okay but on the pricey side for what you're getting.
author: Riverside G.

description: Food is flavorful but really greasy.  Cleanliness is questionable.  This place got some publicity when it was featured in an episode on MTV, Real World.  Not sure why some people keep going back.  Seriously, this is not authentic Chinese.  I would skip it.
author: D C.

description: A nice treat. Very crowded and busy, and you might share tables with other people. Parking is easy to find, however beware of going to far past the restaurant as you will encounter numerous one way roads. I generally would park in the public parking lot right before the restaurant.
author: L L.

description: The food was so good we ate there two days in a row. It's not cute on the inside but you can't tell from the long lines outside waiting to get in. I am a Nanking fan.
author: Suga B.

description: Been here countless times. Every time is a great experience. The food is to die for. Its not yer plain ole Chinese joint. It has a little spunk to it.. The best part is eating across from people you don't even know and having great shits and giggles with!
author: Skoolly T.

description: service was bad, food came out in one sec so obviously nothing was fresh and everything was pre-cooked.  Vegies were drenched in so much sauce and oil you couldn't taste the food not to mention way over priced for what we got.
author: Briana B.

description: I really wish I could have this down here in LA.  I definitely enjoyed everything here. I came up to visit some family and the boyfriend's cousin treated us out here for dinner. I can't recall what I ordered, but I remember it was the noodles. Everything here is family style, so everyone ordered a different entree and we all shared. It's been a year since I've been here, but all I can tell you is everything is SUPER good.  I assure you, nothing will disappoint the palette. SUPER good Chinese food, I tell ya!
author: stephanie s.

description: Getting overrun by toruists but locals eat here too. Food is awesome, had dinner here by myself but met an awesome couple from the UK and had some laughs.  Sesame Chicken and Sweet Potatoes so, so good.  They turn the tables pretty quick so don't expect a long relaxing evening or while glove service but there are plenty of other restaurants that do that stuff.  Come here for the food and a few laughs.
author: Joe H.

description:
I've been coming to this place for 15 years.  Yesterday's visit was my last.

The servers literally do not give a damn about the customers, they ignore them, are rude and impatient.  Heaven forbid if you are not 100% ready to place your order and the server has to wait for 2 seconds while you make up your mind.  The servers are the most inattentive I have ever seen.  You actually have to flag someone down to place an order, to get a refill, to get anything.  There are only 10 tables per room!!!  Come on!

The food is SMOTHERED in sugary sauces. The sesame chicken was WAY overcooked, the only thing making it possible to chew was the heavy sauce that acted as a solvent to soften the food.  The noodles are dripping in oil, though tasty still.  I like the tea, but $3 for tea?!?
The portions are much smaller than they used to be.  Expensive for what you get.
Rather telling, that for an Asian restaurant right on the edge of China Town, there are never any Asians eating there.
Much better value for your money around the corner.
author: Pablo M.

description:
Went there for lunch. Food is all right, along the lines of eric's. Lots of sugar in the food. 

Service comes with a bit of attitude which sort of ruins the meal. They want the high turnover so it is rush rush rush.
author: Nick K.

description:
A trusted friend and colleague with a history steeped in MSG...actually a better description of him is really that he's a well seasoned San Franciscan adept at playing the "name the best restaurant in the neighborhood" game. Anyhow, as the clock inched toward 5 o'clock one day, he listed off three of his favorite Chinese food spots in the city. In third place was the Inner Richmond's Taiwan Restaurant, the second was House of Nanking and the first he promised to take me to once we were both working the FiDi. So I headed off to both this past weekend to really test his ability at naming some of the best places to eat in The City.

The menu was straight forward. It was busy considering it was a Friday at 1:45 p.m., late for lunch and too early for dinner and the service was slow, although I didn't mind because I highly enjoyed the people watching.

My companion and I ordered the sesame chicken and told the owner we had an affinity for shrimp and scallops and he made a few notes and put the order in. We daringly ordered the flower tea, a loose leaf tea shoveled into glass mugs and covered with steaming water.

The vegetables that came along with each entree were fresh and a nice addition to typical totally unhealthy Chinese food, the Nanking sauce on each dish finger lickin' good and the flower tea had spectacular flavor but should have required a straw to get to the actual liquid and beyond the mulch.

My favorite part of the experience, the open air windows and seating and calling out to my trusted friend and colleague Alan as he strolled by, Chronicle sports section underarm, I made sure to tell him that it was a GREAT recommendation.
author: Jenny T.

description: I was visiting San francisco and checked out yelp for somewhere good to go for chinese in China town. This place was an epic fail. Do not go at all costs. The waitress/possibly owner/ family member decided that since we had never been there before she would just make the best dishes she knew. Unfortunately except for the calamari which was really nice everything else was really poor. Even their chicken which was the house special was lacking any major taste. Service was awful and they began collecting our plates before we had finished eating and had food still on them. Worst of all they started counting their tip in front of us as soon as we had left the money in the folder. In my opinion avoid at any cost as this place has nothing going for it. We actually walked through china town the next day and stopped at a small take out store and had the most amazing dumplings. Unfortunately I can't remember the name to recommend.
author: Das Y.

description: This place is for traveling tourist looking for "Chinese food in SF."  It's hyped Asian fusion at its worst.  Take a quick stroll to Chinatown or go to Clement Street, pay half the price, and get much better food.
author: Daniel F.

description: Be ready  to be ROLLED out of this place! Most of the staff is unfriendly, almost comically unfriendly...but MAN- they make up for it in the taste! Been here many times- never had to wait (long, at least). Brought my family there from out of town, and they asked if it was anyone's first time...and it was.. He said "I'll take care of you" (caught me by surprise!)....it was one delicious dish after another....and it didn't stop! I've been to China- and this food was in the top ranks for me. AHH- I miss!
author: Mya S.

description:
While planning our trip to SF, several friends recommended Nanking, promising delicious food, great prices, and I think the word curt may have been used when describing the service.  My friends were absolutely right, and I loved it.  It's all part of the charm.

After working our way through the tables and making at least two people get up so we could slide through, we joined several other couples at one long table.  Two warm waters, no ice, slice of lemon appeared (the charm, again).  Kathryn F. tried the plum wine, which was surprisingly good.  

We saw so much incredible looking food around us, so for our "reverse" ordering strategy, we picked a few we liked and turned to the menu for deciphering.  We settled on the pork pot stickers with peanut sauce, beef fried rice, and Nanking's Famous Sesame Chicken (which should, whenever possible, be ordered using its full title).  There's a certain predictability to Chinese food which was turned delightfully upside-down by our dinner.  The pork pot stickers were perfectly crispy, and the spicy peanut sauce was to die for.  The sesame chicken... forgive me, "Nanking's Famous Sesame Chicken", was not too sweet and had a wonderfully savory flavor, and was served with thinly sliced fried sweet potatoes.  Different, but excellent.  The real winner, though, was the beef fried rice.  It was so perfectly moist, and almost indescribably fresh; they took all the standard ingredients, added zucchini and red onions , and brought it out in minutes!  Bravo.  

I have a feeling this is the place that no matter what you get, it will be amazing.  It sure was for me.  Don't be discouraged by the line out the door, it will move fast and will give you time to gaze longingly at other people's food before you get your own little piece of Nanking heaven.  Highly recommended.
author: Gentry A.

description: First time at this restaurant and very disappointed.  The entrées we chose were tasteless.  I guess I was expecting a little more authentic food since we were so close to China Town.  Maybe it's just my taste.
author: Debra P.

description: I ate at the restaurant Sunday and had not eaten there for quite some time (8 years).  At no time did the server respond to my thank you or comments about the food.  There are many other choices out there.  Thank you.
author: Jim H.

description: I've been going to the House of Nanking on a regular basis since 1985. From about 2000 until four years ago I was either out of the state or out of the country so did not get to visit that restaurant during that period. Two years ago I took my father-in-law there boasting about how good the food was. That was the first time in many years that I had been there. Much to my surprise I found that the quality of the food was not as good as it had been in years past. The service was just as bad as it always was but I was really disappointed in the food. (Waiters have always been rude) Yesterday I decided to take two of my friends there. Once again I told them how wonderful the food was. Well, I was extremely disappointed. The service was just as horrible as it has always been but the food was not good. It was edible but not even as good as it was a couple of years ago. The sweet potatoes were sliced paper-thin and had no taste, the sesame chicken was so sweet it was almost inedible after the first few bites. It is one thing to have bad service with rude waiters but when you combine that with mediocre quality food it is no longer acceptable to me. I will no longer be singing the praises of Peter Fang's House of Nanking.  Like so many other things we see happening in this country, quality and customer care is on its way out. Everyone is in it for the fast buck.
author: Randy H.

description:
The best Chinese food I have EVER had!  All the ingredients were fresh and beautifully balanced.  I LOVED the sizzling rice soup, eggplant side dish, sesame chicken, and pork potstickers.  

YUMMM!
author: Erin A.

description:
Stand in line, sit down, don't look at menu.  Let them order for you, eat the great food and get the hell out so that someone else can sit where you were.

I liked it better before it was remodeled.  Then it really was an adventure.  Now it's more like a strip mall with good food and rude waiters.
author: Tony A.

description:
Is the service good?  No.
Is the seating a bit tight?  Yeah, just a bit.
Is the food Americanized?  I guess, I don't really know, I am after all "American."
Do I care about any of the above? No.

There is always a line outside but they move people in and out of the restaurant at a brisk pace.  The Sesame Chicken was fantastic, particularly the sweet potatoes and cucumber that went along with it.  The Beef with String Beans wasn't as good, the beef was cut in slices just a bit too large.  Overall, it's a pretty good Chinese restaurant.  I did not have ANY problems ordering what I wanted off of the menu.
author: Eric C.

description:
This place isn't as bad or great as people have been saying.  It's definitely a different type of chinese food experience.  In no way, would I consider it authentic.  The best way to describe it would be yuppified americanized chinese food.  Yes, I do love the noodle tower.  It's great!  But, all of the other dishes do have the "same sauce" attitude and get old after a while.  This "same sauce" is tasty, but way too repetitive when you have 2 out of 3 dishes having the same flavor.  You feel like you've eaten the same dish over and over, but with alternating textures.  

The guy wearing the polo shirt IS the head chef/owner.  He's pretty dry and tells you what to eat.  Even the regular wait stuff will be very suggestive.  With that said, taking any out of towner here would serve them well.  

Don't go here if you don't like to be social, you WILL be seated next to a set of tourists or bridge and tunnel types.

I'd give it 2.5, but since I like the food AND price, it gets a 3.
author: Simon Y.

description:
Divine food! I have never had a bad meal here. Huge portions.
You have not lived until you've tasted the green onion cake with peanut sauce!!  Also, try the white pepper mushrooms or the snowpea shoot salad.  Everything is wonderful. The flower tea is a lovely choice, if you want something romantic and warm to drink on a foggy day. 
If you are ordering a soda, you'll just get an unopened can unless you specifically ask for a glass of ice. This may or may not be important to you.
author: Heather G.

description:
So I have lived in San Francisco about 15 years.  And ate here when I first moved.  It was ok, not great and since I figure I have eaten about 3000 meals in this city.  Decided on a lark to go back tonight to eat, and have to say it was the most singularly bad meal in all 3000 I have had.

I guess it could have been an off night, but doubt it.  Had five separate dishes and they were all the worst food let alone Chinese food I have every had.  

The poor food quality was only exceeded by the incredibly bad service.  Was so bad that the owner even asked how we like the food, we decided to be truthful and told him how bad it was.  Didnt even acknowledge us, just turned and walked away.

Its beyond me how anyone with any taste could think this place is anything other than crap.  Anyone rating this more than two stars should be banned from Yelp and run out of San Francisco.  They make a good argument for being able to filter the ratings by user.
author: Robert G.

description:
I should have known from the minute my tourist buddy reccomended this place that it was a bad idea.  But I decided to humor him for like the fifth fucking time in one weekend (please note review of Mas Sake) and do what he wanted to do. 

This place is a fucking joke. Don't even feel like wasting words on the obvious problems. No chopsticks, no soy sauce, no room, no charm. Just tons of maple syrup all over strip mall chinese food. Not even sure if everything was cooked. I get the whole "cramped chinese food place! wow! so hard to get into" vibe, but that's only because I've eaten in good NY Chinese spots that established that cliche. This place is, like I said, a fucking joke.

One star for you Nanking, and two stars for you Justin Basch. I will be making the decisions next time you visit.
author: Farallon Living I.

description:
I almost didn't eat at House of N on my last trip due to all of the crap written on this site about it. I am glad I followed my instincts, better then ever and again I had them choose my plates for me. I have been eating here since 99' and always a satisfying experience (from a food perspective, the inside is a dump, but it's the food I am there for)
Food came out hot and very tasty. I would recommend this place to anyone looking for something different. Also I have a trick, use both your eyes of how many people are inside eating and if your nose is saying "I'm hungry, the food smells good"...
author: Jim A.

description: Scallop Tower is AMAZING! Get it, you won't regret this choice. This is the best spot to go when visiting SF.
author: Jenny S.

description:
overpriced westernized chinese food, the worst meal i've had in my life...
too salty, too greasy, and made me feel sick.
author: Emie L.

description: Best soup (tofu, fish) noodle  I've eaten in SF. The calamari and sesame chicken were very good.
author: Hiep H.

description:
Love this place. I was only in town for a few days, and my SF friend said this was the place to go (she has never been). We went in mid-afternoon on a Monday and there was plenty of seating available. After the waitress took our drink order, we decided on we wanted from the menu. No need, as it turns out. The proprietor arrived at our table and asked if we had any food allergies.

No.

Do we have any religious allergies/restrictions?

No.

"I'll treat you right."

Only after he walked away did we realize that we hadn't ordered, and that he was going to surprise us.

And pleasantly surprised we were. We were brought simmering rice wonton soup (YUM), pea shoot salad with crispy shrimp (YUM), and sesame chicken with rice (YUUUUUM). All in all, a great experience.... good food with the fun twist of surprise.
author: Chris M.

description:
Not what it used to be!  Well the staff is still surly but that has always been part of the charm.  As a long time fan of this place, since 1996, and having gone there dozens of times over the years, I am disappointed to take this off my list of favorite dives.  

After the expansion a few years ago it seemed that they had changed a few of their recipes and with this visit, aside for the sesame chicken there was very little that was memorable.  Nanking has always been a non-stop table turning feeding trough, but at least the food used to be so good that it was all worth it.

Final note - in the old days Peter Fang, the owner, had such pride in the food experience that he often wouldn't allow you to order some combinations of food - that is the era when he won all those awards on the wall - if you go there, you won't see too many awards from the last two years.  If you have never been there though, it is an experience that you may like, and you will probably be satisfied, but if you have been there before, my comments may ring true to you.
author: Mike M.

description: Easily my favorite dining experience in SF. Due to what we read and heard it's best to let the waiters order for you. It sure worked for us. The chicken was incredible. Succulent yet lightly crispy, and the fish we tried was unique and delicious. Superb.
author: Cole B.

description: I was so looking forward to eating at this place because I had heard so much about it. Everyone said this is THE place for Chinese food in San Francisco. A friend raved about it so I figured we couldn't go wrong. We expected a wait since it was a Sunday night, but fortunately we didn't have to wait long. That's about the only positive thing I can say about our experience. The service and atmosphere at Nanking is a bit rough around the edges to say the least. The waitress kept hollering at the other house staff in-between taking our order--literally SHOUTING like an army sergeant doing military calls. Really unpleasant. I actually felt some animosity towards us because we weren't giving her our order fast enough. The food arrived very fast in quickfire succession--so quickly that we couldn't even pace ourselves. We felt rushed like we had to eat in a hurry and get out as quickly as possible. The food was nothing even close to what I was expecting--really really bland and unexciting. The pot stickers were hard. The fried pork egg rolls tasted bizarre. The Bao Bing wrap had gristle in it--the wrap was so thin you couldn't even hold it together without it completely falling apart in your hands. The detoxifying fruit tea, and hot & sour soup were okay. Not one of us enjoyed our meal and left scratching our heads as to how anyone could think this is some of the best Chinese food in all of San Francisco. In a city with as many options as ours this place is completely over-rated. I won't go back again and will have to smack my friend the next time I see him for recommending it to me.
author: Denny G.

description:
I grew up in SF's Chinatown and have always been fascinated at the amount of people waiting in line to eat at this place.  Granted, the line is full of mainly tourists but I still wanted to see what all the fuss was about for myself.

Aside from the flies swarming around everywhere and the poor customer service (what do you expect, it's chinatown!), the food was mediocre.  The "crispy" fried calamari, which was one of their suggested items, was far from crispy.  And the beef dish we had, although somewhat decent, was definitely not worth $15!

I can't believe after two dishes, rice and no drinks, we walked out of there with a $35 tab.  Definitely not worth the hefty prices.
author: Lilo F.

description:
we waited outside in the cool drizzly weather for about 30 minutes, i kept thinking this place better be worth it. and it was- i think it was the best chinese food ive ever had. 

we were a large group of 6, so we ordered a bunch of stuff: 
the lemony calamari was different but delicious!!! 
the sesame chicken was my absolute favorite. 
the sweet potatoes were also super good. 
and the stuffed mushrooms which were a last minute add on to our order were sooooo freakin good i coulda eaten them all!! 
the shrimp dish dont recall the name was kinda weird looking, tasted good, but sight was not appealing at all. 
the fried rice arrived significantly after the rest of the food and was very salty so we dint even eat it. 

the total bill with tip was about 150. they wanted us to pay cash, instead of with credit card but when i insisted they agreed. 

overall i really enjoyed the whole experience at nan king!!
author: jen r.

description: This place never disappoints. If you are feeling adventurous, have Peter the owner order for you. Its always amazing! Get their shrimp cakes!
author: Paula D.

description: Not a single Chinese customer, no chopsticks in sight.....I knew something must be rotten in Denmark.
author: Wakako U.

description: Beware... there is a line up! But it was quick and the food was very tastey.
author: Sofie V.

description: Overrated.  There is better prepared chinese food in SF.
author: Pietari G.

description:
My boyfriend and I stopped in here one Saturday afternoon for a late lunch. It was really crowded so we assumed it was good. 
We were sat by a unfriendly waitress. When the waitress finally came to take our order, another waitress ripped my bfs menu out of his hand while he was looking at it to read what he wanted. I ordered a side of rice - he did not as he had a noodle dish. 

We had to ask for our water a few times. They brought out my dish but not my rice or my bfs dish. I tried a bite and it was ice cold. I hate to send things back but I didn't come to eat cold chicken. The waitress was annoyed and took it back.

20 minutes later they finally brought out both of our dishes but no rice. My bf had to go up to the kitchen to ask for the rice because no one would help us. Someone brought out a big bowl of rice. 

The food was AWESOME I have to say. The sesame chicken and potatoes is pretty delicious. My bf had some noodle dish and it was great as well. 

They finally brought out our check and had charged us for three extra rice. I usually would have just let it go but they were on my last nerve. I told the waitress and she actually tried to argue with me because my bf had a bite of mine. It was none of her concern if he had a bite of my meal - no where on the menu does it say extra for sharing. We ordered one side of rice. I am the customer, I am right. 
I've never not tipped, but there was no way I was going to tip for how rude they were to us

It's a shame because the food is pretty bomb. I will probably get it TO GO - but never eat there again!
author: Lauren R.

description:
I grew up in the San Gabriel Valley, which is hands down the best place to get Chinese food anywhere in the US.  Because of this, I tend to be very picky about the Chinese food I eat, and I like it authentic.

A few of my friends up north were raving about the House of Nanking, so I knew I had to try it.  So I decided to go with them on my last trip to SF.  First thing I noticed about this place was that it was small, cramped and a bit dingy.  So far, so good!  Then, because of the line, one of the waitresses (which I think was the owner's daughter), told us in a stern voice "line against wall".  Nice!  Finally, we got a table and ordered.  

Well, I should say we only got a table, because when the owner found out that I had never been there before (and also the fact that my friends are non Asian) he said "I'll take care of you" and took our menus away before I could even protest.  Alright, fine.  So he's a bit of a Chinese Nazi.  I'm adventurous, I'll let it go.  

So the food came out.  Meh.  Green onion pancakes.  A bit greasy, I've definitely had better.  I can't remember the other dishes very well, because, well, they weren't very memorable.  A chicken dish, beef dish, noodles and rice, and i think a vegetable dish.  All pretty damn greasy, more then I'm used to. 

Overall, I'd give it 3 stars.  It's not authentic Chinese Food (No matter what SF folks will tell you), but it's more authentic then PF Chang's, Panda Express and Pei Wei.  If anything, the owner and staff were pure entertainment, and a reason to try it out.  

Chinese food snob?  You bet.  And I wouldn't have it any other way.
author: M K.

description: House of Nanking is delicious, not terribly cheap (hence 4 and not 5 stars), and filled with loud and hungry people, perfunctory servers, and freaking amazing, clean, perfect food.  My boyfriend and I came here cold and hungry at around 8:45 this past Sunday, and were seated immediately.  We ordered the delicious chowder soup with chicken (creamy, filling broth with corn and veggies, crispy bits of chicken on top), and the garlic fish (super fresh fish lightly panfried with garlic and onions, topped with fresh spinach), and some white rice.  The meal was MADE with the detoxifying tea we ordered on ice--tea magically concocted out of dried apples, plums, and lemons--so delicious and subtle.  I love this place and can't wait to go back.
author: Alanna C.

description: This is the BEST food ever!! There will be a line out the door but its worth the wait!! Everything is made fresh!! It is the best chinese food in the state of CA!! I have not found anything that comes close to it!!
author: F H.

description:
Visiting San Francisco and was told this place was good.

We had the house fried rice and sesame chicken.  The rice was not bad, but the sesame chicken was great.  It came with some sweet potato chips in the sauce and they were good too.   The chicken was slightly crunchy but not burnt at all, and the sauce was reaaal good.  The dish was a hit with us.

The place itself was kind of small and seating was tight, but you get over it quick.  The service was not rude, but not super friendly either, which is ok because sometimes I just want to eat and not chit chat.  

The 2 dishes, a glass of water, and a drink was around $22 and some change.

I would go again if I lived in the area.
author: eddy r.

description:
I went here 10 years ago with a group of 8 people.  A guy, who turned out to be the owner of the place came out and watched at us blankly staring at our menus, then he started yanking the menus out of our hands.  He then said, "Is anybody allergic to anything or have a special diets?"  We one vegitarian at the table who raised her hand and said "Veggie".  
Then he said "I know what you want...." and walked back to the kitchen.  The first plate arrived, then the second plate, third plate, fourth plate, fifth plate.... It was crazy!  The food was AWESOME!  I don't even remember what I had but it was great!  
By the time the eighth or ninth plate came out we had to tell the server to stop bringing us food.  We got the bill and it was a little bit over $120, (granted this was 10 years ago and I'm just getting around to reviewing it now), but 8 people happily fed for $120?  Yes!
I lived in Canada at the time and all of us were tourists so the owner came out and took a picture under the sign with us.  
Great Experience!
The next time I went was with my sister in the middle of the afternoon.  Service was short and blunt, but the food was incredibly tastey!  Quick word of warning, if you're looking for authentic Chinese food you're going to the wrong place.  If you're looking for friendly service with a smile, you're probably going to the wrong place.  If you're looking for excellent food it's the perfect place to go!
author: Matthew R.

description:
I loooove loooove looooove this place!  It's not the most authentic Chinese food but it's yummy nonetheless!  I used to live in Chinatown and so this was always my go to place when I got hungry.

I would have taken a star off because their prices went up after they remodeled the place (the place used to be a hole in the wall with plastic tumblers and mismatched bowls and plates).  Now each dish is about $1.50-$2.00 their original prices but I still think fairly reasonable for good Chinese food. 

I'm a big fan of their Sesame Chicken, the Fried Wontons, and the Eggplant scallops.  Typically they give you a big mug of hot tea/water for free (so no need to order it off the menu!) to wash down all the oil.  

The best time to go is during the weekdays at non-traditional meal hours since this place ALWAYS has lines out the door at night.  If you have a small party, you're probably going to get stuck sharing a table with another party...so this is certainly not the best first date sorta place.  It sucks that they don't have a waiting area because outside of the restaurant smells like garbage/sewer.  Be prepared to wait at least 30 minutes if they tell you 10-15 minutes.  Nevertheless, although the service sucks, the food more than makes up for it!
author: Kristie G.

description: Wow, jesus christ. All the people hating on House of Nanking for not being authentic, so what? I didn't see signs on the way in that claimed it was authentic. I thought our food was very well cooked and it tasted great. I live in the richmond and we have a good deal of chinese joints, but I appreciated the fact that the unique flavor of this place. For those upset with the service, what did you expect when you sat down at a restaurant with large family style tables? I think house of nanking kicks ass.
author: Jay C.

description: I have always left this place pleased.  People knocking down 2 or 2 1/2 stars for service are insane.  Yes, the service could be better.  They are fast and maybe a bit gruff, but really who cares?  I have have 3 different shrimp dishes, and 2 tofu ones, and all of them were fantastic and i would come again.  One of my favorite places in the city.
author: Phil J.

description: Dumplings were excellent. Lost one star for lack of selection on the menu.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Terrible, sums it up.  We visited this place about a year ago and the menu was larger and the crowd was bigger, the food was great.  This time no one was there, the service was slow,  the menu much smaller,the food the same.  We ordered sesame chicken  and it was overly sweet,  no crunch, too much sauce and no sesame seeds?.  Oh, and by the way, others ordered the same dish and mine was missing, so I shared, but glad I didn't waste the money on putting in another order. I have never submitted a review before, but this time I wanted to make sure no one comes there unless it improves. The floor was greasy and hard to walk on.  The day was wet and rainy and it made it dangerous. Employees were pleasant, the only plus.  What a shame, it used to be a great place.
Don't understand other positive reviews?
author: g d.

description: Came here for the second time just recently. It was with a bigger group so we shared everything we ordered. What we ordered was fried calamari, sesame chicken, and crispy beef. The first time I came, I got lettuce wraps with scallops. All of this was really good. Seems a little pricey to me, but it's a tourist trap, so they know that people will keep coming no matter how much they charge. Wait staff is pushy. Overall, really enjoy the food. Both times we came didn't have to wait in line, but a line was formed when we walked out.
author: Wes K.

description: I cannot believe that this place has the ratings and positive reviews that it does. It is probably one of the worst dining experiences I have had. I have dined many different cuisines in many countries and in many settings. Sure the place is a hole in the wall with dirty bathroom..but the food is mediocre at best . The sesame chicken was dry and overcooked, the 'melt in your mouth' calamari were rubber and tasteless, the vegetarian lettuce wraps consisted of some dry, stale vegetables. The service is abrupt, staff is rude and does not demonstrate the slightest interest in your presence. It is as if you are doing them a favor for eating there.
