The hostess who took our order told us she would 'give' us an appetizer that was not even on the menu- deep fried jalapeno's?!?. She then charged us for it on the bill and refused to take it off. When I pointed out that the vegetables served to us were stale, the server told us 'it is fast food' and not to order this next time. We continued to object and got some reduction in the bill and were told not to return ( cant believe that they would even think we would contemplate the thought!!)
author: Tasnim K.

description: Found this place when it first opened 20 years ago. They had one long counter & 4 or 5 tables and few customers. BUT THE VERY BEST FOOD and soon the rest of San Francisco found this place and there were long long lines day and nights ....well worth it. Back in the day Peter the owner & chef use to come by the table & we would simply say give us whatever you have that's the freshest and we were never disappointed.  we never could find those dishes on the menu or on any other restaurant's menu. Still the best just a little bigger and no more off menu ordering. :(
author: Catherine M.

description:
Very good food -- just try to get there at an off hour to avoid a very long line.  Also, you will likely be seated with another group unless there are enough in your own party to take up an entire table.

We tried four dishes and enjoyed all of them.  The eggplant one got rave reviews and was the best I'd ever had it served.

$70 for four dishes with tax and tip included plus 4 cold teas.
author: Charles B.

description: What happened to the House of Nanking?! This used to be one of the best Chinese restaurants in town. Not any more. I had a friend visiting from out of town who wanted an awesome Chinese meal. I said House of Nanking was just the place. Ugh. How wrong I was. The place has been remodeled, the prices have doubled, and the food wasn't good. The service was awful; we had to ask repeatedly for my friend's meal and the rice never even arrived. I'm so disappointed that a formerly great restaurant has been reduced to this.
author: Joyce G.

description: I really don't eat Chinese food because most of it quite frankly sucks in this country. And then there is The House of Nan King. I had the grilled pork and a spinach shrimp saute - both were outstanding. They serve long grain white rice and I would prefer sticky. It is a very popular restaurant with minimal seating so I was cool with waiting in line outside in anticipation of delicious food. I also tolerated the rushed, somewhat unfriendly service. You are here strictly for the food and nothing more. I was very annoyed by their insistance to pay in cash. They made quite a fuss about this. Come'on now, you guys can afford the 2% Visa/MC charge. Simply add it to the price of of your goods.
author: Cim S.

description:
This is some of the best Chinese food I've ever had in San Francisco.

I walked in with friends on a Sunday night. Despite the crowded room, we were seated quickly. The owner, a white-haired older man in a white polo shirt, came up to us shortly after and seemed quite friendly.

We all got menus, but didn't need to look at any of them. Instead, at my friend's suggestion, we asked to let the chef decide for us. The owner asked what we were in the mood for, and we gave him a rough idea -- some seafood, some chicken, and some vegetables. This was all he needed.

Well my god, were we in for a treat. For the five of us, they brought out some amazing dishes. Here's what we had:

- Rice porridge with chicken, egg, and herbs.
- Pork egg rolls and shrimp wantons in brown sauce
- Fried calamari in a lemon vinegar sauce (AMAZING)
- Beef sauteed with onions and garlic
- Sesame chicken
- Sauteed baby greens with duck, pork, and sweet potato

After tax and tip, the total for our meal came to $21 each -- a bit more than you'd normally pay for Chinese, but WAY better than anything I've had in a long time.

The best part: half the dishes we got weren't even on the menu.
author: Christian P.

description:
This place looks like a dump on the outside but on the inside... well it looks like a dump. 

The food isn't bad. Nothing revolutionary but its tasty. Although sometimes oversalted. Service is awful (I had to go behind the counter once to serve myslef a glass of ice water) but the food comes out pretty promptly. I agree with other reviewers in relinquishing the menu and being served whatever the guy wants to send. He does a good job in choosing dishes according to your like of beef/chicked/pork. I was sort of surprised about the prices since Chinese is usually pretty inexpensive but its not totally out there.

It is a touristy place that's in every guidebook so it can get packed with people in jean shorts and fanny packs but they can be easily avoided. Go another night. Don't wait in line outside in the cold for a table. It's not all that. But if you're in the mood for Chinese and there are tables readily available dive in and have a good meal.

If there really is a picture of Rachel Ray in this place as Paul L. says I drop my score down to 2 stars.
author: R P.

description:
The lad I work with have talked about going here for awhile. I've been there once before and he has been a few times. 

I was looking for a Peter Fang experience. I didn't really get one and was a little disappointed. However, the waitress put someone's credit card on the table and I told another waiter and he took it away. When it was time to pay, i put my card on the bill and the same waitress told me that I had to pay cash. 

The food. Really good. The selection of Chinese vegetables in the shrimp dish was superb. They weren't cheap with the shrimp either.  I despise basil which was in this dish but they made it work and it was really good. We had the Tsing Tao beer marinated chicken which also was excellent.  

There is famly style seating and we bumped elbows with a family of tourists, probably from the midwest.  The good thing about this is that you can stare at other people's food and say, hey, send me that please. 

 If you are expecting service with a smile, don't come here. However, if you come to the House of Nanking knowing that the service is brusk, you have to share a table, minimal decor but know that the food is good, you will enjoy your meal. 

Don't let Peter Fang's niceness on the Food Channel's visits to house of Nanking fool you. He will ensure that you have a good meal.
author: Joe C.

description:
Delicious chinese food. Yes the service was a bit rude. But the food was awesome. I am not Chinese so I cannot vouch for authenticity. But my taste buds had a treat!!!

There might be better places to eat because I have not eaten at that many chinese places. So giving it 4 stars and not 5 although this is the best chinese food I know.
author: Homer S.

description: Well, first I have to admit that I have come to expect poor service from 9 out of 10 Asian restaurants. So, that being said - this place was great. The food was fresh, incredibly flavorful and a nice variety.  We will definitely go back.
author: Michael S.

description:
the food was pretty mediocre and soggy the last two times I've eaten there.

it all taste the same.  i can't stand watching the staff eat through my entire meal.  i couldn't believe my eyes, they dabble in every dish it seems.  gross.  serving us with practically full mouths of food and greasy fingers.  no thanks.
author: Noel J.

description: Went on a Friday night and we waited in line for about 45 minutes (we also let the party behind us skip ahead - they had little babies). Place was packed and tiny but the food came quickly and tasted delicious. I would definitely go back. Sesame chicken and glazed sweet potatoes: order this. Not awesome for groups (I would say four and under is ideal), and definitely get the tea !!
author: Anne T.

description:
House of Nanking = Chinese for YUMMY

I ate here even before I moved to CA. A friend who was a tour guide took me here when I came to visit and taught me the "trick"--don't order off the menu. Tell the old guy (or whoever helps you) what kinds of things you like/won't eat, and sit back and enjoy. Out will come a variety of delicious foods, and when you start slowing down, they stop bringing the food. I've never had a bad meal here, and I am mostly veg (eat a little seafood). The veggie mu shu is really good. Had a great eggplant something here too one time. I've been here maybe 20 times. 

There's almost always a wait and it can be a long one, although they will go down the line and look for the right number of diners for the table that is open, so if you are a couple, it is often faster. I wouldn't recommend coming here with a group bigger than 4. 

Be aware that the tables are really close (kind of the same table almost) and sometimes they rearrange the furniture to get you into and out of your seat. 

The decor is average--nothing stellar, not dirty or gross. You're not here to eat the wallpaper, though, and once the food comes you won't care what the place looks like at all as you plow through plates of noodles, string beans, black bean tofu etc.

I know some folks said they felt it was expensive, but I've always felt the pricing was fair for hot, tasty, freshly-made food.
author: t t.

description:
This little place is packed with people around dinner time.  There is almost always a line out the door, but it's worth the wait.  We were outside for probably a good 15-20 mins.

We were seated and the waiter asked us what we like for a table of 6.  He just kept bringing food.  The food seemed to magically stop when we were getting full.  They don't push extra food on you just so you have to pay for it.  The pea shoots were amazingly good and it was some of the best sesame chicken I've ever tasted!!  

If you don't mind a little bit of a wait, this place is awesome!  :)
author: Laura B.

description: We stop in House of Nanking every time we visit SF. We stopped in on a recent Thursday afternoon and the place was empty. That's a first! There's always been a line outside the restaurant any time of the day or evening. We ordered the same food we always get and boy there was a huge difference. It just wasn't the same. Please someone tell me, did the ownership change? I'm sure it's been 20 years we've been eating there and telling everyone who goes to SF not to miss to the food a House of Nanking. I don't know if we'll be back!
author: Ponto M.

description: This place has everything going for it: engaging chef/owner who comes talk to guests, interesting menu, tasty food & fast service. But once I was there with my wife who is a vegetarian and some meat pieces just showed up in her plate. I don't think there is any excuse for sloppiness in a restaurant.
author: Star G.

description: Wow this place is still going strong after all these years. The first time I ate here..there was no such thing as checking-in at any location..and this place was very much a hole in the wall kind of place...well about 12 years from the last time I was here, this place has finally expanded by another 100 sq feet...still small but the flavors are still huge. If you go here for the first time and don't know what to order, don't worry, the manager or sometimes owner will see the confused look on you and your party's faces, take your menus away and say the magic words "don't worry I take care of you". They said it to us back then and happily..nothing's changed..because they bring out what I think are their best dishes containing beef, poultry, seafood, etc. We started with Fish soup. This had so much stuff in it, that it was practically a meal in itself..very tasty...everything that followed was a winner..Nanking chicken, fried calamari, tomato mushroom beef salad, a shrimp dish resembling honey walnut prawns, peashoot with pork, and the spinach salad. With a party of eight, there wasn't exactly a lot of elbow room but who cares, sometimes small places with big flavor and decent service are all that is needed for a good dining experience.
author: Orlando J.

description:
After reading YELP's reviews I couldn't wait to get there. The egg roll was great; the sesame chicken was great; the dish the waiter recommended was served with old tasting chicken. We ordered hot tea and were served a clear glass of tea. very good but we were charged $20 for two cups of tea. When we asked about it they said that it cost $300/ pound.
Give me a break ! They were all about give me the money !! We ate at R & G the next day and loved it !!
author: howard a.

description: This SF institution is one of my regular eat out options. I don't let Peter Fang choose my dishes, he probably hates me for that, but every time I go I know exactly what I'm craving. Quite often its the fried chicken with yams, and/or the pea shoots in the salty chickeny broth. Always get a tea to help wash down my imminent food coma.
author: yolanda f.

description:
what a joke! a line out the door?! i'd be hella embarrassed if someone i knew drove by and saw ME standing out there... my co-workers were all a-flutter over this place after they took a colleague there for a farewell lunch a few weeks ago.
after this afternoon's experience, they AND i are all wondering what kinda hallucinagenic roofies the staff must have slipped into their flowering tea that last time.

we got seated by the kitchen (kinda grimy, yo) and were immediately ready to order... we'd heard that the sesame chicken was to die for and as a rule i never pass up an opportunity to order sizzling rice soup when offered. we also placed an order for their salt an pepper mushrooms to round out the meal. 

thank gOd i ordered a beer. the food took FOREVER!
 i had a chance to glance around the packed place while we waited (and waited, and waited...) hmmm... picture of jamie oliver. interesting. and who's that? wait, oh wait, no... is that...? OMFGITRRWGGOHASAP (as translated from her native acronym tounge, "oh my f*cking god if that's rachel ray we gotta get outta here as soon as possible)!!!  
i don't trust that woman any further than i can throw her, and that ain't far...

we got the soup about 40 minutes in. the flavor was aiight though the rice had been added before service so it was definitely lacking in the sizzle department by the time it reached us.
that was the last that we saw of our meal. and certainly the last we saw of any sizzle. two tables that were sat after us got their full meals served before us... and they had just ordered the chicken, too! the mushrooms came out 50 minutes into the "meal" but they weren't our mushrooms, these had deep fried shrimp floating around in the ominous brown sauce, so they were (relatively) soon whisked off to another table. 

by the time an hour had rolled around, we asked to get everything to go and hightailed it outta there to make room for all of the self described tourists from this site who admit to liking this place. 

we dug into our food back at the office. ew. why? they must have surprise attack snapped that pic of oliver outside the restaurant as he was on his way over to broadway for a boobie show or as he slipped into an msg and undercooked chicken induced coma. yuck yuck yuck. 
do they cook their rice in RV grey water spilloff? and if you're a mushroom fan you'd be better off buying a 72 cent can of button mushies from safeway and noshing on that straigt from the can. 

leave this one to the tourists and rachel ray, y'all-- they deserve eachother.
author: saraH c.

description:
1 star for horrible service. My boyfriend and I decided to check this place out after reading all the good reviews on Yelp. I was very disappointed. The food was mediocre - far away from being authentic Chinese food. We had the scallop lettuce wrap for $18, only to find that there are only 4 pieces of half chopped up scallops in there.

Service is also horrible and the seating in the cramped room is just uncomfortable. In the end, they told us that they dont take credit cards but they took other people's credit cards. Not recommended! This is completely fake and Americanized Chinese food, and you will be disappointed for the bucks you spend.
author: Linda Y.

description: Chinese food for white people.  My husband and I walked down from the financial district because we had been told that it was good.  Two of the dishes had the same kind of sauce (brown and clumpy) and the last dish was actually inedible -- we just left it floating in the thick sauce it arrived in.  Go back?  No way, Jose.  My husband was one of the only Asian people there -- always a bad sign when eating Asian food.
author: Melissa M.

description: Overall great food and simple menu. Staff is a bit rough but hey it in Chinatown and there is always a line with people waiting to sit and eat. Thus guess what??? The wait staff is quick and pushy. Don't get scared the food is good and worth it. Food comes out fast, be specific on what you order as they have selective hearing. We ordered about for dishes and one was better than the other. And to be honest i thought it was lacking a bit in qty per dish but hey this is the total package and what makes Nanking, Nanking. Get over it you will like it.
author: Lamb R.

description: Best chinese food hands down. Make sure you allow the chef to choose the entrees for your party.
author: Aldo C.

description: MY NEW FAVORITE CHINESE SPOT IN SF! BEST SESAME CHICKEN! I can't wait to try everything else on their menu! GREAT PRICES, GREAT FOOD, GREAT LOCATION, GREAT SERVICE! Definitely going back soon!
author: April V.

description:
I actually ate at this place during the Chinese New Year's Parade!  Yep, I joined the line outside the restaurant.  First time eating here, and it's pretty darn good - the chow mein and the sauteed shrimp were delicious.  The stir-fried beef with toasted rice was okay - the beef tasted a bit rubbery.  The toasted rice was yummy though.  The pork chops were okay too; they were a bit salty.  

I'd definitely come back for the big and fresh flavors, good prices, and big portions.  Who cares about the cramped restaurant and so-so service.  If you wanna avoid the line, or be in a shorter line, you should show up for a late dinner, around 9pm.  Show up with cash too.  I don't think credit cards are accepted.
author: Dylan's Aunt E.

description: This is by far my favorite restaurant I have ever been to. Show up and your order will likely be taken by the owner. Just tell him how many people are eating and whether you have any vegetarians and he will hook you up. The lettuce rolled beef is my favorite dish.  Food is very fresh, atmosphere is nice, and I have never been disappointed in my 20+ trips.
author: Marshall N.

description: I love the sesame chicken, and the pot stickers at the House of Nanking. I highty recommend getting this dish, before heading over to Fisherman's Turf/Wharf (Lol) to see the Kenny the Clown show.
author: Kenny T.

description: OMG, what happened to my favorite chinese place???We went there today, soup was cold, the lettuce chicken was nothing like it used to be,service was worse. I am willing to look past bad service if the food is stellar(which it used to be).It seems like the servings are smaller and cost is way up. Come on, 9.95 for won ton soup????!!!!!!Never going back....
author: katie a.

description: I'm just not a big fan of greasy Chinese food, but at least the preparations were classic and the flavors genuine.  Low risk of a bad dish of food here, seems to cater to non-Chinese and tourists...
author: Disco B.

description: Friends introduced us to this place and we have been going there ever since. They have amazing flavorful dishes. Especially the onion cakes, sesame chicken, and house noodles are scrumptious. They will blow you away! They also have some wonderful varieties of tea. The service is super fast and a great value for money.
author: Gopi V.

description:
Definitely the best chinese restaurant ever (my opinion)! The food was so varied and flavorful. The presentation was pretty good and the portions were huge. Make sure you go as a group so you can try lots of different dishes. The hot and sour soup was awesome, and like nothing I had ever had before, and the stuffed mushrooms are great. If you don't know what you want, just tell the owner what kind of ingredients you like and he'll order for you.
Great Dive!
author: Diana H.

description:
the dining room is disgusting, the service is terrible, and it is so loud in here you cannot possibly have a conversation.
Yet, this is the best chinese food i have ever had.  my parents one drove from just to LA to eat here.
author: charlene l.

description:
I don't get it... What's with the three star average here?

I just got phenomenal food which would've cost at least fifty bucks at some white-tablecloth toilet on Valencia Street and I got it for fifteen. What's three-star about that?

Long live House of Nanking!
author: David M.

description:
House of Nanking is wonderful. The food is good, the portions are huge and the price is right. What more can you ask for in a Chinese Cuisine? The wait is a bit long at times but that should be a clear indicator of how good the food is.

The first few times I went I would order the Nanking Sesame Chicken because my friend recommended it. But after being brave and allowing the owner to come over and make up the menu for us. I'm pretty sure that everything on the menu is a winner.

If you ever go to House of Nanking and don't know what to order. Just leave it up to the owner. He'll ask you for your preference of meats and whether you want veges or soup and make up a combination of items to satisfy your hunger.

For being asian he often asks if I'm korean or chinese. At first I wasn't sure what he was doing by asking this question but soon I realized that he knew the different palettes of asians. How korean people tend to consume their foods on the spicier side. Hence dishes like kimchi soup and kimchi. So our dishes come our a little spicier then usual.

If you're looking for a good eatery to take your friends on a night out in the city I highly recommend this place. The location is nice. it is right across from Niebaum Coppola Cafe. Which used or maybe still is where the American Zoetrope offices resided for Francis Ford Coppola's press company. There they serve all the different wines available from the winery/vineyard.

Columbus street is also near by so you could head over to Steps of Rome for some good desserts afterwards.

I would've given House of Nanking 5 stars but I didn't because of the constant waits at time. Wait to get in. Wait to order. Wait to get the check. The place is also a bit crowded so for those of you who are a bit claustrophobic should hope you don't get a seat in the corner.
author: Michael L.

description:
This place is so yummy it was the best Chinese I have ever had ever.
I ordered the sesame chicken and white rice. The flavors were out of this world but be prepared to wait in line.

Minor Update:
Major downfall is the service was bad, but the food is worth it.
Changed from 5 stars to 4
author: Mark H.

description:
There are an awful lot of really, really terrible Chinese restaurants in San Francisco, but this isn't one of them. I imagine a lot of the extremely negative reviews are from folks whose expectations were set too high. Here's how to enjoy your House of Nanking experience:
   1) Expect to wait for a table. 
   2) Expect not-so-great service.
   3) Expect "American style" Chinese food. 
   4) Expect your waiter to offer suggestions. Accept them or ignore them -- either way, you'll get not-so-great service.

It's not a 5-star dining experience and the service isn't stellar or particularly friendly. But it's fairly cheap, and the food is really really good. Follow the instructions above and order the sesame pork (which comes with perfect thinly-sliced and slightly-crispy sweet potatoes on the side). You won't be disappointed.
author: J C.

description:
Best food in Chinatown in my opinion.

Yes, its a bit dirty and kind of a dive, but the food is amazing.  When my parents were in town visiting us, and at a loss of what to order, the server just took care of things and brought us a bunch of dishes that, honestly, most we wouldn't have tried otherwise.

This is one of the big reason I miss living in SF.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I had heard Nanking was good and have walked by it a hundred times.  We had some tourist friends who came in from L.A. and they wanted to check it out.
After waiting in line for about 20 minutes on a Friday night (not bad) with a whole load of tourists we got into the chaos that is The House of Nanking.
There were 6 of us and the waitress ran up and said "I order for you", we all looked at each other and the state of the restaurant and said "Hell no".
We had:
Calamari - Had to get a second order because it was really good
Crab Wontons - Were also good
Sauted Eggplant - Was aslo good but a bit underdone
Some Spicy Hunan Chicken dish - Good but not great
Vegatable Tower - Sucked ass
Crackling Beef - Sucked ass

So far so so food, the waitress came over with our beers and we saw her a second before clearing another table with her fingers in the peoples leftovers.  One of our pars mouth started burning because her hands were in someones chili sauce and it got on the mouth of the beer bottle NASTY.  At the same time I saw them just putting plates of food down on boxes and what ever was laying around while they were waiting to be served.

The place is kind of dirty, and it is a typical get you in and out tourist stop.  The hustle you in and out to make room for the next victims.  
Skip it
author: Andrew D.

description:
Americanized, but still excellent, Chinese food. Cheap, fast, and delicious. We take all of our out-of-town friends here and have yet to introduce it to someone who didn't like it.

Nanking sesame chicken, beef mushu, and their scallop dish, is some of our favorites. Plan ahead and get there early, especially if you want to have dinner there, because it could be a lengthy wait. And, as a heads up, it's a no-frills type of place, so expect plastic cups and limited silverware. You may also end up sharing a table with people you don't know, which isn't bad if you're looking to meet new people over dinner.
author: Irene N.

description:
This place used to rock.  The food was delicious.  Now, I'm a bit disappointed.  You will usually find a line going out the door when you arrive, so we waited.  After we were "retro fitted" into the small dining area we ordered the Sesame Chicken (yummy!) the Crispy Fish (Good texture of crispiness and sauce but skimpy in portion) the fried Calamari (weird sour sauce that made the crispy batter soggy, yuck!) and Onion Cakes(ok).  

I've had better Chinese food, but it's a good place for nonnatives to take their out of town guests to try a taste of Chinatown.
author: Thanh V.

description:
Best chinese food i've ever had.  

atmosphere is a bit hectic, but the food makes up for it.
author: Marcel N.

description: I LOVE HOUSE OF NANKING!! I don't care what other people say.. Oh it's not authentic Chinese food blah blah blah... Oh only tourists go there blah blah blah blah. Yes it is not authentic Chinese food. It's Americanized but damn it, food is really good!!! I love the calamari dish and the sauce that comes with it. OMG. That is all I have to say. All the dishes I tried are tasty and have an abundance of flavor! I recommend House of Nanking!
author: Mark J.

description: We've been waiting for this for quite some time. You have to try the flower tea it's amazing! You can't go wrong, especially if Peter Fang (Owner) is there, he'll never let you down.
author: Scott S.

description: Everyone always said they make the best chineese food in the city.  I never tasted it, however, the sesame chicken was the best.  Small and its tough to get in.
author: Brent F.

description: I'm shocked at this low rating. Yes the owner is a little pushy but the food is the best in chinatown
author: david c.

description:
I came here with a few SF natives that knew the owner/operator since he started as the head chef when it opened. With its growth and popularity, he's now more of the proprietor that makes sure everything is running smoothly and taking care of the regulars. From my first, and subsequent visits, the best thing to do is say it's your first time and he'll have the monthly-rotating menu's specials start coming. Depending on how busy they are, you might have to tell them a round in advance that you don't want any more or else they'll keep coming, like the brooms in the Sorcerer's Apprentice. Oh, but what a way to go. The food is so tasty and perfectly balanced that it's hard to stop, even when I'm absolutely stuffed. 
There can be an amusement style line doubled back on itself out the door but their turnover is pretty good and even a big line can go quickly. Their service is very fast and sometimes you have to as twice for things (not sure if that's b/c busy or lack of English) but it's worth the minor annoyance to enjoy their absolutely scrumptious delights. I guess that minor, occasional annoyance is the only reason I don't give it 5 stars...
author: Bryan Y.

description: I love the old Asian guy that will order for you.  I think it is a standard he gives everyone, but the way he comes over to look at you... grunt... scribble on a notepad, and walk away is hilarious!  This place gets really busy.  Our party sat next to these two guys that really wanted us to ask them what they did for a living.  They also jumped into our conversations.  I am surprised their heads fit through the door!  Back on point, the place tries to cram as many people in as possible.  Be sure your entire party is there.  If everyone isn't, you will not be seated!
author: Rob J.

description:
A friend of mine recommended this place to me and after reading all of the reviews I was excited to try it. We came on a Saturday night at 6:00 - right before the dinner rush. We had to wait about 5-10 minutes to be seated. Right when we were seated, the line outside had grown quite long. So definitely try and come before the rush! 

We were seated by who I expect was the owner. Not the friendliest person but you come to expect that at an Asian restaurant. The service is what it is. Their menu is pretty small compared to your typical Chinese place. Seems like they specialize in a few really good dishes which we appreciated. We ordered the sesame chicken with sweet potatoes and the house noodles. The house noodles were very different from anything I've ever tried at any Chinese or Asian restaurant. Very delicious! Not your typical fried noodles which was nice. The sesame chicken was amazing. It has the perfect amount of sauce and the sweet potatoes are such a nice touch. I also had the flower tea. A very interesting drink - it comes in a regular water glass and has flowers floating at the top. It was very difficult to drink with all the flowers so I had to scoop them out - which I noticed a lot of others doing around me also. 

Overall great food and would definitely come back when visiting San Fran. Look past the mediocre service and just expect a good meal.
author: Hyun Y.

description: This place is essentially a sit down version of Pick-up-stix. The aesthetic is cute and modern, but the food is very unauthentic.  Don't get me wrong, it wasn't bad, but if you're craving real Chinese food this wouldn't be the place to go.
author: Kate A.

description: HORRIBLE service, rude staff and mediocre food. This place is sooo overhyped and definately not worth it. Sesame chicken was so so and the calamari was rubbery and tasted horrible. Avoid this place!!
author: K D.

description: This place SUCKED. Why are there lines out front? We waited forever. Food sucked and it was over priced. People were rude. I would way rather go to New Sun Hong Kong Restaurant.
author: Mike L.

description: Good chinese food, eating area not for the closterphobic.
author: Truth B.

description:
Don't underestimate the shabby looks of this Chinese "cafeteria" as other critics have called it.
People with rich tastebuds often complain about the Chinese using the same sauce in every dish but trust me, you will not find that here.
Each and every dish tastes completely different but incredibly delicious.
And an important note: They do use MSG but if you ask them not to, they will respect that and cook your food without MSG.
Great place to eat if you're not trying to spend a lot of money on a meal if you're having a day in the city.
:)
author: Kiki S.

description:
We went to the House of Nanking because it was recommended by our travel guide and got TOTALLY DISAPPOINTED!!! We have never been to a restaurant with a service that was as bad and unattentive as in the House of Nanking. The waiter didn't exchange a single word with us or even looked at us, he just smashed the plates down on our table and went off. 
But what annoyed us most was the following: I ordered a meal with calamares which was praised as "highly recommendable" and my husband ordered the "Famous Nanking Chicken". After some time, the waiter arrived, and, without any comment, put down a plate which, judging from its small size, looked like a on-the-house-treat to us. About ten minutes later, another plate arrived (apparently my husband's, but as the waiter hadn't said anything and had darted off at once, we could only judge from its appearance), but we were still waiting for mine. So, we asked very nicely where my dinner was. An EXTREMELY UNFRIENDLY waitress (or was it the boss??) seemed to be affronted by this question and started to shout at us that the tiny dish we had got 10 minutes before the other had actually been my dinner and that we shouldn't complain about not getting our dinner at the same time!!! WTF?! Normally, you go out to dinner to eat at the same time, don't you? Still, this woman was throwing her tantrum and swearing at us at full volume until all the guests around us were looking at us. But it was not only us that were treated like that. Other guests were also shouted at or bossed around by this woman.
We have never been treated like that and left hungry, very disgruntled and without a tip (the first time ever).
Our conclusion: NEVER AGAIN!!!

One sentence regarding the food: It was okay, but not better than the dishes you get in average Chinese restaurants (where the service surely cannot be as bad as in the House of Nanking).
author: Sarah R.

description:
I'd like to think of this place as a cheap version of P.F Chang - hyped up place serving overpriced unauthentic Chinese food. Mother China would've be ashamed that such a restaurant actually exists!

At first glance, it seems like a decent Chinese restaurant with long lines and excited foreigners eagerly awaiting to be seated. Once you stepped through the door, you'll be welcomed by the thought of spending the next hour in an uncomfortable, crowded, and germ-infested environment, in addition to sitting side by side with strangers. A visit to the bathroom is like a visit to the sewers. The servers use the same pair of hands to serve your food, mop the floor, bus the table, and handle cash transactions.  -2 stars

Now the food:
I ordered the Shanghai Rice Soup, Stir-fried Scallop w/ lettuce and Nanking Chicken (aka Sesame Chicken). The soup like a fancy version of a porridge soup heavily peppered. The Scallop dish is probably the best dish I had there, but pay $17 a dish for only 3-4 scallops at best cut at 1-2inch thick makes you wonder if this is actually worth. The nanking Chicken is simply a chicken dish double coated with sesame sauce served with unfresh eggplants that tastes like plain sweet potato covered with again the sesame sauce. Overall, I could get the same kind of dish at other Chinese restaurants nearby at half the cost. -1 for food

Service:
Once you're seated, the waiter would offer you water or tea. Since this is a Chinese place, you'd expect the tea to be complimentary. No, you pay $3 for a tea served in a pint-size cup. Rice comes at $1.50 - a dried bowl of rice that tastes like it was cooked 2 days ago. When you make your orders, the waiter would try to sell you their more expensive dishes... thanks for continuing to hustle money from me. After the meal, I took out my card ready to pay the bill and what did I get? "Sorry CASH ONLY" -- WTF? Their excuses? "Credit Card is broken". Turns out they try to make their customers pay with cash so that they can under-report their income to uncle-sam. 10 mins later, the machine magically became operable again. Thanks for making me ran 3 blocks around Chinatown looking for an ATM at 8:30pm. I expected other cheap Chinese restaurants to accept cash, but not a restaurant of this calibur! -1

My beautiful Sunday was ruined by my experience here at House of Nanking. This place not only offends my Asian-taste buds, but also is an embarrasment to all fine-Chinese restaurants in America. HoNanking, please put more heart into your cooking, more effort in improving your service, more generous in your servings, and more attention to your nasty bathroom.

If I could give this place 0 star, I would.
author: Vance C.

description: House of Nanking is one of my biggest disappointments. The service is almost nonexistent.; one lady left after being ignored while I waited. The atmosphere is pure chaos, worst than Bart at rush hour! The food is just OK. My sizzling beef didn't sizzle, it pouted like a teenager. The fried rice had very little flavor. Doesn't frying almost guarantee flavor? It did have big flavorless chunks of meat. Yay, protein! House of Nanking was like that 3AM after a club place but fancier. I don't think I'd ever go back.
author: Andrew M.

description: I think this place is awesome. I love their food and atmosphere. I also like how you sit with random people, sometimes that is fun. I have had a couple fun experiences with the people we were sitting with and also a couple weird ones. Their sweet potatoes are amazing. Im a fan and Im not sure why other people don't like this place. If you have never been here I highly recommend you go and check it out for yourself and make your own opinion. I'm really happy someone recommended that I go check it out.
author: Tony S.

description: I'm not a huge fan of Chinese, but this was definitely worth it. We asked several people where to eat in Chinatown and all of them said House of Nanking. There was a line when we got there, and it took us about 30-45 minutes to get through it, but we noticed after we sat down that there was no longer a line, so I guess it just depends what time you get there. The service was very quick, maybe even a bit rushed, but overall very good. If you don't know what to order, try the Nanking Tofu (or whatever protein you prefer).
author: Brandon W.

description:
If you are looking for authentic Chinese food, this is not the place for you. (I was the only Asian person in the restaurant, besides the waiting staff.) Granted, the food is somewhat tasty but after a few bites, you begin to realize that everything has the same salty and vinegary taste. I would group this place with Panda Express and PF Changs because it is clearly catered to white tourists that don't know the difference between good and subpar Chinese food. Also, don't come here expecting good service. The waitresses bark at you and never say thank you.

As an alternative, I would go to Chef Jia's right next door to House of Nanking. That place is much more authentic and the flavors are impressive.
author: k c.

description: I remember when Nanking House use to be a dingy hole in the wall that made real Chinese good and a crazy good fried rice, but those were the good ol days... Now after renovation and being featured by Zagat Nanking House has transformed into an American-Chinese restaurant serving sweet & sour pork and mongolian beef that is way over priced. Unfortunately their transformation has made me lose my love for them. But I'm glad that some of their food still tastes good, just not as good as in the past.
author: Jackie M.

description:
Great food. Bit crowded and noisy, plus the waiting time.. But it's worth the wait.
The lady running the restaurant is a bit rude, does not appreciate positive feedback. But what the hell.. who cares.. The food is excellent and worth the bucks spent
author: Sujay P.

description: This place used to be one of my favorites! Years ago, I could eat here everyday... My girlfriend recently had a friend come in from out of town and decided that we would take her to a sure bet, guaranteed hit... Unfortunately, this was no longer the case. While our out of town guest thoroughly enjoyed the meal, I found that with the recent remodeling, the price of the food has gone up, and the portions have been reduced significantly. We ordered Mushu Chicken which was not as I remembered, and the pancakes (usually steamed) were very dry and fell apart (as if they were stale). The onion cakes just didn't quite taste the same.... all in all I am in no rush to come back which is really unfortunate considering how much I used to love this place.
author: Charles L.

description: Terrible. We were told to go here and I wish we never went. The service was the worst I ever witnessed. They are so nice when they seat you then BAM they are gone. 20 mins later someone came by to take our order. Very rude. Next thing we know won-ton soup is placed on our table. We didn't order it so I asked the waitress I this came with our meal? She didn't understand English. So we ate it. 10 moms later the chicken comes out and the waitress is staring at me. She then says you didn't order that soup! I said I know and that is what I told you. She snatched the soup from us all pissed like it was our fault. 20 mins later my wife got her fried rice. Oh, by a different waitress. Did I mention they SUCK and are rude? We never saw them again. When we asked for water in the beginning it had floaties in them. I tried flagging one of them down to no avail. Then came time for the check. They don't take credit/debit cards!!!! Glad there were signs posted. So I had to go find an ATM down the street to get cash. Bring CASH! on second thought, DON'T WASTE your money on this place. Service was a wreck.
author: Rob M.

description: It will be tough to find a time when the place is not packed.  That's a good sign though.  People don't line up down the block if the food sucks.  The cramped quarters added to a festive dining experience.
author: Ken B.

description: One of the best Chinese restaurants EVER... try the hot flower infused teas, so amazing!
author: Miss P.

description: Smear doodoo flies, no chop sticks, lack of bang, no love, better seven years ago, decent price, still no good, tourists with maps, bang bang, smear doodoo pistols, way better Chinese in Millbrae.
author: Kiya B.

description:
I don't feel like eating  off the menu so I spoke to the waitress about what I want.
The plate came later with sliced sweet potatoes, fresh button mushrooms, shrimp, calamari, chinese broccoli. Voila! All fried and saute with a hint of spiciness.
Best food cause the cook and the waiter do cater to individual likings.
author: francis p.

description:
Do you see Chinese eat there? ummm, nope.
Is their food Chinese? ummm, far from it.
This one disgusting sauce cover all place is a house of shame. Definitely.
author: joplin w.

description:
I've been going to House of Nanking since way back in the day, so part of the appeal here is sentimental. Maybe one star.

The service here isn't great-read all the reviews. That's a given. It's never been. For twenty years I've been going it's been bad. Don't ask questions about the menu. You'll beg for water. Timing always off. The bill will be thrown at you after you plead for it. It's a bit like the "soup nazi" episode from Seinfeld. You do as you're told here, and YOU WILL LIKE IT. This place has been an SF staple for years, it's always busy and they don't have to work hard for your business. Once Herb Cain gave it a five star review back in the 80's the place was destined to have a line outside forever.

The food is very fresh here. The produce is purchased every morning in China Town and sits in crates on the floor. You can see the fresh cabbage a few feet from your feet. No need to store it in a cooler because those babies are going to be chopped and fried tonight!

The ambience is well...you feel like you're eating in China. It isn't fancy. In fact, it can be quite...raw. Open walls. A bit dingy. Nanking used to be very very small and you often had to share a table, but they opened up a wall and expanded next door, so there is a bit more room now. 

There are many many good restraunts in SF, many good Chinese restraunts, especially in Noe Valley. Don't be afraid to try the holes in the wall. But if you're in the triangle, Nanking is always a good bet.
author: Mercedes P.

description: Recommended by a friend.  It is next door to a restaurant recommended by another site.  House of Nanking was packed, the other restaurant was empty so of course we chose House of Nanking.  We were not disappointed.  Everything we ordered was delicious plus we sampled some from the people sitting next to us.  Also wonderful.  This is a small restaurant with family style seating.  You will get cozy with your neighbors.  Service was very quick if not elegant.  We were not disappointed.
author: Phyllis N.

description:
My friends and daughter found our way to the House of Nanking on the recommendation of another friend. I will not be taking this friend's restaurant recommendations in the future. I was prepared for a delicious meal (at least, that's what I was told to prepare for...), and was greatly disappointed. 

I was initially encouraged by the long wait outside the door (usually a good sign) and by a few people who left the place raving about the food. All those good vibes dissipated as we took our first bites. The sesame chicken was oddly flavored and not even my 11 year old who will eat anything was willing to try a second bite. The dumplings were soggy and the dough around them was literally coming apart on the plate - over steamed? They were supposed to be an appetizer, but actually arrived towards the end of the meal. The tea that we ordered never appeared. I don't have anything positive to add here, other than other people seemed to be happy. But the four foodies in our group were the exception to this rule. 

The restaurant is crowed, noisy and not exactly clean. The bathroom was "gross" in my daughter's judgment. Even the water glasses were a bit off...the water was murky and warm. It didn't exactly help to wash down the food or take the weird taste out of our mouths. 

We walked out hungry, disappointed, and feeling like we had to make formal reparations to our taste buds.
author: Maggie M.

description:
this is definitely some crazy chinese food.  the menu is very limited and every dish has basil in it.  what's up with that?  even the sizzling rice soup had basil in it.  i don't really know how to describe this place, it's more americanized chinese food.  not into this place!  

we tried to order the crispy beef, but the owner said it was too much like the sizzling rice soup so he was going to select some other beef dish for us. OK...what came out was beef roll (kind of like mu shu with the pancake), except this had braised beef and daikon in it with some weird sauce.  1. use cucumber, not daikon 2. just use straight up hoisin sauce.  the owner asked if we liked it and i told him that we didn't really like it and he made a face and walked away or something...whatevs.
author: Wendy S.

description: The service sucks, but the food is so good. If you like Chinese food...then you might not want to eat here--because this is real food and so unlike the kind of sludge you are accustomed to eating. This place is a San Francisco legend.
author: Beth P.

description: Since I live in Chinatown, I definitely know the good ones from the bad ones.  I remain puzzled why so many tourists flock to this restaurant, other than they probably don't know any better.  First, the sesame chicken was presented room temperature.  Second, don't ask for tea unless you want to pay $3.  Third, the service was prompt and unkind.  Fourth, all the dishes have the same brown spicy sauce AND is greasy.  Fifth, the food is overpriced.  And sixth, if you want to good restaurant, head further down to commercial street and try R & G lounge.  Don't believe me?  Then go and you'll see: just don't say I didn't warn you . . .
author: Randy M.

description: The Thrill is Gone..ain't just a blues standard. Memories of mouthwatering morsels in the early 90's give way to  of buckets of oil and an aftertaste out of Solyent Green. Don't be a schmo and join the line..dont experience customer service that resembles being slapped around the face repeatedly with a wet fish. However,  if you must, take a tongue comb for that special aftertaste ritual. Oh and did I say overpriced?
author: Patricia M.

description:
eh. ive eaten better chinese food. this place, not as salty as most chinese food, but not as flavorful. we ordered some chicken dish that was good, i think it was sesame. we tried to order the chow mein but the owner, this cute little chinese man, was like no no no i order you something else you will like ok ok ok ok. so we said ok and he brought out their mushu beef. that was pretty good. the potstickers were bad. no on those.

the place is small and the tables are close together. the people next to my table had to put their rice on our table because their table was overflowing. you are welcome we are nice people! be careful is you sit next to the kitchen...i couldnt tell if the waitress was mad or just yelling. i think chinese do that...they just yell. but anyways she was screaming in my ear. it was more funny than anything else. but i can see some people getting annoyed.

i went on a sunday night and it wasnt very crowded. but i hear on fridays and saturday nights it gets packed.

i think rachel ray went there once. her picture is on the wall. either that or theyre big fans.
author: A. V.

description: Went to' nanking for the fame. Wanted to' see if it lived up to all the hype. It was SUPER busy. We got sat next to another couple. I ordered pot stickers for an appitizer and seseme chicken for my entre. My bf ordered the crackling beef. Pot stickers came out quick. They were great. Then my entre came out maybe 10 minutes later. Also great. But for some odd reason my poor boyfriends food didn't come up like 10 minutes after I got my food. When it came he said it was salty. I would most likely return.
author: Brent C.

description: It is confirmed, worst service ever. The menu was literally thrown at us. The food is delicious, but I just can't subject myself or my friends to this place ever again when there are so many other good options...
author: Nicolas H.

description: This place is the bomdizzle. The vegetables were fresh, the meat delicious. It's like a surprise going there. You just tell them what meat you want, beef, chicken etc, and that you want vegetables and surprise!!!  they bring you something they pick.   It was all delicious and yummy.  Their ice tea is pretty bomb too.
author: Swiyyah W.

description: Went there around 6pm on a Sunday.  We were seated right away. The waiter asked if we wanted tea.  We said yes.  It was a blossoming flower tea.  Very interesting.  However,  since I was not really a tea drinker, i would have declined had I known it was not complimentary.  Anyway, an elderly gentleman came to take our order.  My husband said it's our first time and we really were not sure what to order.  The gentleman got the menus and said he'll take care of it.  We were first  served a vegetable dish ( asparagus).  We did not know what to do with it because we were not sure whether it was an appetizer or a part of the main meal.  Then we were served  a kind of mushu which was very good.  In the middle of eating the mushu and the vegetable (which was too salty for my taste), a bowl of rice was served.  So we started eating our vegetable with the rice.  When the elderly gentleman passed by, we asked if that was it, he said more to come.  True enough, we were served soup which was also good.  Then they brought  a dish of fried squid and fish, and finally a dish of fried shrimp with mushroom.  Overall, I thought the food was okay but it was nothing great.  On hindsight, we should have ordered ourselves had I known our bill would reach almost $80 excluding tip.  I don't think I'd be back there....at least not in the near future.
author: Janice T.

description: If you are looking for incredible food, this is the place!  Do not go to H of N if you are looking to linger on conversation with company.  They are going to get you in and out as quickly as possible.  Not much for ambiance...crowded tables, elbow to elbow, gritty decor, rough around the edges...and if you are the type of person who wishes to be treated like royalty when dining out, this is not the place for you.  In fact, Chinatown is probably not the place for you.  You are not going to be shined on, or handled with extreme care.  You are going to EAT.  I am completely blown away that there are so many negative comments on the food here.  I can only guess that it comes from the disappointment in the other dining aspects of H of N.  The food was by far some of the best Chinese food I have ever eaten.  Living in Southern California I have plenty to choose from, but it's almost worth a flight up to San Fran to eat at this place.  Plus, I know I will be in and out quickly!  That means more time for strolling the streets of this beautiful city.
author: Sasha S.

description:
great food, but the service and friendliness of the staff pretty much matches all of the reviews prior.

good food and a san fran staple....give it a shot.  when i walked in, there was a pigeon just walking around the front dining area.  i had the chicken....at least i hope i did.

try fang for a better experience.....started by the owner of house of nanking.  same food, better setting, better service, friendly faces.
author: Colin L.

description:
why do people like this shithole?

long trendy touristy lines for food that sucks, crowded seating (you're always bumping elbows with the people sitting next to you).

it's just another tourist trap like the stinking rose (shitty food with garlic) 

if you must have chinese in NB, do yourself a favor and go one block up to Brandy Ho's
author: Thömas F.

description:
if you are non asian...........you will love this place.  if you are asian............go to San Tung Restaurant!!!!  

i was there when they were half the size and trying to get business.  they are doing great now and I am honestly very happy for them.  Wish you the best Peter, the owner of house of nanking. If i had to vote one way or the other.............i gotta lean towards the other way.  Sorry peter...........you don't need my help anyways.
author: jason g.

description: Yeah, it's too expensive for chinese but it's sooooo good. I am an indecisive person, (choosing the amount of stars to rate a place probably takes me the most amount of time when I write up these reviews) that's why I love this place. Sit down, don't use a menu and just say, chicken or beef or vegetable and you will end up with the tastiest things on the menu. It's good for a date or a big group. The blossom tea is wonderful, it actually blossoms in the glass right before your eyes.
author: Shanna H.

description: my dad said he used to come here back in the 80s and raved about how awesome the food was.  since he knew what was good we let him do the ordering.  let me tell you..EVERYTHING WAS DELICIOUS!  I honestly don't think you can go wrong with anything on their menu.  I was looking at the food the other tables had and wanted to sample everything. haha.
author: Dez B.

description:
The service is terrible, waiters are not helpful and indifferent, I almost felt that they hated me and despised me for eating there. Food is OK, although lots of dishes use the same kind of sauce. 

I've lived in Nanking for a while, the food has nothing to do with NanKing.
I won't go back again and will hate myself for recommanding it to you.
author: Echo C.

description: I don't get it.  I went here with a friend of mine who "thought" he was a foodie.  Most of the dishes were fried and average.  The only thing cool is that the guy picked out all of the food for us.  You just tell him "give us something good".  Tourist trap if you ask me.
author: Mitch A.

description: I have a dilemma.  One the one hand, the food is pretty darn good.  On the other, the service was rude (if not terrible), and the overall experience (outside of the food, each time I've been here...which is many) is generally not great.  Does the food redeem the service?  Unfortunately, with Chinatown near, and so many other options available, and despite House of Nanking's history (once fabled, but now  a long decade of decline), and I have to say the non-food experience ruins the whole experience.  And that's a shame.
author: H H.

description:
I've only eaten here once and I keep meaning to give it another shot, but why?

First off, it breaks one of my many Restaurant Rules of Engagement: If no patrons are of the ethnicity of the food being served, more than likely it's not going to be authentic or good. So I ignored that rule (I walk past this place every day and never see anyone Chinese eating here), because it's the House of Mudderfuggin' Nanking yo! I mean seriously, there's so much hype, I have to go just to see exactly what is generating that hype. I ate there and I still don't know.

  Clearly, if you read the reviews posted in the window and on the walls, back in the day it was an awesome find because A) it wasn't just another place serving the same Chinese-American dishes as everyone else and B) it was freakin' crazy cheap. I mean like $2.95 for an entree kinda cheap. Yeah, if I was paying $5 for dinner including tip I'd be hyping the living crap out of this place too! Even without the financial factor, it's not even close to being great. There's no point talking about the cheap tables and chairs, the apathetic waitstaff who are numb from the cacophony of tourists and yuppies pounding down on them during nearly every minute of the day and night.

I told the waitress that I wanted what they would consider to be their best pork dish and if it was spicy all the better. She said their best pork dish was "pork with mushrooms" and that it was not spicy. Ok, fair enough.
Anyway, I got the dish and it was slices of pork seasoned with what seemed to be a combination of Lowrey's seasoning salt, MSG and imitation butter seasoning tossed in a wok with some mushrooms and onions. That's it. No sauce, no peppers, no garlic, just the naked ingredients on a plate with a side of steamed rice.
Don't get me wrong, I am not one of those Panda Express people who want their Chinese-esque food swimming in sauce, but a good sauce that clings to the ingredients is not only authentic, but adds depth, complexity and moisture to a dish and is a good test of any cooks skills. Not here, just some artificial flavoring agent and that's it! Then again, I should be greatful that I wasn't subjected to some abhorrent, sickly sweet sauce that seemingly everyone in Chinatown seems to think we gweilos are crazy about.

Ummm, yeah. I keep meaning to give them another shot, but when I have plenty of other more interesting, less crowded and cheaper Chinese dining options in the area, why would I want to?
author: Thomas S.

description: I used to LOVE this place until yesterday. I had a good meal as usual. I love the flavors, the lemon grass, the use of peas, and the chili oil in my wanton soup. However, the giant cockroach that jumped on the table and came straight for me pretty much ended the love. I won't be going back.
author: Jarad P.

description: I have 3 (actually, 5) words, here: Dirty.  Bad food.  Tourist trap.
author: marie m.

description:
If you are looking for fancy, you won't find it here. If you are looking for delicious food with no fuss, JACKPOT!

Rather than ordering from the menu, we told our waitress we were all hungry, didn't want beef, liked our food on the spicy side, and she delivered:  sesame chicken with a side of yams x 2 (it's the only thing of interest of the finicky eater aka The Stud Muffin), lightly battered/fried calamari, and shrimp with mushroom and basil.

Food's not 100% authentic but very flavorful (I have STRINGENT standards for Chinese food ... grew up eating GREAT and authentic home-cooked Chinese meals and have yet to find an establishment to rival mom and dad's cooking).

There are no signs indicating this, but: THEY ONLY ACCEPT CASH!

But go anyway. Make sure you visit the ATM before ya go =)
author: Anna W.

description:
mmmm!  greasy MSG!  

this place is gross....i have no idea why people say it's so good.  i've lived in SF for a long time now, it is possible that back in the day it used to be better.  I will never go there again.  people that like it must be brainwashed by all that MSG.
author: Isabel C.

description:
Probably the best Chinese food i've ever had. All of the dishes are great and unique. You cant really go wrong with any of the dishes, start out with some hot and spicy soup or even the won ton soup. The calamari is a good look, make sure you get that when you go. 

If anybody knows of a better Chinese spot let me know.
author: Justin H.

description:
Okay, here's the thing about House of Nanking - it's SMALL and it's BUSY.  That's the status quo.  It will never be not busy.  It may not be packed, but it will always be busy.  Being that it's a busy place, you have to make your presence known.  Most of the reviewers criticize the service - I laughed reading one reviewer who said she couldn't find the hostess.  There is no hostess.  Not really.  There's two or three waiters running around who are also manning the line out the door (yes, there will be a line out the door).  This is not the type of establishment that's trying to win service awards.  They talk with their food.  And the food is pretty damn good.  If you can deal with no hand holding, you will love this place.

Went here recently for a bachelor party.  Showed up unannounced with a group of nine hungry guys.  They said they'd work on it and had us seated within twenty minutes - speedy for this joint.  One of the owners waited on us.  Her attitude is no BS because, again, this is a BUSY restaurant.  So we said, look we're nine people, we're not finicky eaters - you bring us whatever's good and keep the Tsing Tao (their only beer option) flowing.  She did exactly that.  

I couldn't tell you what we ate that night but it was all scrumptious.  I do remember a vegetarian dish made of sliced cucumbers, asparagus and sesame sauce that was awesome.  And any shrimp/seafood dish is to die for as well.  At the end of the night she brought us the check and didn't charge us for half of all the beer we consumed - about three to four beers each.  

One star off because you will ALWAYS have to wait.  Other that that, this place is great for tourists and locals, couples and big groups, anyone who likes good Chinese.
author: Ryan D.

description: What was a fun and flavorable restaurant now has the worst customer service imaginable. Who doesn't accept credit cards? I felt jostled every time a waiter rushed here and there. Maybe they should just open a takeout window so you can avoid the servers.
author: Johnny T.

description: You sometimes can wait up to an hour for a table in this inconspicuous dive serving Shanghai-style cuisine, but it's generally worth it. I actually discovered it thanks to my visiting brother and sister-in-law, who had read about it in the Sunday New York Times travel section. Order the requisite pot stickers and green-onion-and-shrimp pancakes with peanut sauce, then trust your waiter or the owner to choose the rest. As often as I've returned, I've never been steered wrong. Seating is very tight, so expect a din and prepare to be jostled quite a bit. Service is prompt but inattentive once you start to dig in.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I remember when I first moved to SF people kept going on and on about how the House of Nanking had the best Chinese food in the city etc. etc.  then I went and the place was blah, the service was rude, and the food was super blah.  So I never went back.  I swear, that takeout chinese place in the food court at the crocker galleria, is better than this place.  I don't know why people love to talk this place up so much.  maybe because it's been around for a while? Anyway, if I had friends coming from out of town or I was downtown and wanted Chinese food, I would go to the R&G Lounge which is on the same street, before coming here.
author: cecilia g.

description:
Chinese people dont eat here for a reason.  Im sure if they did, its cuz of the same reason I was forced to.  My friend from SD came up to visit and he heard great reviews from his other white friends.  I dread and Im kinda embarrassed to eat here whenever he comes up.  Im a true bannana myself (yellow skinned on the outside, but really white on the inside), so I have no problems being the only asian in a sea of white.  Im the least racist person out there, but why do you only see white peeps eating here?  Why are there never any Asian people eating here?  It says a lot, doesnt it?  Its proven by the yelp reviews here.  Most asians give this place a 3 star or less rating.  All the the others give it 4 or more.  Im not sure why honestly.  There must be a secret genetic taste bud that asians are lacking?  I liked one other reviewers abbreviation of the name of this restaurant - H.O.N.K.  Put a Y at the end and you have the true nature of this place.

The food is edible using fresh ingredients, the service is rude, crowded tables, the parking is non existent, the line is long.  Definately Americanized chinese food.  Im glad they found a niche in the extremely competitive market here.

Go down the street to Brandy Hos for more touristy americanized chinese food and have some of the best sweet and sour pork you will ever have in your life and thats coming from a chinaman!
author: Jon W.

description:
the first time i came here i was tempted to give this place 2 stars.  i ordered the sesame chicken and was not impressed at all.  but the reality was that i wasn't really impressed with the place as a whole-- it seemed to be just your average chinese food spot.

THEN

i came here last week with a few of my friends around dinner time.  got in line before the line blew up and was seated in 20 min.  then, we ordered a few things but asked the owner to bring us whatever he wanted (minus shelfish)

sitting at a 6 person table with strangers is alright with me! i'm not one of those privacy freaks who think that i deserve some sort of barrier between me and the next group.  the party of 3 i was with sat comfortably next to the party of 3 on the other side.  no problems at all.  tons of food piled all around, and good tea too.

in conclusion, this place is delicious and totally cool if you're fairly liberal about your dining experience.  if you're looking for some fancy-shmancy white-table-clothed spot then keep on walking.  if you just want to check out one of the best chinese food places around, then get on it!
author: L J.

description: Most excellent sesame chicken.  This is what I was wanting when I was ordering general gau's from other places.  Also dumplings are delicious.  Definitely worth a visit and totally hits the spot.  My memory of the service has been totally erased by the deliciousness of that first bite of sesame chicken...
author: Suzy C.

description: For the price, this place is unreal. Yeah it sucks to wait outside, the tables are on top of each other and the waitstaff is a bit terse, but the food is ridiculous. Everything is so delicious and innovative. There's a reason their walls are covered with awards - everyone living in San Francisco should come here at least once.
author: Lindsey S.

description: After trying this place 4 or 5 times, I have never figured out why on earth people would get excited about this place.  The food is average at best - there are far better places for Chinese food (Hunan Homes is right around the corner).  This place is for the people who are scared of the real hole-in-the-walls, but like to feel adventurous and think they are being daring by trying this little place.  Maybe this restaurant started off as good, but it has turned into a sham for tourists.
author: B R.

description: The restaurant does not serve common Chinese dishes, but the dishes they do serve are interesting  and sweet. Come and see what the hype is about but be prepared to have mixed results. Good or bad is up to you and your taste in food.
author: Anthony N.

description: I have eaten here twice and loved the food. The third time I ate here made me decide I probably won't be coming back here anymore. We were a big group and although I know that place is small, it's still no reason for our server to be rude. The food isn't as great as I remember, but maybe that's because I got turned off by the service. For the price we paid, I expected better service.
author: Alexsabs C.

description: As mentioned in other reviews below, the staff is very pushy and want you to eat and make room for another client. Our waitress came over to our table about 5 seconds after sitting down and asked us what we wanted to order, we asked for a couple of minutes to pick up the menu and see it. She kept coming back every 30 seconds to see if we were ready to order. Defenitely try out their hot tea which is served in a big beer glass and has a flower inside. We had the wonton soup but it was plain and a very small serving. The fried rice was also disapointing, it was 95% rice. The only item that was ok was the dumplings but not enough to save the meal and come back to this place. Lots of other options out there.
author: favio p.

description: Oh please.  This is not good food, and definitely not good Chinese food.  People need to stop reading the "best of" pages and make up their own minds about what's worth eating.  After Nanking made a couple of "best of" pages, it went down hill rather quickly.  I guess they got a little too confident for their own good.
author: Angelina J.

description:
So I we were recommended this place when we were on business trip to S.F. With a promise of being pleasantly surprised and I gotta say I was.

On first glance this place is a tiny little Chinese place that really doesn't stick out at all. In fact it seems that it is just a cut above any other good Chinese place...We get there and the place is PACKED... in fact there is a line outside the door. So we waited for about 10 minutes and were hurried in my one of the staff. There were 6 of us who had never been there before and the waitress asked us three questions:

1. What do you want to drink?
2. Have you ever been here before?
3. How hungry are you?

A little confused we answered the questions to the best of our ability. She informed us that since we had never been there before that she would "take care of us" and just like that she was gone... 5 min later a younger waitress brought us our drinks. We must have chatted for less than another 5 min and it started.... The first of waves of delicious courses, brought just a little faster than we could eat them. This family style Chinese place...It is a tad greasy and thick on the sauce, but yo this place is REALLY good.  Tons of animals died for my meal, and I thank them all. To be honest I am not sure what they all brought us but the duck is what I remember... I dunno it doesn't matter really because it was all delicious.
I will be back; I would certainly go back just to bring a friend. This experience was one of the bright gastronomical memories of that that trip. 
But...
So I have a few gripes I guess hence the 4 star rating.
 To be honest I don't think we actually saw our waitress ever again. ...and it was like pulling teeth to get another friggan beer. Also it should be noted that the place is not spotless when it comes to cleanliness. Not bad at all but if you have a touch of OCD like me ..its something you think about.  The bill was pretty pricy for what we actually got... but as mentioned before we were not given many options...or any now that I think of it.
So on evaluation it certainly had a few drawbacks but worth it for good Chinese in the city.
author: Robert H.

description: The cool wood decor and ceramic plates were a total surprise from the outside.  The flower tea in a talk glass mug was another.  They have regular menu and family style which was something I thought was cool.  I would definitely go back but take note it's cash only and can get busy during lunch.
author: Rob C.

description: I've been here once and that was enough...it's small cramped and the line is out the door. I can't even remember the food, if that tells you anything. I have never understood why people go to this place, what i remember of the food it was bland and at best crappy. I had a handful of friends who loved this place and I was baffled by it. There are some amazing Chinese restuarants in San Francisco, this is not one of them.
author: Lea S.

description:
UPDATE: 4 months later and my stomach still hurts.

Avoided a trip to the Emergency room!!
Have to be totally honest here. Have been frequenting HON for more than 20 years. Way back then, it was a tiny hole-in-the-wall, fire-trap with an unique perspective on chinese food. It was common to hear the owner tell a group already eating to MOVE OVER, so new diners could crawl over them to a tiny, greasy table. The owners, whom are still there every night were NEVER friendly...you just dealt with it. Even if the service was abrupt, and the tables and general environment was very dirty [can't believe I continued you go here...uhmmmmmmm, cockroaches the size of a small cat], the food was at times, very good.
It's the total lack of consistency that makes me give it one star. Look at the reviews here!!! This is certainly true of last night's [final] visit. The food was NASTY. To be honest, it's amazing that neither one of us got really ill. The rice had to be days old, the chicken, well, fowl, and the noodles slimy. The servers were even more gnarly than usual!
To give fellow readers context, I rarely if ever write poor reviews, but this visit to HON was so egregious, I was compelled to speak out. 
Beware!
author: Mr. S.

description: The food's good here, but the basic ethnic food rule-of-thumb applies: if (Chinese) people don't eat here (and they don't, for the most part), it's not really (Chinese) food.
author: Maximillian M.

description: My visiting family of four was actually looking for Chef Jia's next door, but since it was closed, we happily joined the crowd here. There was no wait on a Sunday afternoon, but the place was packed. The tea was great, had a blossom that slowly opened and was sweet. My kids loved it. The hot and sour soup was very vinegary tasting. Too much so for the kiddies. We ordered pot stickers which were crispy, not soft, but very good. The fried rice was tasty. We ordered only one main dish, as we weren't very hungry, which was the noodle tower with chicken. It was a very good dish. I highly recommend this joint and next time I'm doing what the other yelpers have done, and have the waiter order for me, once he/she knows our preferences. Great tip.
author: Rene W.

description: I went here today for lunch very excited for my experience but I was completely let down. I'm ok with pushy dim sum type service but the food was subpar and not as affordable as everyone claims.
author: Andrea B.

description: Best chinese food in SF, and if you are fortunate enough to have the owner (Peter) take your order, just ask him "what's good today?" and let him take care of your order.  The food is off the menu and simply the best!
author: Monica E.

description: I just don't get it.  Why do people rave about a place that serves nothing but uber-greasy food?  Even more confusing to me is why people line up and actually wait for it!  For years I've endured my friends' claims that House of Nanking has the best food in the city.  I'm starting to wonder if they've ever eaten anywhere else b/c this place is to be avoided.
author: Sarah L.

description: Total tourist death trap! My work catered with House of Nanking for a meeting and there was so much left-over because we all thought the food was nasty. We ended up throwing everything away. I don't know why there's always a line outside... totally over-rated and non-authentic. Try Hunan Homes up the street for some bombing Hot and Sour soup!
author: Annie L.

description: They put the same sauce on everything - and they order you around - and there's an unfathomable line (?!) - I am so not a fan of House of Nanking.   I hate gloopy sauce.
author: Robyn C.

description: I've heard so many great things about the food here at House of Nanking.  However, I've also heard that the employees who work at this establishment are rude.  MY experience is "RUDE to say the least"! We were extremely excited to try the food here.  As we were staying in Union Square, with a 6mo old baby, this past Saturday  we decided to take the oh so convenient public transportation, in the chilly air of San Francisco, and a bundled up infant,just to be refused at the door.  Were they to capacity?  No. Their website says they close at 10P.  We arrived at 8:55P.  As a couple was being escorted out, I asked what time do they close? The response was "whenever they want".  Point being, with such a great review of the food, that we never got to experience, you would think the owner would be sure that he employed more professional and pleasant staff.  End result is, we dined at Bund Shanghai Restaurant around the corner, and the staff was wonderful!  I can't compare the food between restaurants, because I never got to experience House of Nanking.
author: Mrs A.

description: Do not go, seriously! The octagenarian I was eating with who will usually eat anything said she thought she was choking on the food. There's really nothing Asian about the food except for the staff cooking it. They skimp on the meat, don't give you chopsticks, and don't put hoisin on the mushu. Not only was the food nearly inedible but the waitstaff was rude. Our waiter told me he would bring me what he wanted and refused to give me a menu. It was a headshaking experience and I still can't get the bad flavors out of my mouth. I tried giving it zero stars but Yelp told me I have to complete that field. Gotta go I feel an MSG headache coming on.
author: Keith R.

description: In the words of Flava-Flav, "Don't belive the hype!"  My wife and I moved from Seattle last month.  Seattle has some fantastic chinese food, with Judy Fu's Snappy Dragon topping the list.  Everyone said we need to go to the House o' Nanking for an "orgasmic chinese food experince."  I was left with blue balls.  The service sucks.  The decor is grimy.  The food was just ok.  The thing that killed me was the prices.  We dropped $40 on three dishes!  I was lucky enough to get there before the line formed up.
author: Josh G.

description: A friend highly recommended the place to us. We were a large group of ten so we had to wait quite awhile which would not have mattered had the food and service been better. It seems you either love this place or hate it. I am on the latter end of this spectrum.
