I have all the same complaints as previous posters: the food is mediocre, the seats and tables are way too close together, and the staff are extremely rude. We too encountered the Cash Only problem. My friend somehow got the waitress to take our cards ( we were told later they " prefer" cash, so don't let them fool you) The biggest shock of the night was when we walked in and there were actually people seated on boxes of beer! Absolutely incredible. When food was being brought out my husband was elbowed in the face without even a word. Also, my family and I were on separate bills from our friends but we were sharing our food with them. The waitress actually came over and said " this us theirs" and literally moved our plate back to our side of the table. Apparently sharing is frowned upon here. I will never eat here again and will never recommend this establishment to anyway. The only recommendation I will give is to steer clear of this place!
author: Maryann H.

description: Mmmmm....went here when we were up North with a few friends  Our food was quite good. My favorite was a dish with mushrooms and garlic. Can't get any better than that. We had quite a variety of dishes, as there were 9 of us there. A couple of fish dishes, some chicken, some beef. The only thing that bothered me was that we got all of our entrees and never got our rice. We had already started eating b/c we were starving and didn't want our food to get cold, but you try having a table of Filipinos eat without rice.  That is not a happy table.
author: Mariel C.

description:
Have gone here numerous times over the years and am sad to report that the trend is definitely downhill. So much so far a recent rather poor dinner, that I though I'd add my voice to the comments here. Even the signature sesame chicken dish was rather mushy and floating in sauce, the sweet potato were greasy and limp, yuck. Same bad luck with the pot-stickers and rock shrimp - greasy and warmed over. Even the white rice (how can you mess that up?) was cold. The service, which is usually fairly prompt (albeit rather brusque) was so slow, that we and several other diners were commiserating about how bad it was. 

Perhaps this was all due to the fact that the proprietor - Peter Fang - was nowhere to be seen. In any event, I don't plan on going back to HoN any time soon...there are other betters options and places to discover. It's a pity, because this used to be a much better restaurant. I suppose the tourists will still go they because the tour guide recommendations usually lag reality by a couple of years.
author: David E.

description: Amazing food, and must-visit joint during any tourist's visit to San Francisco. Just about the freshest Chinese food I've ever tasted!
author: D. S.

description: The best Chinese food restaurant in the country. Get to this place. It's in the shadow of the Transamerica Pyramid.
author: Montgomery M.

description: Effing greezy garbage -- and you have to wait in line for it...! I haven't eaten here in years -- I've still got a bad aftertaste in my lower cavities. Anyone who eats here and five stars the place is *so* fired. I secretly believe the reviewers who keep nominating this place for Best Ofs are doing it to prove that they can make shite smell like roses with just their words alone. The House of Nanking became popular because it was in some trashy 80's flick with Christian Slater. Get over it, people, Christ.
author: Perci N.

description: Overrated place serving undercooked (!!!) food. I agree, probably a tourist trap.
author: David Y.

description: TOURIST TRAP. Okay, the quality of the food was not bad.  The prices are way too high.  I went only because someone suggested it...I will never go back.
author: Gillian F.

description: This place is a dirty grease pit! I acturally felt sick after eating here. Everything tasted like it was deep fried in greasy dishwater. This was a awful experience. The only good thing about it was the waiter who ordered for us. He was awesome. Other than that it was bad, bad, bad.
author: Critic M.

description: Love this place! They have such great flavors that are different then your usual chinese spot.  Love the House Noodles which are loaded with flavor and garlic!  Also love the tofu with peanut sauce since I don't eat meat.  Service is funny!  They pretty much tell you how to order or order for you!
author: Audrey L.

description:
took a few friends who wer visiting and had to see North Beach, even though i tried to explain there was more to SF than Fishermans Warf and North Beach.
impressed they were as i was again.
author: Mattew W.

description: Relatives are in town so it was either The Stinking Rose or House of Nanking as the token "What a ripoff" dinner.  We chose House of Nanking since they can't get SF-Chinese-American food in NYC.  All kidding aside,  the food was edible but did everything have to come with red onions?  It was on everything - the shrimp and mushrooms, the calamari, the pork chops, and the pea shoots.  And the rice was hard.  And the service was apathetic.  There was nary a Chinese face around until we showed up and the Germans next to us just kept staring as if we were part of the restaurant experience.  Ugh.
author: Pelle Y.

description: I like their colorful sign, and the metal plates are a nice touch, but the food that sits atop the plates.  Another story, entirely.  Every time I go there, I can count the Asians in the place.  That's a bad sign.  Then I actually ate the food.  I understood why.  The food is bland, to say the least.  But since Rachael Ray endorsed this place, it will continue to serve food to those who follow her.  The rest of you.  Just avoid the place.
author: brenda b.

description:
So we came here because we were recommended it by some friends. We came  1/2 hour early, to be first in line. The line got long fast, and the place wasn't even open yet! Most of the people behind us were very touristy type people, so we were kind of worried. We were actually tourist ourselves, but being Asian we were hoping to see more Asians eating.  
 We do like the other Yelpers said to do, tell them it's our first time, and let the waiter order for us. The waiter asks what kinds of meat, we go with fish and beef. To our surprise it was delicious! The fish dish was a kind of salad, that had a dressing that was to die for and the fried rice was pretty good. The beef and green beans was interesting, had a peanut buttery flavor, but half way through it was a little to much. I could have done without the beef. Overall though, we loved the food.
 A little pricey for the amount of food, but it was good. And of course as all Chinese restaurants are, the service is bad, pushy, and hard to understand, but this is a universal truth that should be known by all food connoisseurs. So we didn't mind the service.
author: Leslie N.

description:
Man.  I had such high expectations....
Urgh #1 - The "clean" plates were greasy - like, "didn't-get-put-in-the-right-dishwashing-cycle" greasy....
Urgh #2 - Horrible customer service.  The 'hostess' was rude, the server all but threw the water & utensils at us, and the bill was put on our table the second the food came out (felt like I was back in Paris)..
Urgh #3 - All I got was a green tea (with clumps of various horticulture floating in it -- tres cute, but I had to manually strain it all out with my fork) with a vegetarian tofu/peanut sauce + "mixed greens" main dish (rice was included)-- and my bill was $16.  Whaaaaaaaaaat?!?!
---------------
OK #1 -- Considering we were there on a Saturday night circa 8pm -- they did seat us relatively fast (10 minute wait for 3 of us..?) not bad.
OK #2 -- The food portions were huge.
----------------------
All in all: a let down.  Impersonal service, food was mediocre -- wouldn't go back there, and wouldn't recommend it.
author: Anjali V.

description: I think its called country rice chowder. Get it with beef. Die happy, knowing your life was lived fully.
author: Ambria S.

description:
best chinese food in the city, hands down. you have to try the snow pea shoot salad, and the egg plant. i could go on and on...yummmmmmmmmm the flower tea is wonderful and there are really flowers in there!

the staff is a little frigid, but i think it's b/c they are rushing everywhere, it's busy.
enjoy!
author: rachel F.

description:
I'm sure this review will help you, dear reader, pose as the definitive review for House of Nanking, among the 600+ other reviews.  San Francisco was one of several stops on a road trip, and House of Nanking was recommended by several locals.  Bar tenders.  Natives touring Anchor Steam with us.  Relatives that live in the area.  All seemed to point us to House of Nanking for dinner, and to let the owner order for us.  With that much buildup, we were set for something good.

Unfortunately, all we got was 'meh.'  We waited in line for over 30 minutes just to get in, were crammed in the corner freezing by the window, and made our generic selections.  Something with fish, something vegetarian, a rice dish, and a chicken dish.  Let the owner sort it out.

We were brought fried rice, wet spinach with shrimp somewhere underneath, a bland chicken dish, and an equally bland vegetarian dish.  I was not impressed by any of them.  Nor pleased.  Nor full.  It was overpriced, but I was more upset about how many people recommended the restaurant.  Does House of Nanking give kickbacks to locals that convince visitors to come in?  Maybe there's a punchcard of sorts; everytime they sucker a tourist into the restaurant they get a stamp, and once they get 10, they'll receive a free tshirt.  There has to be some motivation other than malice to recommend that naive visitors eat here.

Avoid it.  There are much better places in the city that are less crowded and much more tasty.  If you live there, see if you can pick me up a punchcard.  I might have some friends visiting and I want my free tshirt.
author: Aaron W.

description: Yes: it's touristy (seem to be mostly from the UK for some reason), the service isn't exactly friendly, the rice is served in dog bowls, and the bathrooms are not super clean.  But...there is something about this place that pulls us back each time. You can ignore the tourists, the owner is friendly and usually stops by to say hello, the sesame chicken and spicy fish are top notch, and, unless my squirel bladder acts up, I can (usually) hold it until I get home. Good enough for me.
author: Eme L.

description: ate here a few times, it was good, hot,  and pricey.
author: Victor G.

description:
i'd give this place ZERO stars if i could.  i had a few friends in high school that loved this place and would drag me to eat here - i thought the food was terrible then, and it hasn't gotten any better.  and the food would make me sick (literally) every time i went.  everything has this same yucky barf looking sauce on it, just thinking about it is making me heave right now.  before they remodeled (terribly, i might add) and took over the place next door , i dunno, about 10+ years ago, this place also LOOKED like a dump, and we often found little creatures scurrying around, or in our food, and STILL my friends wanted to go there.  WTF??   you call one of them up today, and he's like "nanking is so good, i dunno what yer talking about!"  

if you like food that makes you have to stay near a bathroom the rest of the day (and maybe the next too), go here.  and who are these people that are giving it 5 stars?  are they on the payola?  geez....when even a chinese person says this place sticks, you gotta listen...
author: Suzanne A.

description: Ok, the food here is tasty but the place itself gets dinged on account of the cockroach that I saw scamper across the wall and into the ground while I ate my dinner.  Ugh!  Also, I detect a heavy-handed use MSG in their dishes.  Be forewarned!!!
author: Ariela G.

description: I first visited House of Nanking 15 years ago on a suggestion.  It was fabulous then. . it still is today!  Such a pleasant surprise to remember how great the food is and the service is so unique.  If you haven't tried it already and are adventurous, simply tell your server what type of meat you want and they will make up a sure-fire hit for you!  I don't even order off the menu, I just say "chicken" and viola!  A nice, intimate setting and you won't find food prepared like it many other places.  This is a "must" when in San Francisco!
author: Jason P.

description:
I'm very dissappointed

We used to go to the old version of this restaurant, from 1990-1994 at the same location. There is no comparison. What used to be an exciting menu full of garlic and hot spices, is now a narrow menu of deep fried sesame chicken and  few others that don't even sound intriguing. On a recent visit last week, we sat down and practically got up and left b/c the menu was that bad. But no, we had a few things, they all came in the same boring black bean sauce, no garlic, and LOTS of oil on the plate. For some reason this place still gets good reviews, BUT IT SHOULDNT
author: Peter G.

description:
DISGUSTING!  This place is definitely NOT authentic Chinese.  WORST chinese I've had in my whole life.....I'm Chinese btw.  

The waitress was picking her nose - we really should have ran at that moment.  I can't eat flour - allergic and I asked in Chinese if I could get anything grilled, no flour, instead on the fish or chicken.  The chicken came out and was definitely not sans flour.

The stuffed mushrooms were the most disgusting lumps of what looked like turd - basically pork that is so fried its unrecognizable shoved into overcooked mushrooms.

My boyfriend who will eat just about anything could not stomach this food.  We paid for $40 worth of basically uneaten food and walked out...trying to argue with them was pointless because they did not believe in service.
author: Julie C.

description: 4 stars only because you can't sit and relax, they rush you in and out. But food and service is great! We frequent there and highly recommend it. Served family style, GO! It's great! The owner suggests... Ok, pushes you to get certain things sometimes... Just go with it, he's always right!
author: Maranda M.

description: It was my first time there with a vegetarian friend and the owner recommended two vegetarian dishes (tofu and mushroom).  The food was very tasty but I guess it's because of the MSG :P We shared a table with a family and we met a guy eating along who shared his food with us (very friendly ^^)  We were kind of surprised when we got the check from the waiter, cuz the total was $31 just for 2 vegetarian dishes....They also charged $2/cup for the "flower green tea" which I didn't even drink :P We didn't know they charge for the tea otherwise we will just order water instead.  With the tips, the total was $35 which I can get 6 dishes in other cheaper Chinese restaurant.
author: Sandy C.

description: This used to be a good Chinese dive on the edge of Chinatown.  Not any longer.  I have been going to this place  (a few times a year) for over 16 years and this weekend was my last time.  The service is the worst I have ever had there, the food has become so-so and has gotten really expensive.  For 2 of us it was over $50 and we left hungry.  When I complained  to the so called manager (I think he is actually the owner as he has been there as long as I have been going there) he compared their prices to Coppola's place across the street - too bad the food at Nanking isn't any where near as good...I might as well gone to a Panda Express place in a mall!  At least then the service would have been ok and the food might have been better.
author: Debbie M.

description:
Every time we drive by, the line is out the door and down the street.  My husband got carry out just to see what the hubbub was all about.  I ate his left overs the next day and said "I love this dish, where did it come from"  I don't even like Chinese food.
Tonight we have friends in from Michigan and their relative recommended this place.  We called ahead to see if we could avoid the line, it worked, 15 minutes later we were in.
First, the blossom tea is a must experience, not for the taste, but for the shear pageantry.  I won't say any more, go to YouTube.
Second, the owner comes over and asks if this is our first time, we say yes, and he say he will order for us.
All I can say is get the spinach and fish.  The best Chinese dish I have had in a long time.  The garlic bok choy will put hair on your chest in a good way.  The shrimp triangles, I am speechless.  
The only reason I did not give it 5 stars is that the chicken fried rice was mediocre, and the kids did not love it.  A bit up scale for their palates.
author: Pam M.

description: This place used to be good back in the day.  Now not so good.  The staff is rude. They use the same sause in mose of the dishes....go next door to Chef Gia
author: merockin -.

description:
The food was pretty good, but very overpriced.  We had the sesame chicken and the calamari.  Sesame chicken was ok, though I did enjoy the sweet potatoes.  Calamari was good, but didn't come with anything.  A bowl of rice was plopped down on our communal table, so we naturally assumed it came with the meal.  When we got our bill there was a charge for it. 

The service was absolutely horrible and I am very tolerant.  The waitresses were down right nasty.  One actually yanked the credit card out of my hand.  I would not go back here nor would I recommend it to anyone.
author: Emily W.

description: Little brother was visiting from Philly and wanted to give him a taste of some real Chinese food (even if this spot is super touristy). We loved it! Started with the pork pot stickers and the pork egg rolls. The pot stickers were fantastic and served with the most delicious sauce. I was less impressed with the egg rolls, but they were still pretty tasty. For the entrees, the three of us shared the sesame chicken, a special beef dish and the calamari. My favorite was the calamari, but that's partially because calamari (any preparation) is one of my favorite dishes. My brother, who prefers a crunchy breading, didn't like this one as much. We all agreed that the sesame chicken and the special beef dish were awesome. Highly recommend both. We also had a side of the fried eggplant (another favorite) and that did not disappoint. My only complaint is that the food came out almost too fast!
author: Angela R.

description: I've been coming here for years and it's always delicious. It's in a cute part of north beach at the end of Chinatown. It's a dive in the best sense as far as atmosphere, but be prepared for the traditional and somewhat pushy wait staff and crowded scene of an authentic Chinese restaurant (which I happen to enjoy). Get in where you fit in! Cuz it's delish. The flounder with eggplant is divine. Try to beat the crowds and go either early or late and try not to go on the weekends when it's at it's busiest.
author: Nancy K.

description: Decided to catch a late night dinner around 9pm at House of Nanking.  Very disappointed, as the wait staff was not pleasant.  Did not offer water.  Pushed us to pay early.  The beef sesame was salty.
author: Lisa H.

description: Okay, the average 3-star rating for this restaurant is why I hate Yelpers. This place is amazing. Maybe it's overpriced, maybe it's inauthentic, but you know what? If you allow someone to order for you, you are taking the chance that they may not order the cheapest thing on the menu, and slighting a non-authentic Chinese place for not serving authentic Chinese food is about as relevant as bitching at a car dealership for not selling cheeseburgers.
author: Eric C.

description: DELICIOUS!!! As the first meal of our vacation, lunch after flying all morning (and I mean early morning!), it was exactly what we needed.  We were warned that it's a "tourist trap" but we decided to go anyways.  Since we went at an off time, it wasn't too overcrowded, though for 3pm, there were still a lot of people there, which says something about the place.  We ordered the fried rice and the sesame chicken.  The fried rice was simple and delicious, not over soy-sauced and not too much oil, just good simple flavors.  And it was the perfect compliment to the SESAME CHICKEN!  Hands down the best chinese dish I've EVER had, and between my husband and I, we've had a lot!  Perfect flavors, but the key is that the chicken was crispy and didn't get soggy.  And it's served with sweet potatoes, which I've never seen at a chinese restaurant, but it worked and it was fantastic!   The service was all right, not great but not bad at all.  But you come here for the food and it's a home run for sure!
author: Ragini S.

description: This place was recommended to me by a friend & I really wanted to love it but came away satisfied but not blown away. It was very busy but we were lucky to get a table right away & who seemed to be the owner recommended we let him order for us. Now while I usually like that, in a Chinese restaurant that I've heard so much about, I at least wanted to look over the menu. He brought over the house honey beef & sesame chicken. The beef was very good; tender ribs with a sweet sauce but the sesame chicken was dissapointing; no better than sweet orange chicken from Panda Express or something like that. Then we got some really delicious seafood soup with lemongrass & coconut milk which was delicious but seemed more like a delicious Thai seafood soup than Chinese; strange but delicious. Again, I liked this place but I'm not sure what the crazy hype is all about as it was just ok. I probably wouldn't go back though as there's too many other authentic, more delicious Chinese spots in SF.
author: Sara F.

description: hole in the wall restaurant with very good cheap Chinese food. Not a typical place where locals will go, but rather tourists
author: Prescott T.

description: If you can get over the fact that the service staff is rude and in your face, this is a pretty great Chinese restaurant. The food is amazing. Definitely the best sesame chicken I have ever had. And the sizzling rice soup is fantastic, except that it wasn't sizzling when it arrived, but it was still tasty. Don't let the rude owner ruin your experience either, he is just grumpy. But, he has great taste and you should ask him what to order and he will always send something not on the menu that is delicious. Not the right place for a first date or serious conversation. The dining tables are cramped and people are moving around you everywhere.
author: Summer R.

description: Long lines, curt staff, dirty floors, cramped space, suspect silverware, MSG galore, and you never really know what you're going to get...yet I adore this place. And if this is coming from me, a tiny-bit-impatient-hates-poor-service-germaphobe-needs-my-space-MSG hater, you just know it's worth it.
author: Carolyn C.

description: Anyone else notice how it always smells like human excrement outside this place? ever wonder why? that's enough for me to head elsewhere.
author: Erica W.

description: Totally love this place.  You want good fast Chinese food, eat here for sure.  You can go in there...chat with the guy...tell him how much you want to spend..he brings you out the best dishes!
author: Lisa O.

description:
Delicious and different....much better than your average chinese restaurant, with cooler ambience to boot. May have to stand in line, but it goes quick.

And I don't know about you, but whenever I see a line, I just stand in it knowing there will be some glorious prize in the end. This is very true at Nanking...as you get to the top of the line and able to peek inside, your senses will awaken as you see the hot, colorful plates filled with savory morsels being passed about. mmmm...licking my lips just thinking about Nanking.
author: Lindsay C.

description: I can't stop thinking about it.  The best Chinese meal I have ever had.  Don't order off the menu, ask the server to bring you whatever he likes.
author: Laura G.

description: In 7 years of going by this place nearly every weekday, I'd been only once before when it was the old cramped seating.  The reason was that I figured the place was all hype.  But, I decided to give it a shot and I will say that my fear was valid.  I paid twice as much for food / service / ambiance that was not as good as many of the other choices in the area.  I will say I enjoyed the flavor and chicken quality of the nan king sesame chicken.  But it came to our table on a giant sparse plate with no serving spoon and no rice for several minutes, by which time it got cold.  Our other dish was Mu Shu Shrimp and it was very uninspiring.  No tea unless you asked and even then, they served it in these tacky plastic yellow cups.  No soy sauce or any condiments on the table.  No chop sticks.  No fortune cookie.  There's a ton of better places to choose from.  Don't believe the hype and stroll down Jackson for many better choices.
author: Marc S.

description:
Ever since discovering (and loving) Thai food it's been hard for me to like Chinese food.  But House of Nanking has managed to become one of my must-eats whenever I visit San Francisco for a weekend.  I've been a couple of times, and introduced different friends to the restaurant and made them lovers of Chinese food again too!

The wait is almost always a little daunting on weekends, but it usually moves fairly quickly.  I'm vegetarian and have usually gone with a group of vegetarians, so we just tell the waitress and chef our dietary restrictions and leave it to them to bring out what they'd like.  I'm usually someone who likes looking through the menu and deciding what I want, but it's kind of nice to leave the decision making to the cook.  And, I've never been disappointed.  And, they always bring out the right amount of food, so you're not left wasting or underfed.  And, I've come to realize there's excitement in not knowing what is going to be brought out and being amazed every time.  Since we've gone a number of times, we now know to ask for the onion pancakes and an eggplant dish, but still allow them to experiment with other dishes for us.  The reason I give this place 4 stars as opposed to 5, is that because there's always a wait, they kind of rush you out quickly.  The tables are all extremely close to one another, so we can literally listen in on the neighboring table's conversation.  So, it isn't really a dining experience.. but a fun experience nonetheless!  If you haven't been... you should definitely give it a try!
author: Rachana S.

description: I usually hate Chinese food; I find it too saucy and greasy. House of Nanking, on the other hand, is just great. If you go in a group, ask the chef to make the choices. You will get a variety of yummy, creative, filling dishes, and they are often things you would never think to order. The chef  is friendly but everyone else that works there is usually not. The tea is really great, and the one time that I ordered off the menu, I got super-delicious stuffed mushrooms.
author: Cyrelle D.

description:
Pros:
-Decent prices for Chinese food
-Kind of a fun, albeit, random experience - it's super crowded - everyone is on top of each other - so if you want something a little different from that standpoint, it might be worth trying (trying to look on the bright side!)

Cons:
-Cash only
-Seating is tough to figure out if it's your first time - basically you wait in the line that lines up outside along the window, but I'd recommend still popping your head in, as we did both (husband went inside, and I waited outside) and since we were only two people they seated us immediately.  Apparently they take reservations, but I have no idea how they'd control it, so unless you're a large party, I'd be a little leery of the reservations holding true.
-Found the food just okay (and we've had both authentic and American Chinese food and have traveled to China).  We ordered the house sesame chicken, the house noodles, and shrimp/mushroom stir fry.  Nothing was really bad, but nothing was that special.
-Service was awful, although as soon as I walked in, I expected it.  We didn't really leave a tip - just rounded up.  Also, don't be afraid to shout or wave your hands vigorously to get someone's attention if you need to.

We don't live in SF - and when we visit next, we won't go back here for Chinese.
author: Danielle T.

description: Delicious, delicious, delicious Chinese food. Fresh and fast. We had chicken chow mein, mu shu pork and some incredibly delicious wonton soup. Minus one star for dirty plates and not-so-friendly service.
author: Julie U.

description:
i went there because i wanted to see what everbody's ranting and raving about. i could see why everyone liked it. 

because yalls don't knows what good chinese food is supposed to taste like!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! dis place is hella wacked!!!!!!!!!!! let me tell yalls something!!! if you do not see chinese people in there eating, i'm not talking about 3-4 heads, most likely it sucks!!!! the food there is salty as hell, there is a lot of sauce on everything and why the hell is everybody eating white rice with their chow fun??? 

ok ok, i'm sorry for the over reacting. i just don't like bad food.  i don't mean none of ya knows good chinese food. some of you none asians knows wussup!!! :)
author: RICKY C.

description: I went to House of Nanking with colleagues and to be honest, I was a bit skeptical about it's authenticity since it seemed a bit touristy.  I travel to SF about twice a month so by no means am I a local, but I've tasted enough good Chinese food to have an opinion about authentic flavors.  We were feeling adventurous and just told the host to order up a variety of dishes, given some individual preferences to guide the cooks.  For example, one person could not eat very hot dishes, but I preferred heat and hot all the way.  The host, whom I believe was the owner, went to it and soon we were showered with a steady stream of dishes - seafood soup (flavored to invidual likings), followed by a beef wrap, followed by other deliciousness.  My skeptism is gone and I'll definitely go back for more.
author: Bo T.

description: Boring Chinese food. No aggressive flavors. Their "famous" chicken is super fried and the sauce is boring. The sweet potatoes were undercooked. The house noodles were boring as well. Don't waste your time in this lame place. We followed a recommendation, and we're sorry.
author: Lauren B.

description: The best Chinese food in SF!  The onion cake is to die for !!  And I can't find it ANYWHERE in NYC!!   WTF?!?!
author: Denise Ann R.

description: This spot RULES.  My friend from NYC took me there, and was HORRIFIED that I had not been before.  The freshest ingredients, quick service, and CHEAP!  We had the lettuce wraps, a stir fry with yams and the fried rice soup.  I am already dying to go back.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
What happened here? I remember when this place looked like a major health code violation, and someone had done 360 degrees of graffiti in the bathroom, covering everything including the paper towel dispenser. But, back then, the food was good and plentiful.

The cleaned up interior should have alerted me that something was askew, but I had to pay for an an entire meal before realizing this places's mojo has been subverted as of late. 

As we did several years back, our group of four asked the owner to bring us a bunch of house specialties. Our first course was $9 and consisted of a small tomato side salad big enough for one person. WTF-- a tomato salad?!?! The rest of the dishes were smaller, less flavorful, and more mediocre than the dishes they used to serve. I'd love to know what caused this place to change, but I'm not gonna go back to find out ...
author: Jason B.

description: AVOID !! Ugh, the rudest service, and tiny, carelessly prepared, way overpriced dishes!
author: Berkeley C.

description: Wow, I am surprised at the bad reviews on here. We went for a work lunch and had never been. The chef/owner asked if we had been before, we said no and he said he'd just bring us plates of stuff. Yes, the dishes are different than "traditional" Chinese food but DAMN, it was great stuff! The place looks like nothing special, the line was down the block but thankfully we timed it right and we really enjoyed the lunch. Everything was pretty darn great, not greasy, interesting combos etc. I'll definitely go back!
author: Dana R.

description: After hearing multiple people talk about it like it was the best thing in the world, I decided to check it out yesterday. We split up all the basic stuff- the sesame chicken (good), the calamari (great), the beef (good), and the hot sour soup (good). The food definitely wasn't traditional Chinese food, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. The real appeal of this place is that it stands out on its own outside of Chinatown's main drags, unauthentic enough for everyone to enjoy, while at the same time it has the cramped atmosphere and shitty, rushed service to make you feel like you're getting the true experience. The food was tasty, but I'd prefer dim sum or an authentic, huge-menu Chinese restaurant over this.
author: L. G.

description: ate here once waited in a long line had to sit next to random people. the place is very compacted but the food is the best and the blossom tea is unique the best is the nan king chicken
author: Aaron Y.

description: Late nite good service, skip the menu and simply say what you're into and they hook it up. Can be a wait to sit, and the waitstaff can be bossy but just shut up and eat good. good prices too.
author: Aki S.

description: LOVE the Nan King Chicken.  I usually let the owner pick the remaining dishes.  I've yet to be disappointed.  If you're after authentic Cantonese, this ain't it.  Nan King's dishes are very westernized, but in a good way, not a chain restaurant kind of way.  Go for dinner, after the suits have gone home.
author: Morey S.

description: Best Chinese food in town.  Worst service in town.  But I still go cause their Nanking sesame chicken is sooooo good!  And I love their onion cakes!! YUMMMMMMM.  Just don't let them boss you around.  They can be really pushy, especially with seating arrangements, payment options, and ordering of foods.  Just stand your ground and you'll see that they roll with it.  Get there early to avoid a long line.  Oh, and get yourself a cup of their special tea--it's got goji berries and rosebuds mixed in!
author: K N.

description: Hard clumpy rice at a Chinese place. I was going to stop here but...the sesame chicken was tough, the sauce too sweet and gooey, but the sliced sweet potatoes were good. You can skip this place.
author: Mr T.

description: 5 stars for the food, 2 stars for the service. When the owner is present, 4 star service & great food recommendations from him. it's a busy busy place. Don't expect anything for their service when you there. Just enjoy their food & come out fast! Some plates are chipped & broken but food taste good so I keep going back there. It's worth the wait in line to get their food.
author: Sunny K.

description:
All I have to say is, EWWW! This place is NOT worth your money! 

My boyfriend and I came here on a last minute decision for a late dinner on a Thursday. He lives near the area so he always sees a line forming outside of the restaurant. We were both curious to see what the hype was about. 

We ordered steamed potstickers, mushu pork and the sesame chicken. Our 5 steamed potstickers  showed up swimming in enough sauce for 10 potstickers and the sauce was some concoction of soy sauce and corn starch. I don't know about you, but I'm used to customizing my own dipping sauce for my dumplings! The mu shu pork was assembled at our tables with the waitress's bare hands-i felt uneasy from the potstickers swimming in sauce so this wasn't a positive thing. The last dish we got was the sesame chicken and that was best of the three but that's not saying much. Taste wise, nothing was as good as chinese food i've had in my 'hood for much less money. We paid almost 40 bucks for 3 dishes! Everything was lukewarm in temperature and to top it all off, the next morning, both of us woke up feeling SO parched and had enormous headaches-no doubt the result of MSG!!!!
author: Judy C.

description: I know that this is the big tourist trap, but I love Chinese food and I have lived in SF way too long not to try it out.  So I stopped by during lunch and got there just before noon to avoid the huge line that formed right after we arrived and were seated.  The food was super grubbing, prices were decent and it left me wanting more.  The service was okay, not great, but they can get away with it since the line never dies.  If you are in a rush or can't stand tourists then this is not the place for you.  Try it out once at least, there is a reason it is so popular.  This certainly won't be my regular spot though.  I'm sticking with Yuet Lee for quick and good, Tai Chi for delivery and Betelnut for fancy in the Chinese area.
author: Brian L.

description: Cant believe that i never wrote a review for this place. I used to come here a lot when i didnt lived in the city. Their food is very unique and kinda has a sweetness to their ingredients. There is a longer wait during dinner time. I love all their foods here. Just the though of it, makes me want to visit them tonite!
author: Ernie P.

description: Love the food but only if you go with what the staff recommends.  Service is rapid-fire and prices are reasonable for what you get.  Unfortunately there are quite a few tourists but those can be avoided midweek and during lunch.
author: Jill D.

description: If I say anything bad about House of Nanking, I'm sure someone will jump all over me, going, "You just don't get it." You know what I get whenever I go there? Crappy service and roach sightings.  The food is okay... I love the sesame chicken and admittedly, the veggies are fresher than some Chinese buffet, but it's not the best food I've ever had. It's not even tasty enough to warrant waiting in line, in my opinion. I guess if being treated badly by waitstaff is new and novel to you, then definitely go for the experience. But I think there's a lot of unnecessary hype attached to this most mediocre of places.
author: Megan W.

description: From a Chinese's perspectives this would not be traditional Chinese Food. From what I ordered they put a lot of MSG in their food, and when I say a lot its A LOT! I totally had a headache after the meal.  I probably wouldn't come here again. The prices aren't cheap either, probably because they get a lot of customers and they can jack up prices on food that can be way cheaper in hole in the wall Chinese restaurants.
author: Tracy A.

description: great place to enjoy chinese food in san francisco. I really liked the green tee and the entire fresh food we have orded. This place is also quite popular for the local chinese people so it can't be bad ;-)
author: Joerch 9.

description: Have eaten here twice and the first time was way better than the second. Both times I had the Hot and Sour soup w/ chicken (which was amazing), Sesame Chicken w/ yams (also amazing although a little over fried), and Melts in Your Mouth Calamari (a little too fishy for my taste which tells me that it probably wasn't fresh). Overall I would recommend this place but don't expect good service as the waiters are very negligent and always seem pissed off.
author: Kort S.

description: I've never had anything here I didn't like. On the other hand, I've never really had anything that I was then craving the next day either. I would never come here for dinner and wait on one of those long lines for this food. Luckily, I work very close by and have only been here for lunch. I like that the chef-owner will order for you, but, after going there a few times, I have noticed that there seem to always be the same themes. They're tasty themes, but it's like having the same thing each time.  I do like the cleanliness of the flavors, but I sometimes fear for the actual cleanliness of the food itself. Overall, I'm not rushing to go back anytime soon.
author: Allyson V.

description: long wait, small place but food is great.  mushu wraps, chicken w/ sweet potato, beef soup, pork pea sprouts, hot tea totally rocks my socks!
author: Kae B.

description: Based on all of the reviews, this seems like a place people either love or hate.  I have to agree with most of the haters.  I went here on a date, so I had to be polite. :-)  We ordered the Sesame Chicken and the Fish in Beer Sauce (or whatever it was called).  The Sesame Chicken wasn't as bad as I thought it might have been after reading all of the reviews (the only reason it gets two stars rather than one).  The beer fish was soggy and didn't have much flavor.  Both dishes seemed to share the same sauce AND vegetable -- which was unidentifiable by both of us.  Not to be rude, but I am glad I didn't have to pay for my meal here.  With all of the great Chinese restaurants in SF, why go here?
author: Katie M.

description: Yummy in my tummy!  The best chinese food ever, and you never have to look at the menu.  The waiter will most likely order for you, but you can tip him off on the foods you like and don't like.  I do not recommend going on a hot day, because as good as the food is....the air flow is almost non-existent!  I recommend this place to a lot of friends who are visiting and want some good cooking.
author: Lulu B.

description: This is an excercise in trust...  Don't look at the menu.  Relinquish all control over your meal and let the jedi owner/manager order for you.  He always seems to know what is fresh that day, and even more amazingly how much food it will take to satisfy you.  Not knowing what is going to come next is part of the experience.  There's always a line out the door, but the line is constantly moving.  The tiny kitchen is a production machine.  And the floor staff turns tables more efficiently than any other restaurant in the  city.  $$$  They get money.  It's a very personal and homestyle menu featuring flavors that you really can't get anywhere else.  If you crave consistency, don't like crowds, or have preconceptions of what "chinese food" is, than go somewhere else.
author: Kevin G.

description: The food wasn't terrible, but the experience was absolutely dreadful. We walked in, and everything smelled delicious, but had to wait for almost an hour. Then, when we finally got seated, we were 'lucky' enough to get seated by the owner. Once he had finished handing out our menus, he made small talk and asked if it was our first time to his restaurant, which it was. When he found out, he snatched the menus back and insisted upon 'taking care of use. Before we know it, my family of four had eight huge plates of mediocre food in front of us, and we assumed that since we didn't order any of it, and we barely ate anything, that our bill wouldn't be outrageous. When he came with the bill, it was nearly$ 200. We expressed our concern to the only waiter who passed by in the ensuing thirty minutes, who assured us our bill was correct and we were expected to pay it. So, being the polite people we are, we paid and left, never to return again. Most horrible experience I have EVER had from a restaurant, especially one which came so highly recommended by not only our concierge at the hotel, but also the cabbie who brought us there.  Absolutely outrageous.
author: Danielle L.

description:
no chinese customers. no chopsticks on the table. 
also, no menu (well, they have one but using it is discouraged) and no lingering when you're done eating.
that said, it wasn't bad. but i know why there aren't any chinese eating there. and in chinatown that should tell you something.
author: Brett W.

description: We had a pretty satisfying dinner here. There were eight of us and no one felt like ordering, so we went "Chinese omakase" style. We ended up with a feast with plenty of food to go around: egg rolls, fried pancake, calamari, beef and rice soup, sauteed mushrooms, scallops over fried noodles, sesame chicken, and beef with veggies. While not phenomenal, all the dishes were tasty and covered all the taste buds, from sweet to salty to savory to spicy. It's pretty cramped inside and the service is, well, Chinese, but they have this efficiency thing down to a T. Not including the wait in line, our entire party was in and out in 40 minutes.
author: Amy H.

description: Has gotten pricey.  Going here since the mid 90's.  Peter makes some good off the menu stuff if you tell him what and how you want it made.  We go for lunch more as I am against waiting in line for food.  Doesn't work for me.  Totally recommend this place.
author: A K.

description: Our hotel staff highly recommended this place and since we had no clue where to eat in China town we decided to give this place a try. I was very happy with my meal.  I think the owner waited on us and he actually smiled.  I agree with many reviewers that it's pretty much a given that you don't go to asian restaurants for the service, however, it's always an added plus to get pleasant service with the meal!  Anyhow, he was cordial and I really enjoyed our meal.  We ordered the spicy chicken dumpling soup and a rice dish that included chicken, basil, fresh veggies along with steamed rice and crunchy rice cake.  It was definitely different but that's what made it refreshing.  We went on a Monday during lunch and had no problems getting seated and served.  I will look forward to coming back the next time we are in San Fran!!!
author: kim c.

description:
Ten years ago, I would give this place 5 stars.  I used to live outside the city and I would drive to the city for the delicious fried potstickers with sticky peanut sauce, the nanking beef delicately fried with a perfect sweet glaze, and the nanking "thick" noodles with vegetables.

Now, totally different story.  The sauces are wattery and gross and the service (always weak) has gotten even worse.  You'll always find long lines because of tourists but it's not worth the wait anymore.  Try Chef Jia's next door and get the honey chili chicken!
author: Mike D.

description:
don't order off the menu. just tell them what kinds of meat you like or if your veggie. and to bring enough food for the amount of people at your table. i have tried to order off the menu and never gotten what i ordered--but what came instead was always dee-lish! 
yes, its grungy, grumpy staffed and wobbly tabled, but thats part of the 'charm'.
author: Bad Ass Chic K.

description:
I don't know about anyone else's experiance with The House of Nan King, but it was the top place we ate on our trip to SF. Somehow we lucked out and our party of 7 were seated right away late Saturday night (I guess there is a wait some times?). Our friend/SF local asked us if we just wanted to let the staff decide our meal, and we agreed to give it a shot. And it was well worth it! We told them we'd like mainly veg food with a few fish dishes, and within what seemed like moments, we had 6 amazzzzzzing dishes lined up before us. 
We weren't told any names of dishes, but the Eggplant salad and and the sauteed mushrooms were some of the best I've ever had (and I can't usually stand eggplant). My friend's said the calamari and shrip dishes were also grand.
I think our total bill (beer and six food dishes) came out to about $100. We loved this place so much we were set to come back the next day for lunch, but got off to too late a start the next morning and had to hurry to the airport. I will totally be back here every visit to SF.
author: Tori B.

description: I went to House of Nanking today to celebrate New Years with friends.  We've gone several times and so knew what to expect in terms of service.  The good news is that they are still serving fresh and tasty food that is two or three steps above most every other Chinese restaurant.  The overall taste of some of our dishes was a little too sweet today, but the service was pretty responsive.  They even closed a few of the windows when we asked (hey it is January).
author: Dale D.

description:
One of my many eccentricities has traditionally been a blanket refusal to dine at restaurants that consistently boast a line.  I won't get into the detailed rationale here, but instead say that I did wait in line at the insistence of my local san franciscan friends.  House of Nanking was what they promised:  americanized chinese with a surprisingly light flavor.   
We ordered an open-ended vegetarian appetizer and two veggie entrees, which included some fair-to-middling fried tofu and a very good mushroom dish.  The appetizer was marvelous: some sort of onion pancake type thing with a very mild and sweet peanut sauce.   
Since I totally love slummin' it, I found the greasy table tops and cafeteria chairs charming, but I imagine not everyone would.  Additionally, cash is probably your best bet, as their credit policy seems a little ambiguous.  I kind-of wish this weren't the only chinese I had while in SF, as the pickin's are slim in my native PDX, but if you are local this joint isn't a waste of line-time.
author: Annie H.

description: Given the constant line of guidebook-toting tourists waiting to get in, I have to admit that I was a bit skeptical of this place; so when a couple of colleagues from out of town wanted to eat here, I reluctantly went with them not expecting much. Boy was I in for a treat! We did not even look at the menu; we just told the waiter to bring us whatever is good. Every dish he brought out was delicious- calamari, chicken, fish, and bok choy. I would gladly wait in line here for a meal anyday!
author: Sobhi M.

description:
Love it.  I lived in SF for years and now that I'm a tourist House of NK is a destination. 

If its your first time, let them order for you.  Veg friendly.
author: J C.

description: If you seek ambiance...keep on walking. If you seek chatty friendly service...keep on walking. If you want really good Chinese food (not the typical white-boy Chinese food) at very reasonable prices...look no further. I took a Chinese friend from one of the oldest families in San Francusco...he was thrilled (and a bit embarrassed for not knowing about it first) I've never eaten better Chinese food.  If you don't know what to order, put yourself in the hands of the host/owner/chef. He has never let me down. Don't plan on a leisurely meal and a quiet chat over after dinner tea....it won't happen. Your check will arrive a few minutes after your last dish is served.
author: Rellsky S.

description: Moderate to spendy makes the food a little over priced.  Too much seafood on the menu for me.
author: Joel M.

description: I love Chinese food, authentic, american inspired, heck, just chinese food in general. This one blew me away! Not typical but not too funky. If you are feeling adventurous and like Chinese food, don't waste your time anywhere else. This is the best creative use of chinese style cooking, and spices I have even tried.
author: Gabriel B.

description: If you're in the mood for Chinese and you work in the FiDi, you should give House of Nanking a try. I went with my co-workers and our group left full and satisfied. I've had so much bad Chinese that always left me feeling bloated and greasy, but I never feel that way after a meal here.
author: Nathalie L.

description: With the new face-lift and pristine outlook, I was lauding to applause the new and improve Nanking. But, it turned out to be a big disappointment. The food portions were measly and stingy. What happened to the big plates and sizable food? The plates were bigger than the serving size food. I ordered Nanking shrimps and stuff mushrooms. Oh boy, there were less than 8 shrimps and 7 mushrooms. Both dishes were admixed with chopped cucumbers. In additional to that, they charged you for unreasonable rice or tea dollars. However, the menu price remains same, unchanged. If I were the owner, I would increase a dollar on each item and serve better considerable food.
author: Michael K.

description: Not sure whether to give a three or a four. Heard about this place from a die-hard friend. The head chef took our order and asked us what we liked, Mushrooms was I and Beef was my Boyfriend, and he said he would come up with something great, we were stoked. My boyfriend was greatly delighted: sesame crusted pieces of beef, on a cold bed of sprouts, with tempura fried carrots. I on the other hand was greatly cheated - my vegetarian dish came out: a large plate of mushrooms, yes the sauce and seasoning was amazing , but to pay $8 for a million mushrooms was unfair, because lordy lordy I can't eat a millino mushrooms - overwhelming. Would I go there again yes, the sauces were great, but now I am prepared to be mroe specific on what I like :)
author: Sari G.

description:
i've been coming to this place for over a decade, and the quality has been pretty consistant.  yes it is a hole in the wall chinese place.  but there is a reason there is a line out the door.

a lot of times, its best to just let them bring you what they want.  but, if you want to order somethign specific, you can't go wrong with the cesame chicken or the scallion pancackes in peanut sauce.  the pot stickers in peanut sauce are pretty awesome as well.
author: Steve S.

description: The food here is amazing, if a little pricey.  It's small, kind of loud when its full (and its usually full), but I don't mind.  Because I can't get sesame chicken this good anywhere else.
author: Lauren R.

description: Another fantastic meal from Nanking.  One where I don't have to order and the food is delicious.  Last night we were treated to pork filled egg rolls, crispy pea and shrimp wontons in peanut sauce, a delicious shrimp dish served over wilted spinach with roasted red peppers, crackling beef (amazing!), and seasame chicken.  They keep improving and updating everytime we go in, the decor and the food.  We enjoyed watching our tea ball open and flower in the new glass mugs while we waited for our food.  Delicious as always!
author: Kelly I.

description: Eh. Nothing too special, nice place. The dishes are nicely sided however, kinda on the expensive side and can get pretty crowded during the dining hours.
author: MJ T.

description: Don't bother with a menu just let the crazy chef owner dude bring you what he feels like. The food was FANtastic. We came with a person who only ate seafood and no red meat so all our dishes were either veggie or fishesque and even the other four carnivores were satisfied. And yeah service is sketchy but what do you expect? The Ritz this ain't. Please you have to wait in a line outside to get in, you're not going to get a five star wait staff.
author: Cathy T.

description: Not as good as it used to be, definitely not worth the wait these days. For the price they are charging, they should as least upgrade the very uncomfortable metal chairs...Service was lousy too...
author: L K.

description: This is the best Chinese food in San Francisco and that is really saying something. If you come on the weekend for dinner the line will be to the end of the block, and all those people are waiting for a reason. The Nanking chicken is great, I always order it. The restaurant is small and cramped, but the food is great. If the owner is there just let him order for you, he always know what will go well together. If the owner is not there then I recommend the sesame beef. This is a nice informal restaurant with great food.
author: Mike O.

description: This place is yuck. My husband and I went back twice b/c people raved about their food so much. It's still yuck. The other yuck is that if you tell them to do whatever, their whatever special (that contains the exact same vegetables and stuff as their menu) is twice as expensive! Last point: it's the same sauce on all the dishes!!!!!!
author: unhei k.

description: Change name to House of Grea-zee! Wish the food lived up to the hype. Plenty of food 'round the corner in Chi-Town to get all hiphy for.
author: Johnny C.

description: This place used to be much better back when the dining room and kitchen shared the same space. Once Peter started to expand---the quality began to decline. My last visit was disappointing. The Nanking chicken tasted like everyone else's sesame chicken. This is not the same dish that made me eat here two nights in a row when I first discovered Nanking. The salt and pepper mushrooms were good, but the overall experience made me wonder if I care to eat here again.
author: Troy B.

description: If you don't order fast enough they will order for you. If you go once or twice this is fine. Once you've been there a bunch you realize they give you the same thing over and over. So learn the menu, and order fast. It's worth the possible wait in line.
author: Nihad P.

description: This has to be my favorite restaurant in all of the bay area. I'd read about this place before I'd moved up here and had to see for myself. I'm impressed every time I go and am eager to try new dishes. My favorite dish so far is Sesame Chicken..... it's the best! And make sure you order fried potstickers.
author: Laura B.

description: Tell the cook of this restaurant with my compliments that this is the worst Chinese food on the face of the Earth.  And never trust anything Rachel Ray features on her "Tasty Travels" show.
author: Brent N.

description:
Went here for a first date that turned into a verging-on-two year relationship. What's the secret to our success? A great first date, maybe. Really what charmed me most about that day was the food we feasted on. We ordered: "Whatever's fresh. We also like yams and shrimp." No less than 10 minutes later the waiter arrives with a yummy chinese broccoli salad, fried yams on top. A cold citrusy-soy noodle dish, fresh greens mixed within, and a black bean prawn dish--- but not your typical Chinese restaurant fare (i.e., swimming in that black bean sauce you buy in a jar at any Asian supermarket), but lightly coated and mixed with lots of slightly-crisped veggies. I stuffed my face but didn't feel stuffed and bloaty and gross afterwards, because they skimped on all the things that usually bother me about Chinese food: cornstarched sauce thickeners, limp wilty veggies, MSG, and copious grease. It was totally fresh!!! and totally PERFECT.

I'm sad I don't work on Battery St. anymore, otherwise I'd be at this establishment every other day. But I guess that's good, because when I am in the neighborhood I pop in and order "whatever's fresh" and it feels like a perfect first date everytime.
author: Maris D.

description: When I want Chinese food without the fuss and pomp I go here.  The lines can sometimes be crazy.  They move people in and out so fast they never really seem to be a problem though.  They squish you in like sardines and force you to order quickly.  Nevertheless, with a beer or two you can make it.  Even though you get the sense that they just want you to eat and pay as fast as possible, you can't help but take your time with the food. Its great.  Not a place for first dates or romantic evenings.  If you are looking to rough it or just want some good Chinese, this is the spot.  Also, go early if there are more than two of you.
author: Julian A.

description: Terrible just terrible - even gave it 3 times to see if it was a one off thing... it wasn't and don't let the owner order for you.
author: Joe M.

description:
The food here is good, however, a well rounded dining experience is not always about the quality of the food.  It's about service, ambiance, and overall experience agreed?  I went here last night with my friend for an EARLY dinner.  

I was asked 3 times for my order by 3 different servers.  Not only that, I was asked to moved half way through dinner.  Once we were moved to the back corner by the kitchen I had a server glaring at me for 5 minutes (hinting to leave). Once she brought the check she wouldn't leave my side till I signed it.  Once I signed it she ripped it out of my hand, grabbed our unfinished tea off the table and sent me on my way (not to mention she was mumbling profanities in Mandarin under her breath towards us).  I was at a loss for words.  The thing is....  There was no one waiting to be seated.  

worst dining experience of my existance. $45 later:
soup, tea,1 entree and a rude chinese lady 

enjoy!
author: Andrew N.

description:
If I hadn't been standing outside in the cold weather in shorts like your typical tourist, I probably would have been in a much better mood to enjoy this restaurant.  With that said....the line was pretty far out the door when we started waiting on it, and it moved quite quickly, surprising actually.  The line kinda moves in big waves of people getting ushered in.
I asked for something grilled, and the hostess/waitress recommended a fish dish that was not on the menu.  My friends' food all came and was really tasty, Sesame Chicken and some sort of Chicken Patty thing.  My food essentially was forgotten (although they wouldn't admit it).  And way WAY after they had politely waited for me to get my food and then slowly pick at theirs until it was done, did I finally say I no longer wanted my meal.  Instead of comp-ing my meal, they gave me another plate of veggies, thanks for that ....considering I was no longer hungry, I'd rather you comp umm maybe the fish you forgot to bring for 45 mins?
Aside from all of this...I can't lie the fish was amazing.  I also ordered some tea that was pretty cool, the flower opened up while I drank it and was delicious.
author: m g.

description: I was really skeptical of this place, but went along anyway.  I was totally surprised by how good it was!  We were seated right away, and after looking at the menus for a minute, a man came to take our order.  We started to order a few things, and he asked us if it was our first time there.  For half the group, it was, so he just said he'd take care of us, and that he was the chef.  No ordering at all!  The next thing we knew, some delicious noodles, soup, potstickers, and stuffed mushrooms showed up at the table!  It was great, and I'm looking forward to going back.
author: Bridget L.

description:
I don't get the bad reviews here - they seem written by people who have never eaten at a San Francisco restaurant.  Decor is not a pre-requisite to a good meal and I'd rather have substance over flash.  It's a great thing in SF that you don't have to be rich to eat a truly great meal.

We came early at 6:30 this afternoon, so there was nothing to complain in regards to the service.  

As for the food it was wonderful - we had the calamari with a spicy sauce to start.  It was perfect - not too salty, crispy and cooked just enough so the meat was tender.  We had a fish dish (and yes, we had them pick for us) that was also tender and well spiced.  And as even the haters agreed, the sesame chicken was delicious.  The vegetables in the last two dishes were very fresh and were not the afterthought they typically are in Chinese food.  The chicken came with diced sweet potatoes that were fantastic.  

There was not a common sauce in the bunch.  But I don't understand the bitching about similar sauces.  Other cuisines use the same approach towards food.  Mexican - unless you're having mole in Oaxaca, most dishes will share the same sauce.   Italian - cream or tomato?  And using a Thai basil because you're want to incorporate other ingredients - that's the whole damn evolution of cooking and Bay Area open mindedness to food and life in general.

I had not been there in two years and it was better than I remembered.

Bitching about parking, tourists, decor, etc. contributes nothing to the reviews or quality of the food.
author: Polo P.

description: The place is cramped. The service is average to bad. The food is good. The helpings are sizeable and the appetizer are great. The chicken dishes especially the chilli chicken was very good. The vegetarian collection of tofu, spring rolls and dishes were average at best. Stick to meat of chicken and pork and you would be good. It's a decent Chinese place you may want to try out but there is nothing special about it.
author: Arvind V.

description:
I wanted to go to a chinese banquet type restaurant with fish tanks and my friend had suggested this place. So we went -_-  It was packed inside with no asian people except us : \  I tried to look for the fish tanks but they were no where to be seen : (   Ok whatevers, all the waiters were asian. So we sat and looked at the menu as they kept hustling us to order. The chinese writing was so difficult for us to read. The menu was basically all in english and they realized they had chinese diners as well so they wrote some chinese on the side of each dish. So finally the old man who I believe is the owner stared each one of us at the table with a straight face. So we quickly ordered. We got the 'famous' chicken with sweet potatoes, fried fish on bed of greens, mu shu beef, and egg plant.. Chicken was reminiscent of orange chicken (geeze) althoughI like how the sweet potatoes were prepared. It also came with chayote squash relish which was my favorite. The fried fish was good but it came on a bed of raw spinach (smart business, because what happens when you cook spinach?) The mu shu beef was horrible! It came with chayote squash relish and thanks to that. The egg plant was good and I think it was the same sauce as the fried fish. 

The food is decent but definitely not chinese.
author: Keri T.

description: Ordered the Sesame chicken which is rated so highly by Yelp reviewers but was disappointed.   The chicken was  chewy and clumpy, believe it or not, the size of a baseball and difficult to separate.   Overwhelmingly cloy that I couldn't finish the plate.   Food portion was large but didn't matter.
author: Ralph K.

description: checked out this place on a recommendation from our Lyft driver. what a great, unique spot. food was delicious and fairly priced. don't get offended by the authentic chinese hospitality...it's worth it. get the scallop tower with eggplant and the sesame chicken...fantastic!
author: Steve T.

description: Yes, great chinese food - but I also feel like their food is bombarded with MSG.  Place gets pretty packed and I recommend going to this restaurant before and after lunch hour.  If not, good luck with your 10 minute power lunch.
author: Benjamin B.

description:
Heard good things about this place, so I yelped it. The average doesn't seem good but the negative reviews are all suspiciously similar and illogical: "best place in the world but.." "always been a fan but.." "this place has everything going for it, but...", "this is so FXXED up" (whatever that means) 
I'm glad I ignored these negative yelp reviews from obviously emotional writers and went with my instinct... the food was amazing.  we walked in, were shown to a big table and given menus. We asked the chef/owner for recommendations, after hearing it was our first time there he took away the menus without saying another word.. that was the first hint that our dinner was going to be legit. 
Meal after meal came out, and almost all of them were exquisite. Yes, it's americanized chinese, but that's the way I like it, thank you very much: I have no desire for tripe, eyeballs, or tendons in my meals, I'd very much prefer to pay for actual meat, we're not in a starving country of 1 billion people here. 
We did tell the dude to lighten up on the pork dishes, so maybe he substituted beef or chicken in some dishes but DAMN it was an impressive meal. Oh, and for 3 people it cost $100, as much as our meals usually cost per person at more economically-insensitive establishments in san francisco. 
Service was negative stars but.. who cares? this is not the type of place you come to get napkins unfolded on ur lap for you, it's the kind of place you come to EAT.
Definitely worth a trip, don't even try to pick menu items.. just let the dude do his thing.
author: Rob G.

description:
Geez, this place definitely has some passionate haters as well as some die-hard fans. Really, I think it's all about managing expectations.

Expectation #1: There will be tourists. Somehow this place has managed to be included in every freaking guidebook for people traveling to SF. Having tourists there doesn't really make it a bad place (well maybe besides any place in Fisherman's Wharf... sorta kidding), just let them eat their food and brush aside the fact that they might go yapping on about what their plans at the Wharf are later. But anyway, I've only been with my coworkers, and have never been the only Asian person in there, whatever that has to do with anything.

Expectation #2: Because of #1, you may have to wait in line, outside. I've actually never had to wait in line, as we seem to get there just before the crowds do. But waiting for a table is kind of expected for a small space in a generally busy area.

Expectation #3: Service might be slow. The food comes out relatively fast, but for simple things like getting water refilled or ordering another dish, the staff isn't very in tune to your needs. Of course, once you're done, they'll be all too eager to get you out the door and on your way. Oh yeah, not the friendliest staff, but never overtly rude (at least to us). Expect this, and it's not so bad.

Expectation #4: It's not your typical Chinese food. Both my parents are Chinese. My mom cooks like a gourmet Chinese chef. My dad can't cook worth a damn (but he tries). Both make "Chinese food". Get over the fact that just because it's not typical, it's not Chinese. That being said, some of the food definitely has a different, somewhat sweeter side to it. The keys to having a decent dining experience  are
    1) Eating family-style (or as I always say "splitsies!") so you can share a few things
    2) Ordering wisely (or letting the owner order for you). If there are 5 dishes with that brown sauce everyone is talking about, don't order 3 of them and expect different flavors. If there are 6 fried items on the menu, don't order all of them. Variety is always appreciated, right?
    3) Have some hot tea. Yeah, it might look weird with whole leaves and those funky orange pods (completely edible), but the tea will definitely help cut some of the grease from the heavier dishes

So why 4 stars? Well, seems like my coworkers absolutely love this place. I'm pretty ambivalent to it, but haven't had anything there (as far as food) that was terrible. So on average for the group I go with, 4 stars.... but we'll see if tomorrow's lunch experience degrades this to 3.
author: Alex C.

description: I'm not a San Franciscan, so I don't know Chinatown very well.   However, I visited this eatery with a townie and found it appealing.  It's loud and packed in.  If you don't like sharing a table with strangers then you might not want to eat here.  The food is served family style.  We ordered a dish of fried tofu with peanut sauce and the hot and sour soup.  This fed three.  Good stuff.
author: Devon A.

description: Admittedly, I went in with high expectations, & that's probably why I wasn't blown away. The 40 minute wait didn't help, either, nor did the fact that they aren't very good at maximizing their seating capacity (there were plenty of spots for 2 people, but everyone in line was a bigger party than two, & whenever a party of two rolled up, they were promptly seated). Yeah, the food WAS really good. Not the best I've ever had, & certainly not enough to warrant a wait of nearly an hour, but good enough, & it did hit the spot. Minus the wait (I was cold & hungry), I'd give it four stars. In my book, waiting to get into a crowded restaurant should mean the place is balls-to-the-wall unstoppable, & the House of Nanking was just very good, not great / legendary.
author: Pete J.

description: I don't know why they bother with menus here.  They always end up making you get something else anyways.  I'm not into the attitude here.  I'm also not into the dirtiness or the post-renovation space that somehow doesn't look entirely finished.  The food is fine, but Chef Jia's next door is better, cheaper, and without a wait.
author: Squirrel L.

description: Food was ok. I've had better quality Chinese food. We ordered the garlic fish with spinach, house noodles and bao bing wrap and all of them were a little too greasy.  It's a hole-in-the-wall type with no airconditioning and you have to sit shoulder-to-shoulder with other customers. The bathroom was dirty. The waitress who attended to us was rude and unattentive and the guy who bussed our table knocked over my husband's beer bottle which was still full. He apolofized and then walked away without even offering to replace the beer he spilled. So, needless to say, it was not a pleasant experience for us.
author: Eliza G.

description:
based in NYC but whenever in SF I come by HON. By far (and I mean this) the best Chinese I have ever had in my 37 years on this planet. The owner comes around every table, asks what basic ingredients you like (peppercorn, shredded beef), watches you as you look over the menu then just grabs the menus dismissively and says 'I know exactly what you want.' So the owner ends up bringing his own choices for you, and you know what, it works. Everytime. Trust the owner. hm.... just thinking about their food..... why am I in Manhattan and not SF? 

As with all 'best-kept secret' restaurants, there is a line; you wait outside for 30 minutes on average. as has been said before, it's bloody well worth the wait
author: Ali N.

description: Noah LOVES this place, so I agreed to go.  We told the waiter,  "One dish with chicken, one with fish; one with beef - chef's choice."  It was decent.  It was not fancy or healthy; it was far too salty, but, when eaten before it got cold and gelatinous, it was tasty (as with most Chinese food).  The fish dish and the vegetables were the best.  Definitely not an ambiance place - you do not go here to impress anyone - although, we did see famous comics sitting across the room.
author: Shelley T.

description: You'd never guess from looking at this place (if it weren't for the line down the block) but it is a hidden gem between North Beach and China Town. Excellent, fresh and distinctive Chinese food... Just let the waiter order for you. Standout dishes I've sampled are the calamari, the deep-fried potstickers with peanut sauce, hunan beef with steamed cucumber, and sauteed white fish with green beans. Other yelpers' comments on the sameness of the sauces are somewhat apt, and that does keep me from going here often... Everything is cooked well, not too greasy, and delicious though, and once in a while I just get an itch that only this place can scratch. I recommend going for lunch or an early dinner, or being prepared to wait in a long line (which to me is not worth the wait but obviously it is to a lot of other folks) and share a table. Parking is a bitch around here too.
author: Brian H.

description: Not as exceptional as many foodies have claimed in my little network, but still very tasty and the atmosphere is fun.  Its nearly a tourist trap, but the bustle of the owner makes you realize his dedication to a true American-Chinese experience, regardless of zip code.  As many others have insisted, choose your meat and ask him to cook it in his preference of the day.  He won't let you down.
author: Maurice G.

description: House of NanKing in the Financial District. It's Hunan food, which is a province of China so it's a little twist on your typical chow-mein and fried rice. Very small and affordable place that usually has a line out the door, but then again, that's how most restaurants are in SF. In my opinion, the food is worth the wait, the bad service, and the fact that they only accept cash. My usual dishes there are the melt in your mouth calamari and crackling beef. My new favorite dish there is the eggplant w/ garlic sauce. I get a kick out of their tea, it's a blossoming tea where a pre-made tea bulb is immerse in hot water, and after a minute or so, it blossoms into a beautiful flower. It goes perfect during a nice cold SF night. Would I come back here again? Definitely.
author: My B.

description: Good, cheap, easy (you don't even need to look at the menu!) place to eat Chinese.  You may have to wait in line, but it shouldn't take long.
author: Rohit G.

description: I'm sad to have to report that this place has declined in quality over the past few years.  I agree with other reviews on this restaurant, ignore all the celebrities and awards on the walls - they don't reflect the current quality of this place.  Prices have increased while the quality of the food has declined.  Although the food is still decent, this restaurant is really geared more towards tourists nowadays..The owner of the place seems to push for you to try his recommendations, which were more often than not mediocre.  I'd think you'd be better trying your luck at another hole-in-the-wall restaurant if you want real, good, authentic Chinese food.
author: Minh V.

description: If Seinfeld were filmed in San Francisco, this would be the "Diner" that they went to...My brother and I always go, usually grabbing a beer at Vesuvio nearby before or after, or both.  I can't ever remember ordering, usually the owner guy just picks the food out for us...I am a savvy Bay Area epicurean of sorts, and some places, its good to see what meals come up by letting the waiter or cook offer you some variety...The spice of life huh.  Anyhow, I digress, back to the review...so we go in and grab some grub, its not the cleanest or friendliest place, and the line is sometimes crazy, the food is good and again think of forcing yourself into some variety, BUT its the epitome of San Francisco...bunch of different folks from all walks of life coming together for the experience of it, the ambiance...I think that is why I go back.
author: Evan B.

description:
House of Nanking has lost it.   They used to be good, now they suck! 

Will never go back again.  Chicken was tough and stringy, soup was awful, beef was low quality.  It seems they are using inferior ingreedients....really sad it's gone this far downhill, as the place was very good 5+ years ago.
author: Cadillac X.

description: Decent but expensive.  Always a wait. But worth it if you're looking for Americanized and "clean" Chinese food.  Service was typical, rush you in, not much said, then rush you out.  I've enjoyed coming here with friends.  But by the end, not very memorable.  Over rated!
author: Chase F.

description: The hype seems to do the place a disservice because the food is still good by most standards.  Some people knock it cuz it's not authentic enough but I don't think that's the point when it comes to a place like this.
author: Jonny L.

description: The house of Nanking offers a dining experience so unique we call it "Nanking" so it rhymes with "spanking."  No fuss no muss tasty one-trick-pony food quick and cheap.  Everything we've had is good I love having the staff order for us.  Do it.
author: Cory G.

description:
why y'all gotta hate on nan king???  

ok, so maybe it ain't what it used ta be.  maybe the food has, in fact, fallen off a bit (and simultaneously gotten pricier).  and maybe the remodel has killed some of the, quote unquote, "vibe".  but.  who.  cares?  this joint is perennially packed for a REASON.  all things considered, one would be hard pressed to find equally tasty and/or fun chinese eats in this price range.  chunk king?  yuet lee?  bite your tongues, haters.
