the cranky service and the omnipresent plum sauce are just part of the deal.  so get there early, relax, have a tsingtao and let peter steer the ship.  the uptight people should just stay away.
author: Enriquito A.

description: Mu Shu Crsipy Beef = Religious experience.  A definite must for anyone looking for a great, quick meal that won't break the bank!  The tea with the flowers in it was delicious too!
author: Diana C.

description: Delicious -- just don't go there expecting Chinese food.
author: Tristan H.

description: Of course it tastes good.  everything is fried or heavily laden with sauces.  Not to mention that theres nothing authentic about this place.  Service SUCKS and its not worth the wait in line.  I'll go there again only if an out-of-towner INSISTS.
author: Marcia B.

description: Totally loved this restaurant. There were three of us and we waited about 20 minutes outside for a table. Not bad. We were seated at a table with three others, which was fine, and ordered like we'd never eaten before. I loved the tofu with blackbean sauce, although I wish there had been more sauce, and my companions had the salt-and-pepper shrimp and the beef pancake things (like Peking duck but with beef). They were very happy. We also feasted on the green bean and eggplant sides. The beans were delicious but I thought the eggplant was too fried. Three stuffed people, three drinks = $28 each including tip. I can't wait to go back to San Fran so I can visit this place again.
author: Anna F.

description: House of Spanking is the shit! The eggplant is totally edible and there is always parking available.  Definately your best bet for a spontaneous Chinatown meal. Great for when time is an issue. However if you are footing it with musicians I would suggest going deeper into the heart of Chinatown where you may learn how to use chopsticks in a more private setting.
author: fuck you p.

description: This place rawks. If you go - be sure to have the chef order for you - its the only way to go!! Its a surprise but its well worth it!
author: Inome C.

description:
A friend of mine from out of town recommended it as "the best chinese she's ever had", so I decided to try it out. After waiting almost an hour we finally got a table. The ambiance puts a new meanining in "hole in the wall" - the place was lacking decoration completely, dirty and uninviting. OK, I said to myself - we're not here for that, we're here for the food. The waitstaff didn't care much about our experience either. It's just amazing how they can avoid looking at you in such a small place.

The food was the biggest disappointment after all - bland, cold and lacking flavor.. The hot&sour soup (one of my favourite soups) was watery with floating raw chopped onions, like some scooped them from a taco. I've eaten at lot of Chinese restaurants all over and have never had chopped raw onion in my soup. The rest of the meal was not much better. We ultimately ended up having dinner somewhere else.
author: Ivan B.

description: This place gets hyped a lot and then gets something of a bad rap because of that.  I went on Sunday with my parents and it was excellent.  I've tried R&G, etc., and those are good, but Nanking is just as good if not better.  Certain parts of the dining experience can be a bit sketchy (communal tables, less than refined service) but overall, awesome price and excellent, slightly inventive Chinese food.
author: Juan Pablo S.

description: I don't know what any of the 'less than 5 star' reviews are trippin' about.  Mr. Fong will take care of you and you will walk out a better person because of it.  Amazing every time I've been there.  The tofu wrap concoction is amazing. And the asparagus too, and I don't even like asparagus.  House of Nanking will make you realize you can love things you never thought you could.  The only downer is that they could make their dishes spicy, but the sauces dominate their dishes and your tastebuds so beautifully that it kind of doesn't matter.  dankest chinese food, hands down.
author: Caroline P.

description: I admit it, I'm a tourist and I love this place w/the one sauce they put on every dish.  I visit the Bay Area at least once a year and since the first time this place was recommended, it's a must visit.  And on every visit I say the magic words, "I've never been here before."  Who knows what we end up with, but seriously, the one sauce they use is great.  But is it wicked crowded and cold or hot depending upon the season? yes.  And is it always worth the schelp from whoever we're staying with in the East or South Bay?  definitely.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Beth G.

description: I'm not Chinese, but had much better Chinese food elsewhere. The place is adorned with magazine endorsements, but the food was quite mediocre, hastily prepared, and served on slimy bent-out-of-shape steel platters. The carrots must have been chopped by a third grader! There wasn't one Chinese person eating at this place. The food is really not much better than [insert name of random Chinese fast-food food-court establishment here]. I hope you don't have the misfortune of digesting the unpalatable nourishment served here.
author: Daisuke K.

description: Sooooo good. I have never had such good Chinese food.  I had the veggie mushu and something else I don't know the name of that the owner recommended to us. It had tofu, delicious vegetables, and lightly fried pieces of sweet potato. There was a line out the door at 9:30pm in an otherwise deserted street. Ask your server for suggestions.  (Don't worry about the line -- it moves fast.)  Service was good, food was reasonably cheap. I can't wait to go back!
author: claudia g.

description: I notice that every time I walk by this place there is a line out the door, but hardly any Chinese people. Now I know why. I've eaten Chinese food all my life and I think this place is for people who don't  like real Chinese food. It's very westernized, overrated and overpriced. It's one of those places that Chinese people say "tricks" the non-Chinese people. Maybe it was an off day, but we ordered the garlic fish and it was just some fried battered fish with little flavor. I had to add soy sauce and chili sauce for every bite. I asked if there were any vegetables so they said they would add some-they sprinkled some spinach leaves on top and drizzled it with some sweet vinaigrette dressing. Who puts sweet vinaigrette dressing in Chinese food? The house noodles were boring. The noodles were just some cheap re-hydrated noodles worth a few cents. The menu said it would come with garlic vegetables so I was expecting real pieces of vegetables, but they just sprinkled some raw pea sprout leaves and a few julienned pieces of cucumber. I just tasted soy sauce, hardly any other flavor. The dish was $8.95 I believe. For this price I could get some hand pulled noodles with meat and big pieces of vegetables like broccoli or bok choy at some other Chinese restaurants. I looked at the other tables and saw a lot of deep fried meat and sweet potatoes covered with some sweet  sauce. That's a pretty typical formula to "trick" the non-Chinese customers- deep fry everything, drench it with some sugary sauce, skimp on the ingredients and then over charge them for it all. I thought at least the service would be better than some old mom and pop restaurants in Chinatown, but no-they were not!
author: Ying L.

description: The atmosphere in this place is a little weird, but the food was very good. The soup was so Delicious. I believe it was the dumpling soup. If you go there get it. We also got the melt in your mouth calamari. It was good and lemony. Great food here and can't wait to go back and try more.
author: Shermayne C.

description: Put too much lettuce in most dishes, it is unnecessary.  Food taste good but not as good as Sang Tung or R&G Lounge. I prefer give it 3.5 stars.
author: Robert S.

description: OVERRATED! The food was a tad bit better than your run of the mill Chinese Buffet. Don't waist your time waiting in line! I highly recommend Chef Jia's next door where the food is much better and there is no wait.
author: Daniel H.

description: Fantastic. If you are used to Moo Goo Gai Pan and General Tsaos chicken, you will be dissapointed.  It is a small place with a TINY kitchen but they can crank it out. There must have been fifteen servers/family running around like crazy. It is a hectic busy atmosphere with a potentially long line.  One dish: scallops, spinach and scallions in a soy-based sauce. Awesome. The sesame chicken with sweet potatoes is also unique and delicious.  Almost reminded me of chicken livers. Great place.
author: Brian E.

description: Don't go here for the ambiance or to avoid crowds but if you love well made, unique signature Chinese food, you will not be disappointed. I've eaten here dozens of times over the past decade and never once been unsatisfied.
author: Josh W.

description: The service was brutal at this place!  I would give this a 1 star rating if the rating worked on Yelp!  First I called to make a reservation...and then called back the following week to make sure if was confirmed...the woman hung up on me 3 times when all I was doing was trying to confirm.  Nobody speaks good English, I couldn't find the website either.  We arrived and were sat...the chairs are not comfortable...they cram you in the place.  Then we didn't get menus until after being sat for over 10 minutes.  The server then tried to order for us and then she yelled at us for asking for another bowl for the soup.  All the sauce tasted the same also.  There are so many more Chinese restaurants that will give you better service and more for your money.  The noodles were very garlicy but were good.
author: Matt W.

description: Went back to Nanking again..this time, the food was ok.  It was good, however I didn't "cleaned the plate".  It was more salty and missing the "OMG" factor.  My husband made a good point, we ate lunch at peak time hence the quality may have been less than the previous time.  Robert Irvine from Dinner:Impossible was correct..
author: Susan N.

description: "People love it or hate it; i think it's ok. There's a long line, but owner does pick people to sit first (!). Just leave the choices to him; tell him what you don't like and he'll get you his daily specials."
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
My family and I were visiting the city for the 2nd time and asked everyone which restaurant we should go to, you know, the kind of place that locals adore and would sum up their  local cuisine. Everyone told us that we MUST try House of Nanking so off we went and endured a 1.5 hour line up! 

Coming from Toronto and having had some of the best Chinese food at our own Chinatown (as well as Montreal's), I was expecting something spectacular. I'm afraid this place fell flat. Save your time and your money; don't believe all the hype.
author: Jo R.

description:
I used to frequent this place in the late 90s and I almost always liked whatever dish they chose for me. But the food hasn't been so good lately. Just about everything I ate is either too sweet or too salty. Even when I request something hot & spicy (this is Hunan food, isn't it?) they still give me a plate of something too sugary and salty. After a couple of such experiences, I thought maybe I was just there on a bad day so I went back a few more times but the food was bad every time. And the bill is about $10-12 for an entree and steamed rice, which is quite a bit more than what it used to be. 

I did notice that it is a lot easier to get a table there these days.
author: keith s.

description:
Ordered House of Nanking for a lunch at my office. Literally the biggest hit I can remember. Although the "having them order for you" thing seems to be a price issue for individual diners, they actually gave us a TON of delicious food for a very reasonable price (we just gave them a budget slightly under our average expenditure for a large lunch and the number of people we were planning to serve).
Personally, I found the food slightly more than decent, but when you factor in the sheer amount of food and the enjoyment of everyone else, I have to recommend this place fairly enthusiastically.
author: Jessi C.

description: The best chinese food I have ever eaten by far. If you go, order family style. They will bring you the best of the best. Sit back and let them do their thing.
author: PJ S.

description: If you say yes to Mr. Fang's suggestion that he order for you, don't sit there with a sour face when the food get's to your table because it's not what you expected.  Open your mouth, chew, taste and swallow.  You'll enjoy it.
author: Joel D.

description: House of Nanking is some of the best Chinese food I've had. I make sure to eat there at least twice every visit to San Francisco. The only problem is that you have to wait in line. Carry out isn't so bad if it's busy.
author: R D.

description: Reservations or a list? Not so much. You wait in line at the door until there's space. Then someone takes your order while barely paying attention to you. Then this fantastically yummy food shows up. Seriously, this was some of the best Chinese food I've had. Great flavor, and not overpoweringly cloying sauces. Skip the soup though - the wonton soup had the most bland, uninspired broth I've encountered. It might as well have been water with hot oil in it.
author: Don H.

description: So ok..after much tugging and pulling from my good friend, we finally made it to Nanking..Went there for dinner and found parking on the street curiously fast..i think we were just lucky..but i can see a problem during busy times due to the location of the restaurant..but its definitely worth the hunt because the food really speaks for itself. Our friend Harry comes here almost every week or maybe daily to get his fix I'm not sure but he comes so much that the Chef/owner knows him by face. He tells the Chef to bring anything on our table! WHOA!! Letting the chef bring whatever was a first for me...first course was a spicy won-ton soup with bits of veggies and chicken..the flavor was clean, not too spicy but it was perfect for the occasion due to the cold weather.. second course was my favorite..Scallop tower..ahh yum..it was a marinated seared scallop on top of a thinly sliced lemon and a round roasted eggplant medallion, finished with a dark savory sauce..then served on a bed of sauteed green leaf veggies....combination fried rice followed as a third....then what surprised me was the sauteed prawns as a fourth course...It was not even on the menu!!!It was delish..It was sauteed in a garlic/butter/wine type sauce but not too oily then thickened somehow a little to grab onto the shrimp as u take your bite..scallions were served to accompany it..yummyy...lastly we had to have Harry's favorite the sesame chicken..we enjoyed it with steamed jasmine rice and paired it perfectly..The marinate really i think is the secret to this dish..It was not too sweet or salty..just right..it was paired with sliced sweet potatoes and again some scallions.. What a feast! Thanks Harry for the invite and definitely would not take any coaxing to get me back here... I'm a fan. 4/5 judo chops!
author: Dustin G.

description: While not bad, it definitely doesn't live up to the hype.  At least now when I go back east and people who have tourist'ed in SF ask "omg, have you eaten at the greatest chinese food restaurant ever yet??" I can answer: no, but I have eaten at the House of Nanking.
author: james s.

description: One rule you have to go by when judging chinese food restaurants is ... "the worse the service, the dirtier the bathroom... the better the food" .. hence the food here is great :)
author: Jeremy R.

description: How do they prepare the excellent food dished out here in that tiny kitchen?  I have yet to have a bad meal here.  Everything always seems fresh and is served quickly and and while it is real hot.  The sprouts that seem to come with everything are awesome, too!  I have waited a long time in line here a few times and will do it again.
author: Buckminster F.

description: Americanized Chinese food at it's best.  So sweet and saucy the tourists love it.  This is such a breath of fresh air compared to the many authentic Chinese food places in Chinatown.
author: Jimmy T.

description:
anything with peanut sauce

but really
the onion pancakes
and the sesame chicken
are divine

(eat the green fruit!)
author: Eva S.

description: My fat friends LOVE this place - I think it's greasy and gross.
author: Quartknee K.

description: An amazing experience -- just agree with anything the wait staff says and hold on for the ride.
author: Billy A.

description:
We've been here twice and have loved the food both times. Our last visit something was a bit salty (I can't remember what) but it was still good, and only a small part of what we had. It's a great little place, always packed and loud, so it's a cool stop in the bustling City. Orders come on large plates meant to be shared. Line can be long, but you can always go to the San Francisco Brewing Company just around the corner on Columbus for a cocktail or beer, or take a walk around... the line moves fast!
A lively atmosphere and really good food. I've always thought the staff was OK, they're just not overly American, so they don't engage in conversation. The funny thing is, the poor bastards who own the other Chinese food places nearby are always sitting, by themselves, in their empty restaurants looking hopefully at passersby as they, well, pass by! This place has locked up the local business!
author: Kai T.

description: Yum. That pretty much sums it up. I went here on the advice of a friend, and was almost deterred by the long line. However, we braved it out, and less that half an hour later, were treated to an excellent chinese meal. Not much for decor, although the wall lined with glowing reviews and awards pretty much sums it up. All of the food was great, but the calamari is really something to write home about. A huge amount of food for three people (including drinks) for just $60. Highly recommended.
author: Dana L.

description:
umm... so with all the hype, i thought this place would be awesome. it was... eh, okay. we had the fried tofu and sesame chicken and shrimp fried rice. 

the owner, well... he was a little odd. he didn't speak to us. just came up to us with his pad and took our orders without a word. 

we waited forever for our friend rice. after trying to flag down a waitress, we finally got someone to check on the rice for us... anyway... it came minutes later.

it's really packed and it smells good inside... but the food is eh, okay. nothing special.
author: Mei N.

description: Targeted more for the tourist. Ordered two different dishes but turned out similar taste but just different meat and different colored sauce.
author: Yan M.

description: Cheap and Cheerful at its greatest. Don't order from the menu - just tell the waiter what you like (chicken, eggplant, beer) and it will come steaming and hot (except the beer) and slammed on to your table. Ridiculously cheap, too. Oh, and if you want good service, go to a high-priced-ass-kissing-the-food-ain't-worth-$50-an-entree type place (Don't use the loo, though, as it will scare you.)
author: Mi M.

description: I've lived in Chinatown for many years...we used to call this place the tourist rip off place. Basically, you'll be ripped off of your time when you wait on the sidewalk for mediocre food.  I find everything way too sweet. It is as if they poured hoisin/plum sauce in every dish. If you like sweet stuff & don't mind the wait then this is your place. There are so many other Chinese restaurants I'd rather go to in the area
author: Jenny W.

description:
I've now given House of Nanking a few tries, and each time I've been disappointed. I had it for take out and also dining in, and each time the service is horrible (the servers are pushy and don't even think of asking them any questions), the food is only so-so, and worst of all, EVERY single time they've gotten my order wrong. I've gotten the complete wrong dishes each time I've been there, even when I dine in. 

I'm sad it gets so much hype just because it got listed in some tourist book. For tourists, fine; for locals, no way. And because it was listed in the book, there is always a ridiculous wait for the not-so-great food. 

If you are looking for another Chinese option in the area, I prefer Chef Jia's which is right next door. It's less crowded, better service, and much better food.
author: Kate M.

description: Speaking as a tourist, I love this place....service is not great, the lines can be long, but the food is quite good.  I love the eggplant and the dumplings.  Lat time there I actually ordered off the menu, I was more accustomed to the owner just picking for you, which never bothered us.
author: Joe N.

description: It's hard to get in with a big group, but with just a few people, they will stick you wherever that many seats are free.  This easygoing attitude is the only way to eat here.  say how many dishes you want and ask for a suggestion, the server will ask one or two word questions to determine what you should get, ie "fish?"  if you order this way your food comes out faster, and is usually whatever dishes are the standouts of the night.  I trust a restaurant that is confident enough to put their choice on my table.
author: Ty W.

description: I freakin' LOVE this place!  If you go to SF, it's not to be missed.  I repeat - NOT to be missed!  The food is OFF THE HOOK!
author: Gary G.

description: Best goddamned Chinese in the city. I mean, it's all subjective, but this food is gourmet in the sense that the flavors, colors, and textures blend bleautifully and artfully. But it's not gourmet pricewise or portionwise which has made this a gem and an award winner. And I dig the divey feeling. The owner, in the only shirt I've ever seen him wear, a striped long sleeve shirt with the collar up, will "take care of you" of you if you don't immediately know what to order. But he asks what you like, generally, and gives you amazing dishes, so who would complain? The stuffed mushrooms and crispy tofu are my favorites. And the onion cakes. Mmmm.
author: Liss C.

description: Most of the reviews I write on Yelp are unique, I hope, but consistant with the general consensus. Reading the reviews of this place has me really surprised at the number of not so wonderful ones. Being from San Diego (and not Chinese heritage) I thought at first it must be because some (SOME) folks in S.F. are a bit snobby about their food -- S.F. being such a 'foodie' city. At the end of the day, I don't know why the discrepancy. Maybe it's because I am not Chinese and never had Mama cook it the "right way" ? Not sure. All I can say is that this place has the best Chinese I've ever eaten. I certainly would like a bit cleaner place, but it is not inconsistant with the rest of Chinatown. I know the owner is a bit gruff, but for me it adds to the charm. I would LOVE to find a place with better Chinese in S.F. (please P.M. me!), but until I do, this place is 5 stars in my book.
author: Robert D.

description: I totally agree with Henri. We ate here several weeks ago and I'm going back. This is one of the best Chinese restaurants that I've eaten at. Period. Yes, there's a red velvet rope outside where the line can get long after 6pm so come early. I didn't believe it until I saw it myself, but people actually get in line to eat at this place. What's that tell you? The other restaurants in the area where EMPTY. The place is not fancy and they squeeze you in like sardines, but damn, the food is awesome. I'm talking about food that has FLAVOR instead of the typical Chinese food that all tastes the same, just dressed differently. Let them order for you the first time you come, it's an adventure people!
author: Hieu D.

description: Read about it and decided to try it as we were in the area.  It definitely wasn't a mistake.  The chef waited on us, and, upon realizing we weren't regulars, ordered everything for us. He wouldn't even let us order.  We figured we'd go with the flow and we certainly were not disappointed.  Shrimp, potstickers, sesame chicken, and a different chicken dish made for an absolutely delicious dinner.  We did, however, have to turn away the last noodle dish, and after that, the "chef" wasn't so friendly anymore.  Still, despite it's sketchy-ish atmosphere, the House of Nanking more than makes up for it with their delicious food.
author: Zach S.

description: The food is not bad but the line is  too long on the weekends. The servers get you in and out. I don't even remember what I ate there anymore..
author: V N.

description: The first 2 times we went here there was about 12-14 of us so we told our waiter to hook us up since we didnt know what to order. The food was good especially since we got to taste a bit of a whole bunch of different apps and entrees.  Food ended up being $20 per person. I went back yesterday with my husband so we couldn't order more than 3 dishes and the flavors ended up being overwhelming (not in a good way). I would recommend it for large groups to share. That's the only way to do it 'cause too much of one thing will just be overwhelming.
author: anda n.

description: This place has a bit of a cult following, and for good reason. The food is good and the location a short walk from downtown without having to deal with the crowds in China Town.
author: Sara W.

description: recommend going here for lunch instead of dinner to avoid the long lines.  have been here a few times and always walk away happy.  fried rice, various chicken dishes always do the trick.
author: Kiyo O.

description: I would have given this place 5 stars except the wait staff is kind of lagging some times. I had to remind them 5 times about water before they finally brought it to the table. This is a-typical of most Chinese food restaurants where you can't get the water guy away. The food great! I highly recommend the Nanking Chicken! Mmmmm....I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.
author: Sal B.

description: you guys all have to eat a bag of dicks. this place is so special and if you cant see that then you are small enough for me to squish you like a bug. The owner, if you guys even know that waits on you and vibes you out and ask you a few questions about what you like and takes your menu from out of your hands and tells you "i know what you like. i will bring it right out" who does'nt like surprises....it's like christmas every time i visit this place and the food is to die for  and reasonable!!!!!! they don't have lines wrapping around the block for nothing...so disregard what these ungrateful yelp.comers said.  If you wanna feel like you are a local go to house of nanking, you will feel like norm from cheers for a day. everybody pretends to know your name which i love. If it feels cramped it's only because your fat. I like the fact that you share a long table with strangers....
author: natalia b.

description: Out of this world Chinese food.  Awesome!  Seating is very close and this is not a fancy place - it's all about the food.
author: Russell W.

description: Service is good and the food is simply delicious. Been here 6 times, ordered the same dishes (cos its sooooooooo GOOD).
author: Jennifer I.

description: Top 2 Chinese restaurants I have ever eaten at. Wait in line, and if you have never been there, order Sesame Chicken and let them take care of you for the rest of the meal. Let me forwarn you, the service is not good. Sip your water, because it may not be refilled. But in the end, it does not matter. This place is amazing. If you have not been there yet,  go there now.
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
this is the best experience eating chinese food i can recall. sure, i was more than a bit peckish at the time...sure, i was sitting down with a group of old friends i hadn't seen in over a year....and sure, i'm not generally the biggest fan of chinese food. i could've been full, bloated, lonely, grumpy, and fresh off the boat...this still would've been my favorite experience eating chinese food.

you walk in, sit down, convey any dietary restrictions you may have, and order a tsintao. expect the feeding frenzy to begin before you have time to start up a conversation. not having to pour over a large menu to find a generic chinese dish is a huge plus, especially since the alternative is that you eat something new, delicious, and reasonably priced. being served quickly is a plus because i hear there is generally a line [we ate late on a weeknight, so there was no wait].

this is one of the many great finds in sf. authentic? probably not, but the whole experience feels unique nonetheless.
author: Jon W.

description: I'd like to add .5 to the rating of 3. Even as I waited in the long line, some random person was putting strips of tape all over the sidewalk & even wrote "Try Stir-Fry Mice - Yum-Yum" which was hilarious. Despite the long line & cramped spaces, the food here is pretty good. I didn't think the fried rice was out of this world, but it is way better than all the fried rice made in the city of Chula Vista (,Ca.). Maybe it was because they were in a rush to get to as many customers as possible, but the customer service was horrible & Tsingtao was way too warm. Maybe one day, I'll go to this place when I won't have to wait in line for an hour.
author: Alfonso S.

description: Nanking is what it is, great. affordable food. fun.
author: wayne s.

description:
Not sure why people line up outside for this. We waited 30 minutes, were treated brusquely, and sat at a table that left little room between tables - very uncomfortable. We ordered an appetizer and 2 entrees. My friend's entree was pretty good (garlic chicken) but mine was bland and uneventful. I asked for it spicy (a fish dish that the waiter suggested), but it was not at all. We had dumplings as an appetizer - they were poorly assembled and fell apart at the seem when touched.

One entree arrived first... then the appetizer 5 minutes later... then the other entree.

Stacks of beer boxes serve as places for folks to set plates down for waiters to pick up.

Though the profile says they take credit cards, we were directed to pay cash. I had to run out to an ATM up the street to pay. Not fun.

Skip this place... go next door to Chef Jia's.
author: Adrian W.

description: Sure, I guess Rachel Ray knows her sh**t when it comes to food, and this place IS a good choice for "chinese" food.  (as an Asian person who grew up in the city, i'm always a little embarassed to stand in line outside behind the hordes of tourists from magical places like Wisconsin who unwittingly wear shorts and those silly, overpriced SF logo sweatshirts they buy in Fishermen's wharf.)  the sesame chicken is good, as is the mystery dumpling soup - made up of all kinds of beasts and creatures that crawl the earth.  yeah, it's good, but don't ask for a cup with ice on a hot day...they will charge you extra.
author: K N.

description: Have eaten here twice and loved the food both times. Crispy chicken with vegetables is delicious as well as the Nanking Sesame chicken. Wasn't so crazy about the Nanking scallops but they were good nonetheless. Service here is off and on, the water in the grimey looking plastic cups is definitley not a plus. Would recommend ordering beer with your food and drink out of the bottle. One thing you need to watch for is the bill when you get it, they  tacked on a couple of dollars to each entree. Other than that , enjoy!!
author: christina d.

description: This is THE BEST CHINESE FOOD I HAVE EVER EATEN! I take everyone from out of town here to experience the best. Don't expect any attention from the staff. But who really cares about that if you are eating such good food.
author: E B.

description: Place may seem ghetto from the outside but it's a diamond in the rough. When you go to House of Nanking, just let the owner order for you. Simply tell him how hungry you are and he'll take care of you. Love this joint!
author: Louie D.

description:
I don't care what ya'll say! This place is BOMB! I live in SJ, but we drive to SF JUST to eat at Nanking. The lunch and dinner rush is always crazy, but we don't mind waiting. 
We always get the fish nanking style and the calamari. Most of the time, we don't even look at the menu. We just tell the waiter what we feel like eating (chicken, beef, whatever) and they do their thang! Owner is very nice. We've spoken to him a few times. LOVE THIS PLACE!
author: Edilynne M.

description: hahahaha, this place is so unique in its own ways. it totally reminds me of the soup nazi from seinfeld. I just like to go to this place for the bad service. it sounds weird, but it's very funny. the food is actually very good, not the best like PF Chang's, hahaha j/k, but the food is actually good. the staff seems as if they wake up on the wrong side of the bed each and every single morning. the way they take your order to how they throw the plates on the table just cracks me up. and it makes you wonder... how do they stay in business?... nonetheless, it's the food people go back for. if you're looking for some nice sit down w/ well mannered staff, this place ain't the place for you.
author: Nate C.

description:
I find the discussion of authenticity and tourists here quite interesting. First of all, China is a huge country with lots of diversity- a meal in a local restaurant in Xian is quite different from a hotel restaurant in Shanghai, so which is more "authentic"? Both have Chinese chefs and customers, both are Chinese restaurants. Is the American food at my house in the midwest more authentic that that served in Texas? Seems like a pointless discussion to me. The food I had at Nanking wasn't too far off from meals I've had in Shanghai, but I can't say I've been to Nanjing, and I'm sure others who ate at different restaurants in China have had different experiences. Sure, Nanking doesn't provide chopsticks, but isn't is less wasteful to use a washable fork rather than toss out all those little pieces of wood? It's a rare Chinese restaurant in the US that provides re-useable chopsticks, so I'll give them a break on the utensil front. Regardless, the food at House of Nanking was good, and if you really want "authentic" Chinese food, go to China. Second, someone wrote in their review that Nanking was good for tourists because it was different than what they get in their smaller cities. Ok, SF isn't the biggest city in the US, so some tourists come from bigger cities (like my Chicago-raised self), and many other cities have good Chinese food, including, in my personal experience, Chicago, New York, Seattle, Honolulu and Kansas City, among many others. Also, on the Friday afternoon that I ate at Nanking most of the other customers appeared to be businesspeople from the Financial District and college-aged kids. Sorry for the rant, but it needed to be said.

Overall Nanking was a good dining experience. The woman who served us ordered for us, usually I don't mind this as if often leads to one of their best liked/best prepared dishes. If you are in the mood for something specific, ask, but if you are laid back enough to deal with the surprise, let them order for you and chock it up to "experience." The veggie dish we had was quite good, tasty asparagus and peppers in a sauce that was a tad oily, but nicely spiced. The shrimp and mushroom dish was fantastic, the shrimp were beautifully flavored and the mushrooms cooked to the point of savory perfection. The white rice we were served was ok, a little on the dry side. The hot tea was awesome, floral and delicate, served in a generously sized mug. The restaurant is cramped and small, and the atmosphere a little rough around the edges, but the food was worth it. Friday at a little after 1pm we didn't have to wait for a table for two. Slightly high priced, but really good food.

ps- MSG does not give you a headache, that myth was debunked long ago (see NYTimes 3-5-08)
author: Alison M.

description:
The sesame chicken with sweet potato was amazing.  I absolutely loved the pea shoot salad as well.  The tea was fairly captivating as you watch the blossom unfold in your steaming glass beer mug.

Service was... well, not great.  They forgot our menus at first and we were trying to share a menu with the guy sitting 2 inches away from us.  If you're looking for attentive waitstaff and a quiet meal, then this is probably not the place for you.

The food is great.  Fresh, good ingredients, non-traditional, and super tasty.  1 star deduction for the jam packed quarters, absent service,  & loitering tourists.
author: Kelly W.

description: I'm glad I finally got to try this place!  When I eat Chinese, I usually go with my family but Chinese people don't eat here so I never got the chance to try it.  It's really really good food and I was intrigued by the way we ended up ordering...something with those greens there(points to next table) and with tofu and something good with shrimp.  It was unique, fusion, westernized, creative Chinese.....whatever you want to call it, it was GOOD.
author: Debbie Y.

description:
4.5 star rating for food. really good. not the best in SF China-town though.
- 1.5 for service. we had to ask for water 3 x's.
potpourri in water is not tea!
the over size plates or under sized tables. we ordered 2 dishes and we practically had to place the  bowl/plates on our laps.
and their restroom. you think with all that business, they could have renovated it a bit. at least get a separate store room.

(5 star rating  for my date. hehehe.)
author: Kione E.

description: One of the best dining experiences of my life!  Yes, the line is super long, so don't go with a big group of people.  Best to go one other, max 4.  They seat people as tables open, so if you are a big group, you might get skipped.  The chef comes around and takes a look at your group and pretty much orders for you if you let him.  I suggest you let him.  The food is so tasty my mouth is watering right now just thinking about it.  If you're ever up in this area, it is worth going to!!
author: E T.

description: This is my first ever 1 star review. First of all, i do not understand why people love this place. After a long wait outside, my group of 4 was finally sat at a table for 6, where they also sat two random people. the restaurant was jam packed to the point that it was almost impossible to sit down. my mom used the restroom which she said was horrifying and she also saw some of the food prep area which she was concerned about. The food that we ordered was terrible -- not fresh, not flavorful, not quality ingredients. our server was terse and hurried, and she and the other waitstaff were wearing surgical gloves which was really offputting. by the end, we couldn't wait to get out of there into the fresh air. I was so disappointed having read good Yelp reviews - this was the first time Yelp really let me down.
author: rachel s.

description:
i like the food at house of nanking.
i wouldn't stand in line to go here though...
luckily whenever i've gone it hasn't been packed...
the food tastes different than most other chinese restaurants... maybe that's why i like it... cus i'm generally  not a big fan of most chinese food... unless it's the type of chinese food they have in korea... authentic or not i'm not sure but it tastes fresh to me at least...
author: charlotte s.

description:
great fresh Chinese food! 

it's a little over priced, but then again its right in the middle of tourist central. if you go on a Friday or Saturday night you will literally wait an hour outside to be seated and some how, ordering food, getting it to your table and eating it only takes about 15 minutes. other then that i would definitely recommend checking out their food!
author: Ashley M.

description: Hands down, this is the best chinese food you will ever have, in SF, NYC or otherwise. The line is long and the seating is crowded, but its worth it. Don't order, just let the longtime owner chef "take care of you." But make sure you have the seasame chicken....the Chinese restaurant down the street will never taste as good after being here.
author: Sarah Y.

description: I love House of Nanking. The food is amazing and the combinations are fun and tasty. The ingredients are high quality and because of this  the food is absolutely delicious and not heavy like other places. The tea is really neat, it comes out in this little bud and as it steeps it begins to "bloom" and has a sweet taste. I love the laid back environment. This place is really about the food. The only draw backs are parking (hey, you are in the city) and long lines, so be prepared to wait. It's worth it.
author: Amy W.

description: Had the sesame chicken and house noodles... Exactly 24 hours later had food poisoning. Avoid this place!
author: Julie L.

description: After a nice stroll touring victorians in Pacific hts, we headed to nanking with a recently aquired friend along our trip.  A short ten minute wait, and we were seated.  Fun,colorful from people to thieir logo, the bossy but charismatic server lady told us what to order - fish soup with noodles and share that. If we're still hungry then order sesame chicken, after that if we still hungry, order squid.  So we followed her instructions, and ordered all three.  Wows and ohhhs were exchanged and the day was filled now with euphoric food coma.  The squid was butter soft, sprinkled with vinagary hot sauce.  Orange chicken... Was yummy, but we agreed that the taste resembles Panda's orange chicken.  The fish soup indeed was huge, good thing we had our new friend with us, or we would've cried from not being able to finish this coconut milk based fish soup. Lots of flavors, colorful people, communal table creating interesting exchange of adjatives... What more would you ask for?
author: Mindee C.

description:
Horrible service - we had to asked our initial waitress twice for waters and two additional waitresses two times a piece before our drinks finally arrived.  We had ordered an appetizer as well as three dishes, and all were there before the drinks.  

I had heard good things about this restaurant, but the food was just okay.  It was the same overly fried food laden in sauces that you would find anywhere.  Fortunately, we did not have to wait, as it is definitely nothing special and not worth any time in line.  

Chef Jia's next door is definitely better, and there is hardly ever any wait.
author: Christina F.

description:
How did this get down to 3 stars. It rocks! I eat here every time I come to SF. I enjoy a good dive and this place has some of the best Chinese food I have ever eaten. My favorites are the sesame chicken and the onion cake.  Two people could easily split this and walk away full. If you think you will still be hungry just order some of their delicious soup to go with it. The stir fried sweet potatoes that come with the chicken are awesome. The flowering tea is also fun.

Any later than 6 will probably mean a wait in line, but it's worth it.
author: Aaron N.

description: Think of the word "CULT" when you see all the people standing in line for this restaurant.  Once you get inside (which you will stand in line for a short time) then they herd you inside like cattle, throw a menu at you, and walk away.  Once you do finally get someone to take your order they will bark at you when you pause to ask a question.  It must be the new thing to get treated badly, and pay for!!!!  The food was not cheap, and arrived one dish at a time, and when you ask for the rest of your food, they yelled at you and told you "I KNOW IT'S COMING"  Did we tip....I should say NOT!!!   Will be go back....I SHOULD SAY NOT!!!!!
author: L M.

description: I had been here once in the past and did that "no, I've never been here before" thing and it was ok and I didn't understand what the hype was and I went back the other day with some people who wanted to try it and again did the "no, I've never been here before" thing and it was amazing and I would go back in a second BUT not if there was a line which there always is.
author: Maya S.

description: After years of passing by this super busy restaurant on the way to Little Italy from Chinatown, we finally gave this place a try.  This place is definitely a hole-in-the-wall kind of restaurant with cracked bowls and minimal service. Expect to be asked whether you are a first-timer and then they will presume to order for you. I figured that it's a good call since they should know better than us what their specialities are.  I was pleasantly surprised.  The dishes are generous, the prices are decent (approx. $10 per dish), and the taste is yummy.  Definitely try the crispy shrimp with spicy sauce if you like spicy food.
author: Jeannie L.

description: I've had better Chinese food that comes from Trader Joe's out of my microwave. Granted the waiters didn't order for us, but by ordering Nanking beef, crispy shrimp, and the shrimp/pea patty thing I think I did alright ordering. I don't know what the previous yelper's on here are thinking by calling it the best Chinese food ever. I would have really preferred some Dim Sum, but with the parents in town, Dad insisted on being able to see the meat in the Chinese food prior to eating it. Oh, I don't like flower buds and seed pods in my tea either, or having the tables so close to the other diners you get splattered with parts of their food.
author: Rob H.

description:
pre-conceived notions. i think that's what nan-king is all about. i went into it with people who had nostalgic associations, and i had my own about herb caen and the bright lights, big city. so i had a happy experience and several more after that. especially because the master-man just says "vegetarian?" to me every time and i let him take it away from there. it always goes well. not sensational, but well. and the tsing-tao (sp, i know) helps. 

not to get too philosophical on a fast food joint, but i can understand how someone experiencing it without this a priori weight might walk away wondering why all the walls are tiled-- "do they hose down the whole damn trough everynight like some dirty public men's room?"-- and make the a posteriori judgement that shit be nasty. however, it still has a special little nook in the san fran section of my heart.
author: Chelsea B.

description: This is one of the best tourist trap restaurants you will ever dine in. Really! It's cheap, delicious and half the fun is telling them to send out whatever the chefs wants and living on the edge. Spicy, tasty & quick. That way you can spend the rest of the time taking in the history of the area, shopping or drinking.
author: Colleen B.

description:
hands down the best chinese food place i've eaten in the city.

the calamari isn't on the menu but it SO good.

crispy beef is great too.

not the most amazing service but the food completely overshadows that.
author: Taylor S.

description: Dive-y and full of MSG.  it's a chinese restaurant on the edge of chintown and the sleazy section of broadway.  What did you expect?  the food is addictive and delicous.  and i love it.
author: Alyssa W.

description: I really liked this place. Yes, there was a wait outside for about half an hour but the food was delicious as was the tea. No complaints here other than it was a tad cramped, boo hoo.
author: lisa h.

description:
Here's how the deal goes down at this place.
Tell your waiter that you're veg, and that you like yam, tofu, sprouts, the rice chowder, and mushrooms.
(NOTE: Specifically ask for the rice chowder. It's SO tasty and even dairy free!)
Let the waiter take care of the rest of your order while you watch all the people around you make disgruntled faces because they dislike what they asked for or because the wait staff is gruff with them while 6802341324 tourists are hollering for attention like children.
(NOTE: The reason the service sucks is because the staff would rather you tell them what you like and let them order for you. Believe me, if you do it this way, they'll take care of you and you'll go home happy.)
Explain to tourists at the next table what tofu is. Watch them smile in delight at just how pleasant Californians are.
Have your waiter continue bringing food to your table until it is clear that he's brought enough.
Go home well-fed and perfectly content.

Basically, House of Nanking rules. It's just that it landed in all the tour books and so now locals are angry at having to wait in line for a seat at a touristy restaurant.
You don't want touristy? Try staying away from the best fusion to have landed right on the border of two of the most tourist-ridden districts in town.
You got some time to kill? Welcome to the line. At the end is food that is STILL the jimmy jam.
author: Erin P.

description: Visiting from Chicago and this was recommended from the hotel. We would have given 4 stars because the food was pretty good. But it was crowded and when a guy walked in to dine by himself, the wait staff told him to sit at our table. Both the guy and the wait staff had zero manners and zero social skills so the dining experience was uncomfortable. A simple, "do you mind If he sits here" would have helped.
author: Gina T.

description:
I just do not get why people are so crazy about this place? I have been here a few times, and it is ALWAYS the same experience:
* Cramped, long tables elbow to elbow with strangers. Forget having a conversation there. 
* LOUSY LOUSY LOUSY service. I thought about checking NO service below. Ask for anything and you get a dirty look and a rushed, annoyed response. They never return to your table except to bring food, and collect the check.
* Expensive, white people safe, Asian style food. Maybe that is why people rave. if you want safe, boring food, this is the place. There is little Chinese about the food here.
* Did I mention expensive? 4 people, 5 dishes, two teas and one beer was $80 before tip. Green tea is $2 per person for a large beer mug filled with hot water and a tea bag hanging on the edge.
* Did I mention the bad service?
* Everything seeps to be deep fried. They would deep fry the rice if the could figure it out. Even the pot-stickers were deep fried!

Ambience: You come in, you are crammed into a long table of other people, they throw a menu at you, then start suggesting dishes, eventually say they will "take care of you" and take away the menu. Then, they will just start brining you food. Be careful, they will keep bringing it if you do not say stop.

We started with Calamari. It was deep fried, but not crispy as it was sitting in a pool of oil. The size of the dish was rather small given its large $15 price tag. Next we had the Sesame Chicken, their special dish. This was basically deep fried clumps of chicken in a tangy sauce served with sweet potato slices. The chicken was more deep fried batter than chicken, but it was tasty. We had fish fillet nanking style. Again, deep fried pieces of fish with some vegetables. OK, not great,   The house noodles were a sticky, oily, slightly spicy noodles in a bowl with chunks of deep fried chicken placed on top.  Pass, it is not good.

While it rates moderate at $11 to $30 per person, the dishes are small, and $80 for Chinese food for four people is outrageous given only 5 small dishes. Steam rice is 50 cents per person, not bad, but they charge you even if some of your party do not want it. 

Summary: This place has buzz , but I think it is left over from a previous time when it used to be better. I find it noisy and cramped, with bad service and mediocre food at best, and way too expensive for what you get.
author: Owen R.

description: Unbelievably awful service. They brought us the wrong order and when we asked someone for help they ignored us. She was unbelievably rude when we asked her to split the check after we waited more than 20 minutes just for them to bring it to us. Was the food good yes, was it worth the awful service.... Hell no and it was way overpriced. $25.00 for noodles and string beans!
author: Kacy K.

description: Really no idea how anyone could say this is good food, mediocre at best in my opinion. Had eggplant, sesame chicken and chow mein and I think you can find better Chinese food in the food court at a mall. Service was pretty bad too. Don't waste your time.
author: Danielle R.

description: This was one of the worst meals I have ever had . On the way back to our hotel we had to stop and buy Tums.  Everything was deep fried, even the Scallops, and each dish was covered in the same sauce so it all tasted the same. We had eaten here 4 years ago and looked forward to returning, however it was not the same experience. I felt sick on the way home and had one of the most unhealthy meals I'd ever had and I'm not a purest ~ diners beware!
author: Bonnie H.

description:
Don't expect to be blown away by the friendliness of the staff. The service is fast and efficient however. 

Just go and get the Chef's special for the day and enjoy. Every dish is great, from the shrimp and pork appetizers, to the garlic fish and vegetable dishes. 

They have a beef dish with apples that is killer. 

Great restaurant with great food, just know what you're getting yourself into. And get there early, or expect to wait in line.
author: Brian W.

description: Having heard so much about this place, I have been loving every moment I've been here.  Some have said it's catered to the Whites, but who cares.  The food is great, even though there is no duck hanging in the window or fishes aren't being caught right before your eyes.  You don't even have to look at the menu.  We just tell them what we feel like having or how much we want.  It's kinda like a surprise with each visit.  With my last visit, I had the calamari, mushrooms, chicken and yams, salad, and the tea.  I don't know what's in that tea, other than a flower and some seeds, but it does wonders for my quench of thirst after each bite.  I'd give the Nan 5 stars, but the odd sign and tight quarters drops it down to 4.
author: Vu T.

description: House of Nan King is yet another SF restaurant that's less about the food and the service than it is about experiencing a genuine San Francisco institution. My advice: go with friends, check in with Peter (the owner) or whomever is in charge and then head a few doors down to the place "where friends and girls meet" for a drink. They'll call the bar when your table is ready. Nice! When you sit down, don't bother with the menu, just have Peter order for you. He's a whiz at asking the right questions to find out what you'll like. Be adventurous! You'll try some new things and the surprise of it all will make it an experience you won't forget. Honestly, he's never brought us a dish I didn't like and every time we eat here, I can't believe how cheap it ends up being.
author: Brad L.

description:
coming from a guy that has no chinese blood at all, i found this to be a great restaurant

while not exactly a hole in the wall or diamond in the rough, its prices qualify it, along with the intensity of the flavors

it's just, well, crowded, but for good reason

even the oft-forgotten sampler is a good deal, especially when you're out with very picky people
author: Charles C.

description: This place is controversial!  I for one really enjoy House of Nanking.  I've had dishes with a variety of sauces and so not everything comes in a plum sauce as some suggest.  I've also not had issues ordering for myself off the menu, although giving them some guidelines and then letting them decide generally yields tasty food too.  The sesame chicken is great, especially the yams that come with it.  The tofu dishes and the  asian veggie dish are good too.  Plan your visit for an off-dining time, and you won't have to wait. This place isn't fancy and if you're just a party of 2, you'll probably be sharing a table.
author: amy w.

description: We had a great time!  The owner came to our table and said that he would take care of it.  They brought out a variety of dishes.  Our favorite was the calamari.  I wanted to order another plate just for myself.  The prices were reasonable.  I am definitely going back!
author: Bernardo R.

description: Prices are decent, but the food is overspiced. Also brusque service and very very cramped!
author: Joy C.

description: I would easily give this place a 4 star bordering on a five star based on my favorite dish there, the sesame chicken. if it were more consistent  The sauce is very good and l like the touch of the slices of sweet potatoes/yams that taste great in the sauce.  I've been to House of Nanking probably 8-10 times total.  Two of those times, the sesame chicken was not good because the pieces of chicken were not meaty and it felt like I was just eating scraps of fried breading.  The other times I have been to House of Nanking, the pieces of chicken have been meaty and I've enjoyed the dish.  The other dishes I have had at House of Nanking have ranged from average to good.
author: Josh K.

description: One word from me to you: GO. This place made a Chinese food-lover outta me. The pace is frantic, the food is divine and the waitstaff is big on tough love- to me it doesn't get much better. Most nights the owner is in the house and is willing to create a menu for you if you tell him what kind of meat(s) you like. Their house tea is lovely, full of flowers and flavor. My dream team starts with that then works its way down to crispy tofu with peanut sauce or Chinese greens, the Nanking sesame chicken and sizzling rice soup. I leave complete.
author: Megan W.

description: Wow.....I can't believe the reviews...It has received numerous accolades for outstanding food from food critics.  This place is awesome.......but you have to keep in mind that it is a little hole in the wall with great food and a line.  Whatever you do.....don't go to the bathroom here, you may see things in the kitchen you would rather not.  This place is always busy and that is for a reason....it's damn good.  I always take out of town guests here and they love it.
author: Gretchen H.

description: First of all, I should've known this place would be overrated b/c my bf and I were referred here by the front desk guy at some inn we were staying at during our visit.  They probably pay the inn to advertise.  So we got there and stood in a line where I peeped through the window where I did not see a single Chinese person.  That was a red flag but the front desk guy was Chinese so I decided to wait it out.  Well long story short, I was right....no Chinese people = no good Chinese food
author: Michelle R.

description: Loved it!  The food is great.  Our favorite was the scallop dish.  Only drawback was that the service was very impersonal and the bums on the street keep asking us for a piece of chicken LOL (I'm not kidding)  Word of advice, if you're sitting by the window, ask to have it closed or close it yourself.
author: Lauren S.

description: Nanking is, without a doubt, way worse than it used to be. Its futile to write this review, because people will keep going there and as long as the unsuspecting customers keep rolling in the door, the owners won't change their food back to how it was.  I actually have no problem with the remodel... why shouldn't a restaurant look better and serve good food? In Nanking's case, I truly think the soul went out the food when the owners realized what a cash cow the place could be.  I don't know a whole heap about "authentic" Chinese food, but I know the food at Nanking is not as tasty as it once was.  Too bad.  If you want some fairly okay Americanized Chinese (read: deep fried and sweet) and you are in the hood, then go to Nanking.  Please message me with good Chinese restaurants in the Bay Area, because I'm running out of ideas.
author: Natalie K.

description:
Dirty, crowded, rude service. Delish food.

We went to this place on a recommendation from a friend who apparently has low standards for cleanliness or service. This place made my jaw drop.

A quick summary:
1) the waitress sort of pointed us to this cramped little table next to a disgustingly dirty wall. 
2) the menu was dirty and worn
3) the menu had some amazing-sounding dishes, so we ordered a lot
4) the food came out in wierd intervals, but I guess that's good because our table was so tiny
5) the food was super tasty, except for my one bad decision on the rice
6) when the waitress came over to take our order, she just walked up, shifted her weight to signal her bad attitude, and just put pen to paper...a non-verbal "What the h*ll do you want?". I couldn't beleive it.
7) most of the unlucky people arround us had to SHARE tables with strangers. Not in a nice, comfy, family way, but in a yucky, crowded, sardine way.
8) this was the kicker: one already-seated guy was actually asked to get up and MOVE to another area so a group of three could be seated. A whole new level of bad service. Of course, he is to blame, too, by agreeing to it. Ew.


We ordered:
Shrimp pancake: I wasn't expecting it to be crispy, but oh, man, it was so incredibly delicious. My boyfriend and I agree wholeheartedly, that this is the best item we had.
Combo fried rice: This was gross. It had strange-looking pieces of chicken and uh, something. And about three cups of hard scallions. Maybe I should have known something was wrong with the fried rice because they incorrectly brought us steamed rice. TWICE.
Some chicken dish...don't even remember what it was. It was pretty tasty, though the sauce was too similar to the sauce on the pancakes.

Every platter was badly, badly chipped. 

We were seated immediately, and we went at about 6:00 on a Sunday night. Within minutes of our arrival, a line started outside. Yes, a line. A LINE. Crazy...this place is dirty and the staff was horrible.
author: Karen Z.

description: 3 1/2 stars. The food comes out really fast, they really try to churn you in and out (it's really crowded). I can't really remember what I ate but it was really tasty!
author: Carson H.

description:
I've been here three times--the first two were so good that I couldn't wait to get back.  The third was so bad that I can't wait to get back to undo the sadness and make it good again :-(  

The problem was, we sat down during busy dinner hours and I started to order for everyone, as I knew what was really good--the snow pea salad, onion pancake appetizer (AMAZING), noodle tower--but the owner stopped me and said, "Have you ever been here before?"  And I said, "Yes," and he said, "I'll handle the ordering"..."But I know exactly what I want"..."Trust me," he says.  I'd read Yelp reviews that said letting him choose is the way to go, and I finally gave in on the condition that he'd bring the stuff I'd already mentioned.  Sadly, the noodle tower never arrived, but a bunch of rather bland, greasy, fried stuff did--and I mean a BUNCH.  We had a total of eight dishes for five people, whereas I'd gone here before and ordered one per person and still had leftovers.  Plus, several of the dishes featured seafood, and we had someone in our party who was not into that.  Disappointo!  And of course significantly more expensive than we'd planned on considering all the unnecessary dishes.

I still have faith in the food, but I'm absolutely going to order for myself next time.  And for those of you who take a chance on the owner's choices, make sure you let him know how many dishes you'd like.
author: Courtney C.

description: this place is soo good! their tofu/broccoli dish was YUM. flower tea is yum too and cool to look at.
author: Preety K.

description: Unfortunately, I thought that the food here was mediocre at best and slightly overpriced. Clearly this is a spot for tourists and people who don't know what real Chinese food is or tastes like. If you're looking for an upscale Panda Express, then come here.
author: Jasper H.

description: I try to eat here whenever I'm in town.  Yes, the long line can be daunting.  Bring a friend and gossip while waiting.  Get the whole fish with garlic sauce.  4 stars because of cramped quarters.
author: Lisa M.

description: everytime i drove past this place during lunch or dinner there was always a line that went out the door waiting for a table.  I kept thinking what is so good about this chinese place that people are actually waiting in a line out the door???  a friend and i finally decided to try it and i have no regrets!  keep in mind this place is small and its really a little whole in the wall so you cant really go in and expect superior service.  The owner was really nice tho and stopped by our table and gave us his recommendations.  we just basically told him that we'd like a chicken and beef dish and veggies and let him do his magic!  he brought our some dishes that were YUMMY!!!  i really like how the have sweet potato as a garnish too...my only complaint is that some of the food starts to taste the same after a while...
author: Karisa L.

description:
Ugh - what happened to this place?  I hadn't been here in many years -- was surprised to find that prices have doubled since then, and food quality has gone down.  When we sat down, we ordered tea -- rather than asking us, the waiter brought two cups (mugs, actually) of the expensive flowering tea.  Service was rude, food was mediocre (and did I mention expensive?).  

Leave this place for the Fodor's crowd -- there are so many better Chinese restaurants in SF than this.
author: Ed K.

description: Great tasting food, a little oily if you don't choose the right thing. Loses one star for being so cramped, and another for rushed and poor service. This isn't a place to have a relaxing meal and conversate, you go there to eat get out and relax elsewhere. Not really worth a special trip, but if you are already in the area its worth it.
author: John B.

description:
First of all the place is tiny, staff is rude, food is over priced, and the food is horrible.  We ordered the Spicy Won Ton Soup and it was mediocre, it look good at first but it looked just like won ton soup thrown in with excess fish and pork from other plates and garnished with a lemon wedge and basil (btw chinese food rarely uses basil). The House Nanking Sesame Chicken plate was something similar to sweet and sour chicken with potatoe wedges on the side, it was overpowering with sweet. Not good! The only decen thing was the Fried Eggplant, it was deepfried with batter with black bean sauce. Sadly that was the only thing that was decent, but with that said I would NEVER come back here. Not to mention the rice was not up to par.  One thing that I noticed in the kitchen was a clear plastic bucket with cooked asparagus ready to serve.  Sadly it was served to the table next to us and they really enjoyed it, but it was pre made just like it was at a chinese fast food restaurant. How can that be when you pay a premium price for food here (+$10).  

-I had to ask TWICE for someone to take my order
-The waiters stepped on my foot TWICE and did not apologize
-I had to ask 2 different waiters for my check
-They just threw the check at me, but was in a hurry to collect the bill

Now I know the meaning of doggy bag, I wanted to bag the leftover awful food and feed it to my dog. But my dog is in LA.  So the restaurant can have it.  STAY AWAY!
author: dave c.

description: Food is great, place is divey.  Expect a wait if you go during peak hours.  If the staff refuses your order and makes its own suggestion (which they often do), just go with it.
author: Eric L.

description:
Meh, not impressed. 

I went with a friend and we ordered "one seafood" and "one vegetable", but should have specified "something not fried". 

The rice was soggy and flavorless, worse than Uncle Ben's instant. All that and two beers came to over $30!
author: Allie W.

description: I love this place!  It's STILL among the best chinese food in the City. Yes it's elbow-to-elbow dining... and  often a bit of a wait for a table... but it's such a classic SF meal. My advice: Just sit back and let the old man (your waiter) order for you. He KNOWS what you want. It's freaky.  WARNING: they don't call this place the "Ring of Fire" for nothing. Enjoy the burn.
author: Steven G.

description: I'm not saying this place is the best Chinese restaurant in SF but it's good if you are only craving their Nanking Chicken or Beef and their Shrimp cakes. If you are a big fan of being rushed out of a restaurant when you are trying to enjoy a meal with friends or a date - then by all means come and prepare to wait in a line that takes longer than you spending time eating in the restaurant itself!
author: Alexis D.

description: This place is " hole in the wall" chinese restaraunt serving wonderful dishes for great prices. The staff aren't the friendliest of people, yet the food keeps me coming back again and again. Try their tea with berries and flowers.
author: Amy H.

description: After 12 years of living on the cusp of Chinatown and knowing what good Chinese food tastes like, I know I should hate this place, but for some reason, I always have a soft spot for Nanking.  It's not really good enough to wait in line for, but when you can walk right in it's not too bad.  After a few cocktails, the food is always a real crowd-pleaser.   I personally love the fish dish with the vinegar/milk sauce.  I know it sounds godawful, but it's actually really tasty.
author: Robyn H.

description: I love hole in the wall type spots and this place fits quite well which I like:).  Their food is cheap, portions are large and their vegetarian dishes are excellent in my opinion.  I have had many post all night party lunches here and it hits the spot all the time.  It may be that my high rating for this place is due to my many fond SF trips but who cares I enjoy it ;).  As for being a tourist trap, Chinatown is a tourist trap in general so just deal with it and eat.
author: Mark G.

description: After living here for almost three years i finally decided to see what all the hype was about. I went on a weekday afternoon so there was no wait. This place is a little sparse in decorating and ambiance. I ordered the sesame beef, it seems to be a common chinese dish so easy to make a comparison. My food was served quickly with a side of steamed rice. I also ordered the tea which was not strained and full of loose tea, flowers and these little red pods. I like my tea hot but this was almost nuclear. The sesame beef was served with some fried yams which was interesting and also quite good. All in all this place was good for san francisco chinese. Maybe i'm spoiled being from the east coast and growing up on some bomb takeout. I would recommend house of nan king, but still i don't see what the whole big deal is.
author: mike m.

description:
I give it 4 stars now but reserve the right to give it three once I go back and try some of the not-sweet sauces.   3 of the 4 dishes we got were covered in this very sweet sauce.  It was good but a little over powering.  The onion cake was very good and definitely the highlight of the meal.  The crispy orange chicken was okay.  I've had better at many other places.  The cut of chicken they use is a bit low-budget.  The pea shoot salad was good and the egg plant was excellent.  It was cooked just right.   The pork filled mushroom caps was also good.   I wish I had ordered something not so sweet but we got our menus and abut 3 minutes later the chef came over to take out order so I didn't have time to really look over the menu very closely.   I would definitely go back to try other dishes and maybe I'll lower the rating a star if they don't live up to the expectations.   

I do want to say something about authenticity and the fact that so many people are rating them lower for the fact that they don't serve "authentic" Chinese food.  Personally, I don't think that "authentic" always means "good".   I have several Chinese friends and have been to many 10 course Chinese meals at weddings that were all supposedly very authentic.  A lot of the dishes at these events were not very good, despite the Chinese people at my table devouring them passionately.  I don't automatically think that authentic Chinese food is good or non-authentic Chinese food is bad.  I like to keep an open mind and decide what is good when I put it in my mouth.   Of course, if you are Chinese, I am sure you have a different opinion.  My wife is Indian and she has very certain ideas of what is good Indian and what is bad.  If the food isn't like her mom's then it is bad.  She usually doesn't like any Indian food that isn't regionally like what she was brought up on.  She isn't a big fan of southern Indian food, which I really love.   So basically, what I am trying to say is that you really have to look at who is reviewing the food and what their background is to really understand what they are saying.    If one of the people from the Chinese wedding I went to reviewed the meal we had then he may say it was incredible where I would have said it was too greasy and salty. 

If I was in Tokyo and I walked into an Applebees and saw a bunch of white people, should I instantly think that this place had amazing American food?    Maybe.   Maybe it's the best in the area.  Maybe the white people have bad taste and go here because it reminds them of the crappy American food they get back home.   Maybe it really is the best place to get a cheeseburger in Tokyo.   Who knows.  What I am trying to say is that there are a lot of ways to look at a restaurant and you shouldn't discount it just because there are no Asians nor should you praise it because it is full of Asians.   Trust me, I've been to MANY bad Chinese and Indian restaurants filled with Chinese and Indian people...   Maybe all the Asians are avoiding it since there are so many damn tourists and long lines and it is pricey for lunch.  Maybe they are avoiding it because the can make better food at home.  Maybe they are avoiding it because they are smart and don't want to waste their money?
author: Erick Z.

description: The House of Nanking is a small unpretentious restaurant that stands up to its reputation for delivering high quality delicious food.  We absolutely loved everything that we tried, particularly the sizzling rice soup!
author: Melissa D.

description: The owner of this place is San Francisco's version of the Soup Nazi.
author: Arvey S.

description: It's not authentic, but after reading the Fortune Cookie Chronicles, I am realizing I have no idea what that word means anyway.  The potstickers and the nanking chicken are good enough to keep me coming back.  Even if I only can motivate to do it once a year these days.
author: Julie B.

description: We arrived at the restaurant a half hour until closing, and the chef would not let us order our food, instead choosing for us. He chose the most expensive dishes for my party, and only one or two out of the six dishes were remotely good tasting. There was something brown floating in the  water we were served, so none of us could drink anything. Needless to say, this was not a good dining experience.
author: Ruchi D.

description: I thought this place was new because of how lacking the service was. They're not prompt, you have to wave them down to get water, the check, or any kind of attention. The place looked fine and the food was ok. We ordered the clam wonton - which I have to say was DELICIOUS and unique in look and taste. It almost reminds me of a watered down clam chowder with whole clams and wonton with a hint of spiciness. I highly recommend that and only that. The other two dishes that we got were the house chow mein (not good, very greasy and unappetizing) and the pork chop nanking style (very greasy, battered pork chop meat that was deep fried, then stir-fried in more grease with veggies which came out cold/luke warm). They definitely didn't have enough servers and the server that we had didn't really give a crap. The only thing that I'd come here for is the soup. That's it but that's not enough to come to a place just for soup, is it?
author: Mayana P.

description: I don't care about all the people saying this place is overrated... I went here for the first time about a month ago and loved it!  I also liked that they had blossoming flower tea. As well, the portions were pretty big in my opinion.  One of the dishes that you should try has a scallop with a lemon slice on top.  Also try the hot and sour soup, delicious...
author: K. N.

description: Let's see what adjectives I can use to describe this joint--touristy, greasy (understatement), pedestrian and anyone stupid enough to stand in line at this hole is indeed stupid--like I was once.
author: David P.

description:
Quite possibly the tastiest Chinese food in The City (or perhaps the world).  However, this place always rubs me the wrong way - maybe it's the inattentive service - or the way they try to rush you out before you even get in.  Or when you get your bill you realize that they just charged you $13 for a plate steamed pea-shoots and your simple mid-day lunch is now almost $30 a person.

It's good.  But it never feels 'worth it.'  I will say, however, that getting the wonton soup To Go is well worth it - as it's amazingly delicious and the crispy - yet delicate- calamari is phenomenal.
author: Miscia B.

description: i 've been there couple times over there food was cheap affordable ,service to bad .food was little different then other Chinese restaurant .its ok
author: raja g.

description:
Ok... first drop your pre-conceived notions of customer service.  You go here for the best Chinese food you've ever tasted, not to be pampered...

The first time we went here - about 16 years ago - the owner begrudgingly gave us menus when we asked for them... but only let us look at them for 30 seconds before pulling them away and saying "I'll order for you..." as he walked away.  (They had a line around the block)

What came back was the most amazing array of food that we never would have ordered for ourselves.

Every time I've been in San Fran since - I drop in for dinner and say "You pick - I eat anything and I like things spicy".  I've never left disappointed, and I don't think you will either.
author: Atown F.

description: Recommended by fellow Yelpers a few years ago, as well as friends, we had to try it. The first time we went we took awhile to choose and just asked the owner what he recommends because it was our first time. He immediately grabbed our menus, started jotting stuff down on his paper and left. He came back with the stuffed mushrooms with the nanking sauce and the fried squid with rice. A year and a half later, numerous return visits and after a move out of the city, we still get the same thing (with some extras from time to time) and make it a point to eat here every time we are in the city. We even take our out-of-town visitors who we tour around the city to here almost always. Over the years we've tried a few other things, like the mushu pork with the wrap, the nanking chicken, the fried rice but it's the stuffed mushroom and fried squid that are the best. Oh and if ever you go here, try to avoid ordering all meals that have the nanking sauce. It's good but too much of their sauce in the meal and you'd think that everything tastes the same.
author: Ryan A.

description: how does  this  place  get any 5 and 4 star reviews?  Everything that we ordered was soooo salty and greasy!  Eat here if you want to die early. They get one star for quick  and friendly service.
author: MrsNIFTY G.
