description: love this place for a sit down chinese meal in chinatown, but if i'm looking for dimsum or roast duck i head up the street to chinatown proper and window shop for that perfect roast duck.
author: gino a.

description: The House of Nan King is one of very rare restaurants where the quality of the food overrides everything else. I gave Nan king 5 stars because, frankly, the food was that good. Let me start by saying that if you are the type of person that the level of service at a restaurant is a deciding factor in the overall experience, then the House of Nan King is not going to be your bowl of rice, pardon the pun... The food was hands down the best Chinese food I have had. The Sesame Chicken was the best I have had and the Chow Mein was equally as amazing. I found the scallops to be delicious but the quantity was definitely lacking. My girlfriend had the vegetarian lettuce wraps and continues to rave about them whenever we talk about our trip to China town to friends. Well worth the 45 minute wait. While the seating is "sardine-like" and the service somewhat slow, the food really makes up for it and then some. I cannot wait to eat there again and highly recommend this restaurant to all of you who appreciate a good chinese meal.
author: Douglas H.

description: The wife and I went to this restaurant because we were recommended this place for pretty good chinese food. Upon arrival, we saw that the tables were completely filled-which means that the food must be pretty good. So like all typical Chinese resaurants, the service sucked which seems expected, but these guys were pretty damn rude. We had ordered the Calamri, Chao mein noodles and the Biao bao dish. The calamari was okay,  not overly breaded and in it's "TANGY" -as reviews had put it-  highly recommended sauce, which was basically vinegar and coconut juice.  Okay so I get that it's supposed to be modern Chinese food with a twist, Honestly I don't think it is worth the $14 you'd pay to get this dish. The biao bao was pretty good, being it tasted like greasy Chinese food but a bit better. There was tomatoes under the wrap which we had happily ate toward the end because the calamri contained no veggies and the biao biao was basically meat in greasy garlic sauce.  Once we almost finished, we had noticed the they had convienently left the produce sticker on the tomato. A good sign the tomatoes probably weren't washed well or washed at all. We had complained because at this point we were 55min into the course with no chow mein and now a possibly unwashed tomato we had eaten. Of course the only reply we had gotten from the waitress was "oh sorry"  and than just walked away. No discount or compensation. We  were now running behind schedule and needed to leave so after waiting another ten minutes we decided to just pay at the front and skip getting the chow mein. As for talking to the owner, it seemed quite useless as he was over-inflating his ego talking only to customers he percieved to have fat wallets and or Caucasian.  If you're wondering I am Asian and so is my wife.  I also have a fat wallet but was never approached nor anyone else that fit this description. Anyhow, the overall experience  was not impressive. Btw, I uploaded the picture of the tomato onto this site, so you can find it in the restuaunt photo album.
author: Ken x.

description: Boy, what a disappointment.  My friend and I wondered in on a cold Sunday afternoon.  We were seated in the first dining room which was freezing because the door kept opening.  We asked to move to the other room but were told we couldn't because it was closed.  Right away more parties came in and were seated in the "warm" room.   By this point we were freezing.  We asked the server about a soup on the menu.  He told us he was a chef and asked that we let him make a recommendation.  We told him we wanted seafood but no meat.  What we got was a bowl full of noodles in a somewhat tasty broth and the "seafood" turned out to be a bunch of fish skin, very little actual fish, and a whole mess of bones.    Giving feedback to the waiter about our disappointing experience was useless.  He was argumentative and defensive and the $2.00 tip we left on a $35 tab was way too generous.  I'm a concierge in San Francisco -- not only will I not return, but I sure won't recommend anyone to House of Nanking.
author: Charna G.

description: Great food. Not done in the "traditional" Chinese restaurant way. Plates were presented in a upscale way, but was very flavorful and filling.
author: Matt L.

description: First thought shit I dont want to wait that long for Chinese food. the line was long but it did move pretty fast. Once we sat down the waitress asked how hungry we were and then started bringing us food. Kind of odd that we didnt get to pick off of the menu but I was game. All of the courses and there were about five were pretty good and different then I would have got. The gave us the exact amount of food and it was tasty!
author: Carli M.

description: No-nonsense, good Chinese food.  It's no-frills, not glamorous, and inexpensive.  I just went there and followed the review's advice from the SFGate, which was to ask for a recommendation.  The owner/waiter came over and I asked him for a chicken recommendation.  His response: "I'll take care of you."  I still don't know the name of the dish I received, but it was fantastic.  I'll definitely be back.
author: A A.

description: I understand why this place is getting a bunch of bad reviews, because it's not for everybody. I loved it. I don't know what people are saying about them using only one sauce... we had all sorts of stuff that I wouldn't have ordered, and it was a pretty good variety. The trick is to come in with 3-4 open-minded people and tell the waiter you want the chef's special. They'll bring you a ton of food (that you won't even get the names of), but everything we had was delicious. We combined our table with a honeymooning Australian couple and had a great big family-style meal. It was fantastic. They only serve one type of beer though, I think it was Tsingtao.
author: Alex C.

description: Crowded! Noisy! Probably Greasy! But I really like what I ate here and I can be a picky eater! After looking over the menu, the waitress should she would take care of us and gave us a shrimp dish with rice.  The dish was a bit spicy and saucy. And a bit spicy meant really sweat for me(really sensitive to spicy)! But the dish went nice with beer and rice and my friend, seemed to enjoyed as well.  The draw back of this place however, it was way too crowded and noisy! My friend had to squeeze into her way into her seat and she's petite. But the food was good, service decent, and price on low side.
author: Leon C.

description: If you are easily offended from the rudeness of traditional Chinese restaurants, then stay away. Either you are a tight-ass in cultural experiences or you went to some wrong places. This place's whole magic is based on that rudeness taken to the next level. Pretty much don't be offended if they order for you. Just tell them what you don't/can't eat. They will basically put together what they have  and it will be delicious. It's pretty much Chinese omikase.
author: Peter Y.

description: I have eaten here three times, leading to three letdowns. The food is acceptable, but what price are you willing to pay for an overrated Chinese restaurant? The service here has to be close to worst in the city (took them over ten minutes to even approach our table), and they are way overpriced for what you get. My growing distaste with the whole "family style" concept continues. I will say that the simple menu would be ideal for large groups, but I cannot recommend this establishment based purely on principle. Last time I ate here, they literally threw the food at us, and I came damn close to attacking the staff. The next person who visits that wants to eat at this dump will never be heard from again.
author: Kenny G.

description: When a restaurant offers you to trust the chef, do it.  That lesson applies here as well.  Half of the fun is seing what the hell they will bring to you next.  Delicious Chinese food and the tea is quite extravagant.  It is crowded, and the meal will most likely run you twenty bucks a person.
author: Danny C.

description: This is the only place in Chinatown with the line out the door for a reason...it's so darn yummy. Indecisive orderer? Leave it to the psychic pushy waiter to bring you dishes you didn't even know you wanted. Never been disappointed here :)
author: Gretchen N.

description: There is usually a line outside of this restaurant; I think a lot of tourists come.  However, when I go, I see many "locals" too.  I love the calamari here, it's yum.  The sesame chicken is tasty, but a bit heavy.  Portions are large, and meant to share.  I love me some Chinese food, but I wouldn't say this is my favorite place to go.  Warning:  they wouldn't let my sister and I split the bill on our credit cards; you have to have a $25 minimum charge... so bring cash.
author: Sarah F.

description:
For those of you who think this is the best chinese food in the city/state/world, I hate to disappoint you but this is not really chinese food. The food though is not bad for what it is. The flavoring is distinctly not chinese and definitely caters to the American taste buds. I'd say it's more like fusion, and I can't fault the combination of ingredients. However, to believe that this is Chinese food is somewhat blasphemous.

So anyway, we ordered the potstickers and the fried shrimp cake as appetizers. The potstickers were quite good surprisingly, but I will warn that they are deep fried. This was a shock to me, but it actually turned out quite well. The fried shrimp cake was also not what I expected and was just a deep fried won ton with shrimp inside. Tasty as well but started to get overwhelmed with deep fried dishes. Doesn't everything taste better when it's deep fried?

For entrees, we let the waitress decide since that seems to be the thing to do here. I believe we ended up with the Shaking Beef and the Sesame Chicken. I'm not sure if this is always the case, but the food came out at a lukewarm temperature. This leads me to believe that they make huge batches of these "recommended dishes", which works well when they get to decide the dishes. The sauce in the Sesame Chicken was a little too strong. They include some yam in the dish as a nice addition, but otherwise not much more exciting than sesame chicken you get at Panda Express. The beef dish seemed like it would have been really good if it had been served hot. It included the sizzling rice, which was not sizzling. Unfortunately, this led to an overall disappointing dish.

Overall, I can see the appeal of this restaurant. I can see how it could be good, but please...let's not confuse this food with Chinese food. Peace out.
author: Luke F.

description: Great place.  Looks like a Chinese 'diner', but the food was AMAZING.  Good value.  Great flavors.  Huge portions.  Fast service.  My 9 year old even loved the beef with broccoli and he is usually a picky eater.
author: Wes R.

description:
I'm obsessed with the dumplings appetizer and sesame chicken entree.  The crackling beef is pretty good too.  If you haven't heard, the wait staff likes to sometimes disagree with what you're ordering and order something else for you and go back to the kitchen before you can even rethink your order.  

The tables are uncomfortably close together, and I've heard there are rodent problems there, but I love this place so much I will put these minor  things aside and continue to go there.
author: LT B.

description:
Once upon a time, when I was 17yrs old, I visited San Francisco to look at colleges.  My buddy Ryan and I toured Berkeley, SF State, and The Academy of Art (which I ended up going to).  This was back in the early 90's and SF had not been dominated and torn apart by bastard dot-commers.
I had a cousin living in the city that we stayed with.  He brought us to House of Nanking and I had the best hot and sour soup ever... plus these pot stickers in a peanut sauce that were out of this world.
Fast forward a year and I'm in the city going to college... I get this flashback of this great place, but don't remember the name or where the heck it was located.  IT TOOK ME TWO YEARS TO FIND IT!!!  Hahaha... I can laugh about it now, but you try and ask people around SF about this awesome Chinese place and you'll get 100 different answers.  Anyway, to this day, it's still one of my favorite places.  They ended up expanding, which didn't help a bit.  You will still wait outside for at least a half hour, and you'll still be crammed into the place.  Service sucks, it looks crazy, but it's so worth the experience.
author: Josh F.

description: I'm just so happy work brings me to Kearny Street every month or so. This Chinatown institution is a GREAT stop for lunch. Any place where the staff just brings you  different dishes until you burst is OK by me.  Quite tasty too - possibly MSG influenced but that's nothing a beer can't cure.
author: Skip F.

description:
Disenchanted locals have begun to start calling it House of Same Sauce.


 This is how the review for House of Nanking ends in the Zagat 2006 restaurant guide. Why am I pointing this out in my review? BECAUSE MY SEESTER SENT THAT INTO ZAGAT AND THEY USED IT IN THEIR REVIEW! Which is funny because it's true. Locals = more than one person = Eddo's seester + Eddo Feel free to call it that too, we'll include you in our disenchanted locals category. I'll even start a Myspace group.


 My mom, my auntie, my seester, my seester's fiance Coriander, and I were eating lunch together at my apartment and the conversation turned to Qype.


 Coriander: So Eddo, you always tell us about the places that you really like and you give 5 stars to. Is there anywhere that you give 1 star to?
Me: Man, there's a lot. Lemme think.
Seester: I know - House of Same Sauce.
Me: YES!!!!!
Auntie and Momma: Wha? Where dat?
Seester: House of Same Sauce is in Chinatown. And it's wildly popular. There's a huge line out the door all the time. Mostly tourists and business-y people. And you basically sit, and the owner points at you and barks out what you're going to eat. And then they bring it to you. But the thing is, EVERYTHING HAS THE SAME SAUCE!
Me: Mommy - seriously - it's so bad. And guess what sauce it is? It's PLUM SAUCE! They put PLUM SAUCE on everything.
Auntie and Momma [shock and horror on their faces]: Wha?! Prum Sauce?! NOO!
Ed: Yeah. And guess what's even worse. THEY PUT PEAS IN THEIR JIAO ZIs (dumplings).
Auntie and Momma [still shocked and horrified]: PEAS?!
Seester: Yeah, and they don't even hand roll the dumplings, they use a machine that just stamps the dumplings in and they fall apart and they're soooo bad. And peas!
Auntie: Dats horri-bul. So bad. You guys so lucky to have Grandma always cooking for you. So many people don't know good Chinese food is.
Seester: Here's the thing - it's like it's not even Chinese food. It's like the owner read someone's description of what Chinese food is supposed to be and is imitating that description instead of what it actually is in his cooking. It's so so so so so bad.
Me: Mommy, it's like, it hurts me that people think this is Chinese food. I'm ASHAMED that I am Chinese and this is passing off as Chinese food. I stay awake at night, my stomach turns, thinking of all the people who think this is the food I grew up with. I think this is why I'm so gassy at night, Mommy.
Momma M: Oh yah, you always gassy. Eh-ber since you lee-tle. Dats why we always get you dee-ferent hotel room.
author: eddo

description:
you sit down and almost immediately the server asks if you're ready to order. "uhhh no," but luckily we are already in the know about the server choosing your food for you. "i want something spicy with chicken. and a noodle dish." his response, "okay okay i know what to make. it good. i pLomise." and when the food comes out it ends up being delicious. my only complaint is that a lot of the food had the same flavors in it. oh well. i didn't have to think of what to order and the food came out well. 

there's always a long line outside. so come hungry but be ready to wait a bit first.
author: Regina C.

description: Its definitely a 5 star to me. I would recommend this place to anybody who desires above average Chinese food. Im not sure how healthy the meals are, but it looked so good, and I ate so fast, I didn't care a bit. Cool small place, very tight, fast service, uncomfortable chairs. Get in and get out with a smile.
author: andrew w.

description:
Have been coming here for years with my family.  I took a friend from the east coast to House of Nanking and he aptly described it as "literally the best non sexual experience of my life" I think that sums it up nicely

If you go just let the owner order for you, he will take care of it
author: Ross G.

description: the wonton soup is by far the best i've EVER had and is the single reason why i am giving this restaurant five stars! after having that wonton soup that was all i could think of the rest of my trip to San Francisco! the other dishes were delicious too, but that wonton soup is heavenly!
author: Chich S.

description:
Not the local place you'd though of. i live and work in the area and have loved this place for ever. the menu however, is not what it use to be. limited and everything tastes the same.

oh and when did the people who work there get mean.  there are much better Chinese restaurants in the area trust me.
author: Fr v.

description: This place has best food on earth !!! We go here at least once a month, and try the chicken cakes, sizzling rice crispy soup, salt and pepper chicken, bao bing wrap. They have also opened a new a little upscale restaurant called Fang, that place has great decor and we love their 5 spice fish. The owners of this restaurant are super cool, and sometimes serve dishes outside menu for us to try. The food costs appox $30 for 2 people, so its very cost friendly place too.
author: sf food e.

description: Our hotel highly recommended this restaurant and we now know why. There was a short wait out front yet it was definatley worth it..I recommend the sesame chicken..out waiter john recommend we also order the shrimp mushroom dish so my husband and I could share and sample different cuisines..it was all delicious and well definately be back.its a small place so sitting at the table with other people just makes for more friends..thanks john for the great service well ge back..
author: Ray F.

description: Went to this restaurant from a recommendation with a group of friends.  Was also told to go early as possible as there is a line.  Sure enough there's a rope line, like the ones at the theaters outside the door.  When we got in, the place was cramped because there was so many people being served.  We had no idea what to order so the owner came out and basically collected everyone's menus and asked if there was anything we didn't eat.  He had various dishes brought out for us and wow, never had chinese food so good.  From vegetarian, fish, chicken to beef, the food was so fresh and delicious.  Next time, I'm in the bay area, this is the first place I am visiting.  I wish NC had such a Chinese restaurant that was high quality and not the fast food versions or buffets.
author: Robert L.

description: You can't expect great service, but the food is wonderful. We asked for their recommendation, and five of us got about 7 different dishes. Everything tasted fresh and was flavorful. Definitely the best Chinese place I've ever been to in San Francisco. I'm looking forward to going back.
author: Mia D.

description: Great food is never worth rude service. So says the fortune cookie this place will never serve.
author: Al K.

description:
yes 2 stars and thats being generous. Had Onion Cake it was coated in grease & what tasted like peanut butter! I had chicken w green beans, had no taste so I piled on the hot sauce, friend had the nanking beef it was soooooooooooooooooo chewy we left half!
Did I mention that ALL courses came together within 5mins of ordering. At $8.95 an entree NOT WORTH IT leave it to the tourists!!!!!!!!
author: dawn w.

description: We went early at about 4pm on a Sunday, no wait we walked right in and ordered. Overall the food was awesome. The place itself is kind of tired and dingy. The service was decent and very quick. We will go back again.
author: Tony A.

description:
the only thing you have to order is 'nanking beef', the rest you can let them choose.
the food taste pretty much the same one to another.
author: Suki S.

description: I've only been here twice.  After the first visit I was craving this place for weeks.  After the 2nd visit it didn't seem as good as the first time.  Don't get me wrong, the food is very delicious ... some of the sauces are a bit too sweet for me and some dishes all taste the same but ... all in all the food is very fresh and tasty, and they give large portions and the pricing is reasonable.  Go early or you'll have to wait in line.  The service could use some work and the seating can be uncomfortable.  We were boxed in between other people so everytime they wanted to get up, we had to get up and move to let them out.
author: Miss Purr fec t.

description: This place definitely has pretty good chinese food...but for the wait it always has..its also not worth it.  Prices here are actually pretty steep when you compare it to some chinese places with the same quality of food.  Nonetheless, its still a great place to go if you crave some authentic chinese food.
author: Charles C.

description: Best Chinese food I've tasted thus far.
author: Sandra M.

description: Letting Peter (the owner) order for you is usually a pleasant surprise, but you can't go wrong with the mushu beef or nanking chicken.  when people ask me where to go to eat in SF for cheap eats - this is it hands down.
author: Arzhang S.

description: If you have ever watch the Seinfield episode featuring the Nazi Soup Chef . . . you have found his match in the Nazi Chinese Chef at House of Nanking.      First after waiting for a coveted seat at the long family style table to the left. . you are actually given menus to select from . . personally I think this is a ploy to kill time, because when you finally do order and actually do get food quickly. . . and if you notice you aren't getting what you order. . . the server/chef saids "this is good, eat!" . . . .and it usually is and he is usually right. . . but just once, I'd like to get what I order. . . but then - one doesn't want to get banned - now does one. . .
author: Kea C.

description: This place shows up in almost every tour book so no surprise there that it looks absolutely touristy. Strong favour food but a bit too much on sweet side (yam as a side..go figure!). Good smoky string beans. Portion of food is generous (really really big plates) which could make it fun to eat there with a small group of friends.
author: Uarporn N.

description: Militant service and not as cheap as it used to be. A San Francisco instisution. They did a light remodel in 2006. Ask the Chef to choose your menu for you for a nice assortment of dishes not on the menu. If you oder ala carte get the tsign tao chicken dish.
author: Deno M.

description: I seriously don't know why this place is "popular". The dish wears are not very clean as well as the restaurant itself. The waitresses and the owner are unfriendly and they rush you to finish eating even before you get your order. Most of the dishes have the same sauce therefore everything taste pretty much the same.
author: Jelly G.

description:
Yeah, I don't know why folks are reviewing this like it's a traditional Chinese place. IT'S NOT. This is a kind of modern multi-asian-influenced cuisine. The flavors are original and delicious. So why the three stars?
Well the bathroom is FOUL. There were like 3 different types of bugs (including cockroaches) flying and crawling all over! EWWW. What's the kitchen like?? Though I'm sure this review won't affect their popularity!
Well, I'll still be back because my man LOVES it, and if you go, get the egg rolls! Holy crapoli!
Oh, and expect a bit of a wait... there's never NOT been a line when I've gone.
author: Burleigh Girl G.

description:
Wow, i can't believe the reviews i'm reading about this place. I have to come to its defense!!!! 

Let's do a reality check first:
Are there long lines? YES. So don't come here expecting otherwise.

Rude service? YES. Who cares. The food is good enough that i can tolerate it. 

Cash preferred? SO what? Most asian restaurants want you to pay cash. 

Not authentic? Who cares as long as the flavoring and quality is good. Folks have got to get over this. 

I'm asian and have eaten tons and tons chinese food throughout the united states.  Lived all over u.s.  I have to say about 90% are bad but not this one. Like all restaurants, some dishes are good, some are so-so, and some are bad.

Here are some dishes that rock: fried calamari (hubby's favorite), crackling beef, eggplant dish (forgot the name), wonton soup.
author: Babynorah T.

description:
During my tenure living in The City, this was probably my favorite restaurant in SF.  At the House of Nanking, there were flavors I have never experienced before.  The food is quality, outstanding, and tasty.  It's obvious they spend more energy and money in their food than the ambiance of the establishment.  But eating there is an experience (positive) in itself.  Has a hole in the wall feel. The seating is usually next to another couple or party, and the kitchen is right there, gives it a cozy feeling.  There's action going on everywhere around you and it is not quiet.  They don't take reservations, and usually there's a line.  Never order off the menu, tell the server (who's usually the owner/cook or his wife) to prepare what they believe is the best for that day.  There have been times when I've asked the server to prepare what's best for that day, and it was tasty.  The next time I came, I ordered the same item, was not as good as the last time, but the new recommendation the server offered was outstanding.  
There does seem to be quite a few tourists at the house of Nanking of Nanking.  Is this place in a Lonely Planet or some other City Guide book?  
One other thing, its not exactly authentic Chinese food, more of a modern creative version of Chinese food.
author: Aras A.

description:
Three star average...holy taste buds batman...this is an outrage!
By far my favorite Chinese joint i have ever had. Not sure if its the "heroin sauce" thanks to the abundant use of MSG, or the fact that this place not pretentious in any way. Lets face it, this place is dirty. The service can be harsh...Peter, the little man who takes your order (or orders for you) carries a notepad that never seems to have anything written on it, they rush you in, rush you out, your plate may be clean, maybe not, no chopsticks...hahaha...SO WHAT!!! The food is AWESOME. Enough said.  Pot-stickers are a must. Shrimp cakes...f8ckin awesome. Nanking chicken, can I have more please!!! Delectable noodles. Fish caught in heaven then de-boned by tiny little angels. This place makes me happy that I have a tongue. It makes me happy that I understand that even though this place is a shit-hole...i am a foodie enough to get past the aesthetics and rate it on the food. It like your favorite Dive Bar...HoN is my favorite dive Chinese joint...thanks Peter.
author: Diego C.

description: This place is just good.  Some people cry it is over rated, but I disagree.  Granted a lot of tourists and people from out of town like to come here now, but it is still good.  Give it a shot, do not buy into the Hype!
author: Billy W.

description:
Not at all sure why all of the haters on yelp.   Probably a conspiracy to have the place to themselves.  Maybe it's just too successful and people have to play hip and jaded.    All the people who rated the place at 1 star are obviously smoking crack around the corner.   

Don't care, more room for me and mine!    This is food unlike anywhere else.    The sauces and flavor combinations are truly unique.   The fish dish is just to die for.   It's the only place I ever like eggplant dishes.  Peter is just a master at running this place and it's kitchen.    When you get your seat  (yes, it will be a wait- want faster service and can't tell the difference, go down the street)  don't bother with the menu.   Just tell him you want a chicken/fish/vegetarian dish (whatever your preference is)   and he will read your aura and select the perfect dish for you to eat.  

No shit.   

Try it and tell me it's not perfect.
author: Greg F.

description: It's true, this isn't your classic Chinese food. If you want that, walk up a couple of blocks to China Town. This food is delicious, and part of the charm is that the owner orders for you. I say, go with a group of at least 4 so that you can sample different things. Some people are snobby about the place, because the service isn't great, but the food is so good, that it makes up for it. It is heavy and you get a lot of food, but it is so worth it. I have yet to take anyone there who has had a bad experience.
author: Benjamin F.

description: I don't know why people bag on this place. Sure, it's not fully authentic Chinese food, but I think it's pretty obvious by its clientele that House of Nanking is not trying to target the Chinese crowd. It's still got the hole-in-the-wall feel with some great tasting Chinese-inspired dishes at decent prices (~$15 a dish). I ordered to-go and they did a great job of accommodating my order...best of all, I didn't even need to pick the dishes. They do all the work for me! If you let them pick your dishes for you, you will be happy.
author: Willy C.

description: Left me sitting waiting for my order for 30 minutes before i gave up and walked out.  Don't go.  Go to Jai next door.
author: Eric B.

description:
I would walk by this place every time I would go to Northbeach and I would always see a huge line outside. I would think "this place, can't be that great, it looks like such a nasty hole-in-the-wall." And then one day I totally fell for the "there is a long line so I'll stand here too since it must be good" logic. 
I went with my friend and waited only about 10 minutes to be sat. Of course, we got sat right next to this awkward couple from Canada asking the lady for "soyyah sauce-o" of some bologna like that. They were obviously going deaf because they were talking way too loud. It was pretty miserable to sit next to these two but I continued to come here and sometimes you sit to some interesting people and get into conversations with them. And many of them are traveling. 
I used to be a really big fan of the soups here but they are getting saltier and saltier. I'm really sensitive to salt but even my bf who isn't tells me that they are too salty for him. The sizzling rice soup was my favorite. 
The sesame chicken is to die for! I am vegetarian but I really miss the chicken and get really tempted to eat a piece even though it'd probably make me poo water. But it's that good. My boyfriend gets it and lately I just pick at the sweet potatoes which are amazing. 
I have been getting the plate where they mix up some veggies for you in their garlic sauce. I usually get tofu and eggplant. It is a little too salty or me but doable. It's still good, with a lot of rice. OH, and I really like their tea. 
The reason it doesn't get the full 5 stars is the service has always been terrible. Even when it's slow its not so great service. I always have to ask them to fill my water, get me rice, etc. The owner (I'm pretty sure) is really nice and if you are indecisive he will decide for you what you will be eating. He always delivers. 
I'm kinda craving some house of nanking right now.
author: Aram H.

description: Oh how the mighty have fallen...I used to love to come to House of Nanking in the late 80's and really enjoyed the food.  We'd always ask Peter the owner to just make us what he thought was best that day.  But now, with the exception of the decor, which is definitely improved, the whole experience is much changed and not good.  The food is not even good for Americanized Chinese food--the much lauded "sesame chicken" is basically General Tso's chicken with an extra spoonful of sugar, and the rest of the dishes were overly sweet as well.  The salt and pepper prawns, formerly one of their stand-out dishes, is now a lot of mushrooms, some shrimp and no crunchiness to be seen, and the dry braised green beans were actually in some kind of liquid.  The service was indifferent:  we got all our dishes and had to wait for the rice, and one waitress was actually on the phone when she served us.  This might be acceptable in a dive, but lunch for two with two beers cost us nearly $50.  The lines out the door are clearly based on a reputation earned years ago; for now I'd venture over to Henry's Hunan and have a lovely, and inexpensive, lunch there.
author: Jennifer F.

description: Not quite sure why this place is so highly rated by some yelpers.  Two of us blew $30 on a below average lunch...never expected SF to have worse "Chinese" food than SD.  Save yourself the grief and walk down south a few more blocks to R&G...much better there.
author: Liver B.

description:
Fancy dining?...umm..no
5 star meals?...unh uh..
Attentive waiters?....not so much...
Valet parking?....You wish!
Fun to wait in the cold for a table?....negatory!
Soup Nazi? Umm...maybe a little...

BUT...

Kick as food? Check
GREAT prices? Check
Cool place to take out-of towners? Yup. Watch them look around like "WTF is going on?" Then watch them dig into the food.
Repeat customers? OH YEAH!!

Great food (although this is from a white boy's perspective) that MUST have some sort of addictive chemical in it or something! The eggplant is AMAZING and the beer is nice and cheap. If you're feeling adventurous, have Peter order for you. I haven't gone wrong yet!

Good eats all the way!
author: Nate S.

description:
The restaurant is always busy-lines going out the door.  The food at times is hit and miss.   

Like some of the reviews here, they seem to use the same sauce on all their dishes and the sauce is salty most of the time.

some of the hits the hot and sour soup, their pork chops, salt and pepper spareribs.  

Their vegetable dish always seem to be eggplant.

they are better places to eat hunan.
author: kenny l.

description: I always like dining at Nanking.  Some people think it's touristy, but the food is just plain good.  It's not fancy, it's solid chinese food that will leve you satisfied... at least for a few hours.
author: Justin C.

description: I keep seeing reviews that say it's touristy and inauthentic, whatever that means. All I know is that my friends and I walked in during time off from a convention and practically had to be rolled home. It's cramped, noisy, and stuffy inside, and yet the amazing flavor of the food won me over. Yes, the staff basically grabbed my menu and said, "we'll take care of you." I am so glad I did, since I probably would never have picked the dishes they trotted out for us. I had some sesame chicken that makes me want to slap the guys running the Chinese stall at my local food court -- never knew that dish could taste so good. Chopped steak salad that was like dropping a juicy Philly steak onto fresh veggies. And a spicy fish that knocked me out.  I ate there four months ago, and I'm still talking about it.
author: Joe T.

description: How hard is it to make good Chinese food?  Nanking used to be the money place to go for good food and that's how I remembered my last trip 14 years ago.  I just went last night, and was definitely disappointed.  I love the gruff and quick service, but the food was not flavorful and our waitress talked us out of one dish for another that was horrible.    Maybe I'll go again in 14 years!
author: Dave L.

description: Go to Sam Wo instead. It's actually better and cheaper than this place. And at least there they let you order whatever the f**k you want!
author: Nucnuc M.

description: House of NAS-TEEE!  By far the worst meal we had during our week in San Francisco.  I went here back in the late 80's when it was a highly rated, cheap BYOB place.  Well, they have a bar, it's cleaned up a bit, the menu is smaller, and everything is pretty darn foul.  The potstickers are a heavy deep fried dough like a fortune cookie bathed in a peanut satay type sauce.  The hot and sour soup and the rice chowder soup were notable for being hot and bland.  The 'famed calamari' pushed by our server was fishy and went back to the kitchen, and the deep fried, heavily salted pork was tender only because most of it was fat.  The fact that this place is busy is a testament to the decline in food quality acceptance by the San Francisco populace.  As a Chicagoan who knows food, all I can say is that you people from SF should be ashamed to be supporting this grease pit.
author: Jay K.

description: I heard so much about this place that I definitely wanted to try it. First of all the service was horrible -- very rude to their potential customers. We were 5 in our party and were planning to order our entrees. The waiter told us this was the American way, and said that Chinese order different entrees and share. He said he'd select our meal. The food was not good!  In fact, I could not eat the food at all. We also had a problem with the top of a Cola can being dirty and a dish being unclean. The charge for what the server ordered for us came out to over $85.00
author: Diane M.

description: A terrible experience in a restaurant we have been to for more than 20 years for lunch.  Food was barely edible and service was non-existent.  The dumplings were cold; the beef dish defied description and was barely tasted by the three of us; and, the Nanking chicken was covered in sauce with small pieces of chicken and minimal sweet potatoes.  In the past we simply asked for whatever was good and never a question about the quality or portion sizes.  With so many great places to choose, this one is off our list.  It was twice as expensive as Henry's Hunan and without the quality.
author: Philip K.

description: So good to b back after 10 years !! Still amazing ! Great food, efficient service. Be careful of the line. Choose your hours right :)
author: el m.

description: I have always been a fan of this restaurant and its usually one of the first places to which I liked to bring friends from out of town.  NOT ANYMORE.  Let me tell you that I am now officially starting the NANKING REVOLT.  Think of it as a second coming of the Boxer Rebellion.  I went there today and the owner gave me this look like, 'oh great, YOU'RE here again?'  This guy obviously knows my face after so many times, but because I'm younger and with other students he wants to discriminate against us from the get go.  He never treats the older crowds like this.  The food was thoroughly inconsistent and the Nanking Chicken was chewy and a meager portion.  I never asked for rice but was charged 2 dollars for it, I was RUSHED OUT THE DOOR even though there was no line at 3 in the afternoon.  And here's the real kicker...we made friends with a lovely flight attendant sitting next to us and when we tried to put our credit cards down on the table to pay for our respective meals the guy was ordering us to use cash.  I asked if he was credit card machine was broken and all he did was send over another lady to tell us to use cash.  Again I asked if their credit card machine was broken and finally she gave in and took our cards in a disgruntled fashion.  Shady business.  They are either trying to report less for tax purposes or they are worried about the credit processing fee.  This practice is highly illegal and you should notify your credit card carrier if a restaurant you know tries to discourage you from using a card as they can have their merchant processing privileges revoked for it.  Do you realize that the amount of money that they spend on a 30 dollar bill for processing fees, even with an ugly rate would be like 25-30 cents!!!!  They were willing to make their customers feel like crap over a mere quarter!  If a friggin' quarter means this much to these people I implore you to just imagine for a moment the next time you're waiting in line like cattle for this overrated, inconsistent palace of msg how a business like this would choose to cut corners on quality for kitchen spending.  While you're thinking about that, I'll be waiting in line at Burma Superstar like any other self-respecting San Franciscan.
author: Pablo H.

description: I have been to House of Nanaking a long time back. Back then, people used to line up for hours at any time of the day. I remember the time I stood in line at 4:30 for 6 pm dinner. This place has gone downhill from those glory days. This restaurant was never known for its customer service. They create a community dining by having people share table which is OK for a popular and small restaurant like this, but then they ask you to change table middle of your meal to accommodate other guests !! I would ignore their arrogance for food, but now I don't think I will go back. It is over priced and over hyped restaurant.
author: Shankar K.

description:
Recently I took my parents to this so called well known restaurant. 
Customer service was very bad. They brought the main dish but no rice. 
Soup was not fully cooked. Owner came by and asked us if he should order something for us, he made us a dish which i never had it before and we didn't like it. Nothing was done about it. 
From other dish I bit on a stone (eggplant in garlic sauce) . I notified the owner he just laughed and asked me "really" I carried the stone to him but he was least interested to do anything about it. 
I don't think they care about repeated customers as they get lot of tourist business. But I will be telling my experience that i had from this place to all my friends so i can save them from the bad experience. 

Sad but true......
author: BK H.

description: My boyfriend and I went here for lunch. We ordered the sesame chicken, house noodles, and egg rolls. The sesame chicken was bland even though we added the spicy chilis to it. We had to borrow it from our neighbors since the service was so poor. The sweet potatoes were mushy, and the house noodles came out after we were done eating the sesame chicken. We got there at 11am when they opened but they didn't take our order until 11:20. They brought out the house noodles at 11:50 after we were done eating the sesame chicken. The house noodles were supposed to be thin but they were huge udon noodles. It was really disappointing not only from the poor service but also from the waiting and tasteless food. The total was $35 including tip and was totally not worth it. I don't know what all the hype is about.
author: Molly B.

description: First off, the sesame chicken is damn tasty, and it's worth at least one visit just to try it.  But after a couple visits, being treated like crap got old for me.  You can get equally delicous, cheap, greasy Chinese food at about a thousand other places in the city.
author: Julie M.

description: great food but sometimes it is a long wait. you dont know what they charge you for becuase its all in chinese writing. The tea that they give you is good too
author: steve a.

description:
have not been since remodel, so maybe things have changed but 
in the day, everything was stir fried and amazing

high energy place, yes a hole in the wall but incredible food
fresh, great stuff, amazing sauces
forget the whining about inconveniences just eat there, fight your way if it there is a crowd, ignore the grease dripping from the sign outside,
find your zen center and go for it
sometimes you have to fight to be noticed, and get things like glasses of water,
do not expect a conventional restaurant
onion cakes, nanking shrimp,  tsingtao beer  whatever amazing
if you are lucky the owner/staff will take care of you personally

forget Coppola's place across the street, dreadful arrogant service
author: furtivos h.

description:
My first visit and definitely not my last! I had a great meal there.  Let them order for you. Just tell them how hungry you are and any special dietary needs.  You are set!!!!

If you get the hot tea, don't worry, all the berries and stuff are edible and quite tasty!!!!
author: The R.

description: What happened here? I went a year ago and liked it. Now I will never go back. If you want deep-fried, disgusting chicken in a heavy, gross sauce then go. If not,  find another place in Chinatown. Don't be deceived by the line outside; it's not a reflection of the quality of the establishment. Bathroom is rundown and broken and dirty too. Mean waiters. Perhaps I ordered wrong? Unclear. But there's too many good restaurants in San Francisco to waste time here.
author: Janine Z.

description:
It is what it is what is....

1. hard to get a table at
2. greasy and sticky
3. hot inside
4. cramped
5. the best place in sf to have your waiter or waitress change your order while they are taking it and then eating the one of the best meals of your life.

Some advice. Just order some stuff and they'll change it for you because they think they know what you want. Don't argue, it oddly works.
author: David T.

description: This restaurant rocks!  I've never been told what I was going to eat by the owner of the restaurant I was in but it turned out great!  I would recommend the fried pot-stickers and the sesame chicken!  They are both great dishes that you can eat alone or share.  Always get there as early as possible, a long line starts at about 7pm, if your taking a group be patient it's so worth it!
author: Shawna G.

description: This place lost some no alot of the funk and magic when it tried to go upscale.  The food is still good, the atmosphere and crowd I could live without.  I will not eat there for while because within a 1/4 mile radius you have a lot lot lot better choices namely:  Chung King (better food, way better service); PO KE; Yuet Lee; and for some more $$ The R&G Lounge (way better food way).
author: Victor H.

description:
the foods are so good people,
we had party for 4 and everyone were so happy and so full.
don't forget to order the house special like sesame chicken.
we all agree this is the best sesame chicken that we ever had
author: chris j.

description: If you're looking for a good Authentic chinese restaurant...then this ISN'T the place.  If you're looking for very good 'Americanized' chinese food with an Authentic chinese setting (e.g. bad service, noisy cooks, cramped seating)...then this IS the place!  For the price and the serving portions this restaurants provides, it's not worth it.  You're better off at the hole-in-the-wall chinese restaurants in ChinaTown.
author: D C.

description:
Food is tremendous, atmosphere is classic hole-in the wall Chinatown restaurant with colorful character as it's proprietor.

Dining highlights include:  

Lettuce Wrapped Chicken
Tsing-Tao Prawns
Fried Shrimp Cakes

The line moves pretty quick and is definitely worth the wait.
author: Seamus H.

description: nothing about this experience was good. the sesame chicken was fatty, hard non-breast meat. the hot and sour soup was totally devoid of character. the pot stickers were deep fried, yuck....the beer wasn't even cold.
author: tabitha f.

description: Not sure what was worse the service the food or how dirty this establishment is,without question the worst dining expereience in over 30 years of eating in out  sf ,the ggopy sauces and the arrogant not to mention the complete fithiness of the restrooms and floors is a horror,the food was inedible and the service was atrocious F+++ with all of the great restaurants especially chinese in SF how this place ever managed to draw an award is astonishing and appaling We will never return nor recommend!!!!
author: al g.

description: If the line is that long, it must be fantastic, right? Wrong. The food here is just mediocre. There are no lines at the best Chinese restaurant in San Francisco next door, Chef Jia's. After eating at Chef Jia's, I can't go back to the House of Nanking, even if Chef Jia's is closed.
author: Presto G.

description: the venue is pretty small and although the seating arrangements were tight, i thought the food was very delicious! this is one of my favorite places to eat when i visit san francisco. i definitely recommend it for those who are just feeling for some fast asian food.
author: Erin Felix P.

description: We skipped the menu and just asked for dinner for 4. Worked out amazingly.
author: Marcus S.

description: It was my birthday and what a disappointment!!!  The food qualiy was not what I heard, everything was too sweet, had to consume lots of water to wash it down.  Their signature dish, onion cake, was terrible.  I have had plenty of onion cake in my lifetime, this is probably the worst.  The sweet sauce over the onion cake was not necessary.  Aside the poor quality of the dishes we ordered, the staff were rude, not just to us, but to the entire restaurant customers.  They (4 or 5 of them) were carrying  a conversation in the back of the restaurant talking loudly, at times, like a screaming match.  One of the male staff was even using some Chinese profane language.  That totally had ruined my day.  I consider this is to be a decent restaurant where people can come and have a nice quiet dinner, but this???   What a disgrace to the Chinese community!  On top of all that, everything is overpriced.  This would be my last visit to this place.
author: Celina S.

description: have heard a bunch of hype about this place and it definitely lived up to my expectations! I love how they just ask what you like and don't like and then they do the rest. i usually hate deciding and ordering which can take forever with a large group. And with the family style serving you get to try like ten things anyway. Sesame chicken was f*cking bomb! Potstickers were crispy and delicious. I loved the chicken soup with rice. Yummy pork dish and beef dish, too. The blooming tea is also very entertaining! I'm so glad I met up late so I didn't have to wait in line, though!
author: N. M.

description: Yet another severely under-rated Yelp restaurant. We went in with out-of-town guests (nearly every single out-of-towner who has comed to visit has heard of House of Nanking - any most of them are from the East coast) and had to wait outside for 30 minutes. Yes, not ideal, but you must live in the boonies to not know that there is almost always a line for House of Nanking. I HATE that people on Yelp consider this a reason to give the restaurant low stars - if you don't want to wait in line, don't go. Keep the line shorter for people like me. Anyhow, we site down and the chef asks us if we've been here. Though one in the party had been there before, we say we haven't been. He immediately takes the menus away and says "I'll take care of you." We were promptly delivered several courses of AMAZING food. Spring rolls, shrimp, chicken and rice soup, sesame chicken, mushu. Every single dish was memorable. Though I've obviously had Chinese food many, many times before, this restaurant somehow makes traditional Chineses dishes fresh and interesting again. House of Nanking is always worth the wait and something everyone should try.
author: Niki N.

description: I wasn't sure where to exactly get Chinese food.. A friend of mine recommended me House of Nanking.. I must say, it was absolutely delicous.. Sesame Chicken... one word, AMAZING. it's fried just right, with the honey glaze sauce over it, with a side of sweet potatoes... god they're to die for... and the Chow Mein.. like I've never seen before, but it was also very good; a bit spicy but definitely a goodie. I will definitely be coming back here!
author: Judy L.

description: This place is frequented by new arrivals to San Francisco who do not know any better yet.  The food is overly oily and the place is not the cleanest.  However, always quite popular during lunch with the financial district folks.  For those who are willing to walk a bit further above Keary Street there is a whole world of better quality food and often cheaper.
author: Rosey R.

description:
Our hotel recommended this place for dinner. It was a decent walk and House of Nanking didn't disappoint! This is really the best Chinese food I've ever had. The atmosphere is upbeat and you may be sat with another group of people, but this just adds to the fun. the family next to us saw what we ordered and immediately got their own plate. 
We started with the pot stickers which were great. The peanut sauce added a great flavor that I wasn't used to. Next we had sesame chicken and the garlic ginger scallops. Both were great, but the scallops were the best I've ever had. Great ginger-soy sauce and thinly sliced scallops and a great presentation. I'm pretty sure I've ruined my appetite for Chinese cuisine back home! 
A couple quick notes - a line forms pretty quick outside. Worth the wait. Also, the family that ordered sesame chicken after us got a smaller plate than we did. The plate size seemed random. 
Bring cash!
author: Jeff W.

description:
Not just for tourists anymore!

I went here twice five years ago and thought it was just ok. 

I just went back and it was really good. I was impressed that dishes were fresh, not greasy, and had some nice touches. The eggplant, for instance, was served on a bed of snow pea shoots which are usually expensive and had some battered sweet potato strips as well. I also enjoyed the mu shu and the great tea with flowers floating in it.
author: Arptro H.

description:
The old guy who owned the place is cool!
I went there because of a friend's recommendation and I really liked what I got there..

The man asked if we're indonesians and we said yes.. then he asked if it's our first time and we said yes.. then he asked how many orders do we want and we said 3... then he took care of the rest

the food was delicious and the tea was very interesting (in a good way)
author: Yossita K.

description: Maybe it was what we ordered (fried, fried, and then more fried), but was rather heavy. Or maybe i wasn't in the mood for chinese. Anyway, it was OK, and probably pretty good if I was in the mood for more junky food.
author: hugh k.

description:
...Nnnnno.  Sorry.  No.

I read all the love/ hate in these reviews and decided to give it a go.  Abusive waitstaff who will order my food for me?  Hurrah!  Adventure dining!

We did let our waitress order.  She was relatively polite.  We ended up with six various rapid-fire dishes and a $75 tab. There was a delicious fish dish, and the rest of it was pretty blah.  It took about twenty minutes to get a bill, and we left feeling taken advantage of (yet, sadly unabused.  I was promised abuse!).

Not going back.  Overrated.
author: Jen T.

description:
Don't understand why there is always a line outside the door to this place. Food is not very good and it is extremely dirty inside. 

Would not go back again.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Long lines, overpriced tourist trap food. Lived 5 minutes from it and would never go back there if you paid me to stand in line.
author: Tom F.

description: The service here was pretty bad.  I've always wanted to eat here but have avoided it because of the long lines.  I've also heard really good things from friends. I was walking by randomly with my boyfriend and was shocked when I didn't see a line.  We decided to try it, even though we weren't super hungry.  It took awhile for someone to take our order. . .We ordered one dish.   . . the fried tofu.  It was supposed to come with broccoli, but came with green beans.  When we asked about it they kept telling us that it was fine and we kept telling them it was supposed to come with broccoli.  The waiter then told us that it didn't come with broccoli . . .so I asked for a menu and showed him on the menu . . . he then said he was sorry and that I would have to talk to the owner and walked away.  He didn't get the owner or try to help us.  The staff seemed to treat us and others like we didn't matter.  The food was good but not great and the service really turned me off . . . I don't have plans to return.  It's also really expensive . . . and in my humble opinion overrated.
author: Heather C.

description: Ok I don't know jack about Chinese food, but I know like the sesame chicken plate. It's awful for you and I hit the gym immediately after, but I think it's worth it. It's like Panda Express for grownups.
author: Madalyn F.

description: bad service, whatever, salty food and too pricey! not worth it, not going there again. $0 tips!
author: Vale O.

description: I loved the fried pot stickers. The staff is very abrupt but I wrote that off as part of the experience. The food is excellent. It is small and crowded. We wished we had time to go there more than once on our trip.
author: Michelle D.

description: The wait to get in here is long but well worth it. It was late and this was one of the few places that were still open that my friend and I decided to give it a try. We were impressed. The food was flavorful and the service was fast. You are sitting elbow to elbow with other parties but its a great way to mingle and talk with other visitors or locals. We didn't know what to order and took suggestions from the waiter. She did not steer us wrong. We loved every dish that was ordered and for the price, it was very reasonable. Will definitely come back  here when I visit sf.
author: sally w.

description: this place is freaking amazing.. if you have questions bout what to order, or hesitate in anyway, the chef will order for you. the marinated sweet potatoes are insane.
author: James F.

description:
Don't eat here if you are expecting authentic good food and tolerable service! 
My boyfriend had tried this place years ago and remembered it being good so we went there while we visited San Francisco from Los Angeles. I have tried the best of Chinese food and I was expecting something decent based on the review. Upon arriving, they asked us to get out of the way and threw menus on the table after they sat us down elbow to elbow with other patrons. I was still feeling fine and hoping the poor attitude will translate into fine cuisine. The menu was disappointing (Mushu Tofu with tortilla and plain rice?) but I was still game and ordered a dumpling soup with slow cooked broth.
 When the server brought the soup over, she quickly shoved the hot soup in between me and  another customer without notifying either of us, and the gentleman, unaware of what's happening bumped her and the soup spilled over and burned me. She left me some napkins and served me the same bowl of soup that's half spilled... Call it after shock, but for some reason, I stayed long enough to taste the soup and it was plain as water. Then my boyfriend's pathetic tofu tortilla arrived and we just stood up and left . We were stopped by a woman that asked us what happened and after we explain the situation, she did not apologize and put us on the spot in the middle of the restaurant by asking who did it. Yeah, the exact context "who did it?" The server started to squirm and told her that because that guy had moved and from the corner of my eyes I saw that man's stunned expressed on my way out.

The food was a disgrace and the service was horrible. Do Not Go There!
author: Jackie F.

description: Over rated for sure .... the sesame chicken we had had too much soy sauce and was salty. The chow mein was similar. Service, due to it's busy environment was brisk and lamentable. Not sure why people keep lining up.
author: Adwait U.

description:
Food - average
Service - quick

Don't know why people wait for this food?
author: Phi N.

description:
I am visiting San Francisco and staying at Hilton Financial district. I was trying to figure out a good place for lunch and a nice gentleman by the concierge's desk suggested House of Nanking [which is just a block away]

I walked into this place and it was packed, with very close seating. For a moment I wasn't sure If I wanted to go in, but very glad I did...The owner took my order, I told him I wanted something with a lot of veggies, no tofu and a little spicy. He said he'll order the dish for me ... My dish came out loaded with veggies in a brown sauce... Oh it was the delicious .... Enjoyed every bite of it .... 

I would surely go back .....
author: Ha R.

description: This place is way over rated!  The food was OK and the service was horrible.  Who has heard of a Chinese restaurant that does not have hot mustard sauce.....I say pass...
author: Terrell B.

description: I'm sorry but this friggin' place sucks. What's with all the stellar reviews? I've noticed a trend on Yelp as of late, and its kind of a shame.  Whenever something starts rolling in four and five star reviews, that momentum often becomes self-perpetuating and just carries the place into automatic fame, regardless of if its deserving or not.  This place is certainly not deserving of having an overall four-star rating after 70+ reviews.  Its awful. Its super cramped and tiny, low quality ingredients result in excessively greasy dishes, the service is hasty and pressuring, no doubt to whisk you out quickly and max out the tables they can serve.  Totally over-rated indeed. I've been there twice, but if you really want good chinese food in San Francisco and don't need the ultimate chinatown tourista experience, there are many other better choices, including on Clement Street, Irving Street and even in Chinatown.
author: Rick H.

description: best chinese i've ever had.  just come with an open mind and empty stomach
author: Jo G.

description: I am fat so I want to dictate what I want to put in my belly.  We waited for 45 minutes but thats was fine.  I agree with a previous entry.  DO NOT LET THEM ORDER FOR YOU.  I tried to order for our table but I don't speak my dirty canto language so Peter (the owner I assume) just ignored my order.  He probably knew we were noobs because we were the only fat asians there.  So he decided to order for us.  Thinking he would hook us up he brought out a calamari dish, a soup dish, and a vegetable dish.  They were all very good with quality ingredients but I thought they were just appetizers because the table next to us had the same dishes as their first course.  WTF!  For 3 people I like to order 1.5 dishes per person so every can sample.  After reading that previous entry I feel like we were violated.  For 3 dishes including a soup it was $50!  WTF!  I want to go back and order food I orignally wanted to try but  for the money and freedom to order for yourself I'd rather spend it at R&G lounge down the street.  PS:  Brush your teeth, take a shower and put on some deodorant, Peter.  I am pretty sure it wasnt the food that smelled bad.
author: Fatty A.

description: First impression coming in, oh, it's a small place. But wait, they lead us twice rejected yelpers into another room. Good call. After a pleasant yelp elite party, we had gone hunting for nourishment after being kindly rejected by two closing restaurants before being somewhat welcomed into this one. I was in good company, I think that's why I couldn't focus on the menu and I was hoping someone else was decisive enough to choose for the whole table like my friends and I usually do. The chef came up and I am certain he calculated our gestures and gave us his best for the night, family style. I liked that, even though it might be the rushed thing to do at the time. His good intentions were there and that's what boosted his stars for the night. They did not disappoint with the choices, though I wish I caught the name of some of the dishes. We had asparagus, some kind of fried wonton potato type thingamabob, mu shu'ish beef, and some kind of sweet chicken with steamed rice. Now, we all now I'm an easy to please country boy. But dining here was fantastic. The company helped a lot too. I am however, still trying to get the taste out of my mouth and two bottles of water later... It's still there. After brushing my teeth... still there. Alright, so maybe the next time I go here it will be for lunch. This is probably my fault somehow. =] I need a second opinion.
author: Ryan R.

description: tourist trap...who cares, it was cool standing in line.  the food was great, had a "trust me" from the dude taking our orders....lots of good stuff, i'd def go back...i like how they integrate some new ingredients into traditional chinese foods.
author: Eric t.

description:
want to feel like an asian kid in trouble with your parents at dinnertime? go to house of nanking

need more 'splaining? peep this: if there is a wait, you will be shooed outside with an exasperated wave of the hand. you will be given a fork because you don't know how to use chopsticks. conversational interaction is discouraged. any requests of your server will be met with disapproval. you will inevitably go to bed (emotionally) hungry.
author: Erica C.

description: First of all the food is probably the best Chinese food i ever had the house special is good and you got to try the noodles... service was just ok....
author: Danny C.

description: You know you're in trouble when you walk in and the place is full of white people.  Not only are all the people white, but they are mostly not from around here.  So, if you're from Kansas or Illinois, this may be the place for you. But if you are from San Francisco, New York City or Los Angeles, you do not eat here.
author: Tracy Y.

description: First, never let the chef "take care of you."  He wouldn't allow us to order from the menu and said he would take care of us since we had a large group.  The food was good, but we had to send several things back because he didn't take our dislikes into consideration- which we discussed in the beginning.  However, all of that is forgivable....but finding a LARGE STAPLE in the food (our friend actually almost swallowed it) is not.  When we made the owner aware of this he acted like it was no big deal.  He said it's probably from the box of vegtables.  When the bill came it was obvious we were being charged for the staple dish and when we asked him to take it off our bill he seemed irritated and said, "this isn't McDonald's."  Needless to say, I'll never go back.  The food was so so (I've had it better elsewhere) and the service was horrible.
author: K L.

description: I'm not sure what kind of hold this place has over some people, but House of Nanking is just plain done. In fact, it's overdone. Even more overdone than their sesame chicken. Back in the early 90's, it was all the rage to drink a tsing tao in line while waiting for a table. It was fun to get smacked around by the presumptuous, greedy owner who refused to respect your personal space - or you pocketbook - by violently recommending dishes while pushing you by the collar into your chair. Think Soup Nazi. The trouble is, the food doesn't back up the stale hype and hasn't for years now. House of Nanking is not a loveable hole-in-the-wall treasure. It's an overly hyped embarrassment where the only thing worse than the unamusing bad service is the food. Do yourself a favor. Walk out of the restaurant, turn left, then make another left on Columbus. Go up a few blocks and enter Brandy Ho's, which will be on the left. The owners are terrific and the food is consistent and reliable. It's a trend that is much more deserving of your time and money.
author: Lisa B.

description: so i was skeptical about a restaurant that you just give the ingredients you don't like and they do the rest to give you a few tasty dishes.  but i was blown away with the flavors of 2 dishes, they were fresh and full of flavor.  the only reason i didn't give this place more stars was b/c of our 3rd dish that was forgotten so when we asked about it they just slapped together a dish that was not really as good as the first 2.  but man, i am saddened b/c i will never eat those dishes again b/c i live on the east coast and i actually have no idea what all the ingredients were that i ate!!  i would go back in a heart beat when in san fran.
author: jennifer r.

description: waiter ordered for us. calamari and sesame chicken were delicious. popular among tourists.
author: Ben W.

description: Hey people, this is a terrible restaurant! It is hilarious to see the long lines of tourists all lined up to eat here. Who is recommending this place to them? It is a mystery to me. By the way, I never see a Chinese or Chinese American lining up.  The food here stinks! The service is surly. Anyone who eats here hasnt a clue about Chinese food.
author: Anne B.

description: This place is such a unique experience.  No reservations means long lines outside -- and then once you are seated you immediately feel like you are in a rush to get out of there.  No menus are given - pretty much you have a choice between water, sodas and beer - you tell them beer - who knows what they are going to bring out, but whatever it was it was tasty.  As for the food - the waiter asked if there was anything we didn't like - we told him we were up for anything and then the food onslaught began.  So much food - asparagus in a garlic sauce, some kind of pork egg rolls, calamari, eggplant in a fantastic sauce which some kind of meat or maybe tofu, this crazy beef noodle dish, the special Nanking chicken dish.  I am sure I am forgetting stuff, but seriously the food just kept coming.  We were a big group but we were kind of concerned that there would be too much food but it worked out perfectly and we all were members of the clean plate club.  All of the dishes were fantastic but this is not a place to go where you want to take a time.  You truly feel like you are in a food race because the food comes out so quickly and it just keeps coming.  This is also not a place to go if you are a picky eater or have to know what you are ingesting.  House of Nanking is for those who are a little adventurous but it is not like we ate anything crazy - veggies, pork, beef, chicken and calamari.  You just won't know what is coming out of the kitchen next.  The kicker is -- we got a ton of food and had one-two beers each and it ended up $22 a person.  Almost impossible considering how much food we had.
author: Katie P.

description: i can't see what the fuss is about. i've been there a few times, but there are better places in chinatown. i guess if you're in north beach after bar hopping and want to stay in the hipster scene, it's the next stop.
author: Shinn Z.

description: theres a reason why not many natives eat here.  its not that good.  i went here with some friends, and its like panda express.  me and my friends were the minorities...in a FREAKING CHINESE RESTAURANT.  like ming tsai said, if you look into a chinese restaurant, and you dont see any chinese people inside, the food sucks
author: A L.

description: I've been to Shanghai (with a Chinese local taking me around to the locals spots) and this is the closest thing in America I've ever had to Shanghainese food.  That's because the owner is from Shanghai.  To the many reviewers who say this isn't real Chinese, you're just plain wrong.  China is big, there are many different styles of cuisine.  This is Shanghai style Chinese, and it's treally treal.  (And just because you're Chinese American doesn't mean a damn thing if you have shit for taste.)  House of Nanking is an experience.  Don't pick up that menu, just talk to your server (often times the owner himself) about what you like and don't like and how many dishes you want and he'll arrange your meal for you.  This waiter-to-customer dialog is a very Chinese thing and it will benefit you (you'll probably get a good variety of things with the freshest ingredients of the day).  The line is a bummer, no doubt, but if you're not a big baby (read: most yelpers), you'll have a real Shanghai experience, and that's what House of Nanking is all about.
author: Evan M.

description: The Nanking Chicken paired with sweet potatoes is a great dish.  Peter the owner takes pride in ordering for you and so far it's been a great experience.
author: Ralph H.

description: came with a friend.  was excited with all the reviews and awards postered all over the restaurant.  waited on by the owner/chef.  ordered a couple of dishes for us.  nice guy, bad food.  all hype, i liked none of it, nada, zilch, zero.  chef ordered us some "special" soup.  was won ton soup and not all that special, actually quite bad.  also had, a beef dish, calamari, and string beans w/pork.  bad, eh, and eh.  will only  go back kicking and screaming.  if i wanted okay americanized chinese food, better to hit up pf chang.
author: Bob C.

description: I've been coming here when  it was truly a hole in the wall (over 15 years ago).  It is still pretty much a hole in the wall--you know-- dirty, greasy, loud and such but the food is the only reason we come back.   We don't seem to go back as often as we used to.  Peter (the owner) was much nicer in the earlier days and would strike up a conversation with you and give you his signature sly smile and serve beers as you waited outside.  It was great as the line was so long it would block the entrance to the place next door and they would come out and yell at Peter... that place was empty and I'm sure they were jealous of his success.  Over the years (as the restaurant expanded to the space next door) it seems to have lost most (not all) of its charm.  Sure, the food is still good (order the potstickers and chix w/ sweet potatoes) but don't go there to really enjoy your meal.  From the moment you are seated, it's rush, rush, rush.  They rush over to take your order--don't bother to look at the menu,  just tell Peter what kind of meat or veggies you like and he'll do it for you.  Then, you'll get all sorts of things in various, random order.  You probably won't have time for another beer as they want you in and out as fast as you can eat.  You'll get the food and probably the check at the same time.  You'll be packed in like sardines and won't be able to do much talking.  I swear, we are usually in and out of there in less than 20 minutes.  For the amount of food they serve, the speed is amazing (especially considering  the size of the kitchen).  During the early years, we called it 'cheap chinese' as it used to be one of the best deals in town.  It's not that way anymore (good things never last) but I admire them for what they do--dealing with demanding locals and clueless tourists on a daily basis.   If you've never experienced this place, you have to go at least once to try and figure out why this place is so popular.  You may need to suck in your gut to  fit in the small, cramped seats and tables.  Actually, it's like eatting with 20 of your closest friends--problem is you don't know any of them.  I guess this is a part  of San Francisco that everyone should experience--but probably just once.  I'm sure we'll go back again--I'm a glutton for punishment.
author: Brian M.

description: this place is supposedly real popular according to my sf transplants.  also lines out the door.  the place relaly reminded me of the places in taiwan so i felt pretty close to home.  i dont think i ordered the right dishes because everything was just a bit above decent.  next time i want to try the appetizers with the peanut sauce.
author: Tiffany L.

description: I heard many wonderful  things about this rest. So I took it for a test. If you go after 1:30 pm, place will probably have three tables to spare, and plenty of parking around the corner.  I didn't even know what I was looking at on the menu so I told the owner I am a vegetarian. He started showering my with dishes.  I love mushrooms, and I love tofu. so any thing with those two item in it. I'm all for.  One of the tofu dishes is sweet and sour. crispy on the outside and super steamy and soft in the inside, every bites makes your mouth watery.  Service was okie. I like their hot tea with real flowers in it and not bitter at all.  One thing I didn't apperciate too much is when I was in line to be pay the bill.  I came before a white woman. (sorry I don't know how else to describe an ethnicity).  The woman's bill was accepted before mine.  I'm an asian female and I don't appreciated experience like that.
author: tahni c.

description: This place is overrated.  You don't see Chinese eating there.  Why?  It's not real Chinese food.  If you like garlic and grease on every dish, you go there!  I barely touched the food I ordered. Just looking at the oil on the plate made me sick.
author: A N.

description: I love this place! Although the food does tend to make my stomach hurt on occasion, the deliciousness when you are eating makes it worth it in my book! Although there is usually a line it really does tend to move fast! I would suggest asking your waiter to order for you because they have never steered me wrong! wish i knew what to recommend but I never know what I am eating...these stuffed mushroom things are always really good, the calamari has an interesting almost vinegar-y yummy taste, and their dumplings and the sesame chicken are delicious!! This is some of the best food I have ever eaten, i absolutely LOVE it!
author: Heather M.

description: After all the hype, after all the times I've walked/driven past and seen the lines at all hours, I couldn't help but visit this place as the other place a friend and I went to but discovered it closed at just 6pm!! wow!! We walked the easy chilly walk from Stockton & Powell Sts to Nanking and was shocked there were NO lines..  the first time ever!! We went inside and were quickly shown a table... no sitting side by side but facing each other - the place fills up quickly and they were assembly-line seating us ready for crowds. The quite pricey menu didn't sound too appetizing to me so I decided to play it safe ordering the pork wonton soup and the house thick/short noodles with veggies...  The soup came within minutes...  it was slightly spicy and though I HATE - absolutely HATE - spicy, it was good enough for me to finish it off, though I gasped for air and choked each time I drank the soup liquid....  there was enough wonton for four and between my friend and I it was ample. The house noodles arrived late, about ten minutes later as I think they forgot to place the order. That was a bad point for me and the tabletop was sticky, which I hate to feel in a restaurant of ANY caliber. It disgusts me that a place cannot keep their tables clean but oh well....  when the noodles came, it was HOT and good! Not too hard, not spongy and mushy....  just right! It was tasty and I ate it all up.....  I would like to save for a year or two to return and order some of my other meal items that I like, but this was a good start. My friend and I were the only asians in the place at the time, except for those who worked there. It was noisy and everyone was talkative/loud which - to me - is a good sign that everyone was enjoying their food. There was a lot of head-turning and staring at the other table/people and what they ordered and everyone seemed satisfied. The people who sat next next to us and were served before us - visiting from LA and Boston - loved their pot-stickers with peanut sauce and other items.
