One of them had been here while vacationing previously during the year and now on a business trip, decided it was worth a TAXI-ride from their Redwood City hotel (and back) to try it with her co-worker ~ wow!!  I'd probably return with out-of-town friends....    no parking and as stated earlier: always a line though we lucked out this time. Food is very flavorable!!!
author: Tony L.

description: love this place but can't go there to often for fear of a heart attack.  i love that i can depend on the owner to always order great stuff for me and whomever i'm with at the time.  get the crispy chicken and shrimp.  YUM!
author: Swarup B.

description: I'm always on the lookout for a really good, hole-in-the-wall Chinese restaurant...this didn't do it for me.   It was recommended by friends so I went one evening and was initially encouraged by the crowd and the reviews posted all over the walls. Upon finishing my meal and leaving, I was dissapointed. Service was speedy considering the crowd.  Ordered sizzling rice soup, mu shu (sp?) chicken and fried prawns.  The soup had a LOT of annise in it...so overpowering to the other ingrediants as to render the soup unenjoyable.  Shrimp was very good and the portion size and presentation made it an incredible value for the $11 we paid for the dish.  Mu shu chicken was NOT at all what we expected it to be.  Perhaps we're used to American chinese and this is more authentic...perhaps not...either way, the mu shu chicken reminded me more of P.F Chang lettuce wrap filling than any mu shu I've ever had. It was also served without plum sauce (my favorite part).  It then proceeded to take forever for our check to come.  Overall it was OK.  Price was right, but I don't think I'd come back or recommend it to friends.
author: Jenni D.

description: I've eaten at the House of Nanking several times before and decided to take my dad there for a birthday lunch. We arrived at 2pm on a Friday and the place was packed. There was a line outside that we joined and were seated within 10 minutes. I think everyone will agree that you don't come to this North Beach institution for the service, but the food never lets me down. The distinctively white haired owner took our order, without cracking a smile or looking up from his pad of paper. My parents had never been there, so I took charge of ordering--- well, my dad ordered the fried eggplant, which proved to be our least favorite dish. It had good flavors, a garlicky chili sauce, but was a bit heavy on the fried for us. I ordered the peashoot salad with fried yam strips and crispy tofu. I love this dish. I think I could eat it almost everyday. The light vinaigrette on the peashoots is perfect, a little sesame oil, a little rice vinegar, and whatever else is in it. The peashoots have a great texture, soft and a little crunchy and they begin to slowly wilt in the dressing as the meal goes on. Then we got the sesame chicken with sliced yams and some asian melon that I'm not sure what it is. The chicken is barely battered and has a slightly crunchy edge and a sweet sesame sauce. Its served with white rice and is delicious. This place is an institution for a reason---they do what they do incredibly well. I would recommend this restaurant to anyone and everyone.
author: Ariel D.

description:
have you ever heard an Asian person say "Don't eat at a (insert Asian genre here) restaurant if the only people eating in there are non-Asian"?
well something along the lines of that. this is one of those places that this saying doesn't really seem to count in my book (be it small)...
the house of nanking is a colorful place, bustling and noisy for sure,  you basically get in where you fit in. both times we got stuck by the door and it was a little cold. 
however.
i have been told that everything on the menu here is "delectable" and i like that word alot- as well as using quotes, or if i were giving this review in person i might very well be using air quotes- so this place is alright by me.
the owner of the house of nanking presides over his kingdom, mingling with the little people (us), and offering his imperial opinions on menu selections. he has this "i'll take care of you" flair about him, that i think draws in loyal patrons by the droves. smart guy.
i must say that i am just drooling thinking about the spicy wonton crispy fish soup (not sure if that's exactly what it's called but it's REALLY GOOOOOD! just "trust" him)
i'm definitely heading back to H.O.N. soon to try the other "delectable" delights they have to offer.
cons:
1. the steamed rice is not so fresh, kinda hard and clumpy.....but all the more reason to be low carb, eh?
2. parking is a biatch, too bad they don't validate for the Portsmouth Square parking garage....
author: Lori J.

description: I went here upon the insistent recommendation of a couple friends, and walked away wishing I hadn't just dropped that $14.  I ordered the "famous" sesame chicken with yams, as well as a large mug of green flower tea.  Well, the food was certainly tasty (though not overwhelmingly so) and the tea was fun to drink, but the real bust for me was when I found a short, thick, black hair in my food, at the end of my meal.  Now, i know that this sort of thing happens, but what got to me was the staffs inability to recognize it, and simply say "I'm sorry".  I informed my waitress, who in turn informed the Chinese mafia like mama who was sitting there stuffing her face, reading the newspaper and directing people to do this and that.  She told her in Chinese, and she in turn said something that I can only interpret as "who cares".  Neither of them actually communicated withe me about it, end of story.  Well, I didn't leave a tip, and won't be back.
author: Frankie S.

description: I loved it when it was a hole in the wall but now it is a bit bigger. Worth the wait, and the food was pretty good but not GREAT!
author: Kate K.

description: My favorite place to eat in all of San Francisco!!  This is the one place I would take family and friends when they came to visit, of course my treat. If it's your first time just tell them that and they'll bring out three different plates, or just order off the menu.. Soooo freakin good!!!!!!   Really great cause after a fabulous meal there right around the corner up a few blocks there's Jack Kerouac alley.  Stop into Vesuvio's and have some drinks...
author: Raymond A.

description: Saw this place on Soul Cities on MTV2, the food was good but the customer service is something to be desired.  I thought it was going to be a lot better then what it was.  We ordered chicken chow mein, beef brocolli and seasame chicken.  It was ok but the drama on the table next to us was better.  The waiteress tried to tell the people that they had ordered some soup even though they already got their soup.  This went on for about 10 minutes of our meal.  Needless to say there is a lot better for a lot cheaper and more customer friendly places out there. Will not be returning here.
author: T G.

description: The food was delicious.  A friend and I went on a Thursday night at about 8:00 and had to wait about 20-30min to get a table, not bad.  The menu is great, not your typical chinese food.  Everything tastes fresh.  We ordered the fried calamari, the house noodles, and the country soup with fish.  Everything was stellar, but the soup was literally out of this universe.  The tea is the flowering jasmine tea, so it is also extra good.  Take visitors here for sure, they will be impressed.   And, its just a short walk to all the Italian bakeries!
author: Alex C.

description: This place is a san francisco institution.  I love the food.  Its al fresh and made to order.  if you dont know what you to order, the owner is usually there and will grab your menu and just put an order in for you.  thats what I suggest you do.
author: Jason S.

description: Mediocre food and service and cleanliness.  Whoever gave this a 5 was lying.  Hot and sour soup had zuccini, no mushrooms, chicken instead of pork, peas, and tasted like vinegar.  Fried calamari with lemon was okay, barely, but came with soup, even tho it was main course. Rice came 10 minutes later. Huh? Tea was ordered and none came.  Waiter stuck his thumb in the middle of my soup spoon.  I pulled out my hand sanitizer.  Price was high for small portions of mediocre food.  Give me a break.  This is a rip off.
author: c p.

description: Have been here twice.  The first time, I was with my cousins and we let the waitress order for us.  That was a memorable meal with dumplings, fish stew (including the heads), sesame chicken, scallops, and a shrimp salad.  Yum!  Especially the stew.  The cons?  Tables are crowded and you'll be seated next to strangers (bad for a date), they don't take credit cards, and if you come at a prime time for dinner, you'll be waiting a very long time.  I returned here with my dad for lunch today.  Not being the adventurous sort, my dad ordered sesame chicken from the menu.  No wait, not very crowded, food still good, but we spent more than 20 minutes trying to pay for our meal.  Our waitress had received a UPS package of new shoes and spent the next 20 minutes showing them off to all of her coworkers while ignoring all the customers.  The only other guy working in the place would not acknowledge the tables he was not assigned to.  I'm not a big stickler about service in general, but this was pretty ridiculous.  HON - you get three stars for your yummy food, but service today was not cool.
author: Laura M.

description: Go to Nanking and order the onion rolls. They are quite possibly the most delicious Chinese dish I've ever had. Of course, everything at Nanking is fucking fantastic, and you know what? I actually like that the owner often doesn't take your order, it's nice being surprised. Nanking is the best ever.
author: Matt T.

description: I thought this place was interesting and had a niche of it's own. The charming "let us order your meal for you" thing could be impressive for some westerners.  What you want?  Chicken? Pork? Tofu?  Vegetable? The taste of the food was more fun than anything and there was a plus of not feeling the pangs of MSG.  The food was tasty. A fusion of chinese styles made in an appealing western style what with fork plate and paper napkin settings.  When we got to the end of the meal I looked at my friend and I asked him, "how do we charged if we don't know what we're getting?"  His eyes widened and then the bill arrived, I picked it up and saw it was $40 for: fried mushu stuffed w/mush. and sweet'n'sour sauce; pea shoots with bits of julianned sweet potatoe fries; a whitefish pieces with wine and asparagus; a bowl of rice (wet); and 2 Tsing Taos and 2 teas (the tea was lycium berry & chrysanthemum, over some "green tea").
author: Angel Q.

description: I think a little piece of my heart just broke. I've been lounging around my house wondering what in the world a girl's to do for dinner on a Saturday night...for one, when I wondered if House of Nanking had the unrivaled kindness to deliver to my door. To my dismay, when I looked up this information on my favorite yelp and found "no delivery", I was a bit upset, however, this feeling of distress was nothing in comparison to the  sorrow I felt when I read the latest reviews. How could you!?! How COULD you think that this place was anything less than little nibblets of Chinese heaven. Sure the service doesn't pat your ass when you walk by and leave a chocolate mint on your stool, but Mr. Nanking HIMSELF not only takes your order, but if requested, gives your order for you. It's loud, it's obnoxious, it's what you should expect before you go. I will stand by you Nanking, I will keep your multi-color lights aglow for all the coming years...even without the love and hope from the others before me!
author: Willa K.

description: All we care about is food.... And if u do so too then you'll love this place... I agree that the food is greasy but who cares.. We loved the food with right amount of portions...I loved the "onion cake" with the home speciality sauce...sesame chicken...uumm yumm...
author: Deepu S.

description: it doesn't matter what the service is like. this place is a total dive, but they have the best non-authentic chinese dishes you will ever find. the chef is an artist. he creates these dishes. let them feed you. plus, their tea is REALLY good. i'm a fan.
author: amy s.

description: the food is good. im not a big fan of potato but the way they make it is really good. if you like sweet and sour, this is definitely the place to go to. the chef there is really nice and he can definitely give you some recommendations on what to order. i love their dumpling soup and their sweet and sour chicken with potato on the side.
author: Anita C.

description: my mother insists on going here whenever she visits, but i'm not as excited as she is.  it's tasty, but not supertasty.
author: Puck F.

description: when I first moved to SF, I thought this place rocked..but shortly after I realized that food is a one-trick-pony ...everything tastes the same (more or less.) what I think I really liked was being about to drink beers while we waited outside in line.....its a novelty act for sure....which in itself has its merit
author: Carlos F.

description: heres the deal, i started going here about 15 years ago when i asked someone where to go for Chinese food in the area and was told that the food here is "amazing" . the food back then was amazing, very small place (peter grew the place since then). so small in fact that the tables were so close together that you get to smell and sometimes (if you ask nicely)try out your neighbor's dish.  i do remember the last time i was there (maybe 3 years ago) the food was not as good as i remembered it.  i will still go back next time i go up to SF but i do love Sam Woo's nearby for killer greasy Chinese food! some of the reviews of this place are close minded, go and enjoy yourself and if you want authentic, go to Asia!
author: Jim K.

description: Let the guy waiter person order for you. Its the chef, Peter Feng, (i hope i got his name right) and your food will always turn out good. When I came here, there was a mediumish line. House of Nanking is smack dab in the middle on China town, near this place with rotten tofu, so it smells kinda stinky when you're waiting. In line, my family talked to the people in front of us, who said when the chef orders for you, it always turns out good. The restaurant is EXTREEMELLLYYYY crowded, but i would come back for the food. Since the chef ordered for us, I have no clue what the names are of our food. Also, after talking to my teacher who's a foodie as well, he told me when he went, the chef gave him more Amercanized food, while if you look Chinese, the chef orders to the more chinesey side, which is what i got. So the first thing that came out was this broth soup thing, with vegetables and fried fish. This was one of the more memorable dishes because the fish tasted soooo good. It was no longer crunchy after being drenched in soup, but it was good. Then, we got this tofu, that was crusted in some crunchy salt and peppery. It was pretty good, and the last thing I remember us getting was the chicken. It was crunchy on the outside, and in a sweet orangey sauce, with fried yams on the side. YUMMY!! I really liked that one! The other dishes weren't as good or as memorable.
author: Katie T.

description: This once was a great place to get phenominal food.  But then they expanded, remodeled and now its not the same.  The food isn't special anymore and that makes the always rude service, well, just plain rude.  You could handle the rude service before because you knew the food was going to be great.  Now this has become nothing more than a tourist stop with bad service and ok food.  Too bad....
author: Michelle N.

description: Wow. I can't believe how many people told us to eat here. Probably some of THE worst Chinese food we've ever had. Not good for even a tourist trap. I've been around a long time, and have lived IN and near Chinatowns in NYC and SF, and I really don't understand why people think HON is any good at all. We had some awful fried calamari that was merely greasy and black-peppery; house noodles that were supposed to come with garlicky veggies, which ended up being a sprinkling of cilantro; the peashoots were overly spicy. The rice, which I tasted plain, was BAD. I LOVE good Chinese food--Great China in Berkeley is so much better; there's a place around the corner from HON on Stockton that is ten times better (hint: only Chinese customers were in that restaurant when we went--I wish I could remember the name of it.) NOT ONE Chinese customer was at HON today. I wonder why. AND the waiters were rude and awful.
author: Gina P.

description: because this is what it is, in your face slighty overpriced (tourist and locals included) decent cloying sauce hunan styled (toss in chilli pepper flakes) food ... was my third choice in area, but hey i was not surprised, the beer was ice cold, yeah!
author: tim y.

description: The food is decent (not worth waiting in line for), but this place can now officially SUCK MY BALLS.  I've been here three times and I won't be back.  Yesterday we went here with a couple visiting from out of town; I watched them give preferential treatment to Asian customers and they FORCED US TO PAY WITH CASH.  They refused a credit card, said in broken English "cash only," pointed us to an ATM down the street, then immediately took a credit card from the people at the table next to us.  Also, they gave us the wrong dish even though we made a point to order the "crackling beef."  There were also thick, inedible sticks in our egg rolls (at first we thought they were bones, but on inspection, it was more like pot stems.)  Overall, they sure did their damndest to make sure we won't come back.
author: Jim F.

description: i fly from LA to SF just for Nanking monthly..... lucky i have my own airplane since i am a Doctor....  owner knows how to take care of his customers and knows how to cook
author: Dr N.

description:
my husband, son and i went here on feb 1st/09, around 6:30pm.  

there was no line, although the concierge at the hotel had warned us there might be.  maybe try on sunday nights?

the food was just plain the tastiest Chinese that we have had.  ever.  period.  it was fresh and imaginative.  a woman came over to our table to take our order promptly, and she just asked us what we like (after we'd read over the menu).  i am a vegetarian and my husband is a carnivore.  i ended up with a delicious meal of tofu, wonderfully-flavoured bean pods, and mounds of delicious kale (with crisp sweet potato strips on top).  my husband had the sesame chicken with sweet potatoes.

i can't speak to the whole debate about MSG on this review thread.  true, it does not advertise as NOT using MSG on the storefront (like brandy ho's around the corner).  that said, like someone else said, it does have a Michelin star, and let's face it those don't get thrown around without some examination.  neither of us had a headache/etc afterwards, and there were no ill effects of any sort.  

it's clear this place is more than a step above many of the other chinatown restaurants, not so much for ambience (although it's slightly better) but just plain quality.

fair criticisms: the service isn't great, it's a bit abrupt.  the tables and chairs are just cheap two-person tables all pushed together in rows in communal style.  it isn't kid-friendly (they don't have high chairs and it's just not a family atmosphere).  it also isn't romantic, although there were some decorations and a nice lack of florescent lighting.  

BUT the food is AMAZING.  try it.
author: Elmo G.

description: A friend of mine took a couple of us here a few weeks ago and I have to say it was definitely an experience! The line was long, but not grueling. When we were seated, they packed us into the tiny restaurant (that clearly was NOT up to fire safety code) like sardines. Then the interesting part: while in line my friend had asked us what we "don't" like as far as food goes.  I said "mushrooms & fish" and my other friend said "spicy food". When the grumpy serious looking old Chinese guy came up to us with his pad of paper, he looked at us with a frown and our friend placed the most bizarre order I have ever heard, "3 orders of WHATEVER - no fish or mushrooms and nothing spicy please - oh and some spring rolls".  The grumpy old man frowned even more (didn't think it was possible - but oh it was - i think he wanted to kill whoever said they didn't want fish - oops) and then nodded, let out some grunt and walked off.  (???)  About 10 minutes later we were presented with 3 GLORIOUS dishes of "whatever" which turned out to be some of the best (albeit not as authentic as some would expect) Chinese I have ever eaten.  The first dish was sesame chicken with glazed sliced sweet potatoes - truly by far the best of all the food we ate this night - and the ONE thing that will have me coming back over and over!! The second dish was a beef & broccoli type of entree - also very good.  The third plate was some sort of marinated pork on a bed of yummie citrus flavored sprouts. Mmmm...  And the last dish was our spring rolls. (oh and they brought us a bowl of steamed rice) - everything was so delicious! I had no idea such a risky roulette order of "WHATEVER" could turn out SO GOOD! It was definitely worth the wait, cramped seating and paper towel that stuck to my shoe on my way out. (special thanks to the attentive patron who pointed that out to me as I walked by)  :)
author: Julie J.

description: This place explains why I hate "Chinese Food," because none of it tastes like this!  This is not a place you go for the service, but I kind of like sharing tables with strangers as is often the case here.  Often if you go alone or with just one other person you can skip ahead of the larger groups in the line and not have to wait so long.  I just wish they were in a neighborhood I actually wanted to hang out in, then I'd be there much more often.
author: Q Q.

description: i have to admit, i like this place.  for a gwai-lo place, its pretty damn good.  i still remember the lunches i had at this place 6 yrs ago.... it was damn good....
author: Peter L.

description: packed, rude and frickin delicious.  one of my favorite place to take out of towners who might not have access to a Chinatown of their own.
author: David F.

description: Dirty, rude and pretty darn tasty. Their "famous" chicken isn't all they say it is, but it's still good. but the best part? it's damn cheap!
author: M B.

description: i went here for with a couple of friends. Service was ehh ok. They kept having to change our order because they didn't have certain vegetables on stock. It is crowded and you do have to wait in line. Its pretty small. I honestly thought it would be better. The food was quite salty from my experience in eating chinese restaurants. I wouldn't go back.
author: Jake D.

description: Long line (25-30 people in front of us) but took less than 30 minutes to be seated.  Minimal service from waiter/owner/waitress.  Four people at our table, all meals arrived at different times.  Food fair (fried calamari) to quite good (sesame chicken).  Probably won't be back.
author: Peter L.

description: people hate this place?! i took my food connoisseur friend and she said it wasn't anything to write home about, but i still love it, partly because of the atmosphere and partly because it's pretty darn good chinese food. sure the service isn't great, but c'mon, it's tiny and crowded, but crowded for a reason!
author: vina t.

description: the food here was great the 2-3 times i went b4 i saw a cockroach dining there as well . ill most  likely never go back to this place
author: d l.

description: Best hole in the wall Chinese food in SF. Love the service and the food! A must try for all vegetarians! Not your usual fly rice and noodles..actual good seasonal veggies with excellent spices! Don't expect a white table cloth type atmosphere...just go in and get a sing tao....let the wait staff order for you and enjoy! And for first timer, be willing and ready to wait for a table! It's worth it!!!
author: Avani S.

description: I must admit, I lusted after this place after several visits, even after the proprietor felt obligated to order for us.  The potstickers were amazing, and I love their mu shu beef.  However, don't ever order take-out.  I guess I should have known that that kind of food is only good 5 minutes after it's made.  Please don't make the same mistake.  Still on the search for Chinese food that doesn't self-destruct.
author: emily g.

description: even though i've lived in thhe city for nearly a decade, my first encounter with HofN wasn't until last night.  got into a shsort line, luckily.  since it was our first time and we didn't knwo the drill, the owner guy asked us what we liked, and came out with a fantastic chicken and tofu dish and an alright beef and sizzling rice dish.  but most importantly everythign was super fresh tasting.  it was a fun adventure, i'd go back if it was convenient like last night.
author: e w.

description: its not even debatable that nanking is the best chinese food in the city.  its so delicious its ridiculous.  seriously.  the pot stickers are laced with crack - its impossible to stop eating them until they're gone, and then its hard not to want to lick the plate.  the yams in the nanking chicken, and anything moo shu are both terrific.  its so worth the wait, you just factor that time into the process of going here.  if you want health food, go elsewhere.  but once every few months this place is a must.
author: Erin C.

description: its pretty small so if you are thinking to go with a bunch of friends think on other place. but certainly the food is really good the sesame chicken is awesome and i forgot the name of the other dish i order but it was my first time eating tofu and it was so good.
author: David m.

description: greasy food,uncouth servers and the place is unsanitary
author: aj s.

description: oh my gawd, i thought this place was closed...!!!  fondest memories of some of the finest chinese food around.  noisy, crowded...  the waiter orders for you if you can't make up your mind.  it's a blast...!!!
author: Ken A.

description: Staff pretty annoying and completely overwhelmed - Food is ok
author: laurent i.

description: i do love this place, i really do.  the nan king chicken is deliciously crispy and sesamed and although the fried sweet potato slices they garnish it with weren't quite as crispy as usual, i was still quite happy.  we tried the stuffed mushrooms - something I'd never had here before and they were lovely.  all browned and juicy accompanied by a sweet zucchini.  and for the third - the eggplant.  love it.  the best part is this delicate salad of clover like greens (not sure what they are exactly) which is so unexpected in a saucy chinese food dish.  i love it.  sweet and savory at the same time.
author: Shoshaunna P.

description: Did dinner here on Lonely Planet recommendation and after seeing that the R & G lounge was full. The line wasn't too long (~20 min wait), the waitstaff was the requisite rude, and the food wasn't all that great. A few tables (more than one!) were actually arguing with the main waiter about being ripped off. Hot and sour soup was awful - some salty brew unlike anything I have ever tasted before. Chicken fried rice was fair.
author: Robin A.

description: I was adequately warned that service here was sub par.  So I went with tempered expectations and was still surprised by the poor service.  They got our orders wrong, sodas took forever to arrive and the staff were not friendly.  But, the food was good.  It seems to be popular with tourists/Union square shoppers.  My future visits will be limited to take-out only.
author: K P.

description: nice presentation, owner is a pompous person that  feels like he should place your order. long lines, and very loud, and dirty.
author: drew w.

description: Make sure you make reservations.  Most people don't know that you could and end up waiting outside in line for awhile.    This is the best chinese restaurant in the city and probably the best I've had in the US.  You eat out of a bowl, place is small and they really pack them in.  Upon our party entering, someone asked me why we didn't have to stand in line, I told him that the person I was with was an international movie star (little did he know we had reservations).  The hostess overheard this and lo and behold we had the owner as our waiter.  He explained his style of cooking, his experience and said he would do the ordering for us.  Needless to say, his style of chinese cooking was nothing like I had before . . . It was fantastic and the food just kept coming.  He even had an employee take a picture of him and our group.  I wonder if we made it on his wall.  Everytime I'm in the city I make it a point to go there.
author: gary t.

description: This place USED to be really good... but NOT anymore since they became "popular."  You can get much tastier food and service somewhere else for the almost $50 you'll end up spending for dinner for 2.
author: Sofia A.

description: So it's been probably ten years since I've been to House of Nanking.  It was OK then, but really nothing special. It's more different now than I ever imagined. No line to speak of tonight, so I figure I''ll give it a try. I'm on a per diem so I order the fried Calamari in lemon and garlic sauce for $12.95. Calamari was tender as advertised, but the super sour lemon sauce and nearly raw garlic overpowered it all. Soaked most of the sauce up with the ample portion of white rice which was about the only way I wasn't going away hungry. Asked for tea ($2.95!!), The flowering tea bud in hot water was interesting. Bill was a little over $17.00, but whoa....minimum credit card charge is $25.00. CASH baby!! That sucks. Come to think of it, so did my meal. Probably better to come here with a group so at least you can pay with a credit card. Unfortunately there are no other Chinese restaurants for blocks around. Right.
author: Joe A.

description:
ok, i originally gave this place 5 stars because the food, i thought, was great. the last time i went though i got a tremendous headache/stomach ache and generally just felt disgusting the next day. then i realized that i always felt like this the day after eating at house of nan king. 

the food IS good. i love practically everything on the menu. however, the overload of MSG in their food is enough reason for me never to go back. i suppose i could ask for the food without MSG, but who knows if they would even leave if off. the food is tasty, but that nasty, headache inducing msg has turned me off forever.

another thing that bothers me is the fact that the lights are always so low. i can barely see the person sitting across the table from me, let alone my food. it makes me wonder what they're trying to hide. also, the last time i was there the bathroom was absolutely disgusting. i once read in a book that you should judge the restaurant on their bathroom, since its visible to the customer. if the bathroom is nasty and guests are allowed in there, i wonder how filthy the kitchen is!?
author: Rachel S.

description: i have worked in some fine Chinese restaurants in my life and i have had better food but i must say this is right up there with the best. yes the service, tables,chairs, cups, and plates are cheap and crappy but the the food is worth it all. i would say 90% of the times ive been to nanking the owner has walked up and said "oh 5 people ill bring you 6 dishes" and every time i've been more than happy with his choices so my advice is just leaving it up to the chef
author: andrew h.

description: Food used to be good. It kind sucks now.  Smaller portions and quality of food is not what it used to be.  Peter (the owner) never lets you order what you like, he likes to say "ill take care of you" and gives you his leftover vegatables most lilkely
author: Cesar G.

description:
man this place is amazing. 

they seat you next to whoever has space. the service is fucking awesome, meaning they wont talk to you until you want to orde and then they are there in a flash.  and the food is excellent. so sketchy and delicious. this place is amazing. 


haha by the way noone in chinatown will tell you where it is if you dont speak chinese. i mean House of Nanking is not exactly English. its a name, its not like they cant understand you. i love that!
author: roberto g.

description: I totally understand why a lot of folks don't like this place. The decor is not pretty; the place is extremely crowded; there is usually a long wait; and the staff seem to want to rush their customers all the time. I know all this, but I'm still willing to give this restaurant five big stars. I guess you should develop some sort of appreciation for this restaurant. First of all, this isn't a place to go, hang out, and make an evening of; one should go there to get food. Second, people should go there with an open mind; be willing to try anything. As a matter of fact, I never even order; I let them pick whatever they want for me, and they have never let me down. This is perhaps the best Chinese food I have ever had. Just go there for the great food, and if you'd like to lounge somewhere after dinner and have some drinks, you can always walk up to Vesuvio, which is a block up the street after your dinner.
author: Sepehr M.

description: The House of Nanking has the best chinese food in the world! It's quality is amazing. In 15-20 minutes, your food is ready! It may seem a little long, but boy is the food good! My favorite dish is the vegetable steamed dumplings. As a vegetarian, it's hard to get chinese food without meat, but there's a lot of choices at the House of Nanking.
author: Samuel D.

description: I'm Asian and I really enjoy this place (in reference to another reviewer's comment that s(he) was the only Asian in the place).  Just tell them what type of food you like or tell them to bring what's fresh.  The price is right, the food is good, and the food shines in the end.  Defintiely a place to try if you know what to expect.
author: V N.

description: If you want to die faster then you can try out the food there.  They put an enormous load of MSG and sodium in the food that's why it's so tasty.  Service wise, the boss was very friendly when he came to take our order.  But as soon as the food arrived, his attitude turned nasty.
author: Bella L.

description: Service is poor, bathroom is the worst I've ever used at a restaurant (dim lighting, cleaning products everywhere, no soap, looks like it's never cleaned), and it's kind of expensive, but the food is AWESOME!!!  I always take friends and family there when they're in town.
author: Jo M.

description: This place is a dive and the staff is rude, curt and you're shoved into as small a place as you can possibly take-up and still eat and breathe. That said, I have never had a bad meal here and it's a bonus that it's pretty cheap. The first time I went here, the owner, who takes the orders, got impatient with us trying to decipher the dishes on the menu and snatched them away and said he would bring us stuff. Ordinarily, this would have offended our group, but considering we were sitting in a dive, we merely looked at each other nervously and shrugged. When the food showed up and pretty quickly at that, we completely forgot that it was pretty rude and considered it quite charming that he went ahead and ordered for us. We have since stuck with the same ordering plan (since I'm allergic to shellfish, we order by the main ingredient i.e. chicken, veggie, beef, etc.) and haven't been let down once. We've had visitors we dragged here who were more used nice eateries be happily surprised at how good the food was.
author: Cherie T.

description: good thing most of my favorite unfavorites are located within a quarter mile of each other so i can easily avoid them all. you can get better chinese at panda express.
author: bloopie s.

description: I, too, have been a previous customer of Nanking, and it has been at least 7 or more years since my last visit.   We used to go all the time and loved the food.  What has changed since then?  Most everything.  My memories were of fantastic food that was worth being treated badly by the help -- you put up with that because every dish tasted wonderful.  Not any more.  Has the ownership changed?    The decor is new since then.  The recipes are different, the sauces are not the same taste or consistency - the peanut sauce used to be creamy and wonderful, and is no longer close to the same -- and agreed with another reviewer, the noodles were bad,  the calamari was fishy, the pot stickers were too well done, as was the chicken in the sesame chicken over fried.  Disappointed completely.    Even when we sat down, my dish still had food stuck to the bottom of it that did not come clean from the dishwasher.    My husband asked a server for help, and all she said was "not my table" and walked away -- not even calling someone else over to help us.  The days of our enjoying a Nanking meal are over.  We will not go back and would never recommend it to anyone -- San Francisco offers too many other restaurants with good food and a nice staff.
author: Catherine H.

description: It has been a while since I had been to House of Nanking and I had remembered it fondly. How the owner would convince us to order special items not on the menu which might cost slightly more but were delicious tasting. This last trip how ever was not that great. Yes the food was good enough but the waitress ignored my request for a glass of water three time, once even scolding me not to pester her about it, and this was well after many of the dishes has been served. also, the bill was much more than expected. Nine of us had dinner and the bill was $30 each. A few of us had tea and one person had one beer but no other drinks were ordered. That's a whole lot of money for Chinese food no matter how it tastes. The extremely high cost and the rude treatment means I wont be going back to House of Nan King. There are too many wonderful restaurants in SF to waste time here. Too bad really, but such is life, ever a refinement of choices.
author: David R.

description: not a typical chinese restaurant.  food is interesting and service isn't bad.  a bit too touristy though.
author: Nana B.

description: Okay, I usually don't do negative reviews cause no one likes a hater, but I just can't believe how many people rave about this place and it's just not good. Now I don't care about waiting in line or being crowded in or not having very attentive service - I judge restaurants by their food. I think Chinese food can be great in a little of different ways - like there's delicious, bad for you, american-style fried chinese food. Then there's amazing "don't know what's in it but I don't care" authentic cuisine, and then you've got your modern fusion with latin food or what have you. All are great when done well. House of Nan King seems like it's trying to do a new, modern take on chinese food, which I respect them for, but the food just isn't tasty. We had dumpling soup, sesame chicken and the pork fried potstickers and they all sucked.  Everything was luke-warm and bland.  It was like food you make for a five-year old cause they don't like strong flavors. The potstickers tasted like Hot Pockets, with terrible dough and peanut sauce (again, if you're gonna go non-traditional, atleast taste good). Plus is was overpriced. I just kept thinking that the frozen, Trader Joe's chinese food I had at home would have been much more satisfying.  If you really like chinese cuisine, skip it, you'll be disappointed....
author: Sarah W.

description: The best Chinese food I have ever had in my life. This certainly is a must visit place in San Francisco, rare to find a lot of their preparation in a regular Chinese restaurant. Food is not atall greasy and very creative mix of uncommon vegetables and common meat. You can also get seafood and tofu. Unless you have a really bad-karma, the owner will come  to your table to take order and will ask you whether it is your first time. No matter you are there for the first  or the 10th, which will happen in no time after your first visit,  my advise is always pretend it is your first time, he will make up dishes for you. Really those dishes are very uncommon and palatable! Place is not that clean and sometimes you are under pressure for the line outside. If ambience  were the only criterion, I would not have given this place more than 3, but the food just surpasses everything and it just gets better when you get the cheque, cause you really need  to check it twice for it's so cheap, atleast in the san francisco standards.
author: Kingshuk g.

description: just gross, wouldn't even give it one star.  where is the health department when you need them?
author: merilee b.

description: a chinese restaurant full of white people. hmm. on our weekend visit to the city, i wanted to come back to HON since i liked it the first time. this last visit, we waited outside, in the cold, with lots of others, and apparently this  is normal. the line sometimes snakes around the block, i heard our table mate say. well, i'm not exactly sure why, cuz the food was good, but not wait-outside-in-the-cold-and-freeze-your-ass-off good. so we ordered, and still waited for my damned fried pork chops. i saw three other tables (who came in after us) get their food first. do i complain? i don't know, cuz they're pretty bossy (my server straight up ordered a coke for me when i couldn't decide between that and a beer!), and when my husband finally did ask, she's all "it's coming." and it did. 15 minutes later. it was good though, just not great. and i can i just say how uncomfortable it is to sit next to two strangers. we're a friendly couple, but it was odd. we were so close, i felt like throwing in my two cents when our first couple was taking about "the wire" and again when our second couple starting talking about bill cosby's rant on the afro-american community. it was a weird experience, and since my fingers swelled up to the high heavens due to that MSG, i don't think i'll be back. maybe. i don't know...
author: Ru G.
